headline: Street Art Way Below the Street
text: A vast new exhibition space opened in New York City this summer, with a show 18 months in the making. On view are works by 103 street artists from around the world, mostly big murals painted directly onto the gallery’s walls.

headline: In a First, Brazil Elects a Woman as President
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Dilma Rousseff was elected the country’s first female president on Sunday, as Brazilians voted strongly in favor of continuing the economic and social policies of the popular president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

headline: A New Search Engine, Where Less Is More
text: Start-ups and big companies alike have tried to take on Google by building a better search engine. That they have failed has not stopped brave new entrants.

headline: Candidates Advance Final Arguments
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans made their closing argument on Sunday for capturing control of Congress, assailing President Obama as a champion of wasteful and excessive government, as Democrats countered that returning power to Republicans would embolden corporations and the wealthy with disastrous results for middle-class Americans.

headline: A New Focus on Cargo Security
text: One of the bombs discovered Friday was flown, apparently unscreened, in the cargo holds on two passenger planes in the Middle East. The potentially deadly lapse exposes a U.S. air security loophole The Lede previously discussed in a post in January and another in August.

headline: World Series Game 4: Giants 4, Rangers 0
text: Having returned home, the Rangers won on Saturday and seemed to energize a World Series that had opened in lopsided fashion. But after losing to the San Francisco Giants, 4-0, on Sunday, the Rangers find themselves in a Texas-size hole.

headline: Young Voters Say They Feel Abandoned
text: MIAMI — Two years ago, the University of Miami could not get enough Barack Obama. The campaign rally he held here felt like a rock concert, his face appeared on T-shirts all over campus, and pro-Obama volunteers registered 2,000 new voters.

headline: Suspect in Printer Bombs Gains Notoriety
text: As my colleagues Mark Mazzetti and Robert F. Worth report, American officials said that the two bombs discovered in printers on Friday were assumed to have been made by Ibrahim Hassan al-Asiri, whom authorities described as Al Qaeda in Yemen’s top bomb-maker and a man who loaded explosives into his brother’s body in a 2009 suicide attack that failed to kill Saudi Arabia’s intelligence chief.

headline: On an Indian Reservation, a Garden of Buddhas
text: ARLEE, Mont.  On a rural American Indian reservation here, amid grazing horses and cattle, a Buddhist lama from the other side of the world is nearing completion of a $1.6 million meditative garden that he hopes will draw spiritual pilgrims.

headline: Rally to Shift the Blame
text: In his new role as a political leader, which is what you call somebody if he hosts a rally on the Washington Mall for over 200,000 people, Jon Stewart was a little hemmed at the Rally to Restore Sanity on Saturday. Because sanity should know no party, partisan rhetoric was not on the teleprompter.

headline: In Season of Surprises, Title Race Is Muddled
text: While this college football season has not provided the relentless spate of high-caliber upsets like the 2007 season, when Louisiana State won the national title with two losses, it certainly has delivered on surprises.Consider that with five full weeks remaining in the regular season, three of the top five teams in the Bowl Championship Series standings — No. 3 Texas Christian, No. 4 Boise State and No. 5 Utah — come from outside of college football’s six power conferences.

headline: Russian Activists See Change in a Humble Protest
text: MOSCOW — There was nothing grandiose about the demonstration in Triumfalnaya Square in Moscow on Sunday night.

headline: A Difficult Final Weekend on the Trail
text: CLEVELAND  The upper deck was mostly empty when President Obama closed out the campaign season Sunday afternoon with a rally on the campus of Cleveland State University here. His aides looked grim, fiddling with their BlackBerrys as Democratic National Committee staffers scurried to get a crowd estimate from fire marshals: 8,000 in a hall built for 13,000.

headline: Patriots Knock Out Favre and Grab Control of Division
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  If that was how it was going to end for Brett Favre, it would have been appropriately dramatic. His chin bloodied, his eyes closed, Favre lay on a cart as it took him in to the locker room for stitches, the quarterback looking more like a punch-drunk boxer than the iron man of the N.F.L. who kept his streak of starts alive Sunday. It is now at 292 straight despite fractures in his left ankle that had turned much of the football universe into amateur orthopedists.

headline: Paul Kolton, Leader of Major Exchange, Dies at 87
text: Paul Kolton, who became the first full-time paid chairman of the American Stock Exchange without ever having worked as a stockbroker, died on Wednesday in Stamford, Conn., where he lived. He was 87.

headline: Guard Led 3 Americans Across Iran Border, Released Hiker Says
text: The three American hikers accused of espionage by Iran stepped off an unmarked dirt road  inadvertently crossing from Iraq into the Islamic republic  only because a border guard of unknown nationality gestured for them to approach, the lone hiker to be released said Sunday.

headline: 2 Reviews Cost Jets in Game of Position
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan flipped a red flag all of about two feet to the turf, and the home crowd obediently roared. He had lost his first replay challenge 10 minutes earlier, but that was not going to stop Ryan from questioning the officials again.

headline: Man Is Charged in Killing of Clerk at Queens Deli
text: A 29-year-old man was arrested early Sunday and charged with killing a clerk at a bodega in Queens during a robbery on Oct. 23, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Giants Pitchers Take Pride in Their Serious, and Comic, Relief
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When the fracas erupted and about 50 agitated athletes and coaches squared off for a potential brawl in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series, the Giants relievers did what relievers do: they poured out of the bullpen and ran toward the point of contention. The Giants, a team characterized as a band of bearded, rampaging, thong-wearing crazies, seemed to be itching to fight the bigger and more intimidating Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: The Election on TV and Online

headline: After Delays, a Vote for a President in Ivory Coast
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  With a mixture of disbelief and hope, citizens in this strife-torn West African nation, once a beacon of prosperity for the region, voted Sunday in an oft-postponed presidential election, the first in 10 years.

headline: Weekend Warriors of the Down-Ballot Races
text: The battle for New York governor between Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee, and Carl P. Paladino, the Republican, has captured the most attention by far in the statewide elections this year. But as Republicans seek an Albany comeback after two years of scandal, dysfunction and one-party Democratic rule, the stakes are also high in the campaigns for state attorney general and state comptroller, where polls suggest the Republican and Democratic candidates are in races that are still relatively close.

headline: Lottery Numbers
With Victory, Republicans Would Face Uncertainty
text: MIAMI  If voters engineer the Congressional makeover that strategists in both parties now expect, the implications for governance over the next two years, and for America’s political future, remain a mystery. Ascendant Republicans will have to juggle the Tea Party’s determination to block President Obama’s agenda with centrist voters’ desire for the two parties to work together on jump-starting the economy.

headline: In Albany, Democrats Face Losing the Senate
text: ALBANY  Two years after seizing control of the State Senate for the first time in more than four decades, New York Democrats are in grave danger of losing their narrow majority on Tuesday.

headline: Strickland, Foley Hoping Voters Will Split Tickets

If they have little support elsewhere on the ticket — a decent Democratic gubernatorial nominee burdened by a weak Democratic Senate candidate, or vice versa — they may find some voters whose primary interest is in another race simply voting the party line against them.

headline: Boehner Offers G.O.P. for 2010 Version of Change

headline: Revisiting an Outrage With Gallows Humor
text: Cynicism and compassion are not easily — perhaps not possibly — summoned at the same time. The challenge facing the new musical “The Scottsboro Boys,” which dares to present ugly American history as bawdy burlesque, is to keep audiences dancing nimbly between the two states of feeling, enticing us to cackle knowingly at the plague of racism at one moment, and arousing sorrow and sympathy for its victims the next.

headline: Lucky Magazine Creates Web Videos for Its Birthday
text: Instead of putting candles on a cake to celebrate its 10-year anniversary, Lucky magazine is lighting up its December issue with more than 100 online videos connected to each editorial page in the magazine.

headline: Harry Mulisch, Dutch Novelist, Dies at 83
text: Harry Mulisch, the Dutch novelist whose gift for writing with clarity about moral and philosophical themes made him an enormously influential figure in the Netherlands and earned him recognition abroad, died at his home in Amsterdam on Saturday. He was 83.

headline: In Neck-and-Neck Race, Chasing the Swing Voters

headline: The Colorado River’s Future
text: Last month, Ken Salazar, the secretary of the interior, committed $1.5 million to establish a study group focusing on the Colorado River basin. Modest as the dollar amount sounds, this is a very good investment. The study will be the first of three river basin studies  called the WaterSMART program  aimed at measuring the nation’s water demands and resources, including the potential impacts of climate change.

headline: Mugged by the Moralizers
text: “How many of you people want to pay for your neighbor’s mortgage that has an extra bathroom and can’t pay their bills?” That’s the question CNBC’s Rick Santelli famously asked in 2009, in a rant widely credited with giving birth to the Tea Party movement.

headline: Sorry State of Gun Control
text: As a new Congress looms, we suggest lawmakers travel to Washington by way of West Virginia and an obscure federal building called the National Tracing Center. There they can see workers laboring through unmanageably high backlogs of handwritten paper records submitted by the nation’s gun dealers. This is Congress’s handiwork — at the behest of the gun lobby and to the detriment of public safety.

headline: How We Got Here
text: From the early 1990s through the 2008 election, Americans grew steadily more liberal. Voters became more supportive of government spending and more sympathetic toward the poor. They were increasingly secular and increasingly likely to favor gay marriage. They were more worried about climate change and more inclined to support universal health care. And not surprisingly, they were more and more likely to identify as Democrats.

headline: Rookie’s Gem Has Giants on the Verge of a Title

All of their starters are in their 20s and under club control for at least the next two seasons. Imagine the possibilities, Aubrey Huff said. “This team,” said Huff, the Giants’ first baseman, “has a chance to do something special for quite some time.”

headline: This Week in Small Business: Is the Horror Over?
text: MANY SMALL BIZ OWNERS HOPING FOR A CHANGE TOMORROW? As the election looms, President Obama continues to talk about how his administration is helping small business. But a survey issued last week said that most small-business owners are voting Republican. Another poll finds that “nearly 80 percent of the business community believes that business interests would best be served if the Democratic Party lost majority control of either the House or the Senate.” David Leonhardt of The New York Times says job losses overshadowed the president’s accomplishments. The president pleads for patience with Jon Stewart and promises to start focusing on the deficit next term. Blogger Justin Fox explains the deficit. A new graphic shows how Americans feel about the recession. The national debt is projected to reach three times the size of the economy in 2050 and Reuters columnist James Pethokoukis doesn’t think the President’s deficit panel is on track.

text: The 3i Group’s chief, Michael Queen, believes that a bubble is developing in the market for secondary buyouts, an inflation similar to the technology bubble before the dot-com crash.

headline: I.C.B.C. Buys BNP Paribas Brokerage Unit
text: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China paid a token $1 for a small American brokerage firm, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: McKesson to Buy US Oncology in $2.16 Billion Deal
text: The McKesson Corporation, the health care services company, said on Monday that it would buy US Oncology in a deal worth $2.16 billion, including debt.

headline: Tinsel Town | Simon Doonan’s Very Foodie Windows
text: Tucked away in a generic midtown office building, Simon Doonan, Barneys’s creative director is spinning several thousand recycled Illycaffè espresso tins, cans, bags and paper cups into the department store’s annual window extravaganza, which this year has the theme “Have a Foodie Holiday.”

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Vegan Ma Po Tofu
text: “Ma Po tofu is supposed to bring sweat to your face, and numbness to your mouth,” said Susur Lee, the executive chef of Shang in Manhattan and Lee in Toronto. His famous dish of silken tofu is made fiery with hot bean paste, Thai bird’s-eye chilis and ground Szechwan pepper, and rounded out with soy sauce, vegetarian oyster sauce and garlic. It is best eaten over soothing, bland rice.

headline: I.B.M Said to Seek to Buy Fortinet

headline: Not-So-Great Scott: More Alternate Realities for ‘Back to the Future’

headline: Paddy O’Prado to Make an Appearance
text: Liz O’Connell is a professional horsewoman who works at Anstu Farm in Millbrook, N.Y. She is a member of the New York State Task Force on Retired Race Horses and is active in rehoming off-the-track thoroughbreds. She is a graduate of Cornell University’s College of Agriculture and Life Sciences.

headline: Earlier Flight May Have Been Dry Run for Plotters
text: WASHINGTON  American intelligence officials in September intercepted several packages containing books, papers, CDs and other household items shipped to Chicago from Yemen and considered the possibility that the parcels might be a test run for a terrorist attack, two officials said Monday night.

headline: Anyone Want to Help Build a Reactor?
text: A partnership between Constellation Energy and Electricité de France to build a new reactor in Maryland has broken up, with Constellation concluding that the economics are unfavorable because of electricity market conditions and the terms demanded by the Energy Department for a loan guarantee.

headline: When Internet Companies Slip, Recovery Is Hard

headline: 300 Years of Movies
text: Don’t be put off by the inclusion of requisite scenes and familiar nuggets of dialogue from “Citizen Kane,” “Sunset Boulevard” and “Jaws” in Turner Classic Movies’ seven-part documentary series “Moguls and Movie Stars: A History of Hollywood,” which premieres Monday night. The program is far less interested in myth-telling than in breaking down the gears of Tinseltown’s myth machine. “Unlike a lot of histories that have been made, we’re not a series of clips of the highlights of the great movies,” says Jon Wilkman, the series’ director, writer and producer. Instead, he tells The Moment, it’s about “how Hollywood functioned. It’s a history of Hollywood power — who had it, how’d they get it, what they did with it and how’d they lose it.”

headline: Wilmington Trust and M&T Bank to Merge
text: Wilmington Trust and the M&T Bank Corporation said on Monday that they would merge, creating a major lender in the eastern United States and a global provider of wealth management.

headline: Old, New, Borrowed and Bruce: Springsteen’s Video for ‘Save My Love’
text: Given the opportunity, who wouldn’t want to turn back the clock to the late 1970s and jam with Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band? Apparently not even Mr. Springsteen himself can resist the temptation: in Thom Zimny’s new video for the song “Save My Love,” from Mr. Springsteen’s coming album “The Promise,” the Boss gets to revisit the glory days of 1977 as he and his bandmates were gearing up to record “Darkness on the Edge of Town.” That’s appropriate enough, since “Save My Love” was originally written and produced for the “Darkness” sessions collected on “The Promise,” though the version you’ll hear in the video is a new one that Mr. Springsteen recorded this year.

headline: Send Us Your First Yuletide Sightings in New York
text: Doesn’t it seem that Christmas décor arrives earlier and earlier every year? Now that Halloween has passed, we suspect that some people are already placing little drummer boys and nutcrackers on their front lawns, stringing up lights on their porches and decking their halls with candles (and with menorahs, too). Bryant Park is getting dressed for the occasion. We even saw a faux tree in a store in SoHo the other day. We need you, our readers, to send us dispatches from your neighborhood, your street, your house, of these early yuletide sightings.

headline: Cleary Gottlieb Elects 4 Partners
text: Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton called itself an “international law firm” long before it became trendy to do so. The firm, which is based in New York, underscored its global reach on Monday when it named four new partners and four new counsel from all over the map.

headline: Gulf Seafood Is Safe, Officials Say
text: Extensive testing of Gulf of Mexico seafood by federal scientists has found only minute traces of the dispersant Corexit, which was used to break up oil from the BP spill, officials say. About 1.8 million gallons of dispersant were applied to the waters’ surface and at the wellhead, nearly a mile undersea.

headline: House Proud
text: In 1924, the French designer Jean-Michel Frank collaborated with Hermès on a collection of furniture, including the Confortable armchair and sofa, the elegant, cubic forms of which made it one of the most admired — and widely copied — designs of the 20th century. This month in Paris, for the inauguration of its new home division, Maison, Hermès is reintroducing these and other Frank pieces, including a straw-marquetry screen, a shagreen-covered vanity and the designer’s X-base dining table. Robert Chavez, the president and C.E.O. of Hermès USA, sees ‘‘a very exciting potential in the U.S.’’ for the Jean-Michel Frank by Hermès collection, given the customer demand for furniture with the Hermès label. Previously, the company’s furniture was limited to Pippa, a small collection by the architect Rena Dumas, who designed Hermès stores and who was married to Jean-Louis Dumas, the chairman of Hermès from 1978 to 2006. (Rena died in 2009, and Jean-Louis in May.) Their son, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the company’s artistic director and a sixth-generation member of the founding Hermès family, said starting Maison with historic designs was a deliberate strategy: ‘‘We had to go backward to understand our roots and to go forward into the future.’’ And in that future — April 2011, to be exact — the company will unveil further Maison collections, this time by a roster of (yet to be revealed) contemporary designers.

headline: When Money Alone Doesn’t Qualify a Buyer
text: When we sell or pass down beloved possessions, out of necessity or just desire, we often hope that the new owners will treasure them as much as we did. We want the buyer of that used car we had in college, the one we can’t afford the insurance for, to take as good care of it as we did. Maybe better. We want the friend who gets our old party dresses to party in them, too.

headline: Consumer Spending Up as Incomes Fall
text: Another reason to be concerned about the sustainability of consumer spending growth: Consumer spending eked upward in September (rising 0.2 percent), but incomes fell slightly (down 0.1 percent). Consumers were able to spend more only because they decided to salt away less of their paychecks, reducing their savings rates.

headline: Berlyn, a New Restaurant for BAM
text: The prime restaurant location for visitors to BAM has changed hands but remains in a Germanic mode like its predecessor, Thomas Beisl. Ursula and Jonas Hegewisch, she from Chicago, he from Hamburg, Germany, both once living and working in Berlin, have found room to display their collection of vintage pewter bric-a-brac, including a few gnomes. “We wanted to recreate the real Berlin atmosphere, Ms. Hegewisch said. The chef, Steven Linares, is “learning to prepare German food,” she said. Among the dishes are a type of corned beef mixed like a hash with beets and pickles, spatezle with cheese, some sausages, and maultaschen, a kind of big ravioli with a vegetable filling served in mushroom broth. Rote grutze, a red berry dessert, will be on the dessert menu, and German and Austrian selections will dominate the wine list. The tent on the west side of the restaurant is winterized and will open in a couple of weeks to expand the seating; 25 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland Place), (718) 222-5800.

Mr. D’Andrea becomes director for mobile development; he had been the principal of Liquid Joe, Basking Ridge, N.J., a company he founded. headline: The Woman Who Had the World Enthralled
text: From the start Cleopatra’s story was larger than life: epic in scale, mythic in symbolism and operatically over the top in its grandeur and its spectacle. As Stacy Schiff describes it in a captivating new biography, Cleopatra’s meeting with Julius Caesar was “a singular, shuddering moment,” when “two civilizations, passing in different directions, unexpectedly and momentously” touched.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: A Lethal Bond
text: We are midway through the current season of “Dexter”, and we can certainly see a glimpse of what is to come: Lumen and Dexter are soulmates, two people whose psychologies have been shaped almost entirely by extreme violence. The final scene with them in Rita’s old bathroom perfectly evoked their like-mindedness and their potential for the kind of real connection that Dexter has never experienced. Yet it also revealed his totalizing fear of actually having that kind of bond.Michael C. Hall’s performance here was really powerful: his face seemed to quiver and his body to recoil without actually doing so, as Lumen outlined her biography — her fear of marriage and of stifling convention, her need to breathe and experience thrills in life beyond having the right kind of china. Of course, this terror of dull, suburban normalcy is exactly what keeps Dexter so restive. He saw himself with frightening clarity in Lumen and is clearly afraid of what it might mean that the fates have delivered to him a woman who would not only accept his proclivities but also share them.

headline: A New Restaurant for the Benjamin Hotel

(See: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and Dessert (pdfs)). The space had previously housed restaurants by Larry Forgione and then Terrance Brennan, and the hotel was once the Beverly; The Benjamin, 557 Lexington Avenue (50th Street), 212-715-2400, thebenjamin.com.

headline: A Versatile Vegetable for Hard Times
text: Whenever I think about budget dishes, cabbage is the vegetable that comes mind. Fortunately, the alarming surge in cabbage prices that has hit South Korea hasn’t occurred here, and big heads of green cabbage are still among the best deals you can get at the farmers’ market. Medium cabbages weigh 2 to 2 1/2 pounds. I paid $1.50 for three heads last week and got six dishes out of them, each serving at least four people.

headline: Adam Rapoport Will Lead Bon Appétit, Publisher Confirms

Mr. Rapoport lives in New York and is currently style editor at GQ, where he has worked for more than 10 years. Prior to that he was the restaurant editor at Time Out New York, and an editor and writer in the publications department of the James Beard Foundation.

headline: 100 Years of WWD
text: Women’s Wear Daily, the quippy and quirky trade paper of the garment industry, marked its centennial with a commemorative magazine out Monday that traces the evolution of fashion and also of its own coverage of fashion. For the cover, its editors came up with a pretty novel approach to illustrating 100 years of putting out a paper: a montage of notable designers, celebrities and socialites assembled as if they were the audience of a runway show. Yves Saint Laurent, Coco Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld, Ralph Lauren and Jackie Kennedy are in the front row; Andy Warhol, Claude Montana and Cindy Crawford are all the way in the back, so you can’t imagine that anyone will be complaining too much about their placement (as long as they were included).

headline: When a Debt Collector Calls for Debt You Don’t Owe

headline: A Step That Is New: James Franco Work Studies ‘Three’s Company’

headline: The End Of Western Civilization

He points me to a 2008 paper (pdf) in which he shows that the coming of FDR, combined with America’s exit from the gold standard, was seen by markets as a huge regime change; it was, said FDR’s own budget director, “the end of Western civilization.”

headline: Modeling the Midterms
text: As long as I’m writing about where the Democrats went astray, I should say something about the liberal enthusiasm for political science models “proving” that structural factors and only structural factors — unemployment, changes in personal income, the number of seats in play — explain the Democratic Party’s looming midterm rout. The Democrats would need to lose more than 45 seats in the House of Representatives, Jonathan Chait recently argued, citing one such academic model, for this election to count as a real referendum on Obama’s leadership. Invoking a different political scientist, Kevin Drum suggested that “about 70 percent of the seat changes” this Tuesday are the result of forces beyond the Democrats’ control, leaving just 30 percent of any conservative swing to be pinned on day-to-day politics and policy choices.

headline: The Rent Is High, but These Prices Are Low!

headline: Weird Sunday Marked by Quarterback Follies, Cowboys Slide

It was hard to think supernatural forces were not involved when you had a head coach trying to explain away the benching of his starting quarterback by saying the player doesn’t have as good a command of the two-minute drill as the backup does. Or when a megastar quarterback indulges in unattractive and protracted lauding of his own abilities.

headline: Clinton Facing Heat on Oil Sands Pipeline
text: Battle lines have been hardening over the proposed Keystone XL pipeline over the last couple of weeks. The pipeline, which will stretch from Alberta in Canada to refineries on the Gulf Coast, would nearly double the United States’ capacity to import oil made from Canadian oil sands. Canadian oil sands are a plentiful and secure source of oil, but the extraction process is high in carbon dioxide emissions and takes a toll on pristine Canadian forest ecosystems.

headline: It’s Alive: Big Audience for Debut of ‘The Walking Dead’
text: We’re about to discuss zombies, so you can see the cannibalism joke coming a mile away: viewers ate up the premiere of “The Walking Dead,” the new AMC series, adapted from the comic books written by Robert Kirkman, about humans struggling to survive in a world overrun by flesh-eating ghouls. The first episode of the show, which had the good fortune to make its debut on Halloween night at 10 P.M., was watched by 5.3 million people, AMC said, making it the largest audience for any original series on the channel. (By comparison, the season finale of the AMC drama “Mad Men,” on which the dead do not reawaken and are simply made fodder for black comedy, drew 2.44 million viewers.) Not surprisingly, “The Walking Dead” performed particularly strongly with audience members aged 18 to 49, drawing 3.6 million viewers in that demographic. In a statement, AMC president Charlie Collier said, “It’s a good day to be dead,” and we’ll just leave it at that.

headline: The Politics Game: Playing Midterm Election Bingo
text: Overview | How can students use news coverage to bolster their knowledge of the electoral process as well as their understanding of specific elections? In this lesson, students learn about the midterm elections by playing a game of Midterm Election Bingo. They then create their own election bingo games about historical elections or the electoral process.

headline: The Timing of Social Security
text: Several readers have objected to my assertion, in today’s column, that Social Security was passed “amid strong economic growth, rather than at the bottom of a recession.” After all, wasn’t the program created during the Great Depression? So it was — but not, crucially, during F.D.R.’s first year in office, 1933, when the unemployment rate crested at 25 percent and economic growth was nowhere to be seen. Instead, the program was signed into law in August 1935, by which point the jobless rate was down to 20 percent and falling and the economy was growing at a brisk 8.9 percent clip, after growing by over 10 percent in 1934. By way of contrast, Barack Obama signed the health care bill in March of 2010, when unemployment had barely ticked down from its Great Recession high and G.D.P. growth was still anemic — as, indeed, it remains to this day. Of course it goes without saying that the overall economic situation was worse in the Depression. But Roosevelt could legitimately claim that the country had turned the corner (and, just as importantly, that the 1934 midterms had confirmed his political mandate) by the time he turned from economic policy to old-age entitlements. Obama, on the other hand, got his entitlement passed in the first 15 months of his administration — but one of the (many) reasons it’s been a harder sell than Social Security, I suspect, is that the country is still waiting for real growth to return.

headline: Far Out | ‘AVAF’

In keeping with their maximalist philosophy, the artists test our capacity for visual overload with “AVAF,” a new book from Rizzoli International that comes with a mask and poster no less, along with several thousand photographs, sketches and notes documenting artworks performed and installed at the Whitney and Athens biennials, Los Angeles MoCA, and Deitch Projects gallery. The Moment spoke with Sudbrack about the duo’s strobe-lit visions of utopia.

headline: Additional Costs Expected for Lockheed’s F-35 Fighter

headline: The Opt-Out Solution
text: Americans don’t save enough. In 2005, Americans’ personal savings rate was negative for the first time since the Great Depression ─ instead of piling up savings, we are piling up debt. According to Financial Engines, an investment advisory firm that has surveyed the 401(k) retirement savings plans of 2.8 million people, only 28 percent of savers are on track to retire on 70 percent of our final salaries ─ and 70 percent may not be adequate to pay for health costs or travel. Worse, only one third of American workers participate in 401(k) savings plans at all.

headline: 5 Reasons Democrats Could Beat the Polls and Hold the House

headline: Secretary General Ignores Pleas to Ask China to Free Nobel Peace Prize Winner
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Monday ignored pleas from human rights activists to ask President Hu Jintao of China to release from jail the new Nobel Peace Prize laureate, Liu Xiaobo. Despite Mr. Ban’s statements that he considers human rights a priority, his spokesman, Martin Nesirky, said the secretary general avoided the subject when he met the Chinese leader in Beijing. Mr. Ban, above, also did not congratulate Mr. Liu. As a permanent Security Council member, China can veto a second term as secretary general for Mr. Ban.

headline: Turkey: Separatist Group Denies Link to Bombing Causing Panic in Istanbul
text: The separatist Kurdistan Workers’ Party, known as the P.K.K., denied Monday that it had any connection to Sunday’s bombing in central Istanbul that wounded 32 people and caused widespread panic. The bombing coincided with the end of a two-month cease-fire that the group had declared to clear the way for political talks in an effort to end its conflict with the Turkish government. In two statements to the Firat News Agency, the group disavowed the attacks, and then announced an extension of its unilateral cease-fire until the end of the 2011 general elections.

Now it is their turn.

headline: Republicans Are Clear Underdogs to Flip Senate
text: While Republicans retain a plausible path toward taking control of the Senate on Tuesday night, it would involve their winning at least two seats in which they appear to be underdogs, while simultaneously avoiding upsets in several other races in which they are narrowly favored. Unless the Republicans have a significant wind at their backs and are overperforming in most parts of the country, their chances of doing so are slim.

headline: Texas: DeLay Trial Opens
text: Opening arguments began Monday in Austin in the trial of Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, on state charges of money laundering, as prosecutors told a jury that Mr. DeLay had taken part in an illegal scheme to route $190,000 in corporate money to Republican candidates. A defense lawyer countered that none of the money was given directly to Texas politicians and asserted that Mr. DeLay was guilty only of being a better politician than his Democratic opponents. The contributions helped Republicans take over the Texas House in 2002, paving the way for the passage of a redistricting plan — designed by Mr. DeLay — that gave Republicans more control over the state’s Congressional delegation. In her opening statement, the prosecutor, Beverly Mathews, said: “There is nothing wrong with Republicans trying to dominate the political world. But the means to achieve that gain must be lawful.”

headline: Colorado: Mine Expansion Is Denied
text: A federal judge has voided a permit for the expansion of an operating coal mine on the Navajo reservation, calling for a more thorough review of the project’s impact on the environment and on cultural sites. In a decision issued Friday, the judge, John L. Kane of Federal District Court, ordered an agency of the Interior Department to reassess the permit. The agency granted the permit for the mining of 4,800 more acres at the Navajo Mine in 2005 after concluding that the proposal would have no significant environmental impact. Navajo Mine is operated by BHP Billiton.

headline: Crunching the Numbers on Conan O’Brien’s ‘Show Zero’
text: O.K., so perhaps Conan O’Brien‘s “Show Zero,” the sneak preview of his new TBS show that was simulcast around the Web on Monday night, was not the in-depth test run that some of us assumed it would be. But who’s to say it wasn’t the model of the hyper-efficient late-night show of the 21st century? In just five minutes, you got one monologue joke, one band member, one celebrity guest, one chord performed by a visiting rock band and three Diet Coke commercials. (And zero self-righteous speeches about the evil news media.) At a cost of zero dollars, you got your money’s worth.

headline: Demi Lovato Leaves Tour for Rehab
text: Demi Lovato, the 18-year-old pop singer and Disney star, has withdrawn from a concert tour to check into a rehabilitation facility, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lovato, a star of the Disney Channel series “Sonny With a Chance” and its popular “Camp Rock” television movies, and whose albums include “Don’t Forget” and “Here We Go Again,” had been performing with the Jonas Brothers, another Disney act. But her representatives said in a statement she left the tour over the weekend to address “emotional and physical issues.” The statement added: “Demi has decided to take personal responsibility for her actions and seek help. She is doing just that. Demi and her family ask that the media respect her privacy during this difficult time.” The statement did not specify what treatment she was receiving or the location of the facility. In a 2009 interview with The New York Times, Ms. Lovato talked about her rapid ascent to fame, saying, “Some days I get really excited, and some days I get scared because I feel like I have to live up to certain pressures.”

headline: Check Every Word Before Hitting ‘Send’ (And What to Do if You Didn’t)

headline: As Clinton Visits, Malaysia Promises Fair Trial for Dissident
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian government pledged Tuesday that the opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim would receive a fair trial on sodomy charges, a nod to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s call for the case to be conducted transparently.

headline: No Trumpeting of Low-Level Crime Data
text: Since the end of 2002, the New York Police Department has not made public its statistics on reports of lower-level crimes: a vast trove of complaints about matters like misdemeanor thefts and assaults, marijuana possession and sex offenses other than rape. The lack of data seems odd considering the department’s heralding of historically low levels for major crimes like murder, rape, robbery, serious assault and theft, every year, especially when one considers that the New York Police Department is one of only two of the 500 police departments in New York State that do not make such data available. [NYT]

headline: Pre-Mortem

headline: Dealer’s Choice
text: In Switzerland, a sans-serif, politely modern, supersleek, always tidy, adamantly neutral country, where everything uniformly ticktocks, lock-step, you might begin to think each new building and interior were designed by the same architect. Switzerland even has a typeface — Helvetica — named after it (the country is also known as Confoederatio Helvetica), in which no letter steps out of line. But an eBay purchase led me to Zurich, where I found the serif, the dingbat and the curvy character, all in one: Arthur Rooks.

headline: Focus Hocus Pocus
text: If there’s one piece of conventional pundit wisdom that annoys me most, it’s the constant refrain that Obama was wrong to pursue health care, that he should have focused on the economy instead.

headline: Pelosi Finds Inspiration in Giants’ World Series Win
text: With polls suggesting a tough Election Day for Democrats, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, continues to find inspiration in the unlikely success of her hometown San Francisco Giants.

headline: German Letter Bomb Is Found After Athens Blasts
text: BERLIN  A package bomb addressed to the German chancellor and shipped by air from Greece was found in her office’s mailroom on Tuesday, even as Athens was shaken by a second day of letter bombs aimed at foreign embassies.

headline: One by One, Saddam Hussein’s Aides Are Returning to Tikrit. In Coffins.
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — For years, this town served as the well from which Saddam Hussein drew many of his closest aides. One by one, they are now returning, after meeting their ends in jail cells or on the gallows.

headline: Other Departures at Tribune Company in Wake of Randy Michaels Resignation
text: When Randy Michaels, the embattled chief executive of Tribune Company, resigned on Oct. 22, many employees wondered what would become of many longtime associates he brought in from his days in radio at Clear Channel. That question was answered, at least in part, on Monday when several executives with ties to Mr. Michaels announced that they would be leaving as well.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Gains as Assets Rise
text: The Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, the hedge fund manager run by Daniel S. Och, reported quarterly distributable earnings of $52.1 million, up from $32.4 million in the period a year earlier, on higher fee income resulting from net inflows.

headline: Police in Russia Raid Bank of Billionaire

headline: Math Rage
text: A number of my recent blog posts have involved pointing out adding-up constraints: you can’t have some people spending less than their income unless others spend more than their income, all the world’s currencies can’t devalue against each other, etc..

headline: Republicans Will Win More Governorships (But Democrats Could Get More Votes)
text: Of the 37 governor’s races on Tuesday’s ballot, only 12 are in much degree of doubt. Democrats should win the races in New York and Arkansas and — barring abnormally bad polling — also those in California, New Hampshire and Maryland.

headline: G.O.P. Captures House, but Not Senate
text: Republicans captured control of the House of Representatives on Tuesday and expanded their voice in the Senate, riding a wave of voter discontent as they dealt a setback to President Obama just two years after his triumphal victory.

headline: Rising Seas and the Groundwater Equation
text: Worldwide overpumping of groundwater, particularly in northern India, Iran, Mexico, northeastern China and the American West, more than doubled from 1960 to 2000 and is responsible for about 25 percent of the rise in sea level, according to estimates in a new study by a team of Dutch researchers published in Geophysical Review Letters.

headline: Delphi and WiTricity Developing Wireless Electric Car Charger
text: The auto supplier Delphi and a partner, the WiTricity Corporation, are developing a hands-free charging technology to transfer electricity over short distances without physical contact.

headline: Why Retire Zenyatta?
text: Zenyatta is a perfect 19 and 0. On Saturday she will attempt to win her 20th race and continue her march to history. I don’t think anyone, bar the connections of each of her foes on Saturday, will be rooting against her. And if Bob Baffert is correct, even those with horses in the race will start rooting for her when she overtakes their horse.

headline: Well Rounded
text: The project that put the Bouroullec brothers, Ronan and Erwan, on the map in 1997 was their “Disintegrated Kitchen.” Now the design duo from Brittany aims to stock your kitchen with a new series of stoneware, glass and stainless steel dinnerware and serving pieces designed for the Italian manufacturer Alessi. The Ovale collection plays with multiple variations on a slightly asymmetrical, rectangular silhouette with rounded corners. This sounds simple enough, but the Bouroullecs’ delicate balance between whimsy and refinement will make even the biggest design snob smile. The reasonably priced collection (from $14 for the smallest mocha cup to $275 for the elegant stainless steel ice bucket) will be in stores just in time for the holidays  hint, hint.[?][?][?]ANDREAS KOKKINO

headline: T.I. Returns to Prison

headline: Corona, Queens, 5:07 A.M.
text: Deyjauneh Billups, a poll worker from Corona, Queens, enters the polling station at Louis Armstrong Elementary School, Public School 143, blocks from her home. Ms. Billups, 21, a student at LaGuardia Community College, was one of many college students recruited by LaGuardia in an effort to build civic awareness and involvement, while at the same time helping voters by placing tech-savvy students in polling sites. LaGuardia officials received a grant from the United States Election Assistance Commission to recruit the students.

headline: Flowering Inferno
text: When Prince George received his mother, Queen Mary, for lunch, Constance Spry, who did his flower arrangements, deployed carnations, her bête noir, in conventional containers, which she loathed. But when the queen wasn’t around, the ‘‘flowers’’ were more likely to be kale and lichen-crusted branches massed in serving pieces that Spry raided, to the amusement of her royal client, from his Meissen dinner set.

headline: Running Boom Fuels Two Top Races One Week Apart

Like any good social scientist, he decided to quantify their failures:

headline: Keeping Score: How Good Was the Pitching in the Postseason?
text: For all the commentary in the regular season that this was the year of the pitcher, I expected to be disappointed by the pitching in the postseason. Rarely do postseasons play out according to the expected narrative, but if anything, the pitching of this postseason exceeded expectations.

headline: Champions League: Too Many Players Missing Too Much Soccer
text: Ahead of the World Cup last summer, we reported on the number of injuries — serious and niggling — that plagued players who endured scores of games during the long league and cup seasons in Europe. headline: Immigrant Job Gains, Native-Born Job Losses
text: We’ve written before about the two-track economy emerging in the United States. One dividing line between the two tracks, it seems, may be immigration status: In the year after the official end of the most recent recession, native-born workers lost 1.2 million jobs while foreign-born workers gained 656,000 jobs, according to a new analysis of government data by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: All the Good Dogs You’ve Loved Before

But I’m not just tugged at by the satisfactions of mere nostalgia. In following those lonely and haunted dirt roads back to my childhood, I’m on a quest to try to understand the adult I’ve become.

headline: Inflation: An Important Clarification

headline: Trove of Gershwin Materials Moving to Library of Congress
text: A large archive of material related to the songwriting team of George and Ira Gershwin will be moved from San Francisco to the Library of Congress, The Los Angeles Times reported. Before Ira Gershwin’s widow, Leonore, died in 1991, she said that she wanted the archive eventually to go to the national library, but her will allowed for her nephew, Michael Strunsky, to keep it in California for as long as he wanted first.

headline: MTV Apologizes to Glaad for ‘Jersey Shore’ Segment

Brian Cox, Jim Gaffigan, and Chris Noth will round out the ensemble cast, under the direction of Gregory Mosher (last season’s “A View from the Bridge”).

headline: Borne Back Ceaselessly to His Long Show

Khodorkovsky adjourned here on Tuesday to await the judge’s verdict, which the jailed former oil tycoon said would be a test of Russia’s commitment to the rule of law, even as he expressed little hope of being cleared and spared another decade or more in prison.

headline: Merely Affluent vs. Truly Rich
text: Most people know that the top income tax rates used to be much higher than they now are. What’s much less known is that the top brackets started at much higher income levels than today’s top brackets do. In other words, the tax code used to draw sharper distinctions between the merely affluent and the truly rich.

Accented with precious metals and stones, the pieces (from $195) include necklaces, rings, earrings, bracelets and jeweled purses. Available at Soigne K boutique, 717 Madison Avenue; (212) 486-2890.

headline: Literary Tree-Spotting

Among the notable titles is a 30th-anniversary edition of “The Tree,” by John Fowles, which the Book Review’s Jennifer Schuessler calls “a hard-to-summarize meditation on art, nature, individualism and mortality — sort of a cross between Thoreau’s ‘Walden’ and John Berger’s ‘Ways of Seeing,’ with a dash of ‘The Gift,’ Lewis Hyde’s cult-classic manifesto on creativity, thrown in for good measure.”

They are undefeated in five home games, a big reversal from last season when they were .500 on home ice. They’ve won four straight, gotten three of four points in games against the Blackhawks, and have played like the team many thought they’d be last season, but weren’t.

headline: When Print Isn’t Plentiful, the Future’s Not So Fun

Such questions rattle through your mind during the happily long history lesson about typography at the start of Jordan Harrison’s “Futura,” a thought-provoking drama that does not live up to its potential.

headline: The Heated Debate Over Proxy Access
text: Proxy access is a hotly debated topic. Advocates contend that loosening the limits on proxy access will empower shareholders, heighten board accountability, restore shareholder confidence and result in more economically run public corporations. Detractors refute these propositions and assert that proxy access is a Potemkin village that will pre-empt state law, enable special-interest shareholders to hold up companies and otherwise provide corporations with few of the benefits that its proponents argue, other than increased costs to comply with new regulations.

headline: Interest Checking for Small Businesses?
text: A little-known amendment to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act could reshape the way small businesses bank. The amendment, added in the House of Representatives with no debate, repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts, which are known as demand deposit accounts. The prohibition had been part of the Glass-Steagall Act and was in force for nearly 70 years.

headline: In ‘Waiting for Superman,’ a Scene Isn’t What It Seems
text: One of the many affecting scenes in the documentary “Waiting for Superman” shows a mother on a personal tour of a high-performing Harlem charter school she wants her son to attend. She looks with perceptible longing at baskets of books and welcoming classrooms, and says “Wow” when told how children struggling with reading, like her first grader, Francisco, receive tutoring.

headline: Now in the Mix | Nomia
text: A cool (and stunning) 5 foot 11, Yara Flinn is readily mistaken for a runway clothes hanger. But if the Brooklynite designer appears on the catwalk, it’s to take a bow at the end of her show. Not that she isn’t her own best model. Now only in her second season and with her first runway show under her belt, Flinn is clearly looking at her own downtown style for inspiration. “I’m always thinking of comfort — physical or psychological — it’s about the great fabrics like stretch silk,” she says. Translation: no-brainer, well-made pieces like slouchy jumpsuits, cropped crepe tees and ombre chiffon sash dresses. And, at prices ranging from $150 to $500 a girl could easily go all out. “I never usually wear a complete Nomia look,” the 27-year-old designer insists. “I’ll incorporate an American Apparel or Salvation Army T-shirt to my wool and mesh leggings and biker jacket with a pair of vintage roper boots from Capezio.” Her “do try this at home” advice: just add some pieces from Uniqlo (“their jeans have a great fit and don’t stretch out”), Metropolis Apparel (43 Third Avenue) and Beacon’s Closet (88 North 11th Street, Brooklyn).

headline: A Water Bottle That Filters as You Drink
text: Before that 26.2-mile run or a simpler jog around the park, runners might want to add this Bobble reusable water bottle to their equipment. It’s made from recycled plastic and has a built-in charcoal filter. After an initial rinse, to flush out charcoal particles, the bottle, which can be squeezed and has a squirting top and snap-in cover, can be reused, but should be washed regularly. It was created by the industrial designer Karim Rashid. The manufacturer says that the plastic complies with federal consumer standards for reuse, and that it is free of BPA, PVC and phthalates.

headline: Selling Salts of Many Colors and Shapes
text: Jennifer and Mark Bitterman opened the Meadow, a shop with a narrow yet broad inventory in Portland, Ore., four and a half years ago. Narrow because they specialized in salt, chocolate, wine and flowers. Broad because they carry more than 100 kinds of salt and close to 400 different chocolates, mostly in bars.

headline: Armenian Walnuts, Steeped in Syrup
text: They look like black olives, but they are whole walnuts, picked green in the Ararat Valley of Armenia, and steeped in sugar syrup until they turn lush, sweet, tender and irresistible, a little like marrons glacés, only moister. They are made by Harvest Song, a company that specializes in excellent Armenian preserves. The walnuts are a perfect foil for pungent cheeses, pâté or roast duck or game. You can also nibble them after dinner or slice them to decorate pumpkin pie. And that manhattan? Drop a preserved walnut in the glass instead of a maraschino cherry.

headline: Dancing Stars Beat World Series Winners
text: “Dancing With the Stars” outdrew the final game of the World Series in the ratings on Monday night as 19.6 million viewers watched the ABC reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The two-hour installment of the dancing competition, which celebrated its 200th episode by bringing back dozens of former contestants, boosted ABC to No. 1 on the night. Fox ranked second over all with its World Series coverage, which drew slightly higher preliminary overnight ratings than Game 4 on Sunday. Final ratings for that game showed an average of 15.5 million viewers tuned in. CBS placed third on the night, and NBC was fourth.

headline: Dosa Garden
text: THERE are plenty of reasons to dine on Staten Island: atmospheric, old-school Italian and German joints; stellar pizza; an intriguing range of Mexican foods; the city’s best Sri Lankan; and, since last year, Dosa Garden, a South Indian restaurant in the Tompkinsville neighborhood, a short cab ride up Victory Boulevard from the ferry terminal. Its talented chef and owner, Karuppiah Chinniah, hails from Chettinad in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, an area known for its intricately spiced dishes, many of them nonvegetarian. Unlike many of the city’s other South Indian menus, half of Dosa Garden’s is dedicated to meat.

headline: Smallest College Endowments Perform Best, Study Finds
text: College endowments returned an average of 12.6 percent in fiscal 2010  and, unusually, the smallest endowments performed better than the largest ones, according to preliminary data from 80 colleges and universities gathered for the comprehensive Nacubo-Commonfund Study of Endowments to be released in January. According to the data, institutions with assets under $25 million had an average return of 14.1 percent, compared with 12.3 percent for those with assets over $1 billion. Smaller endowments tend to be invested more than larger ones in traditional assets such as domestic equities, which performed well in the rebound from the previous year’s sell-off, and fixed income, which benefited from declining interest rates. The institutions spent an average of 4.3 percent of their endowment in fiscal 2010, and on average, annual giving paid for 6.2 percent of their operating budgets.

headline: Israel: Defying Ban, Palestinians Renovate East Jerusalem Schools
text: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority said Tuesday that the authority had helped renovate 14 schools in East Jerusalem, in defiance of Israeli claims of sovereignty over the area and its ban on Palestinian political activity there. He went to a school in Dahyiat al Barid, on Jerusalem’s outskirts, to dedicate a section the authority had helped renovate, but Israel barred him from entering a refugee camp within the municipal boundaries for another ceremony. He said at the dedication that it did not matter if he was stopped. “We are translating steadfastness into facts on the ground,” he said. The Palestinians hope to make East Jerusalem the capital of their future state.

headline: Vikings’ Ills Run Deeper Than Moss

headline: Belgium: Archbishop’s Aide Resigns
text: The spokesman for the head of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium, Archbishop André-Joseph Léonard, quit Tuesday, saying he could no longer speak for a man who had spoken harshly of AIDS and homosexuality and sympathized with some pedophile priests. The resignation of the spokesman, Jürgen Mettepenningen, 35, came just days after the archbishop promised to keep silent on the sexual-abuse scandal in the Belgian church until at least Christmas. Mr. Mettepenningen said the archbishop was out of touch with Belgian Catholics, adding, “At times, he behaved like a loose cannon who thinks everybody else is wrong.”

headline: The Meaningful Luxury of Paying Attention
text: VALÉRIE MACCARTHY, an opera singer-cum-jewelry designer, had flown in from Paris to attend to various businesses and pleasures, so I met her in SoHo for lunch, and realized that we were coincidentally near Realm, a swanky new boutique. I relayed some luxe details I’d read: like, it is a source for Jean Claude Jitrois and Alexis Mabille, hard-to-find labels in this country. The owner, a woman of goodly fortune, was splashing out on wild extras like engraved black plexiglass shopping bags and customer car service via private Bentley.

headline: Niger: Voters Approve New Charter
text: Voters in a referendum accepted a new constitution that will limit presidential powers and begin a return to civilian rule. The electoral commission said Tuesday that turnout on Sunday was a record 53 percent and that 90 percent of voters favored the constitution. Among other provisions, the document would re-establish a limit of two five-year presidential terms, which was thrown out by in August 2009 by President Mamadou Tandja. He was ousted in a military coup in February.

headline: New Record for a Modigliani at Sotheby’s
text: A 1917 painting by Amedeo Modigliani titled “Nude Seated on a Divan” sold for $68.96 million at Tuesday night’s Impressionist and Modern Art Evening Sale at Sotheby’s New York, setting a new a record for the artist’s work. The star attraction of the sale, the painting had been expected to bring about $40 million, according to Sotheby’s estimate, but competition among five bidders drove the price relentlessly up.

headline: Insider Case Draws In a Surgeon Turned Banker
text: When FrontPoint Partners came to light on Tuesday as the unnamed hedge fund that federal authorities said had traded on inside information from a French doctor, so did the name of another doctor: Chip Skowron.

headline: Mets Add Ricciardi as Special Assistant
text: The Mets bolstered their front office staff Tuesday by hiring J. P. Ricciardi, the former general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, as a special assistant to the Mets’ new general manager, Sandy Alderson.

headline: NATO Sees Threats, but Is Reluctant to Say Just Who the Enemy Might Be
text: BRUSSELS  NATO’s secretary general expects two headlines out of this month’s annual summit meeting in Lisbon: an agreement to build an alliance-wide missile defense system, and NATO’s own “reset” with Russia, whose president has accepted an invitation to the meeting and says Moscow will explore cooperation on missile defense.

headline: Anti-Stoning Group Voices Fear Iranian Woman Could Be Executed
text: According to the International Committee Against Stoning, a human rights group led by an Iranian exile in Germany, Iran could be planning to execute Sakineh Ashtiani, a woman initially sentenced to death by stoning for adultery, despite an international campaign to save her.

headline: A Transit Bargain, Truly Underground
text: It is New York’s other subway, home to oddities like hexagonal trains and sparkling-clean platform floors. Its odor, musty but not unpleasant, is unlike anything else in the city, and it stops at cross streets that can befuddle: Ninth Street in Manhattan? Really?

headline: For the Intensely Political and Partisan DeLay, an Unusual Election Day (in Court)
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Tom DeLay, one of the most powerful Republican congressmen ever to emerge from this state, wanted to spend Tuesday cheering on his party and tracking the turnout in the election.

headline: On the Day of the Dead, a Little Music to Ease the Passage
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — “We’re here!” Alberto Chávez called out, hoping to sing for those who were here no longer.

headline: Election Night Live | Opinion 7:45pm ET
text: The Times's David Shipley and Ross Douthat discuss conservatism in the U.S. and whether a divided Congress could work together.

headline: Where Do Democrats Go Next?
text: Indianapolis

headline: Obama Is Expected to Urge Cooperation on Economy and an End to Vitriol
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will address the election results with a news conference Wednesday afternoon at the White House, where he is expected to call for both parties to put aside the vitriol of the last several months and work together to restore the nation’s economy.

headline: New Owners, Less Debt Give Texas a Shot at Lee
text: In five months, the Texas Rangers went from bankruptcy to playing in the World Series.

headline: All Day at the Polls
text: Following Deyjauneh Billups, a poll worker at Louis Armstrong Elementary School in Corona.

headline: Cotton Clothing Price Tags to Rise
text: Synthetic linings. Smaller buttons. Less Italian fabric. And yes, even more polyester. Unusually high cotton prices have apparel makers scrambling to keep down costs, but consumers be warned: cotton clothing will be getting more expensive.

headline: A Referendum, Not a Choice
text: For weeks now, the White House and Democrats have been trying to drive home the idea that Tuesday’s vote is a choice between Democratic and Republican philosophies and visions and not a referendum on President Obama and the Democratic party. But according to exit polls, that message didn’t seem to reach the people who voted for Republican candidates. Check out the chart.

headline: Victories Suggest Wider Appeal of Tea Party
text: The Tea Party victories by Rand Paul of Kentucky and Marco Rubio of Florida underscored the extent to which Republicans and Democrats alike may have underestimated the power of the Tea Party, a loosely-affiliated, at times ill-defined, coalition of grass-roots libertarians and disaffected Republicans.

headline: France To Try Landis
text: Floyd Landis and his former coach will stand trial in France in a computer hacking case. French judicial officials said Judge Thomas Cassuto decided to try the case against Landis, who was stripped of the 2006 Tour de France title for doping, and his coach, Arnie Baker, but had not set a trial date, The Associated Press reported. Those officials wanted to remain anonymous because the proceedings were supposed to be secret.

headline: W.P.S. Extends Reserve Deadline
text: Women’s Professional Soccer said its teams would have an extra two weeks to pay into a reserve fund to help struggling clubs. The league extended the deadline after two of the league’s eight teams, F.C. Gold Pride in Hayward, Calif., and the Freedom in Washington, said they were seeking additional investors.

headline: Do Believe the Hype
text: New Delhi

headline: Zenyatta vs. the Great Horses? Watch for Yourself
text: How would Zenyatta perform against great racehorses like Citation and Cigar? To answer that, Horse Racing Simulation and the National Thoroughbred Racing Association have created a virtual simulation of Zenyatta racing against nine top thoroughbreds throughout history.

headline: Election Night Live | News 8:15pmET
text: The Times's Marcus Mabry and Jim Rutenberg discuss the impact of outside financing in this year's races.

headline: Hearing Is Held for Man Accused of Jihadist Ties
text: A former Staten Island man accused of lying to federal agents about plans to join overseas extremist groups including the Taliban appeared briefly on Tuesday in federal court in Brooklyn, where prosecutors indicated that they would oppose bail.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Trial Opens Over Damages in Oracle Copyright Case With SAP
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  The dispute between the software giants Oracle and SAP, in one of the most closely watched court cases in Silicon Valley history, is not over whether SAP engaged in a copyright infringement scheme, but over how much damage was done to Oracle.

headline: Investors Forget Lending Lessons
text: Buyout barons are paying themselves on the back of the market’s short memory. Dividend recapitalizations are on pace to exceed the volume in 2007. Dunkin’ Brands and Getty Images illustrate the latest efforts by private equity firms to get ahead of potential changes to American tax laws. But in their zealous quest for Treasury-topping returns, investors seem to have forgotten recent lessons.

headline: World Series Ratings Fall
text: The San Francisco Giants’ victory in Game 5 of the World Series on Monday night was seen by an average of 15 million viewers, down 11 percent from the 16.9 million for last year’s comparable game between the Yankees and the Phillies.

headline: Reports of Intimidation and Electronic Problems Surface at Polls Across the U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  Voters in some states encountered isolated problems with electronic voting machines and delays in the opening of polling stations, but they also reported many instances of voter intimidation and misinformation.

headline: Election Night Live | Opinion 8:45pm ET
text: The New York Times's David Shipley and Brent Staples discuss economic insecurity, keeping the U.S. competitive in the global marketplace and how race impacted this year's elections.

headline: Republican Party Time
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Muslim, Hindu, Whatever
text: Some commenters point out, in regard to my post about the plot to impose Sharia arithmetic on America, that Arabic numbers — and the evil zero in particular — are actually Indian in origin.

headline: Imam Is a Shepherd to West African Immigrants in Harlem
text: Long before daylight breaks in Harlem, the imam Souleimane Konaté puts on a wide embroidered robe and wakes up his wife, Assiata, so she can pray in their one-bedroom apartment while their 9-year-old daughter Fanta sleeps.

headline: Election Night Live | News 9:15pm ET
text: The Times's Megan Liberman and Matt Bai discuss the latest exit poll data and what it portends for Democrats in the House.

headline: Another Election, Another Wave
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Tea Party Comes to Power on an Unclear Mandate
text: The Tea Party movement set the agenda in its first midterms, its energy propelling the Republican sweep in the House and capturing the mood of a significant chunk of the electorate, with a remarkable 4 in 10 voters in exit polls expressing support for the movement.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting places on Tuesday throughout the country.

headline: Independents Fueled G.O.P Gains
text: Democrats lost significant support Tuesday among nearly all demographic groups in a midterm election that was a referendum on President Obama and a Democratic-controlled Congress in a stubbornly weak economy.

headline: In Republican Victories, Tide Turns Starkly
text: Somewhere along the way, the apostle of change became its target, engulfed by the same currents that swept him to the White House two years ago. Now, President Obama must find a way to recalibrate with nothing less than his presidency on the line.

headline: Rubio Continues Quick Rise in G.O.P. With Win in Florida Senate Race
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  Jeb Bush said he had to fight back tears when he introduced the victor in the Florida Senate race, Marco Rubio, “the right man at the right time.” Mr. Rubio, when he took the stage amid the palm trees at the Biltmore Hotel, in front of a mostly bilingual crowd, was no less emotional  about his uphill battle to defeat a popular governor, and about what he described as his abiding faith in the dream lived out by his immigrant parents.

headline: Wednesday: Many a Little League Rooter
text: With today’s theme, some entries went in quickly while others needed to be pieced together.

headline: A Victorious Paul Vows to Stick to Message
text: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  From the earliest days of his campaign, even before his Republican primary victory that shook up the Kentucky political establishment, Rand Paul has pledged not to compromise. And that was the message he returned to on Tuesday night as he celebrated a Senate victory over his Democratic opponent, Jack Conway, the state attorney general.

headline: G.O.P. Makes Gains Toward Narrowing the Gap in the Senate
text: Republicans improved their lot in the Senate on Tuesday but were foiled by Democrats in a few key states with a high number of independent voters in their bid to capture both houses of Congress.

headline: The Senate Races
text: Republicans improved their lot in the Senate but were foiled by Democrats in a few key states.

headline: Election 2010
text: Voters in Tuesday’s elections sent President Obama a loud message: They don’t like how he’s doing his job, they’re even angrier at Congressional Democrats and they gave the House back to the Republicans. The Republicans spent months fanning Americans’ anger over the economy and fear of “big government,” while offering few ideas of their own. Exit polls indicated that they had succeeded in turning out their base, and that the Democrats had failed to rally their own.

headline: In House Victories, Republicans Oust Old and New Democrats Alike
text: Republicans captured the House Tuesday by ousting powerful Democratic committee chairmen as well as newcomers who faced a voter backlash after supporting an aggressive Democratic legislative agenda for the past two years.

headline: Election Night Live | Opinion 9:45pm ET
text: The Times's David Shipley and Charles M. Blow discuss the quantitative side of this election.

headline: Major Technical Difficulties
text: Behind closed doors in Washington, American officials are shaping an overhaul of the 1994 federal statute that requires phone and broadband carriers to ensure their networks can be wiretapped.

headline: Mr. Ban Pulls His Punches
text: In a meeting with President Hu Jintao of China in Beijing on Monday, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, discussed climate change and efforts to ease tensions on the Korean peninsula. Mr. Ban also nudged China to play a greater role in peacekeeping and in finding political solutions to conflicts in Sudan and Somalia.

headline: They Really Are Giants
text: Let’s remember this later when we are locked in to professional football and the gloom of winter. Let’s remember it when rich baseball teams go on their off-season spending binges, packing the payroll with talent for their annual open-checkbook march to the playoffs.

headline: Katrina’s Unfinished Business
text: New Orleans is finally rebounding from much of the devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina. But five years later, a big problem remains: blighted neighborhoods. To attract a vibrant middle class, these neighborhoods need to be repaired and restored, or, at the very least, stabilized. Residents who have been unable to rebuild because storm relief grants were too small or unfairly calculated need more help from the city and state.

headline: The House Races
text: Republicans captured control of the House of Representatives, riding a wave of voter discontent.

headline: Election Night Live | News 10:15pm ET
text: The Times's Megan Liberman and Jim Roberts analyze the latest story lines and what to expect in the coming hour.

headline: Cuomo Cruises to Win in New York Governor’s Race
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, completing a painstakingly plotted comeback from political ruin nearly a decade ago, won a resounding victory on Tuesday in the race for governor of New York, easily beating his Republican rival, Carl P. Paladino.

headline: Apparently, My Congressman Is Still A Rocket Scientist
text: NJ-12 has been called for Rush Holt.

headline: Blumenthal Wins in Connecticut to Take Dodd’s Senate Seat
text: Richard Blumenthal, the longtime attorney general of Connecticut, withstood a $50 million spending assault, his own major missteps and a brutal climate for Democrats on Tuesday, defeating the professional wrestling tycoon Linda E. McMahon to capture a Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd.

headline: A Guide to the Caribbean on a Budget
text: If you have your low-budget heart set on high-end islands like St. Bart’s or St. Martin or Turks and Caicos this winter, with enough research and flexibility you may be able to pull it off. But the real way to keep costs down is to head to the lower-cost islands that actively compete for travelers with light wallets.

headline: Election Night Live | News 10:45pm ET
text: The Times's Megan Liberman and Michael D. Shear discuss the salient points of this election.

headline: Was It Worth It?
text: We don’t know the final extent of the Democratic losses yet. But we do know the questions that liberals and Democrats will be asking themselves tomorrow morning. Was it all worthwhile? Was the 111th Congress’s flurry of legislative activity worth the backlash it helped create? Were the health care bill and the stimulus worth handing John Boehner the gavel in the House of the Representatives? Did it make sense to push and push and then keep on pushing, even after the polls and town halls and special-election outcomes made it clear the voters were going to push back?
