text: WORLD

headline: Election Night Live | News 11:15pm ET
text: The Times's Megan Liberman and Jackie Calmes on the challenges President Obama faces with Republicans in and out of congress.

headline: Perry Re-elected in Texas Governor Race
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Gov. Rick Perry won a resounding victory over his Democratic challenger, Bill White, a triumph for the conservative Republican governor who was early to embrace the antigovernment Tea Party movement.

headline: Defeated in Delaware, but Scarcely Sounding It
text: DOVER, Del.  Nothing could save the Tea Party candidate here, Christine O’Donnell. Not her folksy appeal, not her headline-grabbing gaffes, not even, it turns out, her witchcraft.

headline: $68.9 Million Modigliani Gets Auction Season Off to a Healthy Start
text: Classic images from art history, a doe-eyed female nude by Modigliani and a seminal Monet waterlily attracted bidders from around the world on Tuesday night at Sotheby’s sale of Impressionist and modern art.

headline: Wall Street Closes Higher at the End
text: Squawk boxes barked the news over the trading floor at Barclays: the Fed was back in.

headline: How Obama Saved Capitalism and Lost the Midterms
text: If I were one of the big corporate donors who bankrolled the Republican tide that carried into office more than 50 new Republicans in the House, I would be wary of what you just bought.

headline: Solar-Panel Maker to Close a Factory and Delay Expansion
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Solyndra, a Silicon Valley solar-panel maker that won half a billion dollars in federal aid to build a state-of-the-art robotic factory, plans to announce on Wednesday that it will shut down an older plant and lay off workers.

headline: Phys Ed: Will Training in the Heat Improve Your Performance in the Cold?
text: Can training for hot weather help you to perform better when the temperature outside begins to drop? That question, the answer to which intuitively would seem to be a resounding no, became the inspiration for a new study by scientists at the human physiology department at the University of Oregon. For the study, published last month in The Journal of Applied Physiology, researchers recruited 20 highly trained competitive cyclists from the university’s cycling team and local cycling clubs and put them through a series of laboratory performance tests, including a time trial, under both hot and cool conditions.

headline: Word of the Day | jibe
text: jibe •\ˈjib\• noun and verb

headline: In News Coverage, Tea Party and Its ‘New Personalities’ Hold the Spotlight
text: The Tea Party movement was the big media news in the elections on Tuesday, and it was also a big topic behind the scenes at news organizations.

headline: Election Night Live | News 11:45pm ET
text: As the Republicans take the house majority, The Times's Megan Liberman and Michael D. Shear discuss the ramifications for Democrats.

headline: Tight Deadline for New Speaker to Deliver
text: In leading his party to midterm triumph, Representative John A. Boehner, the next speaker of the House, is not at the endgame. He is at the beginning of the next and harder fight.

headline: Schneiderman Is Elected New York’s Attorney General
text: Eric T. Schneiderman, a Democratic state senator from the Upper West Side of Manhattan who doggedly  even desperately  clung to Andrew M. Cuomo’s coattails in the closing days of the campaign, was elected by a comfortable margin on Tuesday to succeed him as New York’s 65th attorney general.

headline: Cuomo on a Collision Course With Unions
text: It was perhaps the most memorable line from Eliot Spitzer’s 2006 campaign for governor of New York, a pithy promise as well as a threat: “Day 1,” he declared, “everything changes.”

headline: Google Settles Suit Over Buzz and Privacy
text: Google informed users of its Gmail service Tuesday evening that it had settled a class action lawsuit brought against it by some users who were upset by the way the company rolled out its Buzz social networking service.

headline: Tea Partiers and Republican Faithful Share Exuberant Celebrations
text: WASHINGTON  This is what a red wave looks like here, at least in election night party terms, circa 2010: hugging, high-fiving, Heineken-toasting Tea Party insurgents (in “Don’t Tread on Me” garb) and establishment Republican types (“business casual”) united and rejoicing in a night of Democratic pain.

headline: Thomas DiNapoli Re-Elected Comptroller in a Tight Race
text: Thomas P. DiNapoli, the Democratic state comptroller, narrowly defeated Harry Wilson, the Wall Street trader turned first-time candidate, allowing Mr. DiNapoli to return for a full term as the state’s chief financial officer.

headline: In Governor’s Races, Republicans Make Gains
text: On an Election Day with one of the largest number of governors’ races in memory, Republicans gained governorships across the country, and particularly in the political battlegrounds of the industrial Midwest where Democrats have dominated in recent years.

headline: Patrick Hangs On as Massachusetts Governor
text: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick won a second term in Massachusetts on Tuesday despite an aggressive challenge from his Republican opponent, Charlie Baker.

headline: Child Thrown From Balcony To His Death
text: A 2-year-old boy was thrown to his death from the balcony of a seventh-floor apartment in Queens on Tuesday night by a distraught woman who had been living with his family, the authorities said.

headline: Struggle by Democrats to Guard House Seats
text: Republicans captured six Congressional seats in New York and New Jersey on Tuesday night, riding a wave of voter dissatisfaction that swept Democrats across the country out of power.

headline: Late Voting Delays Results for Connecticut Governor
text: Thomas C. Foley, a wealthy Republican businessman, and Dannel P. Malloy, a former Democratic mayor of Stamford, were locked in a tight race to become Connecticut’s next governor, according to preliminary returns early Wednesday.

headline: Once Again, City Voters Approve Term Limits
text: New Yorkers voted overwhelmingly to limit politicians to two consecutive terms on Tuesday, undoing a highly contentious change to the law pushed through by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg two years ago.

headline: In California, Boxer Wins Senate Race, and Brown Is Governor
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Feeling pessimistic, but bucking the national trend, California voters decided against a pair of untested Republicans in favor of old-school Democrats on Tuesday.

headline: Election Night Live | 12:15am ET
text: As the night comes to a close, The Times's Megan Liberman and Matt Bai analyze the new reality in politics and the balance of power in Washington.

headline: Nathan Deal and Republicans Win in Georgia
text: ATLANTA  Leading an apparent Republican sweep of the state, Nathan Deal, a conservative former congressman, won Georgia’s governorship on Tuesday by stifling a comeback attempt by the state’s last Democratic leader, former Gov. Roy E. Barnes.

headline: Shannon Tavarez, Nala in ‘Lion King’, Dies at 11
text: Shannon Tavarez, who won a featured role on Broadway in “The Lion King” at an open audition for child actors, and who spent seven months performing in the show before receiving a diagnosis of leukemia in April, died on Monday. She was 11.

headline: Charlie O’Donnell, Whose Voice Was Fixture on TV, Dies at 78
text: Charlie O’Donnell, whose resonant off-camera voice was a fixture on American television for decades, most notably in heralding the opening of the game show “Wheel of Fortune” for 28 years, died on Monday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 78.

headline: Adapting a European Tool to U.S. Mortgages
text: Covered bonds, a financing tool popular in Europe since the 18th century, are winning converts in America as a new way to finance residential and commercial mortgages, Julie Satow reports in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | November 3, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Democrats on Verge of Retaining New York State Senate Majority
text: On an otherwise disappointing night for New York Republicans, the party appeared to be on the verge of either retaking the State Senate or throwing the chamber into a tie, but a few key races remained undecided in the early morning hours.

headline: California Rejects Marijuana Legalization
text: OAKLAND  California voters rejected a ballot initiative on Tuesday that would have legalized marijuana for recreational use, but disappointed supporters of the measure lighted up anyway outside their campaign headquarters here and vowed to continue pushing for a day when cannabis is treated like tobacco and alcohol, not heroin and cocaine.

headline: Republican Kirk Wins Obama’s Old Senate Senate
text: CHICAGO  In a stinging defeat for Democrats on President Obama’s home turf, Representative Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican, won a narrow victory for the United States Senate over his Democratic rival, Alexi Giannoulias, the state treasurer whom the president had endorsed to take over his former seat.

headline: Harry Reid Keeps His Seat as Democrats Hold Senate
text: LAS VEGAS — Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader and a symbol of the Democratic establishment, fought back a fierce challenge from Sharron Angle to win re-election on Tuesday in a contest that offered a stark test of the Tea Party against one of the most effective political operations in the nation.

headline: Cypress Lane Founder to Close the Hedge Fund
text: Shafiq Karmali, a former Goldman Sachs trader, is shutting his hedge fund and returning investors’ money a little more than a year after starting it, three people briefed on the decision told Bloomberg News.

headline: In Iowa, Voters Oust Judges Over Marriage Issue
text: DES MOINES  In a rebuke of the state supreme court with implications for judicial elections across the country, voters here removed three justices who participated in a ruling last year that made the state the first in the Midwest to permit same-sex marriage.

headline: In G.M. Comeback, a Big Role for Washington
text: When executives from General Motors begin pitching its public stock offering to investors this week, they will extol the company’s financial turnaround, its snazzy new lineup led by the plug-in Chevrolet Volt, and its growing operations in China and other international markets.

headline: ‘Write-in’ (Murkowski) Performs Well in Alaska
text: SEE UPDATE:

headline: Riding Along With the Candidates
text: Andrew M. Cuomo cruised to victory as governor of New York, Kirsten E. Gillibrand retained her Senate seat and Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut’s attorney general, was elected to the U.S. Senate.

headline: S. Korea Fires Warning Shots at Boat
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean Navy fired warning shots at a North Korean fishing boat on Wednesday after the vessel strayed across the two Koreas’ border on the Yellow Sea, the Defense Ministry said.

headline: A Georgia Democrat Retakes the Lead
text: ATLANTA — A Democratic congressman in Georgia has now taken the lead in a race in which his Republican opponent had been declared the winner.

headline: Facebook’s Early Employees Are Moving On
text: Facebook, the most successful start-up of the last decade, is only six years old, and an initial public offering is still a way off, Verne G. Kopytoff reports in The New York Times.

headline: Solar Firm to Close a Factory and Delay Growth
text: Solyndra, a Silicon Valley solar-panel maker that won a half billion dollars in federal aid to build a state-of-the-art robotic factory, plans to announce on Wednesday that it will shut down an older plant and lay off workers.

headline: Tea Party Triumphs in Rural Colorado
text: DENVER — Scott Tipton, a Republican businessman backed by the Tea Party movement, defeated a three-term Democrat incumbent, Representative John Salazar, in Colorado’s Third Congressional District.

headline: S.E.C. Weighs Rules on Unfettered Market Access
text: Unlicensed high-frequency traders will no longer be able to gain unfettered, or “naked,” access to public markets under a rule being considered by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: PhosAgro Weighing Potash Bid, Russian Report Says
text: PhosAgro, a major fertilizer producer in Russia, is said to be preparing a bid for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan to rival the $39 billion offer from BHP Billiton currently under consideration in Ottawa.

headline: Toomey at Helm of a Republican Wave in Pennsylvania
text: ST. DAVIDS, Pa.  Pat Toomey, a former Republican congressman, defeated Representative Joe Sestak, a Democrat, on Tuesday in a razor-thin Senate race in Pennsylvania that was not called for hours after polls closed.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 3, 2010
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from The Times’s article “Sometimes, Lucky Numbers Add Up to Apartment Sales.”

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Starts Second Fund
text: Last year, when Marc Andreessen set up shop on Sand Hill Road, the tree-lined home to Silicon Valley’s venture capital firms, he was already a big name.

headline: How Much Food Does Your Family Waste?
text: How much of the food that is in your refrigerator right now will end up in the garbage can? The Well blog’s “From Farm to Fridge to Garbage Can” tells of studies that show 93 percent of people buy food they never use. Are you and your family among them? Why do you think food goes to waste in so many homes? How do you think that could be prevented?

headline: R.B.S. and Mitsubishi UFJ in Talks on $6.4 Billion in Assets
text: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial may buy project-finance assets from Royal Bank of Scotland as large Japanese banks start deploying the $56 billion they have raised in share sales in the past two years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Icahn Fires Back At Lions Gate in Legal Battles
text: Carl C. Icahn says he will appeal a court ruling upholding a swap transaction by Lions Gate Entertainment that he claims hindered his hostile takeover bid for the studio, Reuters reported.

headline: Khodorkovsky Awaits Russian Judge’s Verdict in 2nd Trial
text: The second trial of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the jailed former oil tycoon, adjourned on Tuesday to await the judge’s verdict, which Mr. Khodorkovsky said would be a test of Russia’s commitment to the rule of law, even as he expressed little hope of being cleared and spared another decade or more in prison, Michael Schwirtz of The New York Times  reported.

text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Red Grandy, Expecting the Unexpected
text: As a 21-year-old military photographer in West Germany with few skills, I set off one day in 1963 to seek advice from the best news photographer I knew. That was Francis J. Grandy, the chief photographer for Stars and Stripes in Europe, a post he held for 35 years.

headline: Dell Buys Boomi to Bolster Cloud Computing
text: Dell has agreed to buy Boomi, a cloud-computing services start-up, in an effort to shore up its ability to provide software over computer networks.

headline: Barry Diller Raises Coca-Cola Stake
text: For Barry Diller, it seems, there’s nothing like the real thing.

headline: L.S.E. Calls Turquoise Trading Glitch Suspicious
text: The London Stock Exchange said a glitch on its Turquoise cross-border share trading platform might have happened under “suspicious circumstances,” requiring it to delay the adoption of the same technology for its main trading system.

headline: Washington Times Sold to Founder for $1
text: The Washington Times, the ailing newspaper, has been sold for $1 to a group backed by its founder, the Unification Church leader, Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

headline: Lloyds Names Santander UK Executive as Its New Chief
text: Lloyds Banking Group on Wednesday named António Horta-Osório as its new chief executive, succeeding Eric Daniels.

headline: First New York to Start Hedge Fund, Report Says
text: First New York Securities, a proprietary trading firm that manages about $350 million, plans to start its first hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Greece Halts Overseas Mail as Bombs Cross Borders
text: ATHENS  After a season of bitter and widespread protests over austerity measures to address its financial crisis, Greece faced new turmoil on Wednesday as the authorities investigated an elaborate bomb plot in which relatively mild explosive devices were sent to embassies in Athens as well as to the leaders of Italy and Germany.

headline: Wall Street Hopes to Gain as Democrats Lose House
text: After the midterm elections on Tuesday, Wall Street may get another crack at reshaping financial regulations more to its liking. The shifting of the House of Representatives back to Republican control — with a big pickup of at least 58 seats — could help the financial industry ease some of the most onerous aspects of the new regulatory regime.

headline: Wellspring Raises $1.2 Billion for Latest Fund
text: Wellspring Capital Management, the New York private equity firm whose holdings include the Checkers hamburger restaurant chain, has raised $1.2 billion for its fifth and largest fund, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: I.C.B.C. Looks to Southeast Asia
text: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China said on Wednesday that it was looking for acquisitions in countries in Southeast Asia where now it has no presence, Reuters reports.

headline: The TV Watch: Politics and Show Business
text: The pundits were wrong. They suggested the results were a foregone conclusion. Plenty of people didn’t bother to vote. And at least one contender, who claimed to be “exhausted” by the grueling process, seemed almost to welcome defeat.

headline: The Failure of Mortgage Modification
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: History Goes Up in Flames on Fawkes Night
text: “Please to remember, the fifth of November, a tale of gunpowder, treason and plot.” So begins a common British nursery rhyme commemorating a foiled attempt 400-odd years ago to blow up the British Parliament and restore a Catholic monarch to the throne. The leader of these efforts, Guy Fawkes, was eventually executed for his actions, but his memory lives on each November as Britons everywhere host firework displays and bonfires in remembrance of the occasion.

headline: Mall Owner Westfield Plans $3.5 Billion Spin-Off

headline: Stoked
text: I grew up without a fireplace because my neurotic (but fabulous) parents were afraid of fire. So I’ve always been obsessed with them. In the house we built on Shelter Island, I put a bright orange vintage Preway in the bedroom. I had to search far and wide, and finally found the right one on Craigslist. The Preway is no longer in production, but you can still get free-standing fireplaces from Malm, a company out in Santa Rosa, Calif., that has been making them with great proportions and clean lines since the 1960s. (The one above is available from Design Within Reach.) When I am making a piece of pottery, I know that it’s finished — and that it’s good — if it looks like it’s supposed to be that way, like it’s been uncovered rather than created. To me, that’s a Malm fireplace. And I like that it’s democratic, not precious. At its height of popularity, you were as likely to see one in a mobile home as you were in a groovy modernist manse. Those who dismiss these beauties as a bit of ’70s nostalgia need to look again. I’m never happier than when I lie in bed and stare at my Preway, a glowing beacon of orange optimism in the corner of the room.

headline: British Agency Says Google Violated Privacy Law

headline: Mme. Curie Is Dead; Martyr to Science
text: PARIS, July 4.--Mme. Marie Curie, whose work alone and with her husband on radium and radiology has been one of the greatest glories of modern science, died at 6 o'clock this morning in a sanitarium near Sallanches in Upper Savoy. Her death, which was caused by a form of pernicious anemia, was hastened by what her physicians termed "a long accumulation of radiations" which affected the bones and prevented her from reacting normally to the disease.

headline: Bolsheviki Seize State Buildings, Defying Kerensky

This time, for reasons unclear to us, readers expanded their regrets beyond the financial sphere — in many cases far, far beyond it. We now give you a selection, lightly edited. Warning: You may have nightmares. It is a coincidence that we are running this on the day after an election.

headline: Bill Clinton Wishes Lil Wayne ‘a Good Life’ After Jail

headline: Laura Catena Uncorks Argentina
text: Eight years ago, Laura Catena got the notion to write a book about Argentine wine. Who better to do it? As the daughter of Nicolas Catena, Argentina’s most celebrated winemaker, she grew up watching Mendoza’s wine culture evolve from run-of-the-mill jug wines to globally revered malbecs. Her father was the prime mover in that development, an economist by training who fell in love with Napa and became determined to bring a new level of ambition and expertise to his family’s Mendoza vineyards, first planted in 1902. But the younger Catena, now 43, had little idea that telling this story would consume so much time.

headline: Patton's Career A Brilliant One
text: Gen. George Smith Patton Jr. was one of the most brilliant soldiers in American history. Audacious, unorthodox and inspiring, he led his troops to great victories in North Africa, Sicily and on the Western Front. Nazi generals admitted that of all American field commanders he was the one they most feared. To Americans he was a worthy successor of such hardbitten cavalrymen as Philip Sheridan, J. E. B. Stuart and Nathan Bedford Forrest.

headline: Elizabeth Cady Stanton Dies at Her Home
text: Mrs. Elizabeth Cady Stanton died at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon at her home in the Stuart Apartment House, 250 West Ninety-fourth Street. Had she lived until the 12th of next month she would have completed her eighty-seventh year. Mrs. Stanton had been ailing for several months, but had not been seriously ill. Of recent years she became very stout, and this, combined with her naturally large frame, made the use of a cane necessary. Saturday she was confined to her bed. Though physically incapacitated, her mental powers were as much in evidence as ever, and only in the first part of the week she had written two articles for publication. Early on Saturday Mrs. Stanton dictated to her secretary a letter.

headline: Our Men In Drives On Guadalcanal
text: Washington, Nov. 11 -- The Army and Marine forces on Guadalcanal Island carried out offensive action against the Japanese there both on the east and west on Monday (Solomons date), the Navy reported in a communique issued here today. The communique indicated, by lack of word to the contrary, that the operations proceeded successfully. Army planes based in Alaska destroyed seven Japanese seaplanes and damaged two cargo vessels in the western reaches of the Aleutian Islands, the Navy said.

headline: The Tea Party Giveth …
text: If you look at the 2010 midterms in the aggregate, the Tea Party phenomenon looks like an enormous plus for the Republican Party. The right-wing demoralization of 2008 evaporated, and conservative turnout surged. Exit polls showed 4 in 10 voters expressed support for the Tea Parties. In House races, state house races, and state legislature races, the movement seems to have been immensely successful at energizing the grassroots without turning off moderates and independents.

headline: In Bush Memoir, Policy Intersects With Personality
text: George W. Bush’s memoir “Decision Points” could well have been titled “The Decider Decides”: it’s an autobiography focused around “the most consequential decisions” of his presidency and his personal life from his decision to give up drinking in 1986 to his decision to invade Iraq in 2003 to his decisions regarding the financial crisis of 2008. It is a book that is part spin, part mea culpa, part family scrapbook, part self-conscious effort to (re)shape his political legacy.

headline: Cutting Up, Rocking Out and Jamming on Ukuleles
text: The most revelatory moment in the Ukulele Orchestra of Great Britain’s concert at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening probably came during its performance of “Psycho Killer,” the Talking Heads song, when you realized that David Byrne had missed the boat by not recording the tune with an ensemble of singing ukulele players. Or maybe it was during the group’s gracefully sung, delicately plucked account of David Bowie’s “Life on Mars,” an idiosyncratic reading of an offbeat selection, even before it morphed into a handful of songs from entirely different universes: among them Stevie Wonder’s “For Once in My Life,” the theme song from “Born Free” and the Who’s “Substitute.”

headline: Graphic Content | Another Great IDEA
text: Over the past couple of years, some important graphic design magazines in the United States and abroad have folded or severely reduced their pages, and even the survivors are increasingly migrating to digital formats. Although a few standbys are still plugging away in printed form, there is one magazine that has so successfully resisted digital pressures that it has even expanded its scope. IDEA: International Graphic Art and Typography, now in its 343rd issue, is one of the most beautifully designed and comprehensively edited graphic design magazines in the world. It is a model of acuity and panache. And yet I cannot always decipher it because it is in Japanese.

headline: Entrepreneur Has Uncle Mo Going for Him

Maybe he would play shortstop for the Mets someday or become a multimillionaire. Maybe he’d own a young racehorse that would run so fast that anything, even a Kentucky Derby win, would seem possible. Repole never did play for the Mets. Other than that, he’s doing pretty well.

headline: Honda CR-Z Finds Tuner Love at SEMA Show

Now, it appears Honda wants at least part of that market back, and a collection of radically tweaked CR-Z hybrids on display at this year’s SEMA Show is meant to do just that.

headline: Another Move for Eric Hara
text: You’ll need a GPS to follow Eric Hara these days. He left David Burke’s empire to become the executive chef at the Oak Room in the Plaza. He’s reduced his workload there, becoming consulting chef with his cooks in place. He is now the executive chef and a partner, with Sal Romano, at Agua Dulce on Ninth Avenue and 53rd Street (whose original chef, Ulrich A. Sterling, left this summer) and 9, next door to Agua Dulce. The original chef of 9, which opened for about 15 minutes and is now temporarily closed, was Michael Berardino, who is out. The food at 9 will now go from Mediterranean to American. Mr. Hara has also resigned as the consulting chef for two restaurants, Siena and Dekko in Astoria, Queens, which have yet to open.

headline: A Bunker Mentality, Busted
text: BAGHDAD — The muffled thuds of a bombing rolled through my open bedroom windows around dinnertime. For a moment, they sounded like thunderclaps — there had been an autumn storm just a day earlier — but these sounds, this sickening succession of concussion waves rippling across Baghdad, suggested something different.

headline: Teaching Children How to Vote
text: When I was 3 or 4, my father took me into the voting booth for the first time. He had to lift me high to help him push the levers, and on the way home we talked, I’m sure, about Democracy and Responsibility and How Machines Count So Very High. Over the years he lifted me less often, and the talks driving home became more nuanced, but it was a ritual, that visit to the voting booth — closing the curtain, making a hushed and private choice, snapping the curtain open again.

headline: The Strange Death of Fiscal Policy
text: One clear result of the midterms is that we won’t have anything like a further round of stimulus. And this, in turn, means that the narrative all the Very Serious People will tell is that fiscal policy was tried, it failed, and that’s that.

headline: Reid Assails Polls That Predicted His Loss
text: NEVADA – Senator Harry Reid of Nevada has long made a point of saying he doesn’t like polls. Throughout these last two years – as Mr. Reid saw poll after poll suggesting he was in trouble – he told whoever would listen that the polls were wrong, that he was going to win, and that he was not concerned. Outside his circle, it seems fair to say that not many people believed him.

headline: A New Name on the Morphoses Roster

His co-founder and the company’s director, Lourdes Lopez, said on Wednesday that a different artistic director will be put in place each season. First on the list is Luca Veggetti, the Italian stage director and choreographer. He will produce an “original, full-length, multidisciplinary staging” of Euripides’ “Bacchae” next season, collaborating with the Italian composer Paolo Aralla, the performance artist and playwright Luca Scarlini and the flutist Erin Lesser, the company said.

I was 44, a lifelong jazz snob, who viewed the prospect of watching teenagers perform a musical with dread. We were going to see something called “Sweeney Todd.” I’d never heard of it. Music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim. I had no clue.

headline: Seattle Symphony Names New Executive Director
text: The Seattle Symphony, suffering from a momentary leadership vacuum, has settled on a British orchestra official, Simon Woods, as its next executive director. Mr. Woods, a former president and chief executive of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra who is now chief executive of the Royal Scottish National Orchestra, will take over in Seattle in May, the orchestra said on Wednesday. Meanwhile, Mr. Woods will spend one week a month in Seattle starting in January, a spokeswoman said, and the chairwoman of the orchestra’s board, Leslie Jackson Chihuly, “is taking an active role” until he arrives. The orchestra’s previous top administrator left in February, and a temporary replacement departed last month. Mr. Woods’s arrival will coincide with that of the new music director, Ludovic Morlot, who takes over next season from Gerard Schwarz. Mr. Schwarz is in his 26th season with the orchestra.

headline: Play It Again, Paul: Another Lecture-Demonstration of a Bach Monument

He has added a second lecture-demonstration in advance of his Nov. 16 performance of the third book of Bach’s “Clavierübung,” a complex and monumental work, to celebrate the reinstallation of the Kuhn organ at Alice Tully Hall. He has added a similar session at the church on Tuesday, at 7:30 p.m. ($10 suggested donation). The concert is part of Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival.

headline: Face Time | Bottega Veneta’s BVX
text: Bottega Veneta, best known for its high level of artisanal craftsmanship and logo-free take on luxury living, has partnered with the Swiss watch giant Girard Perregaux to produce its first watch, the BVX. As elegantly subtle as the house’s signature woven leather accessories, the unisex watch features a dark, brushed-titanium curved case with a brown face and a cigar-colored crocodile strap. But don’t let the sexy simplicity fool you: inside this chic exterior lies an 18-karat rose gold automatic movement made expressly by Girard Perregaux for Bottega Veneta. And this watch has a face that even Dorian Gray could love, with nary a name or initial marring its smooth, lacquered surface, adhering strictly to the company’s famous motto: “When your own initials are enough.” The BVX is $14,600 and will be available starting in December.

headline: To Soak or Not?
text: In my column this week I divulge the fact that I no longer soak dried beans before cooking them. If you’re like me, and don’t know that you want to make bean stew until, well, the moment you want to make bean stew, then that eight-hour prep just isn’t in the cards.  That said, soaking beans overnight to soften them is really a great choice if you’re the kind of person who knows what you will want for dinner tomorrow. The eight hours or so spent in the water drastically reduces the cooking time. This saves energy and gets your dinner on the table faster once you bring everything to a boil. So feel free to soak the beans for this recipe if you’re so inclined. Just watch them carefully to see when they are done – probably in half the time it took me with unsoaked beans. Another issue that I briefly bring up in the column is refrigerating the beans while they soak. Years ago, I was taught that soaking beans might start to ferment if left in a very warm room overnight. Soaking in the fridge eliminates this concern. However, several readers have written to me saying that they never refrigerate their soaking beans and haven’t had any problems. One friend, from the Caribbean, said she always soaks her beans outside on the porch overnight in 80-degree weather, and that those beans seem to cook up perfectly well. I’m curious to hear how you do it – do you soak at room temperature or in the fridge? What about quick soaking? Many readers use pressure cookers, so I’m asking, do you soak if you use a pressure cooker? Leave a comment to share your leguminous adventures.

text: The insightful Belgian conductor Philippe Herreweghe, a pioneer in the early-music movement who founded the splendid Collegium Vocale Gent, has performed and recorded a wide repertory of sacred works. So it was a no-brainer for Lincoln Center to invite Mr. Herreweghe to participate in the White Light Festival, a three-week exploration of music that delves into spiritual realms.

headline: Cool Alchemy: Merging East and West for a Universal Beat
text: The singer Omar Souleyman, on his second tour of the United States this year, has become a breakthrough artist in the United States in what used to be called world music. How? Why?

headline: Warrior-Dancer Monks, as Smooth as Silk
text: The history of Shaolin martial arts stretches back centuries. The fascination of Western male outsiders is a more recent phenomenon, but it’s making up for lost time in impressive fashion. Can any boy, whether he’s 8 or 80, resist China’s glorious warrior-monks?

headline: Window-Dressing Warriors
text: SOMETHING apparently stolen from Bergdorf Goodman was on display in the window of Juicy Couture’s store on Fifth Avenue during Fashion Week in September: a mannequin with one very long arm draped with a half-dozen headphones.

headline: ‘Dancing’ and Voting
text: The television networks interrupted much of their prime-time schedules on Tuesday for election results, but ABC dominated the early part of the night with its “Dancing With the Stars” results episode. It attracted 16.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. That number was subject to revision in final ratings results, but ABC appeared to lead the night over all, averaging 7.4 million viewers from 9:30 to 11 for its election coverage. CBS placed second with reruns of “NCIS” (11.5 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (11.1 million) from 8 to 10 followed by news coverage (5.2 million). NBC was third, and Fox was fourth.

headline: ‘Merchant of Venice’ Delays Its Opening
text: 6:44 p.m. | Updated

headline: Victory! Defeat! Oh, the Humility
text: There is something about elections that apparently makes the people who participate in them feel small, which is interesting considering the outsized ego often required to run for public office in America these days. The election-emotion is a sense of humility that apparently is not bound by victory or defeat.

headline: Taylor Swift Album Is a Sales Triumph
text: In the diminished world of the music business, where album sales have plunged by more than 50 percent in the last decade, genuine blockbusters are an endangered species. But this week the recording industry got a rare bit of good news with the unmitigated triumph of Taylor Swift’s “Speak Now.”

headline: Wildly Rocking Shadows in an Ominous World
text: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, the company formed in 2003 by the Wal-Mart heiress Nancy Laurie and led by its artistic director, Benoit-Swan Pouffer, possesses spacious Chelsea headquarters, the money to commission works by out-of-town choreographers and an online store. Yet the most attractive part of the Cedar Lake package is its 15 dancers  even in less-than-stellar pieces and wearing socks. (They love to dance in socks.)

headline: Canada Blocks BHP’s Takeover Bid for Potash
text: Yielding to political opposition, Tony Clement, Canada’s industry minister, said late Wednesday that his government would not approve a proposed $38.6 billion purchase of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan by the big Australian miner BHP Billiton, The New York Times reports.

headline: Inspectors Haven’t Seen Enough Flying for ‘Spider-Man’ Safety to Pass Muster
text: Increasing the likelihood of another delay for “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the producers of the coming $60 million Broadway musical were unable to present all of the two dozen flying and aerial maneuvers on Wednesday for safety inspectors from the New York State Department of Labor, requiring them to return before performances can begin.

headline: Canada Blocks BHP’s Purchase of Potash
text: OTTAWA  Yielding to political pressure, Canada said on Wednesday that it would not approve a proposed $38.6 billion purchase of Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan by BHP Billiton, the large Australian mining company.

headline: Chevrolet Camaro Voted Hottest Car at the SEMA Show
text: LAS VEGAS — Election night at the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show here was not exactly a night of upsets. The voting for the show’s hottest car, truck and S.U.V. favored vehicles with a long history at the SEMA Show: the Chevrolet Camaro was selected the Hottest Car, the Ford F-Series the Hottest Truck and the Jeep Wrangler the Hottest 4×4-S.U.V.

headline: Iran Responds to Alarm on Woman Sentenced to Stoning
text: France’s foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, said that his Iranian counterpart had assured him on Wednesday that Iran’s judiciary has not yet decided to execute a woman sentenced to death by stoning.

headline: At Home With Eli Wallach
text: In 2010, A. O. Scott visited his uncle, who has acted in more than 90 movies, in his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Documenting Accumulation and Its Discontents
text: WHEN Corinne May Botz was a preteenager in Glen Rock, N.J., she and her two sisters appeared on a segment of “Good Morning America” as the “bad example,” she said recently, in a story about children’s messy bedrooms. (Asked by the television reporter why she didn’t clean her room, she recalled her 11-year-old self replying airily, “I don’t have time!”)

headline: Gran Turismo 5 Discs Being Stamped Now, Says Creator
text: Kazunori Yamauchi, the creator of the Gran Turismo driving simulator series for the PlayStation, is in Las Vegas for the SEMA Show, a trade show for the automotive aftermarket industry, otherwise known as the “wheels and babes” show.

headline: Cornyn ‘Gratified’ By Senate Results
text: Republicans are in line to pick up at least six seats in the Senate this midterm campaign. But that doesn’t mean party leaders won’t face questions about whether the G.O.P. could potentially have snapped up more.

headline: Neighborhood Mischief Caught on Tape
text: STEVE MILLER is justifiably proud of the manicured grounds around his stately stucco home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. So he was nonplussed last year when he discovered that someone had been tossing plastic bags of dog excrement into the sculptured shrubs around a palm tree in his front yard.

headline: In NoHo, a Bento Box They Can Live In
text: MOST architects meet their clients through referrals or networking. Mishi Hosono and Adam Weintraub, of Koko Architecture and Design in Manhattan, met one of theirs just before their wedding 12 years ago, when Ms. Hosono was trying to figure out how to put on the dress she planned to wear.

headline: On Marathon Sunday, the Long Haul Begins Before Dawn
text: Sam Teichman knows he is supposed to be sitting on a bus on Sunday morning, headed to the starting line of the New York City Marathon on Staten Island. Teichman, 31, signed up for the race’s official transportation and was assigned to a bus leaving the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Who’s Getting Endplayed?
text: The bronze medal winners in the Imp Pairs at the world championships in Philadelphia last month were Kelley Hwang of New York and John Zilic of Houston. They defended carefully in the diagramed deal, Board 9 of the final session.

headline: Gates Foundation Gives $30 Million to Smithsonian
text: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has given the Smithsonian Institution $30 million to create an endowment for online education programs aimed at students in underserved communities. The donation was reported on Wednesday by the Puget Sound Business Journal. In a press release, the Smithsonian said it would use the donation to build on existing programs that use interactive Web sites, online conferences, distance learning and games to reach new audiences. The donation follows two $10 million grants by the foundation to the Smithsonian since 2009, one of them to support the construction of the new National Museum of African American History and Culture. The chairwoman of the Smithsonian’s board of regents, Patricia Q. Stonesifer, is a former chief executive of the Gates Foundation.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Online Privacy
text: Although the Federal Trade Commission last week dropped its investigation of personal data inadvertently collected by Google’s StreetView cars, state authorities and officials in European and other countries are still looking into privacy issues related to the service. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a New York Times technology reporter who covers Google, about the latest developments. Ms. Miller says that Google has taken new steps aimed at protecting privacy, which satisfied the F.T.C., but consumer groups and privacy advocates are dismayed about the agency’s decision. Google recently revealed that in addition to location photos, its StreetView cars gathered passwords and e-mail from unencrypted Wi-Fi networks.

headline: Garden Officials Reopen Arena After an Asbestos Scare
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  A fire alarm blared at the Knicks’ training center Wednesday, its shrill bursts disturbing an otherwise peaceful afternoon. No one was evacuated. No fire trucks rushed to the scene. Another false alarm.

headline: Justices Revisit Tax Credits for Religious Schools
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday returned to a subject that produced a major and closely divided decision eight years ago: how far may the government go in aiding religious schools?

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,347 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 3
text: A view of the day in sports, with many midair acrobatics.

headline: The Road Ahead Turns Right
text: Energized by their big victories in the midterm elections, Congressional Republican leaders wasted no time on Wednesday in putting President Obama and Democrats on notice: the days of single-party control are numbered and legislating in Washington is about to get a whole lot more complicated.

headline: Obama to Face New Foes in Global Warming Fight
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and the new Congress appear headed for early confrontations over the reach of environmental regulation and federal subsidies for fossil fuel development.

headline: General Motors Can Fly Again for Stock Sale
text: DETROIT — General Motors executives have been cleared for takeoff again.

headline: Israel Attack Kills a Top Militant in Gaza
text: GAZA  A Palestinian leader of an Islamic extremist group inspired by Al Qaeda was killed in an apparent Israeli airstrike in Gaza City on Wednesday, according to the Israeli military.

headline: Fed to Spend $600 Billion to Speed Up Recovery
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, getting ahead of the battles that will dominate national politics over the next two years, moved Wednesday to jolt the economy into recovery with a bold but risky plan to pump $600 billion into the banking system.

headline: In the Capital, Rethinking Old Limits on Buildings
text: WASHINGTON — For all the towering ambitions of this city’s residents, its buildings are generally short and boxy.

headline: Accumulation and its Discontents
text: Corinne May Botz, a 33-year-old artist, is exploring the dark side of domesticity through her photographs of other people’s things.

headline: Erica Eden of Smart Design on Pyrex
text: Erica Eden is an industrial designer at Smart Design. (Winner of this year’s National Design Award for product design, it is the company that created the OXO Good Grips, among other human-friendly tools.)

headline: In the New Iraq, a Familiar Taste of Misery
text: BAGHDAD  Ten people died at Aroba Square, near a gold-domed shrine in the capital, where a bomber strolled a little after sunset before he blew himself up.

headline: Palin’s Endorsements Lay Base for a 2012 Run
text: If Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor, decides to run for president in 2012, she will now have plenty of help.

headline: Yemen’s Drive on Al Qaeda Faces Internal Skepticism
text: SANA, Yemen  As Yemen intensifies its military campaign against Al Qaeda’s regional arm, it faces a serious obstacle: most Yemenis consider the group a myth, or a ploy by their president to squeeze the West for aid money and punish his domestic opponents.

headline: A Livable Bento Box
text: Using the obento as a model, architects created a multifunctional space that made full use of a 1,300-square-foot apartment.

headline: Solemn End to Trial for ’98 Attacks
text: Their names were not read aloud, but the impact was there. Page after page of them were shown on courtroom monitors, carrying the names of the hundreds of people who died in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa.Jurors, seeing the names go by, appeared riveted and solemn in the quiet courtroom.

headline: Oracle and SAP Reach a Partial Settlement, But Trial Continues
text: SAP has agreed to pay $120 million to settle part of a lawsuit brought by Oracle over copyright infringement, according to a source familiar with the matter.

headline: Pelosi Coy on Future in Post-Election Interview
text: Nancy Pelosi‘s time as Speaker of the House is almost up, but she is not yet tipping her hand.

headline: A Few Chores Before the Freeze
text: IN the spirit of full disclosure, I have to admit the garden has not looked so good lately. I lost control of it at the end of the summer when I took a vacation to Cape Cod. It seemed like an extravagance to hire someone to water and weed, and anyway, I figured, the flowers could withstand a few weeks on their own.

headline: Wall Street Gets Its Groove Back
text: By SUSANNE CRAIG

headline: Amid a Tea Party Whirlwind, Connecticut Is an Island of Calm

headline: Sales at George Smith, Sferra and Others
text: Silver flatware, hollowware, crystal, porcelain and frames are 40 to 70 percent off during the Christofle sale at Soiffer Haskin, through Nov. 7 (the Atomes d’Argent Candelabra by Richard Hutton, regularly $1,300, is $780; a Menorah by Adam Tihany, originally $2,000, is $1,200); 317 West 33rd Street (Eighth Avenue), (718) 747-1656, soifferhaskin.com.

headline: Floor Covering Transformed
text: Randy Twaddle began drawing electrical transformers — those metal boxes on telephone poles — more than a decade ago.

headline: France: Extradition Order For Rwandan
text: A French court on Wednesday ordered the extradition of a Rwandan rebel leader to the International Criminal Court in The Hague on charges of raping and killing civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The rebel, Callixte Mbarushimana, was arrested in Paris in October on a warrant from the international court, which has charged him with 11 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Prosecutors say he is the main political leader of the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, which uses Congo as a base to attack the Tutsi-led government of Rwanda across the border. Mr. Mbarushimana, 47, plans to appeal the extradition ruling, his lawyer told The Associated Press.

headline: ‘Bunny Williams’ Scrapbook for Living’
text: If you want a book to beat yourself over the head with while bewailing your shortcomings as a host, housekeeper and decorator, we recommend “Bunny Williams’ Scrapbook for Living” (Stewart Tabori & Chang; $60). First of all, it is heavy. Second, it is chock full of beautiful instructive pictures on things like how to set up a bar for a party, which will torment you even more, because, frankly, yours will never look this good.

headline: Facebook Offers Local Deals for Mobile Users
text: Facebook introduced a feature on Wednesday that will allow retailers and other merchants to offer coupons and special deals through its mobile application, intensifying competition in the market for mobile searches and advertising.

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Opens Kiosk in Grand Central
text: For downtown design aficionados and others who have lamented the geographic undesirability of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum on East 91st Street, a satellite version of the museum’s shop is now open in Grand Central Terminal. The small, tightly edited store — a kiosk in the Graybar Passage — will carry 25 products, including Cynthia Rowley’s Band-Aids ($10); patterned masking tape ($22), right bottom; the PlayShapes Wooden Toy by Miller Goodman ($150), right top; and at the high end, the Junghans table clock ($360). Gregory Krum, the museum’s director of retail, who is overseeing the kiosk, said he envisioned it as “a gem-like thing in a dark and gritty passage” with “a very strong, carefully considered selection of stuff.” Open Monday through Saturday, through the end of January; information: (212) 661-0298 or cooperhewittshop.org.

headline: The Risks in Alcoholic Drinks
text: To the Editor:

headline: YouTube Withdraws Cleric’s Videos
text: LONDON  Under pressure from American and British officials, YouTube on Wednesday removed from its site some of the hundreds of videos featuring calls to jihad by Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born, Yemen-based cleric who has played an increasingly public role in inspiring violence directed at the West.

headline: End Tables
text: JON CALL believes that end tables are the stepchildren of the living room, overlooked and ignored in favor of the sofa, the star of the room. And he’d like to change that.

headline: How the Fed’s Move Could Trickle Down to Consumers
text: WASHINGTON  In its latest move to help the economy, the Federal Reserve is about to restart its monetary printing press  or rather, the electronic equivalent.

headline: A Slave Ship in New York
text: New York, Nov. 4, 1860

headline: G.M. Cleared to Use Private Jets to Promote Stock Sale
text: 5:41 p.m. | Updated General Motors executives have been cleared for takeoff again.

headline: Buffalo Takes Paladino’s Defeat in Stride
text: BUFFALO  For what turned out to be a fleeting moment, he shone a spotlight on this struggling city tucked away in a corner of New York State. And the day after the man with the spotlight, Carl P. Paladino, was trounced in the election for governor, his hometown offered a collective shrug.

headline: G.O.P. Expands a Base From South to Midwest
text: LAS VEGAS  For Democrats, the new political map colored by the midterm elections was nothing short of bracing: Vast stretches of uninterrupted Republican victories across the Midwest and the South, with Democrats left clinging to the coasts, lonely strips of blue on a very red horizon.

headline: G.O.P. Faces Choice in How to Oppose
text: The day after the election always dawns sunny and full of hope in Washington. From Representative John A. Boehner on down, Republicans talked on Wednesday about how open they were to working with the president (except, perhaps, for repealing that whole health care thing). Rand Paul, the next senator from Kentucky, said on MSNBC that his family was hoping to meet the Obama girls. You could almost see the two dads stretched out in front of the TV, sharing a laugh at “Phineas and Ferb.”

headline: Ouster of Iowa Judges Sends Signal to Bench
text: DES MOINES — An unprecedented vote to remove three Iowa Supreme Court justices who were part of the unanimous decision that legalized same-sex marriage in the state was celebrated by conservatives as a popular rebuke of judicial overreach, even as it alarmed proponents of an independent judiciary.

headline: Israel: Officials Cancel Trip To Britain
text: A Foreign Ministry official confirmed Wednesday that Israeli officials would not travel to London this month for an annual British-Israeli strategic dialogue because of the fear of arrest. Britain adheres to the principle of universal jurisdiction, which allows its judges to issue arrest warrants against anyone suspected of war crimes anywhere in the world. Pro-Palestinian activists have threatened Israeli officials with arrest on allegations of war crimes against Palestinians, causing several officials to cancel plans to visit Britain. In Jerusalem on Wednesday, the British foreign secretary, William Hague, reiterated his government’s commitment to resolving what he called the “unacceptable situation” with regard to universal jurisdiction. An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman, Yigal Palmor, said that the issue was the “top item” on Israel’s agenda for Mr. Hague’s visit.

headline: Shift May Push Democrats to Compromise on Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday invited Congressional Republican leaders to negotiate about extending the soon-to-expire Bush-era tax cuts, but he stood his ground by arguing against the Republicans’ demand to keep those cuts for income above $250,000.

headline: Invitation to Veterans, Friends and Families
text: The editors of Home Fires are requesting the participation of readers for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11. If you are a veteran, or friend or relative of someone who served during wartime and would like to share a written message or recollection, or a photograph recalling a veteran or their service, you can send it to us via e-mail at opinionator@nytimes.com. Please put HOME FIRES in the subject line of your message.

headline: Shopping With Jon Call
text: Jon Call, an interior designer and the owner of Mr. Call Designs, believes that end tables are the stepchildren of the living room, overlooked and ignored in favor of larger pieces. And he’d like to change that.

headline: Tending to Sick Computers, and Their Owners
text: Aurora Thornhill used to work at an apple orchard near Limerick, Me., where she grew up. Now she spends her days with Apples. Ms. Thornhill, 26, is an assistant retail manager at Tekserve, the independently owned Apple store on West 23rd Street in Manhattan. She started there in March 2008, working in the intake section  Tekserve’s triage unit, where an ailing computer is given a diagnosis. She has since become an expert in gadget protection, developing her own technique, using compressed air and a credit card, for applying screen protectors to iPads  the kind of thing the techies at Tekserve obsess about.

headline: Fed Gets Aggressive After Months of Holding Back
text: For much of the last year, there were three basic camps on what the Federal Reserve should be doing.

headline: Out With the Lamb Chops and in With the Lasagna
text: A change in the occupant of the governor’s mansion in Albany can mean more than a new direction in public policy. The state’s chief executive can also set the tone with his style. Herewith, a taste of the old and the new:

headline: Colombia Suspends 7 in Military After Children’s Killings
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombia’s army has suspended seven officers and soldiers for failing to control their troops in connection with the brutal murders last month of three impoverished children near Colombia’s northeast border with Venezuela.

headline: Promise of Renewed Battle Over Reach of Health Care
text: While Republicans cannot fulfill their campaign promise to repeal the new health care law any time soon, they can lead Congress in a sweeping re-examination of its more unpopular provisions, including new taxes and a requirement for most Americans to carry health insurance.

headline: Finish Rabin’s Work
text: TODAY marks 15 years since an assassin’s bullet killed my friend, Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli prime minister. Since his death, not a week has gone by that I have not missed him. I loved him and his wife, Leah, very much. On the occasion of the anniversary of his death, his yahrzeit, the world would do well to remember the lessons of his life: his vision for freedom, tolerance, cooperation, security and peace is as vital now as it was 15 years ago, when he happily spoke and sang for peace at a huge rally in Tel Aviv just before he was killed.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Face Uncertain Future
text: House Republicans have made punching bags of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, criticizing the federal bailout of the mortgage giants and promising to end the government’s longstanding use of the companies to reduce the cost of mortgage loans.

headline: Sitting Here Thinking of Acapulco
text: Jamey Garza has been intrigued by the Acapulco chair — which has a colorful nylon-cord or plastic bucket seat on top of an iron base — since he first encountered it nearly 10 years ago. Mr. Garza, an artist and designer, and his wife, Constance Holt-Garza, had two of the cord version in their yard in Marfa, Tex., and while the chairs didn’t age well, they did provide inspiration for a new design. “We realized we could redefine the Acapulco chair by making it an interior piece, with a wishbone leg base and a leather bucket seat,” he said. The Garzas have spent the better part of this year refining their chair, and last month they introduced three versions — round, oval and square — all hand-made of quarter-inch-thick saddle leather set atop iron bases, which come in plain black or a choice of seven powder-coated colors. Prices start at $500 (the Desert Round Lounge Chair is $650); information: (432) 729-1946 or garzadesignbuild.com.

headline: Money for Scientific Research May Be Scarce With a Republican-Led House
text: Federal financing of science research, which has risen quickly since the Obama administration came to power, could fall back to pre-Obama levels if the incoming Republican leadership in the House of Representatives follows through on its list of campaign promises.

headline: Seeking a New Law’s Protection, Loft Tenants Instead Find Grief
text: After New York State passed a law this summer extending residential rights to people living in illegal lofts in much of the city, the seven tenants of 360 Jefferson Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, acted fast.

headline: The Day After the Day After
text: O.K., you poor little Democrats. Stop sobbing. Lift up your little liberal heads and shout. There’s gonna be. ...

headline: Motive Sought in Killing of Queens Child
text: A day after a 2-year-old boy was thrown to his death from a seventh-floor balcony in Queens, his family, neighbors and investigators struggled on Wednesday to understand what might have motivated the suspect in the case to kill him.

headline: A Scale-Back Is Possible in Financial Overhaul Law
text: Only three months after the enactment in July of the Dodd-Frank Act, the financial regulation legislation that was intended as a response to the financial crisis, a section of the act has already been repealed.

headline: Stately Home Awaits the Return of a Political Son
text: It is perhaps the most spectacular perk of the governor’s job: a 40-room Victorian mansion, with a full-time domestic staff, on six rolling acres above the Hudson River.

headline: China: House Arrest For Rights Lawyer
text: A prominent rights lawyer who was released in September after years in prison remains under house arrest in his hometown in Shandong Province and is not allowed to receive visitors, Human Rights in China, an advocacy group, said Wednesday. The lawyer, Chen Guangcheng, is a vocal critic of government policies, especially of forced sterilizations or abortions by local officials trying to enforce adherence to the one-child policy. Mr. Chen was held under house arrest for one year starting in 2005, then was imprisoned for four years on criminal convictions. Human Rights in China said no one, not even Mr. Chen’s mother, had been allowed to visit Mr. Chen, who is blind, or his wife, Yuan Weijing, since early October.

headline: After 52 Years of Waiting, One Delirious Day
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The mayor quoted Jerry Garcia, and one player pulled underwear out of his pants and held it up before 100,000 people. Another player referred to a ballot proposition to legalize marijuana as spectators with orange wigs and provocative signs cheered, snapped photos and blew kisses at their heroes.

headline: You Want a Toy With That?
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Lost in the nationwide electoral tumult Tuesday was another important vote, this one by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, which took on one of the great (tasting) issues of our day: the Happy Meal.

headline: Mr. Obama, It’s Time for Some Poetry
text: On my blog, a Times reader named Eddie asked about President Obama: “Where is the man I voted for?”

headline: Republican House Could Re-energize Trade Talks
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama may find a rare opening for possible bipartisan cooperation, with a Republican House helping to re-energize American efforts to reduce trade barriers.

headline: Cuomo’s Transition Is Already Well Under Way
text: Thousands of résumés to shuffle through. An inauguration speech to draft. A senior staff to assemble. And perhaps most important of all, decisions about who gets which office.

headline: Impropriety Is Alleged at City Transit Union
text: Transport Workers Union Local 100, the influential labor group that represents many of New York City’s subway and bus workers, is no stranger to squabbles. Years of in-house clashes and strife prompted its current president to run on a “Take Back Our Union” platform when he was elected last year.

headline: A Cuomo Heads Back to the Executive Mansion
text: The governor’s residence at 138 Eagle Street in Albany is rich in family memories for Andrew M. Cuomo, the governor-elect.

headline: Focus Changes for Louisiana in Oil Cleanup
text: Louisiana is scaling back and altering a project to construct sand berms along its coast to block and capture oil from the BP spill, the state’s governor, Bobby Jindal, said this week.

headline: To Save Money, Save the Health Care Act
text: In the name of fiscal probity, the incoming Republican leadership in Congress has committed to doing whatever it takes to stop the health care reform act from taking effect. Yet many of the provisions that politicians have been taking aim at are the ones that save money  like those that reduce excessive provider payments and create new institutions to curb cost growth.

headline: Drugs Seized in Tunnel Near Border
text: LOS ANGELES  A drug-smuggling tunnel and approximately 30 tons of marijuana were discovered early Wednesday in the Otay Mesa section of San Diego, said officials from Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the United States Drug Enforcement Administration.

headline: Sorting Out the Election
text: Tuesday’s election was indeed a “shellacking” for the Democrats, as President Obama admitted after a long night of bad news. It was hardly an order from the American people to discard the progress of the last two years and start over again.

headline: The Beer Summit Catches On in Illinois
text: CHICAGO – Has the “beer summit” become the go-to reconciliation stunt of modern politics? The awkward meeting between Illinois Senator-elect Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican, and his defeated rival, Alexi Giannoulias, the state treasurer and a Democrat, over two brews in a dive bar here on Wednesday night certainly suggests so.

headline: After New York Losses, Head of State G.O.P. Is Under Fire
text: A day after a disastrous defeat in statewide races despite huge gains for their party across the country, the soul-searching among New York State Republican officials quickly turned to recriminations  and, from several corners, calls for the resignation of the state Republican chairman, Edward F. Cox.

headline: Rocky, Bullwinkle and My Dad
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hopeful in 3 Tight Races, G.O.P. Is on Cusp of Control of New York Senate
text: While the 2010 election was largely disappointing for New York Republicans, there was a silver lining.

headline: To the Left, to the Left. No, to the Right.
text: Mr. Wan is my mover.

headline: Did Polls Underestimate Democrats’ Latino Vote?
text: The two Senate races where the actual winner was different from the leader in our polling-based projections were Colorado and Nevada (it’s also probable that we’ll miss Lisa Murkowski’s victory in Alaska once all her write-in votes are — eventually — counted).

headline: In Rubio, Some See Rise of ‘Great Right Hope’
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  For many Tea Party conservatives, Hispanics, and young Americans frustrated with the national debt that baby boomers have saddled on their future, Marco Rubio’s victory in the Florida Senate race gave them an extra reason to celebrate.

headline: Meanwhile, in Albany
text: As he celebrated winning New York’s governorship with 62 percent of the vote, Attorney General Andrew Cuomo said New Yorkers sent him a mandate to “clean up Albany.” The problem is that New Yorkers, who complain a lot about Albany, also basically re-elected the whole bumbling, fumbling, corrupt Legislature.

headline: New Energy Outfoxes Old in California
text: There are several ways to look at Tuesday’s overwhelming endorsement by California’s voters of the state’s global warming law: as a vote for clean energy over dirty, as a rebuke to carpetbaggers, as proof that good things can happen when a political leader  in this case, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger  leads.

headline: Royal Family Fight Heads to a New York Courtroom
text: Family disputes over money are almost always unpleasant and difficult to untangle. When such a dispute involves a family that rules a small country and a fortune that amounts to tens of billions of dollars, the complications multiply.

headline: Halloween’s Afterlife
text: It’s a few days after the e’en of Oct. 31, and the trick-or-treaters have packed away their costumes and divided up their loot. But along one of the city’s streets (and we suspect many) the stoops are still in full regalia, and they’ll remain that way for a while longer.

headline: From Brooklyn to Beijing, and Into a Caldron
text: BEIJING  China had captivated the imagination of Paul Cabo for as long as he could remember. Maybe it started with the documentaries he saw as a child about the Great Wall. Or his desire to understand his recently immigrated Chinese classmates at Abraham Lincoln High School in Coney Island. Or maybe it was kung fu movies.

headline: Andy Irons, Surf Champion, Is Dead at 32
text: Andy Irons, a three-time world surfing champion from Hawaii whose progressive wave riding and intense rivalry with Kelly Slater invigorated the sport’s competitive scene, died Tuesday in a Dallas hotel room while traveling home to Kauai. He was 32.

headline: Rejecting Bid Sends Bad Signal
text: Canada may have just shot itself in the foot. The country’s government said that BHP’s $39 billion takeover bid for the Potash Corporation provided no net benefit to the nation.

headline: Lost Notes Will Linger as Footsteps Fall
text: There was a death in the family.

headline: For N.F.L. Players, Another Risk: Heart Disease
text: PHILADELPHIA  Eighteen years after his last football game, Brad Quast has a stack of medical records describing the devastating effects of a brief career of very hard knocks: badly injured knees, the remnants of a serious neck injury sustained while playing in college and enough concussive damage to have caused short-term memory loss.

headline: Bloggingheads: Can Obama Turn It Around?

headline: Keep It Clean
text: I’m noticing a rising number of comments containing obscenities — usually no more than most of us use in conversation, but this isn’t ordinary conversation, it’s the !@#% New York Times, and there are rules. Your perfectly reasonable comment will get deleted if it uses indecorous language.

headline: Word-Woozy Roundelay in Average Town Ruled by Singular Sadness
text: The strange beauty of life and its sometimes unbearable weight are both considered with a screwball lyricism in Will Eno’s new play “Middletown,” which opened Wednesday night at the Vineyard Theater in a pitch-perfect production directed by Ken Rus Schmoll. In this delicate, moving and wry amble along the collective road to nowhere, the folks are friendly, and the view of star-dappled skies and modest homes is familiar and comforting.

headline: The Family That Votes Together ...
text: More disappointment is in store for Democrats in mourning who might hope that “That Hopey Changey Thing,” a new play at the Public Theater written and directed by Richard Nelson, would provide the solace of a taunting attack on the rise of Sarah Palin. They will have to search for the comforts of aggrieved rhetoric from the usual providers on cable television.

headline: Genentech Offers Secret Rebates for Eye Drug
text: Genentech has begun offering secret rebates to eye doctors as an apparent inducement to get them to use more of the company’s expensive drug Lucentis rather than a less costly alternative.

headline: Keeper of Giants’ Bats and of Team’s History

If anyone embodies the 52-year endurance test the San Francisco Giants underwent to reach baseball’s summit, it is Mike Murphy.

headline: A Possible Issue: Days Off for Jeter
text: Only four shortstops started at least 150 games last season. Derek Jeter, who turned 36 in June, was one of them. The next oldest, at 33, was Alex Gonzalez of Atlanta. As the Yankees embark on a fascinating and potentially uncomfortable set of negotiations with Jeter to decide what could be his final contract, many numbers  from the 64-point drop in his batting average this past season to the 74 hits he needs for 3,000 for his career  will be discussed.

headline: Next Stop on Moss’s National Tour: Tennessee
text: Randy Moss will go to the Hall of Fame some day. But on Wednesday, only one team wanted him.

headline: Russia: Banker Blames Rival For Raid
text: The billionaire banker Aleksandr Y. Lebedev said Wednesday that he believed that a rival paid the police to carry out a raid on his Moscow bank headquarters “in hopes that suddenly our clients would run away.” In an interview with Kommersant FM, a radio station, Mr. Lebedev said that “some rich and corrupted” figure planned the raid on his company, in which masked men with automatic weapons swarmed into his office on Tuesday and searched for evidence in a criminal case. Mr. Lebedev, a former lieutenant colonel in the K.G.B., has dabbled in politics over the years and owns an opposition newspaper, Novaya Gazeta, that is harshly critical of the government. His remarks suggest, however, that he does not see the raid as having been politically motivated.

headline: Italy: Police Strike at Crime Families
text: The police seized assets worth $561 million and arrested 47 people, including Sicilian businessmen, politicians and public officials, in an overnight anti-Mafia raid on Wednesday in Sicily and in several other regions, including Lazio, Tuscany, Emilia Romagna and Friuli Venezia Giulia. The arrests were based on four years of investigations into three Mafia families in the Catania area, in eastern Sicily, a police statement said. Separately, the police arrested 50 people accused of having links to the Camorra, a Naples-area crime group, including four municipal police officers, and seized $84 million in assets.

headline: Decisive Gains at State Level Could Give Republicans a Boost for Years
text: The battle for the nation’s statehouses drew far less attention this year than the fight for Congress, but the Republican surge at the state level could have a longer-lasting impact than the one in Washington.

headline: Outside Groups on the Right Flexed Muscles
text: On the way to winning back the majority in the House on Tuesday, Republican challenger after Republican challenger overcame significant fund-raising gaps to beat their opponents, bolstered by a deluge of spending by independent groups.

headline: Boehner Becomes the Lead Character as Roles Are Reversed in the Capitol
text: WASHINGTON  The first sign of the new pecking order on Capitol Hill was the pack of cameramen jammed inside Representative John A. Boehner’s suite early Wednesday morning. As the Republican leader in a House run firmly by Democrats, Mr. Boehner had sometimes had trouble making his voice heard.

headline: Google and VivaKi Extend Partnership
text: On Thursday, Google and VivaKi, a digital agency that is part of the Publicis Groupe, will announce a two-year renewal of their 2008 partnership that will incorporate a new platform for buying video and mobile display ads in the United States and Europe. The platform, an extension of the VivaKi Nerve Center trading desk, or the Audience on Demand product, would allow companies to bid on mobile and video display advertising space in real time on ad exchanges, including Google’s DoubleClick exchange.

headline: Joseph Gavin, Who Helped Put First Man on Moon, Dies at 90

Gavin Jr., who rode herd over the immensely complex design, construction and testing of the first manned vehicle to land on the moon — a task that included anticipating 400 different landing surfaces, from ice to boulders to dust to potholes — died on Saturday in Amherst, Mass. He was 90.

headline: Japanese Runner Looks to Make Mark in New York

Fujiwara, whose 2:08:40 at the 2008 Tokyo Marathon is second fastest among active Japanese marathoners, will make his New York debut Sunday.

headline: News Quiz | November 4, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Restaurants in the Caribbean From World-Renowned Chefs
text: THE club sandwiches and shrimp cocktails that once defined resort cuisine are undergoing a transformation, as several high-profile chefs have opened Caribbean outposts of their top-shelf franchises. And though the chefs face notable challenges  thanks, in part, to geography and limited infrastructure  the ventures offer a way for them to infuse their brands with a tropical appeal.

headline: 36 Hours in St. Martin/St. Maarten
text: AMONG the accolades awarded to Caribbean islands (most beautiful beach, easiest on the budget, most relaxing), the award for most densely developed probably goes to St. Martin/St. Maarten — the half-Dutch, half-French island in the West Indies. That is not to say the island’s natural beauty is ruined. It remains a stunningly picturesque place with some of the Caribbean’s most arresting scenery (here it could win a prize, too). But all that development — boutique hotels, casinos, marinas, high-rise resorts — means visitors are never short on options. And thanks to a seemingly endless construction boom, those options keep multiplying.

headline: 6 Caribbean Beaches to See Before You Die
text: CARIBBEAN beach vacations sometimes get a bad rap. Too much monotony, the naysayers grumble. The only thing to do is lie on the beach, and they all look the same. But the Caribbean Sea — with islands that are flat, mountainous, tiny and vast — is specked with beaches that defy tropical conventions. There are beaches with gray sand, beaches with pink sand, those that seem to go on forever without any sign of human life, and others that hum with activity.

headline: My Own Private (Rental) Island, in the Bahamas
text: SO the idea was this: Six days with my wife on an uninhabited, mostly unpowered Bahamian island.

headline: 6 Action Adventures in the Caribbean
text: WHEN it comes to a Caribbean vacation, the idea of an extreme activity takes on a new meaning. Would it be taking a walk on the beach? Possibly. Eating lunch delivered poolside? Closer. A marathon towel-napping session? Definitely.

headline: In the Caribbean, a Wave of New Resorts Offers a Range of Enticements
text: A WAVE of new hotels and resorts usually open their doors during high season in the islands. And despite the economic stasis, this year is no exception. There is, however, one discernible difference: they’re highlighting experience along with escape. Whether high-end or mid-range, the most interesting newcomers are underscoring their location through cuisine, cultural events, design or programs.

headline: 7 Caribbean Resorts That Go All Out for Families
text: CLOSE your eyes and imagine a Caribbean paradise: throngs of baby sitters minding tots around the raucous swimming pool, chicken fingers on every menu and Big Bird plodding cheerfully along the beach, the white sand drifting across the Muppet’s yellow feathers.

headline: Gagosian Opens First Paris Gallery
text: Larry Gagosian started his career in the early 1970s by selling posters on the U.C.L.A. campus. Soon after, he moved onto reselling artworks — a trade he was so good at he was soon nicknamed “Go Go.” Today, he is one of the world’s best known gallerists, with nine branded spaces, including one in Athens and two in London, that specialize in contemporary artists ranging from Pablo Picasso to Damien Hirst and Cindy Sherman.

headline: Credit Suisse Seeks to Liquidate Tamarack Resort

text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm managed by Henry Kravis and George Roberts, is set to raise more than $2.5 billion for new funds in the second half of this year, as firms seize on a rebound in deals to attract investor cash, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Do Employees Still Feel Lucky to Have Jobs?
text: It has now been almost three years since the economy entered the Great Recession and two years since it took the nosedive in the fall of 2008. Though the economists say the recession was over months ago, the small-business owners I talk to have not seen sales rebound to where they were. Some businesses haven’t rebounded at all. I have been in business for more than 30 years, and I have never seen anything like this. It’s like a normal recession but with an extra year or two thrown in. Yes, things have stabilized, and in some cases they have gotten better. On the human side, things are precarious.
