headline: The Other Oil Cleanup
text: It was a little past 9 on a scorching July morning in South Texas, and Tony Buzbee was gunning down the Gulf Freeway outside Houston in his cherry red Ferrari 612 Scaglietti (license plate BUZB 8) on his way to a court hearing in Galveston. Buzbee’s right hand was occupied with one of his ever-present La Gloria Cubana cigars, while his left stayed in intermittent contact with the wheel as he recounted how he destroyed an insurance company’s expert witness in a recent deposition. So total was the demolition, in Buzbee’s telling, that the witness retired on the spot from any future trial work. “I basically made him admit that his entire compensation model was” fouled up, Buzbee said with undisguised relish, as well as the blunt profanity that is a hallmark of his conversations.

headline: Swiss Re Repays Buffett’s $3 Billion Loan

headline: Small Wonder | The Jambox
text: A few years ago, when the San Francisco company Aliph released the Jawbone — a pretty little nugget of a Bluetooth headset that offers superior “noise assassin” technology — I wasn’t quite sure what to make of it. It was certainly an attractive piece of design. Early models sported a super-techy grill designed by the company’s chief creative officer, Yves Béhar, and later models included one that was just the shade of red to match my hair. But I could never get past the fact that I didn’t really mind talking on a phone, no matter how many bells and whistles the Jawbone could offer.

headline: Oscar Catches Up With Uncle Eli
text: “THERE’S something I want to show you,” Eli Wallach says, ushering me into his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. On this occasion what he has in mind is a drawing by Al Hirschfeld, one of two that hang prominently in the front hall: “That’s Annie and me, on our 50th anniversary.” Anyone with a memory of New York theater  or, for that matter, of the Sunday Arts & Leisure section of this newspaper  extending back a few decades would surely recognize Hirschfeld’s affectionate likeness of Mr. Wallach and Anne Jackson, his frequent co-star and also his wife of 62 years. Never one to miss a cue, the real-life Ms. Jackson steps forward to accept a modest bouquet of purple irises, rewarding the bearer with kisses and a version of the incandescent smile so brilliantly captured and caricatured by Hirschfeld’s pen.

headline: Markets at 2-Year High a Day After Fed Decision
text: Stocks surged Thursday as the markets responded positively to the Federal Reserve’s decision to buy more government securities to stimulate the economy.

headline: Another Sign of Disinflation
text: The Labor Department released its quarterly productivity report this morning, and it showed that the labor costs that went into a unit of production fell slightly this summer. That’s another sign that the economy is a long way from any kind of worrisome inflation, as I argued in a column today.

headline: Eye-Popping
text: The artist Tauba Auerbach deals with perception and illusion, finding moments of ambiguity between two dimensions and three. (Think of her trompe l’oeil ‘‘folded’’ canvases, at this year’s Whitney Biennial.) Which is why, presumably, she fell so hard for pop-up books. ‘‘When a page closes, you see an object kind of smush, and in that moment, it’s in a liminal state not unlike the Fold paintings,’’ she says. Auerbach began collecting classic pop-ups like ‘‘Alphabeta Concertina’’ and ‘‘Andy Warhol’s Index (Book)’’ last year, and also began the process of making her own. To create ‘‘[2,3]’’ — which is being introduced this weekend by Printed Matter at the NY Art Book Fair — she spent months teaching herself how to construct complex geometric shapes from strips of paper, then several more creating templates and instructional videos so that the printer could reproduce them. Among the pieces are ‘‘Cubearc’’ (above), a delicate Möbius-like curl and ‘‘Ziggurat’’: 10 nested tiers that telescope out to 18 inches high. ‘‘I tried things that someone who had experience probably would have shied away from,’’ says Auerbach, who insists that her goal ‘‘wasn’t to make the most complicated thing possible. It was just to make something beautiful and uncanny happen.’’

text: Elderly Americans are more likely to have medical problems than elderly Britons, but once they turn 70, older Americans live longer, international researchers said Thursday.

headline: CT Scans Cut Lung Cancer Deaths, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON  Annual CT scans of current and former heavy smokers reduced their risk of death from lung cancer by 20 percent, a huge government-financed study has found. Even more surprising, the scans seem to reduce the risks of death from other causes as well, suggesting that the scans could be catching other illnesses.

headline: Spaghetti, the No. 8 and Green Underwear: Rituals to Run With

She knows that her best friend’s father has just lit a candle — timed precisely for her start of the New York City Marathon — at St. Christopher’s Church in Baldwin, N.Y., just as he does for every marathon she runs.

headline: Abroad, Fear That Midterm Result May Turn U.S. Inward
text: PARIS  Just two years ago, the election of President Obama resonated far beyond American shores, inspiring euphoric assessments in Europe in particular that American politics had embarked on new and enduring change after years of the Bush administration. It took the midterm elections this week to finally persuade some among Mr. Obama’s global fan club to think otherwise.

headline: Obama Invites Republican Leaders to Dinner
text: In the aftermath of this week’s electoral “shellacking,” President Obama on Thursday invited Congressional leaders to literally break bread later this month at a dinner at the White House as he tries to adjust to a new political order with Republicans ascendant.

Many parents remain reluctant to talk about how much money they plan to leave their children, and that can lead to conflict among siblings and hurt feelings long after the parents are gone.

headline: ‘Life’
text: I think the first record I bought was Little Richard’s “Long Tall Sally.” Fantastic record, even to this day. Good records just get better with age. But the one that really turned me on, like an explosion one night, listening to Radio Luxembourg on my little radio when I was supposed to be in bed and asleep, was “Heartbreak Hotel.” That was the stunner. I’d never heard it before, or anything like it. I’d never heard of Elvis before. It was almost as if I’d been waiting for it to happen. When I woke up the next day I was a different guy. Suddenly I was getting overwhelmed: Buddy Holly, Eddie Cochran, Little Richard, Fats. Radio Luxembourg was notoriously difficult to keep on station. I had a little aerial and walked round the room, holding the radio up to my ear and twisting the aerial. Trying to keep it down because I’d wake Mum and Dad up. If I could get the signal right, I could take the radio under the blankets on the bed and keep the aerial outside and twist it there. I’m supposed to be asleep; I’m supposed to be going to school in the morning. Loads of ads for James Walker, the jewelers “in every high street,” and the Irish sweepstakes, with which Radio Lux had some deal. The signal was perfect for the ads, “and now we have Fats Domino, ‘Blueberry Hill,’” and [expletive], then it would fade.

headline: Stray Cat Blues
text: He’s been a global avatar of wish fulfillment for over four decades and managed to eke more waking hours out of a 24-hour day than perhaps any other creature alive (thanks, Merck cocaine and amphetamines!). As Keith puts it: “For many years I slept, on average, twice a week. This means that I have been conscious for at least three lifetimes.”

headline: Asked and Answered | Anton Corbijn
text: After directing the indie Joy Division biopic “Control” and the George Clooney thriller “The American,” as well as scores of music videos for groups like Nirvana, U2 and Depeche Mode, Anton Corbijn is back to where it all began for him: portraiture. No matter the strata of their celebrity, Corbijn manages to draw out something as yet undiscovered from his subjects. “Inwards and Onwards,” on view at Stellan Holm Gallery until Dec. 15, is a small selection of Corbijn’s black-and-white portraits of the creative people whose orbits have intersected his own. Rockers like Tom Waits and Anthony Kiedis mingle with painters such as Richard Prince and Lucian Freud. Corbijn holds them all in equal regard.

headline: Cuba Dance Notebook: A Thrill for Young Fans

headline: 2010 SEMA Show: From Hot Rods to Exotics to Hybrids
text: The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show in Las Vegas is an opportunity for companies selling aftermarket automotive accessories to let their imaginations run wild. Refinish a Rolls-Royce in black primer? Hot-rod a hybrid? Is one engine enough? Why not two? There are no limits. Nearly one million square feet of exhibit space inside the Las Vegas Convention Center is packed with one display after another, and aisles that seem to stretch for miles; what there is no room for inside spills out into the parking lots, to the nearby Sands Convention Center, and even various casinos.

headline: Making Mortgage Lending a Family Affair

headline: Renée Zellweger Selling Upper East Side Apartments

headline: Guiding a Child to Financial Independence

So when Stephanie decided to move back home after graduating from Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., her mother was delighted. “We didn’t get to spend that much time with her when she was on the East Coast, so it was the best thing ever,” she said.

Relocation is a frequent suggestion, especially with fans in Winnipeg and Quebec City clamoring for clubs to call their own again.

headline: How We Learned to Recycle
text: Garbage shame is such a normal part of today’s parental discourse (“No, you can’t have an AquaPod! It’s a waste of packaging!”) that most of us don’t think about it anymore. Landfills leak climate-changing methane. Plastic water bottles stretch to the moon and back.

headline: Reading Dogs and Untrained Boys
text: It is generally agreed that humor is subjective. Looking across the recent crop of picture books that specialize in gently absurd comedy, one can imagine grown-ups wondering if kids will get the joke. But that would underestimate even very young children’s ability to appreciate the incongruous, the nonsensical, the flat-out eccentric.

headline: The Caucus
text: After losing badly in the 2008 elections, Republicans began a blue-print of the strategy that led to this week's House takeover.

headline: Former Hevesi Aide Morris Settles Charges
text: From Danny Hakim at City Room:

headline: Oil and Gas Bribery Case Settled for $236 Million
text: WASHINGTON  Six oil and gas service companies and a prominent freight-forwarding company agreed to pay about $236 million in criminal and civil penalties in one of the largest corporate bribery cases ever to focus on a single industry, federal authorities said Thursday.

headline: Just Over the Page, a Parallel Universe
text: For years a gulf in the book world has been widening. The digital age has brought about a separation between a book’s story and its platform, its medium of delivery. The same story can now make its way to the reader by iPod, iPad or iPhone; by Kindle, Nook or Sony Reader; by laptop or desktop; or of course, by the old-fashioned printed page. As the options increase, the platform itself becomes more transparent and, some would argue, irrelevant. Today’s reader has grown so used to encountering pages of different shapes, sizes and technological eras that he or she hardly notices the page itself anymore.

headline: Now I’ve Said My ABCs, Tell Me What My Social Values Should Be
text: Sorry, “Sesame Street” and “Dora the Explorer.” Moms want preschool TV to be more about teaching children social skills and less about pushing clear academic goals — at least that’s what Disney executives say new internal research indicates.

headline: The Corner of Bitter and Sweet
text: It’s not just any big red lollipop. It’s the biggest, sweetest treat in the first take-home goodie bag from the first birthday party Rubina has ever attended. That makes it a treasure to have and hold as long as possible — well, overnight in the fridge, anyway, for enjoying the next morning, after a night of happy dreams.

headline: Theater Talkback: When Shabby Shines
text: “Gatz,” the marathon reading of “The Great Gatsby” now at the Public Theater, is set inside a dowdy office where the digital age doesn’t seem to have dawned. Watching this show (when it played at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.) made me appreciate how much beauty there can be in places were life feels most vacant: abandoned buildings, parking lots, empty classrooms, edge-of-town restaurants, dowdy motel rooms.

headline: Apple Invites Developers to Submit Mac Apps
text: Developers who have created applications for Apple products,  including the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch, began receiving e-mail invitations on Wednesday to submit applications to the coming Mac App Store.

headline: Harrison Is Fined Another $20,000
text: James Harrison has said he still doesn’t know what he could have done differently on his hit to a Cleveland receiver three weeks ago that drew a $75,000 fine from the N.F.L. and became one of the prime examples in the league’s crackdown on hits to the head.

headline: In Connecticut, Two Men Prepare to Be Governor
text: Thursday was the first full day of work for the transition team of Dannel P. Malloy, the Democrat who was certain he was the winner in the race for governor of Connecticut.

headline: When a City Feels Like Home
text: If you’re reading this sandwiched between a stroller and a student’s overstuffed backpack on a New York City subway, consider the big picture: You’re traveling along hundreds of miles of track, a triumph of awe-inspiring urban planning. And despite the scale of it all, you’ve no doubt found a way to appreciate more intimate aspects of city life — a favorite coffee shop, a picnic spot, a shared interest with an eccentric neighbor (or perhaps that’s you). While the big plan allowed the city to grow, the warmth of its communities is what make it a home. Through these different lenses, three new picture books celebrate city life.

headline: A Beautiful Relationship
text: Bink is cheerful, fearless and messy. Gollie is skinny, precise and superior. Bink is heart and Gollie is head. Of such contrasts is the best-friend relationship forged. In this three-chapter picture book, written in dialogue, Gollie seems to call the shots — at first. She’s taller. She’s worked on her vocabulary: “Here I am where none but a few have ventured. What an extraordinary accomplishment.” She makes pronouncements: “I must inform you that you are giving a home to a truly unremarkable fish.”

headline: Tracking a Needle in a Haystack of 45,000
text: For years, fans at the New York City Marathon have waited hopefully on the city’s streets for their friends and family to run past on their 26.2-mile journey. With little or no idea where the runners are on the course, spectators are left to watch the kaleidoscope of humanity surge by, from the gazellelike leaders to the weekend warriors struggling to reach the finish line.

headline: September Rally Pushes Hedge Fund to Close
text: A relatively new hedge fund announced its own death knell this week, citing turbulent conditions and an unfortunate bet against the market for the decision to shutter the firm, which managed nearly $300 million in assets at its peak.

headline: App Smart Extra: Password-Protecting Photos
text: If you’ve ever worried about someone stealing your logins and passwords, this week’s App Smart column offers some solace, in the form of secure password keepers.

headline: Theater Listings: Nov. 5 — 11
text: Theater

headline: A Vegan Chef Dishes Up Thanksgiving
text: The Los Angeles chef Chloe Coscarelli is best known for winning the Food Network’s “Cupcake Wars” with her dairy- and egg-free cupcake recipes. But Ms. Coscarelli, a recent graduate of the University of California, Berkeley, and the Natural Gourmet Institute in New York City, also has a passion for vegan savory foods, particularly at Thanksgiving.

headline: Rare Winner for Southern Democrats
text: ALBANY, Ga.  In an election cycle with few success stories for Democrats, the unlikely re-election of Representative Sanford D. Bishop Jr., 63, in Georgia’s Second District, has lifted the spirits of demoralized liberal Southern Democrats.

headline: Fear Darkens Czech Uranium Mining Town
text: STRAZ POD RALSKEM, CZECH REPUBLIC — The national uranium company in the Czech Republic, Diamo, has been working for years to keep toxic waste left by decades of uranium mining from poisoning some of the country’s largest underground stocks of fresh water or reaching the Elbe River.

headline: NBC Cancels ‘Undercovers’
text: NBC is ending the run of what was once one its most promising new series of the season with the decision that it will not order any more new episodes of the series “Undercovers.”

headline: Mental Health Days From School
text: On Monday, Jody Becker walked her girls to school. (The same school she wrote about here on Motherlode.) Her kindergartener was cheerful, but her second grader was dragging after a night of trick or treating. By the time they reached the front door, the older girl was saying she felt sick, so Becker detoured over to the school nurse and signed her daughter out for the day.

headline: First Look | Linda Farrow Luxe
text: The British designer Linda Farrow was one of the first to see the vision thing as a fashion thing — she started her namesake eyewear line back in 1970. Over the years, Farrow’s glasses have provided chic cover for everyone from Yoko Ono to Kanye West. Now, Linda Farrow Luxe is introducing a special collection of 50 frames that includes both updated styles from the archives and new designs curated by Simon Jablon, Farrow’s son and the managing director of the brand. “Every year we push the collection in design and technicalities but still have the same essence,” Jablon says. Take, for example, the large Jackie O. cat-eye frames covered in cream, taupe, gray, aubergine or black snake. The retro style is modeled above by the actress Nathalie Love, who appears — alongside her best friend, the artist Louis Eisner — in a campaign by the photographer Tim Barber that is, well, worthy of framing.

headline: All You Need to Know About the Workouts
text: Bruno De Julio has been a workout analyst and thoroughbred owner for the past 20 years. He is the author of “Bruno on Workouts: Exposing the Mystery” and can be found daily at Racing With Bruno and Grade One Racing.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | The Brecht Forum
text: At the Brecht Forum, a community center on West Street, communists (and others) gather daily for activities serious and entertaining, like a Marxist version of Monopoly.

headline: Where Marxists Pontificate, and Play
text: IF communists have a reputation for anything, it is seriousness. (And if you have seen old photos of Karl Marx, you know that he did not smile much.) But at the Brecht Forum, a community center on West Street where revolutionaries and radicals gather daily to ponder and to pontificate, they also play. (Smiles abound.)

headline: High-Risk Insurance Pools Are Attracting Few
text: After the health care law passed, concerns emerged immediately that a $5 billion appropriation would not be nearly enough to cover the hordes expected to enroll in a network of new insurance pools for people with pre-existing conditions. The government’s health care actuary projected that hundreds of thousands of otherwise uninsurable people would rush to gain coverage this year, and that the money would be exhausted by 2012.

headline: Ireland Plans More Budget Cuts to Reassure Bond Investors
text: The Irish government, in its latest step to salvage its fiscal credibility, said on Thursday that it would step up its program to cut the deficit by proposing 6 billion euros ($8.5 billion) in savings for its 2011 budget.

headline: No Comment, Please
text: Over the years, some of my husband’s business clients have become friends. Recently, one of them left his wife of 20 years, a dear friend, only to take up with another woman in a whirlwind, post-every-feeling-on-Facebook, talk-about-your-great-sex-life kind of affair. My husband doesn’t want to offend his client, but may I nudge him toward more modesty, at least until he starts divorce proceedings?

headline: With Conan on the Way, Leno a Late-Night Loser to Letterman

headline: The Other Mendelssohn Finds a New Champion
text: Fanny Mendelssohn, a gifted pianist, composer and conductor who was overshadowed in her lifetime by her famous younger brother, Felix, is primarily remembered today for her short piano pieces and songs. But her catalog of almost 500 works also includes three sacred cantatas; “Das Jahr,” a large-scale piano work; and concert arias.

headline: Every Little Horse He Names Is Magic (Or Just About)
text: Like Jerry Moss, Sting is no stranger to success. Sting achieved superstardom as the frontman of the rock trio, The Police, on Moss’s A&M Records label. So perhaps it seems fitting that the most decorated racehorse that Moss has ever owned is named after the band’s third album, Zenyattà Mondatta.

headline: Amok on the Road to Daddydom
text: Early in “Due Date” the odd-couple main characters, Peter and Ethan, visit a pot dealer. As Ethan (Zach Galifianakis) checks out the bud, his reluctant companion, Peter (Robert Downey Jr.), waits in the living room with the dealer’s two children. Peter has been kicked off a plane and forced into a car with Ethan, and he isn’t happy. He swats away the children’s questions and mocks the girl, and her brother, who looks about 9, bounces a toy off Peter’s head in seeming retaliation. One thing leads to another, and Peter punches the boy in the stomach so hard that the child doubles over, which certainly gives the expression “belly laugh” new meaning.

headline: Touch of Croatia in Judith’s Story
text: Spirituality, in its myriad guises, is the express concern of the White Light Festival, a novel multidisciplinary series now running at Lincoln Center. Yet even positioned amid masterworks by Bach and Brahms, an electronic installation inspired by Renaissance church music and a dance derived from martial arts, “Judith,” a semistaged dramatization of a 16th-century epic on a biblical theme, made for a curious fit. Katarina Livljanic, a Croatian singer and musicologist, presented the work’s New York premiere with members of the Ensemble Dialogos at the Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday evening.

headline: Ear-Catching, Modern Madrigals for String Quartet
text: It says a lot for Stephen Hartke’s “Night Songs for a Desert Flower” (2009) that when the Brentano String Quartet performed the work alongside quartets by Haydn and Beethoven at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, it seemed fully a part of the continuum: a modern extension of the musical language those composers spoke and as eloquent in its way as the music of its celebrated predecessors.

headline: On His Own, Still Summoning the Drama
text: Sam Newsome compresses a lot of energy into the sound of his soprano saxophone, but he isn’t out to overwhelm you with it. He’s a clear-headed improviser, adept with space and tension. He has an outsize command of the horn, especially in the realm of extended technique: split-tone multiphonics, slap-tongue articulation, seamless circular breathing. What you notice most in his playing, though, is the tight drama of unfolding logic.

headline: The Fake Scandals Begin
text: One of the things those of us who remember the 90s really don’t miss is the parade of fake scandals — the endless investigations into alleged White House misdeeds (140 hours of sworn testimony into allegations that the Clintons had misused their Christmas card list).

headline: Yankees to Play Santa, for a Price
text: The Yankees hope to ring in the Christmas season with their fans this year. For the first time, the team is hosting a “Breakfast With Santa” on the mornings of Dec. 4 and 5 at the Hard Rock Cafe at Yankee Stadium.

text: Anyone who’s spent time writing for the Web knows the basic rule: Keep it short. Attention spans, we are told, are collapsing faster than pig houses on Angry Birds. At this rate, municipalities won’t just fluoridate their city water supply, they’ll have to Ritalinize it as well.

text: Generations of New York actors have derived steady work and income from daytime serials but that work is disappearing as longtime soaps end.

headline: The Blissed-Out Rhythms of the Young and in Love
text: Visually distinctive and aurally delightful, “Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench” has style to burn. A soulful black-and-white commentary on love, art and their competing demands, this Boston-based musical from Damien Chazelle floats on a wave of spontaneity and charm.

headline: New York’s Rare Family Compounds
text: RESTORATION work is under way on the facade of the town house at 16 East 84th Street, one of a neo-Georgian triplet of dwellings built in 1901 by the socially prominent King family.

headline: Forest Gems
text: A look at some of the forest areas in four New York City boroughs.

headline: China: New Subway Line Planned for Beijing
text: Trains on the longest subway line in China will make a trial run before the end of the year, traveling a 30-mile route between southwest and northwest Beijing, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Thursday. The route connects an existing line with a new 14-mile extension. City officials say they hope the new line will help alleviate clogged roads. In recent months, Beijing residents have complained that traffic in and around the city has been worse than anytime in years. A recent traffic jam from outside Beijing toward Inner Mongolia lasted for 10 days and drew international attention. Xinhua reported that Beijing has four million cars on the roads, and the city is one of the most congested in the world. Beijing plans to open four other new lines by the end of 2010.

headline: Potholes Along the Laugh Track
text: WHAT glories await a brave, wisecracking upstart who decides to pursue a career in stand-up comedy? If you can distinguish yourself at the microphone, maybe you’ll earn your own headlining tour, movie roles or a television show, or a spot on the lineup of the New York Comedy Festival, the annual celebration of setups and punch lines that started on Wednesday and runs through Sunday. But prepare for a few rites of passage: antagonistic crowds, unglamorous performance spaces, living out of a suitcase while crisscrossing the country from club to club. And don’t expect any of that to change, even after you’ve become a household name.

headline: Nbc To Cancel ‘Undercovers’
text: NBC is ending the run of what was once one of its most promising new series of the season with the decision that it will not order any more episodes of “Undercovers.” The show had been highly anticipated because it came from the executive producer J. J. Abrams of “Lost” and it had kicked off a bidding war among the networks last year when Mr. Abrams pitched the idea. The show, about two spectacular-looking undercover agents who also happen to be a married couple running a high-end catering business, was also notable because its stars were black. Scheduled on Wednesdays at 8 p.m., the show never took off in the ratings, and the numbers that arrived Thursday for the previous night revealed it had hit a new low. Only about 5.8 million viewers tuned in. NBC said it would probably still broadcast the six remaining episodes that have been produced.

headline: Miró’s Odd Homage to Dutch Masters
text: Ever the contrarian, the Catalan painter Joan Miró rebelled by turning to the old masters. And not just any old masters: he started with the homely genre scenes of Jan Steen and Hendrick Sorgh, with their stock characters of misbehaving maids, soused guests and impish children. In the Metropolitan Museum’s “Miró: The Dutch Interiors,” these presences become floating, Surrealist apparitions  unmoored and ambiguous but still mischievous.

headline: I Feel Bad About My Memory
text: Nora Ephron worries about a failing memory in the title piece of “I Remember Nothing,” her inviting new collection of essays. But even her most amnesiac readers still remember “I Feel Bad About My Neck,” the 2006 collection that this new book closely resembles. That resemblance is helpful in some ways and alarming in others.

headline: Generating Inflation Expectations
text: A number of readers have asked how the Fed can change inflation expectations when it has little or no current traction — that is, what can the Fed actually do?

headline: The God-Science Shouting Match: A Response
text: In reading the nearly 700 reader responses to my Oct. 17 essay for The Stone, (“Morals Without God?“) I notice how many readers are relieved to see that there are shades of gray when it comes to the question whether morality requires God. I believe that such a discussion needs to revolve around both the distant past, in which religion likely played little or no role if we go back far enough, and modern times, in which it is hard to disentangle morality and religion. The latter point seemed obvious to me, yet proved controversial. Even though 90 percent of my text questions the religious origins of human morality, and wonders if we need a God to be good, it is the other 10 percent — in which I tentatively assign a role to religion — that drew most ire. Atheists, it seems (at least those who responded here) don’t like any less than 100 percent agreement with their position.To have a productive debate, religion needs to recognize the power of the scientific method and the truths it has revealed, but its opponents need to recognize that one cannot simply dismiss a social phenomenon found in every major society. If humans are inherently religious, or at least show rituals related to the supernatural, there is a big question to be answered. The issue is not whether or not God exists — which I find to be a monumentally uninteresting question defined, as it is, by the narrow parameters of monotheism — but why humans universally feel the need for supernatural entities. Is this just to stay socially connected or does it also underpin morality? And if so, what will happen to morality in its absence?

headline: The Really Strange Bedfellows That New York Politics Made
text: If you have followed the strange tale of Eliot Spitzer — and who hasn’t these days, what with his running a vigorous rehabilitation campaign — you get the sense that the former governor of New York must have read his share of Greek classics. In Alex Gibney’s new documentary, “Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,” Mr. Spitzer says that hubris played a role in his stumble. Like Peter Elkind’s recent book, “Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,” the movie quotes from a 2005 speech in which Mr. Spitzer jokingly describes a T-shirt that he was given with “Hubris is terminal” on it. After being exposed, Mr. Spitzer told an aide, “Welcome to a Greek tragedy.”

headline: Near Vukovar, Serbia’s President Apologizes
text: Serbia’s president, Boris Tadic, crossed the Danube on Thursday to meet his Croatian counterpart, Ivo Josipovic, and together the two men visited memorials to both Serb and Croat prisoners and civilians who were executed during the fierce battle for control of the city of Vukovar nearly two decades ago.

headline: A Social Media Firestorm About Apple Pies
text: The blogosphere is abuzz this afternoon with a story about Monica Gaudio, a writer who found an article she wrote in 2005 about the evolution of English apple pie recipes in a food magazine called Cooks Source. The issue? Ms. Gaudio said she had never been contacted by the publication about using her article.  Thanks to the Internet, the debate has been playing out on the likes of  Twitter and Facebook and the author’s own LiveJournal page, where Ms. Gaudio wrote about how she tried contacting the publication after a friend told her he had seen her article in it. According to the post, Ms. Gaudio contacted Judith Griggs, the magazine’s editor, and asked for the following:

headline: Is It Really a Pension? It’s a Problem
text: Is Social Security a pension plan?

headline: Stay Tuned for Soap Stars’ Next Acts
text: IF people at the Knitting Factory recognized Jake Silbermann’s cornflower-blue eyes last month, they were too cool to let on. The handsome Mr. Silbermann, looking considerably more pulled together in a sport coat and sweater combo than most of the 20-somethings attending the Royal Flush film festival at this Brooklyn club, took questions from the small audience following a screening of his short film “Stuffer.”

headline: New York’s Rare Family Compounds
text: Family compounds were always few and far between in New York City. But traces of some of the old enclaves can still be seen.

headline: New Policy on Safeguarding Information
text: President Obama on Thursday rolled back a proliferating array of markings by which federal agencies have kept unclassified information from the public, issuing an executive order intended to create a uniform way of handling such information.

headline: Marital Strife and C.I.A. Obligations
text: “Fair Game,” directed by Doug Liman from a screenplay by the brothers Jez and John-Henry Butterworth, is partly, maybe even primarily, the portrait of a modern marriage under stress.

headline: The Rich, Detailed Fullness Found in Empty
text: The Buddhist influence on art of the past 50 years is, like much else in the Buddhist worldview, immeasurable. “Grain of Emptiness: Buddhism-Inspired Contemporary Art,” at the Rubin Museum of Art, wisely doesn’t attempt such a survey. Instead it offers up an eclectic, not-the-usual-suspects group of five artists: Sanford Biggers, Theaster Gates, Atta Kim, Wolfgang Laib and Charmion von Wiegand.

headline: Seeping Out of Houston, Slowly
text: THROUGHOUT the 1990s, DJ Screw pioneered hip-hop’s slide into the psychedelic. From his base on Houston’s south side, his method of slowing and manipulating records, a style that came to be known aƒs chopped and screwed — or just screw music — took rap to a state of primordial ooze. His music was woozy and immersive, elastic and gummy, and also an apt companion to the prescription-grade cough syrup that was one of the city’s favored narcotics. He was the figurehead for the style up until he died, from an overdose of codeine in combination with other drugs, in 2000.

headline: Democrat Wins Illinois Governor Race
text: CHICAGO – Gov. Patrick J. Quinn was declared the winner of the race for governor of Illinois by The Associated Press this afternoon.

headline: Is Microsoft’s Xbox Kinect Racist? No.
text: On Wednesday night, the gaming site GameSpot posted an article raising the question of whether Microsoft’s new Xbox Kinect — the facial and body-recognition system that allows you to play video games by simply moving your body, no controller required — had difficulty recognizing faces with dark skin tones.

headline: What Springsteen Kept to Himself

headline: Meager Means, Rich Imagination
text: The self-taught artist Eugene Von Bruenchenhein was a slight man of meager means. Born in Marinette, Wis., in 1910, the son of a sign painter and shopkeeper, he never finished high school, and once the family moved to Milwaukee, lived most of his life in a small house built by his father. He was too short to serve in the Army during World War II. He worked in a flower shop and then a bakery, and after health problems forced an early retirement in 1959, when he was 49, he got by on a Social Security check of $220 a month until his death in 1983.

headline: Some Venti Tunes to Go With That Latte
text: TIMOTHY JONES would blush at the notion, but he’s one of the quiet shapers of American culture.

headline: Protracted Wait for G.M. Payback
text: Taxpayers will have to wait a while to reclaim the money invested to keep General Motors out of the scrapyard. The carmaker is running far more smoothly after declaring bankruptcy last year: it earned as much as $2.1 billion in the three months to September, its third straight quarter of profits. But the terms of G.M.’s coming share sale show that, once public, the stock will have to as much as double before its biggest shareholder, the United States government, gets close to breaking even.

headline: A Powerful Chorus Harmonizing ‘Dark Phrases of Womanhood’
text: Tyler Perry has been led out to critical slaughter so many times, it might seem a wonder that he continues to make movies. Except that Mr. Perry addresses his movies to black audiences and, until recently, has shown relatively little interest in crossing over. His enormous commercial success with a mainly black audience and the often ferociously hostile reviews from mostly white critics might seem symptomatic of an insurmountable racial divide. Black people love him and white people don’t get him, and that sort of thing, which might be somewhat true but ignores that another important dividing line runs along taste and not color.

headline: A Draftsman Who Turned More and More to Dynamism
text: Degas was an end and a beginning, a bridge between the neo-classicism of his teacher’s teacher, Ingres, and the painting of modern life by that scruffy band of outsiders known as the Impressionists. He was a draftsman of preternatural gifts, the last major artist in a line going back to Giotto to make exacting delineation of the real world a central drive. But in his acute attention to empirical experience, stripped bare of the academic apparatus of myth, historicism and moralizing, he also was a quintessentially modern man.

headline: Week 9 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 9. They also answered reader questions earlier this week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Once on Sleepy Beat, Regulator Is Suddenly Busy
text: Cotton, sugar, silver, wheat: in investment circles, commodities like these are hot.

headline: Louisiana Rethinks Its Sand Berms
text: In a story in late October, I reported on the continuing effort by Louisiana to build sand berms in the Gulf of Mexico to block and capture oil from the BP spill. Back in June, BP ponied up $360 million for the berms, of which roughly $140 million was left.

headline: In New York City Parks, a Fall-Color Tour
text: STANDING atop the breezy peak of Moses Mountain on a recent afternoon, I was struck by the juxtaposition of two facts: One, all I could see in any direction was a dense canopy of red maple, oak and hickory treetops, the leaves revealing autumn’s first golden blush. Two, I was in Staten Island.

headline: Paradise or Prison?
text: David Carr unplugs for six days on Little Deadman's Cay.

headline: Politics and Baseball: Where the Wild Things Are
text: What a week in fashion it was, and I’m not even talking about the long drum roll up to the Lanvin sale at H & M. Rather, I refer to the exuberant displays of hair and fashion we saw in politics and baseball.

headline: Breathe In, Breathe Out, Fall in Love
text: IN the front hall of the Victorian house was a laminated sign that said “Shoes,” and underneath it a row of Birkenstocks and Danskos stretched along the wall. I could hear voices coming from the meditation hall upstairs, so I figured people were already finding their seats. I sat down and pulled off my motorcycle boots, wishing every object had its own little sign. If only my ex-boyfriend had worn a sign the night before that said “ex-boyfriend,” I would not have slept with him.

headline: Harebrained Plans by Half-Wits
text: Terrorism is stupid. Terrorists are stupid. It seems to me that these truths have not been sufficiently acknowledged, especially by movies, which tend to imagine terrorists as the diabolically clever authors of complicated conspiracies. But surely the recent historical record suggests that for every extremist mastermind scheming in a cave somewhere, there are innumerable stooges, fools and copycats, their dreams of glory tethered to half-baked ideas and harebrained plots. Incompetence married to zeal is hardly benign — dumb people have done their share of damage in the world — but it can nonetheless be funny.

headline: Sacrificing Some Star Power to Reinvent the Patriot Way
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Tom Brady and Deion Branch sit next to each other in the New England locker room, a throwback to a time when Brady’s hair was more buzz cut than Bieber and the Patriots were the N.F.L.’s darlings instead of its dominators.

headline: All the President’s Memories
text: We seem to be witnessing a renaissance in protests — if that’s the word for it — against political books. When Sarah Palin went on a bus tour last fall to promote “Going Rogue,” a man at the Mall of America threw tomatoes at her. When Tony Blair appeared in Dublin to promote his memoir, “A Journey,” people threw eggs and shoes. During Karl Rove’s recent tour in support of “Courage and Consequence,” a handcuff-carrying activist tried to arrest him for war crimes — twice. Thank goodness George W. Bush, whose “Decision Points” hits stores on Nov. 9, already comes with a Secret Service detail.

headline: ‘Porgy and Bess’ Will Be Reincarnated — As a Musical
text: Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer-Prize winning playwright of “Topdog/Underdog,” and Diedre Murray, the musician and composer, are developing a new version of “Porgy and Bess” that features rearrangements of George Gershwin‘s famed score and plays down its roots as an opera.

headline: Two Say Pelosi Should Step Aside as Leader
text: With Speaker Nancy Pelosi still deliberating about her future, some House Democrats are not waiting to make their own feelings known.

headline: 'The Dutch Interiors'
text: A look at how Joan Miró transposed some of Steen and Sorgh’s figures into his own works.

headline: A Stoic Marine Undone by Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell
text: You could bounce quarters off the taut abdominals of Alexandra Everett (Dreya Weber), the blond, self-assured protagonist of Ned Farr’s film “A Marine Story.” A Marine major who has served four deployments in Iraq, Alexandra is first seen returning to her hometown in the California desert in the summer of 2008 and briskly walking the 10 miles from the train station to the house where she grew up.

headline: Who Got the Most Bang for Their Bucks?
text: After all the talk about the impact of independent groups on this year’s midterm elections, the debate over at least one important question can now begin in earnest: Which groups were the most effective?

headline: Animated Ambiguity, Featuring a Big Head
text: Michael Jackson’s “Bad,” blasted near the end of “Megamind,” the witty 3-D animated deconstruction of superhero movies from DreamWorks Animation, encapsulates the paradoxes of a story in which evil morphs into good and vice versa. There was always something innately silly in Jackson’s wispy-voiced, childlike affectation of macho ferocity. My first reaction to a singer whose clout suggested a crooked finger more than a clenched fist was, “Oh, come off it, little boy.”

headline: Accommodations Angst
text: EXTRA time. More breaks. A small, quiet room. Seeking such accommodations on entrance exams can be a journey of angst for students with learning disabilities and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. A new set of federal regulations, published in September and effective in March, could smooth the path.

headline: Special Section on the Sandwich Generation
text: Aging parents run short on money just at the time that they need specialized care. Adult children fail to launch and move back home with their parents. And people in their 40s, 50s and 60s are stuck in the middle, supporting the older and younger generations amid their own uncertainty about continued employment.

headline: Wealthy and Worried, India Is Rich Arms Market
text: A big item on President Obama’s India to-do list this weekend is securing a $5 billion deal for Boeing to sell 10 of its C-17 cargo planes.

headline: A Game’s Big Players
text: “Jews and Baseball: An American Love Story” chronologically name-checks history’s most famous Jewish ballplayers, from the 19th-century pioneer Lipman Pike to the current Red Sox mainstay Kevin Youkilis. The film tosses off instantly forgettable fun facts before pausing to dwell on two superstars: Hank Greenberg, who played first base and outfield for the Detroit Tigers in the 1930s and ’40s, and Sandy Koufax, the Dodgers’ legendary lefty from the 1950s and ’60s. Both men made national headlines when they decided not to play in important games on Yom Kippur.

headline: Name Debate Echoes an Old Clash of Faiths
text: CÓRDOBA, Spain  The great mosque of Córdoba was begun by the Muslim caliphs in the eighth century, its forest of pillars and red-and-white striped arches meant to convey a powerful sense of the infinite. With the Christian reconquest of Spain in the 13th century, it was consecrated as a cathedral.

headline: McConnell Eases Talk of a Thaw
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, said Thursday that “the only way” his party would succeed in advancing its agenda was to ensure that President Obama was defeated in two years, seemingly bringing a quick end to post-election professions from both sides about working together.

headline: ‘Cleopatra’
text: That Egyptian Woman

headline: Femme Fatale
text: Papyri crumble away. What remains of her home is 20 feet underwater. She died before Jesus was born. Her first biographers never met her, and she deliberately hid her real self behind vulgar display. A cautious writer would never consider her as a subject. Stacy Schiff, however, has risen to the bait, with deserved confidence. “Saint-Exupéry: A Biography” and “Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov)” demonstrated her mastery of the form. “The Great Improvisation,” Schiff’s analysis of Benjamin Franklin’s years in Paris, revealed a different genius: the intellectual stamina required to untangle the endlessly tricky snarls created by the intersection of human personalities and international relations.

headline: Tea Party Moves Quickly to Flex Muscle
text: WASHINGTON  The incoming leadership of the new House Republican majority hardly had a chance to relish its dismantling of the Democrats before the Tea Party came calling in the form of Representative Michele Bachmann.

headline: Social Security: Pension Plan or Transfer System?
text: Sixteen years ago, I wrote a column on Social Security, and got more negative mail than I have ever received before or since for anything I have written. You can read samples here, here, here, here, here,  and here.

headline: Nomination for Massachusetts Chief Justice
text: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick, newly elected to a second term, nominated Justice Roderick L. Ireland on Thursday to be the first black chief justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.

headline: Gal Takes Straighter Path, Hoping to Have It All
text: There are enough funny lines and successful bits of comic business scattered through Casper Andreas’s “Violet Tendencies” — an ugly-duckling fairy tale about a woman with lots of gay friends who is looking for love herself — to keep you amused as long as your expectations aren’t particularly high, or if your primary agenda is to ogle the beefcake. Two men in bed: “I love you.” “What’s my name?” Pause. “I am so in love with you.”

headline: Western Meets Horror
text: Western meets horror in the Australian high country in “Red Hill,” a galloping revenge tale that uses young blood to unearth old sins.

headline: Citigroup Prevails in Lawsuit Over EMI Deal
text: By PETER LATTMAN

headline: Vermont Nuclear Plant Up for Sale
text: Entergy Nuclear, evidently convinced that the Vermont legislature will not allow the company to run the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant for another 20 years, announced on Thursday that the plant was up for sale.

headline: Ready for New York’s Streets After Defying Death in Mine
text: Edison Peña blinked in the glare of camera flashes and shook his head as if in disbelief that he was in New York to run the marathon. Humble in his crisp black suit and brown shoes, he may be a miner by trade, but he is a runner at his core. Nothing daunts him now, not even singing an Elvis solo.

headline: Donor Groups Find Success in Elections
text: After all the talk about the impact of independent groups on this year’s midterm elections, the debate over at least one important question can now begin in earnest: Which groups were the most effective?

headline: With Debut of ‘Conan,’ Marketers Join Team Coco
text: EARLIER this year, millions of comedy fans, college students, Harvard alumni and insomniacs joined Team Coco, the fanciful name for devotees of Conan O’Brien that sprang up during his final days at NBC. Now, the ranks of Team Coco are being swelled by major marketers like AT&T, General Motors, Microsoft and the News Corporation.

headline: Damage Control
text: In the time since my Home Fires post, “Death and Memory,” was published, I’ve received a number of illuminating and often quite touching responses from readers. I’d like to address some of them here.

headline: A Freshman Year to Remember
text: From the title on down, “Cherry” is an icky, sticky movie, designed to titillate and tug the heartstrings at the same time. It starts out looking like a freshman-year coming-of-age story, as Aaron (the Ed Westwick lookalike Kyle Gallner) is driven by his domineering mother and ineffectual father to an unnamed Ivy League college, where he meets his roommate, an oversexed future frat boy. (The suspiciously small campus was actually in Kalamazoo, Mich., a center of both higher learning and film-production tax credits.)

headline: Disney Junior to Focus on Social Values
text: LOS ANGELES  Move aside, “Sesame Street” and “Dora the Explorer.” Mothers want preschool television to be more about teaching children social skills and less about pushing clear academic goals  at least that’s what Disney executives say new internal research indicates.

headline: With Second Tier, a Hotter Stove This Winter
text: Last winter, when a relatively weak class of free agents prompted many teams to fill their needs through trades, the refrain around baseball was “just wait until 2010.” But with Roy Halladay, Josh Beckett and Joe Mauer having signed contract extensions, and with other stars losing their luster or recovering from injury, a once-deep pool of top talent has given way to a group that, as it did last year, centers on an ace and two outfielders.

headline: Plumbing the Head
text: This is the eighth in a series.

headline: Jet Engine Failure Causes Worry on Manufacturer
text: The blowout of an engine on Qantas Flight 32 on Thursday was the latest in a series of problems involving Rolls-Royce engines and analysts said it raised serious questions about the company’s ability to develop the engines for the newest generation of commercial and military airplanes.

headline: After Months of Feuding, Obama Makes Overture to Business Group
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is moving to cool down his war with the United States Chamber of Commerce, one of the most bitter political feuds of the last two years.

headline: Higher Levels of Lead Seen in City Tap Water
text: New York City health and environmental officials on Thursday advised residents to run their tap water for at least 30 seconds before drinking or cooking with it after testing showed a rise in the percentage of homes with elevated levels of lead.

headline: India: The Next Generation
text: Ahead of President Obama's visit, young Indians shared their thoughts on the relationship between the two countries.

headline: A Motel Stay Leads to Creepy Happenings
text: There are lots of reasons why horror filmmakers keep checking their characters into seedy motels: they’re cheap, reliably creepy and, with luck, will spark latent “Psycho” associations among viewers old enough to make them. Sometimes the strategy works — “Identity” (2003) and “Vacancy” (2007) are two of the more recent examples — but not even the Bates Motel itself could save the mess that is “Beneath the Dark.”

headline: Obama Aide Adjusts Course for a Comeback
text: WASHINGTON  At a time of tumult, the corner office in the West Wing is a center of calm. With the rest of Washington in a frenzy over the “shellacking” President Obama’s party took in this week’s elections, his new chief of staff quietly and methodically plots out a refashioned White House to manage his recovery.

headline: Heisman Front-Runner Is Focus of Investigation
text: MADISON, Miss.  The N.C.A.A. is investigating Auburn University’s recruitment of Cam Newton, a star quarterback and front-runner for the Heisman Trophy. John Bond, a former Mississippi State quarterback, said on Thursday that he was approached by a former teammate about a “specified payment” that would be required to secure Newton.

headline: Baghdad Studio of Feisty TV Station Shut Down in Dispute With Iraqi Government
text: BAGHDAD  Baghdadiya, a satellite channel that broadcasts out of Cairo, is best known outside Iraq for its reporter Muntader al-Zaidi, who threw his shoes at President George W. Bush at a news conference in 2008.

headline: Silence Before the Storm
text: The words of a president can convey — or conceal — a great deal of meaning. As the United States approached the central crisis in its history, there was no reason to expect great eloquence from the man whose election had precipitated that conflict. Abraham Lincoln was often described as an uncouth barbarian, and had received the least education of any presidential nominee in American history, save Andrew Jackson. Yet there he was in the fall of 1860, standing before the American people, the embodiment of their hopes and fears. In this politically charged atmosphere, the words that flowed from his pen, and his equally expressive silences, did a great deal to define the conflict coming into view. This occasional feature in the Disunion series will probe Lincoln’s language, looking at his speeches and public pronouncements during the long transition between his election eve on Nov. 5, 1860, and his First Inaugural Address on March 4, 1861.

headline: The Sweet Tune of Perfection
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Jerry Moss has survived cancer. He has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. He is a Bronx native who went to college in Brooklyn but found a life in California, a good one. Still, he remains a Yankees fan, a devoted one.

headline: For Obama, Foreign Policy May Offer Avenues for Success
text: WASHINGTON  The elections on Tuesday gutted the Democrats on the House Armed Services Committee, paved the way for a pro-Israel Cuban-American to preside over the House Foreign Affairs Committee and removed the most antiwar Democrat from the leading Senate foreign policy committee.

headline: A Big Game Saturday. Good Luck Finding It.
text: The only televised college football game on Saturday between undefeated top 10 teams will not be on ESPN, CBS, ABC, ESPN2, ESPNU or Versus. It will be carried by a network that is not available to every cable home in the country and isn’t even rated by Nielsen.

headline: Pirated Films From Nigeria Are Seized in Brooklyn
text: For years, fans in Brooklyn have devoured films from Nigeria, paying $3 for bootlegged copies of the latest releases at utilitarian stores in the Flatbush neighborhood that distribute cellphones, calling cards and an evening’s entertainment.

headline: Scholars Reconsidering Italy’s Treatment of Jews in the Nazi Era
text: Italians took everything from Ursula Korn Selig’s family during World War II, including a hotel the family owned on the Riviera and the money they carried after fleeing Germany’s persecution of Jews in 1938.

headline: Murray Wins Senate Race in Washington
text: In one of the nation’s straggler election contests, Senator Patty Murray of Washington won the Senate race in Washington state, narrowly defeating Dino Rossi, who conceded Thursday afternoon.

headline: In Florida, a C.E.O. Prepared for Cuts
text: MIAMI  Many of the newly elected Republican governors have said they want to run their state like a business. But few have been as brash and bold in corporate life  or with their economic campaign proposals  as Rick Scott, Florida’s new chief executive.

headline: Lottery Numbers
How the Tea Party Fared
text: At least 44 candidates associated with the Tea Party won their races on Tuesday.

headline: California Shifted, and So Did Jerry Brown
text: LOS ANGELES — Jerry Brown has seen this before: a budget in crisis, a Legislature divided, a state confronting the possibility that its glory days are behind it.

headline: Delays at New York Airports Aren’t Improving, U.S. Says
text: Flights through New York’s three major airports are delayed or canceled more often than anywhere else in the nation, and the government’s efforts to correct the problem have so far come up short, the federal Transportation Department said Thursday.

headline: For G.O.P., Big Ambitions Face Daunting Obstacles
text: WASHINGTON  Republican leaders in Congress are preparing to take power in two months with ambitious and sometimes contradictory goals for economic and fiscal policies, leaving little common ground with President Obama and much uncertainty about the potential impact on the nation’s problems.

headline: Sonia Sotomayor’s Last Laugh
text: Justice Sonia Sotomayor is accustomed to being underestimated and to surpassing the expectations of her doubters. So I’ll wonder if she even took the time to ponder the leak last week of a May 2009 letter to President Obama from a famous Harvard law professor lobbying for the selection of Elena Kagan to replace Justice David H. Souter, whose retirement had recently been announced. I’m quite sure it is the professor, Laurence H. Tribe, rather than Justice Sotomayor, who is mortified by the revelation that he had dissed the soon-to-be-nominee, a graduate of Princeton and Yale Law School, as “not as smart as she seems to think she is.”’

headline: To Harlem Churchgoers, Marathon Is a Nuisance
text: There is dancing along the streets. Gospel, soul and salsa music blare from speakers and bandstands. Spectators jockey for position on sidewalks and side streets, while thousands of runners pass in dribbles and waves. Crowds cheer.

headline: Iran Says It Gave Afghans $500 Million
text: Iran has given $500 million in official assistance to Afghanistan for infrastructure and other reconstruction projects in recent years, Mahmoud Barimani, a senior Iranian Foreign Ministry official, told the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday. Mr. Barimani accused the United States and its allies of destabilizing Iran’s neighbor and increasing the violence there rather than solving the country’s problems. In 2006, Iran reported that its aid had totaled $200 million. Last month President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan admitted that Iran had given his office “bags of money” worth millions of dollars. Mr. Barimani did not mention those payments.

headline: German Artist Wins $100,000 Prize
text: Hans-Peter Feldmann, a German artist known for creating carefully conceived installations from everyday images, has won this year’s Hugo Boss Prize, the Guggenheim announced on Thursday night.

headline: Bank of America Fights Pressure on Mortgages
text: Bank of America on Thursday rebuffed claims by a lawyer for several big investors, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, that it should buy back troubled mortgages because the loans were made improperly.

headline: 'Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'
text: Photos from the new Broadway musical.

headline: Friday: Secret Phrase Contest
text: Because today’s crossword involves a contest, it is being offered free to readers. Click here to download a PDF of the puzzle as it appears in the print edition.

headline: Here’s Your Valium, What’s Your Hurry?
text: They’re giving out the wrong drug at the Belasco Theater, where “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” opened on Thursday night. As in the 1988 Pedro Almodóvar movie that inspired this star-jammed musical, Valium is consumed in large quantities by many characters. That is so pharmaceutically irresponsible. What this production needs — immediately and intravenously — is Ritalin.

headline: Human Development Report Shows Great Gains, and Some Slides
text: UNITED NATIONS  The world has made significant progress in income, education and health over the past 40 years, but the gains have been uneven and in some places war and the ravages of AIDS shortened life spans, according to a United Nations report on Thursday.

headline: Gauging the New Political Atmosphere
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hevesi Adviser in Pension Scandal Makes Deal to Plead Guilty to Felony
text: Hank Morris, a onetime political adviser to Alan G. Hevesi, the former state comptroller, on Thursday became the latest figure in the corruption scandal involving the New York pension fund to agree to plead guilty.

headline: Parking Rules
text: On Friday, because of Diwali, the Hindu festival

headline: BofA Rejects Calls to Buy Back Mortgages
text: Bank of America on Thursday rebuffed claims by a lawyer for several big investors, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Pimco, that it should buy back troubled mortgages because the loans were made improperly, The New York Times reports.

headline: A Loss, and a Farewell, for the Red Bulls
text: Harrison, N.J.

headline: Facing New Crisis, Haitians Prove Skeptical
text: CORAIL, Haiti  Hours before the first raindrops and stiff winds of Tropical Storm Tomas arrived Thursday night, a group of aid workers bent on evacuating earthquake survivors from a tent camp here roared away in vans empty-handed.

headline: Rangers Look for Revenge but Don’t Find It Against the Flyers
text: PHILADELPHIA  The game was hyped as the rematch of last April’s breathless season finale, when the Flyers beat the Rangers in a shootout to win a playoff spot and send the Rangers home.

headline: With Homegrown Talent, a Rising Power on Long Island
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  After Hofstra’s women’s soccer team lost, badly, in its season opener, then fashioned the longest winning streak in the country, the next game it plays could still be its last of the year. Possible, but not likely.

headline: Time Running Out for Mets on Takahashi
text: The chances of Hisanori Takahashi remaining with the Mets are dwindling by the hour as the deadline to re-sign him approaches. With no significant progress in contract talks, it appears he will leave the Mets. The Mets are not willing to guarantee a two-year contract for Takahashi, the versatile Japanese left-hander who wants at least that to remain with the team.

headline: For Some Bushmen, a Homeland Worth the Fight
text: CENTRAL KALAHARI GAME RESERVE, Botswana — They were on the move beneath an unyielding sun, and for a while their approaching shapes seemed just another part of the desert, their tattered clothes bleached like the thorny scrub around them. These weary Bushmen — four men, three women and an infant — were nearing the end of a two-day journey, walking their way toward water.

headline: Are Polar Bears More than ‘Threatened’?
text: 10:43 p.m. | Updated The Center for Biological Diversity is known for creative public relations stunts, like deploying one of its lawyers in a polar bear suit at climate talks in Copenhagen last December:

headline: Re-elected Texas Governor Sounding Like a Candidate
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Gov. Rick Perry says he has no interest in running for president, but one would never know it by watching him this week.

headline: Bushmen Resettle on Outskirts of Reserve
text: Since the 1980s, Botswana has both coaxed and hounded the Bushmen to leave the Central Kalahari Game Reserve, intending to restrict the area to what its name implies: a wildlife refuge empty of human residents.

headline: A Democrat Is the Winner in Washington
text: Senator Patty Murray of Washington State has won a fourth term, narrowly defeating her Republican challenger Dino Rossi, who conceded Thursday afternoon.

headline: Rasmussen Polls Were Biased and Inaccurate; Quinnipiac, SurveyUSA Performed Strongly
text: Every election cycle has its winners and losers: not just the among the candidates, but also the pollsters.

headline: Wall Street Ends the Week Higher
text: Stocks rose on Friday as a better-than-expected jobs report helped the market extend robust gains of the day before, keeping the major indexes at their highest levels for at least a year.

headline: Learning in Dorm, Because Class Is on the Web
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Like most other undergraduates, Anish Patel likes to sleep in. Even though his Principles of Microeconomics class at 9:35 a.m. is just a five-minute stroll from his dorm, he would rather flip open his laptop in his room to watch the lecture, streamed live over the campus network.

headline: The Crisis in Public Housing
text: After nearly two decades of weak financing from Congress, a large number of the public housing developments that shelter 2.3 million of the nation’s poorest, most vulnerable people are falling apart.

headline: Grim Lesson of Bomb Plot
text: To the Editor:

headline: Midwest at Dusk
text: If Balzac were alive today, he would plant himself in that region of America that starts in central New York and Pennsylvania and then stretches out through Ohio and Indiana before spreading out to include Wisconsin and Arkansas. He’d plant himself in the working-class families in this area.

headline: Last Chance for a Pontiac
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medicare and the Republicans
text: An overwhelming majority of older voters chose Republican Congressional candidates in Tuesday’s election. They were propelled in large part, we suspect, by distorted and inflammatory attack ads claiming that President Obama’s health care reforms would “gut” their Medicare coverage and implying that a Republican-controlled Congress would somehow rescue them.

headline: A Crack in the Wall
text: When the Supreme Court took up a case about a school choice program in Arizona this week, Justice Elena Kagan said she had been “puzzling and puzzling” over it. Why, she asked the state’s lawyer, instead of providing families with vouchers, is Arizona’s program “so much more complicated and complex and unusual”?

headline: Campaign Money to Burn
text: After Tuesday’s vote, there is no limit to the ambitions of stealth political groups bankrolled by anonymous check writers. Two of the flushest pro-Republican operations, American Crossroads and Crossroads GPS, plan to extend their campaigning into the lame-duck session of Congress with waves of misinformation about tax and immigration issues.

headline: Asteroids and Global Warming
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Focus Hocus-Pocus
text: Democrats, declared Evan Bayh in an Op-Ed article on Wednesday in The Times, “overreached by focusing on health care rather than job creation during a severe recession.” Many others have been saying the same thing: the notion that the Obama administration erred by not focusing on the economy is hardening into conventional wisdom.

headline: A Firing at NPR: Issues of Fairness and Financing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,348 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A View From Myanmar as Election Nears
text: For a country that has been under some form of military government since its creation in 1962, Sunday’s elections could engender change, even if that change occurs on the junta’s terms.

headline: Chronicle’s Coverage of Sit/Lie Prompts a Question
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 4
text: The day in sports, from soccer to golf.

headline: California: Transgender Candidate Is New Judge
text: Voters in the San Francisco Bay Area elected the first transgender trial judge in the country on Tuesday. Victoria Kolakowski, a lawyer who underwent gender reassignment surgery more than two decades ago, won the race for Superior Court judge in Alameda County with more than 50 percent of the vote.

headline: California: Competency Hearing Set In Kidnap Trial
text: A judge in the trial of Philip and Nancy Garrido, accused of kidnapping Jaycee Dugard in 1991 and holding her for 18 years, has set a tentative date in March for a mental competency hearing for Mr. Garrido. Judge Douglas Phimister said that would allow time for court-appointed psychiatrists to evaluate Mr. Garrido. The Garridos were arrested in 2009 at their home outside Antioch, Calif., where Mr. Garrido is accused of holding Ms. Dugard and two children he fathered by her. She was 11 at the time of her kidnapping. Several news organizations have sought to have transcripts of Ms. Dugard’s grand jury testimony released. Stephen A. Tapson, a lawyer for Ms. Garrido, objects to releasing them, saying they described “a tale of woe and misfortune” that would prejudice a jury. “This stuff is evil,” Mr. Tapson said.

headline: Displaying Shooting Touch, Knicks Return to Prime Time
text: CHICAGO  Three years ago, the Knicks wandered onto a national television broadcast and so humiliated themselves that their own coach declared, “We’re not ready for prime time.”

headline: A Simpler Label For Not-So-Secret Information
text: President Obama on Thursday rolled back a proliferating array of policies by which federal agencies had kept unclassified information from the public, issuing an executive order intended to create a uniform way of handling such information. Mr. Obama’s order requires agencies to use only one term  “Controlled Unclassified Information,” or CUI  when stamping certain documents that officials believe should be safeguarded but that are not delicate enough to warrant being classified. That label would replace almost 120 markings that various agencies had developed to protect information.

headline: Glen Little, Better Known as Frosty the Clown, Dies at 84
text: Glen Little, better known as Frosty the Clown, who performed at the White House and was a teacher and mentor to a generation of clowns with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, died on Oct. 26 in Kimberly, Idaho, near his home in Burley. He was 84.

headline: Student Aid at For-Profit School Will Be Reviewed
text: Apollo Group Inc. announced Thursday that next month the Department of Education would review its University of Phoenix, the nation’s largest for-profit college. The review will look at how Phoenix, which took in $1 billion in Pell grants last year, has handled federal student aid it has received since the 2009-2010 academic year. Last month, in a move that depressed the stock values of the for-profit higher education sector, Phoenix withdrew its forecast for fiscal 2011, saying it expected a decline in new enrollments.

headline: New York Teams Believe Improvement Begins With Recruiting
text: Last year, college basketball in the New York metro area was in the midst of a drought that threatened a record. That mark of four years without a local team in the N.C.A.A. tournament has since been tied, and this season, there is a new crop of coaches, all of whom are trying to figure out how the drought came about and how it might end.

headline: Smart-Growth Policy Splits Environmentalists
text: Most people would assume that environmentalists would rather protect tall trees than tall buildings.

headline: Defeat of Proposition B Cements Labor’s Power
text: The scene at Hi Dive, a bar on the Embarcadero tucked under the Bay Bridge, was a merry one late Tuesday night.

headline: After a Study, Healthy Changes Block by Block
text: Seven years ago, Leony Calderón felt much older than her 30 years. “My joints hurt so much, it was hard to go up stairs,” Ms. Calderón said last week at her office at the Greater Humboldt Park Community Diabetes Empowerment Center. Dangerously overweight, she stopped menstruating, had high cholesterol and was pre-diabetic. She knew something had to be done.

headline: A Comet Closeup
text: Here’s a closeup of Comet Hartley 2, which was photographed during a flyby by the EPOXI mission. There are jets of gas spewing from the sun-heated surfaces of the object. I post it here simply for the sake of its stunning, stark beauty (Credit: NASA/JPL, CalTech/UMD):

headline: Hard Work and Money Helped State Democrats Resist G.O.P. Tide
text: Campaigning in the crowded Schaumburg Metra station before the election this week, Michael Noland, a Democratic state senator in one of the state’s most hotly contested races, lowered his voice to make what he described as a confession: “I voted for Ronald Reagan.”

headline: Rick Perry, Master of the Friendly Attack
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: More High School Students Acquire Online Credits
text: Brett Rusnock can follow his students’ every move on his laptop: how much time they spend on computers each day at Waltrip High School in Houston, their scores on quizzes and when they stop working. He even gets e-mail alerts when they toil at home into the wee hours. “I can play Big Brother a little bit with this,” Mr. Rusnock said.

headline: Bernanke Fearing Fate of Japan, Not Greece
text: WASHINGTON  By placing a $600 billion bet on the Federal Reserve’s ability to encourage the recovery, Ben S. Bernanke is gingerly trying to avoid the mistakes of Japan, where deflation has stymied growth. But the antideficit Republicans who seized control of the House on Tuesday draw cautionary lessons from a different country: debt-stricken Greece.

headline: Debra Winger Drops Back In
text: When Debra Winger, the actor who is now as famous for walking away from her chosen profession as for excelling within it, first met with the producers of HBO’s psychotherapy drama “In Treatment,” it was because they were hoping to entice her to take on the role of Frances, a complicated, unhappy and sometimes evasive leading lady whom Winger wryly describes as “just another in a long line of women I hope never to become.” Early meetings between actresses and producers are an odd Hollywood ritual. They’re not quite mating dances; they’re more like strenuously casual preinterviews for a first date, full of mutual courtesies designed to prevent any hurt feelings. Accordingly, Winger arrived prepared — not only with a list of questions and ideas about the role, but also with the names of several other performers the producers might want to pursue instead of her if she wasn’t the right fit. “I had in my head the names of five other actresses,” she said, “all of whom I thought would, in a way, be better. It’s pretty amazing who’s out there, not working.

text: gruff •\ˈgrəf\• adjective

headline: Costly ‘Spider-Man’ Can’t Get Off the Ground
text: It’s supposed to be the biggest, costliest, splashiest show of the Broadway season, but so far it’s just the most troubled. Executives with “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” said Thursday that the opening of the oft-delayed, $60 million musical would be set back once again, this time by three weeks, meaning it will miss lucrative Thanksgiving week, forgo an attention-getting bow over Christmas, and open during the box office doldrums of January.

headline: BNP Paribas Profit Beats Expectations
text: BNP Paribas, the large French bank, reported on Thursday a profit for the third quarter that easily topped expectations, as strong growth in its consumer banking and investment management businesses offset a decline in commercial and investment banking, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: In a Cost Per Vote Analysis, Some Candidates Did Not Get What They Paid For
text: Your attention is expensive. Gov. Rick Perry’s campaign spent $14.58 for every vote he received in the general election. Democrat Bill White spent $11.76. And those were the efficient contests.

headline: Live vs. Distance Learning: Measuring the Differences
text: The educational value of online courses has been debated for years, based on a large but uneven body of research. An analysis of 99 studies by the federal Department of Education concluded last year that online instruction, on average, was more effective than face-to-face learning by a modest amount.

headline: Passion Still Burns for New York’s Bravest
text: Matt Long’s record at the New York City Marathon prompts meager praise when measured against the elite runners. He has completed New York four times, with a personal best 3 hours 13 minutes in 2005. Long, a New York City firefighter, has competed with the city’s fire department team in Mayor’s Cup races against its police officers, helping the firemen maintain a commanding 23-4 edge in the series.

headline: Airgas and Air Products Executives Meet
text: Airgas, the industrial gas company that has been fending off a $5.5 billion hostile bid from a rival, Air Products and Chemicals, said senior executives from the two companies met on Thursday to discuss their views on Airgas’s valuation, Reuters reports.

headline: Zenyatta Competes at the Breeders' Cup
text: This Saturday is expected to be the final race of Zenyatta's career.

headline: Avis Needs More Financing for Dollar Thrifty
text: Avis Budget, which recently raised about $400 million by selling notes, will require additional financing to complete the Dollar Thrifty transaction, its top executive said.

headline: Wal-Mart Unit Involved in Japan Insider Trade Probe
text: Wal-Mart Stores, the world’s biggest retailer, said it was cooperating with an investigation into possible insider trading related to its takeover of the Japanese retail chain Seiyu, Reuters reports.

headline: Regulators Await ‘Flash Crash’ Panel Advice
text: Federal regulators may get the ammunition they need to impose new market rules when they meet an advisory panel on Friday to discuss the May 6 plunge that briefly sent the equities market and related futures into a tailspin, Reuters reports.

text: Canada’s farm minister offered one reason that Canada blocked the proposed takeover of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan on Thursday, but markets will have to wait a month for all the details to emerge, Reuters reports.
