text: Today’s word, in association with the brilliant Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Despite Cadbury Bump, Kraft Misses Revenue Target
text: Kraft Foods reported weaker-than-expected quarterly revenue, after price increases taken to offset rising ingredient costs hurt sales, Reuters reports.

headline: What Are Your Personal Superstitions?
text: With the New York City Marathon just two days away, runners have been revealing some of the superstitions and rituals that they believe will affect how well they will run those famous 26.2 miles. What do you think about this? Can months and months of grueling training really come down to a lit candle or a certain number appearing — or not — on a runner’s race bib? What superstitions do you follow, and why?

headline: In Nigeria, Companies Miss Deadline for Telecom Sale
text: A group of private companies missed a deadline Thursday to provide a $750 million down payment to purchase Nigeria’s ailing state-run telephone company, the latest setback in efforts to privatize the firm, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Coke Plans $4 Billion Debt Sale, Its Biggest Ever
text: Coca-Cola announced a $4 billion debt offering on Thursday, the biggest in its history, as the world’s top soft drink maker aims to take advantage of low borrowing rates, Reuters reports.

headline: JPMorgan to Resume Foreclosures This Month
text: JPMorgan Chase expects to start refiling foreclosure documents in a couple of weeks, according to Charlie Scharf, chief executive of retail financial services, Reuters reports.

headline: In Qantas Blowout, Concern for Jet Engine Maker
text: PARIS  Shares of Rolls-Royce, the British aircraft engine maker, extended their declines on Friday after the chief executive of Qantas suggested that a design flaw or manufacturing defect was the most likely explanation for a engine blow-out that forced one of the Australian carrier’s A380 jets to make an emergency landing in Singapore on Thursday.

headline: Banks Face $31 Billion Loss on Mortgage Buybacks
text: The top United States banks could face up to $31 billion in losses from buying back bad mortgages, Standard & Poor’s said in a report on Thursday, Reuters reports.

headline: Xstrata Wins Round in Battle for Sphere Minerals
text: Sphere Minerals, an Australia-listed iron ore prospector, fended off an attempt by its biggest shareholder to derail its agreed $522 million takeover from the global miner Xstrata, Reuters reported.

headline: Fed May Let Strong Banks Increase Dividends
text: The Federal Reserve is soon expected to allow some healthy banks with strong capital levels to increase dividend payments, according to people familiar with the decision, Reuters reports.

headline: First Yuan Credit Default Swaps Signed
text: The first yuan-denominated credit default swaps insuring bonds and loans were signed Friday as China experiments with derivatives blamed by some European and United States officials for exacerbating the global financial crisis, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Coal Remains Top as Green Power I.P.O. Struggles
text: Waning investor interest in clean energy contrasted sharply with enthusiasm for coal on Thursday as shares in Enel Green Power fell on their debut while Coal India‘s soared, Reuters reported.

headline: China Police Confine Prominent Artist
text: BEIJING — A phalanx of Beijing police officers confined the prominent artist and activist Ai Weiwei to his north Beijing home on Friday, a move he suggested came at the behest of unnamed but powerful political figures in Shanghai who feared that he was about to embarrass them.

text: If you spend your day replying to e-mail in Microsoft Outlook, you may find yourself with a stack of open message windows all over your screen by lunchtime. Fortunately, most recent versions of Outlook can help you keep things tidy by closing the windows for you.

headline: Mail.ru, Facebook Backer, Up 41% After London I.P.O.
text: The Mail.ru Group, a Russian investor in Facebook, surged as much as 41 percent in London trading after raising $912 million in the city’s biggest initial public offering since July, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: ‘Homage’
text: In my recent column on Stephen Colbert’s coinage of “truthiness,” I wrote that the title of Charles Seife’s new book, “Proofiness,” is “very much a homage to Colbert.” Laura Kozin e-mails: "My brain stubbed its toe on this. I thought we pronounced it ‘an (h)omage.’ Did I miss a change to spoken ‘h’? Is it now ‘a herb garden’ as well?” Steve Penn e-mails: “Your last column indicated that you pronounce homage with the ‘h.’ Me too. A few years ago, on the radio, I was jolted to hear this word pronounced oh-MAZH. A real stomach-turner. Since then, I've heard this pronunciation fairly frequently on the radio and occasionally on television. Are the broadcast folks cooking up a new pronunciation, or do they intend some word other than homage?”

headline: One on One: Vivek Kundra, U.S. Chief Information Officer
text: Vivek Kundra is the chief information officer of the United States. His job is to help shape the use of technology in government and build tools to help the public navigate the incredible amount of data and information available.

headline: Bush/Nixon
text: The early reviews of George W. Bush’s memoir “Decision Points” are already out, even though the book is under a sales embargo until next Tuesday. If you want to read one of the book’s “deluxe” copies — the hand-numbered, hand-signed edition that comes with a slipcase, a “special color photo frontispiece” and a $350 price tag — you’ll have to wait even longer, until Nov. 30.

headline: My Week in Collections
text: Human resources, strategic planning, lean manufacturing, cost cutting, social-media marketing, concept this, buzzword that, blah, blah, blah. In the end it’s all about money — specifically, getting someone to give you some. And that’s what I’ve been doing a lot of lately: trying to get a whole bunch of people who owe me money to pony up.

headline: BlackRock Fund to Finance and Securitize U.S. Mortgages
text: A BlackRock fund will begin financing United States home loans this month customized for a new breed of residential mortgage-backed securities that avoids the conflicts tainting many of today’s private issues, Reuters reported.

text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden vest inside a mosque in northwestern Pakistan during midday prayers on Friday, government officials said, a strike apparently aimed at people who had declined to support the Taliban.

headline: Georgia Holds 13, Saying They Spied for Russia
text: MOSCOW  Georgia’s Interior Ministry announced Friday that it used a former Soviet officer to infiltrate Russia’s military intelligence service, uncovering dozens of covert agents working in Georgia.

headline: Indonesia’s Volcano Erupts Again
text: MAGUWOHARJO, Indonesia  A powerful overnight eruption of Mount Merapi created chaos for Indonesia’s disaster response effort on Friday after an explosion of hot gases and debris killed scores of people and sent more than 160,000 villagers fleeing to underprepared evacuation camps.

text: Three days after Connecticut was thrust into an unflattering national spotlight because of an embarrassing series of election mishaps, Dannel P. Malloy, the Democratic candidate, emerged victorious Friday over his Republican rival, Thomas C. Foley, in their bitter battle to become the next governor of Connecticut.

headline: Zenyatta’s Inspiration Brings a Songwriter Back to Horses

headline: Mapping Ecosystems, the Better to Conserve Them
text: Environmentalists have a special affinity for maps. Whether terrestrial or marine, the environment and its ills are tied to a geography that can be expressed in a rectilinear scale.

headline: Complaint Box | Complaint Box
text: About a year ago, I submitted a lighthearted complaint to this section about my undying disdain for the stinky ginkgo trees in the Queens neighborhood in which I lived at the time. The editor expressed interest but regretfully told me that there were simply too many complaints to publish. Maybe in the future, I was told.

headline: Video Shows Indonesians Fleeing Volcano
text: Updated | 4:07 p.m. As my colleague Aubrey Belford reports from Indonesia, the latest and most powerful eruption of the Mount Merapi volcano in central Java, late Thursday night, killed dozens of people and sent more than 160,000 villagers fleeing an explosion of hot gases.

headline: BBC Staff Strikes Over Changes to Pension Plan
text: LONDON  Journalists at the British Broadcasting Corporation started a 48-hour strike Friday morning to protest planned pension cuts, causing some disruption to global programming.

headline: Age Of Diminished Expectations
text: So, we have a “strong” jobs report — with total employment still 7 1/2 million less than it was three years ago, we had job gains slightly higher than the number needed to keep up with population growth.

headline: Tension and Levity in Sao Paulo
text: INTERLAGOS, Brazil — I arrived in the paddock this morning under clear skies and very hot weather, but as the day progressed, the thickened clouds came and it rained. There’s a brilliant sunset as I write. Sorry to write about the weather, as if I have nothing else to say. No, in fact, the different kinds of weather is just an example of the different senses of atmosphere in the paddock.

headline: Tension and Levity in Sao Paulo
text: INTERLAGOS, Brazil — I arrived in the paddock this morning under clear skies and very hot weather, but as the day progressed, the thickened clouds came and it rained. There’s a brilliant sunset as I write. Sorry to write about the weather, as if I have nothing else to say. No, in fact, the different kinds of weather is just an example of the different senses of atmosphere in the paddock.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: It’s … Superman?
text: “Superman: Earth One,” the first in a new series of graphic novels from DC Comics, is perched at No. 1 on the hardcover list. This installment, written by J. Michael Straczynski and illustrated by Shane Davis, wonders what would happen if the origin of the Man of Steel were told in the present day. The story not only chronicles the young Clark Kent’s journey to becoming Superman, but shows how he lands his job at The Daily Planet (which in this retelling is suffering from declining readership. Great Caesar’s Ghost!).

headline: Bankers’ Trust
text: There’s something for everyone at F.D, the philanthropist and collector Fiona Druckenmiller’s new Midtown boutique. That is, if the everyone in question is seeking exquisite new and vintage jewels (the shop boasts an impressive cache of period Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels), watches, sculptures, Art Deco furniture, photography, first-edition manuscripts and swanky barware. The interior, designed in collaboration with the décor firm Pamela Banker Associates, is best described as cozy chic. “We wanted it to be homey and welcoming, not intimidating,” Druckenmiller says. “People will hopefully feel comfortable enough to linger, have a coffee or glass of wine, and spend time learning about the objects that interest them.”

headline: Letter: The Women’s Empowerment Issue
text: The Women’s Empowerment Issue was an enlightening, challenging, inspirational read. What an amazing set of women were featured, from the courageous undocumented U.C.L.A. women to the marvelous president of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, not to mention the inspiring venture philanthropists who have put their safe lives on hold to help others. Thank you for lifting up such a diverse group of women and for reminding us all of the difference we can make to empower women.

headline: Fantasy Politics
text: Throughout his recent run for Senate, the Florida Republican Marco Rubio made a big deal of the sacrifices his Cuban immigrant family made “so that I could live the American dream.” By campaign’s end, he was using the phrase so regularly that spokesmen for his Democratic opponent, Congressman Kendrick B. Meek, were reminding reporters that Rubio did not have a patent on it. The American dream mattered a lot in this election. Americans for Prosperity, a conservative activist group, laid out plans for repealing President Obama’s health care reform and fighting environmental regulation at its Defending the American Dream Summit two months ago. The president, meanwhile, closed this fall’s campaign with an exhortation to “restore the American dream for not just some, but for every, every, everybody in this great land.” If both sides agree that the dream is imperiled, and that recovering it is a top national priority, then it may be this “dream”of ours is not a unifying idea but a vague slogan, no more to be trusted than any other piece of campaign rhetoric.

headline: Stats Appeal
text: Over the past year, friends and readers have sent me a number of “reports” from something called OkTrends, which offers up data-driven assessments of online behavior, like “The Big Lies People Tell in Online Dating.” Often these are enjoyable, and I’ve even passed some along to others. I was dimly aware that OkTrends drew its conclusions from mining the data of OkCupid, a dating site. But I never thought much about that; I’m not in the market for online dating. Even so, this informal distribution of entertaining research is also a de facto distribution of buzz for the OkCupid brand. Here, it seems, is data mining as marketing.

headline: A Life in Pictures
text: At 29, you’re the subject of a new book, “Sophie Crumb: Evolution of a Crazy Artist,” an album of drawings that was edited by you and your parents. It opens with a series of full-page color reproductions of crayon compositions you did as a 2-year-old. Can your parents be accused of exploiting you?  That’s hilarious. How can it be exploitation when I’m well paid?

headline: The Sons Against the Widow
text: Four months after he remarried, my father died in an accident. During his brief second marriage, he often told family and friends, “What’s mine is mine, and what’s hers is hers,” indicating that he wanted his estate to go to me and my brother, as stipulated in his will. (My mother died from cancer about five years ago.) But New York law allows a spouse to claim about one-third of that, and his widow intends to, despite my father’s wishes, although she has resources of her own. This is legal, but is it ethical? NAME WITHHELD, LONG ISLAND

headline: The Headache That Wouldn’t Go Away
text: “My arm — something is biting my arm!” The 26-year-old woman struggled to sit up in bed. What’s wrong? her husband asked, alarmed and suddenly wide awake. His wife didn’t seem to hear him. Suddenly, her whole body began to jerk. Although he had never seen a seizure, the young man knew immediately that this was one. After a long and terrifying minute the jerking stopped and his wife lay quiet with her eyes closed, as if she were asleep. When he couldn’t wake her, he picked up the phone and dialed 911.

headline: Letters: Party and Punishment
text: While I agree wholeheartedly with Virginia Heffernan’s assessment in The Medium that the partying, out-of-control woman is a particular object of fear and revulsion, I find it unfortunate that she used my comments as grist for her argument. My comments are not reserved exclusively for celebrities — or for women. Let me be clear that I would have offered that same comment had the subject in question been a man. Furthermore, the use of my comments to support Heffernan’s thesis that we “demonize fun-loving women” requires a complete disregard for the context in which they originally were made. I was responding to a question about what lengths I would go to, as a father, should one of my children (I have 17-year-old triplets) develop a life-threatening addiction, all other measures having been exhausted.

headline: Letter: An Uncompromising Woman
text: Anyone who knows the situation in Liberia would take issue with Daniel Bergner’s characterization of President Sirleaf as an “uncompromising woman.” Any leader of a country in a situation like Liberia’s will have to compromise every day in every way with giant donors like the World Bank, the E.U. and the U.S. State Department, not to mention the competing interests and demands of a war-ravaged population and a political class that is constantly fighting over a very small plate of spoils.

headline: Letters: Coming Out Illegal
text: My husband and I both work to send our kids to college in California. We vote, pay taxes, do volunteer work and obey the law. The story about the illegal immigrants attending school with in-state tuition made us both livid. These illegals have no right to be in our country, and yet California, with huge financial problems, gives them in-state tuition! What’s wrong with this picture? Who gets to pick and choose which laws to enforce? Why should illegals get a break on anything?

headline: The Rise of the Tao
text: YIN XINHUI reached the peak of Mount Yi and surveyed the chaos. The 47-year-old Taoist abbess was on a sacred mission: to consecrate a newly rebuilt temple to one of her religion’s most important deities, the Jade Emperor. But there were as yet no stairs, just a muddy path up to the pavilion, which sat on a rock outcropping 3,400 feet above a valley. A team of workers was busy laying stone steps, while others planted sod, trees and flowers. Inside the temple, a breeze blew through windows that were still without glass, while red paint flecked the stone floor.

headline: Letters: Calling Mr. Mom?
text: What started as a discussion of women’s lack of parity in the workplace devolved into a discussion about parental roles and responsibilities in and outside the home. When will women’s lack of equality in the workplace be viewed as a valuable issue in its own right, rather than having to be related to motherhood? Parity has not been reached by childless women either, and we face the additional discrimination that workers without families face: the expectation that we cover for colleagues who are caring for sick children, work late because we don’t have to pick up kids and support financing for on-site child care. Maybe once we’ve made more progress for working mothers, we can focus on treating all workers equally, whether they choose to procreate or not.

headline: Letters: The D.I.Y. Foreign-Aid Revolution
text: It was a pleasure to read Nicholas D. Kristof’s article on “do it yourself” foreign assistance. The efforts of private American citizens to advance human-development causes at the community level are exceptional stories that are frequently untold.

headline: Prize Descriptions
text: I visit Wikipedia every day. I study the evolving entries for Internet-specific entities like World of Warcraft, Call of Duty, Foursquare and Picasa, often savoring the lucid exposition that Wikipedia brings to technical subjects that might not be expected to inspire poetry and for which no vocabulary has yet been set.

headline: When Brother Becomes Sister
text: When my brother Dennis, now known as Dee, announced that he was transsexual, he gave me the Jan Morris book “Conundrum.” He explained that before he could do anything drastic — that is, undergo what is delicately referred to as “gender-reassignment surgery” — he had to have permission from a psychiatrist and live as a woman for a year. I let myself hope that Dennis would be content to stay semi-in-the-closet so he could keep his job teaching music at a Catholic school in the Bronx, that he might be content to feel subversive playing the organ in the choir loft while wearing ladies’ underpants. I should have known better: Dennis had always been capable of achieving with surprising speed things that seemed impossible, like saving up from his paper route to buy a pool table while in grade school. Within days of telling me he was transsexual, he was taking hormones. They stopped hair from growing on his hands and arms, encouraged breasts to grow (but not enough to please him) and discouraged male hormones, causing, eventually, a form of chemical castration.

headline: Some People Find the Marathon Annoying
text: The New York City Marathon is this Sunday, which means thousands of runners making their way through every borough, innumerable fans, and many flavors of blaring music. Many regard the marathon as a joyous occasion, but others see it as a serious disruption in their lives, Trymaine Lee reports in The Times. And nowhere is the conflict between excited supporter and annoyed city dweller more apparent than at mile 21, or 138th Street in Harlem, when the marathon turns down Fifth Avenue for the final stretch. As some runners hit the wall and others push themselves for the finish, the race cuts a swath through the daily lives of the neighborhood’s residents, for good or ill.

headline: Citigroup Prevails in EMI Lawsuit
text: British financier Guy Hands had sought $8 billion from the banking giant over his ill-fated acquisition of the troubled music company EMI Group. The jury awarded him nothing.

headline: The Entente Frugale
text: Nickname for a new 50-year Anglo-French military treaty.

headline: Week 9 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Chiefs (5-2) at Raiders (4-4)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Raiders by 2 1/2The last time the weekly previews led off with a Chiefs-Raiders capsule, Len Dawson squared off against Daryle Lamonica, and Red Smith’s analysis was peppered with “Laugh-In” references.

headline: Why Zenyatta Matters
text: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for nearly 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. She is confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

headline: Stretch Work: From Young To Old(er)
text: ON the surface Jonah Bokaer is nearly ethereal, with brown eyes that melt and a tendency to speak in near-whispers. But when he laughs  hearty and devilish  a more tangible side shines through: it’s as if Mr. Bokaer, 29, is an old man stuck in a young person’s body.

headline: Friday Reading: High-Risk Health Insurance Programs
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Week Ahead: Nov. 7 — 13
text: Art

headline: Vain Glorious | Sex in a Bottle
text: When Frederic Malle, the master French perfumer, proclaims that his latest fragrance is one of his best ever, it’s nothing to sniff at. He knows from perfume. To celebrate his company’s 10-year anniversary, Mr. Malle teamed up with one of his favorite noses – Dominique Ropion- to create Portrait of a Lady, a heady mixture of ingredients such as Turkish rose essence, raspberry, cassis, cinnamon, patchouli heart, ambroxan and musk. The resulting scent- lushly feminine, with a sensually earthy dry-down courtesy of the patchouli- is fragrant proof that this lady has some serious sex appeal. Available next month for $280 (100 ml) at Barneys New York, or join the waiting list at Malle’s Editions de Parfum, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941.

headline: New York Philharmonic Gets Approval for Trip to Cuba
text: The New York Philharmonic’s Cuba strategy worked. The United States Treasury Department has issued a license for the orchestra to visit Havana sometime next year, a Philharmonic spokesman said in an e-mail late on Thursday. (The orchestra was in Luxembourg, wrapping up a European tour.) The Philharmonic last year canceled the trip because the Treasury Department had denied permission for its patrons — who were paying for the visit — to go along, viewing them as tourists and thus not allowed under United States sanctions. The orchestra tried to get around the problem by adding an educational concert and listing the patrons as docents. The spokesman, Eric Latzky, said approval came late Wednesday. The dates still have to be worked out.

headline: Putting Nutrition at the Head of the School Lunch Line
text: THE lunch menu at my son’s elementary school  Public School 29 in Brooklyn  looked very tempting recently: vegetarian chili, sofrito brown rice, confetti corn salad, pico de gallo, salad bar, milk. Making the menu even more appealing was the price: $1.50.

headline: Inside the List
text: SATISFACTION: Keith Richards’s autobiography, “Life” (reviewed by Liz Phair on the cover of the Nov. 14 Book Review), hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1, unsurprisingly. (My favorite line, from Page 524: “I’ve been cooking bangers all my life, and I only just found out from this lady on TV that you have to put bangers in a cold pan.”)

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Village Voice: Robert Sietsema’s 10 most challenging dishes in New York City. Respect. – Sam Sifton

headline: More About Password Security
text: In my post about password security last week, I suggested that a good way to come up with different passwords for every site without having to remember or store them is to make up a simple routine or algorithm that converts the name of a site into an eight-character password.

headline: Outside Boston, the Charming Larz Anderson Auto Museum
text: The Larz Anderson Auto Museum in Brookline, Mass., which bills itself as “America’s oldest car collection,” recently named a new curator and director of public programs, Sheldon Steele, who spoke of the museum’s origins in a recent interview at the museum.

headline: Jury Begins Deliberation on Penalty for Killer
text: NEW HAVEN  The jury considering the fate of the convicted killer in the Cheshire home-invasion case deliberated on his penalty for the first time on Friday and sent out two notes indicating a deep division on the central question of the trial: whether or not the defendant, Steven J. Hayes, is to be sentenced to die.

headline: Harmonious Is Ready for Her Close-Up
text: In a “bucket list” moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since — when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: A Long Way From Boy Chorister
text: IN “Elijah,” the Old Testament oratorio by Felix Mendelssohn, the prophet has but one bar to collect himself before cutting loose with 1 Kings 17:1 (“As God the Lord of Israel liveth, before whom I stand, there shall not be dew nor rain these years, but according to my word”). Then the overture begins, and Elijah takes his seat for about 20 minutes, until called on to bring a child back from the dead, rout the priests of Baal and deal with the wicked royals Ahab and Jezebel.

headline: A Man and His Bad Dreams: Coppola Turns a Nightmare Into a New Film
text: Just the memory of trying to get Marlon Brando to perform his lines in “Apocalypse Now” should be enough to provide Francis Ford Coppola with a lifetime of nightmares. But Mr. Coppola, the director whose films include “The Godfather” and “The Outsiders,” dreams of more universal terrors, and it was one such vision that inspired his coming film, “Twixt Now and Sunrise,” which he is currently shooting and plans to release next year.

headline: Another Volcanic Eruption Raises Death Toll in Indonesia
text: An overnight blast from Mount Merapi pushed the number of deaths to more than 100 and spewed ash over several villages.

headline: Medina Senghore and Kareem Collie
text: WHILE rules are useful  if not essential  to establishing order in a love life, the trick is knowing the precise moment to throw them out.

headline: Beyond Tourism
text: The conviction that traveling in general, and walking in particular, can bring inspiration and even enlightenment is a very ancient one, and it exists in many cultures across the globe. As the old adage, taken up by the wandering scholars of medieval Europe, had it, “Solvitur ambulando” (“It is solved by walking”). In the sixth century B.C., the Indian saint Mahavira is said to have received enlightenment while walking, and the idea is still current. I recently met an itinerant Jain nun who told me: “This wandering life, with no material possessions, unlocks our souls. There is a wonderful sense of lightness, living each day as it comes.” For her, journey and destination became one, thought and action became one.

headline: Cuban Plane Crash Kills 68 People
text: MEXICO CITY  Working amid dense thickets of thorny trees, rescue workers retrieved cockpit voice and data recorders on Friday from the wreckage of a plane that crashed in central Cuba, killing all 68 people aboard, Cuban media reported.

headline: Neighborhood Watch
text: In three previous novels and a book of short fiction, Gish Jen draped her characters’ troubles in a mood of antic good humor, then gradually allowed those troubles to reveal themselves. In “Typical American,” readers came to understand, through Jen’s adroit storytelling, the disappointments beneath the resilience of the Chinese immigrants Ralph and Helen Chang; in “Mona in the Promised Land,” Jen gave us the identity struggles of the couple’s American-born daughter. Still more complex were the varieties of emotional experience among the Wong family in “The Love Wife,” whose chorus of voices began with an exuberant clamor and ended up somber, reflective and hushed.

headline: The Diary of a Killer in Chechnya
text: Every so often a lengthy newspaper or magazine article arrives that all but demands a fuller and even longer treatment. Such was the case in the Oct 31. issue of The Sunday Times magazine in London, which published translated excerpts from the diary of a Russian spetsnaz officer who served for more than a decade as one of the Kremlin’s shadowy fighters in the Chechen wars. (Access to the article is protected by a pay-to-view firewall; to read it, you’ll have to buy at least a temporary subscription.)

headline: Wall Street Schadenfreude
text: By HEIDI N. MOORE

headline: Jousting Justices
text: In these equable days on the Supreme Court, when dissents are fashioned as polite disagreements and Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg are the best of friends, it is hard to imagine a time when the court was a roiling caldron of ill will. But so it has been at various points in its history — “nine scorpions in a bottle,” in the phrase attributed, perhaps erroneously, to Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.

headline: Cuba Dance Notebook: It’s the Dancers Turn to Watch
text: HAVANA – The dancers of American Ballet Theater and a few members of New York City Ballet had the chance to rest their legs and watch a bit of dancing themselves during a visit Thursday to Cuba’s National Ballet School.

headline: Rock Star
text: View slide show >>

headline: In Oregon, Elder Sleuths Size Up Local Businesses
text: File under: What a smart idea.

headline: Application Inflation, and Extra Time on the SAT and ACT for Students with Disabilities
text: The latest edition of Education Life, The Times’s quarterly supplement, will be published this weekend and, as always, there is lots of “news you can use” for college applicants and their families.

headline: 90 Chefs, 340 Waiters and a Sea of Rabbis
text: David Scharf is planning a little get-together on Sunday in Brooklyn: dinner for 4,500 Hasidic rabbis.

headline: Wasting Away
text: You know those delicate debut novels, the ones that take place in coastal Maine, in which, if the author is searching for any truth at all, it’s only for a small, particular one? Well, “Hate: A Romance,” Tristan Garcia’s first effort, is not among them. It’s frenetic and French, for a reader who knows Deleuze from Derrida, who will chuckle when Garcia refers to the “domestic troubles” of Althusser. (That’s a joke, by the way, but you may need Wikipedia to figure it out. I did.)

headline: The Lay of the Land
text: Where are we? Answers drift across the woods and salt marshes in John Casey’s beautiful, elegiac new novel. One person after another takes a bearing, sets a course, loses the way, makes a correction.

headline: Extra Time for College Admissions Tests
text: Students with learning disabilities or attention deficit problems can ask for special accommodations when taking college admissions tests. However, guidance counselors and disabilities advocates say the process can be onerous, an issue explained in today’s Education Life feature.

headline: Macy’s, Like Journey, Doesn’t Stop Believing
text: For the third holiday season in a row, the Macy’s division of Macy’s Inc. will run a Christmas campaign that carries the theme “Believe.”

headline: Growth on a Finite Planet – So Far, So Good
text: .When was the last time the United Nations issued a major report that was upbeat? They exist but are hard to find. Well, this week’s release of the 2010 Human Development Report, on the 20th anniversary of this effort to track human progress, was summarized this way:

headline: A World Unto Themselves
text: When Leo Tolstoy formulated his dictum that all happy families are alike, he overlooked at least one counterexample, albeit drawn from a world quite foreign to his own: the household of John and Abigail Adams. “The happiness of our family,” Abigail noted in 1788, “seems ever to have been so interwoven with the politics of our country as to be in a great degree dependent upon them.”

headline: Wages And The Slide Toward Deflation
text: I get a fair number of comments to the effect that worries about deflation are all wrong, look at commodity prices. I’ve tried in the past to explain why we should focus on sluggish, sticky prices, not volatile prices like commodities — hence core inflation. But let me add another point: arguably the stickiest, sluggishiest prices are those of labor. So why not focus on wages?

headline: Up Front: Eliza Griswold
text: As the daughter of the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, Eliza Griswold brought along some unusual personal baggage when she set out to research “The Tenth Parallel,” her recent book about the clash between — and within — Islam and Christianity along a geographical line from West Africa to Indonesia.

headline: The Nobelist and the Pygmies
text: Whether he sets his tales in Africa, England, his native Trinidad or anywhere else, V. S. Naipaul is always writing about V. S. Naipaul. In this respect, “The Masque of Africa: Glimpses of African Belief,” his 30th book and 16th volume of nonfiction, is not different. This latest journey to the continent is part of a larger whole, the developing narrative of a single consciousness.

headline: Hundreds Were Raped on Congo-Angola Border
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than 600 women and girls were recently raped along the Congo-Angola border during a mass expulsion of illegal immigrants, according to the United Nations.

headline: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: Police-Car Windows Smashed in Brooklyn; Suspect Is Shot
text: Updated, 4:29 p.m. | A man who smashed the windshield of a police car with a large rock in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, early Friday morning was shot during a scuffle with an officer who confronted him, the police said.

headline: Far From the Track, a Horseplayer Makes His Picks
text: I remember way back in the golden age of racing, that being three years ago for me, looking forward to the sport’s biggest day. The Breeder’s Cup, was the day I marked on the calendar months in advance and couldn’t wait for it to get here. It was the bright light in my dreary existence. I knew that somehow, someway, I would be at a simulcast center enjoying my favorite day of the year. But alas, all good things must come to an end, at least in my life. There is no simulcast center available anymore in my area. Due to time and budget constraints, venturing further away from home is inapplicable at this time. Now, the day that couldn’t get here soon enough, is taking too long to go away.

headline: Is That Bottle Talking to Me?
text: When you’re selling vodka, a product that has what some critics say is a limited differential of taste, purveyors of ultrapremium brands have had to find other ways to compete.

headline: An Uncertain Nuclear Countdown
text: If the clock is ticking on the lifetime of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, when will it actually close?

headline: Grace and Culture Intertwined
text: American Indian art is some of the most beautiful ever made anywhere on earth. Some of us have loved it as long as we can remember. And with a new permanent-collection installation at the National Museum of the American Indian in Lower Manhattan, we can love it even more.

headline: Better All the Time
text: The thesis of Kevin Kelly’s bold new book begins with its title. How can technology — an inanimate collection of human inventions — want anything? According to Kelly, a professional tech-watcher and former editor of Wired magazine, it’s because technology is like a living organism, animated by the same evolutionary forces that resulted, over eons, in the human brain. Moreover, for Kelly, the whole process has been progressive and predictable: the eventual appearance of the BlackBerry was immanent in the Big Bang.

headline: The Renault Engine Deals
text: People at the Red Bull team, which has dominated the season with 14 pole positions in 17 races and with seven victories, spent much of the season complaining about a lack of power from its Renault engines. On Thursday, Christian Horner, the team director, responded to a remark from the Ferrari team director — who said if he had the Red Bull car his team would have won the title already — by saying that if he had the Ferrari engine his team would have won the title already.

headline: The Renault Engine Deals
text: People at the Red Bull team, which has dominated the season with 14 pole positions in 17 races and with seven victories, spent much of the season complaining about a lack of power from its Renault engines. On Thursday, Christian Horner, the team director, responded to a remark from the Ferrari team director — who said if he had the Red Bull car his team would have won the title already — by saying that if he had the Ferrari engine his team would have won the title already.

headline: Holy Warrior
text: Who better to review a 1,000-page Jewish book that comes out in the fall than the author of an 800-page Jewish book that came out in the spring? Adam Levin’s first novel, “The Instructions,” appears a summer after my own novel “Witz,” whose title translates to “joke,” though it’s no laughing matter: it’s about the Last Jew in the World. And did you hear the one about Chaim, who was stranded on a desert island? When the rescuers finally arrived they found he’d built two fully equipped synagogues out of palm trunks and homemade rope. Curious, they asked him, “Why two?” Chaim answered, “One I pray in, the other I’ll never step foot in.” In the spirit of that joke, consider one of our books the Jewish novel you’ll never begin and the other the Jewish novel you’ll never finish.

headline: Lost in Juárez
text: The veteran British journalist Ed Vulliamy is visiting Ciudad Juárez, epicenter of Mexican border violence, when a massacre occurs at a drug rehabilitation clinic in an impoverished neighborhood on the outskirts of town. The year before, more than 1,700 people had been killed in Ciudad Juárez; in the previous week, 75 were slain, including one who was beheaded. Ciudad Juárez has the world’s highest homicide rate. And drug gangs armed with military-grade weapons usually reserved for professional soldiers all but control the city. The day after the massacre, Vulliamy rushes to the clinic and produces a gruesome report.

headline: Weekend Competition: Emotive Conjugations
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise what the philosopher Bertrand Russell called “emotive conjugations” – irregular verbs which encapsulate a moral flexibility by which we judge others more harshly than ourselves.

headline: Now Online | T Design & Living Winter 2010
text: The Yankees may not have made it all the way this year, but T’s winter Design & Living issue offers plenty of good reasons to cheer for the home team. Our cover story singles out half a dozen young designers who are making it big in the Big Apple. Elsewhere in the issue, Pilar Viladas tours the architect Tom Kundig’s latest house and discovers it to be as comfortable on the inside as it is rugged on the outside; Sandra Ballentine drops in on the public art maven Yvonne Force Villareal and gets an eyeful of her colorful private life; and William Middleton visits a little modern house on a big freeway. We meet the knit wit Donna Wilson, whose kooky creature comforts are on display this month at the Future Perfect stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and shadow the design world’s stealth supplier, the American born, Zurich-based dealer Arthur Rooks. Jonathan Adler rekindles an old flame — the Malm floating fireplace — and Fred A. Bernstein writes about the horrors of being a houseguest. No place like home indeed!

headline: Jobs Are Growing, Even in Manufacturing
text: Just after the election, we learn that the jobs numbers were better than we thought. I’m sure President Obama was pleased when he got the word.

headline: Recipes From the Cabbage Patch
text: For home cooks on a budget, cabbage remains one of the best culinary bargains around, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Get Me Out of Here
text: A  month before the invasion of Iraq, in the grim winter of 2003, officials in the Bush White House invited me and one of my colleagues to come discuss their plans for post-Saddam Iraq. Publicly, President Bush had not yet chosen to go to war. But the decision was so pre­ordained that his top national security aides were eager to explain that they had thought through the endgame in a way no previous occupants of their offices had when Washington went to war in Korea, Vietnam or the Persian Gulf. For several hours they described their detailed plans to remove the Baathist leadership and replace it with technocrats who would get the country humming again. The United States and its allies would quickly become a light-footprint peacekeeping force.

headline: Fox News Topped Networks on Vote Night
text: The Fox News Channel’s midterm election coverage attracted more viewers than any of the broadcast networks’ coverage, according to the Nielsen Company.

headline: Soccer Matchups to Watch This Weekend
text: SATURDAY

headline: Hard Times
text: The economic recession that never seems to end for working-class Americans is making itself felt in the crime fiction of authors whose regional roots run deep. Dennis Lehane, not the cheeriest of writers in the best of times, seems downright depressed about the way things are going in New England. In MOONLIGHT MILE (Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99), he brings back Patrick Kenzie, the private detective from Dorchester, Mass., whose anti-establishment attitude and “class rage” fueled the violence of his earliest novels, to paint a bleak picture of nice towns coming apart at the seams.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FINISHING THE HAT: Collected Lyrics (1954-1981) With Attendant Comments, Principles, Heresies, Grudges, Whines and Anecdotes,  by Stephen Sondheim (Knopf, $39.95.) Sondheim’s analysis of his songs and those of others is both stinging and insightful.

headline: A Different Kind of Sex Talk With Teens
text: The age at which Europeans and Americans first have sex is the same — 17, on average, on both sides of the Atlantic. The percentage who use birth control from the start? In Holland it’s 64 percent and in the United States it’s 26 percent. The percentage who have regrets about their first time, wishing they had waited: 63 percent of boys and 69 percent of girls in the United States, and only 5 percent of boys and 12 percent of girls in the Netherlands. Teen pregnancy rates: three to six times higher here than in Western Europe. S.T.D. rates: 20 to 30 times higher here than Holland. H.I.V. rate? Theirs is six times lower.

headline: Paperback Row
text: WHEN EVERYTHING CHANGED: The Amazing Journey of American Women From 1960 to the Present, by Gail Collins. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.99.) From downtrodden secretaries in the 1960s to the campaigns of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Sarah Palin, this is a smart, engaging look at American women’s strides and the hurdles they still face. Collins, a columnist for the New York Times Op-Ed page, combines capsule histories and the drama of the era with the memories of regular women who lived through it all. These were times, Collins writes, in which women “were not meant to compete with men, to act independently of men. . . . Then, suddenly, everything changed. The cherished convictions about women and what they could do were smashed in the lifetime of many of the women living today.” SARAH FROM ALASKA:  The Sudden Rise and Brutal Education of a New Conservative Superstar, by Scott Conroy and Shushannah Walshe. (PublicAffairs, $15.95.) Conroy and Walshe covered Palin’s vice-presidential campaign for CBS and Fox News, respectively, and their book underscores the vigor of her crusading populism and a political record that is decidedly blurred. MOLLY IVINS: A Rebel Life, by Bill Minutaglio and W. Michael Smith. (PublicAffairs, $15.95.) Self-invention is a central thread in this biography of the witty, passionate liberal columnist who died in 2007.

headline: Five-Link Friday: Sacrilege Takes Various Forms
text: Among the many reasons to be thankful you live in a such a diverse city, there is this: Diwali. For it is on this Friday that the Department of Transportation recognizes the Hindu festival of lights, and in its municipal beneficence, suspends alternate side of the street parking rules. Hallelujah.

headline: China Assails Nobel Peace Prize as ‘Card’ of West
text: BEIJING  Accelerating its assault on the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, China denounced the prize on Friday as a political tool of the West, and an official warned that countries acknowledging the honor would “bear the consequences.”

headline: Behind the Scenes, a Race of Logistics
text: With more than 43,000 participants, 2.5 million spectators and a course that stretches over 26.2 miles and 5 boroughs, the New York City Marathon is more than a sporting event, it is a vast international spectacle.

headline: India on $200 Million a Day? Not!
text: Critics of President Obama’s are abuzz with the charge that the American government will spend $200 million a day, or a total of $2 billion, to send the president on the 10-day mission to four countries that began today.

headline: Family Celebrates Life of Slain N.B.A. Player on His Birthday
text: It’s good sometimes to get a reminder about what really matters in life. Arguments over playing time, controversies over Twitter posts and other daily dramas in the hoops world do not seem to be that important in the long run.

headline: It’s Beauty-and-the-Beast Time Again
text: “A global initiative unprecedented in National Geographic Society’s storied 122-year history.”

headline: Young Wall Street Parties Like It’s 2007
text: If its after-hours parties are any indication, Wall Street is officially back in business.

headline: Sony: The Ghost of Christmas Past
text: When I was a kid (around 25 years ago), Christmas was a time of family, food and the searing-hot hope that I would be in possession of some new gadget come the morning of Dec. 25. And no matter what that gadget was, it was likely to have one common feature: The name “Sony” printed somewhere on it.

headline: Is That Bottle Talking to Me?
text: Eric A. Taub, over on Gadgetwise, talks about a new bottle of vodka from a Dutch company that uses LED technology to stand out from the crowd. An electronic band of bright blue lights can be programmed to display one of three scrolling messages, with each one up to 255 characters in length. Luckily for those who like to store their vodka in the fridge,even in sub-zero temperatures, the display keeps on working.

headline: A Yearbook Dedicated to Inclusion
text: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J.

headline: So, Runner, What’s on Your iPod?
text: When the announcement came last week that the Sony Walkman was no more, I got nostalgic. That little yellow box and its successors changed my relationship with music — and running.

headline: Pregame Huddle: Fight for No. 1
text: Oregon has earned its No. 1 ranking, but teams like Alabama and Auburn are still in the hunt.

headline: The Morning Line: There’s News Beyond Zenyatta
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: When the Economy Revs, Trucks Roar
text: There is a truism in Detroit that the health of the economy can often be gauged by sales of trucks. Now, as the economy seems to be recovering, albeit slowly, more ad campaigns for truck brands are being introduced.

headline: A Fan’s Guide to Booing, N.H.L. Version
text: To boo or not to boo? That is the question, at least according to Maple Leafs General Manager Brian Burke, who this week called Toronto fans disgraceful for booing the team’s captain, Dion Phaneuf. But is he right?

headline: A Star to Steer By
text: You know the Little Prince, of course: the golden hair and ruddy cheeks, the long scarf trailing in the Sahara wind, all familiar from Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s beloved 1943 parable. But what about the pilot? Saint-Exupéry made sketches of the narrator of “The Little Prince,” but the airman — whose crash-landing gives the Prince’s planet­-hopping philosophical adventures their frame — never makes an appearance in the book’s final version.

headline: Angels, Demons and Blockbusters
text: For an industry supposedly in decline, book publishing still offers welcome surprises. Years ago, anyone who admitted to writing young adult books — more likely, “books for teens” —at a cocktail party would be faced with a blank look. “Are you ever going to write a real novel?” was the common response. But ever since the success of books as different as Laurie Halse Anderson’s “Speak” (1999), a grittily realistic portrait of sexual violence in high school, and “Twilight,” it’s become clear that writers have at least as much freedom in Y.A. books as they do in adult fiction, as well as an audience that is loyal, smart and self-renewing. Sherman Alexie, Nick Hornby, Jane Smiley and Oscar Hijuelos write for young people now, and if they see fit to mention it at a party, they are likely to hear, “How can I get into that?”

headline: Spellbound
text: Salman Rushdie’s new children’s novel arrives under circumstances that are, to put it mildly, less anxious than those that surrounded his first, “Haroun and the Sea of Stories” (1990). Rushdie has said he conceived “Haroun” before the fatwa that was issued in response to “The Satanic Verses,” in 1989. But “Haroun” was difficult to detach from its fraught moment. After all, its hero was struggling against forces determined to silence storytelling, a plot point that couldn’t help reminding you that the author was, too.

headline: Interactive Books (‘E’ Not Included)
text: Years ago, I was a supporter of a new literary movement, one that uprooted the traditional tenets of narrative in modern fiction: Choose Your Own Adventure.

headline: When Stories Had Sharp Teeth
text: When I was 10, I found an ancient collection of Grimm fairy tales in the basement. I cracked the dusty black cover, not expecting much (I knew Cinderella and Snow White and their stupid hair and trilling voices from movies I’d outgrown) and was transfixed. These stories were sick, serious and bloody. Cinderella’s sisters did what to their feet? I sat on that cold basement floor and read the entire thick volume (a 1920 version, with sinuous Art Deco illustrations by Elenore Abbott).

headline: A Life Preserved in Clay
text: The slaves best known to most Americans are ones who escaped. Harriet Tubman, Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth: fugitives and then freedom fighters. Very rarely do we hear about individual slaves who made a name for themselves while in bondage. One who did, quite literally, was an extraordinary artist known by his first name only: Dave.

headline: BMW to Build Megacity Electric Car in Leipzig
text: “When you get your driver’s licenses in 10 years you will drive an electric BMW,” Norbert Reithofer, chief executive of BMW, said to the children of workers at the automaker’s factory in Leipzig, Germany, on Friday.

headline: No Food Network or HGTV as Scripps and AT&T Feud
text: There is another programming blackout affecting AT&T U-verse customers — but this time the programmer says it’s not about money.

headline: Serving Up Healthful School Lunches
text: Today’s Patient Money focuses on school lunch money, how it’s spent and what you get for it.

headline: Seasoned Collaborators, Back on Track
text: JOHN FORD found his muse in the laconic, masculine John Wayne, while Don Siegel liked featuring a taciturn Clint Eastwood in his thrillers. The director Tony Scott has found his go-to hero, an often flawed, seemingly ordinary guy who rises to the occasion, in the Oscar winner Denzel Washington. Together the unlikely pairing of the British action director who specializes in fast-paced, stylized action flicks (“Top Gun,” “The Last Boy Scout”) and an American leading man typically associated for his stirring portrayals of inspirational men like Malcolm X and the football coach Herman Boone, have made five films together. In their latest, “Unstoppable”  the others are “Crimson Tide,” “Man on Fire,” “Déjà Vu” and “The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3,” from last year  Mr. Washington plays a veteran engineer who must safely halt an out-of-control locomotive in Pennsylvania carrying combustible liquids, with or without the assistance of his headstrong rookie conductor (Chris Pine). The movie is loosely based on an actual incident in which a train in Ohio traveled 66 miles without a crew member on board.

headline: TimesCast | November 5, 2010
text: Threat of flooding in Haiti; a better-than-expected jobs report and politics in the social media age.

headline: The Alessi Effect
text: For the last three decades, the Italian home products manufacturer Alessi has been at the forefront of design, producing instant icons like Michael Graves’s bird-whistle teakettle (above), Philippe Starck’s infamous Juicy Salif juicer and Richard Sapper’s elegant espresso pot — a fixture on many a yuppie’s high-end cooktop. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is celebrating the 90-year-old company with an exhibition, ‘‘Alessi: Ethical and Radical,’’ which opens Nov. 21. Central to Alessi’s success is its creative mastermind, Alberto Alessi, a grandson of the founder, who has run the company since the 1970s. ‘‘He’s absolutely unique in the amount of time and money that he has spent on design,’’ said Kathryn Hiesinger, the exhibition’s curator. Included in the show are planned reissues of designs from the 1920s, ’30s and ’40s, a time that Alberto Alessi describes as ‘‘predesign,’’ before the rise of glossy ‘‘designer’’ products — which is ironic coming from the man who helped invent the category. But, as Heisinger explained, ‘‘Alberto is now in his minimalist, simplicity mode; he’s against overdesign.’’ Well, he’s been right before.

headline: QE Madness
text: It has been really interesting to watch some of the commentary over quantitative easing by the Fed: while people like me see the Fed’s actions as way too timid, there’s a substantial faction out there that sees them as the end of Western civilization. Right now the most popular story on Bloomberg is Jim Rogers saying that Bernanke doesn’t understand economics, that he’s “debasing the currency.”

headline: Breaking Down Day 2 of the Breeders’ Cup
text: Matt Carothers is the host of “:58 Flat” and “Blinkers Off” on TVG, as well as being one its regular analysts. He started playing the horses long before the law allows.

headline: Benmosche: ‘I’m Feeling Very Good’
text: While the American International Group continues its effort to remove the federal government’s massive ownership stake in itself — incurring a $2.4 billion loss for its third quarter in the process — there’s another consideration hanging over the insurer: the health of its chief executive.

headline: Pelosi Says She Wants to Remain House Democratic Leader
text: WASHINGTON — Despite steep losses for her party in Tuesday’s elections, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California said on Friday that she would run to remain the leader of the House Democrats, even as some of her colleagues urged her to step down.

headline: When ‘Poison’ Was a Cinematic Antidote
text: A MILESTONE in American independent film and the inciting spark for what came to be known as the New Queer Cinema, Todd Haynes’s first feature, “Poison” (1991), has always stood for much more than itself. “The whole world is dying of panicky fright,” reads its opening title, an apt epigraph for a contemplation of difference, affliction and stigma that arrived at the height of the AIDS crisis and became a lightning rod in the culture wars of the 1990s.

headline: Tevye Remembers: Harvey Fierstein on Bock and Stein and ‘Fiddler’
text: The recent deaths of Jerry Bock and Joseph Stein, two of the creators of the musical “Fiddler on the Roof,” prompted us to ask Harvey Fierstein, Broadway’s most recent Tevye, to reflect on the show and its meaning. His reminiscence follows:

text: THE GIST Men keen on a short-term relationship are more interested in checking out a woman’s body than are those looking for long-term love.

headline: Debunking the Myths of the Midterm
text: Every election develops its own mythology, usually before the official results are even certified, and this week’s was no different. And like all mythology, the narrative that is being woven around the midterm elections by Bulfinches from both parties is a blend of history, facts and, yes, myths.

text: Kevin Clauson has been on the job as an associate at a law firm for less than a week, and he has not yet needed to get a single stitch.

headline: When ‘Best’ Isn’t Good Enough
text: A FEW years ago I got this note from a mother in my son’s class. “Hey, we both end our e-mails with ‘Carpe Diem’! Hope the parents in class won’t confuse us, ha-ha!” Naturally I thought she was kidding, and wrote back saying our different names might be a tip-off we were not the same person. “Oh, sure,” she said, “but I’ve used ‘Carpe Diem’ forever. People know me by that one. It would be great if you used something else from now on. Thanks!”

headline: Charging Ahead in First Big Wave Contest for Women
text: LINCOLN CITY, Ore.  Women have surfed some of the biggest and scariest waves known to man. They have challenged the towering peaks at the break called Mavericks in northern California. They have elbowed into the crowded wave lineup on Hawaii’s North Shore. They have pulled into heavily loaded barrels of water at Teahupoo in Tahiti. But they had never had their own big wave contest  until Wednesday.

headline: Nebraska Attorney General Looking at Senate
text: The 2012 election cycle is up and running.

headline: Leaked Video Shows Clash at Sea Between Chinese and Japanese Ships
text: Japan’s government is trying to find out how video clips, apparently shot by its Coast Guard during a confrontation with a Chinese trawler in September, ended up on YouTube this week.

headline: Need to Know
text: SHORTAGE AND DEMAND As the population ages and as 30 million newly insured enter the system in the wake of health care legislation, the market for nurses is among the largest projected for any occupation. Between 2008 and 2018, more than 580,000 jobs have to be filled, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics — a 22 percent increase over today.

headline: Modern Vintage
text: A Zaha Hadid-designed wine tasting pavilion (above) or stemless Riedel wineglass may seem commonplace now. But they are manifestations of a cultural shift that happened after the so-called Judgment of Paris in 1976, in which a number of California wines were deemed superior to their French counterparts. On Nov. 20, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art will open ‘‘How Wine Became Modern: Design and Wine 1976 to Now.’’ Organized by Henry Urbach, the museum’s curator of architecture and design, the exhibition — which is designed by the architects Diller Scofidio and Renfro — explores the evolution of wine’s visual and material culture. It includes a gallery devoted to the subject of terroir, a commissioned wall work by Peter Wegner that charts more than 200 paint colors with names like Cabernet and Crush, and a look at, among other issues, the effect of architecture on wine tourism. The museum knows the subject well, having organized the first architectural competition for the design of a winery, in 1985. The winner was the architect-artist team of Michael Graves and Edward Schmidt, resulting in Clos Pegase, the prototype of the modern designer winery.

headline: 45, Male and Now a Nurse
text: BALTIMORE’S gritty Levindale section is a world apart from Ponce Inlet, Fla., the upscale barrier island where Rich Van Rensselaer owned a boutique liquor store and coffee shop before becoming a trauma nurse. If you had asked Mr. Van Rensselaer in 2004 if he thought he would trade in life in Margaritaville for scenes from “The Wire” — treating gunshot wounds, drug overdoses and unmanaged diabetes in one of the city’s busiest emergency rooms — he might have assumed you had been to one too many of his wine-tasting events.

headline: The China Boom
text: IN her ballroom dance class, Li Wanrong has learned to tango and cha-cha. At lunch one day, she tried a strange mix of flavors — pepperoni pizza, the spicy sausage and oozing cheese nearly burning her tongue. Then there was that Friday night before going clubbing for the first time when new friends gave her a makeover, and she looked in the mirror to see an American girl smiling back wearing a little black dress, red lipstick and fierce eyeliner.

headline: What Do You Mean I Can’t Take This Course?
text: WINDSOR G. HANGER, a 2010 Harvard graduate from Asheville, N.C., had been excited to finally squeeze in a course called “Painting Day and Night” senior year after recreational dabbling while in high school. But then she showed up the first day to find 25 others with a similar vision. Thirteen would have to disappear. To her shock, the instructor sprung an impromptu test, asking everyone to spend the next few hours painting still lifes.

headline: There’s More Than One Way to Apply to College
text: AS if college hopefuls didn’t have enough decisions to make, here’s one more: which application to use.

headline: The Perfect (College) Match
text: CHOOSING a compatible college is a life decision right up there with choosing a compatible mate, and the new service WiseChoice.com leverages that analogy. Students complete a five-part questionnaire whose Likert-scale cross-examinations resemble a dating site’s, and for good reason. “eHarmony was our model,” says Lori Grandstaff, a vice president. The profile, along with academic and financial input, informs the free computer-generated psychoanalysis.

headline: Algebra Refigured, Totally
text: MATH is not an easy subject. For many, the corollary conclusion is that learning math is unavoidably unpleasant.

headline: On the College Essay
text: “Generally, topics about bodily functions, body parts, how much you love your boyfriend/girlfriend, or a play-by-play of your game-winning goal don’t say much about how you will contribute to a small community.” And “Proof-reading is essential — make sure you aren’t writing about ‘Muslin’ extremism or being ‘abducted’ into the National Honor Society.”

headline: A Is for Abstinence
text: BELOW is a handy chart for abstinence advocates. A study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has found a decided link between celibacy and good grades. Among high school students who earn mostly A’s, 32 percent have had intercourse, compared with 69 percent of their peers with D’s and F’s. And on risk-taking measures like consuming alcohol or using condoms, the better students were also the more cautious.

headline: Going Clubbing
text: THE student tour guide probably recognized the dazed look on our faces. We had driven six hours through cornfields to visit Grinnell College. The Iowa cornfields ended at the very edge of campus. “We are in the middle of nowhere,” he acknowledged.

headline: Loan Payback
text: ON Oct. 28, the Department of Education published new rules meant to protect students from overly aggressive and deceptive recruiting by for-profit institutions, and to provide consumers with information like whether graduates earn enough to pay back their student loans. The government has zeroed in on for-profit programs as the industry has grown — enrollment tripled from 2000 to 2008, to 1.8 million — and as federal student aid they dole out has increased nearly sixfold. (Recent video shot by secret shoppers with the Government Accountability Office shows recruiters misleading applicants about potential earnings and financial aid.)

headline: At Registration, to the Savvy Go the Spoils
text: NEXT week, undergraduates at New York University will go online in the middle of lectures or skulk out of classes where computers aren’t allowed. Over the last few weeks, Cornell students set their alarms at sunrise.

headline: Banning the Bottle
text: STUDENTS’ new green cause: promoting that most quotidian of beverages — tap water. According to the Earth Policy Institute, 86 percent of plastic water bottles in the United States end up as garbage. Not to mention the $2 students shell out for a bottle.

headline: Looking for Students Like Me!
text: IT was early in my junior year, before my college search had begun in earnest, that the letters started coming. It began as a trickle, but I was quickly inundated. One stands out in my mind: a letter informing me in a manner both presumptuous and peremptory that “at long last” my college search was over. Soon after, I received a letter from clairvoyant admissions officials at another college, asking me to gaze into the future with them and envision myself at their school. Having already learned of the end to my college search, I was confused to find myself frolicking on the greens of another university.

headline: Week 10 College Football Matchups
text: The first week of November is a melancholy time in college football. The season is in full swing, but the end is in sight. A good or bad start can be erased with wins or losses in November. This week the Mountain West takes center stage as a pair of top-five teams battles for a conference crown as well as maybe a spot in a Bowl Championship Series game (or even a shot at a national title). In the South, Alabama travels to Baton Rouge with the SEC West in the balance. At the same time, Texas Christian plays Utah. It would be a good Saturday to be in front of several televisions. Oklahoma State hosts Baylor (yes, Baylor) with each team in control of its destiny in the Big 12 South. There is a logjam at the top of the Big 10. How will that shake out? There are only a few Saturdays left.

headline: Where Did God Go in Afghanistan?
text: Ten thousand feet over Fort Benning, Ga., and I was praying for my life. Literally. I was about to jump out of a C-130 airplane to earn my Airborne “wings.” I desperately wanted my chute to open. Under my breath, I whispered Isaiah 40:31: “but those who hope in the LORD/will renew their strength./They will soar on wings like eagles.” At service the day before, the minister had handed out bookmarks inscribed with that passage.

Though 20th Century Fox Home Video is releasing the collection — Fox controls eight of the films in the set (four of which are appearing on DVD for the first time) — it also includes important Kazan films from Sony (“On the Waterfront”) and Warner Brothers (“East of Eden,” but also “Baby Doll,” “A Face in the Crowd,” “Splendor in the Grass” and “America America,” making its DVD debut).

headline: Interactive: Bush Addresses 9/11 Policy Controversies in Memoir
text: Former President George W. Bush’s forthcoming memoir, “Decision Points,” will probably receive close scrutiny by people who have followed the legal and policy debates that arose over his administration’s approach to the war on terrorism. The book, obtained by The New York Times ahead of its publication date, covers, among other topics, five areas that address Mr. Bush’s use of presidential powers and his view of executive authority. In an interactive feature, The Times’s Charlie Savage takes a closer look at Mr. Bush’s decisions.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Stacy Schiff on the Life of Cleopatra
text: This week: Stacy Schiff discusses her new biography, “Cleopatra: A Life”; Julie Just looks back on her five years as the Book Review’s children’s books editor; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: Onyewu and Ibrahimovic Come to Blows at Milan Practice
text: There’s always tension between attackers and defenders who regularly do battle on the soccer field. Even in training, players on the same team can develop a tense rivalry. But things boiled over at Milanello on Friday during an A.C. Milan training session, according to multiple reports from Italy, including this one, in Italian, from La Gazetta dello Sport.

headline: Exploring Trusts for the Disabled
text: With the battle over taxes and estate planning techniques about to heat up, one type of planning vehicle has avoided contentious debate: the special-needs trust. These trusts are supposed to supplement the benefits a disabled person receives from the government  paying for additional services or equipment not otherwise covered  but not to supplant them.

headline: Antibiotics Research Subsidies Weighed by U.S.
text: Worried about an impending public health crisis, government officials are considering offering financial incentives to the pharmaceutical industry, like tax breaks and patent extensions, to spur the development of vitally needed antibiotics.

headline: Fighting the Alienating Newspeak Gobbledygook
text: As a modern prayer, this might serve: Lord, spare us from the tedium and pettiness of office life! Of course the qualities that make an office soul-chilling also make it the perfect setting for absurdist satire, a form that had special relevance for writers in the old Eastern bloc countries yearning to speak free. And what better stand-in for the state, with all its baffling whims and cruelties, than the office?

headline: Dr. Weil’s Simple Roasted Root Vegetables
text: Sometime the best foods at Thanksgiving are the simplest, cooked in their natural state with minimal spices to let the original flavor shine through.

headline: Fed Chief Defends Action in Face of Criticism
text: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Friday defended the central bank’s decision to inject $600 billion into the American economy, in the face of objections from European and Asian officials about the weakening of the dollar that is likely to result from the action.

headline: On the Run in New York
text: On Sunday, 45,344 runners traversed all five boroughs in the 41st running of the New York City Marathon. Review the race route to the right and photos from the marathon.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 5
text: Photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Dead Coral Found Near Gulf Oil Well
text: Dead and dying coral reefs were found this week in a survey of the sea floor near BP’s blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico, scientists say. The scientists say it it highly likely that the reefs were damaged by the BP oil spill.

headline: Following Tradition at Army, After Detour at Air Force
text: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Inside Army’s practice facility, a good punt away from Michie Stadium, Jared Hassin bolted out of his stance in the backfield and turned the right corner with an option pitch, leaving only a view of the No. 7 on the back of his black jersey.

headline: Yes, a Recovery Did Begin
text: Brad DeLong says that there was no economic recovery earlier this year, so it’s wrong to say that the recovery faltered.

headline: Look of the Moment | Flame On
text: The Look: Head-to-toe red — from the fiery mane to the flirty feathers.

headline: A Nightclubber’s Quiet Retreat
text: Jayma Cardoso, the nightclub impresario and Scott Campbell, a broker, are busy even for New Yorkers. Their streamlined apartment was designed to be a refuge.

headline: U.S. News & World Report to Become Online Only
text: U.S. News & World Report, the magazine that in recent years has gone from a weekly, to a semimonthly to a monthly, will no longer exist as a regularly printed publication.

headline: A Brooklyn Apartment Beckons
text: AS a born-and-bred Manhattanite, Kirsten Abrams never considered living in any other borough.

headline: Running Less and Cross-Training More
text: When I was younger runner, I came across a tip from a collegiate champion in a magazine, a tip called the 2 percent rule. In distance running, the champion asserted, 98 percent of all training should be running and the remaining sliver dedicated to cross-training.

headline: Turn Piles of Waste Into Piles of Cash, City Asks
text: Except when visualizing alligators in the sewers and lost fishbowl pets, New Yorkers rarely think about what happens to the stuff that drains from sinks and toilet bowls. But 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater go down the tubes every day, where it begins a long and expensive process before it is buried and forgotten.

headline: Running New York in His Prime Was a Priority for Gebrselassie
text: Haile Gebrselassie posed a question: “Do you think I’m old?”

headline: Paying Off a Mortgage
text: PAYING off a mortgage or even paying down the balance early might seem enticing to most borrowers. There’s the big savings in interest payments and the freed-up cash flow that can result, not to mention the emotional benefit of wiping out what for most people is the largest financial burden of a lifetime.

headline: Thoughts On Pelosi
text: I’m not objective here — I’ve sort of made a point of not hanging out with politicians, but I have spent some time with Nancy Pelosi, and like her. I’m also, of course, not an expert on political maneuvering.

headline: Secret Cars Kept Under Wraps, in Public
text: CELEBRITIES wear disguises to dodge the paparazzi. Isn’t that Brad Pitt under the tweed flat cap and shades? Mel Gibson behind the silly mustache? Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen wearing cat whiskers?

headline: Mets and Takahashi Part Ways
text: Hisanori Takahashi’s time with the Mets is over after one successful season, and he will seek another team in free agency beginning Saturday.

headline: Outstanding in a Class of One
text: WHEN a vehicle maker cannot decide exactly how to classify its product, consumers (and reviewers) are bound to struggle as well.

headline: Waltz, Tango and Polka, With a Brazilian Accent
text: The Brazilian pianist Marcelo Bratke has recorded music from all over the repertory, but his performances in New York lately have been devoted to the music of his country, particularly that of Heitor Villa-Lobos and Ernesto Nazareth. His program at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening, though billed as a tribute to Villa-Lobos, was split between the two, with dances by Nazareth (and, as an encore, a movement from Milhaud’s “Saudades do Brasil”) making up the second half.

headline: Loaded, Unlocked: Cadillac Made Life Easier for Thieves
text: IT is not the sort of list that automakers aspire to top: in August, the Highway Loss Data Institute, an industry research group affiliated with the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, named the Cadillac Escalade as the vehicle with the highest rate of insurance claims for theft. The group reported that 2007-9 Escalades had a claim frequency of 10.8 for every 1,000 insured vehicles, about five times more often than the average passenger vehicle.

headline: After a Lone Hand Beckons, Grief, and Lipstick on a Naked Woman
text: Before the start of “SuperGabriela,” a two-part work presented by Cosmin Manolescu & Serial Paradise Company at Performance Space 122 on Thursday evening, a hand appeared through the folds of a black curtain. It was more silly than spooky, like a glimpse of Thing from “The Addams Family.”

headline: Pleading Sanity
text: Two days before his suspension from MSNBC, the anchor talked about his partisanship.  At his Rally to Restore Sanity, Jon Stewart complained about the shrieking tone of cable news. Were you watching when a montage juxtaposed footage from your news show with that of Glenn Beck’s? I saw that. I was sitting at home, with my notebooks for the election, in that Saturday haze that anybody who does five shows is still in until the middle of the afternoon on Saturday. I was thinking: That’s odd. I wouldn’t think of myself in those terms. Why is my videotape there?

headline: Taming the Courtney Monster
text: The singer and actress Courtney Love hopes for a comeback with a new album with her band, Hole.

headline: Courtney Love: ‘I’d Like to Be Trusted Again.’
text: ON Monday night, at a screening of the movie “Due Date,” Courtney Love told a reporter from Style.com that she was trying to take better care of herself.

headline: Stuffed Cabbage, a Classic Worth Revisiting
text: STUFFED cabbage, or at least, the kind served in diners and made by millions of grandmothers of Eastern European descent, is a sweet-and-sour affair. The sweetness comes from any range of ingredients  honey, ketchup, sugar, you name it  and the sour from citrus or vinegar. It’s almost always too sweet, and the sourness somehow lends no balance at all. But the concept is a good one.

headline: A Vegetable Wellington, Fit for a Duke
text: EVER since the weather turned cold and blustery, I’ve had puff pastry on the brain in buttery, flaky profusion.

headline: Top Player Withdraws From World Championship Competition
text: Magnus Carlsen, the No. 2 player in the world (No. 1 if the results of the Pearl Spring tournament in China that ended last week are included in the rankings), has withdrawn from the competition to select the next challenger for the world championship.

headline: A Rural Suburb With a Flinty Past
text: BRANCHVILLE, a hilly corner of Ridgefield in Fairfield County about 50 miles from Midtown Manhattan, gets its name from a railroad junction of the late 1800s. Its air was once smoky from mills that churned out glue and varnish. Its land was scarred by miners in search of granite, quartz and mica.

headline: Hard Times, Sometimes Unvarnished
text: Just as the newly unemployed look back in wonder and dismay at the money they used to squander on shopping sprees and restaurants, viewers in a recession may regret the time wasted on “Jon & Kate Plus 8” or “Keeping Up With the Kardashians.”
