headline: Big Fish in Small Theaters Often Find a Big, Scary Ocean on Broadway
text: Broadway or death. The reigning wisdom of theater producers these days is that if a play is ever going to grow up — that is, be taken seriously, receive lots of attention and, above all, make money — it can do so only on Broadway.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: In this Sunday’s Travel section, David Carr goes off the grid on a private island in the Bahamas. “No more than a small rise of volcanic rock, shells and sand lying all by its lonesome off Long Island in the Bahamas,” he writes, “Little Deadman’s Cay would seem well cast either as a paradise or prison with palm trees.”

headline: Inside Carmen’s Lusty Lair, The Walls Keep Closing In
text: The tenor Brandon Jovanovich offered a chilling reminder of the perils of a toxic love affair when Richard Eyre’s production of “Carmen” returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening.

headline: Special-Needs Trusts: Report Your Experiences
text: In this weekend’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about the ins and outs of special-needs trusts, which are trust accounts for disabled people that can help them preserve eligibility for government benefits and supplement those benefits as well.

headline: Netgear Wants to Wirelessly Connect New Televisions
text: Netgear, the maker of a number of wireless products, has a plan to beat its competitors, which include Belkin and Cisco, and double its revenue in the coming year. It involves the television.

headline: Footnote
text: The Metropolitan Opera said William Shimell would replace Wolfgang Holzmair and sing the role of Don Alfonso in “Così fan Tutte” this season. The production opens on Tuesday. The Met said that Mr. Holzmair had a sinus infection.

headline: In Other Gershwin News
text: A large archive of material related to the songwriting team of George and Ira Gershwin will be moved from San Francisco to the Library of Congress, The Los Angeles Times reported. Before Ira Gershwin’s widow, Leonore, died in 1991, she said that she wanted the archive to go eventually to the Library, but her will allowed for her nephew, Michael Strunsky, to keep it in California for as long as he wanted. Mr. Strunsky, 76, who lives in San Francisco, attributed his decision to transfer the archive partly to his getting older and partly to the fact that royalties and licensing fees for Ira Gershwin’s work, which he had used to support the archive and keep it open to researchers, had declined in recent years. The archive will join other large holdings of Gershwin material at the Library of Congress.

headline: Before Suspension, Mets’ Rodriguez Moved in With Clubhouse Manager
text: Shortly after a judge in Queens ordered Francisco Rodriguez to stay away from his girlfriend because he had an altercation with her father at Citi Field in August, Rodriguez moved in with someone many Mets players have grown to trust over the past two and a half decades: the team’s clubhouse manager, Charlie Samuels.

headline: First Look | J. Crew Men
text: “I just wanted to capture the momentum of the day,” says Frank Muytjens, the head designer of men’s wear at J. Crew. Equipped with a Canon EOS 7D camera, Muytjens drew out the ease and effortlessness of J. Crew’s spring 2011 collection on his models leading up to the presentation yesterday at Milk Studios. “It can get crazy backstage, but it’s always a calm and organized chaos,” Muytjens says. This mentality complements the Americana feel derived from Cy Twombly, Irving Penn, naval uniforms and Prouts Neck: “It’s a clean, fresh look but with a lot of texture — disheveled dressy. Fabrics with metal yarns woven in – nubby rustic yarns for sweaters, but in a fitted silhouette.” Highlights include a reworked gray hoodie elevated through toggle and button closures, paired with vintage patchwork detailed shorts. The collection hits stores on Feb. 11.

headline: CBS Leads
text: Two top CBS sitcoms on Thursday delivered their highest ratings since their September season premieres, and ABC’s “Private Practice” drew a large audience for an episode that dealt with the rape of a character. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS was the night’s most-watched network with “The Big Bang Theory” (13.9 million viewers) and “$#*! My Dad Says” (10.9 million). ABC saw surging ratings for the episode of “Private Practice” (10.2 million), called “Did You Hear What Happened to Charlotte King?” Fox ranked third with new episodes of “Bones” (9.1 million) and “Fringe” (5 million), while NBC struggled with comedies.

headline: The Female Scientist, the Biggest Secret
text: Women abound in plays about science. How else would writers simplify lofty concepts for the audience without some wife, sister or comely student fetchingly furrowing her brow at the brilliant fellows and saying something along the lines of, “Wait, let me get this straight ...”?

headline: Stuffed Cabbage Without the Sweet Sauce
text: Stuffed cabbage need not be difficult, nor do you have to serve it in a ketchupy, sickly sweet sauce. Made with a well-spiced tomato sauce, it can be really good. I made stuffed cabbage with lamb and rice for this week’s Minimalist.

headline: A Clever Defense From a Hard-to-Find Play
text: A few bridge deals are especially appealing because they require an unusual play that would not occur to many.

headline: Documentaries and Ties That Bind or Unravel
text: IN 2002, while he was making “Capturing the Friedmans,” his investigation of a notorious child-abuse prosecution on Long Island, the director Andrew Jarecki received a piece of documentary wisdom. “When this is over,” Sheila Nevins, the president of HBO Documentary Films, told him, “you will have had one of the most amazing experiences of your life. You’ll understand your subjects in a way you don’t understand your own family.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 5
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a haunted house in Chelsea, children learning about the Second Avenue subway, the World Wrestling Entertainment’s fan appreciation day and more.

headline: Unyielding, an Oligarch vs. Putin
text: I wish I had enough space to reprint in its entirety Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky’s closing statement, as his latest sham trial in Russia came to an end earlier this week. I have never been so moved by the words of a businessman.

headline: The Facebook Skeletons Come Out
text: AMONG the many firsts in the 2010 elections, it is safe to assume that the following words had never before been uttered about a future member of Congress, “This is a candidate who is probably best known for getting drunk and having sex on television.”

text: Sound familiar?Head on over to the Well blog, and join the conversation.

headline: Man Started Flight Elderly and White, and Ended It Young and Asian
text: Updated | Saturday | 11:18 a.m. Air security professionals, and immigration officials, are puzzling over the possible implications of an intelligence alert issued by Canada’s Border Services Agency this week about a man who boarded a flight to Vancouver in Hong Kong disguised as an elderly white man and then removed a head and neck mask during the flight to reveal that he was, in fact, young and Asian.

headline: A Sugar and Salt Solution for Haiti’s Cholera Epidemic
text: Twenty years ago I witnessed what seemed to be a medical miracle in a village deep in Bolivia: a nearly lifeless child dehydrated by severe diarrhea was given sips of a sugar and salt solution and recovered in a couple of hours. Curious about this simple yet lifesaving mixture called oral rehydration solution, I learned that United States-funded scientists had discovered it in 1968 in then-East Pakistan as a simple, cheap alternative to intravenous treatment. Defying all expectations, the researchers learned that at the right proportions, oral rehydration could resurrect even severely dehydrated adults suffering from cholera.

headline: British Troops Accused of Abusing Iraqi Detainees
text: LONDON  A lawyer for 200 Iraqis demanding a public inquiry into what they have described as brutal mistreatment by British soldiers in a secret detention center near Basra told the High Court in London on Friday that the abuse amounted to “Britain’s Abu Ghraib.” The assertion was buttressed with video recordings that appeared to show British interrogators bullying, humiliating and threatening a detainee.

headline: Robert K. Futterman
text: Mr. Futterman, 51, is the founder and chief executive of Robert K. Futterman and Associates, an independent brokerage and consulting firm specializing in urban retail markets. RKF, as the company is known, was responsible for leasing the retail space in the Time Warner Center, and it currently serves as an adviser to the Port Authority for the World Trade Center redevelopment.

text: In a parallel universe, LeBron James is a Knick, running the break with Eddy Curry and Jamal Crawford; Larry Brown was never hired and Isiah Thomas was never fired, nor found liable for sexual harassment.

headline: For Gays, New Songs of Survival
text: AT first listen, “We R Who We R,” the current single from the pop singer Ke$ha, sounds like just another entry in her glitter-caked catalog of dance hits. Eccentrically spelled song title? Check. Effervescent electro-pop production courtesy of the megaproducer Dr. Luke? Check. Ample use of Auto Tune? Double check.

headline: Others? A Mystery, Thank Goodness
text: Who wouldn’t want to live in this house? Or just in the library, which constitutes most of the set of Yale Rep’s moving new production of “A Delicate Balance,” Edward Albee’s 1966 Pulitzer Prize winner. It’s an almost frighteningly grand room with tall, multipaned windows and dark paneling from floor to sky-high ceiling. The bar  the room’s spiritual center  fills at least half a dozen bookshelves.

headline: A Political Play From the ’40s, Very of the Moment
text: “State of the Union” is a very funny, very smart play. And when it won the Pulitzer Prize, people must have thought: Oh, good. Now that all the manipulation and dishonesty in presidential politics have been exposed, things will change and the American government can go back to serving, and existing for the good of, the people.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: One Night, Two Orchestras and Widening Ambition
text: OVER the past 25 years, the Westchester Philharmonic has built a reputation as perhaps the county’s premier purveyor of large-scale orchestral works, but the philharmonic may soon have to share its musical turf. The Westchester Chamber Orchestra, which has quietly established itself with well-received accounts of smaller works, intends to expand the size of its ensemble and the scale of its offerings.

headline: The Pelosi-Bachmann Conundrum
text: While the results of Tuesday’s midterm election are mostly clear — thanks, Washington State, Connecticut and Illinois for beating my deadline; still waiting on you, Alaska  and  Minnesota — there are plenty of questions about the future.

headline: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching After Finding Hydrogen Leak and Crack
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Discovery, already delayed three times by technical problems and bad weather, was grounded again Friday, this time by a potentially dangerous gaseous hydrogen leak in a vent line attached to the ship’s external tank.

headline: An Unavoidable Collision
text: When, on a Friday afternoon in December 2000, a black woman, her 2-year-old strapped to her back and her 3-year-old and 5-year-old in her arms, left a South African squatter camp and stepped into the path of a speeding commuter train, it was no accident. But the white motorman who unavoidably plowed into them   he was an accident, a random accessory to the mother’s despair.

headline: Still Life Americana: Beyond Fruit
text: Can there be such a thing as an American still life? A pretty good case is made for it in the opening galleries of “American Still Life: Treasures From the Parrish Art Museum” in Southampton, N.Y.

headline: For Some Women, Elite Start Could Mean a Lonely Race
text: It is hard to imagine that any of the more than 43,000 people scheduled to run in the New York City Marathon will be wanting for company during their 26.2-mile tour of the town. But because the elite women start before the rest of the field, several national-class women could find the race something of a solitary endeavor.

headline: Officer’s Extortion Conviction Prompts Calls for Full Exoneration of ‘Norfolk Four’
text: WASHINGTON  The recent conviction of a Virginia police officer supports the case for full exoneration of the “Norfolk Four,” former sailors convicted of rape and murder, who received conditional pardons from Virginia’s governor last year, lawyers for the men said.

headline: Middle Eastern Flavors, and Hookahs, Too
text: IF you are in the George Street neighborhood of New Brunswick and hungry for good, basic Middle Eastern food and fresh salads, Kairo Kafe is your place.

headline: From Rugs to Kebabs
text: Before Ali and Fatima Khayatian opened Honey, a cozy grocery and cafe in Teaneck, they sold Persian rugs wholesale.

headline: A Lincoln Photograph – and a Mystery
text: Washington, Nov. 6, 1860

headline: Immigrants’ Pilot Lessons Spur Inquiry by the U.S.
text: BOSTON  Federal officials could not explain Friday how more than 30 immigrants charged with being here illegally got clearance to take flying lessons at an airstrip outside Boston.

headline: Return From Injury Is Stunning to Everyone but Himself
text: RENTON, Wash.  The scar curves just above Leon Washington’s right ankle, its path snaking three inches up his leg. Each time Washington looks down there, he is reminded of an injury so gruesome  as if stolen from a horror movie  that his former Jets teammates fast-forwarded the play on film.

headline: Action Sought On Gay Policy
text: The Log Cabin Republicans, a gay rights group, asked the United States Supreme Court on Friday to allow a California trial judge’s order barring enforcement of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gay members of the military to go back into effect. The group asked the court to vacate a decision Monday by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to keep the policy in place until it considers the government’s appeal of the state judge’s decision. (AP)

headline: A Formula for Good Wine
text: Richard Pisacano has a winning formula for turning fine North Fork grapes into first-rate wines: He has Roman Roth do the winemaking at Wölffer Estate.

headline: A Lifetime With H.I.V.
text: What is it like to be born with H.I.V.? How does it affect your outlook? Four young adults speak about their lives.

headline: Aperitif, a French Bistro, Roams Far Afield
text: APERITIF is a French bistro and much more than that. This Rockville Centre newcomer, which opened in late July, is owned by the Sage Bistro Restaurant Group, which also has Sage Bistro in Bellmore, Brasserie Persil in Oceanside and Sage Bistro Moderne in Woodbury. The two owners, Peter Oktas and Julio Velasquez, met when they worked at Bistro Cassis in Huntington. Mr. Oktas was the manager, Mr. Velasquez the chef.

headline: Indian to Go, and Plenty of It
text: Occupying a narrow, cheerfully lighted storefront, Ambadi, a carry-out Indian food shop in White Plains, has just celebrated its sixth birthday. From its opening days as a vendor of India’s street food, the place has worked, year by year, to expand its menu in response to public demand. Apparently, busy diners from the surrounding business community wanted more than a couple of samosas to go. The menu now offers a long list of entrees.

headline: Shell Presses for Drilling in Arctic
text: HOUSTON  Eager to win approval for its stalled plan to drill for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, Royal Dutch Shell is beginning a public lobbying campaign, including national advertising, on Monday. As part of the effort, the giant oil company is promising to make unprecedented preparations to prevent the kind of disaster that polluted the Gulf of Mexico earlier this year.

headline: Census Finds Single Mothers and Live-In Partners
text: More than a quarter of the unmarried women who gave birth in a recent year were living with a partner, according to a Census Bureau report that for the first time measured the percentage of unmarried mothers who were not living alone.

headline: Italian Pastas Meet the Arabian Nights
text: AT Eclisse Mediterraneo Cucina, a new restaurant in White Plains, richly flavored Persian dishes share the menu with gorgeous labor-intensive Italian pastas — and whichever style you choose, you’re bound to bump into the unusual and the unusually delicious.

headline: Doing Good by Default
text: At the end of Tuesday’s Fixes column about changing the default choice from “opt in” to “opt out” for decisions like putting money into a 401(k) account, donating organs or taking an AIDS test, I asked readers to send in their own ideas about where else the opt-out default could be applied for the common good.

headline: Living In | Branchville, Conn.
text: This hilly corner of Ridgefield, more moderately priced than some parts of Fairfield County, was once an industrial zone with glue factories and stone quarries.

headline: Black and Republican and Back in Congress
text: WASHINGTON  For the first time in over a decade, the incoming class of Congress will include two black Republicans, both of whom rode the Tea Party wave to victory while playing down their race.

headline: 2010 Faltered as a New ‘Year of the Woman’ in Politics
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Patty Murray of Washington is still the same self-described “mom in tennis shoes” she was back in 1992, when she was ushered into Congress in what some called the “Year of the Woman.” But this week, Ms. Murray barely eked out a re-election victory, in a cycle that will see no increase in the number of women in Congress  and possibly even a decrease in the House.

headline: Of Airlines and Aerobatics
text: MY parents were economists who worked to improve conditions in the developing world. We lived in Latin America and Africa before settling in the United States. These circumstances exposed me to travel and different cultures, creating in me a passion for aviation and adventure.

headline: Direct From the Farm: Homey Yet Elegant Italian
text: THE menu looks sensational. Grilled octopus with salsa verde. Salumi. Pizza Margherita. Spaghetti carbonara. Veal saltimbocca. And it tastes sensational.

headline: Fresh From the Roaster
text: Well before arriving at the modern, glass-sheathed headquarters of Omar Coffee you will sense your proximity to it. That’s because every day, starting at 7 a.m., its 500-pound-capacity roaster churns into action, filling the air with the pleasingly smoky fragrance of beans being processed.

headline: Tea Party Rooted in Religious Fervor for Constitution
text: Late on the afternoon of Election Day, James Renwick Manship joined the assembly of Tea Party supporters outside the Capitol. He wore a cravat, a powdered wig, a tricorn hat and a brass-buttoned coat in the blue and buff colors of the Continental Army. Such is the standard attire of his vocation portraying George Washington.

headline: Safer Football, Taught From Inside the Helmet
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Alan Pelc has been taught how to block since his Houston boyhood, how to push and pulverize and punish oncoming defenders on the football field. This was different. He was learning how not to punish himself.

headline: A Suicide More Complex Than a Slogan
text: In one of the last updates he posted on his Facebook page, Joseph Jefferson sounded like yet another young gay person succumbing to overwhelming social rejection, if not outright bullying.

headline: It’s Official: Republican Concedes in Illinois Race
text: A day after The Associated Press declared Gov. Patrick J. Quinn the winner of the Illinois governor’s race, his Republican opponent, Bill Brady, did too.

headline: A Tailor, Called Upon by Designers and Politicians
text: When the trend-setting fashion designers Marcus Wainwright and David Neville of Rag & Bone wanted a top-of-the-line men’s wear maker for their hip brand, whose door did they knock on? Martin Greenfield’s.

headline: Latinos Reached Milestones in Midterm Races
text: PHOENIX — There was plenty of grim news for Latinos in Tuesday’s election results: three Latino congressmen were voted out, the odds of an immigration overhaul appeared to diminish and — here in the state that gave rise to the strictest immigration measure of all — hardliners were re-elected amid vows to continue cracking down on illegal immigrants.

headline: A Seaside Home in Turkey
text: Mica Etergun, the New York interior designer, took a stone ruin and turned it into a luxurious vacation home.

headline: U.S. News & World Report to End Monthly Publication
text: U.S. News & World Report, once part of the triumvirate of newsweeklies but reduced now to a spare monthly, will print its last issue for subscribers in December.

headline: Dividends From Fannie and Freddie Surpass Aid
text: WASHINGTON  The federal government made a profit of $1.1 billion in the third quarter on its huge bailout of the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, even as the two companies continued to lose money on bad loans.

headline: Coaches Shouldn’t Be Immune to Penalties
text: The new N.C.A.A. president, Mark Emmert, has an idyllic view of what the intercollegiate athletic experience, at its best, could be.

headline: Running for Your Life
text: IT was still dark when Dr. Thomas A. Farley got to Central Park on a cool October morning and started stretching his grasshopperlike legs, blending into the background in black shorts and a T-shirt. He was training for the New York City Marathon, and would not let a sore Achilles’ tendon stop him from a four-mile run.

headline: Jill Clayburgh Dies at 66; Starred in Feminist Roles
Breeders’ Cup Opens With Controversy, Including a Fight
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The first day of the Breeders’ Cup started with an altercation between the jockeys Calvin Borel and Javier Castellano over rough riding. It ended with confusion and concern over whether one of the favorites in the Ladies’ Classic, Life at Ten, was healthy enough to be in the $2 million race.

headline: As H.I.V. Babies Come of Age, Problems Linger
text: WARWICK, R.I. — “They’ve been telling me since age 3 that I would die,” Tom Cosgrove said quietly. “Then age 6, age 8, age 10.”

headline: Finding a Spot in the Wild
text: Angélique Kidjo, 50, the Grammy-winning African pop star, savors the rare Sundays when her touring schedule allows her to be home with her family. She lives with her husband, Jean Hébrail, and daughter, Naïma, 17, in a condominium in Park Slope, Brooklyn. After growing up in Benin, in West Africa, Ms. Kidjo spent 14 years in France, then moved to New York in 1997. On Thursday, she performs at Carnegie Hall.

headline: To Capitalize on Low Bids, Navy Hopes to Name 2 Winners for Ship Contract
text: The Navy’s new littoral combat ships are supposed to be quick enough to run down coastal patrol craft and diesel submarines.

headline: Zenyatta Is Hard to Beat, and Harder to Ignore
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It takes some kind of horse to get people talking about horse racing beyond the Kentucky Derby and the other Triple Crown races. Cigar was the last one to capture the imagination of casual sports fans by tossing off a 16-race winning streak over his 1995 and 1996 seasons, winning the Breeders’ Cup Classic and Dubai World Cup in that span.

headline: Olbermann of MSNBC Suspended Over Donations
text: Keith Olbermann, the leading liberal voice on American television in the age of Obama, was suspended Friday after his employer, MSNBC, discovered he made campaign contributions to three Democrats last month.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE FETCH CLUB, a haven for pampered pooches, fills a space where Fulton Fish Market smells once wafted. There is certainly no odor in this deluxe dormitory for dogs — the air is ionized and purified. The water is filtered, and the food is organic.

headline: With New Resources, Urban Students Are Encouraged to Apply to College
text: YONKERS, N.Y.

headline: An Actress of Feminist Ethos
text: The actress Jill Clayburgh, known for her portrayals of strong, independent women, has died.

headline: Campaigning for Others, Christie Proves a Star Near and Far
text: One of the biggest winners of the elections this week was not on any ballot. Gov. Chris Christie, campaigning for fellow Republicans from California to Massachusetts, trailed perhaps only Sarah Palin as the booster most sought after by his party’s candidates, and most avidly received by the party faithful.

headline: Cities as Hubs of Energy and Climate Action
text: Nov. 7, 8:25 p.m. | Updated A pair of energy and development specialists from the mayors’ offices in New York City and Los Angeles are going global.

headline: Despite Losses, Nancy Pelosi Will Run for House Post
text: WASHINGTON  Despite severe election losses that cost her party the House, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday that she would run to remain the leader of House Democrats even as some of her colleagues urged her to step aside.

headline: Saudis Warned U.S. of Attack Before Parcel Bomb Plot
text: WASHINGTON  Saudi intelligence officials warned the United States in early October that Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen was planning a terrorist attack using one or more aircraft, three weeks before a plot to send parcel bombs on cargo planes was foiled at the last minute, American and European officials said Friday.

headline: Gimelstob Bets That Expert Will Get Him to Finish
text: The former professional tennis player Justin Gimelstob has never run a marathon, but now he has $10,000 and a great deal of pride at stake in his first one on Sunday. So he was only too pleased when Laura Skladzinski offered to help. Even though she is only 25, Skladzinski has more than enough experience for the two of them.

headline: Political Funds Remain an Asset for Many Ex-Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON  Henry Bonilla, a Texas Republican and former member of Congress, has tapped into his political piggy bank to fly around the United States, eat at some of San Antonio’s finest restaurants and to cover bills at luxury hotels like The Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Education Unit Lifts Washington Post Company
text: The Washington Post Company said third-quarter profit more than tripled on sales growth in its higher education unit, which is facing government scrutiny, and a pickup in advertising revenue in its newspaper business. The company, which publishes The Washington Post, said it earned $60.9 million, or $6.84 a share, up from $17.1 million, or $1.81 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 7.3 percent, to $1.19 billion. Earnings doubled at the Kaplan education unit, which accounts for almost two-thirds of revenue. Still, enrollment growth for higher education programs slowed, and the company said that pending government regulation of commercial colleges and a new free-trial period for students might hurt earnings. Revenue at the newspaper division rose 5 percent to $163.4 million. The Post’s print ad sales rose 3 percent to $72 million. Stock in the Post Company, which is based in Washington, rose $14.48, or 3.8 percent, to $398.38.

headline: Fluor’s Shares Surge on Improved Business Outlook
text: Shares in the Fluor Corporation, the construction company, surged nearly 10 percent in response to the company’s announcement that its order backlog had expanded 18 percent and that it would increase its share buybacks. On Thursday, Fluor raised its share repurchase program by 7.2 million shares to a total of 12 million shares, or 6.7 percent of its outstanding stock as of Oct. 29. The company said its order backlog rose to $33 billion in the third quarter amid new project awards for infrastructure, mining, oil and gas, including an oil sands project in Canada. The increase marked the second consecutive quarter of expansion, Fluor said. Stock in Fluor, which is based in Irving, Tex., rose $4.73, to $54.53.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Showdown in Utah
text: On Saturday, all eyes will be on the Mountain West. At least all the eyes that can be. Texas Christian will travel to play Utah in one of the more intriguing matchups between undefeated teams this season. Both teams have established themselves as top-notch programs in the past decade, but they find themselves lagging behind Boise State this season when it comes to non-B.C.S. teams cracking the B.C.S. This game provides a chance for each to showcase why they should be considered among the country’s elite. Another team that is hoping for some national recognition is Baylor, which beat Texas last week and is hoping to go into Oklahoma State and upend the Cowboys. Nick Saban is sure to get a, ahem, loud reception when Alabama takes the field against Louisiana State. Perhaps Les Miles can draw on some of his magic and help the Tigers beat back the Tide. Arkansas and South Carolina face off in another marquee SEC matchup, while Arizona will look to slow down Stanford’s offense in a key Pac-10 game.

headline: The Votes Are In. Eloquence Didn’t Win.
text: If the American political process had any integrity, winning candidates would grab the microphone on election night and say, “Hey, all you haters out there, guess what? I so totally won! Now I’m the boss of you. This is going to be awesome.”

headline: Saturday: Poinciana Feature
text: Since the contest in Friday’s puzzle is still open to entries (until midnight Sunday), we’ll continue with our contest-hint ban in today’s comments.

headline: Learning to Love Foreclosures?
text: In the most recent mortgage mess, the Obama administration has  oddly and disturbingly  been arguing that foreclosures are, in effect, good for the economy and should proceed apace as banks get their snarled paperwork in order.

headline: The Grizzly Manifesto
text: I think it is time to take back the mama grizzly.

headline: China Blusters On
text: There’s apparently no limit to China’s arrogance, not to mention its tone-deafness. According to The Times’s Michael Wines, China this week formally asked European nations to boycott the Oslo ceremony where the Nobel Peace Prize will be awarded  in absentia  to the imprisoned Chinese democracy activist, Liu Xiaobo.

headline: Working With India
text: President Obama will spend three days in India beginning on Saturday  the longest foreign stay of his presidency. Indians are still feeling anxious and insufficiently loved. But the trip is a clear a sign of the importance that Mr. Obama places on the relationship. As he should.

headline: That’s the Latest
text: It’s no surprise that triumphant Tea Party politicians are seeking ranking posts within the incoming House Republican majority. But their likely speaker, Representative John Boehner, already has a problem with Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, the doyenne of conservative insurgents.

headline: Tone-Deaf in D.C.
text: It would be easy to misread the results of Tuesday’s elections, and it looks as if the leaders of both parties are doing exactly that.

headline: Two Arrests in Shooting Death of 5-Year-Old
text: LOS ANGELES  It was a real-life Halloween nightmare: 5-year-old Aaron Shannon Jr. was posing for pictures in his Spider-Man costume in the backyard of his family’s South Los Angeles home when men opened fire from a nearby alley. Aaron was hit in the back of the head and died in the hospital the next day.

headline: N.F.L.’s Union Files Complaint to Agent
text: The N.F.L. players union Friday issued a disciplinary complaint to the N.F.L. agent Ian Greengross for the reported actions of his associate Kenny Rogers.

headline: Have It Your Way
text: Bacon, egg and cheese on a roll, toasted, with ketchup and mayo. The cash register clangs.

headline: Germany: 18-Year-Old Faces Charges of Terrorism Over Internet Videos
text: An 18-year-old man was arrested in northwest Germany on Friday on charges that he posted three videos on the Internet in October threatening terrorist attacks unless a convicted terrorist serving a 12-year prison term was released, the police said. The police said the suspect, whom they would not identify because he might be tried as a juvenile, uploaded three crude yet threatening videos onto YouTube. He also downloaded bomb-making manuals from the Internet, but was unable to make explosives because he did not have money for materials. In the videos, the man hid his face while claiming to speak on behalf of what he called the German mujahedeen. He demanded the release from prison of Daniel Schneider, the leader of the so-called Sauerland Cell, whose members were convicted in March 2010 for planning attacks on United States military installations in Germany. The police said that there was no evidence that the suspect was linked with Al Qaeda or any terrorist groups but that he had become a dangerous longer.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.N. Chief Says He Discussed Human Rights Privately in China
text: United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon addressed mounting criticism that he was notably soft on China’s human rights record by saying that he had raised the issue in private during his visit there this week. Mr. Ban said that China was on the path to political reform and building a society based on the rule of law. “I hope that the Chinese government will further expand the space for civil society and take further steps that reflect and uphold its commitment to international human rights standards,” he said at a news conference. He stopped short of calling on China to release imprisoned dissident Liu Xiaobo, the winner of this year’s Nobel Peace Prize, an award that infuriated Beijing. China is one of five permanent Security Council members that can veto Mr. Ban’s quest for a second term starting in 2012.

headline: Elderly Are Cut From Meals Program
text: Dorothy Hinks may be enfeebled but she is proud.

headline: For Some Catholic Schools, It’s Admission Test Time
text: Breathless, with beads of sweat forming on his brow, Jahumi Harrigan, 23, hurried into the gym at Cathedral High School on East 56th Street on Friday morning, hand in hand with his 13-year-old sister, Asha.

headline: Britain: Citizenship Restored to Cleric Wanted on Terrorism Charges in U.S.
text: A British government ruling stripping the Egyptian-born Muslim cleric known as Abu Hamza al-Masri of his British citizenship was struck down Friday by a special immigration court. But government officials said the court’s action would not affect the government’s plan to extradite the cleric to the United States, where he is wanted on terrorism charges. Officials in the office of Home Secretary Theresa May said no decision had been made on whether to appeal the immigration court’s ruling to a higher British court. The immigration panel upheld the claim by lawyers for Mr. Hamza, 53, whose real name is Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, that losing the British citizenship he gained through marriage in 1986 would leave him stateless, because Egypt’s government has revoked his Egyptian citizenship. He has carried his fight to avoid extradition to the European Court of Human Rights. He is wanted in the United States, where he is accused in connection with a plot to establish a terrorism training camp in Oregon, and is alleged to have had a role in planning a terrorist ambush in Yemen in 1998 in which 16 foreign tourists, some of them Americans, were taken hostage. Four hostages were subsequently killed.

headline: Rangers Keep Devils Winless at Home
text: NEWARK  Misery compounded misery for the Devils on Friday night. After a long, unsuccessful trip, they returned to the Prudential Center and were outplayed by the Rangers, 3-0.

headline: France: Protesters Block Train Carrying Nuclear Waste
text: Protesters blocked a train carrying nuclear waste back to Germany on Friday, chaining themselves to train tracks a few hundred yards from the railway station in Caen, in northwestern France. The train, with 11 carriages of treated nuclear waste and 3 carriages full of riot police officers, was headed to Gorleben, Germany. The waste, which was created in German nuclear power plants and treated in France by Areva, was returning for storage in Gorleben, in Lower Saxony. The protesters called the shipment “the most radioactive ever,” an accusation contested by Areva, which had melted the waste, mixed it in glass and put it into containers. The German Parliament approved a bill recently extending the life of the country’s 17 reactors by 12 years, although they were supposed to have been shut down in 2020.

headline: Success Comes to Knicks From Unexpected Places
text: Toney Douglas got the ball last, cradling it near midcourt as fans rose for an ovation and the clock hit all zeroes. This might not be the precise image that the Knicks cast for themselves after their free-agent shopping spree in July, but it might be the most fitting.

headline: France: Roma Expelled From Church
text: About 13 Roma were expelled Friday from a church just south of Paris, the third expulsion of Roma in the past few days. The 13, including two adolescents, had been in France for a decade and had been moved from a squat. They took refuge in the church of St.-Nicolas de St.-Maur-des-Fossés hoping for better lodging, but were removed after the priest there signed an expulsion order. On Wednesday, two encampments of Roma  one nearby at Créteil and the other in Lyon, were also emptied by the police. France was sharply criticized this summer for a more intense effort to expel Roma who are non-French and who overstay their three-month visa, and for breaking up illegal encampments of Roma and traveling people, including French citizens, who have been living on land not designated for them by municipalities. France says Romania and Bulgaria must do more to integrate their Roma citizens, and spend more of the money the European Union provides for that purpose. But the Roma say they are not wanted in Romania.

headline: Climate Panel Offers Ways to Raise Cash to Cope
text: UNITED NATIONS  After grappling with a fundamental deadlock between rich and poor nations over climate change, a high-level United Nations panel on Friday proposed a smorgasbord of ways to raise $100 billion annually to help developing countries cope with global warming.

headline: Hearing the Returns with Mr. Lincoln
text: In 1860, a cub reporter named Samuel R. Weed scored the assignment of a lifetime when his St. Louis newspaper sent him to spend Election Day with the man who might become America’s president. Surprisingly, no one else had thought of it, and Weed arrived to find a relaxed Abraham Lincoln, greeting him “as calmly and as amiably as if he had started on a picnic.”

headline: U.S. Islamic Web Site Is Taken Down
text: LONDON  A United States-based extremist Islamic Web site was taken down on Friday after the British authorities complained of a post praising a young woman who stabbed and nearly killed a British lawmaker over his support for the Iraq war.

headline: A Quick Adjustment for Wall
text: WASHINGTON — Most rookies say the speed of the game is the biggest difference between college and the N.B.A. John Wall doesn’t really have a problem adjusting to the quicker pace. It’s the players that have been in the league who will have to adjust to him. Already regarded as one of the fastest players with the ball in his hand, John Wall was a blur Tuesday night in the Wizards’ home opener against the Philadelphia 76ers.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Violence After Sentence in Oakland Killing
text: OAKLAND — Protesters vandalized storefronts and clashed with the police here on Friday night after a white former transit police officer was given what they considered to be a light sentence for the killing an unarmed black man. But protests initially seemed less violent than others that have surrounded the controversial case.

headline: Charles McDowell, Commentator, Dies at 84
text: Charles McDowell, a retired columnist for The Richmond Times-Dispatch who brought a folksy manner to a regular stint on the PBS program “Washington Week in Review” and to a prominent role in Ken Burns’s PBS series “The Civil War,” died Friday. He was 84.

headline: Exporting Our Way to Stability
text: AS the United States recovers from this recession, the biggest mistake we could make would be to rebuild our economy on the same pile of debt or the paper profits of financial speculation. We need to rebuild on a new, stronger foundation for economic growth. And part of that foundation involves doing what Americans have always done best: discovering, creating and building products that are sold all over the world.

headline: Drug Gang Chief Reported Killed in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican authorities said Friday that a leader of the Gulf drug gang had been killed in Matamoros during a day marked by street fighting between soldiers and gunmen that paralyzed the city, which is across the Rio Grande from Brownsville, Tex.

headline: Shirley Verrett, Opera Singer of Power and Grace, Is Dead at 79
text: Shirley Verrett, the vocally lustrous and dramatically compelling American opera singer who began as a mezzo-soprano and went on to sing soprano roles to international acclaim, died Friday morning at her home in Ann Arbor, Mich. She was 79.

headline: Elite Moscow Tournament Off to a Fast Start
text: Four of the five games Friday in Round 1 of the Tal Memorial, one of the top tournaments of the year, ended decisively.

headline: In India, Obama Courts Corporate America
text: MUMBAI, India  President Obama, fresh off a stinging electoral defeat for Democrats, opened a 10-day tour of Asia on Saturday with a courtship of corporate America, including private meetings with American business executives who are here for his visit and an announcement that he will lift longstanding restrictions on exports of closely held technologies to India.

headline: Russian Journalist Beaten in Moscow
text: MOSCOW  A journalist for the popular daily newspaper Kommersant was seriously injured Saturday morning in an attack that his editor said was probably connected to his work.

headline: NATO Investigates Report That Afghan Soldier Killed 2 G.I.’s
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO and Afghan officials on Saturday said they were investigating reports that an Afghan soldier turned his weapon on American troops, killing two soldiers.

headline: What Does Racing Need? Let’s Start With More Owners
text: Jim Squires is the breeder of the 2001 Kentucky Derby winner, Monarchos, and the author of “Horse of a Different Color” and “Headless Horsemen.”

headline: Mark Sanchez’s Body Language and Decision-Making
text: Three points about the Jets heading into the Detroit game, or three more than they had against Green Bay:

headline: A Sudden End for Democratic Entrepreneurs in Congress
text: Almost exactly a year ago, The Agenda introduced  readers to the 11 entrepreneurs among the freshman class in the House of Representatives. Now, after an election that has turned control of the House over to the Republicans (and left the Senate more evenly divided), only six of them will become sophomores — all four Republicans, but just two of seven Democrats. Five Democrats lost their re-election bids, and none of those races were particularly close.

headline: Brian Jones Previews Texas Christian-Utah
text: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for CBS College Sports Network, which will televise the Texas Christian-Utah game at 3:30 p.m. Eastern. He can also be seen every Tuesday night during the season as part of “The Tony Barnhart Show” at 9 p.m. and “Inside College Football” at 10.

headline: The Abolitionist’s Epiphany
text: Boston, Nov. 7, 1860

headline: Champions League Chalkboards
text: Beginning with this installment, the Goal blog is inaugurating a new feature that offers a statistical (courtesy of OPTA) and graphic representations of select matches from the European Champions League. At the end of each week when matches are played, the editor of zonalmarking.net, will provide analysis powered by the Total Football iPhone/iPad app, which is available at totalfootballapps.com and the iTunes App Store. Similar Chalkboards can be dissected at the Web site of the Guardian of Britain and at the zonalmarking Web site.

headline: Filming Secretariat’s Story While Learning a Sport
text: Randall Wallace knows a thing or two about show business. He wrote the screenplay for “Braveheart,” which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned him a nomination for best original screenplay in 1996. He is also a novelist, songwriter, producer and director, and even has a black belt. What he is not is a horseman, and yet one would never guess that after viewing “Secretariat,” which he directed and which has grossed more than $46 million domestically.

headline: When ‘House Effects’ Become ‘Bias’
text: Perhaps now that the election is over and things are slightly calmer around here, we can take questions from readers a little more often — or even do a “mailbag” column once in a while.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy was unrepentant in the face of criticism that he intervened to win the release of a 17-year-old Moroccan runaway arrested for theft. The girl told prosecutors she dined at Mr. Berlusconi’s villa but denied having sex with him.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JIMMY KIMMEL

headline: Hyatt Introduces Hypoallergenic Hotel Rooms
text: If you’re the sort of traveler who can’t leave home without your antihistamine, Hyatt may have a solution for you: a hypoallergenic guest room.

headline: Prime Number
text: The dollar amount in political contributions that Keith Olbermann, the top anchor on MSNBC and a leading liberal voice on American television, made to three Democratic candidates last month. Mr. Olbermann was suspended indefinitely on Friday without pay. The suspension underscored the clash between objectivity and opinion in television journalism. Most news media outlets discourage or prohibit contributions by employees. But Michael C. Moynihan, a writer for the libertarian magazine Reason, asked, “Isn’t it unfair to hold Olbermann, who is one of the most partisan people on television (if not the Earth), to the same standards as, say, Brian Williams?”

headline: Back Then: 1946
text: In 1946, President Harry S. Truman was midway through his first term when Republicans who had pilloried him as a symbol of the New Deal seized control of Congress for the first time in 14 years. One Democrat, Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, had a novel idea for Mr. Truman, who had no vice president at the time. Here’s how The Associated Press reported it, quoting Mr. Fulbright:

headline: The Morning Line: Spotlight Shines on Borel
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Coral Die-Off Took Scientist by Surprise
text: Early on in the BP oil spill, I interviewed some marine biologists who had spent nearly a decade charting a series of deepwater coral reefs in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Children’s Books With Online Extras
text: Got tweens at home? In this week’s Sunday Book Review, I take a look at three young-adult novels (“Spaceheadz,” by Jon Scieszka with Francesco Sedita; Patrick Carman’s “Skeleton Creek: The Crossbones”; and “The Search for WondLa,” by Tony DiTerlizzi) that expand their storytelling powers beyond the printed page and onto the Web, using fake and real Web sites as well online video to add to the reading experience.

headline: The Obamas in India
text: President Obama announced a host of new trade deals with India, supporting tens of thousands of American jobs, as he began a 10-day Asian trip on a determinedly domestic note.

headline: Zenyatta, a Hungry Superstar
text: Horses like to be horses. But it is hard for handlers to allow their horses just to be horses, when preparing them for a $5 million race. Details are fine tuned, training is designed to have the horse peak at the precise moment the gates open for a race they have been preparing for a year.

headline: The Man Who Made the Marathon
text: George A. Hirsch is the founding publisher of New York magazine, the longtime publisher of Runner’s World and the chairman of the New York Road Runners.

headline: Breeders’ Cup Takes Back Seat in France
text: Update Workforce, the morning-line favorite for the Turf, has been scratched because of the firm condition of the Churchill course.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Group Still in Miller’s Corner
text: 2:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: Jule Sugarman, Director and Architect of Head Start, Dies at 83
text: Jule Sugarman, a primary architect of Head Start, the federal support program for millions of poor preschoolers, died Tuesday at his home in Seattle. He was 83.

headline: In Venezuela, a New Wave of Foreigners
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  On this booming continent, oil-rich Venezuela is the exception: South America’s only shrinking economy this year. Officials are rationing hard currency. Government takeovers of private businesses are increasing. One prominent financial analyst recently had just two words of advice for investors here: “Run away.”

headline: Bernanke And The Shibboleths
text: Everyone hates quantitative easing. The inflationistas believe that it’s the end of Western civilization (but as a correspondent points out, we want them to believe that; similar beliefs about the end of the gold standard helped recovery in the 1930s); meanwhile, the rest of the world is furious at the Fed’s actions.

headline: Portrait of the Electorate: Table of Detailed Results
text: A look at which groups voted for the Democratic or Republican candidate for the House of Representatives.

headline: Rightward, March: The Midterm Exit Polls
text: How bad was it for Democrats last week? By nearly every demographic measure, the party lost ground, significantly in some cases.

headline: Starting From Scratch on Day 2
text: I was sitting in the press box at Churchill Downs. It was quiet. No sound was coming from the many televisions, and the people who had time to talk had already left; everyone else was typing.The lights, those lights that were to make this first night-time Breeders’ Cup racing so special, were still on, illuminating an empty racetrack.

headline: Acrostic: Powerful Stratego Piece
text: Whew! The answers in today’s acrostic aren’t all eight letters long, so I don’t need to take up valuable blog space lauding that (as I did with the previous two acrostics). Even better, the answers aren’t all three letters long, which would take up valuable space in the Sunday magazine section, pages perhaps.

headline: While Warning About Fat, U.S. Pushes Cheese Sales
text: Domino’s Pizza was hurting early last year. Domestic sales had fallen, and a survey of big pizza chain customers left the company tied for the worst tasting pies.

headline: Geoffrey Crawley, 83, Dies; Gently Deflated a Fairy Hoax
text: Were there really fairies at the bottom of the garden, or was it merely a childhood prank gone strangely and lastingly awry?

headline: America and India: The Almost-Special Relationship
text: NEW DELHI — At a panel discussion last week on relations between India and the United States, Strobe Talbott, the former American diplomat, told an audience of Indian business leaders that he had learned a valuable lesson about India: Do not hyphenate it. As in Indo-Pak. (Or, in a close cousin of a hyphen, as in Chindia.) The audience smiled at his epiphany: India matters because it is India.

headline: Why the Government Is Promoting Cheese
text: Have you noticed your restaurant food getting cheesier lately? It may be due to the efforts of Dairy Management, a marketing creation of the United States Department of Agriculture. The role Dairy Management plays in the national promotion of cheese is explained in an investigative report from the New York Times reporter Michael Moss.

headline: Discover Card Forges Tie to the N.H.L.
text: Just over two months ago, Discover Card acquired the naming rights to the Orange Bowl for four years and to the 2013 B.C.S. national championship game. On Monday, Discover will announce that it is the official credit card of the N.H.L. in the United States and the presenting sponsor of its 2011 All-Star Game in Raleigh, N.C.

headline: Are Rising Commodity Prices An Inflationary Signal?
text: Right now everyone seems to believe that rising commodity prices are telling us to beware of inflation. I think that’s dead wrong. Partly that’s because the sticky prices are the ones to worry about. But it’s also worth having some perspective on commodity prices themselves.

headline: Texas Considers Medicaid Withdrawal
text: Some Republican lawmakers  still reveling in Tuesday’s statewide election sweep  are proposing an unprecedented solution to the state’s estimated $25 billion budget shortfall: dropping out of the federal Medicaid program.

headline: QE Is Not CM
text: Yes, I know: YHTMAAAIYP*. But: as a followup to my shibboleths post, I’m a bit shocked at the way so many people are treating US quantitative easing as somehow equivalent to Chinese currency manipulation.

headline: John Boehner and the Politics of Crying
text: WASHINGTON — A presumptive new speaker of the House; so much to consider. Where will John Boehner stand on energy policy? Will he be able to manage Michele Bachmann? And how often will he weep?

headline: Racing’s Holy Grail: the Pick Six
text: David “Buc” Geier helps run the Corner Cocktail, a tavern in the horse-racing hinterland of Kansas City, Mo. He has as many opinions and ideas on the Sport of Kings as he does un-cashable tickets in his desk drawer.

headline: Tag-Along Marketing
text: Everything is in place for location-based social networking to be the next big thing. Tech companies are building the platforms, venture capitalists are providing the cash and marketers are eager to develop advertising.

headline: After 90 Years, What’s Another Marathon?
text: Four days beyond his 90th birthday, it might be enough for Jon Mendes to celebrate having the original parts and warranty on his knees and hips.

headline: Now Appearing: George W. Bush
text: WASHINGTON — When the hip-hop star Kanye West says he can “connect with” George W. Bush, perhaps it is time to think about whether America has begun to reconsider its 43rd president.

headline: All I Want for Christmas: Wins by the Ladies
text: Kate Miller is head of racing media for William Hill Company in England and works with the odds compilers in the company’s Leeds office. She also is the daughter of the former racecourse bookmaker Charlie Miller, and knows her way around horses.

headline: U.S. Vote Could Derail Russia Ties
text: WASHINGTON  The Republican election victory last week was fueled by opposition to President Obama’s economic and domestic initiatives, but it could undo his central foreign policy achievement, his new partnership with Russia, and embolden anti-American hawks in Moscow.

headline: New Mangini Embraces Old One
text: BEREA, Ohio  Perhaps Eric Mangini reached his lowest point in January. He was eating too much, sleeping too little and wrestling with a chewing tobacco habit. His job as the Cleveland Browns’ coach was fraught with uncertainty.

headline: The Horse to Bet: Girolamo
text: Jonathan Socolow, who works in Moscow, is an avid horseplayer.

headline: Zenyatta Just Misses Breeders’ Cup Victory
text: Zenyatta, 19-0 coming into the race, gave her all, coming from last to present a challenge at the finish, but it was Blame who stuck his head out to win the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic on Saturday night at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

headline: In Japan, U.S. Defends Fed Actions
text: KYOTO, Japan  The United States confronted growing restiveness with its economic policy on Saturday as leading Asian countries resisted its call to set limits on trade deficits and surpluses while also warning that the decision to pump more money into the American economy would have harmful global repercussions.

headline: Democrats Divided on Tax Cut Strategy
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and Congressional Democrats are struggling for a strategy to deal with the soon-to-expire Bush-era tax cuts, each side uncertain whether the other is up for a fight with Republicans in the wake of the Democrats’ election trouncing  or whether they could win, in any event.

headline: The Story of Mancuso: A New Chapter, but It’s Still in the Context of Vonn
text: In the eight months since the Vancouver Winter Olympics, Julia Mancuso has surfed on the islands of Maui and Hawaii, vaulted off a Swiss Alps cliff in an extreme ski competition, vacationed on Easter Island, served in her sister’s wedding and put in weeks of training on snowy slopes in New Zealand and Chile.

headline: Still Here
text: Now that’s a surprise: Joe Nocera on the joys of Stephen Sondheim.

headline: American Sikhs Decry Screenings
text: WASHINGTON  Three national Sikh advocacy and civil rights organizations have said federal transportation officials plan to always search turbans at airport screening stations, even if wearers pass through state-of-the-art body imaging scanners.

headline: Running Backs Shift, but Bond Holds Tight
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Brandon Jacobs shrieked. He was standing at his locker at the Giants’ practice center a few days before Halloween when one of his teammates startled him, then momentarily disappeared.

headline: U.S. Workers Are on Alert After Breach of Data
text: WASHINGTON  Federal workers at the General Services Administration are on alert against identity theft after an employee sent the names and Social Security numbers of the agency’s entire staff to a private e-mail address.

headline: What’s in That Slice?
text: Cheese consumption in the U.S. has almost tripled since 1970, adding calories and saturated fat into the American diet at a time when obesity rates are climbing. But since 1995, a nonprofit marketing corporation created by the government has been working with retail chains to increase the amount of cheese in their products, including Domino’s American Legends line.

headline: Hulkenberg, of All People, Scores Pole in Sao Paulo
text: INTERLAGOS, Brazil — Murray Walker, the great Formula One television broadcaster in Britain, was famous for his (often unintentional) bons mots, and one of his most famous was, “Anything can happen in Formula One, and it usually does.”

headline: Hulkenberg, of All People, Scores Pole in Sao Paulo
text: INTERLAGOS, Brazil — Murray Walker, the great Formula One television broadcaster in Britain, was famous for his (often unintentional) bons mots, and one of his most famous was, “Anything can happen in Formula One, and it usually does.”

headline: Jets’ Star Guard Combines 305 Pounds of Power With the Little Things
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Brandon Moore is a 305-pound right guard for the Jets who is not merely considered the best player at his position in the N.F.L., but also tougher than a boot  or so his coach, Rex Ryan, gushed on consecutive days last week.

headline: In Efforts to End Bullying, Some See Agenda
text: HELENA, Mont.  Alarmed by evidence that gay and lesbian students are common victims of schoolyard bullies, many school districts are bolstering their antiharassment rules with early lessons in tolerance, explaining that some children have “two moms” or will grow up to love members of the same sex.

headline: Alaska Writes a Senator Back Into Contention
text: ANCHORAGE  Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska played many novel roles in her historic run as a write-in candidate. She was the insurgent incumbent, the maverick moderate, the outsider from the establishment, the underdog boasting about her seniority.

headline: He Saw Trouble Coming. Now He Sees It Going.
text: ARE we finally coming out of the woods, economically speaking?

headline: When a Rig Moves In Next Door
text: IN the sparsely populated pastures of De Soto Parish in Louisiana, the ability to extract gas from shale  which can involve a process known as fracking  has been welcomed as an economic windfall. Some residents call it a gift from God.

headline: Political Books Best-Seller List
text: “Obama’s Wars” by Bob Woodward made its debut at No. 1 in the latest survey of political best-sellers in October as American voters were preparing to render their verdict on how the nation is being governed.

headline: White Democrats Lose More Ground in South
text: It was less than 50 years ago that a young man named Lewis McAllister Jr. won a special election to become a Mississippi state representative.

headline: Chasing Pirates: Inside Microsoft’s War Room
text: AS the sun rose over the mountains circling Los Reyes, a town in the Mexican state of Michoacán, one morning in March 2009, a caravan of more than 300 heavily armed law enforcement agents set out on a raid.

headline: Myanmar Votes in Election Controlled by Military
text: YANGON, Myanmar  Polling places appeared nearly empty around Yangon on Sunday as the rest of the city went about its business in the first election in this closed and tightly controlled nation in 20 years.

headline: A Manager Who Stuck to His Guns and Fired Away
text: To everyone in baseball he was Sparky Anderson; hardly anybody called him George. But as a manager, he was not just a spark. He was a bonfire who sometimes burst into a three-alarm blaze.

headline: For David Lee, a New Team, a New Town and a New Look
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  This is how David Lee realized he was truly wanted here. The Los Angeles Lakers had just handcuffed Lee, holding him to no points and handing the Warriors their first loss of the season. That night, Golden State’s first-year coach, Keith Smart, called him.

headline: Can the Fed Draw a Virtuous Circle?
text: TWO momentous events occurred last week, and what was most startling for the financial markets was that they were so utterly predictable. As if on cue, the markets rose.

headline: Bloomberg Questions U.S. Inquiry Into China Trade Practices
text: HONG KONG  Criticizing China was a popular campaign tactic for Democrats and Republican candidates alike in many campaigns this year, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York was quick to leap to China’s defense on Saturday.

headline: Working (and Living) the Company Way
text: SEEN through the wide arc of history, ours is an edgy, mistrusting moment. Since the financial crisis two years ago, Americans have shown persistent skepticism about large corporations. According to a Pew Research Center report earlier this year, for example, only 25 percent of those surveyed say big business has a positive impact on how things are going in the country.

headline: Taking On a Second Mortgage to Pay the Foreclosure Lawyer
text: For some Florida residents, the price of getting out of foreclosure will include taking on a second mortgage  payable this time to their lawyers.

headline: At 102, Outliving Friends, Family and Her Savings
text: Mary Spencer was born during the Roosevelt administration. Theodore’s.

headline: When a Camcorder Becomes a Life Partner
text: YOU can shoot compelling video these days even when you have your hands full.

headline: $27.5 Million for 9/11 Workers
text: A group of workers who claimed they suffered health problems as a result of being exposed to debris from ground zero during its removal and transfer to a landfill on Staten Island stand to receive $27.5 million in a settlement announced on Friday.

headline: Ask Your Mentor for Help, Not for Brownie Points
text: This interview with Martha S. Samuelson,  president and C.E.O. of the Analysis Group, a consulting firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Bernanke Attempts to Soothe Doubters
text: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, continued on Saturday to rebut critics who feared the central bank’s latest bid to stimulate the economy could trigger dangerous inflation down the line and antagonize other countries by weakening the dollar.

headline: Yemen Judge Orders Arrest of Qaeda-Linked Cleric
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Yemeni judge on Saturday ordered the “forcible arrest” of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born cleric who is believed to play an important role in the regional branch of Al Qaeda.

headline: How Portable Is Your Life?
text: MOVING can be one of the most stressful events in life, although it can also be a great adventure. The option may seem especially tempting today, as some regions have much brighter job prospects than others amid the overall employment slump.

headline: Estate Tax Issue Offers Quick Test for Congress
text: AFTER their election victory on Tuesday, Republican leaders in the House promised progress on many fronts, including a turn toward more fiscal discipline and less economic uncertainty.

headline: 18 Bodies in Acapulco Grave Identified as Kidnapped Men
text: MEXICO CITY  The 18 bodies discovered in a mass grave just outside Acapulco have been identified as those of most of the 20 men who were kidnapped as they arrived last month for a brief vacation at the Pacific beach resort city, Mexican state authorities said Saturday.

headline: Savoring Baghdad, Where Each Night Is a Battle

text: To the Editor:

headline: Apple and I.B.M. Aren’t All That Different
text: EVERY once in while, there are symbolically intriguing historical moments in the corporate world, and one of them occurred last month. On Oct. 18, Apple and I.B.M. reported their quarterly results, and Apple’s total profit surged past I.B.M.’s.

headline: The C.F.L., and Learning to Love the Rouge
text: A madcap finish in a recent C.F.L. game. Enjoy the implications of the rouge.

headline: Replay Isn’t the Kind of Review That Will Make Umpires Better
text: Missed calls by umpires during the past baseball season prompted Commissioner Bud Selig to say he would examine the umpiring and replay systems. One reason the expansion of instant replay in baseball is objectionable is that it advances the notion that umpires are an addendum to the game, a necessary evil.

text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Recovery for Wall Street Pay
text: Bonuses will be up this year, according to an influential study by compensation expert Alan Johnson.  His research indicates pay in financial services will increase about 5 percent this year.

headline: More On Shibboleths
text: A few more thoughts on the problem of shibboleths in the face of a depressed world economy:

headline: Republican Gains Cheer a Former Power Broker at His Money-Laundering Trial
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  On the day after Republicans trounced Democrats in the midterm elections, Tom DeLay strolled around a courtroom here with an American flag lapel pin, looking carefree and chatting with strangers at his money-laundering trial with the habitual charm of a seasoned politician.

headline: Princess Haya Re-elected President
text: Princess Haya bint al-Hussein of Jordan was overwhelmingly re-elected as the president of the International Equestrian Federation on Friday after a contentious campaign that marked the first time in the federation’s history that an incumbent president had been challenged. Princess Haya won in the first round of voting at the federation’s general assembly in Taipei, Taiwan, capturing 90 of 124 votes. Her opponents, Sven Holmberg of Sweden and Henk Rottinghuis of the Netherlands, received 23 and 11 votes.

headline: Falling Back
text: Six poems to mark the end of daylight saving time.

headline: The Cost of a Vote Goes Up
text: The votes are in; the money has been counted. We can start assessing the damage to American democracy caused by the Supreme Court’s decision to allow corporations, unions and their lobby groups a free hand to deploy their money to elect the candidates of their choice. Already one thing seems certain: Votes are getting more expensive.

headline: Throwing the Bums Out for 140 Years
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Our Banana Republic
text: In my reporting, I regularly travel to banana republics notorious for their inequality. In some of these plutocracies, the richest 1 percent of the population gobbles up 20 percent of the national pie.

headline: Judges Were Independent. Then They Were Defeated.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Long Live Lady Luck
text: One of the most striking things about our recent midterm elections is that foreign policy played absolutely no part in the voting  and for that we have Lady Luck, and some good intelligence work, to thank. In fact, in the past year we’ve won the lottery five times in row. How often does that happen?

headline: Plenty of Work for the Lame Duck: The $4 Trillion Question
text: The Bush-era tax cuts are set to expire at year end. That means the lame duck Congress has tough choices to make and not a lot of time to make them.

headline: Barack Obama, Phone Home
text: AFTER his “shellacking,” President Obama had to do something. But who had the bright idea of scheduling his visit to India for right after this election? The Democrats’ failure to create jobs was at the heart of the shellacking. Nothing says “outsourcing” to the American public more succinctly than India. But the White House didn’t figure this out until the eve of Obama’s Friday departure, when it hastily rebranded his trip as a jobs mission. Perhaps the president should visit one of the Indian call centers policing Americans’ credit-card debts to feel our pain.

headline: Compounding a Conflict of Interest
text: AS hard as it sometimes is to write a story, it can be much harder to un-write one that should never have been published.

headline: Plenty of Work for the Lame Duck: And Other Urgent Business
text: Taxes are not the only heavy lifting for Congressional leaders in the lame duck session. Before they can go home for the holidays  to celebrate or lick their wounds  there is a lot more of the people’s work left to do.

headline: ‘Blindsided’: A President’s Story
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Federation Rankings Reflect a Youth Movement
text: Every two months, the World Chess Federation ranks the top players. In addition to the main list, there is one for the best players under age 21. Increasingly, the lists hold many of the same names.

headline: For State’s G.O.P., Now Flush, Risks on the Horizon
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: F.S.U. Coach Suspended
text: The A.C.C. suspended the Florida State women’s coach Mark Krikorian for one game and fined the university $25,000 for not taking several starters to the league tournament. Krikorian left the players home from the tournament in an apparent attempt to rest them for the N.C.A.A.s. Without them, Florida State lost its A.C.C. opener to Wake Forest. Florida State must forfeit its A.C.C. tournament expense reimbursement of roughly $15,000. (AP)

headline: First Openly Gay Episcopal Bishop to Retire
text: Bishop V. Gene Robinson, whose consecration as the first openly gay bishop in the Episcopal Church set off a historic rift in the global Anglican Communion, announced to his New Hampshire diocese on Saturday that he intended to step down.

headline: In Presidio, a Grasp at the Holy Grail of Energy Storage
text: Dozens of gray compartments, lined neatly in rows, inhabit a boxy concrete building on the edge of the impoverished border town of Presidio. The only sound, aside from occasional clanking, is the whirring of air-conditioners to keep the compartments cool.

headline: The Texas Shuffle
text: A roundup of notable new songs from the state’s great artists.

headline: Sunday: Leading Articles
text: Today’s theme involves the sort of wordplay I really enjoy in a Sunday puzzle. It’s a simple but clever twist, and novel as far as I know.

headline: Black Business Leaders Ponder Mayoral Election
text: Generations of the city’s black business leaders have played a vital yet largely unsung role in the struggle for civil rights and black political and economic empowerment in Chicago  from the Great Migration in the early 20th century to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s battle for open housing in the 1960s to the victory of Harold Washington in the 1980s to the making of a black president on a warm November night in Grant Park two years ago.

headline: Fair Photo or Cheap Shot?
text: The Times ran a striking photograph of President Obama at his post-election news conference last Wednesday and it wasn’t long before readers responded with an outpouring of messages to the Public Editor, all complaining of the newspaper’s decision to use this closely-cropped photo of Mr. Obama.

headline: Redistricting Reality Ahead for Cocky G.O.P.
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: As City Employees Tighten Belts, Some Elected Officials Are Reluctant to Adjust Theirs
text: When aldermen vote Nov. 17 on a budget for 2011, they are expected to help close the city’s $655 million fiscal hole by again requiring all employees to take almost five weeks off without pay.

headline: Readers Comments on Inequality
text: My Sunday column wrestles with growing economic inequality in America — and the sad reality that our income gaps look like those of a classic banana republic. I didn’t have space in the column to look at why the gaps have grown larger, but this is explored at some depth in the Slate series that I mention and link to in the column. It’s not fundamentally about tax policy, but my hunch is that it has a good deal to do with social mores and acceptability.

headline: If Not ‘The Man,’ Kane Takes on Role of ‘The Reveler’
text: Jay Blunk was a newly appointed Blackhawks executive in June 2008 when he was struck by how easily Patrick Kane was able to move through a passenger terminal at O’Hare International Airport. The then-19-year-old Blackhawk was (and is) one of the bright young stars in hockey, having won the Calder Trophy as National Hockey League rookie of the year for the 2007-8 season.

headline: In Whitman and Fiorina, Candidacies That Did Not Compute
text: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: New Role for Gavin Newsom, but Fuzzy Guidelines on What It Will Be
text: The sun reflecting off his slicked-back hair, Mayor Gavin Newsom took the microphone Wednesday afternoon and smiled upon the sea of humanity crammed into the Civic Center to celebrate the Giants’ World Series victory.

headline: In Oakland, Defeat of Measure Isn’t the End
text: The television news crews that descended on Oakland last week to cover the outcome of Proposition 19, which would have legalized marijuana in the state, are now long gone, along with the high hopes of many local cannabis entrepreneurs.

headline: Pelosi Urges Unity and Says She Will Work Toward Democratic Rebound
text: In a letter to colleagues, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who is seeking to remain as minority leader despite her party’s steep election losses, urged House Democrats to unite behind her and even said she hopes to help ousted lawmakers return to Congress in two years.

headline: Obama Invokes Gandhi, Whose Ideal Eludes India
text: NEW DELHI  Not long after Barack Obama was elected president, the United States Embassy in India printed a postcard showing him sitting in his old Senate office beneath framed photographs of his political heroes: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Abraham Lincoln and the great Indian apostle of peace, democracy and nonviolent protest, Mohandas K. Gandhi.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Nov. 7
text: With the midterm election results still rolling in, this Sunday’s television talk shows focus on the lame duck session of Congress that begins in just over a week, and the next session, when Republicans will control the House.

headline: Sweat | Already a Winner, With 26.2 Miles to Go
text: Update, Monday, Nov. 8 | Click to read how Carmen’s marathon day turned out.

headline: Nightlife Still Lively in Baghdad Neighborhood
text: An upswing in violence in Baghdad has not stopped local residents from stepping out in the evening to the colorful lights and diversions of the Karada district.

headline: G.O.P. to Fight Health Law With Purse Strings
text: WASHINGTON  As they seek to make good on their campaign promise to roll back President Obama’s health care overhaul, the incoming Republican leaders in the House say they intend to use their new muscle to cut off money for the law, setting up a series of partisan clashes and testing Democratic commitment to the legislation.

headline: No Sentence Yet, but Jurors in Cheshire Killings Offer a Hint of Their Thinking
text: NEW HAVEN  Jurors considering the fate of the convicted killer in the Cheshire, Conn., home invasion case deliberated for a second day without reaching a verdict Saturday on whether to impose a death sentence, but sent a note indicating that they remained focused on arguments that could spare the life of the defendant, Steven J. Hayes.

headline: Syracuse Still a Win Away From a Trip to a Bowl
text: SYRACUSE  The rejuvenated Syracuse football team had one final chance to win on Saturday, but Orange fans seemed to know a lost cause when they saw one. Most of the big crowd had hustled toward the exits at the Carrier Dome, not even pausing for another look.

headline: In the Midst of Controversy, Auburn’s Newton Dazzles
text: AUBURN, Ala.  The group hug for Cam Newton started on the tailgates outside Jordan-Hare Stadium here Saturday. Signs fit for a political rally were leaning up against cars or being carried around on wooden sticks: “Don’t Hate on Cam” and “Yes, We Cam.”

headline: Off Center Stage, T.C.U. Bolsters Case With a Rout
text: SALT LAKE CITY  Texas Christian’s resounding victory over Utah on Saturday could be watched by only a limited cable television audience, so T.C.U. Coach Gary Patterson used an analogy from plain old network television to sum up his team’s chances of playing for the national title.

headline: Sign Hill
text: South San Francisco proudly advertises its history to every passing motorist northbound on Highway 101. Industry has changed, though, since the sign’s 1923 construction: biotechnology has replaced steel mills and slaughterhouses.

headline: Zenyatta Misses History by a Head
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Her owners, Jerry and Ann Moss; her trainer, John Shirreffs; and for that matter anyone who had watched and loved the great racemare Zenyatta knew that the real running  the edge-of-the-seat-drama  really didn’t start until she turned for home. Nineteen times before, Zenyatta had looked desperate and in trouble at the top of the stretch. Nineteen times before, she had found a gear to rocket past her rivals in the final strides.
