text: NATIONAL

headline: College Football Replay: Nov. 6
text: Photographs from the day’s college football games.

headline: $27.5 Million Settlement for 9/11 Workers
text: A group of workers who claimed they suffered health problems as a result of being exposed to debris from ground zero during its removal and transfer to a landfill on Staten Island stand to receive $27.5 million in a settlement announced on Friday.

headline: Long Island House Seat Is Back in Play
text: A new vote count on Long Island appears to have called into question the apparent victory of an incumbent Democratic congressman on Long Island.

headline: Bronx Family Mourns a Baby and Protests a Father’s Arrest
text: A homemade placard outside the stately old apartment building on Davidson Avenue in the Bronx told of the heartbreak inside on Saturday.

headline: Vows: Hiroko and Ryan
text: Two doctors, Hiroko and Ryan, met in an emergency room in a children's hospital. She had Snoopy stickers on her ID badge and he was coincidentally wearing Snoopy socks. A love affair was sparked.

headline: Turnout Appears Light in Myanmar’s Election
text: YANGON, MYANMAR — Polling places appeared nearly empty around Yangon on Sunday as the rest of the city went about its business during the first election in 20 years in this closed and tightly controlled nation.

headline: Obama Pointedly Questioned by Students in India
text: MUMBAI, India  When Michelle Obama, the first lady, introduced her husband to a group of college students here on Sunday, she urged them to ask him “tough questions.”

headline: New Guides to Istanbul Offer Insider Tips
text: Thanks to a handful of new books by locals in the know, visitors to Istanbul can now delve even deeper into this city’s delights.

headline: Jets-Lions Subplot to Watch: Suh vs. Brandon Moore
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The television cameras in Sunday’s Lions-Jets game will focus on the telegenic battle between Matthew Stafford and Mark Sanchez, and why not? We’ll see two sophomore quarterbacks, each taken in the first five picks of the 2009 draft, with promising futures, winning smiles and boyish good looks. But in the trenches is where the real main event on Sunday may be: the Lions’ Ndamukong Suh versus the Jets’ Brandon Moore.

headline: Charlie Whitehurst a Juicy Target for Giants
text: It’s a strange run-up to an N.F.L. game when a lot of people are just hoping that a quarterback (Charlie Whitehurst) will leave the field in one piece.

headline: The Man Who Blesses Horses
text: In a “bucket list” moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since — when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: Meltzer Misleads
text: Reading Allan Meltzer’s latest, you might think that the CPI and the PCE deflator — two alternate measures of inflation — were telling dramatically different stories about what was happening to the US economy. But here’s what they actually did:

text: On our walk with the dogs to Catfish pond on Saturday, my younger son and I, along with a neighbor, mused on the wondrous lives of newts, specifically the eastern newt. Here’s a video snippet:

headline: A Breeders’ Cup Convert
text: Kate Miller is head of racing media for William Hill Company in England and works with the odds compilers in the company’s Leeds office. She also is the daughter of the former racecourse bookmaker Charlie Miller, and knows her way around horses.

headline: Hey, Ms. Traffic Agent, a Break for a Working Stiff?
text: It is an old strategy among parcel delivery drivers in New York City: Leave a parking summons tucked on your windshield and hope the ticket agent walks right past your illegally parked truck, believing it has already been ticketed.

headline: Hollywood Actors Reach Tentative Deal Early on New Contract
text: LOS ANGELES — With little fanfare, Hollywood’s movie and television production companies and actors unions early on Sunday morning said they had agreed tentatively to a new three-year contract that provides a 6 percent increase in wages and increased health and benefits contributions by the companies.

headline: Protesters Rally in Seoul Ahead of G-20 Summit
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Tens of thousands of protesters held a peaceful, almost festive, rally in Seoul, South Korea, on Sunday to protest the Group of 20 summit meeting that begins here on Thursday.

headline: Weir Wins Men’s Wheelchair Division
text: As the men or women’s elite runners jostled their way through Brooklyn, a sprint to the finish was under way in Central Park in the wheelchair division of the New York City Marathon.

headline: Gebrselassie Retires After Dropping Out
text: 1:01 p.m. | Updated Haile Gebrselassie announced after he dropped out of the New York City Marathon that he is retiring from running.

headline: New York City Marathon as It Happened
text: When world record holder Haile Gebrselassie dropped out of the New York City Marathon just more than halfway through, it opened the door for a different man from Ethiopia to grab the stage and Gebre Gebremariam took advantage.

headline: Gebremariam Wins Men’s Race in Debut
text: Growing up in Ethiopia’s northernmost region of Tigray, Gebre Gebremariam studied Haile Gebrselassie in school, memorizing his medals and records, learning what it took to be a legend.

headline: Live Analysis: Jets 23, Lions 20, OT, Final
text: The team that ripped off five straight wins earlier this season seemed to forsake their Jets uniforms, leaving behind a sloppy, mistake-prone, ugly new incarnation of Gang Green over the past two weeks. But the final moments of a 23-20 overtime win in Detroit on Sunday may have reawakened the sleepwalking Jets.

headline: An Untested Two Set the Women’s Pace
text: Before this year, Edna Kiplagat had developed a distant relationship with the marathon. She had run the event just once, finishing 10th in the Las Vegas Marathon in 2 hours 50 minutes 20 seconds. Her coach and husband, Gilbert Koech, felt that she needed time away from the 26.2-mile distance and instead focused on developing her career in shorter road races.

headline: The Morning Line: Racing’s Heartbreak
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: For Stanford, Dreams of the Rose Bowl
text: STANFORD, Calif. — As the Stanford players exited the field after their 42-17 victory against Arizona on Saturday night, they were met by a fan waving a poster that read, “WAKE UP AND SMELL THE ROSES.”

headline: Greek Premier Claims Victory in Local Elections Seen as a Referendum on Austerity
text: ATHENS  Since he was elected a year ago, Prime Minister George Papandreou has struggled to satisfy two difficult and seemingly mutually exclusive constituencies: international financial markets and Greeks.

headline: Boos for Childress, Inside Stadium and Out
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Brad Childress, the embattled Minnesota Vikings coach, expected boos and catcalls at the Metrodome on Sunday, and you didn’t have to walk into the building to hear them.

headline: Morality Tales as Horror and Suspense
text: Last November, Doubleday published John Grisham’s “Ford County,” a collection of short stories from a man whose specialty is full-length legal drama. These stories were revelatory. They showed how much verve, suspense, instruction and moral ambiguity Mr. Grisham could pack into bare-bones plotlines. He could accomplish in 40-page virtual synopses what he normally does in 400-page novels.

headline: Running With the Elites
text: Some of the world’s top runners competed for the New York City Marathon title, with the veterans edged by the newcomers.

headline: Texas Two-Step
text: Hmm. Do you remember how Texas showed that conservative policies work — it was weathering the slump just fine, it had a balanced budget, and so on?

headline: Pentagon Openings Give Obama Options
text: WASHINGTON  With critical decisions ahead on the war in Afghanistan, President Obama is about to receive an unusual opportunity to reshape the Pentagon’s leadership, naming a new defense secretary as well as several top generals and admirals in the next several months.

headline: Live Analysis: Giants 41, Seahawks 7, Final
text: In training camp, the Giants were overshadowed by their splashy New York counterparts, and after their back-to-back losses in September, there seemed to be little reason to pay them any mind.

headline: ‘Scottsboro Boys’ Is Focus of Protest
text: A group of about 30 people gathered on Saturday afternoon in front of the Lyceum Theater to protest a matinee of the new Broadway musical “The Scottsboro Boys,” which retells the story of nine African-Americans between 12 and 19 who were falsely convicted of raping two white women in Alabama in 1931. The show, written by the celebrated team of John Kander and Fred Ebb and directed by the Tony-winning director Susan Stroman, uses the minstrel tradition to tell the story of how racism infected the judicial system.

headline: Web Browsing Takes a Social Turn
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Silicon Valley is awash in tales of the “PayPal Mafia,” the tight-knit group of PayPal alumni who have helped one another start and finance a crop of new companies.

headline: At Mile 16, Gebrselassie Ends His Race, and Career
text: Word spread Saturday that the great Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia had a knee problem. Then came a message from his Twitter account Sunday morning that seemed casual and ominous.

headline: A New Bridge, Too Far to Notice
text: The marathon course featured a $600 million change this year — although many runners said they did not notice.

headline: Clayburgh’s Unforgettable ‘Unmarried Woman’
text: In the most famous scene in Jill Clayburgh’s most influential movie, her character reacted to the news that her husband wanted to leave her. Ms. Clayburgh’s Erica responded with such naturalness, confusion and wounded pride that she captured the imagination of a generation.

headline: How Liable is Goldman?
text: Professor Eric J. Pan talks about the role of clearing firms and possible consequences of the Bayou case.

headline: She Who Belts Out the Uncertainty
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Carrie Underwood poses with the microphone, grips it firmly as an athlete might, pulls it slowly away from her mouth as she hits the biggest, longest notes. When her right arm is bent at 90 degrees, and her head’s tilted back just so, she exudes victory. Miniaturized and cast in gold plate, she would look perfect slapped atop a trophy, maybe one for winning a televised singing competition.

headline: In Rediscovered Osborne Play, Glimpse of Angry Young Writer
text: When an unknown John Osborne revolutionized British theater in the 1950s with his furious, establishment-battering autobiographical play “Look Back in Anger,” it wasn’t the first script he had written in which he challenged postwar conformity.

headline: The Fine Art of Card Reading, Courtesy of a Top Practitioner
text: Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., is known as one of the world’s most imaginative declarers. He again proved that his reputation is justified in the diagramed deal, which was Board 4 of the final session of the World Open Pairs in Philadelphia last month.

headline: An Elephant, a Jellyfish and a Man With a Lot on, and in, His Mind
text: Apparently you can go home again. You just have to be prepared to confront another version of yourself when you get there, a version who may not be at all sympathetic to the intrusion.

headline: Luminaries and Hopefuls Join to Ensure Choreography’s Future
text: If ballet is to have a future, it needs new choreography. Let nobody doubt that steps are being taken to make that future happen. The New York Choreographic Institute is dedicated to promoting the development of choreographers by providing dancers, rehearsal space and time, symposiums and seminars on choreography and other theater arts, and choreographic fellowships with individual companies.

headline: An Ensemble Sheds a Spotlight on New and Unusual Repertory
text: The Riverside Symphony, one of New York’s feistier freelance ensembles, has made a point of playing new works and rarities, and giving young soloists a spotlight in concertos. The orchestra is celebrating its 30th anniversary, and, true to form, it opened its season at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening with an ambitious program in which the closest it came to the standard repertory was in Schumann’s “Genoveva” Overture and Sibelius’s Seventh Symphony: works you can go many seasons without hearing in concert.

headline: The Porous Bernstein Border
text: Consider the two sides of Leonard Bernstein as fraternal twins gazing at each other across a divide. One is a dazzling Broadway melodist, the other a classical composer in search of a universal musical style. The two confronted each other on Saturday evening at the David H. Koch Theater in a concert, “Lucky to Be Me: The Music of Leonard Bernstein,” devoted to vocal pieces from both sides of the fence.

headline: The Mulch, the Tunics, the Lunges
text: In “Wilderness,” a new movement installation presented by Dance Theater Workshop at the Invisible Dog Art Center, Yanira Castro continued her mission of fleshing out the relationship between two groups of people: those doing the watching and those doing the performing.

headline: Speech and Harm
text: As every public figure knows, there are certain words that can not be uttered without causing shock or offense. These words, commonly known as “slurs,” target groups on the basis of race, nationality, religion, gender, sexual orientation, immigration status and sundry other demographics.  Many of us were reminded of the impact of such speech in August, when the radio host Dr. Laura Schlessinger repeatedly uttered a racial slur on a broadcast of her show. A public outcry followed, and ultimately led to her resignation. Many such incidents of abuse and offense, often with much more serious consequences, seem to appear in the news by the day.

headline: A Cuban-American Cultural Exchange Comes Full Circle
text: HAVANA  Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, stood by a fluted pillar in a lofty studio at the National Ballet School here on Friday, keeping time with his hands as a group of male students practiced jetés in a circle.

headline: Monday: Utterance
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I particularly admire puzzles that tell a story as you solve them from top to bottom. We don’t quite have a story today but there’s a little surprise near the end that, if things work out correctly, makes you revisit the theme with a new appreciation. The first three theme answers start with words that are roughly synonyms. The final one starts with CATCH, another synonym, but the full answer, CATCH PHRASES, provides further justification for the first three. Nicely done.

headline: Aronian Grabs Early Lead at Tal Memorial
text: Levon Aronian, the top seed in the tournament, has won two of his first three games.

headline: A Ceremony for Jews Who Fought for Germany
text: FRANKFURT — German soldiers, including one wearing a skullcap with his uniform, filed silently through a leaf-covered cemetery in Frankfurt on Sunday to lay wreaths at a memorial for 467 Jewish soldiers killed fighting for the kaiser during World War I.

headline: An Airy Touch Delivering Emotional Heft
text: Of all the terms that could describe a pianist’s work, “rightness” is probably among the least precise. Yet again and again as Alessio Bax performed at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, everything in his program unfolded with an ease, precision and beauty so seemingly effortless that the music appeared to live and breathe of its own volition.

headline: Onto Streets of New York, the Miner Perseveres
text: Edison Peña could be forgiven for having to slow to a walk at times during the New York City Marathon on Sunday. His training, after all, came via subterranean loops of only a few miles at a time, with the tunnels of a collapsed gold and copper mine for a course and sawed-off work boots for footwear.

headline: Italian Leader Urged to Resign by Former Ally
text: ROME  A former political ally-turned-adversary of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi called on Sunday for the Italian leader to resign and make way for a new government with a revamped legislative program and a broader political base.

headline: Ash in the Air, Confusion on the Ground
text: GEMAMPIR, Indonesia  As this village emptied around her, and the Mount Merapi volcano boomed not too far uphill behind a veil of dust, Puranti stood crying here on Sunday afternoon, frozen with indecision. A few hours earlier, her relatives had gone back to fetch fresh clothes in their village  farther uphill toward Mount Merapi, in an area so close to the volcano’s rim that it had been evacuated days before.

headline: American Ballet Theater in Cuba
text: Dancers experienced moments artistic, historical and personal during their visit to Havana.

headline: Guinea Votes in Its First Democratic Presidential Election
text: CONAKRY, Guinea — After weeks of delays, ethnic tensions and clashes between the police and rival groups of supporters, this mineral-rich but poor West African nation quietly went to the polls Sunday to choose its first-ever democratically elected president.

headline: Joyce Theater Announces Its Spring Lineup
text: Ronald K. Brown and his dance company Evidence will kick off the Joyce Theater’s spring season with a world premiere set to the music of Stevie Wonder, the theater announced. The piece, “On Earth Together,” created to celebrate the company’s 25th anniversary, will run Feb. 8 to 13. Other companies will present well-known pieces and new works during the season, which runs through August. Highlights are to include the world premiere of “Dark Habits” (March 8 to 13), an examination of fashion and drama from Keigwin + Company; and the New York premiere of “Chapters From a Broken Novel” from Doug Varone & Dancers, with a score played live by David Van Tieghem, the composer (March 15 to 20). The Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which has been presenting works at the Joyce since 1984, will offer perhaps the most somber performance of the season. In its last program there before the company disbands in December 2011, it will perform some of its most famous pieces, including “CRWDSPCR” and “Antic Meet” (Mar. 22 to 27). And in June the Gotham Dance Festival expands last year’s lineup with two programs of works by the choreographers Monica Bill Barnes, Brian Brooks, Kate Weare and Patrick Corbin, along with six emerging artists in its Summer Sampler Matinees, on Saturdays and Sundays.

headline: Dreamworks Animation’s ‘Megamind’ Is a Megahit
text: DreamWorks Animation has another hit on its hands: “Megamind,” the story of a supervillain turned superhero, which reached No. 1 with an estimated $47.7 million in its opening weekend at the North American box office, according to Hollywood.com, a compiler of box-office statistics. That result is better than the opening for the studio’s hit “How to Train Your Dragon,” which sold $43.7 million in its first weekend, but lower than initial results for its pictures like “Kung Fu Panda” and “Monsters vs. Aliens.” In an unusual move “Megamind,” distributed by Paramount Pictures, saved a substantial part of its television marketing push to avoid competing with midterm election ads; 40 percent of the film’s TV advertising budget was spent over the past week. The comedy “Due Date” (Warner Brothers) was second, with a strong $33.5 million. The Lionsgate drama “For Colored Girls,” adapted by Tyler Perry from Ntozake Shange’s seminal play, “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow is Enuf,” was third with a solid $20.1 million. The ensemble action film “RED” (Summit Entertainment) chugged away in fourth place with $8.9 million for a new total of $71.9 million. “Saw 3D” (Lionsgate) was fifth with about $8.2 million for a new total of $38.8 million.

headline: A Free Evening of Arts for the Military
text: The actors Adam Driver (“Mrs. Warren’s Profession”) and Joanne Tucker (“Little Doc”), both below, will present an evening of free jazz and readings for military personnel, veterans and their families on Monday night at American Airlines Theater. It will be the first performance by their group, Arts in the Armed Forces, since it gained nonprofit status in September. David Cromer will direct performances by actors including Eric Bogosian, Susan Sarandon, Dianne Wiest and Lauren Ambrose, among others, in honor of Veterans Day. Mr. Driver, a former Marine lance corporal, said by telephone on Sunday that the idea for the company came from a need that he and Ms. Tucker, whom he met while studying theater at Juilliard, noticed for more culturally diverse entertainment for the troops. “We called U.S.O. events ‘mandatory fun,’ ” Mr. Driver said of his time in the Marines, citing an event that included a skateboarding demonstration and a contest to win a date with a San Diego Chargers cheerleader. “You couldn’t help but feel marginalized.” Now they hope their organization will encourage dialogue between artists and military members. “In a place where emotions are not talked about, there seemed a need,” Mr. Driver said. “Putting words to feelings is a powerful thing, and theater was the best way for me to do that.” The readings include works from the playwrights John Patrick Shanley, a former Marine who will introduce the evening, Charles Fuller (“A Soldier’s Play”) and Stephen Adly Guirgis (“The Little Flower of East Orange”). Their plays have a “grittier edge,” Ms. Tucker said, but are not necessarily about the military. The program begins at 8 p.m.

headline: Footnotes
text: Career Transition for Dancers will celebrate 25 years of helping performers on the road to post-stage careers with a gala on Monday at City Center. Angela Lansbury will be the host, with a performance lineup that includes dancers from Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and American Ballet Theater, along with numbers from “42nd Street” and “Chicago.” Tickets and more information: careertransition.org. ... Jules Feiffer, above, the creator of the long-running Village Voice comic strip, will give a tour of his life using a slide show of his own comic strips, as well as those from his mentors and contemporaries, during a presentation to benefit the Writers Guild of America, East Foundation. Mr. Feiffer won a Pulitzer Prize in 1986 for his work as a cartoonist and was nominated to the Comic Book Hall of Fame in 2004. In March his autobiography, “Backing Into Forward,” was published by Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. The benefit will be held at 8 p.m. on Nov. 15 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said in an interview broadcast Sunday night that he views last week’s mid-term Congressional elections as “a referendum

headline: U.S. Revises Offer to Take Sudan Off Terror List
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has told Sudan that if it allows a politically sensitive referendum to go ahead in January, and abides by the results, the United States will move to take the country off its list of state sponsors of terrorism as early as next July, administration officials said Sunday.

headline: ‘Days of Our Lives’ Renewed for 2 More Years
text: In a welcome bit of news for the daytime soap opera segment, NBC will announce on Monday that it is renewing its only daytime soap, “Days of Our Lives,” for two more years.

headline: No Decision on Penalty in Cheshire Triple Murder
text: NEW HAVEN  The jury considering whether the convicted killer in the Cheshire home invasion case is to be sentenced to death ended its third day of deliberations on Sunday without reaching a verdict.

headline: Scientists Join Forces in a Hostile Climate

headline: Mayor’s Daughter Is Hurt in a Fall
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s younger daughter, Georgina, was injured on Friday night during an equestrian tournament in Syracuse after her horse’s saddle came loose and she fell, her spokesman said.

headline: ‘Morning Joe’ Host’s Other Plans on Election Night
text: Where was Joe Scarborough on election night? He was 160 miles from MSNBC’s studio, speaking to students at Williams College in Massachusetts with his co-host, Mika Brzezinski, who graduated from there.

headline: Fresh Off Victories, Republicans Share Their Plans
text: Rand Paul, the newly elected senator from Kentucky who received ardent Tea Party backing, said Sunday that the movement’s success was “equal parts chastisement” to Democrats and Republicans, particularly on the issue of the ballooning federal debt.

headline: Best Way to Recruit a Runner? Take Him for a Ride
text: The torch is passed, one way or the other.

headline: Chinese Animator Seeks a Global Role
text: BEIJING  Ostensibly, there is no connection between the 2008 vampire movie “Twilight” and a Warren Buffett cartoon series meant to teach financial basics to children.

headline: Where Marijuana Is a Point of Pride
text: NEDERLAND, Colo.  Millions of Americans expressed their feelings about marijuana last week. In Colorado, 24 communities voted to ban or restrict shops selling legal medical marijuana. In California, voters wrestled with the question of legalization for recreational use  with issues of health, crime and taxes all coming into play  then voted no.

headline: Lincoln Wins. Now What?
Plan for Electric Cable to Grid Nears Deadline
text: A deadline looms to save a project, years in the planning, that would involve digging under the Hudson River to connect New Jersey and Manhattan, but government officials cannot agree on how to share the costs. Sound familiar?

headline: Maneuver Over Copters Is Opposed
text: The Air Force has taken a beating over its contract process in recent years. But if officials thought a new approach would avoid controversy, they have been disappointed.

headline: Back in the Fold, and Back on the Slopes
text: VAIL, Colo.  After he won the second of his three medals at the Vancouver Olympics in February, Bode Miller tried to explain, yet again, why he has never been fixated on the final result in a sport that is all about getting across the line fastest.

headline: High Hopes for Conan O’Brien’s Debut
text: Only 17 months after his last reappearance in a starring role on late-night television, Conan O’Brien is back.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,353 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Saturday:

headline: Olbermann, Impartiality and MSNBC
text: MSNBC, worried that its reputation as a fair broker of the news hung in the balance, sent Keith Olbermann to the woodshed on Friday for an unpaid suspension because he had donated $7,200 to some of the Democratic politicians he had championed on his hit show “Countdown.”

headline: In Lame-Duck Session, a Hint of the Governing to Come
text: This week, Washington starts to regroup.

headline: Fouls Mar Knicks’ Effort in Sloppy Loss to 76ers
text: Landry Fields, the Knicks rookie guard, had toned down his act by the second time he was called for a foul  one for three shots  in 64 seconds late in the third quarter Sunday. Rather than looking as if he were horribly aggrieved, Fields merely tried to change the officials’ minds by pointing upcourt.

headline: In a Suburb, a Microcosm of the Nation
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.

headline: Irish Debt Woes Revive Concern About Europe
text: LONDON  When interest rates soared last week on Irish government bonds, it served as a grim warning to other indebted nations of how difficult and even politically ruinous it could be to roll back decades of public sector largess.

headline: New York City Marathon Photo Replay: Nov. 7
text: A look at the marathon from elite runners to people on the street watching them pass.

headline: Doctor Prepared for the Worst at Marathon
text: On Sunday morning at 7:30, Dr. Stuart Weiss, the medical director of the New York City Marathon, was holding a coffee with one hand, gesturing with the other, and moving at the stereotypically brisk pace of an emergency room doctor. Walking in and out of the white medical command tent in Central Park, he was focused, he said, on “What’s missing? What’s missing? What’s missing?”

headline: For Afghan Wives, a Desperate, Fiery Way Out
text: HERAT, Afghanistan  Even the poorest families in Afghanistan have matches and cooking fuel. The combination usually sustains life. But it also can be the makings of a horrifying escape: from poverty, from forced marriages, from the abuse and despondency that can be the fate of Afghan women.

headline: It’s Harder to Run the Marathon When the L.I.R.R. Barely Runs
text: Usually, a disruption on the Long Island Rail Road can be measured in losses of time, productivity and maybe a home-cooked meal. For Frank Priedemann, the problems on Sunday had a more tangible cost: about $350.

headline: Facing Marathon, Knicks Should Pick Up the Pace
text: Just when New Yorkers were ready to be excited about them, the Knicks reminded fans that they are a work in progress  for many a lifelong work.

headline: Friedman Casts Shadow as Economists Meet
text: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  The Federal Reserve is portraying its $600 billion plan to prop up the economic recovery as a difficult but needed step to promote growth by lifting stock prices and making long-term borrowing even cheaper.

headline: Like a Monitor More Than a Tutor
text: Sitting at a dining room table festooned with papers, colored folders and laptop and iPad screens in his Upper West Side apartment, Benji Sternberg, 13, rattled off correct answers to a slew of homework questions, peppering them with wisecracks and occasional bursts of song.

headline: The Jets Finally Get Going With a Hurry-Up Offense
text: DETROIT  Like a college student who waited until the last minute to study but somehow pulled an A, the Jets were a little cocky and a little sheepish after their comeback 23-20 overtime victory over the young Detroit Lions on Sunday.

headline: Kindness of a Stranger That Still Resonates
text: CANTON, Ohio  The event was a reunion for people who were never supposed to meet, commemorating an act of charity that succeeded because it happened in secret.

headline: With Book, Bush Is Back in Spotlight
text: George W. Bush will end a self-imposed silence about his presidency in an NBC prime-time special on Monday, the eve of the release of his memoir, “Decision Points.” That the interviewer will be Matt Lauer, the co-host of the “Today” show, reveals calculations by Mr. Bush and his advisers, as well as a campaign by NBC.

headline: Giants Put on a Highlight Show, Using the Seahawks as Extras
text: SEATTLE  The Giants did not beat the Seahawks on Sunday so much as they battered and embarrassed them. They gained nearly four times as many yards, held the ball for more than twice as long, committed fewer penalties, converted third downs more efficiently, forced more turnovers, and on and on it went.

headline: Phone Apps Aim to Fight Harassment
text: It was almost a year ago that a subway ride turned Violet Kittappa into an activist.

headline: Eagles’ Quick Strikes Doom the Depleted Colts
text: PHILADELPHIA  For a few minutes Sunday, it appeared the Philadelphia Eagles would run away from the Indianapolis Colts and Peyton Manning, the N.F.L.’s most thrilling quarterback. The Eagles were out-highlighting a usually explosive offense hampered by injuries that made it look like a high-performance car with a very flat tire.

headline: Now in Power, G.O.P. Vows Cuts in State Budgets
text: Republicans who have taken over state capitols across the country are promising to respond to crippling budget deficits with an array of cuts, among them proposals to reduce public workers’ benefits in Wisconsin, scale back social services in Maine and sell off state liquor stores in Pennsylvania, endangering the jobs of thousands of state workers.

headline: Burning Desperation
text: Self-immolation has become a common form of suicide for Afghan women. Photographer Lynsey Addario speaks with women who survived their suicide attempts.

headline: Paying the Lowest Yield on Company Debt

text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  The man with perhaps the most gruesome job in sports was unenviably busy. While other football fans spent the last weekend of October watching games, the 74-year-old retiree prepared still more formal inquiries into events that occupy him more than anyone would prefer  two high school football tragedies.

headline: A More Personal View of a Detainee’s Trial
text: The trial of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani has attracted intense interest as a test of the Obama administration’s strategy to try Guantánamo detainees in civilian court. But few have as much personal connection to the case as the group of onlookers who fill several rows of the Manhattan courtroom.

headline: T.C.U.’s Rise Could Lead to Change in Leagues

headline: D.E.A. Deployed Mumbai Plotter Despite Warning
text: WASHINGTON — American authorities sent David C. Headley, a small-time drug dealer and sometime informant, to work for them in Pakistan months after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, despite a warning that he sympathized with radical Islamic groups, according to court records and interviews. Not long after Mr. Headley arrived there, he began training with terrorists, eventually playing a key role in the 2008 attacks that left 164 people dead in Mumbai.

headline: Yankees Start the Wooing of Lee Immediately
text: The Yankees called the agent for pitcher Cliff Lee shortly after free agency began at 12:01 a.m. Sunday, telling the agent that signing Lee was one of their top priorities this off-season, an official in baseball briefed on the matter said.

headline: Suicide in Herat
text: Even the poorest families in Afghanistan have matches and cooking fuel. The combination usually sustains life. But it also can be the makings of a horrifying escape: from poverty, from forced marriages, from the abuse and despondency that can be the fate of Afghan women. text: Since the St. Louis Blues came into existence in 1967, they had never shut out the Rangers  until Sunday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Rule on Hits to the Head to Be Discussed
text: On Tuesday, N.H.L. general managers are scheduled to discuss Rule 48, which prohibits blindside and targeted checks to the head, amid mounting pressure to outlaw all contact to the head.

headline: Amazon Has a Reported Deal to Buy Parent of Diapers.com
text: Amazon.com plans to announce Monday that it will acquire Quidsi, the e-commerce company that runs Diapers.com, for about $540 million, according to a person with knowledge of the deal.

headline: For Family of Slain Activist, No End in Sight for Case
text: HAIFA, Israel  Seven years after an American student, Rachel Corrie, was killed in Gaza by an Israeli military bulldozer she tried to block, becoming a global symbol of the Palestinian struggle, her parents and her older sister sit in an Israeli court in this northern city with two hopes: to confront the men who ran over her and to prove that the army investigation into her death was flawed.

headline: Inconsistency, Yet a Winning Streak, for the Raiders and Campbell
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the span of a few hours Sunday, so much changed. The weather turned from stormy to calm; Oakland quarterback Jason Campbell went from scapegoat to savior; and the Raiders’ season went from murky to clear.

headline: Mr. Peanut’s New Look? Old School
text: ON Madison Avenue, there are talking dogs, talking horses, even talking margarine tubs, not to mention talking brand characters like the E*Trade babies and the Keebler elves. But Mr. Peanut, the dapper Planters mascot since 1916, has never spoken  until now.

headline: My Endless New York
text: I CAME to New York University in 1987 on a whim. The Thatcherite assault on British higher education was just beginning and even in Oxford the prospects were grim. N.Y.U. appealed to me: by no means a recent foundation — it was established in 1831 — it is nevertheless the junior of New York City’s great universities. Less of a “city on a hill,” it is more open to new directions: in contrast to the cloistered collegiate worlds of Oxbridge, it brazenly advertises itself as a “global” university at the heart of a world city.

headline: MSNBC to Lift Olbermann Suspension on Tuesday
text: Keith Olbermann will be allowed to resume his nightly program on MSNBC on Tuesday, the channel’s president said Sunday night, after he was suspended for donating money to three Democratic candidates.

headline: A New Leader for the Democrats
text: Nancy Pelosi has been an extremely effective speaker of the House for four years, shepherding hundreds of important bills toward passage and withstanding solid Republican opposition. Her work in passing health care reform and strong ethics oversight achieved what many thought was legislatively impossible. But is she really the best the Democrats can come up with as their leader as they slip into the minority?

headline: Doing It Again
text: Eight years ago Ben Bernanke, already a governor at the Federal Reserve although not yet chairman, spoke at a conference honoring Milton Friedman. He closed his talk by addressing Friedman’s famous claim that the Fed was responsible for the Great Depression, because it failed to do what was necessary to save the economy.

headline: The Next Campaign
text: Trounced in Tuesday’s elections, some Democratic leaders are already plotting a 2012 comeback based on the same brutal big-money tactics employed so effectively this year by Republicans. Harold Ickes, a top Democratic operative and fund-raiser, told The Los Angeles Times that it was a mistake for the White House to discourage profuse spending in a fistfight. Steve Phillips, a California fund-raiser, said fellow Democrats need to learn from the right wing.

headline: Two Mines
text: Over the years, the federal government has done far less than it should  and far less than the law requires  to guarantee the safety of Appalachia’s miners. So it was a welcome break with grim history when the Labor Department asked a federal judge last week to shut down a Kentucky mine owned by the Massey Energy Company. The mine has been cited for about 700 safety violations this year alone.

headline: South Korea Is a Start
text: With protectionist policies gaining dangerous traction everywhere, the global economy needs a strong champion of free trade. After neglecting the issue, President Obama has now committed to winning approval of a free-trade pact with South Korea that was signed by the Bush administration in 2007 but never voted on in Congress because of staunch Democratic opposition.

text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Reports this week will include wholesale trade inventories for September (Tuesday); trade deficit for September, import prices for October and weekly jobless claims (Wednesday); and Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for November (Friday).

headline: Portions and the Power of Suggestion
text: How small is a “small” portion? No food chain quite agrees. A small soda at Long John Silver’s, for example, is 20 ounces of liquid; a small at Pizza hut is 16. But these labels matter. The label assigned to a portion affects its apparent size, according to a study soon to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research.

headline: In Grief and Defiance, Baghdad’s Christians Return to Scene of Attack
text: BAGHDAD  To get to Mass at Our Lady of Salvation Church on Sunday, worshipers had to pass through a blockade of police trucks, past armed sentries on the rooftop, and through a security checkpoint where they were frisked for weapons and explosives. Some came in mourning black, many in tears, most in a spirit of quiet defiance.

headline: Charles Reynolds, Magicians’ Magician, Dies at 78
text: Charles Reynolds, who described his business as providing “chaste, charming, weird, wonderful and supernatural illusions”  and who proved it by coming up with two entirely different ways to make an elephant disappear  died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Artie Wilson, Shortstop Who Was Mentor to Mays, Dies at 90
text: Artie Wilson, a pesky, slap-hitting shortstop in the Negro leagues who created a signing feud between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians after he hit .402 for the Birmingham Black Barons in 1948, a circumstance that may have cost him a major league career, died Oct. 31 in Portland, Ore. He was 90.

headline: Putting a Number on Free Agents
text: Even before Buster Posey and Brian Wilson embraced on the mound at the end of the World Series last week, the free-agent season was upon us. More than 200 players are now free agents, free to negotiate and sign with teams of their choosing, most often the highest bidder. It may look chaotic from the outside, with one player signing for $8 million over two years and another for $80 million over five years, but spending has followed a fairly consistent pattern.

headline: Mental Health Visits Rise as Parent Deploys
text: Young children in military families are about 10 percent more likely to see a doctor for a mental difficulty when a parent is deployed than when the parent is home, researchers are reporting Monday in the most comprehensive study to date of such families’ use of health insurance during wartime.

headline: Why Did You Burn Yourself?
text: HERAT, Afghanistan — “Why did you burn yourself?” asks the doctor. “If I threw myself from a building, I’d break an arm or a leg, but I wanted to die,” Halima answers. “That’s why I set myself on fire. I thought I would die instantly.”

headline: An Exhibition Opens Under a Paris Museum
text: The Palais de Tokyo, which has hosted its share of underground art, is headed underground in an entirely different way. The museum has inaugurated a new 97,000-square-foot basement space that links it to the adjacent Musée d’Art Moderne. Initially created in 1937 for the the World Expo, the space had been sealed up for years. It is now to be reconverted into a contemporary art space by 2012 — but in the meantime, the derelict environment is serving as an inspiration to one artist.

text: China’s national oil companies have been on a spending spree and the deal-making looks set to continue unabated for some time, The Financial Time reported.

headline: Countering China, Obama Backs India for U.N. Council

headline: For Jets, Another One for the Road
text: Maybe this latest Jets getaway win against the 2-6 Lions won’t satisfy many observers. Jets fans would probably prefer to win games with the degree of certainty similar to the victories rung up by the old Soviet Red Army hockey team in the 1970s and 80s. Or even with the aplomb shown by the Giants against Seattle on Sunday.

headline: Doughty Hanson Snaps Up Vue Entertainment

text: THE BIG NEWS LAST WEEK It wasn’t the U.S. midterm elections. Or the researchers in Britain who may have cured the common cold. Nope. It was the long awaited return of … the McRib sandwich. The lesson from McDonald’s — will we never learn? — is to give your customers what they want!

headline: Ashland to Sell a Unit to TPG for $930 Million

headline: Commerzbank Posts Profit, but Less of It
text: Commerzbank, the second-largest bank in Germany, on Monday reported a quarterly net profit of 113 million euros, less than a third the previous quarter’s, citing losses in central and eastern Europe and a “low level of securities activities.”

headline: Chrysler Narrows Its Loss and Raises Its Forecast
text: DETROIT  Chrysler, the smallest of the Detroit automakers, said on Monday that it had reduced its losses to $84 million in the third quarter and raised its financial forecast for the year even though it is still in the early stages of revamping its vehicle lineup.

headline: Harrah’s Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
text: Harrah’s Entertainment, the world’s biggest casino operator, has set the expected price range for its planned initial public stock offering and announced that it would be changing its name to the Caesars Entertainment Corporation.

text: In the 10 years they have been together, Charissa Benjamin and her Serbian husband have always flown from their home in Washington to spend the winter holidays in the warmth of her native Antigua.

headline: Photos Show Stanford After Brutal Beating in Jail
text: Photographs of the bloodied former billionaire R. Allen Stanford, who was beaten unconscious last year in the Texas jail cell he shared with 14 other men, were published by The Daily Mail on Monday.

headline: Accounting Battle Distracts From Barcelona’s Success
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Johan Cruyff, the Dutchman who both played for and coached F.C. Barcelona, once noted that in soccer “it doesn’t matter how many goals they score, as long as you score one more.”

headline: A Quant in Love: Boaz Weinstein and Tali Farhadian
text: Boaz Ronald Weinstein and Tali Farimah Farhadian were married on Saturday evening at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi James E. Ponet performed the ceremony, with Cantor Angela Warnick Buchdahl taking part, The New York Times reports.

headline: Why Ndamukong Suh Was Chosen to Kick an  Extra Point
text: The rookie defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh missed what turned out to be a crucial extra-point attempt against the Jets on Sunday. But there’s no mystery as to why he was chosen for the duty after the Lions’ Jason Hanson was injured. Suh is good at it.

headline: Bank of America May Pay Bonuses in Shares
text: Bank of America is running out of time to fulfill a promise to raise more capital by year-end and may be forced to make up the shortfall by paying some bonuses in stock rather than cash, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Blame Is King for a Day
text: Sid Gustafson, D.V.M., is a novelist and equine veterinarian specializing in thoroughbred sports medicine and equine behavior. He currently practices regulatory veterinary medicine, representing the safety and welfare of thoroughbred racehorses.

headline: Eli Lilly to Buy Avid for Up to $800 Million

headline: Harry Potter and the Inexplicable ‘Simpsons’ Meta-reference
text: Though it can be difficult to get excited for Halloween-themed television programs a week after the holiday, the producers of “The Simpsons” did their best to get over that roadblock by resorting to some good old-fashioned star power. For a segment called “Tweenlight” that at least began as a parody of the “Twilight” books and movies, the show recruited as the voice of its hunky young vampire none other than the white-hot British heartthrob at the center of a money-minting fantasy film franchise: Daniel Radcliffe, the “Harry Potter” star. (Evidently, no one from the “Lord of the Rings” was available.)

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: Gatherings of insurance executives and public health doctors this week will be looking at possible changes to the health care overhaul from dramatically different perspectives.

headline: Obama Nudges India To Lead
text: President Obama gave a fine speech this morning to the Indian parliament — and to China and Pakistan, which clearly were intended audiences as well. That emphasis on how democracy isn’t an impediment for a developing country seeking economic growth was all about China. Likewise the stress on the links between two great democracies amounted to a studied contrast with Sino-U.S. relations, especially in the aftermath of the Liu Xiaobo Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: I.S.S. Backs Blackstone Bid for Dynegy

headline: WWFD? WSWC?

headline: Portrait of a Demanding Boss
text: When Andrew M. Cuomo takes over as governor on Jan. 1, he will bring a management style that is demanding and focused, insistent on results and disinclined to entertain dissent. In interviews with more than 50 former aides and colleagues, The Times found a picture of his leadership emerging: He sets his sights on a few priorities, frequently to underscore his political goals, plots several steps ahead and is fixated on avoiding mistakes.

text: The Chinese Government and investors are pouring money for the first time into the animation and film industry, causing a radical transformation in China's entertainment landscape.

headline: Superstar! The Molly Shannon Story
text: There are those performers whose outgoing characters are the polar opposites of their shy, retreating selves, and then there is Molly Shannon. In her six seasons at “Saturday Night Live,” Ms. Shannon embodied tireless, talkative creations like Sally O’Malley, the 50-year-old dancer; Jeannie Darcy, the hopeless stand-up comedian; and, of course, Mary Katherine Gallagher, the Catholic schoolgirl with dreams of superstardom. Many of those same qualities are on display in Ms. Shannon’s performance in the Broadway musical “Promises, Promises,” in which she plays Marge MacDougall (a role she took over from the Tony winner Katie Finneran), a barfly who lands in the lap of Chuck Baxter (played by Sean Hayes) on the worst possible night. And they are all characters with which she shares a thing or two, if a recent telephone interview with the enthusiastic, impassioned, occasionally out-of-breath Ms. Shannon is anything to go by.

headline: Giants Are Besting Jets With Big Margins
text: Unlike the Jets, who have been scratching out victories, the Giants have been dominating.

headline: Rally Stalls on Worry About Europe, but Gold Soars to $1,400 an Ounce
text: Stocks were mixed on Monday, while gold soared to a new nominal high and the dollar edged up as concerns resurfaced over financial struggles in Europe.

headline: A Loss Happens but Doesn’t Diminish Zenyatta
text: In a “bucket list” moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since — when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: I’m creative. You’re quirky. He’s bonkers.
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared emotive conjugations – irregular verbs with which we judge others more harshly than ourselves.

headline: Bank Chiefs Say Growth in Economies Is Still Uneven
text: BASEL, Switzerland  Central bank chiefs warned Monday that economic growth remained uneven, especially in industrial countries, as new data reinforced fears of a slowdown in Germany, Europe’s biggest economy.

headline: Oil Spill Panel Opens Hearings
text: The presidential commission investigating the causes of BP’s oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has opened two days of hearings and is presenting its preliminary findings. A live feed is here. So far the presentation has been chock full of graphics and digital animations about the structure of the Macondo oil well, as John M. Broder reports.

headline: It Sleeted!
text: Let it be known that at 9:19 Monday morning, as bitter gusts blew in from the northwest and temperatures hovered in the low 40s, the light rain spattering the south side of West 42nd Street between Broadway and Avenue of the Americas was briefly mixed with sleet.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: 2 Blasts Near Shiite Holy Sites in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Two car bombs aimed at Iranian pilgrims exploded near two of the holiest shrines for Shiite Muslims in Iraq on Monday, as Iraqi leaders met in an inconclusive effort to resolve their country’s long political deadlock.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Michael Alvarez joined the Telemundo Communications Group in a new post, vice president for New York advertising sales, handling duties that include serving as a sales lead for the Telemundo network sales New York office and managing a team of account managers for the New York region. He had been senior vice president for branded content and sponsorships at the New York office of Intersport. Telemundo is part of the NBC Universal unit of General Electric.

headline: Are Credit Card Lines Growing? No.
text: 12:04 p.m. | Updated

headline: Are Credit Card Lines Growing? No.
text: 12:04 p.m. | Updated

headline: What’s Gained, and Lost, In an Era of Virtual College Searches and Applications
text: How did technology become both my new BFF and my arch-enemy? I find myself lusting for any iGadget that I can afford, wouldn’t think of going on vacation without my Kindle, and tell students how lucky they are to be able to Google their college searches. Life is good and clean and quick and secure when it’s online.

headline: On Our Radar: Texas Battles Climate Regulation
text: Texas officials step up their efforts to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its authority to regulate the state’s carbon dioxide emissions, the highest in the nation. The attorney general, Greg Abbott, has filed seven lawsuits against the agency in the last nine months related to climate rules and other environmental controls. [The Los Angeles Times]

headline: Mr. Gibbs Sides With the Press in India
text: The White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, is known for his angry tirades directed at reporters.

headline: Video of Russian Journalist’s Beating
text: MOSCOW  A graphic video said to show a reporter being beaten nearly to death on a street here appeared on a Russian news Web site on Monday, illustrating the severity of an attack that drew attention from domestic and foreign groups defending journalists’ rights.

headline: Stojakovic Odd Man Out in New Orleans
text: Forward Peja Stojakovic used to be one of the most feared shooters in the N.B.A. His smooth delivery, which rarely broke down under game pressure, was a thing of beauty.

headline: The Other Texas Republican on Book Tour
text: Former President George W. Bush is not the only Texas Republican on book tour.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –A page one story by Landon Thomas Jr. on Monday looks at Irish debt, and what it portends for Europe. John Bruton, former prime minister of that embattled nation, assures us via Bloomberg that a default is unthinkable — short-sellers, beware. The ever astute Morgan Kelly, however, warns that while bad loans to developers have caused great grief so far, greater grief awaits the Irish when their long recession finally causes a wave of mortgage defaults. And finally, looking back to 2006, what do you want to bet that Malcolm Gladwell wants to revise this analysis. Toward the end of the Irish expansion, growth was built on cheap debt, a real estate bubble and a smattering of fraud.

headline: My Friend FRED
text: Some readers have asked about the graphs that show up in some posts; many of them come from FRED, the terrific data site of the St. Louis Fed. FRED lets you both create and customize charts of US data, and lets you create permalinks to the charts too — a significant convenience in my case, because for technical reasons creating a non-FRED chart requires me to move back and forth between the Times and Princeton VPNs.

headline: Kill Americans, Says Yemeni-American Cleric
text: Updated | 1:57 p.m. In a new video message posted on a jihadist Web forum on Monday, Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born cleric based in Yemen whose most inflammatory sermons were withdrawn from YouTube last week, said that the killing of Americans by Muslims requires no special sanction.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Vigilante Partners
text: Fans of the short-lived ABC drama “Eli Stone” were surely happy to see its star, Jonny Lee Miller, turn up on “Dexter” on Sunday night. I know I was. Mr. Miller aces just-shy-of-sleazy charm, though here he is a full-on sleaze and psychopath: a motivational speaker named Jordan Chase who seems to appeal to sexually disenfranchised average Joes. It’s a guy not unlike the one Tom Cruise played in “Magnolia,” if that character had led a band of deranged torturers, which Chase seems to be doing.

headline: Monday Reading: When to Pay Off Your Mortgage
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Red Bull Wins Formula One Constructors’ Championship
text: Red Bull Racing clinched its first ever Formula One constructors’ championship at the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday, but the landmark moment was overshadowed by the team’s decision not to institute team orders to give its driver Mark Webber a better shot at the drivers’ title.

headline: Fed Action Gets an Unexpected Endorsement From India
text: NEW DELHI  When the United States Federal Reserve announced last week that it would buy $600 billion in Treasury bonds to help bolster the economy, it quickly came under attack from Germany, Brazil and China, which said America was trying to devalue the dollar to the detriment of other nations’ exports.

headline: Monday: The $29,000 Client
text: This week, as I explained on Friday, I’m writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

headline: Health Commissioner Blazes the Trail
text: Practicing what he preaches, Dr. Thomas A. Farley, New York City’s health commissioner, finished Sunday’s marathon in 3 hours 18 minutes 28 seconds — very respectable for a 54-year-old man, though a full three minutes slower than his own prediction.

headline: Toyota Turns to Consumers for ‘Ideas’
text: From our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog:

headline: Numberplay: Beating Impossible Odds
text: One of the hallmarks of great puzzles is that when you encounter them for the first time, you get the feeling that they are impossible. Like Alex, our hustled victim, and the way he felt about the pizza puzzle a few weeks ago, you think: “That just can’t be. There must be some mistake.” In the very best puzzles, some residue of this feeling remains even after you know the answer. Today’s puzzle is of this type. It concerns a historical scenario very similar to that of the prisoners and light bulb puzzle a couple of months ago.

headline: Now Drinking | Beyond Tequila in Mexico City
text: Ever since the diminutive mezcalería La Bótica opened in Mexico City’s fashionable Condesa neighborhood on Cinco de Mayo 2005, mezcal has steadily risen from hipster novelty to ubiquity in restaurants, neighborhood pubs and classic cantinas alike. Savvy chilangos have reappraised the country’s rich alco-history, looking beyond tequila — and lately even mezcal — for new sources of national pride and connoisseurship.

headline: Judge Upholds Award Against Goldman
text: A federal judge on Monday denied a request by the investment firm Goldman Sachs to throw out a record-setting arbitration award that was levied this year.

headline: Death Penalty for a Killer of 3 in Connecticut
text: NEW HAVEN  A jury voted on Monday to impose the death penalty on a habitual criminal who took part in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead, a crime of such inexplicable cruelty and randomness  the family was apparently chosen after being spotted in a shopping center parking lot  that it upended a debate about capital punishment.

headline: More FREDding
text: Just a quick illustration of why I — along with the Fed and everyone else who’s serious about these things — use core inflation rather than headline inflation to measure trends. Here’s core versus headline CPI growth for the past decade:

headline: Label Says That’s Michael Jackson on New Michael Jackson Song
text: You put Michael Jackson‘s name on a record, you’d think it’s a given that Jackson is somehow involved in the material it contains. But the Epic Records division of Sony Music now finds itself in the unusual position of having to reaffirm that the King of Pop really did provide the vocals for a new release being put out under Jackson’s name – and to make clear that Prince is not connected to the album.

headline: Volcano Is No Deterrent to Presidential Visit
text: NEW DELHI – Neither rain nor sleet nor snow – or, more precisely, volcanic ash – will keep President Obama from his Indonesian homecoming this time, the White House says.

headline: Report Reveals Forces Destroying Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
text: A powerful and innovative international journalistic effort has revealed the web of interests — from boat captains to European government agencies to fish auctions — behind the devastation of Atlantic bluefin tuna.

headline: The Saddest Exacta I Ever Cashed
text: Jeff Deitz M.D. practices in New York and Connecticut. Two decades before he psychoanalyzed his first patient, his father taught him to read the form at Pimlico.

headline: A Series of Small Booms

headline: Investigator Finds No Evidence That BP Took Shortcuts to Save Money
text: WASHINGTON  The lead investigator for the presidential panel delving into the BP oil spill said on Monday that he had found no evidence that anyone involved in drilling the doomed well had taken safety shortcuts to save money.

headline: Los Angeles Philharmonic to Broadcast Live in Movie Theaters
text: First operas, then ballets and now, increasingly, orchestras. The Los Angeles Philharmonic has joined the movement to transmit performances live to movie theaters. The orchestra announced Monday that it would beam three performances conducted by Gustavo Dudamel later this season, reaching 450 theaters in the United States and Canada.

headline: With Appeals, an Execution, if It Happens, May Be Many Years Away
text: NEW HAVEN  The death sentence voted by jurors on Monday for Steven J. Hayes, the man convicted of the Cheshire, Conn., killings, does not mean he is likely to be executed any time soon. In fact, it has merely started a new chapter that may last far longer than the response, investigation, hearing and trial touched off by the events of July 2007.

headline: New York University Ad
text: Promotion for the master's program in hospitality industry studies at New York University's Tisch center.

headline: Bloomberg Called Obama ‘Arrogant,’ Murdoch Says
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York apparently made some not-so-nice remarks about President Obama to a fellow billionaire, Rupert Murdoch, who passed it along to an Australian newspaper.

headline: Cuomo’s Signals on Silver’s Leadership Unclear
text: CAROLINA, P.R.  Andrew M. Cuomo will not be sworn in as governor of New York for seven weeks, but his jockeying with the Legislature has already begun.

headline: Ads for N.Y.U. Have Their Words in the Clouds
text: Every cloud, so they say, has a silver lining. These days, clouds are also lined with words, and a campaign from New York University seeks to take advantage of that.

headline: They Will Not Be Missed
text: In addition to depriving the Democratic Party its House majority, this political season has cost us the services of three of the country’s most prominent “centrists” — Evan Bayh, the Indiana Democrat who grew so tired of the Senate that he declined to run for re-election; Charlie Crist, the Florida governor and Senate hopeful who left the G.O.P. to run, and lose, as an independent against Marco Rubio; and Arlen Specter, who was defeated in Pennsylvania’s Democratic primary after he switched parties to avoid a primary challenge. I’ve written critically about each of these figures before (Specter here, Crist here and here, Bayh here), but I think it’s worth pausing a moment, amid all the midterm analysis, to emphasize what they represented and why they won’t be missed.

headline: Flooding Raises New Cholera Fears in Haiti
text: ST. DENIS, Haiti  Three medical workers arrived at a clinic near here over the weekend on a mission to deliver supplies and spread the word about preventing a deadly cholera outbreak from getting worse after the torrential rains brought by Hurricane Tomas.

headline: Banned Hits Return, Along With Confusion
text: When the N.F.L. announced a crackdown on hits to the head and neck a month ago, Bill Polian, the president of the Indianapolis Colts and a member of the competition committee, said he was a little surprised by the uproar over the well-publicized handful of blows that spurred it. He almost sounded optimistic about the state of tackling.

headline: First Lady’s Dance Moves Woo Indian Crowds
text: NEW DELHI  While President Obama is wooing India with promises of increased trade and United Nations clout, his wife’s charm offensive has included serial hugs and a talent for Indian dance.

headline: Bloomberg Says Daughter Is Recovering After Fall
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said his younger daughter, Georgina, was faring reasonably well Monday after being injured on Friday when she fell off the horse she was riding during an equestrian tournament in Syracuse.

headline: Too Many Investors Are Actually Collectors
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Friendship Parallels a Strategic Partnership
text: NEW DELHI  Three decades and two oceans stand between President Obama and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India. But on a dais here after a joint news conference on Monday, the two men, neither known for their social ebullience, were inseparable: the youthful, lanky American president’s arm firmly fixed on the older man’s shoulder, Mr. Singh grinning widely with his arm wrapped tightly around Mr. Obama’s waist.

headline: TimesCast | November 8, 2010
text: An unexpected announcement from President Obama; former President Bush returns to the spotlight and the future of mining under the sea.

headline: For One Real Estate Investor, Vinyl Siding Never Lost Its Shine
text: Like many creative professionals who live in Williamsburg, Lewis Canfield possesses a Renaissance man’s variety of passions and hobbies. He worked in the movie industry, profited from the Internet boom, dabbled in art, developed an interest in women’s perfume scents and now buys, sells and renovates Brooklyn real estate.

headline: A Small-Business Barometer in Astoria
text: Marino & Sons Fish Market opened on 30th Avenue in Astoria, Queens, in 1932, fulfilling the dreams of a scrawny teenager from Sicily who had been peddling fish from woven baskets along the streets of Manhattan.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Post: Say what? Seven of the 14 “C”-rated New York City restaurants sampled by reporters were hiding their dirty-restaurant grades. They face fines up to $1,000 – Glenn Collins

headline: Will Gebrselassie Reconsider? Countrymen Hope So
text: The marathon world-record holder Haile Gebrselassie announced his spur-of-the-moment decision to retire from the sport after he dropped out of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, but his fellow Ethiopian athletes and fans, and others close to him, believe he may reconsider the decision.

headline: Catching Up With Jane Birkin
text: Jane Birkin may be best known for her namesake Hermès bag and her scandalous duet with Serge Gainsbourg on ‘Je T’aime … Moi Non Plus,” but these are only specks of sequins in her glittery 45-year career. At 64 years young, Birkin has recorded more than 20 albums, acted in more than 65 films, worked as a designer, a model and a muse, and actively supported a slew of humanitarian causes. Along the way she even picked up an Order of the British Empire title.

headline: With Stunning Rally, Zenyatta Wins Over Critics
text: Horse racing let us down a lot last weekend. We saw a disgraceful and indefensible jockey fight in the winner’s circle; a perplexing series of events that led to Life At Ten jogging around the track at Churchill Downs under the lights; a fatal injury to Rough Sailing in the Breeders’ Cup Juvenile Turf.

headline: Despite Protests, Waste Arrives in Germany
text: BERLIN  After three days of protests and occasional violent clashes with the police, a train hauling 123 tons of nuclear waste finally arrived Monday in northern Germany. The nuclear waste, which had been reprocessed in France, was transferred to trucks that were expected to encounter a final gantlet of protesters en route to a storage facility near the former Gorleben salt mines.

headline: In the U.S., Sticker Shock in Reverse
text: When I dropped off a rental car recently in New York City after visiting my daughter at her college’s parents weekend, I suffered a severe case of sticker shock. I had been cursing myself for forgetting to refuel the midsize car in New Jersey before re-entering New York. Now I would be stuck paying New York gas prices.

headline: Joan Nathan’s Jewish-French Thanksgiving
text: The best cookbooks do more than provide new recipes — they tell a story of food and culture that can teach and inspire home chefs.

headline: 7 People Killed Since Saturday Night
text: Updated, Tuesday, Nov. 9, 11:05 a.m. |The mini-spike in murders that has pushed the homicide rate up 15 percent so far this year continued with three more killings this morning, following four on Saturday night and Sunday. Through Sunday, there were 459 murders this year, compared with 399 at this time last year, the police said this morning. Here are the seven new killings:

headline: College Sticker Prices Rising, but So Is Financial Aid
text: The College Board recently released its latest report on college costs, and it is chock-full of nutritious charts and graphs. One takeaway is that while sticker prices for college tuition may be rising,  for the typical student out-of-pocket higher education costs have actually fallen in recent years, thanks to more generous financial aid.

headline: Obama Presses to Complete Free-Trade Deal With South Korea
text: WASHINGTON  The White House is intensifying negotiations with South Korea on revising a free-trade agreement negotiated by the Bush administration, even though the accord still faces opposition from Democratic politicians, labor unions and the Ford Motor Company.

headline: Stargazing Under a Brighter, Greener Light
text: Amateur astronomers in this city don’t have it easy. The brightest lights in New York’s nighttime burn from Broadway marquees and skyscraper windows, obscuring Orion, Gemini and the Dippers from their rightful place in our sky.

headline: Challenge Heard on Move to Kill Qaeda-Linked Cleric
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge heard a legal challenge on Monday to the Obama administration’s decision to authorize the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, even as Mr. Awlaki, the American-born cleric tied to Al Qaeda and now hiding in Yemen, called for new attacks on the United States in a video posted to the Web.

headline: Carrots: Digging Deeper for Fall Flavor
text: The interior of my refrigerator is filled with an orange glow. For one thing, it’s just that time of year (stay tuned for pumpkin recipes). For another, I bought several pounds of carrots recently for a huge Moroccan salad that I’d planned to add to an already ambitious menu for a book party. But by the time I finished making frittatas, farro salad with beets and beet greens, fixings for black bean tostadas, and tahini and chard stalk dip for 100 people, there simply wasn’t time to make that beautiful salad. I left several pounds of carrots in my refrigerator.

headline: U.S. Sets New Rules for Packages on Cargo Planes
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday moved to tighten air cargo security, banning large toner and ink cartridges from passenger flights and demanding new inspections on “high risk” shipments headed to the United States on all-cargo flights.

headline: The Morning Line: A List of Believers
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Izinyoka
text: A South African term for those who steal electricity – based on the isiZulu word for snakes.

headline: South Korea Drops Its Call for Apology From North
text: SEOUL, South Korea  In a shift that could pave the way for new talks on the dismantling of North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, the government in the South has quietly abandoned its demand that the North apologize for the sinking of a South Korean naval vessel, no longer making that a condition for the nuclear talks or other future exchanges.

headline: Brian Eno: Seven Sessions on a Milk Sea
text: The first video installment of a new improvised composition featuring Brian Eno with Jon Hopkins and Leo Abrahams.

headline: Lehman Lawyers Seek a Fresh $90 Million

headline: Vinyl Siding: Love It or Hate It?
text: Some people think it’s a scourge on neighborhoods. Bloggers devote Web sites to mocking its worst examples. While vinyl siding may seem like a material that simply protects homes from the elements, it draws every element of opinion about its appearance and presence in neighborhoods.

headline: A Prime Retail Spot, but No Takers
text: Queens has the highest retail vacancy rate in New York City — at 13.7 percent, it is nearly double the rate that Manhattan had in the second quarter of this year. But if there’s one spot where empty storefronts are a rare commodity, it is on Roosevelt Avenue, between roughly 72nd Street and 84th Street, a bustling commercial district on the edge of Jackson Heights.

headline: Principles for Managing Climate ‘Management’
text: The final report has been issued from the Asilomar Conference on Climate Engineering Technologies that was held last spring in Pacific Grove, Calif.

headline: Vintage Brand and Corporate Names to Be Auctioned
text: A cache of venerable brand and corporate names, not used for years — and, in some instances, decades — is to be auctioned next month in New York.

headline: The Morning Skate: Head Check Rule Comes Under Fire
text: It’s just like the N.H.L. to pat itself on the back and trumpet its great accomplishments, then turn around and stab itself in the back, or at least shoot itself in the foot. It’s a pathology the league has exhibited repeatedly when it comes to changes designed to improve the game.

headline: An Early Demise for ‘A Life in the Theater’
text: Broadway has its first commercial failure of the 2010-11 season: David Mamet’s play “A Life in the Theater,” which stars stage and television star Patrick Stewart and the former “Grey’s Anatomy” actor T.R. Knight, will close on Nov. 28, five weeks ahead of the originally scheduled end of the run.

headline: First Look | George Esquivel for Fratelli Rosetti
text: Fratelli Rosetti’s latest collaboration, with George Esquivel, the recent Council of Fashion Designers of America inductee, has us beaming with patriotism. The “America” satchel — a flexible leather bucket bag in natural leather, sea blue, white and black — promises to be as covetable as the designer’s signature handmade shoes. “It’s so minimal in design – in terms of shape and structure,” Esquivel says. “But the true beauty of the bag is revealed when it is put to work.” Indeed, the shoulder strap can be removed transforming the tote into a proper purse; a bag inside the bag can be carried on its own as an evening clutch. The America is available in mid-November, but the collaboration will continue through the fall 2011 season with more carry-alls to come. Now that’s our idea of the American dream.“America” satchel, $1,200. Available at Fratelli Rossetti flagship locations, call (212) 888-5107.

headline: Israel Plans 1,000 Housing Units in East Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM  Israel has published plans for some 1,000 new housing units in a hotly contested area of Jerusalem, advancing the approval process at a delicate time when the United States is pressing Israel to renew a freeze in settlement construction and get stalled peace negotiations with the Palestinians back on track.

headline: Myanmar Refugees Spilling into Thailand
text: BANGKOK  Clashes between an ethnic rebel group in Myanmar and government soldiers have pushed a flood of at least 10,000 refugees across a river into Thailand, one day after Myanmar held its first election in 20 years.

headline: An Ode to Vinyl Siding in Williamsburg
text: A real estate buyer and seller points out some examples of vinyl-sided homes in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Salon Names New Editor

text: Lars Kroijer got rich charging investors fat fees as a manager of his hedge fund, Holte Capital.

headline: Sanofi Asks Genzyme to Keep Path to Deal Open
text: Sanofi-Aventis on Monday sent a letter to Genzyme’s chief executive, asking that the biotech giant not seek to block its unsolicited takeover bid by altering its board or using anti-takeover laws in its home state, Massachusetts.

headline: A Game of Inches
text: Zenyatta was beaten for the first time in her career. For many of us watching the Breeders’ Cup Classic at Churchill Downs, it was a rollercoaster of emotions throughout and there was a huge deflated feeling afterward.

headline: Here He Comes: the Improvisational Music of Brian Eno
text: Unless you are Stephen Hawking, there is a good chance that Brian Eno is smarter than you. But that’s O.K., because rather than using his intellect for nefarious purposes or taunting you with his superior exam grades, Mr. Eno, the musician, producer and multi-hyphenate, channels his powers into artistic pursuits. To promote his new album, “Small Craft on a Milk Sea,” he has started a series of videos, titled “Seven Sessions on a Milk Sea,” documenting improvised performances at his London studio with the musicians Jon Hopkins and Leo Abrahams. An entry, titled “Signal Success,” can be seen above, and subsequent videos will be posted at Mr. Eno’s official Web site, brian-eno.net/seven-sessions. Now leave him be so he can play six simultaneous chess games and prove the existence of cold fusion.

headline: Deal Gives Amazon a Diaper Strategy

headline: A Temporary Place for the Food Trucks of Tavern on the Green
