headline: Going Into Detail: Developing Proofreading Skills
text: Overview | How can we learn to pay closer attention to detail in writing? How can we put knowledge about grammar and mechanics into practice? In this lesson, students consider errors in signage and other textual displays and create lists of common errors to check as they proofread. They then practice proofreading and develop strategies, taking into consideration the possible consequences of making language mistakes.

headline: A Treasure Trove of Japanese Art for St. Louis Museum
text: A collection of nearly 1,400 Japanese prints and related works has been donated to the Saint Louis Art Museum, the museum is to announce on Tuesday. Charles and Rosalyn Lowenhaupt have donated their entire collection of works on paper, amassed over the past two decades. They also gave all of their books, exhibition catalogs and research materials to the museum’s Richardson Memorial Library.

headline: Very Old Bones, Back Underground
text: Over the past 17 years, thousands of pieces of human remains dating back to the 18th century have been unearthed in the course of construction projects in and around City Hall.

headline: Tuition Reimbursements for Jobless Graduates?
text: In this weak economy, many recent, and soon-to-be, graduates of colleges and graduate schools are having a difficult time finding jobs, leading at least one to ask whether it’s possible to get back money spent on tuition.

headline: Republican Concedes in Race for Connecticut Governor
text: The Connecticut governor’s race is finally over.

headline: Slumber Spas
text: There’s no rest for the weary these days, at least if the number of spas offering ‘‘guided sleep’’ treatments is any indication. Yelo Spa in New York City is adding targeted power naps to its menu for ailments like jet lag, stress and hangovers.

headline: Oil Traveled Up the Gulf Food Chain, Scientists Say
text: While officials in Washington pick apart the sequence of events that led to the release of nearly five million barrels of oil in the Deepwater Horizon disaster, scientists are still trying to figure out where all of that oil went.

headline: GrubHub Gets a Cash Delivery
text: 1:24 p.m. | Updated  Correcting number of restaurants in partnership with GrubHub.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Will Live On in a Second Season
text: Good news for undead zombies who consume the flesh of the living and the television viewers who love them: AMC said on Monday that it has officially ordered a second season of “The Walking Dead,” its original series adapted from the comic books written by Robert Kirkman about human survivors in a world overrun by the ambulatory deceased. (Catchy phrase, no?) Though AMC ordered just six episodes of “The Walking Dead” for its first season, it seemed a virtual certainty that the show would rise again when its debut episode, broadcast on Halloween, broke a ratings record for that cable channel by drawing 5.3 million viewers, the largest audience it had recorded for an original series. AMC, which is also the home of the serial dramas “Mad Men,” “Breaking Bad” and “Rubicon,” said the second episode of “The Walking Dead” was watched by more than 4.7 million people.

headline: Afghan Government Drops Corruption Charges Against Aide
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government has dropped all charges in the controversial corruption case against an aide to President Hamid Karzai, said the official whose office oversaw the case.

headline: The Caucus: 'Decision Points'
text: Former President George W. Bush is expected to begin a book tour for his new memoir, "Decision Points," with an appearance on NBC on Monday night.

headline: In Surprise Move, Coda’s Chief Executive Resigns
text: In a move that surprised many observers of the electric-car industry, Coda Automotive announced Friday that its chief executive, Kevin Czinger, had resigned. The move comes shortly before the public debut of Coda’s electric sedan. According to Coda, Mr. Czinger will be replaced by its board co-chairman, Steven Heller, on an interim basis, pending a search for a chief executive with “deep manufacturing, marketing and sales strengths.”

headline: The Newest, Latest Parenting Trend
text: Two recent articles are cause for a lot of chatter on parenting Web sites, highlighting, as they do, new trends that are not actually new and may not actually be trends.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Thailand, India and Germany.

headline: Glimpsing a Scientific Future as Fields Heat Up
text: About 25 years ago, before I came to The Times, I had a job interview at U.S. News & World Report. I really wanted the reporter position, and it seemed to me that things were going well. Then I was asked, “What will be the important medical news next year?”

headline: What We’re Reading: For God or Government
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: For Edge on Alzheimer’s, Testing Early Treatments
text: Much of the research on Alzheimer’s next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

headline: Genes as Mirrors of Life Experiences
text: For decades, researchers have ransacked the genetic pedigrees of people with mental illness, looking for common variations that combine to cause devastating conditions like schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The search has stalled badly; while these disorders may involve genetic disruptions, no underlying patterns have surfaced  no single gene or genes that account for more than a tiny fraction of cases.

headline: The Perils of Presidential Dancing
text: As my colleague Heather Timmons reports, video of Michelle Obama dancing with Indian children during a state visit has won hearts in India. “Twice in two days,” The Times of India reported, “the First Lady demonstrated in Mumbai that she could swing to desi beats with the best of them, pulling off matkas and jhatkas [dance moves involving swaying hips] like a seasoned performer.”

headline: British and U.S. Law Firms Merge
text: Partners at two law firms — Squire, Sanders & Dempsey in the United States and the Hammonds of Britain — agreed to merge on Monday, the latest in a series of trans-Atlantic consolidations.

headline: New Lines of Attack in H.I.V. Prevention
text: The hottest news in AIDS in the last year was the partial success in a South African clinical trial of a microbicide  a gel women can put in their vaginas to kill the virus before it can infect them.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 8
text: A view of the day in sports, with Allen Iverson arriving in Turkey and two women making hockey history.

headline: Mendes Crosses Finish Line of 5-Borough Trek
text: Jon Mendes of Manhattan, who walked the New York City Marathon on Sunday four days after his 90th birthday, crossed the finish line of the 26.2-mile course after nine-plus hours.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Thailand, India and Germany.

headline: House Panel Asks F.D.A. About Inspections in Puerto Rico
text: In a sign of what may be the new kind of post-election scrutiny of the Food and Drug Administration, leading members of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform sent a letter Monday to the agency asking whether understaffing at a district office led to oversight problems of drug manufacturing.

headline: Going Public With Open-Book Management
text: The last time we counted, we found that more than a million people have been touched by open-book management through the SRC family. While that’s an impressive number, it’s far short of, say, the 300 million people living in the United States. One way that we could bump up the number would be to get organizations in the public sector to try opening their books.

headline: Eurofile | Back to Bucharest
text: Disappointed to find that much of central Paris now serves up the same street-level visual refrain as most American cities — Gap, Zara, Starbucks, Subway — friends visiting from Boston yearned for an urban adventure. Where could they go for a long weekend that hadn’t yet been subjected to the centrifuge of globalization? “Bucharest,” I replied, and they laughed out loud. “Bucharest!? Is there anything to see there? And what about the hotels and the food?”

headline: Voices Raised to Echo Higher Worlds
text: Whatever a listener’s spiritual bent (or lack thereof), surely only a zombie would have been unmoved by the transcendent singing of the Tallis Scholars on Sunday afternoon in the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.

headline: Miracles of Light Mix Audio and Visual
text: As if anticipating the earlier encroachment of darkness brought on by clocks turned back for the season, some of New York’s concert halls have come aglow in a metaphorical sense. Spiritual illumination is the express concern of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center, which continues through next week. And at the Rubin Museum of Art, a new chamber-music series bears a similarly luminous banner: Resonating Light.

headline: Bill Campbell on Coaching RockMelt and Google vs. Apple
text: In Silicon Valley, where even mid-level executives seem to be escorted by public relations handlers, Bill Campbell is a bit of an exception. An elder statesman of the tech industry, he prefers to remain out of the limelight.

headline: Cyclists Condemn Prosecutor’s Decision
text: Last week The Vail Daily News reported that an Eagle County, Colo., prosecutor had declined to press felony charges against Martin Joel Erzinger, a financial manager who allegedly fled the site of a crash with a cyclist in July.

headline: Singer Marked by a Sense of History
text: Even as a teenager leading a punk-rock band Paul Weller looked back. His 1970s band, the Jam, was openly fond of Mod-era British Invasion songwriting from a decade earlier. Since then Mr. Weller has maintained a long, steady career in Britain, where he’s fondly known as the Modfather. His concert on Sunday night at the Best Buy Theater was sold out; many audience members had British accents.

headline: The Obamas in India
text: The first couple — working on both diplomatic and charm campaigns — have been an unexpected success during their trip to India.

headline: She Got Her Gold. More Important, She Earned Her Gold.
text: For Sunday’s Metropolitan section, Carmen Peláez, wrote a Sweat column describing her soul-wrenching decision to run the New York City Marathon in the face of monumental self-doubt. “I may not have a runner’s body, but I have a runner’s heart,” she wrote. Here’s what happened Sunday.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'American Psycho'
text: A. O. Scott looks at Mary Harron's film adaptation of the Bret Easton Ellis novel about a Wall Street serial killer.

headline: Dispatches and Details From a Life in Literature
text: Herzog, the title character of Saul Bellow’s 1964 novel, is famously a writer of letters he never sends, letters to friends, rivals, relatives and strangers; letters that satisfy his craving “to explain, to have it out, to justify, to put in perspective, to clarify, to make amends.” The letters are, by turns, cranky, coruscating, clever and cerebral: the outpourings of a man overflowing with ideas and grievances, and reeling from the complications of his life and the stubborn mystifications of the world around him.

headline: Microsoft Places Big Bets on New Smartphone
text: In 2007, when the Apple iPhone first went on sale, Microsoft‘s operating system dominated the American market and Apple essentially commanded zero percent. Now it’s the other way around, with Apple the top smartphone in the United States and Microsoft’s Windows Mobile operating system stagnating around 3 percent.

headline: Phillips Takes the Fall for a Season in Ruins
text: For weeks, Wade Phillips’s perplexed countenance seemed to mirror the Dallas Cowboys’ season gone awry: nobody could quite figure out how things had gone so wrong for a team that began the season talking about hosting a Super Bowl. Nobody  especially Phillips, it seemed  knew how to stop the Cowboys’ slide from America’s Team to N.F.L. doormat.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Fashion Show'
text: The model and entrepreneur Iman is a host and judge of the design competition.

headline: The Measure of Love in Zenyatta’s Finest Hour
text: Carole-Terese Naser follows thoroughbred racing from Six Horses Sanctuary, an equine retirement facility, in central Maine.

headline: 2011 Musical America Winners Announced
text: Musical America, which publishes the Musical America International Directory of the Performing Arts and maintains the Web site musicalamerica.com, has announced the winners of its 2011 Musical America Awards. Its musician of the year is the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, soon to begin a season-long stint as artist in residence at the New York Philharmonic. The composer of the year is Thomas Adès; the conductor, Rafael Frühbeck dr Burgos; the vocalist, the baritone Simon Keenlyside; and the educator, Vivian Perlis, the founder of Yale University’s Oral History of American Music. The awards are to be presented at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 13.

headline: The Fashion Cop Is on the Beat
text: Were it not for “The Fashion Show: Ultimate Collection,” whose second season begins Tuesday on Bravo, our universal impression of the Somali-American supermodel Iman, an entrepreneur who is fluent in five languages, would surely have remained positive. Iman is 55 and looks 37. She designs handbags, jewelry and other accessories for a line called Iman Global Chic, which translates the looks of her African heritage for a Home Shopping Network audience that might not otherwise be exposed to such adventuresome style. Additionally she does charity work for organizations like Raising Hope for Congo, and she is Mrs. David Bowie.

headline: Late Inspiration Carries Gimelstob to the Finish
text: The brevity of the congratulatory note was satisfaction in itself. Andy Roddick, in Switzerland for a tennis tournament, sent a text to Justin Gimelstob on Sunday night saying simply: “Well done, Sir. Send me wiring instructions.”

headline: Spalding Gray Archives Acquired by University of Texas
text: Describing his travels in Thailand while filming a small role in “The Killing Fields,” Spalding Gray, the actor, author and monologist, compared the experience to – among other things – a stay at “a pleasurable prison.” Though the experience, preserved in his indelible performance piece “Swimming to Cambodia,” found him famously concluding that he “knew what it was that had killed Marilyn Monroe,” the notebooks and journals that formed the basis of that monologue will surely be treated to a better stay at their new permanent residence at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: In a First, Guineans at Home and in N.Y. Vote for President
text: The sun had barely risen Sunday morning as thousands of New Yorkers in four patient lines sipped coffee on a cold and quiet Harlem block. The group, Guinean expatriates about to vote in their country’s first democratic presidential election, clutched their voting cards with anticipation.

headline: A Gambling Town Bets a Museum Can Compete
text: BILOXI, Miss.  Just months before a quirky little museum designed by the architect Frank Gehry was set to open in this Gulf Coast resort town, the waves from Hurricane Katrina lifted a three-story floating casino, slot machines and all, and slammed it into the project.

headline: After Breast Cancer, Women Prefer Silicone Implants
text: Women who receive silicone implants after breast cancer surgery are happier with their reconstructed breasts than women who receive saline implants, a new study shows.

headline: Rare Hits and Heaps of Misses to Pay For
text: Research, in any field of science, is not the risk-free business that might easily be supposed from the confident promises of scientific spokesmen or the daily reports of new advances.

headline: A Direct Hit of Drugs to Treat Brain Cancer
text: It was a desperate measure, for a desperate disease. Fourteen months ago, Dennis Sugrue let doctors thread a fine tube through his blood vessels and up into his head, so they could spray the drug Avastin directly into the part of his brain where a tumor had been cut out. It was an experiment, devised mainly to find out whether the procedure was safe, and to gauge how much Avastin the brain could tolerate. But Mr. Sugrue, then 50, was hoping the experiment would also free him of cancer.

headline: Dark or White? (Not the Turkey)
text: WHEN my family gathers for Thanksgiving, we don’t fool around. We’re cooking for, count ’em, 35 mouths or so, and most of them like to drink wine. So we can’t be concerned with a dainty meal, a fancy bottle, china and crystal. Our mission: Get a ton of good food ready before people start gnawing on the table legs, and give them plenty to drink.

headline: They Both Go Well With Stuffing
text: WHITES

headline: DealBook Debate: Foreclosures
text: Document problems in the foreclosure process have raised questions about the culpability of banks.

headline: The Warner Music Archive
text: The company has launched an ambitious project to sort its nearly 100,000 boxes’ worth of stored music memorabilia.

headline: Of Sleet, Roaches and Wal-Mart
text: The morning began with idle chatter about sleet before quickly moving to the weightiest subject of life and death.

headline: Predicting the Future in Science — or Not
text: What can we expect from science and medical research next year? The possibilities are discussed in a special report in this week’s Science Times.

headline: Pairings: Potted Shrimp
text: Why not give a nod to the mother country on Thanksgiving? The early colonists had no thought of severing all ties and, when it came to food, adapted to the provisions available on American shores while maintaining a taste for pie and tea.

headline: ESPN Breaks Up ‘Sunday Night Baseball’ Team
text: ESPN ended its 20-year association with Jon Miller and Joe Morgan as the voices of “Sunday Night Baseball” on Monday. They declined to renew Morgan’s contract and have asked Miller if he wants to stay on as the radio voice of the Sunday night games. Discussions are continuing.

headline: That ‘Mad Men’ Look? It’s Vintage Janie Bryant
text: Janie Bryant was having trouble focusing. As the costume director of “Mad Men,” she’s been in the spotlight before, but last month, when she was in town to promote her first book and receive a giant award for her work from Fashion Group International, she was really spinning.

headline: Commodity Prices
text: For everyone who thinks that we should view commodity prices as the right measure of inflation: they’re very, very volatile. Here’s the annual rate of change in the IMF commodity index over time:

headline: Scratching Under the Vinyl Era
text: The images have been scattered about in dusty and moldy warehouses, relics of the pre-Internet age when photography was integral to selling music, and the photographers  names like Irving Penn, Annie Leibovitz, Lee Friedlander and Robert Mapplethorpe  went on to become nearly as famous as the subjects they captured and defined.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘American Psycho’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks at the Wall Street satire “American Psycho,”adapted from the Bret Eaton Ellis novel and directed by Mary Harron. The film follows the Wall Street trader and serial killer Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale), from his mundane daily routines to his brutal acts of violence. But Mr. Scott sees the film, in some way, as a comedy of manners. “It’s often very funny,” he says, “though the overall tone is almost as cold and inhuman as the main character himself.”

headline: Jets-Browns Is Next Battleground for Ryan vs. Ryan
text: The Ryan brothers remember only highlights from their infamous fight at Southwestern Oklahoma State. It started in a dormitory and spilled outside, where two friends broke their noses while attempting to restore peace.

headline: The Flash Crash, in Miniature
text: BlackBerrys were buzzing inside Progress Energy in Raleigh, N.C.: in a blink, the 102-year-old utility had been virtually wiped out on Wall Street.

headline: Strides in Materials, but No Invisibility Cloak
text: Blame it on Harry Potter.

headline: Disunion: The Civil War
text: An unfolding history of the major events of the Civil War, starting with the election of Abraham Lincoln.

headline: Olbermann Apologizes to Viewers, But Not to MSNBC
text: 6:15 p.m. | Update In an aggressive statement questioning the legitimacy of his two-day suspension from MSNBC, Keith Olbermann addressed his fans Monday night, saying that they were responsible for his scheduled return to the air on Tuesday, following revelations that he had contributed to the campaign funds of three Democrats in last week’s election.

headline: 2010: An Aligning Election
text: Elections with results as dramatic as this year’s are sometimes referred to as “realigning elections.” The term — although somewhat ambiguous and overused — usually refers to an election in which one party not only gains a significant amount of power, but coalitions also shift, the signature of which is usually that the rising party performs particularly well in certain geographic regions or among certain demographic groups.

headline: More Seats for Freshmen at G.O.P. Tables
text: When there are a whole bunch of new friends coming to town, you want to make them feel welcome. When they are new fellow members of the House of Representatives, you might also take a polite pre-emptive strike.

headline: Steinbrenner on Veterans’ Ballot for Hall of Fame
text: The Hall of Fame announced Monday that George Steinbrenner, the longtime Yankees owner who died in July, was one of 12 candidates who will appear on the ballot of the latest incarnation of the veterans committee, which meets at the winter meetings in December.

headline: A Novel Tactic in Climate Fight Gains Some Traction
text: WASHINGTON  With energy legislation shelved in the United States and little hope for a global climate change agreement this year, some policy experts are proposing a novel approach to curbing global warming: including greenhouse gases under an existing and highly successful international treaty ratified more than 20 years ago.

headline: Hard Steps to Walk a Fine Line in ‘Scottsboro’
text: In the new Broadway musical “The Scottsboro Boys,” a black actor plays the part of Samuel Leibowitz, a white Jewish lawyer from New York who defends nine African-American youths wrongly imprisoned for raping two white women in the Alabama town Scottsboro in 1931.

headline: Mining the Seafloor for Rare-Earth Minerals
text: For decades, entrepreneurs have tried to strike it rich by gathering up ugly potato-size rocks that carpet the global seabed. Known as manganese nodules, the rocks are plentiful in nickel, copper and cobalt, as well as manganese and other elements, but lie miles down in inky darkness. Building giant machines to vacuum them up, despite much study and investment, has never proved to be economic.

headline: Jewish Critic of Israel Chosen to Speak at Frankfurt’s Kristallnacht Commemoration
text: Updated | Tuesday 2:48 p.m. Reports on German news sites indicate that the Kristallnacht memorial in Frankfurt passed off without incident on Tuesday evening. A photograph of the event on the Web site of Süddeutschen Zeitung showed the keynote speaker, Alfred Grosser, and Dieter Graumann, a leader of Germany’s Jewish community, smiling together.

headline: Quantum Computing Reaches for True Power
text: In 1981 the physicist Richard Feynman speculated about the possibility of “tiny computers obeying quantum mechanical laws.” He suggested that such a quantum computer might be the best way to simulate real-world quantum systems, a challenge that today is largely beyond the calculating power of even the fastest supercomputers.

headline: How Cancer Acquired Its Own Biographer
text: In Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee’s lab, a Stanley Kubrick-like space at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center at Columbia University, enormous white freezers with digital temperature readouts keep tissue at 80 below zero. Sterile work stations with transparent hoods and bacteria-scattering blowers emit an unearthly blue light. And there is a bountiful supply of mice that, thanks to the addition of a jellyfish gene, literally glow either red or green in the dark.

headline: Football Remains No. 1
text: Despite the Green Bay Packers’ blowout victory over the Dallas Cowboys, NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” extended its streak as the No. 1 program on television on that night for the ninth consecutive week. Nielsen’s preliminary estimates show the game up slightly, compared with the matchup a week ago between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New Orleans Saints, which drew 18.1 million viewers opposite the World Series. CBS, in second place, got an assist from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which lasted throughout the 7 p.m. hour and helped lift CBS’s “60 Minutes” in the 8 p.m. hour. ABC placed third over all, behind NBC and CBS, and Fox was fourth.

headline: A Civil War Timeline
text: To mark the sesquicentennial year of the Civil War in 1861, The Times has prepared an interactive timeline covering events from Lincoln’s election on Nov. 6, 1860, through the imposition of martial law in St. Louis on Dec. 26, 1861. The timeline contains pictures and drawings from the Times archive and the Library of Congress along with links to the original Times articles. There are also links to Topic pages on individual subjects and an overview of the war, with searchable archive articles, resource lists and essays by historians and from authoritative reference sources, along with an extensive recommended-reading list. More material will be added as the commemoration progresses. Visit the timeline »

headline: And Now, Predictions We’ll Back 100 Percent
text: It’s a fool’s errand to make precise predictions about the future. Even the famously prescient often fall on their faces.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: KID CUDI

headline: Mets’ Alderson Adds More Depth — to Front Office
text: The Mets don’t have a manager yet, and their bullpen minus Hisanori Takahashi is looking mighty thin, but their front office continues to grow in imposing fashion.

headline: A Happy 125th Birthday for the Osborne
text: The film historian Robert Osborne could not have been happier that the crowd sang, “Happy birthday, dear Osborne” on Sunday night, not “dear Mr. Osborne” or “dear Bob.” It was not his birthday.

headline: Justices Hear Case on Taxing of Students
text: WASHINGTON  “How do you draw the line,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor asked at a Supreme Court argument on Monday, “between a student who is working and a worker who is studying?”

headline: Indian Point Reactor Shut Down After Transformer Blast
text: A transformer exploded on Sunday evening at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in northern Westchester County, N.Y., causing a fire and an automatic shutdown of the reactor, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday. No one was injured and no radiation was released, the commission said.

headline: Scientists Probe Beak Trouble in Alaskan and Northwestern Birds
text: Nov. 10, 11:55 p.m. | Updated Federal biologists are intensifying research on a large and unexplained rise in the frequency of deformed beaks in a wide range of bird species from Alaska through the Pacific Northwest, including British Columbia. The deformities reduce the birds’ ability to feed, clean themselves and raise young, according to the scientists, from the United States Geological Survey. [Nov. 9, 8:46 a.m. | Updated  I’ve posted an interview with two of the biologists.]

headline: Hints on Dark Matter and a Wealth of Planets
text: Both planetary science and cosmology are ripe for big news in 2011, the former in its effort to find planets beyond the Earth and the solar system that could harbor water and thus life as we know it, and the latter in the unending effort to figure out what the universe is made of.

headline: For NASA, Closer Looks at Mercury and Mars
text: On Earth, 2011 will be another tumultuous year for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration: its space shuttles will be retired, and it will have to wrangle with Congress and the Obama administration over a rocket and a destination for the United States’ human spaceflight program.

headline: Ambac Files for Bankruptcy
text: Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurer, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after seeking to negotiate a plan with its biggest creditors.

headline: Last Gasp for Factory Bequeathed by Soviets
text: BAIKALSK, Russia — When the aging paper mill in this Siberian town is transforming logs into rolls of cardboard that resemble giant thread spools, Eduard Merkulov not only has a paycheck but also faith in the future. Maybe there is a place in the new Russia for a middle-aged laborer like him, calloused hands and all.

headline: Troubles on Russia's Lake Baikal
text: Workers at an ailing paper mill in Siberia are clinging to their jobs in the face of financial pressure and criticism from environmentalists.

headline: What Happens to Health Care Now?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Government Surveillance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vicious Economic Circle
text: To the Editor:

headline: Company Accused of Firing Over Facebook Post
text: In what labor officials and lawyers view as a ground-breaking case involving workers and social media, the National Labor Relations Board has accused a company of illegally firing an employee after she criticized her supervisor on her Facebook page.

headline: Assessing Alzheimer’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Change Will Not Come Easily to the Security Council
text: The idea of overhauling the Security Council, even by the slow standards of the United Nations, has been under negotiation for about 18 years with no end in sight. Vague talks initiated under the auspices of the Open-Ended Working Group, mocked as the “never ending” committee, gave way in 2009 to what was supposed to be real negotiations.

headline: Caution Ordered as 9/11 Deadline Nears
text: As the deadline approached for more than 10,000 ground zero workers to opt into a multimillion-dollar settlement with the city and its contractors, the federal judge overseeing the cases said on Monday that it would take several more days to tally and verify “the huge influx” of responses.

headline: Players’ Case Stays in State Court
text: The N.F.L. and other sports leagues were dealt another setback Monday when the Supreme Court said it would not review a lower court decision that said players could challenge positive drug tests in state court.

headline: No. 2 House Democrat Will Try to Retain Post
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the No. 2 Democrat in the House, said Monday that he would try to hold on to that position when his party slips into the minority next year as the leadership of House Democrats remained in turmoil one week after devastating election losses.

headline: Fighting Bullying With Babies
text: Imagine there was a cure for meanness. Well, maybe there is.

headline: In Second, and Mulling an Olympic First
text: At a news conference a couple of hours after she finished second at the New York City Marathon, Shalane Flanagan hinted that she might compete in the United States marathon trials for the 2012 London Olympics.

headline: Census Reports Money Transfers
text: The Census Bureau reported Monday that United States households transferred $11.7 billion to friends and family members abroad in the year that ended August 2008. Of those who transferred, 84 percent were foreign born, the bureau found. The amount of money was far lower than that reported by other organizations like the World Bank, which estimated that transfers from the United States totaled nearly $50 billion in 2008. An analyst with the bureau said the discrepancy stemmed in part from different ways of accounting. Aaron Terrazas of the Migration Policy Institute said illegal immigrants, a large source of money transfers, tended to be undercounted in census surveys.

headline: After the Flash Crash, More Reasons for Anxiety
text: Since the financial world was set on edge on May 6 when the Dow Jones industrial average fell about 700 points and then largely recovered, similar flash crashes have occurred with alarming frequency, The New York Times reports. They have occurred in more than a dozen individual stocks.

headline: Beware Bonds With High Risk and Low Protection
U.S. Report Faults Christie, as Prosecutor, on Hotel Stays
text: WASHINGTON  When he was a top federal prosecutor, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey routinely billed taxpayers for hotel stays whose cost exceeded government guidelines, according to a report the Justice Department released on Monday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,357 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: D’Antoni Fires Back at Report That He Criticized Ex-Knick Lee
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.— The Knicks are 3-3 and not in a position to overlook opponents. But on Monday, instead of being asked questions about the Milwaukee Bucks, whom the Knicks visit on Tuesday, Coach Mike D’Antoni was asked about David Lee’s return to Madison Square Garden with the Golden State Warriors on Wednesday.

headline: Obama Visits a Nation That Knew Him as Barry
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The two houses where he spent part of his boyhood stand pretty much the way they did when he went back to Hawaii four decades ago. The two schools he attended have grown larger but, in spirit, remain unchanged. Some of his old friends can still be found around the neighborhood.

headline: Tax Cut Timing Is Proving Problematic for Democrats
text: WASHINGTON  When one party controls the White House and Congress, it controls the calendar for what gets done and when. So how is it that Democrats ended up in such a fix over what to do about the expiring Bush-era tax cuts?

headline: The Impossible Dream
text: One of the most frustrating tendencies of mainstream leaders in the United States is their willingness, year after debilitating year, to embrace policies that have no hope of succeeding.

headline: Would Deal for Lee Look Good at Age 38?
text: Say what you will about A. J. Burnett, whose erratic performance last season gave critics plenty to work with. But the biggest concern about Burnett before the Yankees signed him was health, and that has not been an issue. This is exactly what Darek Braunecker promised.

headline: Britain and France Make a Deal
text: Britain and France last week announced that they would begin a new era of defense cooperation intended to conserve their military power at a time of shrinking military budgets. The plan involves sharing nuclear weapons research and other expensive weapons development programs, pooling aircraft carriers in times of crisis and jointly training rapid-reaction brigades that can fight side by side under a single commander.

headline: Disciplinary Proceedings Begin for Contador
text: The International Cycling Union has asked Spanish cycling officials to begin disciplinary proceedings against the three-time Tour de France winner Alberto Contador, the Spanish rider who tested positive for a banned drug at the Tour more than three months ago.

headline: Sibling Bond Strengthens Amid the Ordeal of Cancer
text: Justina Mejia has become fluent in the language of cancer.

headline: Seasonal Slippage
text: Just about now, I remember that the trees on this farm will be bare for the next six months. It always comes as a surprise. The maples and hickories have mulched themselves with their own leaves, and they seem to have gone rigid now that they carry so much less sail in the wind. Everything that can die back has done so. The last of the woodchucks have gone down their burrows. The tide of dormancy is rising all around me, and on a rainy day with the woodstove going, I wonder whether I’ll sink or swim.

headline: The Return of the Risk Arbs
text: Keith M. Moore, a managing director at MKM Partners in Stamford, Conn.

headline: U.S. Loss Reveals a Shrinking Talent Gap
text: In sports, it is always fascinating to watch Goliath struggle (unless you root for Goliath; some people do).

headline: 2 Charged With Fraud of Millions From Pianist
text: In August 2004, Roger C. Davidson walked into a computer services shop on Main Street in Mount Kisco, N.Y., seeking help with his virus-plagued computer.

headline: Azerbaijan: Ruling Party Takes Majority of Seats in Elections
text: The ruling party in Azerbaijan, a former Soviet republic led by a strongman president, dominated parliamentary elections on Sunday, according to preliminary results released Monday.

headline: The Woe-Is-Us Books
text: Last week, as I was preparing a presentation for still another conference on the fate of the liberal arts in our time, two things happened.

headline: Georgia to U.S.: ‘Don’t Tread on Me’
Thrust Into the Glare by a Race She Wasn’t Running In
text: As she rang in 2010, Susan Bysiewicz seemed unstoppable. Polls pointed to her as the favored Democrat to be Connecticut’s next governor, a dream since her days at Yale, and she had begun mapping out exactly how she would change the state.

headline: Spinning Art, or Money, Out of E-Mail
text: In 1994, a 31-year-old journalist trying to expand her connections began hosting parties for other media people. She started out poring over mastheads, inviting editors at various publications by phone, then, in time, by fax. Later, when e-mail became ubiquitous, she e-mailed 10 at a time through her AOL account, which was all that service allowed at the time.

headline: Plucked From Their Web Writing to Promote a Vaseline Brand
text: IF you’ve been complaining about dry skin on the Internet, Vaseline may have heard you. With winter just around the corner, the brand is announcing a new advertising campaign for its Vaseline Intensive Rescue skin cream product, sold by Unilever. The campaign represents the first time Vaseline has used crowdsourcing to find product spokeswomen.

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: Miller and Morgan Done on Sunday Night
text: ESPN ended its 20-year association with Jon Miller and Joe Morgan as the voices of “Sunday Night Baseball” on Monday. They declined to renew Morgan’s contract and have asked Miller if he wants to stay on as the radio voice of the Sunday night games. Discussions are continuing. Each announcer is a Hall of Famer. Morgan entered as a player in 1990, and Miller received the Ford C. Frick Award from the Hall of Fame this year in recognition of broadcasting excellence.

headline: Warped Justice
text: In reaching a plea deal to end the prosecution of Omar Khadr, a former child soldier held at the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, detention center, the Obama administration achieved its political goal of avoiding having this disturbing case be the first to go to trial under its revamped military commissions. But this is not a legal victory anyone can feel proud about.

headline: Orchestras on Big Screens: Chase Scene Needed?
text: The performing arts have long been holdouts for unfiltered, direct connection between audiences and performers in a digitized, electronic and screen-laden world.

headline: Midnight Deadline for 9/11 Settlement Nears
text: With a midnight deadline looming for more than 10,000 ground zero workers to opt into a multimillion-dollar settlement with the city and its contractors, a federal judge said it would take days to determine whether 95 percent of the workers had accepted the settlement — the threshold required for it to take effect. If ratified, the settlement, which would pay up to $712.5 million, would officially end the lawsuits by firefighters, police officers and others. Read about the settlement deadline on the Green blog.

headline: Iran Rejects Accusations Regarding Nuclear Inspections
text: Iran rejected accusations on Monday that it is refusing to cooperate with United Nations inspectors seeking to determine whether it is developing nuclear weapons. The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Yukiya Amano, told the General Assembly that the Islamic republic had failed to provide the required cooperation to confirm that all the country’s nuclear material was for peaceful purposes.

headline: After Vikings’ Rally Succeeds, Coach’s Humor Fails
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Cracking a joke that requires context can be tricky, especially for a coach whose job is a topic of national debate.

headline: The Private Way Around the Checkpoints
text: I KNOW a lot of you will be interested in this tip, judging from the huge response I got to last week’s column on the new regime of even stricter security and more aggressive body pat-downs at airport checkpoints.

headline: Qantas to Keep A380s Grounded After Discovery of Oil Leaks
text: Qantas Airways will keep its fleet of six Airbus A380s grounded for at least another 72 hours after oil leaks were discovered in the engines of three planes, the company’s chief executive said Monday.

headline: A Blow to the Courts
text: Like the rest of this year’s political campaign, state judicial elections were awash in cash and blaring attack ads. The spectacle raises legitimate doubts about the impartiality of even the most respected judges.

headline: Ryan Grasps for Ways to Reduce Jets’ Penalties
text: The Jets have won six of their first eight games, some more convincingly than others. Their 23-20 overtime victory Sunday over the Detroit Lions was not one of their most dominating efforts, but Coach Rex Ryan was happy that the team persevered. To a point.

headline: Italy: Cardinals to Ponder Response By Church to Sexual Abuse Cases
text: More than 200 cardinals meeting at the Vatican later this month for a consistory to nominate 24 new cardinals will participate in a Nov. 19 “day of reflection and prayer” on pivotal issues facing the church, including its response to cases of clerical sexual abuse, the Vatican said in a statement on Monday. The discussion will also focus on religious freedom in the world, relations with other religions and procedures for accepting disaffected Anglicans into the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Remote in Hand, Manning Quietly Takes Control
text: Eli Manning brings the running backs together each Thursday for a meeting. Sometimes with a remote control in his hand, Manning stands before them and reviews game footage that he cut up and packaged, with members of the coaching staff looking on. Every Friday, Manning does the same with the receivers.

headline: Salon Editor Leaving to Write Book
text: Salon, the Web site that helped found online journalism before many newspapers and magazines had even thought about the Internet, is changing editors.

headline: Prosecution Closes in Trial of Detainee
text: Describing how a young Tanzanian man had joined a crew of terrorists inspired by Osama bin Laden’s call to attack Americans anywhere in the world, a federal prosecutor asked a jury in closing arguments on Monday to convict him for his role in the deadly bombings of two United States embassies in East Africa.

headline: DePodesta Sees Familiar Faces on Mets

text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times discuss how the U.S. can influence China.

headline: At Legal Fringe, Empty Houses Go to the Needy
text: NORTH LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Save Florida Homes Inc. and its owner, Mark Guerette, have found foreclosed homes for several needy families here in Broward County, and his tenants could not be more pleased. Fabian Ferguson, his wife and two children now live a two-bedroom home they have transformed from damaged and abandoned to full and cozy.

headline: Licensing Fees the Main Topic of Oracle Testimony
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle’s chief executive, added star power but no fireworks to a copyright infringement trial pitting his company against its rival SAP.

text: WASHINGTON — Prospects for Congress to authorize repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy face new uncertainties as time runs out for the Senate to act and strong objections remain among Republicans and the most senior ranks of the military.

headline: The Crossroads Nation
text: Bill Clinton used to talk about building a bridge to the 21st century. President Obama talks about laying down a “new foundation.” But Clinton was always vague about what the land on the other side of that bridge was going to look like, and Obama is vague about what edifice is going to go on top of that foundation.

headline: Michael Seifert, SS Guard at Camp in Italy, Dies at 86
text: Michael Seifert had settled into a quiet retirement in Vancouver, British Columbia, living in a little white stucco house, gardening in the backyard. A former lumber mill worker, he had a seemingly pristine, if prosaic, background.

text: As the Transportation Security Administration scrambles to address vulnerabilities in procedures for screening cargo, it is facing growing criticism from travel industry groups over the escalating security measures for passengers.

headline: Olbermann Offers Apology to Fans, but Not to MSNBC
text: In an aggressive statement questioning the legitimacy of his two-day suspension from MSNBC, Keith Olbermann told his fans Monday night that they were responsible for his scheduled return to the air on Tuesday after revelations that he had contributed to the campaign funds of three Democrats in last week’s election.

headline: Tuesday: Meandering
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Back in September, we had a David J. Kahn puzzle where a ring of circles spelled out the first opera in Wagner’s Ring Cycle (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Today’s puzzle has a meandering path of circles spelling out an appropriate line from a poem in J.R.R. Tolkien’s fantasy series, The Lord of the Rings. Who says that New York Times puzzles don’t cater to the full cultural gamut?

headline: Howard Van Hyning, Percussionist and Gong Enthusiast, Dies at 74
text: Howard Van Hyning, a New York City Opera percussionist who long ago became entranced with a rare set of gongs constructed for Puccini’s “Turandot” and eventually acquired them, allowing City Opera and other companies to perform the work as the composer intended, died on Oct. 30 at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 74.

headline: Carl Sagan, an Astronomer Who Excelled at Popularizing Science, Is Dead at 62
text: Carl Sagan, an astronomer who became one of the nation's best-known scientists by enthusiastically conveying the wonders of the universe to millions of people on television and in books, died yesterday at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle. He was 62 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

The largest power failure in history blacked out nearly all of New York City, parts of nine Northeastern states and two provinces of southeastern Canada last night. Some 80,000 square miles, in which perhaps 25 million people live and work, were affected.

headline: Publisher Is Chosen to Oversee Imprint at Penguin Group
text: David Rosenthal, the publisher who was ousted from Simon & Schuster in June, has been named the president and publisher of a new book imprint at Penguin Group USA, the publishing house said on Monday. He will begin in January.

headline: Low Rates Hurt Bonds for Housing
text: It is not just retired savers who are struggling with a sharp reduction in their investment income as interest rates hover near zero. Hundreds of affordable housing projects across the country are feeling the pain, too.

headline: New Winter Festival at Alice Tully Hall
text: Lincoln Center, which is still hip-deep in transcendence in its new White Light Festival, a wide-ranging exploration of spirituality in music and other art forms, will announce plans on Tuesday for a late-winter counterpart: the Tully Scope Festival, based in Alice Tully Hall and running from Feb. 22 to March 18. Intended to display the refurbished hall’s versatility, the festival will present relatively small-scale presentations spanning the centuries from the Baroque, in programs by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants (music of Rameau) and Jordi Savall and Hespèrion XXI (music of Spain and Mexico), to the present, with Heiner Goebbels’s semistaged concert work “Songs of Wars I Have Seen,” of 2007. The festival opens with “For Morton Feldman,” a two-concert celebration of the life and music of that American composer, including his late work “For Samuel Beckett,” with performances by the International Contemporary Ensemble, Axiom and the Clarion Choir, on Feb. 22 and 24. Les Percussions de Strasbourg will offer the New York premiere of Gérard Grisey’s “Noir de l’Étoile” and a Xenakis program. The guitarist and singer Tyondai Braxton, above, and the Wordless Music Orchestra, and the kamancheh (a stringed instrument played with a bow) player Kayhan Kalhor and Brooklyn Rider present other contemporary programs. Roger Norrington conducts the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment in works of C.P.E. Bach. The pianist Louis Lortie plays Liszt’s “Années de Pèlerinage.” And when Emanuel Ax performs Schubert piano works and songs (with the baritone Simon Keenlyside), transcendence is not beyond the realm of possibility.

headline: F.D.A. Urges Two Steps for Safer CT Scans
text: The Food and Drug Administration has concluded that manufacturers of CT scanners should do a better job of training and educating those who use their equipment, and that the machines themselves could be made safer by warning operators that a dangerously high radiation dose is about to be administered.

headline: The Neediest Cases Fund
text: For more than 100 years, The New York Times has asked readers for contributions to its Neediest Cases Fund, to give direct assistance to troubled children, families and elders. The first year’s contributions totaled $3,630.88. The total now is about $6 million a year, and over the years the Fund has raised more than $275 million.

headline: Barclays Profit Hit by Big Loss at Investment Banking
text: Barclays, the British bank, said Tuesday that its profit fell 76 percent in the third quarter from a year earlier, dragged down by an accounting charge at its investment banking unit that overshadowed a stable underlying picture.

headline: Worldwide Dance Celebrated in Madrid
text: Most people think the only dance to be found in Spain is flamenco. But for more than 30 years, a contemporary dance scene has been developing, with Spanish choreographers producing rich and varied repertoires. Foreign companies are also finding enthusiastic audiences there.

headline: On the Muzzle Brake of the AMD-65 and Other Reader Contributions
text: The At War blog is well past one year old now, and one of the most gratifying results of its brief but busy life has been the level of engagement it has drawn from readers. Material posted here, seemingly small or not prominently displayed (at least compared to a front-page treatment in the newspaper), routinely generates heavy e-mail feedback in addition to the comments visible under each post. For the staff that makes At War possible, reader feedback has produced many news and investigative tips, led to new sources and helped some of us learn new things.

headline: In Global Forecast, China Looms Large as Energy User and Maker of Green Power
text: China’s push for rapid economic development will dominate global energy markets and be the single biggest force in spurring higher oil prices and carbon emissions linked to climate change over the next quarter-century, the International Energy Agency reported on Tuesday.

headline: How Do You Use Wikipedia?
text: According to Virginia Heffernan, who writes the column the Medium in The New York Times Magazine, Wikipedia has become an essential catalog, especially when it comes to “digital artifacts” and the Internet itself. Do you use Wikipedia? If so, what for, and why?

headline: Pimco Chief: Fed’s Move Is ‘Not Enough’
text: Mohamed El-Erian, Pimco’s chief executive, said in an interview with DealBook that the Federal Reserve’s decision to buy up to $600 billion in government bonds does not go far enough. The plan, informally known as QE2, could reduce the risk of deflation and a double-dip recession, but will fail to overcome an “unusual” period of low growth and stubbornly high unemployment that may linger for years.

headline: Kindler, Yoga and the Art of Deal-Making
text: The irrepressible Robert A. Kindler, vice chairman and head of global mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley, is a busy man these days, even in a slow market. In the past year he has advised CF Industries Holdings in its successful hostile offer for Terra Industries and its defense from an unsolicited Agrium offer; Qwest Communications in its $10.6 billion acquisition by CenturyLink; and Continental Airlines in its business combination with United Airlines.

headline: Nick Folk Didn’t Know He Had Won the Game
text: The Jets’ Nick Folk kicked the overtime winner against Detroit on Sunday as if he didn’t feel the pressure of a game-deciding play. It turns out he didn’t. He thought the Lions would get a possession if he made the kick. In the off-season, the N.F.L. changed its overtime rules for the postseason, not for the regular season, but Folk wasn’t aware of that distinction.

headline: The Writing on the Wall

The bathroom walls — every square inch of all eight walls — are composed of blackboard and supplied with chalk in many colors in narrow channels along shallow shelves.

headline: Glimpses of an Everyday Past in Iraq
text: I was greeted by snapshots when I first entered Iraq in 2003. Relatives clinging to snapshots of loved ones gone missing, pleading for help. Snapshots of family members killed in errant bombings, stained with the tears of grieving family members. Snapshots of happier times, proudly displayed by Iraqis kind enough to invite me into their homes.

headline: In Myanmar, Opposition Concedes Defeat in Vote
text: BANGKOK  The main military-backed party won an overwhelming victory in the first election in 20 years in Myanmar, according to international news agency reports from inside the country, in a vote that was carefully engineered by the military to assure its continued grip on power.

As prices for conventional energy decline, so does interest in energy conservation and in nuclear plants, experts say.

headline: Obama Pledges Expanded Ties With Muslim Nations
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  President Obama, renewing his call for better relations between the United States and the Muslim world, used a long-awaited homecoming trip to this island nation to make a symbolic visit on Wednesday morning to the largest mosque in southeast Asia  even as he declared that “much more work needs to be done” to fulfill the promise he made 17 months ago in Cairo of a “new beginning.”

headline: Asked & Answered | Oriol Balaguer
text: If you ask the Spanish pastry chef and chocolatier Oriol Balaguer what he did before he opened his Chocolate & Confectionary Studio in Barcelona eight years ago — launching his eponymous brand a year later — he’ll tell you he was a “sweets chef” at a restaurant for seven years. It just so happens that restaurant is El Bulli. Because Balaguer’s a humble sort of genius, it’s not until you see his compositions or bite into one of his violet-cassis-filled dark-chocolate pods that you realize you’re in the presence of a dessert deity. For those who can’t access his freestanding boutiques in Barcelona, Madrid or Tokyo, New York’s Borne Confections stocks the chocolate products (and, for the holiday season, the panettone). That’s where T caught up with him while he was in town for a certain event that celebrates his favorite things: design, architecture and, yes, gastronomy.

headline: A Murderer Is Sentenced to Die
text: A jury  sentenced Steven J. Hayes to death on Monday for his part in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., in which a woman and her two daughters were killed, in a crime of such incomprehensible savagery and randomness that the trial upended a debate about capital punishment. [NYT] The sentencing followed trial that lasted nearly two months, during which jurors were “exposed to images of depravity and horror no human being should have to see,” as Judge Jon C. Blue of State Superior Court said while thanking them. (Also see The New York Post and The Wall Street Journal.)

headline: Goldman Had Just 2 Down Trading Days in 3rd Quarter

headline: We Are Not The World

headline: Markets Fall for a Second Day as the Dollar Improves

headline: Ryan Murphy Brings a Bullying Story to ‘Glee’
text: In the first five episodes of its sophomore season “Glee” has addressed topics as ephemeral as “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” and the music of Britney Spears, and as enduring as the nature of religious faith. In Tuesday night’s installment it turns to subject matter that is timely and also substantial: the episode, called “Never Been Kissed,” finds Kurt Hummel (an openly gay character played by Chris Colfer) antagonized by a bully who harasses him because of his sexuality, and it addresses the consequences of Kurt’s decision to stand up to his tormentor.

headline: New Haven, Seeking to Get More Students Into College, Will Pay Tuition
text: Public high school students in New Haven now have another reason to go to college: free tuition.

headline: The Diplomacy of Cross-Border Bankruptcy
text: Provisions within the Dodd-Frank overhaul of financial regulations call for studying the possible creation of an international resolution authority to deal with institutions on the brink of collapse. Just how hard creating such a mechanism would be can be seen by the limited progress in this regard on the corporate bankruptcy side.

headline: Will Zidane and Materazzi Ever Hug It Out?
text: The feel-good story of the week may just not be true. How sad. I had been so happy to read that Zinedine Zidane and Marco Materazzi had hugged and made up during an impromptu meeting in Milan last week.

headline: G.M. Is Saying Goodbye to Mr. Goodwrench
text: For more than three decades, Goodwrench has been the name of the service department of General Motors’ dealers. Its ad mascot was Mr. Goodwrench, a pleasant, clean-cut mechanic (though he was played with more sass by Stephen Colbert in a series of commercials in 2003, including the one you can see above).

headline: Confusion Over Program to Spot Illegal Immigrants
text: In 2008, the Bush administration announced an ambitious new program to help federal officials detain and deport illegal immigrants held on criminal charges by using fingerprints collected by local police departments.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Medical Residents and Taxes
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Plug My Ride
text: It used to be much simpler to earn your environmental stripes, but these days anything short of brewing your own biodiesel gets you dirty looks in yoga class. At least Hertz is making things a little easier. Beginning in late December, customers in New York, Washington, D.C., and San Francisco, and on select college campuses, will be able to rent a Nissan Leaf, the first mass-market, zero-emissions electric car. The Leaf can go about 100 miles on a full charge, so if you’re planning on roving into the wilderness of no charging stations (Hertz is working on building an infrastructure of stations nationwide), you’re better off with the slightly less saintly hybrids, like Priuses and Volts, also available. Rest assured, for those vacationing without a vegan or a sense of environmental outrage, there is still fun to be had: Mustangs, Sebrings and Caddies galore. Go to hertz.com.

headline: For Tepper, Washington Is an Investment Guide
text: The hedge fund manager David Tepper has done well again by betting on the moves of Washington.

headline: HCA Plans $2 Billion Dividend
text: HCA’s private equity owners are getting another big payday.

headline: ‘Fela!’ Is Sued for Copyright Infringement
text: 11:19 a.m. | Updated

headline: The Myth of Record-High Gold
text: Note: The original, shorter version of this post has been restored below. A longer version appeared in Wednesday’s edition of The Times.

headline: Without Lifers Like Jeter, Yankees Lose Their Aura
text: No major league team is more conscious or protective of its history than the Yankees. They have won 27 World Series and created the YES Network, which never replays a “classic” game they lost.

headline: Now on Taxi TV: Salvo in Terror-Trial Debate
text: The television in a New York City taxicab is a good place to get an update on the weather or learn about a new tourist attraction. It is also, starting Tuesday, a medium for one of city’s most contentious political debates.

headline: Pablo Schreiber, Jennifer Carpenter in ‘Gruesome Playground Injuries’
text: One of the more challenging acting assignments of this Off Broadway season, Rajiv Joseph’s romantic drama “Gruesome Playground Injuries,” has cast the roles of two self-sabotaging childhood friends who jump back and forth in time between the ages of 8 and 38. Pablo Schreiber, a Tony Award nominee for the 2006 revival of “Awake and Sing!,” will play the manic Doug, and Jennifer Carpenter, who stars on the Showtime series “Dexter” as the title character’s sister Debra Morgan, will play the pained Kayleen in the New York premiere at Second Stage Theater this winter, publicists for the show said on Tuesday.

headline: The Morning Report: Chevron’s Natural Gas Play
text: Welcome to The Morning Report, where you can find everything you need to know in the world of deal-making at a glance. Tuesday’s big stories include:

headline: Tuesday: Can We Do This Net 30?
text: This week, as I explained on Friday, I’m writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

headline: Cholera Moves Into the Beleaguered Haitian Capital
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A cholera outbreak that had been largely confined to the countryside has now begun to spread in the teeming capital filled with overcrowded, unsanitary earthquake survivor camps, prompting the authorities on Tuesday to brace for a more severe epidemic than previously thought.

headline: Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2010
text: Delicious no-meat recipes for your holiday table from some of your favorite chefs and cookbook authors.

headline: Movie Studios Support Debut of ‘Conan’ on TBS
text: The executives at TBS who sell commercial time during “Conan,” their new show with Conan O’Brien, ought to be breaking out in a chorus or two of “Hooray for Hollywood.”

headline: How Do You Advise Your Child to Slow Down, and Wait?
text: For Nicole and many of her peers, the college waiting game has officially begun. These next five weeks until Dec. 15 — the day she learns the fate of her early decision application — will, I imagine, pass very slowly. But Nicole is hardly sitting back, watching the clock tick with her feet up on her desk. Life as a high school senior is full steam ahead, kind of.

headline: Czech Transport Minister Loses Driver’s License
text: The transportation minister for the Czech Republic has been banned from driving for six months and fined 5,000 Czech crowns (or $283) for driving with a fake license plate on his Maserati,  The Associated Press reported.

headline: Pelosi and the Rayburn Precedent
text: Democrats who support Nancy Pelosi’s bid to remain her party’s leader in the House — over the objection of more conservative Democrats — have been pointing to a historical precedent. The legendary Sam Rayburn of Texas did stay on as minority leader after Democrats lost control of the House in 1946 and again in 1952, and no Democratic speaker has faced a similar dilemma since. (Tom Foley of Washington had the job in 1994 when Democrats were turned out and he lost his bid for a 15th term.)

headline: Gant Brings Back That Yalie Preppy Look
text: Gant, the ne plus ultra of preppy attire, is going back to its roots and setting up shop in one of New Haven’s most historic buildings. Opening on Nov. 22, the Gant Campus Store — set in the site of the former Langrock Fine Clothes men’s department store — will house a selection of Gant, Gant Rugger and Gant by Michael Bastian. The Gant brand is also working with Yale for a spring re-release of the defunct Yale Co-op shirt collection, which was manufactured during the 1960s. (Every card-carrying Yalie owned at least one of these Co-op shirts back in the day.) The Moment caught up with the Gant president and chief executive, Ari Hoffman, to find out more about the homecoming.

headline: Food Photography: To Illustrate or Not?
text: On Monday, Melissa Clark (@goodappetite) posted a question on Twitter about whether or not cookbooks should contain pictures. Matt Armendariz (@mattarmendariz), a food blogger and photographer, took a poll on the matter.  I weighed in wondering if the opinions I shared with Times readers in an article I wrote on this very issue five years ago should be revised.  I asked if, with the increase of people taking pictures of their prepared food, cookbook authors would be  wise to include pictures to provide reference for budding shutterbugs.  Since many of you come here to learn about taking better food pictures, I would love to know what you all think. Should cookbooks always include photography or not?  Please post your thoughts here.

headline: Will Florida Governor Pardon Morrison Before the Music’s Over?
text: As Charlie Crist walks on down the hall to the end, beautiful friend, of his term as governor of Florida, he still has a few items on his agenda. Among them: the possibility that he could pardon Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors, for convictions stemming from a 1969 concert appearance in Miami.

headline: Obama and China Play Rival Suitors to Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Less than a day before President Obama touched down in Jakarta on Tuesday, a high-level Chinese delegation wrapped up a three-day official visit here by announcing that Beijing would invest $6.6 billion in desperately needed infrastructure improvements. The announcement’s emphasis on roads, bridges and canals  not to mention its timing  laid down a not-so-subtle challenge to Mr. Obama: Show your Indonesian hosts the money.

headline: Inflation Delusions
text: Wow — so the official right-wing line seems to be that all the talk about falling inflation is a leftist plot — that real people know that prices of real things like groceries are soaring. I should have guessed that from the ravings of our resident troll (singular — internal evidence suggests that there is only one).

headline: SunChips War Spreads to Canada
text: In early October, Frito-Lay said it was scaling back its effort to replace the conventional packaging for its SunChips brand with a compostable, plant-based bag in the United States.

headline: Talking With Depression-Era Parents About Money
text: Many people who lived through the Great Depression tend to view money through a prism that’s different from the rest of us. They may be less willing to openly talk about financial matters, experts say, or they may simply prefer to keep their affairs to themselves.

headline: Let the Kvetching Begin
text: The N.H.L.’s annual general managers’ meeting is taking place in Toronto today, and several of the biggest front office names will be arriving with plenty on their mind. All indications are that they could be in for a long day.

headline: Jordanians Go to Polls Under Cloud Of a Boycott
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Voters went to the polls in Jordan on Tuesday in a parliamentary election that was boycotted by the country’s main opposition group. The vote is likely to bolster allies of the Jordanian monarchy, but it could also deepen alienation from the political process.

headline: Boone Plots Different Path Back to N.B.A.
text: The former N.B.A. center Josh Boone hopes he’s on the road less traveled back to the league. Boone, who played four seasons for the Nets, couldn’t find a guaranteed gig the N.B.A. this year.

headline: Using Poetry as a Way to Survive
text: A series of recent documentaries about education have offered clear-cut narratives about how to save America’s schools, through policies like increased school choice, or freeing schools from their bureaucratic shackles. But a new education film that made its premiere this weekend has a different aim: it wants to show how hard change actually is.

headline: Jack Levine, a Painter Who Twinned Realism and Satire, Dies at 95
text: Jack Levine, an unrepentant and much-admired realist artist whose crowded history paintings skewered plutocrats, crooked politicians and human folly, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Fab Confab | IHT Luxury Conference
text: The International Herald Tribune is hosting its 10th annual luxury conference today and tomorrow. In keeping with previous conferences, the IHT has chosen a theme that captures the fashion mood of the moment. This time round, the focus is on heritage and, not surprisingly, the event is being held in London. Suzy Menkes, the IHT fashion editor for the past 22 years, is grilling speakers like Alber Elbaz, Karl Lagerfeld, David Lauren and Christopher Bailey on far-ranging topics, including whether luxury brands need a history to have a future and how quality and craftsmanship can be meaningful in the era of fast fashion. In the video above, Elbaz reveals how his own heritage is defined by something his mother once told him: be big in work but small in life.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Financial Times: Jancis Robinson on what oak barrels do to wine, obviously and less obviously, and how fashion for oaky flavors is changing. – Eric Asimov

headline: Money in Piracy Attracts More Somalis
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The monsoon season has ended. The Indian Ocean is calm again. For Somalia’s pirates, that means one thing: it is a busy time of year.

headline: Some Companies Shift Health Costs to Better-Paid
text: With health care costs climbing even higher during this enrollment season, more employers are adopting a tiered system to pass on the bulk of those costs to their employees by assigning bigger contributions to workers in top salary brackets and offering some relief to workers who make less money.

headline: Cowboys’ Bad Decisions Add Up Under Jones
text: With Jerry Jones, the Cowboys’ owner, finally dropping the inevitable coaching ax on Wade Phillips, a decision he arrived at weeks after everyone else, including his players, mentally cleaned out Phillips’s office, you may join the voting on what ranks as the worst of Jones’s decisions. The list is so long that the doomed hiring of Phillips is currently somewhere around No. 10.

headline: Higher Pay, Higher Insurance Costs
text: With employers asking workers to bear an increasing share of the burden of higher health care costs, some companies are trying to spare their lowest-paid workers.

headline: No Criminal Charges Sought Over C.I.A. Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  Central Intelligence Agency officials will not face criminal charges for the destruction of dozens of videotapes depicting the brutal interrogation of terrorism suspects, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

headline: Has Attachment Parenting Imprisoned Mothers?
text: As promised, more discussion about the essay by Erica Jong in this weekend’s Wall Street Journal. I found it to be a mishmash of old accusations against overinvolved parenting. Katie Allison Granju is the author of the book

headline: In Curt Exchange, U.S. Faults Israel on Housing
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s criticism of new Israeli housing plans for East Jerusalem, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s even sharper retort, have thrown the Middle East peace talks into jeopardy, with the dispute over Jewish settlements looming as a seemingly insuperable hurdle.

headline: What Jim Webb Didn’t Do
text: As an example of the kind of centrist failure I was talking about yesterday, here’s David Paul Kuhn interviewing Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia:

headline: Your Friends Are Making You Fat and Lazy
text: Your friends are making you fat and lazy, according to a new working paper.

headline: The Annual Discussion: Wines for Thanksgiving
text: Over at Saignee, one of my favorite wine blogs, the proprietor, Cory Cartwright, is letting off an amusing amount of steam. Basically, he feels he’s surrounded by Thanksgiving idiots, offering the same trite wine suggestions they foist onto the populace each year.

headline: Will Crist Pardon Jim Morrison Before the Music’s Over?
text: As Charlie Crist walks on down the hall to the end, beautiful friend, of his term as governor of Florida, he still has a few items on his agenda. Among them: the possibility that he could pardon Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors, for convictions stemming from a 1969 concert appearance in Miami. Dave Itzkoff has more on ArtsBeat

headline: A Gluten-Free Thanksgiving
text: When Silvana Nardone’s son Isaiah was diagnosed with gluten intolerance three weeks before Thanksgiving, the Brooklyn mom knew she faced a particularly challenging holiday meal. But as the owner of a bakery and founding editor of the food magazine Every Day With Rachel Ray, Ms. Nardone was up to the challenge.

text: Cirque du Soleil, the Montreal-based circus company whose show titles have given us such linguistic innovations as “Kà,” “Koozå” and “Zaia,” has arrived at a name for the new acrobatic production it will open next year at Radio City Music Hall. And that name is…

headline: From 45th St. Perch, Watching Musicals Come and Go
text: Late September, Saturday, 8 a.m. A deep sleep is interrupted by what sounds like the world’s largest vacuum cleaner, and then cries of alarm: “Watch it! Watch it!”
