text: One of many gems by Karl Lagerfeld at the International Herald Tribune’s annual luxury conference, currently in session:

headline: TimesCast | November 9, 2010
text: Obama's visit to Indonesia cut short; U.S. marriage law challenged and Conan back on the airwaves.

headline: Goldman Fined $650,000 for Lack of Disclosure
text: The Wall Street firm Goldman Sachs learned in mid-2009 that one of its traders had been formally notified by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was the subject of an investigation. But Goldman did not tell other regulators about the inquiry for about seven months, a violation of securities regulations.

headline: Indonesian Minister Blames Michelle Obama for Handshake
text: Immediately after a ceremony on Tuesday welcoming President Obama to Indonesia, the country’s conservative Muslim information minister took to Twitter to argue that America’s first lady, Michelle Obama, was entirely to blame for a televised handshake between the two that has left him open to charges of hypocrisy.

headline: Newton Faced Suspension at Florida
text: The redemptive narrative of Auburn quarterback Cam Newton, the front-runner for the Heisman Trophy, has taken another turn.

headline: Notes from the Underground | Alexander Cowings
text: The multi-talented Alexander Cowings brought together several forms of performance in his explosive show at the Producer’s Club in midtown Manhattan. Joined by the dancer Calvin Booker, the two performed the seldom-seen art of hip hop tap, championed by Savion Glover in the 1990’s with the hit show “Bring In Da Noise, Bring In Da Funk.” Cowings crooned a number of original R&B diddies, backed by a live band of drums, electric guitar, and stand-up bass, marking intervals in the music with furious bursts of tap dancing. The evening ended with a powerful performance by Cowings’s mother, Kim Kalesti, and an open tap jam.

headline: Q&A: New York Options for a Christmas Shopper
text: I will be traveling by myself to Manhattan in the first part of December to Christmas shop. I like the area near the Plaza Hotel for its proximity to concerts and good restaurants. Can you recommend restaurants where I would be comfortable dining alone, and some lodging and cultural locations? No limit on expenses.

headline: Behavior: Too Much Texting Is Linked to Other Problems
text: A study suggests that the high school students who spend the most time texting or on social networking Web sites (or both) are at risk for worrisome behaviors including smoking, risky sex, depression, eating disorders, drug and alcohol abuse and absenteeism.

headline: The S.E.C., Whistle-Blowers and Sarbanes-Oxley
text: Congress seems to love whistle-blowers.

headline: 'Long Story Short'
text: Colin Quinn in an excerpt from his new Broadway show, directed by Jerry Seinfeld. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Broadway Theaters to Dim Lights for Clayburgh
text: When Broadway’s 40 theaters dim their marquees at 7 p.m. Tuesday to honor the life and acting career of Jill Clayburgh, who died on Friday, one house will stand out more than the others: The Broadhurst, where Ms. Clayburgh’s daughter, Lily Rabe, is now giving a critically acclaimed performance as Portia in “The Merchant of Venice.” Ms. Rabe took time off last week to be with her mother and father, the playwright David Rabe, and family members but returned to the production Saturday night.

headline: Mother Charged With Murder in Death of Malnourished Girl
text: The mother of a drugged and malnourished 4-year-old girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died in September has been indicted on murder charges, Brooklyn prosecutors said Tuesday.

headline: Honoring the President’s Mother
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia – President Obama was welcomed as a hometown boy made good – exceedingly good – when he arrived here Tuesday afternoon. But long before he became president, his mother, Stanley Ann Dunham, touched many lives in Indonesia, where she worked as an anthropologist, becoming a pioneer in microfinance and creating services like credit and savings for the poor.

headline: American Speech: Jargon of Fistiana (1933)
text: by Robert E. Creighton

headline: In Its First Night, ‘Conan’ Is a Champion
text: In what is almost certainly the largest audience that has ever tuned in for a television appearance by the curator of the Leavenworth Nutcracker Museum, the debut of “Conan,” the new late-night show starring Conan O’Brien, got off to a strong start Monday night. In his first outing on TBS at 11 p.m., Mr. O’Brien (who, you may have heard, had a network gig before moving to basic cable) drew an estimated 4,155,000 viewers, according to TBS.

headline: Recipes for Health: Salads
text: Browse a variety of healthy salad recipes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Mitsubishi Reveals U.S. i-MiEV Ahead of L.A. Auto Show
text: When Mitsubishi said it was planning on bringing its i-MiEV electric car to America, you were probably thinking what I was thinking — yeah, right. The tiny car, which has been available in Japan since last year, is slightly bigger than a fish tank and about as attractive as a walrus — not to mention its odd name.

headline: ArtsBeat: In Its First Night, ‘Conan’ Is a Champion
text: Dave Itzkoff reports that the debut of “Conan,” the new late-night show starring Conan O’Brien, got off to a strong start Monday night. In his first outing on TBS at 11 p.m., Mr. O’Brien (who, you may have heard, had a network gig before moving to basic cable) drew an estimated 4,155,000 viewers, according to TBS.

headline: 3 Senators Renew Call to End ‘Don’t Ask’
text: With the effort to repeal the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy facing uncertain prospects in Congress, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut independent, and two Senate Democrats, Mark Udall of Colorado and Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, on Tuesday reiterated their call for allowing gay soldiers to serve openly.

headline: Former Glaxo Lawyer Indicted
text: A former vice president and associate general counsel for the British pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline has been indicted on charges of making false statements and obstructing a federal investigation into illegal drug marketing, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday.

headline: E.P.A. Subpoenas Halliburton on Fracking
text: The Environmental Protection Agency said Tuesday it had subpoenaed Halliburton for information on the chemicals it uses for hydraulic fracturing, a natural gas drilling technique involving the high-pressure injection of water, sand and chemicals deep underground to break up rock formations.

headline: Black Caucus Opens Door to Republicans
text: The Congressional Black Caucus has a message for a pair of black Republicans newly elected to the House: Our doors are open.

headline: A Room With a Broadway View
text: Steve Kenny, in a new About New York column, takes a look inside an apartment on West 45th Street, near Eighth Avenue, with a great view of the Al Hirschfeld Theater, where the new musical “Elf” is in previews.

headline: Wall St. Fuels a Rise in Wages in Manhattan
text: Illustrating just how much faster Wall Street rebounded from the recession than the rest of New York City’s economy did, the federal Department of Labor reported Tuesday that wages rose by nearly 12 percent in Manhattan at the beginning of the year, even as they fell in every other borough. (See report here.)

headline: The Morning Skate: Is the Shootout in Danger?
text: Lots of the buzz surrounding today’s meeting of N.H.L. general managers concerns the proposal by Florida’s Dale Tallon to institute a coach’s challenge. One reason that proposal has gotten so much attention is that it was sparked by a game involving the Maple Leafs and anything involving the Maple Leafs is almost guaranteed to generate a disproportionate amount of buzz.

headline: 'The Four Brooklyns'
text: An excerpt from the workshop of "In the Footprint" (formerly known as "Brooklyn at Eye Level"), performed by the composer Michael Friedman at the Brooklyn Lyceum in 2008. (Video courtesy of the Civilians)

headline: Broadway Has Told the Story of the Scottsboro Boys Before
text: The new Kander and Ebb musical  “The Scottsboro Boys” at the Lyceum Theater is not the first time that the harrowing tale of nine African-American youths falsely convicted of rape in 1931 Alabama has been presented on Broadway. The author and screenwriter John Wexley [pdf] dramatized the story in a 1934 play, “They Shall Not Die,” [pdf] that was produced by the Theater Guild and staged at the Royale Theater (now known as the Bernard B. Jacobs).

headline: DeMint and Cornyn Work Together This Time
text: Senator John Cornyn of Texas could be excused for being a bit peeved at his fellow Republican senator, Jim DeMint of South Carolina.

headline: Apartment Therapy | Creative Growth at Manhattan House
text: Nothing says “If you lived here, you’d be home now” like a model apartment. But with a glut of new apartments gathering dust bunnies on the market, real estate developers are upping the ante on the marketing tool.

headline: Success at Different Speeds
text: Let’s be clear: you should not ask to solve the puzzle with only one letter on the board, even if you do have a very good feeling about the answer.

headline: Political Polls and Pundits: Parsing the Midterm Election Results
text: Overview | What do the 2010 midterm election results mean for the country? What can exit poll data tell us about how Americans are thinking about politics and government? In this lesson, students closely examine the exit polling data and analysts’ interpretations to better understand the midterm election results.

headline: Head of Cooper-Hewitt Wins British Design Award
text: Bill Moggridge, the director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in Manhattan, and the man who designed the first commercial laptop computer in 1982, was awarded the 2010 Prince Philip Designers Prize by Britain’s Design Council on Tuesday. Mr. Moggridge, who assumed his post at the Cooper-Hewitt in March, is the first designer to lead the museum, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution.

headline: G-20 Expected to Endorse Bank Rules
text: BASEL, Switzerland  The Group of 20 is expected to endorse new capital requirements for the world’s banks this week, even as banking groups assert that they will undercut bank profits, hurt lending and eliminate jobs.

headline: E.U. Fines 11 Airlines Over $1 Billion in Cargo Cartel
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission on Tuesday fined 11 airlines and air carriers a total of €799.5 million for participating in an air cargo cartel.

headline: Bloomingdale’s and Penney Join Holiday Ad Throngs
text: With Halloween past and Thanksgiving on the way, Bloomingdale’s and J.C. Penney are sharing their plans to woo consumers for the Christmas shopping season.

headline: For Dieters, the Advice Never Ends
text: Over the years in my quest to lose weight, friends, family members and, most recently, readers of this blog, have been generous with their advice. They tell me, often with a passion that borders on the fanatical, that the key to weight loss is (fill in the blank).

headline: E.U. Signals Tough World Trade Policy
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union signaled on Tuesday that it would pursue a more aggressive trade policy, including bringing more cases to the World Trade Organization and negotiating more bilateral deals with countries like India and those in Southeast Asia.

headline: Nike's 'Girl Effect' Video
text: A video from Nike challenges conventional poverty campaigns.

headline: Five Jobless Workers Per Opening in September
text: There were five unemployed workers available for every job opening in the United States in September, according to a Labor Department report released today. The ratio rose slightly from August but has generally been trending downward since the recession ended in June 2009.

headline: Hearst Official to Replace Klein at Helm of City Schools
text: Read the latest version of this article that appeared in the newspaper.

headline: HCA’s Owners Reap Handsome Returns
text: Remember those halcyon days of 2005 to 2007, when private equity firms routinely snapped up companies for $10 billion or more? Here’s a question: Today, more than three years after the credit crisis closed the window on the these so-called megabuyouts, what’s the most successful of the lot?

headline: With New Mantra, Raiders Rise Again
text: ALAMEDA, Calif.  Nothing was going right for Oakland quarterback Jason Campbell against the Kansas City Chiefs. After another mistake-marred possession in the first half of his biggest game as a Raider, Campbell sat slumped on the bench.

headline: Charting China’s Energy Explosion
text: If your gasoline and electricity bills go up in the years to come, and you want to blame someone other than yourself, a new report by the International Energy Agency has some ammunition for you.

headline: He Doesn’t Need Sheet Music. He Can Fake It.

headline: A123 Batteries Slated for Chinese Electric Car
text: A123 Systems of Massachusetts said Tuesday that its lithium-ion batteries were going into a new subcompact electric sedan to be introduced in 2012 by SAIC Motor, among the largest automakers in China.

headline: Called the Boss Unqualified? Not Me, Says Olbermann
text: Keith Olbermann, host of the MSNBC program “Countdown,” called the publication of a supposed e-mail exchange between him and a Philadelphia columnist, Stu Bykofsky, a fraud on Tuesday.

headline: China Looms Large in Luxury Industry's Vision
text: LONDON — When Chinese shoppers stride into a Gucci store these days, they had better be shown the highest quality of the couturier’s haute de gamme.

headline: A Single Site for Online Shopping Discounts
text: By shopping in the online malls of credit card issuers, hotels and airlines, you can earn loyalty program reward points or cash back for your purchases.

headline: Sergeant Accused of Killing Afghan Civilians Faces Hearing
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  A lawyer for the Army staff sergeant accused of being the ringleader in the killings of three Afghan civilians tried to cast doubt on the charges Tuesday at a hearing that will determine whether the soldier faces a court-martial.

headline: Now Showing | Visible Panty Line
text: Part old-school gymnasium, part downtown gallery, the first VPL store from the British designer and former stylist Victoria Bartlett is further evidence that the label with a funny name — VPL is short for Visible Panty Line — is a serious concern. Bartlett says she chose the eclectic interior, which brings to mind onesie-clad musclemen doing chin-ups, in order “to evoke a vintage gymnasium, since the VPL aesthetic was originally based on vintage undergarments.” Besides, she adds with a nudge, “I’m inspired by a life well-lived — I’m not stuck on minimalism.”

headline: For California, a Rebuff on 2 Pollution Plans

headline: Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell: Don’t Lose Focus on the Mission
text: The author is an active-duty Marine sergeant in his mid-20s. He enlisted in 2002, served two tours in Iraq, and is now back in the United States, where he is a member of OutServe, an organization of gay and lesbian members of the United States armed services. He has asked that his name not be published.

headline: The Future of Mining Under the Sea

headline: Metropolitan Museum to Revamp Its Plaza
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art plans to undertake a multiyear redesign and renovation of its plaza on Fifth Avenue and said it had selected a landscape architecture firm, OLIN, to lead the project. In a telephone interview the Met’s director, Thomas P. Campbell, said that the need to replace the museum’s two fountains, which have been turned off for several years, led to a broader discussion of the plaza’s layout. “Obviously the front steps are one of the great gathering points in New York, but the rest of the space is perhaps less successful,” he said. Apart from the steps, he said, the rest of the space, including the fountains, would be completely rethought. He would not specify a budget but said, “Obviously, it’s going to be an expensive undertaking.” A museum trustee, David H. Koch, has pledged $10 million for the project. The Met expects to complete the renovation by 2015.

headline: Voting Was Smoother on Election Day, Council Finds
text: Following the mishaps with the new computerized system that marred voting during the primary election, the City Council decided to ask voters about their experience on Election Day.

headline: Teacher’s Death Exposes Tensions in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES  Colleagues of Rigoberto Ruelas were alarmed when he failed to show up for work one day in September. They described him as a devoted teacher who tutored students before school, stayed with them after and, on weekends, took students from his South Los Angeles elementary school to the beach.

headline: The Dress Finally Fits: Harvey Fierstein to Star in ‘La Cage aux Folles’
text: Harvey Fierstein’s two Tony Awards for best actor resulted from his signature talent playing women, as the drag artist Arnold Beckwith in his play “Torch Song Trilogy” (1982) and as house frau Edna Turnblad in the musical “Hairspray” (2002). He also won a Tony in 1984 for writing the book of the musical “La Cage aux Folles,” which centered on the drag performer Albin, a role that won Tonys for George Hearn in the original “La Cage” and for Douglas Hodge in the current Broadway revival.

headline: The Yosemite Photographers
text: Photographs by Earl Brooks, A. C. Pillsbury, Harry Pidgeon and Ansel Adams.

headline: Ansel Adams or Not? More Twists
text: In the beginning, there was just Rick Norsigian, a California man who announced in July that he believed that he had purchased “lost negatives” of Ansel Adams for $45 at a garage sale.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

headline: An Alternative to Alternate-Side Parking Rules
text: Every New Yorker has seen them or been one of them: motorists napping in cars idling in the street, or maybe knitting a sweater or reading “Moby Dick” while waiting for the alternate-side parking prohibition to end.

headline: All Orbs but No Surrender at This End of the Rainbow
text: As a self-described “terrestrial person” whose “feet are firmly planted on the earth,” the singer Jane Scheckter marvels at the longtime fascination of songwriters with heavenly orbs, especially the moon. Seven songs in her new show, “The Moon, the Stars, Albert Einstein and Love,” have “moon” in the title, and seven others have “star” or “stars.” There is also a rainbow, “a stairway to paradise” and “Never Never Land.”

headline: Los Angeles on Two Wheels
text: Although known for its car culture, the city can be managed on a bike.

headline: Los Angeles on $100 a Day
text: WHEN I told people I was visiting Los Angeles for a week without setting foot in a car, one word came up more than any other: “impossible.”

headline: How a Little Man Became a Big, Big Marine in World War II and Beyond
text: When the legendary Marine Corps general Victor Krulak was a boy, his father, a jeweler, gave him two pieces of advice. The first was: “Nobody ever learned a bad habit from a horse.” The second: “You will be short, and you will be bald. But you don’t have to be fat.”

headline: Bubbles of Energy Are Found in Galaxy
text: Something big is going on at the center of the galaxy, and astronomers are happy to say they don’t know what it is.

headline: Turkey: Europe Seeks Changes on Speech Freedoms
text: Turkey must make strides in safeguarding freedom of speech and of the press if it wants to join the European Union, says a report released Tuesday on the country’s progress in complying with the union’s standards. Among the examples cited in the European Commission’s report were a multibillion-dollar tax penalty on a media group that has been critical of the government and the jailing of more than 100 journalists under a law that limits criticism of the state.

headline: Russia: Beaten Journalist Now Faces Slander Charge
text: Prosecutors pressed criminal slander charges on Tuesday against a journalist who was savagely beaten two years ago, though it appeared that they were eager to end the case quickly, with a $100 fine the most severe potential punishment. Still, the case against the journalist, Mikhail Beketov, has been widely condemned. Mr. Beketov, an outspoken journalist in the Moscow suburb of Khimki, was beaten so viciously that a leg and three fingers had to be amputated, and he is unable to speak. Mr. Beketov has been accused of defaming the Khimki mayor, Vladimir Strelchenko, by saying that he was involved in the blowing up of Mr. Beketov’s car, which predated his beating.

headline: France: 5 Arrested on Terrorism Charges
text: The authorities have arrested five people suspected of intending to “commit terrorist acts” in France, said Agnès Labrégère, a spokeswoman for the Paris prosecutor’s office. Those plans included the assassination of the moderate rector of the Great Mosque of Paris, according to Bernard Squarcini, chief of the French domestic intelligence service, Agence France-Presse reported. About two dozen people have been arrested in recent weeks on suspicion of involvement in terrorism, and France has been on high alert against an attack.

headline: In Brooklyn, Dramatizing Real Discord
text: “So there’s ULURP,” begins the second song in a new musical about Brooklyn. “ULURP is the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure/Which required community involvement and public review/Of all kinds of New York City land-use projects.”

headline: World Cinema Foundation
text: Images from the films appearing in the World Cinema Foundation program at BAMcinématek.

headline: Brazil’s Best, Restored and Ready for a 21st-Century Audience
text: The French film critic Georges Sadoul called it “an unknown masterpiece” and once flew all the way to Brazil, in vain, in hopes of seeing a complete version. Orson Welles, in Brazil in the early 1940s to make a movie of his own, did view it in its entirety and pronounced the experience “fabulous.” More recently, both David Bowie and Caetano Veloso have also promoted it.

headline: Plenty of Perky, Even This Early
text: If you spend enough time with Rachel McAdams, it’s easy to get lost in the pleasure of her company, or at least become enjoyably distracted. Effortlessly likable, she has a way of keeping you tethered to her character even when your attention begins to wander. Such is the case in “Morning Glory,” a passably amusing romantic comedy with a laugh-strewn script that’s almost undone by the hard sell of an enterprise that drills every emotional beat into your head, an approach that suggests that the filmmakers see their audiences less as viewers with thinking brains and more as patients with thick skulls.

headline: Homes for $600,000
text: A three-bedroom historic house in Bozeman, Mont., a two-bedroom apartment in Eureka, Calif., and a one-bedroom former firehouse in Philadelphia.

headline: What You Get for ... $600,000
text: BOZEMAN, MONT.

headline: Once Rivals, Cuomo and Paterson Present a United Front
text: They have been friends, members of New York’s political aristocracy and rivals  sometimes bitter rivals  for the state’s highest office. But on Tuesday, the departing governor, David A. Paterson, and his successor, Andrew M. Cuomo, presented themselves as partners.

headline: In Uruguay, a House of Stone
text: A four-bedroom house in Punta del Este is on the market for $2.9 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Uruguay
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE IN A GATED COMMUNITY IN JOSÉ IGNACIO, URUGUAY

headline: Captivating the Eye, Challenging the Brain
text: The words that hover around Bruce Conner — avant-garde, experimental, collage, Beat, artist — aren’t likely to get the average moviegoer out the door and into a theater seat. Neither is the title of the current Film Forum retrospective devoted to him, “Bruce Conner: The Art of Montage.” But there is no reason for anyone to dread the two alternating programs of Conner shorts, 70 and 75 minutes long. There is plenty of pure pleasure to be had from these films, for the eye and the heart as well as for the brain.

headline: Glamour Salutes Its Heroines
text: MONDAY evening, on the stage of Carnegie Hall, Julia Roberts was performing the role of celebrated actress, making a delightfully amusing yet touchingly self-deprecating speech at Glamour magazine’s annual Women of the Year Awards. She held up a shiny red trophy composed of interlocking dinner-plate-size rings and asked what the heck it was supposed to be.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Class-Action Suits
text: WASHINGTON  The most significant business case of the Supreme Court term so far involves a $30 charge for what was said to be a free mobile phone.

headline: A Plane Ride Into the Alaskan Wild, Trout Aplenty
text: LARSEN BAY, Alaska  Jay Wattum, a bush pilot for Kodiak Legends Lodge, sang snatches of the song “Highwayman” as he banked his float plane, a de Havilland DHC-2 Beaver, south over Karluk Lake near the southwest corner of Kodiak Island.

headline: Marilyn’s Stuffing
text: Adapted from “Fragments” by Marilyn Monroe (Farrar, Straus & Giroux; $30)

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s Stuffing Recipe Stars in a Remake
text: THE image of a bombshell cooking her way to nirvana may seem old-hat now, thanks to Nigella, Giada, Padma and the like. But back in the 1950s, a Hollywood starlet was not expected to squander her talents (or risk her manicure) chopping onions.

headline: Suspect in Psychiatrist’s Killing Ruled Unfit for Trial
text: A man accused of slashing to death a psychologist on the Upper East Side was declared mentally unfit to stand trial on Tuesday and will be sent to a state psychiatric center until he is deemed competent for court.

headline: 32 New York Catholic Schools to Close
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York on Tuesday proposed closing 31 elementary schools and a high school next year in what church officials said was the largest school system reorganization in its history.

headline: U.S. Says Holocaust Fund Was Defrauded
text: While fleeing the Nazis in 1941, an 11-year-old girl dodged airplane bombs as she crossed the Dnieper River in Ukraine, ultimately finding refuge in Donetsk, where she and her mother lived in hiding until the liberation of 1944.

headline: The Pasadena Project, and Others
text: A look at some Scientology building efforts.

headline: In Pasadena, a Model for Scientology’s Growth Plan
text: PASADENA, Calif. — The opening of a Scientology center in this city’s Old Town neighborhood was a significant local event. Church members spent $10 million to buy a historic four-story building and $6 million more to restore it to its 1906 luster before a gala dedication ceremony on July 18.

headline: A Sly Campaign That Has Fun With the Product and the Form
text: A campaign for Kahlúa, the coffee liqueur from Mexico, is taking an offbeat tack that is indicative of a change in how marketers speak with consumers.

headline: Republicans Maneuver to Oust Their Leader
text: WASHINGTON  Turning their attention to the 2012 presidential election, Republican leaders are digging in for a battle over control of the Republican National Committee, judging that its role in fund-raising, get-out-the-vote operations and other tasks will be critical to the effort to topple President Obama.

headline: A New Round in a Long Coal Battle
text: BECKLEY, W. Va.  When advocates for judicial reform point to examples of how money can influence courtroom decisions, they often cite as exhibit A the case of Hugh M. Caperton.

headline: Health Rules Are Waived More Often
text: As Obama administration officials put into place some of the new rules that go into effect under the federal health care law, they are issuing more waivers to try to prevent some insurers and employers from dropping coverage and also promising to modify other rules because many of the existing policies would not meet new standards.

headline: Federer Says He Asked IMG About Bets
text: PARIS  Roger Federer said Tuesday that he had sought a detailed explanation from Ted Forstmann, the head of his management company IMG, after a lawsuit charged that Forstmann had increased a bet on the 2007 French Open final after consulting with Federer.

headline: Currency Move Changes S. Korea Plan
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The Federal Reserve’s decision to pump $600 billion into the American economy has put South Korean government officials in a difficult spot.

headline: From Ex-Mental Hospital to a New Mixed-Use Life
text: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.  Until it closed in 1989, the Traverse City State Hospital was among the largest employers in this small city in northern Michigan. Two new commercial and residential construction projects are bringing the old asylum, renamed the Village at Grand Traverse Commons, closer to regaining that distinction.

headline: Democratic Strategists Say Damage Control Prevented More Election Losses
text: WASHINGTON  As bad as election night was for House Democrats, top party strategists say it could have been far worse.

headline: A Cheese for Scooping
text: Mike Gingrich, an owner of Uplands Cheese in Dodgeville, Wis., has made just one cheese for the last 10 years: Pleasant Ridge Reserve, in a firm, deeply nutty-tasting Alpine-style. Then, three years ago, Uplands hired Andy Hatch, a young cheesemaker who was keen on making his own mark. The result? Rush Creek Reserve.

headline: A Greek Prepared-Food Shop on the Upper West Side
text: After working for years in his father’s Manhattan food markets, Paul Likitsakos, above, has opened his own Greek prepared-food shop, Anthi’s. Named for his daughter, it’s the size of a doll’s house. Every inch is taken up with trays and platters of specialties, most of them from the store’s compact kitchen. Moussaka and pastitsio, under cloudlike béchamel, are from family recipes. There are also flaky spanakopita; dips like baba ghanouj and tzatziki; thick yogurt with honey or figs; and sweet pastries.

headline: Lavo
text: THE imaginary mailbag this week spilled forth an imaginary request from an imaginary jock. I endeavored to answer him.

headline: The Harrison
text: 355 Greenwich Street (Harrison Street), TriBeCa; (212) 274-9310; theharrison.com.

headline: Chefs’ Tips for the Thanksgiving Meal
text: IF you want to talk turkey about cooking Thanksgiving dinner, get a professional chef in New York City on the phone. In matters of experience and scale, they have much advice to offer the rest of us, whether we’re preparing an off-a-truck Butterball for the 20th time or a $150 heritage bird for the first.

headline: Concrete Steps to Nowhere
text: Like many observers, I’ve been wondering how Republicans are going to deliver on the mandate they believe voters gave them last week. After all, it’s a lot easier to say you’re going to close a yawning budget deficit without raising taxes than to set out plans for doing so, because the plans will involve cutting programs that people like.

headline: Ask.com to Return to Old Service
text: SAN FRANCISCO  After failing to make any headway as a search engine, Ask.com is largely abandoning the effort and will now become a question-and-answer service.

headline: New Connecticut Governor Faces Fiscal Woes
text: A week into his transition, Dannel P. Malloy can finally, officially, call himself Connecticut’s governor-elect. Now, maybe he can remind himself why he wanted the job in the first place.

headline: Mets Candidate Has a Record of Rebuilding
text: When Terry Collins took over the Anaheim Angels  as they were then known  in 1997, the franchise was reeling. The team had experienced an epic collapse down the stretch in 1995, and fallen to 91 losses the next season. A nucleus of talented young players needed direction and discipline, and the organization lacked credibility in the shadow of a more accomplished neighbor.

headline: In These Lean Days, Even Stores Shrink
text: SANTA ANA, Calif.  A temporary wall slices the Anchor Blue store here in half. On one side are abandoned dressing rooms, a few mannequins and no customers. On the other are racks jammed with clothing and accessories  and more customers than ever coming into the store.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Welcome to DealBook
text: DealBook reinvents itself with an expanded team of journalists and a host of new tools at its disposal.

headline: Challenges Await U.S. at Group of 20 Meeting
text: WASHINGTON  Anyone wondering what President Obama will face when he arrives in South Korea on Wednesday for a global financial summit meeting need look no further than an announcement by China’s leading state-endorsed rating agency, which downgraded the United States’ credit rating on Tuesday  and provocatively questioned American leadership of the global economy.

headline: A 24-Karat Safety Net for Investors
text: Think of it as the Tea Party of investments.

headline: Mets Won’t Necessarily Follow Moneyball Path
text: By hiring Paul DePodesta as the vice president for player personnel and amateur scouting, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson has reunited much of the management team that helped spawn the Moneyball legend in Oakland.

headline: Busy Mother Gets Help to Focus on Her Life
text: Susana Ramos, 35 and recently separated from her husband, lives in the Inwood section of Manhattan, in a cramped two-bedroom apartment in the back of the building, behind which black garbage bags pile up. She lives in that neighborhood to be close to her parents, so they can help her with her children when she is at work.

headline: Bush Interview Is a Bust for NBC
text: A rare appearance in prime time for former President George W. Bush finished a disappointing fourth place in the ratings in its time slot on Monday. The NBC News special “Matt Lauer Reports,” featuring an interview with Mr. Bush, who was promoting his memoir, attracted a modest audience of 7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, fewer than its rivals in the 8 p.m. hour, including Fox’s “House” (9.7 million); CBS’s comedies “How I Met Your Mother” (9.1 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (8.6 million); and the first half of ABC’s two-hour “Dancing With the Stars,” which averaged 20.4 million from 8 to 10. NBC was fourth for the night over all, trailing ABC, CBS and Fox.

headline: Congo Republic Declares a Polio Emergency
text: An explosive outbreak of polio is taking place in the Congo Republic, with 201 cases of paralysis found in two weeks and 104 deaths, the World Health Organization said Tuesday.

headline: At HCA, Hot Debt Markets Offer Chance at Big Payday
text: So long as investors are throwing money into the bond markets, private equity firms are taking advantage by cashing out of their investments in a hurry.

headline: How $25 Billion in Savings Can Evaporate
text: Note to the incoming Republican majority in the House: Eliminating government programs that do not exist does not save money.

headline: Radioactive Material Leaks Into Mohawk River
text: WASHINGTON  Several hundred gallons of water contaminated with radioactive materials from a 1950s nuclear research site spilled into the Mohawk River near Schenectady on Oct. 25, prompting an investigation by the United States Energy Department.

headline: Stage Set for Showdown on Online Privacy
text: WASHINGTON  After “do not call” lists became popular, more than 90 percent of people who signed up reported fewer annoying telemarketing calls. Now, privacy advocates are pushing for a similar “do not track” feature that would let Internet users tell Web sites to stop surreptitiously tracking their online habits and collecting clues about age, salary, health, location and leisure activities.

headline: Letting Diageo in Could Help Trade in China
text: Scotland has Scotch and China has white liquor. Baijiu, a clear drink that is 50 percent alcohol, is China’s national pride.

headline: New York Schools Chancellor Ends 8-Year Run
text: Joel I. Klein, who presided over a radical reorganization of the New York City school system and drew praise and criticism for efforts to raise test scores and hold teachers accountable for them, resigned on Tuesday as chancellor after eight years in the job.

headline: Ex-Glaxo Executive Is Charged in Drug Fraud
text: In a rare move, the Justice Department on Tuesday announced that it had charged a former vice president and top lawyer for the British drug giant GlaxoSmithKline with making false statements and obstructing a federal investigation into illegal marketing of the antidepressant Wellbutrin for weight loss.

headline: Scrutiny Takes Toll on For-Profit College Company
text: Stanley H. Kaplan started his tutoring business in the basement of his parents’ Brooklyn home in 1938. As standardized tests became a bigger fixture of American education, his company became a national operation, preparing millions of students for the SAT, LSAT, MCATs and other tests.

headline: Chevron to Buy Atlas Energy in a Competition for Natural Gas
text: Chevron on Tuesday became the latest energy company to set its sights on unconventional natural gas exploration, announcing that it had reached an agreement to acquire Atlas Energy for $3.2 billion.

headline: Back to the Ancient Days of Angst and Irritability

It opened on Tuesday night and plays through Jan. 8 at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street; (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwood’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Aug. 17; the full text is here.

headline: The Enduring Myth of Gold’s Record High
text: Washington

headline: Schools Chief Has Much in Common With Boss
text: Cathleen P. Black earned a reputation in publishing as a tough-minded chief executive who never left her employees guessing what she wanted. A student of management, she wrote a book about strategies for success in the corporate world. She thrived as head of a large media company, showing little interest in politics or a public-service job  until, it seems, a big one suddenly opened up.

headline: Ex-Detainee’s Defense Calls Him Qaeda Dupe in Its Closing
text: The first former Guantánamo detainee to be tried in civilian court was used by Al Qaeda to assist in the 1998 bombings of two United States embassies in East Africa, his lawyer told a jury in his closing argument on Tuesday.

headline: Bush Recollection Puts Spotlight on Miscarriage
text: The image of a mother handing her teenage son a jar containing the remains of her just-miscarried fetus may be a disturbing one.

headline: Vodafone Selling Stake in Softbank
text: The Vodafone Group said Tuesday that it plans to sell securities in the Japanese wireless operator Softbank Corporation for £3.1 billion ($5 billion).

headline: Eisner’s Studio and AOL Pair Up for Web Series
text: In a deal to be announced Wednesday, Michael D. Eisner‘s Web studio, Vuguru, will produce half a dozen scripted Web video series for AOL.

headline: N.H.L. Proposes Letting All-Star Captains Pick Reserves
text: N.H.L. general managers have proposed a new format for selecting players for the All-Star Game, which has failed to generate interest among fans in recent years.

headline: Why Rush to Cut Nukes?
text: THE sweeping Democratic midterm losses last week raise serious questions for President Obama and a lame-duck Congress. Voters want government brought closer to the vision the framers outlined in the Constitution, and the first test could be the fate of the flawed New Start arms control treaty, which was signed by President Obama and President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia last spring but awaits ratification. The Senate should heed the will of the voters and either reject the treaty or amend it so that it doesn’t weaken our national defense.

headline: Recalling History on a Day of Light and Darkness
text: BERLIN — Germans felt the push and pull of their history again on Tuesday, when Nov. 9 came up on the calendar. That is the day in 1938 when Hitler’s gangs attacked Jewish property in a prelude to the Holocaust, and the very same day 51 years later when the wall dividing East and West was breached, signaling the end of the cold war.

headline: A Rare Goal in Another Loss to a First-Place Team
text: The Rangers worked tirelessly, and they entertained their fans at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night. They kept the score close, but for the second straight game they fell at home to a red-hot team on a winning streak.

headline: Joel Klein’s Tenure
text: Joel I. Klein, who presided over a radical reorganization of the New York City school system, stepped down as chancellor after eight years in the job.

headline: Raiders Are Hoping to Heal
text: ALAMEDA, Calif. — After putting together their first three-game winning streak in eight seasons, the Oakland Raiders have this weekend off. Will the Raiders, who are off to their best start since the 2002 season, when they went to the Super Bowl, gain rest but lose momentum?

headline: After a Personal Scandal, a Small Political Upswing
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Recently, Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina watched “The Blind Side,” the Oscar-winning movie about a white woman from Memphis who mentors a homeless black teenager. The film so “touched my heart,” the governor said, that he wrote a letter to the woman who inspired the character, praising her “acceptance and unconditional love.”

headline: Containment-Lite
text: Don’t believe everything you read in the paper. Take this headline that appeared a couple weeks ago, when I was in New Delhi, in The Hindustan Times: “U.S. Not Seeking to Contain China: Clinton.” It was referring to a statement made by Secretary of State Hillary Clinton while on a swing through Asia. No, Washington is not trying to contain China the way we once did the Soviet Union, but President Obama didn’t just spend three days in India to improve his yoga.

headline: Phone Apps to Navigate Traffic
text: DREADING traffic jams this holiday season? There are apps for that. The advent of GPS-enabled cellphones has generated a wave of applications, many of them free, that turn drivers into veritable traffic reporters.

headline: Driver Beware: Deer Collisions Peak in Mating Season
text: These are fraught weeks for drivers, deer and the nation’s car insurers: costly auto-deer collisions make a special jump during the mating season, usually October through December, and peak each November.

headline: Kevin Rubs It In
text: My Mom used to say, “When you’re blue, wear red.” America took that advice on Election Day, and you can color Kevin happy. My conservative brother celebrated by doing his year-end political letter early. Here is his tour d’horizon:

headline: States Out of Balance
text: The Republican Party’s most visible triumph last week was in the House of Representatives, but the more lasting  and possibly more destructive  result was in statehouses across the country. Republicans won more than 690 new legislative seats, taking back at least 19 state chambers and 10 governor’s seats from Democrats. Republicans previously had been in full control of nine states; now they will fully control at least 20.

text: Just in time for the holiday season, Americans are about to be hit with a spate of advertisements promoting the joy and wisdom of atheism.

headline: Buehrle’s Gold Glove Announcement Is Bobbled
text: Mark Buehrle’s second career Gold Glove award led to an error by his wife, Jamie, who congratulated her husband in her Facebook status Monday night. The post was deleted a short time later.

headline: Washington Worries About New Power Couple
text: WASHINGTON  At one of those ritualistic Washington dinners where the commander in chief is expected to perform stand-up comedy, President Obama once noted that he had an affinity for Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader.

headline: The Fed vs. the G-20
text: When President Obama arrives in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday for the summit of the Group of 20 leading economies, he will be met by blistering criticism of the Federal Reserve’s plan for “quantitative easing”  pumping $600 billion into the weak American economy over the next eight months.

headline: CT Scans for Lung Cancer
text: A government-sponsored study has found that annual CT scans could reduce the mortality rate from lung cancer in very heavy smokers and former smokers by 20 percent. Its leaders suggest that many thousands of lives could be saved annually. This exciting advance still raises serious questions for individuals and their doctors and for the economics of the health care system.

headline: Editors’ Note: Blogs on NYTimes.com
text: The blogs on NYTimes.com have been experiencing technical difficulties, occasionally preventing readers from accessing them. And because of problems updating the blogs, some news posts will be found in corresponding sections; some posts for DealBook, for instance, can be found at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Justice Stevens on ‘Invidious Prejudice’
text: A great deal of what public figures have said about the proposed Islamic cultural center near ground zero in Lower Manhattan has been aimed at playing off fear and intolerance for political gain. Former Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court, on the other hand, delivered one of the sanest and most instructive arguments for tolerance that we have heard in a long time.

headline: Utility Official Suspended for an E-Mail Masquerade
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A Pacific Gas and Electric executive has been suspended with pay for using a fake name to join an online discussion organized by opponents of so-called smart meters, the utility company said on Tuesday.

headline: Eager Collectors Snap Up Pop Art at Sotheby’s Auction
text: It was to have been Warhol’s night. Waiters in black served Coca-Cola in old-fashioned green-glass bottles to the throngs of collectors and dealers who packed Sotheby’s salesroom on Tuesday night, an homage to a 1962 Coke bottle painting by the artist that was on offer.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,360 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Food Network and HGTV Back on AT&T System
text: HGTV and the Food Network are back on AT&T’s U-serve television system after an almost three-day lapse.

headline: Knicks Revert to Old Form in Lopsided Loss
text: MILWAUKEE  Brandon Jennings, the point guard the Knicks could have drafted slithered past them again. David Lee, the All-Star forward they traded to chase after other free agents visits Madison Square Garden on Wednesday. As much as the Knicks try to turn the page they cannot avoid the past.

headline: Emilio Massera, Leader of Brutal Argentine Junta, Dies at 85
text: BUENOS AIRES  Emilio Massera, a leader of the military junta of Argentina’s bloody dictatorship and the former head of the country’s most notorious political prison, where an estimated 5,000 people were tortured and killed, died here on Monday. He was 85.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Protein Sports Drinks Work?
text: Could sports drinks be improved with the addition of protein? That question has long gripped physiologists and nutritionists. It’s well established that the carbohydrates (sugars) that sweeten most sports drinks aid performance. They provide immediate fuel for straining muscles, keep blood-sugar levels stable and allow you to work out for a longer period of time or at a higher intensity, or both, than if you don’t swallow any extra fuel. But why wouldn’t taking in protein, together with carbohydrates, during a workout or race make you even more speedy and durable? Protein, after all, is what muscles fundamentally are made of, so it seems reasonable to imagine that adding it to sports drinks could provide some additional benefit.

headline: Word of the Day | mosaic
text: mosaic •\mo-ˈza-ik\• noun

headline: Officials Try to Rescue Cruise Ship
text: It was supposed to be a luxurious seven-day cruise to the Mexican Riviera. But two days in, this majestic vacation for thousands of passengers turned into an unpleasant journey on the high seas.

headline: Britain: Decision Pending on War Crimes Charges
text: A defense ministry lawyer told a panel of high court judges on Tuesday that three British soldiers filmed abusing Iraqi detainees held by British forces in southern Iraq may face war crimes charges. As the court completed hearings on a petition for a public inquiry into the treatment of more than 220 former detainees, the lawyer, Philip Havers, said that evidence against the soldiers had been passed to Britain’s military prosecutors, who will decide whether there is a criminal case against the soldiers under a 2001 British statute on war crimes, which penalizes any actions against prisoners of war that amount to “outrages upon human dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment.”

headline: France: Pension Bill Signed Into Law
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Wednesday that he had signed into law his contentious pension-reform bill after the Constitutional Council gave its blessing to the measure. The bill, which prompted strikes and demonstrations for weeks, raises the age by two years both for minimum retirement benefits and for a full pension. The law will go into effect next July. Mr. Sarkozy, left, had made a major issue of the bill as a symbol of his ability to stand firm and to prove to the financial markets that France can reduce its budget deficit.

headline: Posada to Have Knee Surgery
text: Yankees catcher Jorge Posada is scheduled to have surgery Wednesday to repair a torn meniscus in his left knee, according to a person in baseball briefed on the matter. While the operation is not serious, it underlines the age issues that the Yankees have to confront with Posada, who turned 39 this past season and may be entering the final year of his major league career.

headline: Mother of Girl Who Died Is Charged With Murder
text: The mother of a drugged and malnourished 4-year-old girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died in September has been indicted on murder charges, Brooklyn prosecutors said Tuesday.

headline: Argument for 9/11 Trial Site, Now Playing in City’s Taxis
text: The television in a New York City taxicab is a good place to get an update on the weather or learn about a new tourist attraction. This week, it is also a medium for one of city’s most contentious political debates.

headline: Auction Records Fall at Phillips’s Sale of Contemporary Masters
text: Crowds jostled and jammed their way into Phillips de Pury & Company’s spanking-new Park Avenue salesroom on Monday night to watch as some contemporary masters, like Warhol and Murakami, topped expectations and others, like Cindy Sherman, Felix Gonzalez-Torres and Rudolf Stingel, brought record prices.

headline: $25 Billion in Cuts, if the Math Worked
text: Note to the incoming Republican majority in the House: Eliminating government programs that do not exist does not save money.

headline: Rudolf Barshai, Conductor and Violist, Dies at 86
text: Rudolf Barshai, an orchestral conductor who built a prominent career in the West after defecting from the Soviet Union in the 1970s, died on Nov. 2 in Basel, Switzerland. He was 86 and lived nearby in Ramlinsburg.

headline: News Quiz | November 10, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Chevron to Buy Atlas in Race for Natural Gas
text: Chevron became the latest energy company to set its sights on unconventional natural gas exploration, announcing on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Atlas Energy for $3.2 billion.

headline: A Woman’s Journey From an Artist’s Barn to a Mansion’s Walls
text: On Sunday, a sturdy centenarian from Maine named Doris Bryant Makas stood in an opulent Upper East Side mansion and stared across a hundred years out to a sandy spit of land in the ocean, and saw herself.

headline: Secret Gifts During the Great Depression
text: WHO was B. Virdot?WHO is Helen Palm?

headline: For Morgan Stanley C.F.O., a Hard Road Ahead
text: Ruth M. Porat has a knack for escaping unscathed from tough situations.

headline: Insurgent Seized Aboard Afghan Airliner
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least one passenger suspected of being an insurgent managed to board an Afghan airliner bound for the Middle East before the authorities ordered the plane to return to Kabul, Afghan and NATO officials said Wednesday.

headline: Singapore Air Pulls 3 Airbus Jets From Service
text: HONG KONG  Singapore Airlines pulled three of its A380 superjumbo jetliners from service on Wednesday after tests revealed oil stains on their engines, the airline said on Wednesday.

headline: A Lesson in Control
text: “A Stanford M.B.A. named Roy Raymond … comes up with an idea for a high-end place … and calls it Victoria’s Secret. After five years he sells the company to Leslie Wexner and The Limited …Happy ending, right? Except two years later, the company’s worth $500 million and Roy Raymond jumps off the Golden Gate Bridge.”

headline: To What Piece of Technology Would You Write a ‘Love Letter’?
text: New York Times technology columnist David Pogue recently wrote what he called a love letter to the Canon S95 camera, so impressed was he with details like its huge light sensor and tiny size overall. If you were to write a similar letter to the piece of technology that means the most to you — whether you own it or just covet it — what device would you write to and what would you say?

headline: At HCA, Debt Markets Yield Big Payday
text: So long as investors are throwing money into the bond markets, private equity firms are taking advantage by cashing out of their investments in a hurry.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 10, 2010
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from The Times’s article “Toyota Says 65% of Recall Repairs Are Completed.”

headline: Return of the Samurai
text: Tokyo Bay, Nov. 10, 1860

headline: How (and Where) Lincoln Won
text: The Civil War was the largest, bloodiest conflict fought on American soil, but today its geography — from elections and secession to the back-and-forth of military struggle — is often obscure. This article is the first in a series in which Susan Schulten, a historian at the University of Denver, uses maps to illuminate the secession crisis and the war it produced.

headline: In Jakarta Speech, Some Hear Cairo Redux
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  In a much-anticipated speech focusing on development, democracy and religion, President Obama sought on Wednesday to strengthen America’s ties with Indonesia, a rising Asian power with the world’s largest Muslim population. But his intended audience was also elsewhere in the Muslim world, especially in the Middle East, where he began talking last year of a fresh start between the West and the Islamic world.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Bumbard
text: Today’s word, in association with the superior Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Met Is to Repatriate to Egypt Artifacts From King Tut’s Tomb
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is voluntarily returning 19 artifacts to Egypt that had been in its collection for decades and that Met curators recently determined came from Tutankhamen’s tomb, the museum said on Tuesday.

headline: Scouting the Steelers, and Looking Ahead for the Jets
text: If you love football, there were plenty of reasons to want to catch the Steelers-Bengals game on Monday. Was it a division rivalry? Check. Were there good player matchups? Check again. The Steelers are, well, the Steelers. With the Bengals, Carson Palmer, Terrell Owens and Chad Ochocinco and Company always provide entertainment.

headline: Montmartre Art Studios Open to Public
text: Few neighborhoods in the world are as associated with art as Montmartre in Paris. Since the middle of the 19th century, it has been attracting artists with its enchanting location overlooking Paris, the domed Basilica de Sacre Coeur, winding, cobblestone streets and cozy cafes. Monet, van Gogh, Dali and Picasso are only a few of the great names associated with the district.

headline: War and Conscience: Expanding the Definition of Conscientious Objection
text: Since Vietnam, the military’s rules governing conscientious objector status have effectively required service members to declare themselves pacifists in order to qualify. Conscientious objection, as defined by military regulation  (pdf) is “a firm, fixed, and sincere objection to participation in war in any form or the bearing of arms.”

headline: Q. and A. With Eric Mangini
text: BEREA, Ohio – I spent a day at the Cleveland Browns’ facility two weeks ago to report this article on Eric Mangini that I wrote last Sunday. Mangini gave me a few hours of his time, some of which we spent touring the facility, most of which we dedicated to an interview. The gist of that day is in the article, but there were quotations, ideas and themes I did not get into. Here are excerpts.

headline: Q&A: Buffing Up Chrome With Browser Extensions
text: Q.

headline: China Sentences Activist in Milk Scandal to Prison
text: BEIJING  A former journalist who became the public face of a campaign seeking justice for children harmed by tainted dairy products was sentenced Wednesday to two and a half years in prison on charges that his efforts disrupted social harmony.

headline: For Entrepreneurs, a Lesson in Keeping Control
text: “A Stanford M.B.A. named Roy Raymond ... comes up with an idea for a high-end place ... and calls it Victoria’s Secret. After five years he sells the company to Leslie Wexner and The Limited ...Happy ending, right? Except two years later, the company’s worth $500 million and Roy Raymond jumps off the Golden Gate Bridge.”

headline: A Smarter Strategy for Hiring a No. 2
text: Over the past two weeks, I’ve read Adriana Gardella’s case study and follow-up blog post about hiring a No. 2 with great interest. The pieces discuss the advantages of using a recruiter and whether it makes sense to hire someone who will focus on tasks or on vision, and they make a lot of good points. Based on my own experiences, however, I have an alternative suggestion: Don’t!

headline: Teenage Dreams and Nightmares: Talking ‘Never Been Kissed’ With Ryan Murphy of ‘Glee’
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers.

headline: Officers Tie British Cuts and Risk to Falklands
text: LONDON  A group of retired British admirals has publicly attacked the decision of Prime Minister David Cameron’s government to scrap Britain’s only aircraft carrier and its entire fleet of Harrier jump jets, saying it exposes the Falkland Islands to renewed attack by Argentina.

headline: Rapper Finds Order in Orthodox Judaism in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The tall man in the velvet fedora and knee-length black jacket with ritual fringes peeking out takes long, swift strides toward the Western Wall. It’s late in the day, and he does not want to miss afternoon prayers at Judaism’s holiest site.

headline: Now Accessorizing | Kilian Hennessy
text: Kilian Hennessy’s delicious scents have inspired a handbag collection. By Kilian, the perfumer’s first foray into accessories, consists of six beautifully crafted clutches that go on sale exclusively at Bergdorf Goodman in New York on Dec. 8. Inspired by art deco jewelry artists like Jean Despres and Gérard Sandoz, the Swarovski-crystal-encrusted and stingray-accented evening bags (priced from $1,995 to $2,995) are made from lacquered plexiglass and salute the timeless elegance of Judith Leiber and the high-impact style of Joan Collins.

headline: Obama Nears a Deal to Reduce Trade Imbalance
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Obama administration officials said Thursday that they were close to securing a compromise agreement to help reduce vast trade imbalances, a step that could ease conflict among the major world economies over commerce, currency and monetary policies.

headline: G.M., Days Away From Stock Offering, Posts $2 Billion Profit
text: DETROIT  A week before its initial public offering, General Motors reported its largest quarterly profit in 11 years on Wednesday, showing that the slimmed-down automaker no longer needed huge sales to generate significant earnings.

headline: Deadline Extended for 9/11 Settlement
text: New York City is giving more than 10,000 workers an extra eight days to decide whether to settle their lawsuits over illnesses they attribute to exposure to environmental hazards during the rescue and cleanup work at ground zero.

headline: Haider Ackermann Takes Manhattan
text: Haider Ackermann’s spring collection of pleated maxi skirts was one of the most lauded shows of the season, but if you’re wondering what the designer may reference for fall, look in your own backyard. The Colombian-born, Belgian-trained Ackermann, who is in New York for a lightning visit, says he has been keeping his eyes wide open during his stay. “The youth culture here is really cool to look at,” Ackermann said Tuesday at a special personal appearance at Saks. “I stayed uptown and downtown and I loved seeing the different types and attitudes.” Even watching runners in Central Park and along the Hudson is apparently grist for the mill. “They’re absolutely lovely,” he said. “I will translate everything I’ve seen into my next collection.”

headline: ‘The Story of Stuff’ 2.0: An E-Waste Sequel
text: Just a few weeks ago, I was despairing over how difficult it is to recycle e-waste in New York City even though nearly every computer and MP3 player package today has a cute little green admonition to “please recycle.” This week, I see a bit of light on the horizon.

headline: Tentative Deal in Iraq Keeps Maliki in Power
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s leaders reached a tentative agreement late Wednesday night to create a unity government embracing the country’s major ethnic and religious factions, ending an eight-month political impasse and returning Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to power for a second term as prime minister.

headline: Biking Los Angeles
text: I set out to see if I could make it in Los Angeles on $100 a day. It’s possible, it turns out. But only if you do away with a car. Now, I know what you’re thinking. Los Angeles, the sprawling metropolitan region that is home to both the Hollywood Hills and the Valley, on a bike? Well, I found it not only possible but enjoyable. In truth, I was liberally aided by the surprisingly nimble public transportation system. But I rode 15 to 40 miles a day on trips to Beverly Hills, along the coast, downtown and to Pasadena. Highlights from my trip (and some cool photos) are already online. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to get back to my very demanding research of frugal Buenos Aires.

headline: A Journey From an Artist’s Barn to a Mansion’s Walls
text: On Sunday, a sturdy centenarian from Maine named Doris Bryant Makas stood in an opulent Upper East Side mansion and stared across a hundred years out to a sandy spit of land in the ocean, and saw herself.

headline: Families Struggle to Care for Veterans
text: When Jim Hewes, a San Diego painter and Vietnam veteran, received the diagnosis of colorectal cancer in February 2008, his wife, Libby, suddenly became his aide, therapist, homemaker and advocate — his everything. Through long months of chemotherapy, radiation and surgery, she dressed wounds, changed colostomy bags and tried to hold onto her own equilibrium.

headline: The Great Cyberheist
text: One night in July 2003, a little before midnight, a plainclothes N.Y.P.D. detective, investigating a series of car thefts in upper Manhattan, followed a suspicious-looking young man with long, stringy hair and a nose ring into the A.T.M. lobby of a bank. Pretending to use one of the machines, the detective watched as the man pulled a debit card from his pocket and withdrew hundreds of dollars in cash. Then he pulled out another card and did the same thing. Then another, and another. The guy wasn’t stealing cars, but the detective figured he was stealing something.

headline: Gremlins
text: As some readers no doubt noticed, all Times blogs were down for a long time — from early yesterday afternoon until some time this morning. No, I don’t know what it was about, although the tech people are saying something about an infection from Dealbook.

headline: Fathers and Sons Stand to Gain in Atlas Deal
text: Chevron’s $3.2 billion deal for Atlas Energy promises a big payday for two fathers — and their sons, too.

headline: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows; New Jobless Claims Drop
text: The United States trade deficit narrowed in September, with American exports at their highest level in the last two years, according to government figures released on Wednesday.

headline: B-Rating America
text: OK, actually A+ rating America. Via Calculated Risk, China has created a new, independent rating agency — and it has now sharply downgraded the United States:

headline: Trash-Can Defense Against Robber Wins High Praise
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly hailed the shopkeeper in Park Slope, Brooklyn, who fended off a robber with a plastic trash can as a hero.

headline: RTE Gets Palinized
text: The Journal’s Real Time Economics, having had the audacity to point out that Sarah Palin’s attack on quantitative easing was factually challenged, gets a blast from the barracuda. As I read it, they seem somewhat shocked — it sounds as if they’re deeply surprised at being accused of villainy simply because they pointed out that the facts are somewhat at variance with what politicians on the right are saying.

headline: G.M. Posts $2 Billion Quarterly Profit
text: From our colleagues at Business Day:

headline: Now Drinking | Boxed Water Is Better
text: You’ve got to have a hard sell and catchy slogan if you’re a bottled water company trying to introduce your product in New York City, which is reputed to have some of the best tap water in the world. After all, this is a place where people have tried to actually bottle the tap water. Sometimes, though, a straightforward approach is best. And so the entrepreneur Benjamin Gott named his company Boxed Water Is Better.

headline: Testing Begins on 9/11 Waterfalls
text: There has been a rainbow this week at ground zero.

headline: Lott and Daschle Offer Advice on Getting Along
text: As Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell, the Democratic and Republican leaders in the Senate, prepare for battle in the next two years, two men who held those posts in the last decade say there are ways to improve the tone in Washington.

headline: LVMH Defends Its Big Stake in Hermes
text: Pierre Godé, vice president of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, told the French financial daily Les Echos in an interview published on Wednesday that his company had respected both “the spirit and the letter of the rules,” and explained why LVMH had opted to take a more than 17 percent stake in Hermès, rather than cash out of its equity swaps.

headline: Letting the Estate Tax Die
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.11/11/10 | Updated to fix garble

headline: Jeter’s 5th Gold Glove an Error, Metric Says
text: Within an hour of Tuesday’s announcement of the American League Gold Glove awards, editors at Baseball-Reference.com summed up the general reaction to Derek Jeter’s latest victory at shortstop: “We can’t believe it either,” a notation briefly on the site said.

headline: F.D.A. Unveils Proposed Graphic Warning Labels for Cigarette Packs
text: WASHINGTON  Federal drug regulators on Wednesday unveiled 36 proposed warning labels for cigarette packages, including one showing a toe tag on a corpse and another in which a mother blows smoke on her baby.

headline: ‘Wall Street,’ Starring Chaplin and Fairbanks
text: They were among the most famous actors of their day and the best of friends: Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin. During World War I, they teamed up with Mary Pickford and toured the country at rallies to help sell Liberty bonds to help finance the war effort.

headline: Holocaust Fund Is Victim of Fraud, Prosecutors Say
text: A fund dedicated to collecting reparations for Holocaust survivors from the German government was defrauded of more than $42 million over 16 years by a group that included six employees and custodians of the fund. [NYT]

headline: Who’s the Front-Runner?
text: Public Policy Polling offers more grist for my “Sarah Palin is not the 2012 Republican front-runner” mill. They have 2012 polls out for California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, New Hampshire, and Pennsylvania, and Mitt Romney is ahead in four of them (and ahead by a mile in New Hampshire), while Mike Huckabee leads in two. Palin performs respectably across the board, but she never breaks 20 percent; her numbers are similar to Newt Gingrich’s, who regularly polls in the mid-teens. In general, Romney leads because he wins moderates by a mile and then splits conservatives with the other candidates, while Palin generally polls in the single digits among moderates. But it’s worth noting that Romney’s formula can easily fall apart:

headline: ‘Oklahoma!’ Revival in D.C. Generates Broadway Buzz
text: Only two musical revivals are set for the 2010-11 Broadway season so far — “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” and “Anything Goes” — and the word is that only one other revival, “Godspell,” is possible right now. Which means it looks like there won’t be enough shows to fill the four slots in the musical revival category of the Tony Awards come spring.

headline: Show Us Your City: The Duckmaster Tours Memphis
text: A few weeks ago, we asked readers to give us the local point of view by submitting a short travel video that shows why their city, town or neighborhood is amazing. This week, Jason Sensat, Duckmaster at the historic Peabody Hotel, shows viewers a few of his favorite places to take the family in Memphis, Tenn.

headline: Electronic Dating Violence
text: The use of technology to humiliate or intimidate a romantic partner.

headline: Is Josh Freeman the Class of the 2009 QB Class?
text: Editor’s note: We seem to have solved the technical problems here and at the other New York Times blogs. Thanks for your patience.

headline: Gran Turismo Creator Picks 1969 Chevy Camaro for Next Version
text: While the world waits for Sony Computer Entertainment to formally announce a release date for Gran Turismo 5 — Sony’s online Style store says it will go on sale on or about Nov. 30 — the game’s creator, Kazunori Yamauchi, seems to be pushing ahead with version 6.0.

headline: Are Parents Just Saying No to Marijuana Legalization?
text: Among other disappointments for liberals last Tuesday was the failure of California’s Proposition 19, which would have rewritten state law to allow local jurisdictions the right to regulate and tax the use of marijuana for personal consumption.

headline: Olbermann: Policy ‘Needs to Be Adapted’ to Modern Journalism
text: Keith Olbermann returned to his MSNBC program, “Countdown,” on Tuesday after a two-day suspension with words of thanks to viewers who supported him, including about 300,000 who signed a petition calling for his reinstatement.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: —Refreshing this page gives you live updates of the mess Irish bonds are in. (Hat tip to Joe Weisenthal.)

headline: Turkish Action Movie on Gaza Flotilla Raid Unlikely to Calm Regional Tensions
text: Updated | 2:30 p.m.After viewing the trailer for a new Turkish action movie, in which the hero travels to Palestine to exact revenge on the Israeli commander who ordered the raid on the Gaza flotilla, in which nine Turks were killed, the Israeli news site Ynet News suggests, “The already tense relations between Israel and Turkey are about to get even more strained.”

headline: Cashman in Arkansas to Talk to Cliff Lee
text: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman is in Arkansas on Wednesday to meet with the free-agent pitcher Cliff Lee and his family, according to a person in baseball briefed on the matter.

headline: A McQueen Retrospective at the Met
text: “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty,” an exhibition of the fashion of the late British designer, will open at the Costume Institute on May 4, the Metropolitan Museum of Art said today. The exhibit will include designs from Mr. McQueen’s postgraduate show at Central Saint Martins in 1992 until his final collection in 2010. He died in February.

headline: So She Thinks She Can Dance? Tyne Daly Testing the Waters For a ‘Ballroom’ Revival
text: Tony-winning actress Tyne Daly (“Gypsy”) and Jerry Mitchell, the Broadway choreographer-turned-director (“Legally Blonde”), began a workshop this week to prepare for a Nov. 17 reading of the 1978 musical “Ballroom,” which was Michael Bennett’s first project following the triumphant 1975 Broadway debut of “A Chorus Line.”

headline: White House Editing Caused Drilling Ban Dispute
text: Some 11th-hour White House fiddling with an Interior Department report on offshore drilling safety wrongly implied that engineering experts had endorsed a political decision to impose a six-month ban on deepwater drilling, the department’s inspector general concluded in a finding made public this week.

headline: Bag of Tricks
text: Bucking the trend for rustic satchels, some luggage designers are boldly traveling forward. Delsey has developed a way to prevent surprise overweight charges: two bags in the company’s Helium Fusion Lite 2.0 line ($120 and $130; delsey.com) have a built-in scale that triggers a red indicator when your luggage tops 50 pounds. At Tumi, where all-black Alpha rollers are standard business issue, innovation comes in a splash of color. The new Accent Your Alpha program ($50 at Tumi boutiques; tumi.com) lets road warriors distinguish their bags with monogram patches, zipper pulls and luggage tags in six punchy hues. And while you’re waiting in baggage claim, you may wish you had Travelteq‘s Trip, a sit-on carry-on (above; about $1,100; travelteq.com). The aluminum frame has wheels that pivot outward to stabilize, the telescoping handle acts as a seat back, and an upholstered seat invites you to take a load off. Upgrade to the fully loaded model with battery-powered stereo speakers, and time will fly.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Investing in Gold
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Black Democrats in New York Face Imminent Loss of Clout
text: Even as Democrats gathered in the ballroom of a Manhattan hotel last week to celebrate their party’s sweep of statewide offices in New York, a sober realization began to dawn among some in the crowd: What once seemed like a new golden age for the state’s black political establishment could be on the verge of an abrupt collapse.

headline: Growing List of House Democrats Oppose Pelosi as Leader
text: The speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, looks ahead to the new Congress in an op-ed column in USA Today on Wednesday, but she continues to face a small rebellion within her own party about returning as Democratic leader.

headline: About Last Night (and This Morning)
text: Dear Readers: Thank you for your involuntary patience while City Room and the rest of the nytimes.com blog universe suffered a spell of frequent crashes starting late Tuesday afternoon. We seem to have things under control now. Read while you can.

headline: Club Form and Forgiveness Earn Players International Opportunities
text: An interesting series of international friendly matches takes place later this month, and national team managers are beginning to fashion their squads. A few call-ups to note:

headline: The Idiots’ Guide to Publishing
text: Matthew Swanson and Robbi Behr are idiots. No, really — the couple (after bidding a Steven Slater-esque adieu to their previous careers as graphic designers) founded Idiots’ Books, an independent press run out of their Maryland barn. There they live, work and raise two children. Swanson writes and Behr illustrates, and together they distribute their snide, satirical works through a bimonthly subscription service. (Titles include “The Baby Is Disappointing,” a sarcastic paean to parenting, and “Facial Features of French Explorers,” a microanalysis of the craniofacial quirks of adventurers like Samuel de Champlain.) They also maintain a blog about their lives.
