headline: Punishing a Bad Report Card?
text: Report card time. That has always been a fairly good day at Alyssa’s house in Houston. This time around, though, things aren’t going so well, and Alyssa’s mother is looking for some advice. Here’s the comment she left Tuesday on an unrelated post:

headline: Wooster Group Plans New York Premiere for ‘Vieux Carré’
text: The downtown experimental theater troupe Wooster Group will hold the New York premiere of its latest multimedia stage work, Tennessee Williams’s “Vieux Carré,” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center from Feb. 2-27, publicists for the Wooster Group said Wednesday.

headline: A Bonus Bump on Wall Street
text: As further proof that Wall Street is not Main Street, the Department of Labor has reported that wages grew 12 percent in Manhattan from January to March, lifted by a rebound in Wall Street bonuses.

headline: Guare’s Gamble of Epic Proportions
text: THE director George C. Wolfe vividly remembers the day in 2004 when John Guare handed in his new play “A Free Man of Color,” his first epic work for the stage. The Public Theater had commissioned Mr. Guare to write a play about race and class in New Orleans around 1801, on the eve of the Louisiana Purchase. The play was to be modeled on 17th century English Restoration comedies, reflecting their interlocking, ribald plots that lampooned the social classes. The commission had been made in 2002, but Mr. Wolfe, then the head of the Public, hadn’t heard from Mr. Guare in two years.

headline: More Supporters Say Michael Jackson Is Singing on Michael Jackson Song
text: For those of you keeping score at home, the tally of people who say that a recently released single attributed to Michael Jackson does indeed contain vocals by the King of Pop has gone up by two.

headline: Amtrak Allies Acela With Nets and Devils
text: Amtrak appears undaunted by New Jersey Governor Chris Christie’s decision to halt construction of a second set of rail tunnels under the Hudson River to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Post: The city has failed to collect 90 percent of the fines owed by street vendors. – Nick Fox

headline: A Character He Can Sink His Phobias Into
text: NEXT weekend the Tony Award-winning actor Denis O’Hare opens on Broadway in “Elling,” playing an anxious mental patient trying to re-enter society. But if you’re a fan of the HBO series “True Blood,” in which he plays the arrogant and acerbic Russell Edgington, the vampire king of Mississippi, what you no doubt want to hear about are his fangs.

headline: Heat Still a Work in Progress
text: When LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh agreed to join forces on the Miami Heat, the comparisons to the 72-win 1995-96 Chicago Bulls began almost immediately. With Tuesday’s overtime loss to the Utah Jazz, perhaps that talk can now cool off.

headline: Activision Sees Latest Call of Duty Game Breaking Records
text: On Tuesday Activision, the maker of popular video games including Guitar Hero and Tony Hawk, began selling the latest version of one the company’s most popular game franchises, Call of Duty: Black Ops.

headline: The Sifty Fifty Thanksgiving List
text: The Sifty Fifty is a list of 50 of my current favorite restaurants in New York City. (It’s part of The Scoop, a free New York Times iPhone app that can be downloaded from the iTunes store; you can also check out the list, with a map, online.)

headline: Concern at ‘Promises, Promises’ for Kristin Chenoweth
text: Audience members at “Promises, Promises” were concerned at the end of Tuesday night’s performance when star Kristin Chenoweth did not appear for the curtain call beside cast mates Sean Hayes, Molly Shannon, and others — some of whom looked disconcerted. The arrival of an ambulance near the stage door was troubling, too. But Ms. Chenoweth, the original Glinda in “Wicked” and a Tony Award winner for “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown,” appears to be all right. A publicist for the production said on Wednesday that Ms. Chenoweth, 42, experienced dizziness after her final scene and was unable to take her curtain call. Per standard policy, the production stage manager called an ambulance and emergency medical technicians examined the actress in her dressing room. She was diagnosed with mild dehydration and was released shortly thereafter. Ms. Chenoweth is taking off the Wednesday matinee to rest and is expected to return to the show for the Wednesday night performance.

headline: In the Midst of Extraordinary Wildlife
text: Noah Snyder-Mackler, a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania, is studying the evolution of social behavior in the gelada, a primate found in Ethiopia. Scientist at Work will check in from time to time with Mr. Snyder-Mackler, whose expedition continues into December.

headline: Along Jamaica Bay, a Landfill’s Visual Legacy
text: Nathan Kensinger, photo-chronicler par excellence of the city’s neglected corners , has just published the last installment of a three-part photo essay on Edgemere in the Rockaways, home to both what the city called the longest continuously operating dump in the United States until it closed in 1991, as well as a 20-block city-owned stretch of abandoned oceanfront.

headline: G.M. Officials Stick to Earnings Script

headline: You Supply the Movie, Rifftrax Supplies the Laughs
text: I used to love “Mystery Science Theater 3000.” It ran on TV from 1988 to 1999, and cracked me up every time. You can read up on it on Wikipedia, but the basic idea was you watch a really terrible old movie, usually a sci-fi B movie. At the bottom of the screen, you see the silhouettes of three professional hecklers as they talk to the screen and riff on the awfulness of the movie and the acting.

headline: Doping Rule’s Extra Consequences

text: LONDON  A demonstration against government proposals to cut education spending and steeply increase tuition for university students turned violent on Wednesday as protesters attempted to storm the building that houses the Conservative Party.

headline: Cheating Charges Embroil Auburn and Newton
text: If we didn’t know any better, we might suspect the Southeastern Conference was getting jealous. It was falling behind in scandal and mayhem news. For a while there, Southern California was stealing all its thunder. While everyone fixated on the Reggie Bush fiasco, the SEC was left waving in the background, “Hey, the N.C.A.A. is looking into the recruiting hostesses at Tennessee!” Well, now it’s got something to really crow about: the prohibitive favorite for the Heisman Trophy is drawing allegations the way Lindsay Lohan draws paparazzi.

headline: Seeing a Patient Outside the Hospital
text: I was having lunch with another nurse outside the hospital when I spotted a former patient of mine.

headline: China Still Bans Rare Earth to Japan
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese government is continuing to block shipments of crucial strategic minerals to Japan, according to industry executives, analysts and a Japanese official.

headline: Hall of Famers Who Played for One Team
text: Derek Jeter is not yet a Hall of Famer but he is heading into his 16th full season with the Yankees. Few players in the free-agent era have remained with one team for as long as Jeter; players are more likely to leave teams for more money elsewhere.

headline: Sydney Sips
text: Australian drinking culture took a serious hit during the temperance movement: for the better part of the 20th century, pubs were required to close by 6 p.m., a restriction that fostered binge drinking (the notorious ‘‘six o’clock swill’’) and dampened any creativity behind the bar. But an interest in cocktail craft has sprung up in cities down under, starting first in Melbourne’s small, speakeasy-style laneway bars and taking hold most recently in Sydney. In 2007, new laws made it easier and cheaper to open bars here, resulting in an onslaught of pocket-size watering holes that are big on character, from buttoned-up boîtes to faux dives.

headline: Young Forward Gives Cavaliers New Bounce
text: NEWARK  The temptation is to burst into superlatives, to see the leaping and the soaring and the dunking and to let the imagination wander. Sometimes J. J. Hickson, the Cleveland Cavaliers’ stringy, pogo-stick forward, inspires a little irrational exuberance.

headline: For Edge on Alzheimer’s, Testing Early Treatments
text: Much of the research on Alzheimer’s next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

headline: U.S. Dodges Bullet in Busy Hurricane Season
text: One of the most active hurricane seasons on record is coming to a close, although you might be forgiven for missing it if you live in the United States. In an exceptional run of good luck, the nation avoided a direct hit by a hurricane for the second year in a row.

headline: College Kids These Days
text: David Brooks: Gail, one of the things I get to do in this job is visit college campuses. This has made me more relaxed as my own kids apply to college. I’ve learned that if you put me in an unmarked room with students from any of the top 100 colleges in the country, and let me have a one-hour discussion with them, I wouldn’t be able to tell if I were at the school that was No. 1 in the U.S. News ranking or No. 100. There are a lot of smart kids everywhere.

headline: In-Flight Fire Endangers Delivery Date for Boeing 787
text: Boeing halted test flights on Wednesday of its 787 Dreamliner, a day after an onboard fire forced an emergency landing, reinforcing expectations that the long-awaited plane faced more delays.

headline: Report Questions the System Used to Flag Rikers Island Inmates for Deportation
text: As the Obama administration steps up efforts to deport immigrants held on criminal charges, federal officials in New York City have long been on the job. At the city’s main jail on Rikers Island, immigration officers comb through lists of foreign-born inmates, then question, detain and deport about 3,200 of them a year.

headline: Unserious People
text: OK, let’s say goodbye to the deficit commission. If you’re sincerely worried about the US fiscal future — and there’s good reason to be — you don’t propose a plan that involves large cuts in income taxes. Even if those cuts are offset by supposed elimination of tax breaks elsewhere, balancing the budget is hard enough without giving out a lot of goodies — goodies that fairly obviously, even without having the details, would go largely to the very affluent.

headline: FIDE Picks Grischuk to Take Carlsen’s Place, If Not Fill His Shoes
text: Less than a week after Magnus Carlsen of Norway, the No. 2 player in the world in the official rankings (and No. 1 in unofficial but more up-to-date calculations), made his surprising announcement that he was withdrawing from the cycle to select a challenger for the world championship, the World Chess Federation announced Wednesday that he will be replaced by Alexander Grischuk of Russia, No. 6 in the world.

headline: What Do East Coast Women Need to Learn About Entrepreneurship?
text: In a just-published New York Times article, Pamela Ryckman explores whether the most financially successful West Coast women, particularly those in Silicon Valley, are more entrepreneurial than their East Coast counterparts — and, if so, whether something can be done about that disparity.

headline: Jay-Z and Charlie, Together on Stage

headline: Vain Glorious | Revlon’s Fire & Ice
text: In Revlon’s 1952 ad for the Fire & Ice Collection, Richard Avedon photographed model-of-the-moment Dorian Leigh in a sparkling silver gown framed by an amorphous tuft of red fabric (a copy of a Balenciaga cape), her hands drawing attention to her blood-colored manicure and lipstick. One of the most indelible ads in fashion history, the image was part of a niche campaign that included a Peggy Olsen-worthy tagline — “Are you made for Fire & Ice?” — and a bizarre questionnaire that asked, ‘Have you ever wanted to wear an ankle bracelet?’ and ‘Does gypsy music make you sad?’ While a lot has changed since 1952, Fire & Ice has a new shelf life now that Revlon has re-released three “lip-and-tip” pairings ($4.79 – $ 8.99). The ad, shot by Mario Testino, restages the original, with a few notable exceptions — the actress Jessica Biel stands in for Leigh, ankle bracelets are so last century, and that dress is no knockoff.

headline: Letter: Traveling While Fat
text: To the Editor: In response to Rob Goldstone’s “Tricks and Trials of Traveling While Fat” (Oct. 24), I ask: has Mr. Goldstone seriously considered a diet? Wouldn’t he be a healthier traveler after shedding some of his 285 pounds? Instead of going to Fiji, where bulk is revered, or choosing a larger seat, try smaller meals and more exercise.

headline: The Sugarplum Diet
text: ACT I of “The Nutcracker” ends with snow falling and snowflakes dancing. Yet “The Nutcracker” is now seasonal entertainment even in parts of America where snow seldom falls: Hawaii, the California coast, Florida. Over the last 70 years this ballet — conceived in the Old World — has become an American institution. Its amalgam of children, parents, toys, a Christmas tree, snow, sweets and Tchaikovsky’s astounding score is integral to the season of good will that runs from Thanksgiving to New Year.

headline: Resisting the Online Tracking Programs
text: If you have ever worried about specifically aimed ads that seem aware of your private moments on the Web, such as looking at sites for kitten-heel pumps, eczema medications or how to get out of debt, here is something else to fret about.

headline: Letter: Literary Asheville
text: To the Editor: The recent “36 Hours” article about Asheville, N.C., (Oct. 24) omitted two important literary sites. The boyhood home of Thomas Wolfe, at 52 North Market Street, shows visitors some of the influences on one of America’s great novelists. In nearby Flat Rock is the home of the American poet and biographer of Lincoln, Carl Sandburg, who moved to the area in 1945 to allow his wife to continue to breed champion dairy goats. The farm and the Sandburg home are a National Historic Site. Any trip to Asheville would be enriched by visiting these homes.

headline: Field Report: Palm Reader
text: In Los Angeles, where appearances matter, the palm trees that line Sunset Boulevard are strictly for show. To find a palm that bears fruit, you need to drive two and a half hours southeast. In the scrubby Coachella desert valley, oases of date palms rise from the gray-brown dust — acres of spiky green fronds on spindly stems supporting thousands of pounds of zahidis, barhis and other varieties. It’s like the edible back lot for the set of “California: The Movie.”

headline: Magic Show
text: Designers and cultural producers are in the business of divining the future. Now, thanks to a new exhibition at the National Arts Club, some of the world’s leading creatives have made a full-fledged jump to the dark side. Curated by Stacy Engman, “Contemporary Magic: A Tarot Deck Art Project” features the minor and major arcana as reinterpreted by 78 art and fashion world luminaries who were each matched with a card based on themes that recur in their work. Among the newly anointed mystics are Karl Lagerfeld (King of Wands), Marc Jacobs (Knight of Pentacles), John Currin (Ten of Cups) and Tracey Emin (the Empress). And in an occult line call that would have taken a master magician to adjudicate, Mickalene Thomas gets the nod as the High Priestess.

headline: A Personal Story of Sexual Harassment
text: Earlier this week, I wrote about a new iPhone application that allows women to report street harassment in seconds. The application, available on iTunes, and its forthcoming Android counterpart, grew out of ihollaback.org, a Web site where women post stories of sexual harassment, groping and other unsavory incidents.

headline: The Tonys Find a Home. The Bad News? It’s Small. The Good News? It’s Actually on Broadway.
text: When the Tony Awards first moved from a Broadway theater to Radio City Music Hall in 1997, the main reason was size — Radio City could accommodate nearly 6,000 people, many more than even the largest Broadway house. Once the giant music hall booked Cirque du Soleil from June through September of next year, though, the Tonys were forced to hunt for new real estate for the 65th annual awards ceremony.

headline: Garth Fagan Dance at 40
text: The company celebrated its 40th anniversary at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with premieres of dances by Mr. Fagan and Norwood Pennewell.

headline: Turning 40, but Still Flying Through the Air Like a Picture of Ease
text: Garth Fagan Dance has been around for 40 years (it began as Bottom of the Bucket, but ... Dance Theater). And Norwood Pennewell has been with the company for all but eight of those years, a remarkable career for any dancer, but more so in light of the exacting rigor of Mr. Fagan’s oeuvre. You have to have serious chops to pull off those endless, off-center balances, disparate movement languages and space-eating leaps, and Mr. Pennewell  along with Nicolette Depass, the troupe’s other miraculous veteran  never disappoints.

headline: A Change in Season and Regimen
text: IF Lisbeth Salander, the dark-lipped, pierced dynamo of Stieg Larsson’s “Millennium” trilogy, wanted to soften her look a bit, November would be a good time to get rid of one of her tattoos. That also goes for LeBron James, whose “Loyalty” tattoo, scrawled across his rib cage, has attracted derision since he left Cleveland for Miami.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: WHOA, NELLY Ralph Lauren has introduced the Big Pony Collection, a new line of fragrances intended for men ages 18 to 30. In a nod to the fact that a polo team has four members, there are four scents named for supposedly desirable attributes of young men today: Sporty (lime and grapefruit), Seductive (dark chocolate and musk), Adventurous (mint and ginger), and Stylish (mandarin and kyara wood). All come in colorful flasks ($50 to $65 each).

headline: Cisco Reports Higher Profit But Sees Some Weaknesses
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A tepid forecast from Cisco Systems on Wednesday sent the tech giant’s shares down sharply during after-hours trading and shook Wall Street’s confidence that the economy is recovering.

headline: Income And Life Expectancy
text: I’ve referenced this before, but here’s the Social Security Administration study. Look at Table 4: since 1977, the life expectancy of male workers retiring at age 65 has risen 6 years in the top half of the income distribution, but only 1.3 years in the bottom half.

headline: The Seduction of Lovers, Plotted at a Faster Pace
text: The list of significant conductors who have never worked at the Metropolitan Opera grew shorter on Tuesday night, when William Christie made his company debut in Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte,” a revival of Lesley Koenig’s simple, sunny and charming 1996 production. Though Mr. Christie has conducted at leading opera companies in Lyon, Zurich and elsewhere, his major contributions have come from Les Arts Florissants, the early-music ensemble he founded in 1979, based in France.

headline: Quirky, Eclectic and Precise
text: The opening dance quartet of Neil Greenberg’s new “(like a vase),” at Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday night, has a low-key air, cultivated but quirky, mildly camp and somewhat arch. The movements contain enough contrast and variety to hold your attention but not to change your breathing. This dancer prances on half-toe while her torso tips one way and then another, while that dancer stretches on the floor. But they make it feel as if it were just for insiders: interesting if you’re interested.

headline: Android Is 2nd in Mobile Sales, Gartner Says

headline: 5 Tips for Searching Gmail
text: A 2009 research report about e-mail usage found that at least 247 billion messages are sent in a single day. That’s more than 2.8 million little e-mails that fly around the Internet every single second.

headline: Madoff’s Wares Go on the Block

headline: New York Harbor, Then and Now
text: Since 1909, the city has tested the waters within New York Harbor to measure their overall quality. The effort started when the harbor, with nearly 600 miles of waterfront and about 240 miles of shipping channels, received hundreds of millions of gallons of raw sewage discharged straight from the sewer pipes.

headline: Shelf Life | On the Case
text: It feels a little sacrilegious to call anything stamped Louis Vuitton a doorstop, but ‘‘Louis Vuitton: 100 Legendary Trunks’’ (Abrams; $170 for the deluxe edition, above) qualifies by heft alone — it’s nearly 500 pages and weighs about 10 pounds. The exhaustive, lushly illustrated book traces the history of Vuitton luggage; carry-ons these are not, either in spirit or in scale. There are engineering innovations (a bed that folds into a trunk, for the 19th-century explorer Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza), concept-only wonders (the ‘‘Jetsons’’-esque Mars Trunk, which opens to reveal a mini cocktail bar and CD and book storage) and trunks customized to hold the inspirations and playthings of writers and artists (books for Ernest Hemingway, surgical knives for Damien Hirst). An accompanying exhibit is on view at the Carnavelet Museum in Paris until Feb. 27, 2011.

headline: A New Hired Gun for the S.E.C.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Wednesday that Joseph K. Brenner, a partner at WilmerHale, has been selected as chief counsel of the division of enforcement.

headline: In the Case of a Terrier, ‘No Pets Allowed’ Is Overruled
text: Charlie the teacup Yorkshire terrier can stay.

headline: A Long-Delayed Alliance, Cohesive and Potent
text: Better late than never  far better. AfroCubism, the group of Malian and Cuban musicians who have made an album together and who performed at Town Hall on Tuesday night, is a long-delayed collaboration. It’s a musical chemistry experiment that Nick Gold, the founder of World Circuit Records, tried to assemble in 1996 by bringing Malian musicians to Havana to work with elder-generation Cuban musicians, for trans-Atlantic Afro-Cuban fusions.

headline: A Last Look at South American Birds
text: Sunday, Nov. 7

headline: In Boston, Listening to a Young Playwright Adept at Silence
text: BOSTON — What you notice most about Shirley, Vt., is how quiet it can get. This is not the silence classically associated with small-town America, a noiselessness that probably doesn’t exist anymore anyway. There are, after all, cellphones in Shirley.

headline: Gap, Its U.S. Sales Tepid, Joins the Rush to China
text: SHANGHAI  With sales in the United States sluggish, one of America’s best-known apparel brands  Gap Inc.  is joining the rush to enter China’s fast-growing consumer market.

headline: Airbnb Raises Cash to Expand Budget-Travel Service
text: Airbnb, the service that matches budget-minded travelers with locals who are willing to rent out an extra bedroom, is getting a nice room upgrade.

headline: Nurkowski? Makowski? Murckoski? Counting the Write-In Votes in Alaska
text: 7:39 p.m. | Updated  JUNEAU, Alaska – “Liza Makowski?”

headline: Judge in Mel Gibson Case Denies Gag Order
text: 8:23 p.m. | Updated A state court judge in Los Angeles denied Mel Gibson’s request for a broad gag order closing off access to information from the paternity action involving himself and Oksana Grigorieva, a lawyer representing Ms. Grigorieva said.

headline: France: President Signs Pension Reform Bill
text: FRANCE: PRESIDENT SIGNS PENSION REFORM BILL

headline: Uganda Seen as a Front Line in the Bioterrorism Fight
text: ENTEBBE, Uganda — The laboratories of Uganda’s Ministry of Agriculture, Animals, Industry and Fisheries sit on the top of a quiet hill on a turnoff near the airport, behind an eroded fence. At the end of a hallway is a room with an unlocked refrigerator.

headline: Opposition to Power Line at a Fjord Runs Deep
text: NORHEIMSUND, Norway  Change comes hard around these deep fjords on the west coast of Norway. When the first hotel went up in this town in 1857, the pious townsfolk protested: hotels brought drinking, they feared, and loose women.

headline: BJ’s Shares Pop on News of Potential Sale
text: Investors piled into shares of BJ’s Wholesale Club on Wednesday like shoppers at one of its warehouses hunting for big deals, pushing the stock up 12.6 percent as the company prepared a potential sale of itself.

headline: Judge Rebukes State Agency Over Atlantic Yards Timetable
text: It comes too late to halt construction, but a judge has issued a stinging rebuke to the state agency overseeing the $5 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, finding that it made “totally incomplete representations” in legal papers about how long it would take the project to get built, in “what appears to be yet another failure of transparency.”

headline: Brad Mehldau Is a Jazzman in a Classical Mood
text: Brad Mehldau, a star in the jazz world, has lately been asserting himself in classical precincts as well. He has written song cycles for Renée Fleming and Anne Sofie von Otter, and both singers have recorded those works with Mr. Mehldau at the piano. His solo and ensemble recordings have touched on his classical leanings too. They show him grappling with formal notions of structure and thematic development, and seeking a balance between the precisely defined gestures of composed music and the freedom and spontaneity of improvisation.

headline: Title Insurance Concept Spreads Into Art Sales
text: Though standard in real estate transactions, the concept of title insurance, which guarantees that a seller is the free and clear owner, has been resisted by the art world.

headline: Book Review: Jet Age — The Comet, the 707, and the Race to Shrink the World
text: In 1958, fewer than 1 in 10 American adults had ever traveled in an airplane. More than half a century after the worldwide sensation of the Wright Brothers, and almost 20 years since the Pan Am Clipper began service across the Atlantic, flying was still widely considered a vehicle for daredevils and tycoons. To cross an ocean, civilians and soldiers alike usually went by boat.

headline: Near Madrid, a House of Concrete I-Beams and Steel Girders
text: A Spanish architect built the house he shares with his partner and two children using pieces of infrastructure.

headline: Peace in the Pursuit of Maine Clams
text: This film has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

headline: Refining The Elevator Pitch
text: Young people starting programs for social change attend a one day boot camp designed to refine their pitch.

headline: The Perfect Dress for Making a Statement
text: “MADE in Dagenham” is not remotely what you would call a fashion film. Set in 1968, in an automobile factory outside London, it is a dramatized account of the landmark labor dispute between the Ford Motor Company and a group of female sewing machinists who demanded equal pay with men. Archival footage from this period does not suggest the actual participants in the action were the style icons of their day.

headline: Via Twitter, Kanye West Chafes at ‘Today’ Interview
text: An interview between Kanye West and Matt Lauer for NBC’s “Today” show flared into a Twitter storm when, on Tuesday night, Mr. West wrote that he’d been ambushed by Mr. Lauer, a “Today” host. Mr. West said he intended to respond to remarks by former President George W. Bush, who has said that Mr. West’s criticism after Hurricane Katrina  that Mr. Bush did not care about black people  was “one of the most disgusting moments” of his presidency.

headline: The New Icons of Fashion
text: ANNA DELLO RUSSO lives in a glass house  the virtual kind  her subtlest gesture or sartorial quirk scrutinized by her legions of fans. Pecking at their keyboards, those online viewers wax effusive. “She is like Coco Chanel to me,” one admirer exclaimed on The Sartorialist, the popular blog. “Isn’t she fabulous ... so jolie laide,” gushed another on The Fashion Spot; a third posting on Ms. Dello Russo’s blog, to her: “I love when you wear pink.”

headline: A Searching Look at Combat Wounds to the Spirit
text: Part of the mission of “Wartorn: 1861-2010,” an HBO documentary about post-traumatic stress disorder, is to see that its subject is taken seriously. That kind of special pleading, however necessary, can have a dulling effect on a film, and “Wartorn” sometimes starts to feel prim and preachy. But it also has its share of quietly devastating, haunting scenes, echoes of the nightmares that veterans are bringing home with them from Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Add Edwards to List of Jets-Browns Story Lines
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan brought props to his news conference Wednesday: a blond wig, a Cleveland Browns cap and a brown XXXXXL T-shirt with a pillow underneath. Then he poked fun at the Browns’ defensive coordinator, his twin brother, Rob.

headline: How the Best Got That Way: Finding Plays
text: Experts often seem to be luckier than the less capable, but it is usually because they find plays that make life difficult for their opponents. This deal features the winners of the World Open Pairs in Philadelphia last month, Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein.

headline: It’s a Tablet. It’s Gorgeous. It’s Costly.
text: Every time there’s some new hot, heavily hyped gadget from Apple, it takes only a few months for the copycats to crop up. IPod? Zune! IPhone? Android!

headline: Cancer as Old Foe and Goad to Science
text: On its first page “The Emperor of All Maladies” sets forth its intention: to be a definitive history of how cancer has been understood, treated, feared and politicized throughout all of recorded human history. That’s a staggeringly tall order. Yet the author, Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee, seeks to make it even taller. His book also aspires to be “a biography of cancer,” even though Dr. Mukherjee (a cancer specialist and researcher with stellar credentials) cannot exactly explain what that phrase means.

headline: Putting Star Power Behind Good Works
text: THE telephone connection was fuzzy, ruffled around the edges by Hurricane Tomas, bearing down on Haiti, where Sean Penn had agreed to an interview from the tent in a refugee camp where he was living.

headline: Therapy Dogs at Work
text: Therapists who work with autistic children have found that some useful treatment comes with four paws and fur.

headline: Kelly Hoppen Introduces an iPhone App
text: Kelly Hoppen, the English interior designer, has published six books. She also owns a store in West London and holds an occasional five-day master class (for which she charges about $4,700, including tax). “I have a multimillion-pound business,” she said.

headline: For Autistic Children, Therapy on Four Legs
text: SHADOW, a black Labrador retriever, knows how to interact with people without overreacting to them  a necessity for a well-trained therapy dog, said her owner and handler, Ani Shaker.

headline: Going Korean
text: Pedicures are disgraceful.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: A Social Web Browser
text: Netscape alumni are introducing a browser called RockMelt that integrates social media into the browser. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Miguel Helft, a technology reporter for The New York Times, about how this new browser works. Mr. Helft says RockMelt makes it easy to post to Facebook, Twitter and other sites and communicate with friends. But users must log in because RockMelt manages interactions with social networking sites in its data center. Given the competitiveness of the browser market, RockMelt can anticipate challenges, Mr. Helft says.

headline: Nike Harnesses ‘Girl Effect’ Again
text: FIFTEEN years ago, Nike made a splash with an advertising campaign known as “If you let me play.” The ads drew considerable attention  and praise  because they advocated the benefits for girls and young women of participating in sports.

headline: No Bridge Too Far: Literary Agents Move to Brooklyn
text: When David Black contemplated moving his 21-year-old literary agency to a new office space this summer, he had one nagging worry: the East River.

headline: Can a Nerd Have Soul?
text: THE SINGER Mayer Hawthorne was born almost 13 years after the Supremes’ Motown classic “You Can’t Hurry Love” first lit up radio waves and dance floors. He was a toddler when the song’s bass line, maybe the most famous in the history of pop-and-soul music, was amplified and repackaged as the basis of Daryl Hall and John Oates’s No. 1 hit “Maneater”; it was also suited up and sent back into action by the likes of the Clash, Katrina and the Waves and even other Motown artists. Something about those repeated eight notes — originally played by the Motown house bassist James Jamerson in 1966 as if small shocks were being delivered to his index finger — continued to evoke, across a span of decades, the tachycardic rush of new love or lust.

headline: Campaigning for Friends as Much as for Sales
text: DURING the economic downturn, many brands turned to nostalgia marketing to strike a reassuring chord, like General Mills selling Trix and other varieties in retro boxes, Nationwide Insurance resurrecting its “Nationwide is on your side” slogan and Bumble Bee Tuna reviving its “Yum, yum, Bumble Bee” jingle.

headline: A Wireless Speaker(phone) for Smartphones
text: Jawbone, maker of all kinds of earpieces for mobile phones, has branched out into the speaker business. Its first foray, the four-pack-of-butter size Jambox, seems to have succeeded right out of the gate.

headline: Prostate Cancer Drug Gets Lukewarm Review
text: There is only “moderate’’ evidence that the newly approved prostate cancer drug Provenge helps patients, according to an analysis done for Medicare that was made public on Wednesday.

headline: The Turban Makes a Glamorous Comeback
text: Once linked to grannies in housecoats, the turban has a new association for young women.

headline: The Head Wrap Comes Back, Again
text: WEARING a turban demands confidence. You have to believe, truly believe, in your look. You have to commit — it’s a turban, after all. And if you use hats to hide uncooperative hair or to keep a low profile, the turban is not a smart choice.

headline: A New Canvas Store in SoHo
text: Andrew Corrie, a British ex-banker, introduced Canvas two years ago as a collection of furnishings with the tag line “Simple Sustainable Style.” Since then, what began as a hobby inspired by serving on the board of the nonprofit group Aid to Artisans has grown into a proper brand with more than 300 products artfully showcased in its first store.

headline: The Egle Table Lamp From Artemide
text: The new Egle table lamp can multitask: the diffuser rotates 300 degrees, and the stem rotates vertically and horizontally. The base, which is slightly concave, doubles as a reflector and a jewelry tray. The 10-watt LED bulb, which throws out a circle of light some two feet in diameter, provides both direct light and — if you aim the diffuser so the light reflects off the base — an ambient glow.

headline: The Hazel Effect
text: THE street addresses of my life, and there have been a great number of them, have often felt less like home to me than the places I’ve written about. The New Canaan, Conn., of 1973, when I was writing about it in the early ’90s. The Arizona of the near future, in a recent novel. I love landscapes of the imagination, less so the topographies of the so-called real world. And I suspect that’s the case with many writers of fiction.

headline: Sales at Alessi, Waterworks, John Robshaw and Others
text: On Nov. 11 only, Alessi will mark down all items in its stores 20 percent (a Michael Graves tea kettle, regularly $175, is $140); 130 Greene Street (Prince Street), (212) 941-7300, and 30 East 60th Street (Madison Avenue), (212) 317-9880, alessi.com.

headline: Patrick Jouin on Reconciling Functionality With Aesthetics
text: Patrick Jouin, the Paris-based designer, has a diverse portfolio that includes hotels, lamps and space age-like furniture made with a process known as “selective laser sintering.” And a surprising number of his projects are food-related — restaurant interiors for Alain Ducasse, a pasta pot and cutting board for Alessi, flatware for Puiforcat, a special spreader for Nutella, and a Champagne bucket and saber for Mumm, to name a few. Many of these objects are now on display in Manhattan, at the Museum of Arts and Design, in “Patrick Jouin: Design and Gesture,” an exhibition that runs through Feb. 6.

headline: A Final Cocoon: Dying at Home
text: THERE is some confusion about the cause of the liver disease that has given Fred Kress a short time to live. The 46-year-old handyman and house painter, who lives outside of Baltimore, had had hepatitis C, which causes liver damage, for several years. Doctors at one point suggested that alcohol abuse may have been a contributing factor, which makes no sense, Mr. Kress and his family say, because he was never much of a drinker. The real culprit, he now believes, was chemical: he didn’t wear the right mask when he was painting houses, and when he did his craft projects, making alien masks out of fiberglass resin, he worked in a small, windowless room, ignoring all the warning labels on the supplies he used.

headline: A Barter Network for Designers on a Budget
text: After a year’s trial period, OurGoods.org, an online barter network for designers and artists in New York City, is open to the public. The site promotes the swapping of skills, space, labor and art objects; designers on a budget will find an expanding list of offerings, including custom wallpaper, vintage fabrics and lessons in soap making and upholstery.

headline: Plant Experts’ Picks for Hardy Indoor Plants
text: Houseplants for shady windows, dry winters and inept gardeners.

headline: Hard to Kill: Houseplants for the Inept
text: FOR years now, my foyer has been a halfway house for indoor plants  that is, halfway between a cozy berth in someone else’s home and a pauper’s grave in my backyard.

headline: Drug Suits Raise Questions for Doctors, and Juries
text: Judith Graves, a 67-year-old retired investigator for the United States Army, developed a rare medical condition called jawbone death after taking Fosamax, a drug used by millions of American women with thinning bones.

headline: Shopping With Nancy Fitzpatrick
text: The owner of the historic Red Lion Inn in Stockbridge, Mass., picked out furnishings for guest rooms with a distinctive sense of style.

headline: Walter Isard, Economist Who Studied How Regions Evolve, Dies at 91
text: Walter Isard, an economist who founded the field of regional science, inspiring social scientists to study the relationships between such factors as geography, migration and land use in local or regional economies, died on Saturday at his home in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 91.

headline: Gleeful Gore at Players Theater
text: When you see a good show, you like to come away with a keepsake: the ticket stub, the program, perhaps a T-shirt purchased in the lobby. The people behind “Play Dead” apparently know this, because they make every effort to send you home with a fellow audience member’s entrails stuck in your hair or lodged in your tote bag.

headline: Guest Room Furnishings
text: AS the owner of the historic Red Lion Inn in Stockbridge, Mass., and a developer of the Porches Inn in North Adams, Mass., Nancy Fitzpatrick has spent plenty of time designing and renovating guest rooms.

headline: A Titan of Business? Just Call Him Coach
text: Joe Moglia became the head coach of the expansion Virginia Destroyers of the two-year-old United Football League on Wednesday  his first coaching job in 27 years.

headline: FedEx’s Chief on the Payoff of Corporate Giving
text: Frederick W. Smith, chairman and chief executive of FedEx, doesn’t publicize his own giving much, but enthusiastically supports his company’s efforts, which he said in an interview pay dividends in many ways.

headline: Sprint Gets an iPhone, Sort Of
text: Update: Added calculations regarding the amount of data per minute was used when placing an VoIP call.Thanks to the wonder that is Voice over Internet Protocol, better known as VoIP, people have long been able to make phone calls from computers or, say, an iPod Touch.

headline: Raise High the Bridge Beam for a House in Spain
text: Las Matas, Spain

headline: U.S. Blocks Iran’s Bid for a U.N. Board Seat
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United States orchestrated the defeat of Iran’s push to gain a seat Wednesday on the board of the new United Nations organization dedicated to gender equality around the world, in keeping with the broader American strategy to isolate Iran.

headline: In Case of Disaster, Carriers Stand Ready to Airlift Aid
text: WAYNE YANKOVICH was at his home in Indianapolis on his day off when he heard that an earthquake had just struck Haiti. His wife, Louise, was downstairs watching CNN and immediately relayed the news.

headline: The Special Pain of a Slow Disaster
text: THE water came slowly, masking its power with sluggishness. But Farooq Tariq, a human rights activist long accustomed to helping hapless civilians through Pakistani disasters, knew it meant trouble.

headline: Knicks’ Walsh to Have Surgery
text: 8:53 p.m. | Updated Donnie Walsh, the Knicks’ president, said he would have hip-replacement surgery next week and would return to the team as quickly as possible. Walsh, 69, has relied first on a wheelchair and then a walker since undergoing neck surgery in June to remove bone spurs.

headline: Italian Studies Regains Spot on the List of AP Courses
text: The Advanced Placement Italian Language and Culture program  which began in 2005 and was suspended last year because too few students were participating in it to warrant the cost  will be reinstated next year, and its AP exam will again be offered in May 2012.

headline: Promising Catcher Appears Ready for Pinstripes
text: The Yankees gave $2 million to Jesus Montero in July 2006, outbidding the Mets, the Boston Red Sox and the Cleveland Indians. Their investment got them a stocky 16-year-old hitting prodigy from Venezuela and the belief that they had signed their next great catcher.

headline: Trading Up: Military Jackets
text: Military jackets recombine elements of various archetypes to create subtly masculine coats with a bit of brass-button flair that are anything but standard issue.

headline: Ex-KB Home Chief Receives Probation
text: Bruce E. Karatz, a former chief executive at KB Home, was sentenced on Wednesday to five years of probation after he was convicted in April of hiding from auditors and regulators that he had backdated stock options.

headline: Morgan’s (Brief) Response to ESPN’s Move
text: Joe Morgan’s first comment since ESPN declined to renew his contract with “Sunday Night Baseball” this week was short and succinct.

headline: Standard Issue: Just High Military Style
text: IT’S no secret that former soldiers often feel that their years of service go unsung — even today, on a day dedicated to veterans. But our men and women in uniform get an indirect homage every day of the year, given the undisputed sway the military holds in one realm: the wardrobe. From brass-buttoned blazers and A-2 leather bomber jackets to khaki trousers and camouflage cargo pants, it has bestowed more clothing styles on the civilian closet than any other walk of life.

headline: The Haggling Begins for Troubled Assets
text: It is the biggest rummage sale in Wall Street history — what one investment company calls “the Great Liquidation.”

headline: A Butcher Who Lacks a Killer Instinct
text: John McFadden Jr. jokes that his fate was sealed when he was born the same year his father bought Staubitz Market, a butcher shop in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that was established in 1917. Mr. McFadden, 43, got his start in the family business at age 10, sweeping up blood-soaked sawdust (the traditional butcher-shop floor covering). Now co-owner with his father, 74, he lives a few blocks from the shop with his wife, Christine Kim, 44, and their son, Aidan, 5, in Carroll Gardens and has a woodworking shop upstate.

headline: Trial of 2nd Man Will Revisit the Horror of a Triple Murder
text: Connecticut is catching its collective breath after the diet of appalling details that spilled out daily from the trial of Steven J. Hayes, who got the death penalty on Monday for his role in the Cheshire home invasion that left a woman and her two daughters dead.

headline: Economic Crisis Sidelines Fate of the World’s Poorest
text: WASHINGTON  Last year, after a personal appeal from President Obama in which he cited his own family’s experiences in Kenya, world leaders gathered at the Italian hill town of L’Aquila pledged $20 billion over three years to help millions of the world’s poorest farmers grow enough food to feed themselves  a “landmark achievement” organizers said in a report.

headline: No Room in This Town for Change Brought by an Inn
text: SALISBURY, Conn.

headline: Disclosure Runs Into 140-Character Limits
text: If you bought Yoplait yogurt recently, you may have noticed more than the usual nutritional data on the container. Those with pink lids bore the slogan “Save Lids to Save Lives” and a promise to donate 10 cents for each lid sent in, up to $1.6 million, to Susan G. Komen for the Cure, an organization that supports breast cancer research.

headline: U.S. Struggles to Restore Middle East Talks
text: WASHINGTON  With tensions between the United States and Israel flaring again over Jewish settlements, the Obama administration and its allies worked feverishly on multiple fronts Wednesday to put Middle East peace talks back on track.

headline: Monopoly by Marc Jacobs
text: MARC JACOBS is the Michael Bloomberg of the West Village and also its Sam Walton. Jane Jacobs would have loved him, if she wasn’t overcome by conniptions at his oozing influence over her beloved neighborhood streets. He is a colonialist, an extender of brands, and in very good shape.

headline: At Some Nail Salons, Feeling Pretty and Green
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The bottles of nail polish at the Nova Nail Spa include Sky Sparkle blue, Hot Blooded pink and I Feel The Earth Move brown. But the predominant color at Kim Pham’s chic salon is health-conscious green.

headline: New Yorkers From Mexico Escorted Miner in Race
text: Millions of people around the city and the world watched and cheered Edison Peña as he ran in the New York City Marathon on Sunday.

headline: Pledge to Give Away Fortunes Stirs Debate
text: WITHOUT a doubt, the biggest event in philanthropy this year was the Giving Pledge, a commitment by 40 of the wealthiest Americans to give away at least half of their fortunes, about $600 billion.

headline: Jefferson’s Army of Nation Builders
text: Swarthmore, Pa.

headline: A Bonanza of Riches for Bank Rescuers
Quintin Dailey, Gifted but Troubled Player, Dies at 49
text: Quintin Dailey, a talented but troubled basketball player whose missteps, including a sexual assault conviction, contributed to the University of San Francisco’s decision to drop its storied basketball program for three years, died Monday in Las Vegas. He was 49.

headline: As Donors Retrench, Challenges for Universities
text: AS the stock market soared for two decades, college and university endowments swelled with gifts. Over the last 10 years, contributions to higher education have risen an average of 4.1 percent a year, despite the downturn.

headline: Cooking and Shopping With Mom and Dad
text: Four lessons from South Florida, where I spent part of last week helping my parents get settled. (They spend the winter there.) We were together two nights, and I opted to cook.

headline: With New Coach, Cowboys Hope to Stop Their Free Fall
text: IRVING, Tex.  Two days after firing its coach, America’s favorite 1-7 football team returned to practice, which meant the Dallas Cowboys returned to their crazy version of normal, which meant the circus returned to Valley Ranch. Around here, they call that Wednesday.

headline: What Everything Means
text: I can’t stop thinking about the elections. Last weekend I saw “127 Hours,” and all I could think about was that this was a metaphor for the lame-duck session of Congress.

headline: Pooling Small Contributions, Hoping for Big Results
text: IT was just about a year ago that Kelsey Warner had a chance to help save someone’s life.

headline: The Rich Are Different From You and Me. They Give More.
text: AT the top of the economic ladder, many Americans are generous with their wealth and time, supporting efforts to meet basic human needs, education, the arts, religion, the environment, animal welfare and more.

headline: Giving a Gift and Getting a Return
text: FOR retirees increasingly worried as interest rates on their savings accounts and money market funds have plunged below 1 percent, an appeal from their alma mater or a respected charity, offering a return of 5 percent or more on a charitable gift annuity, can seem like a rare opportunity.

headline: Charities Wrestle With Tax Uncertainty
text: A GROWING number of charities are persuading donors to create a little-known kind of endowment as the troubled economy and this year’s hiatus from the estate tax create problems for charities that depend on major lifetime gifts and on bequests.

headline: Looking for a Job? Try a Nonprofit
text: OVER the last few years, as corporations fired workers en masse, some of the newly unemployed began sending their résumés to nonprofits. But often the job picture there was just as bleak  even as the need for services became greater.

headline: Online Giving, One Person at a Time
text: SHORTLY after the devastating Typhoon Ondoy made landfall in the Philippines last year, Wendy Harman, social media director at the American Red Cross, noticed that her organization had hit the “trending topics” list on Twitter, a list of the social network’s most-discussed subjects. Thousands of people around the world were posting the Red Cross’s toll-free phone number and asking their friends to donate to the rescue effort.

headline: Boston Museum Grows by Casting a Wide Net
text: ABOUT four years ago, at the suggestion of a mutual friend, Ronald C. Wornick paid a call on Malcolm A. Rogers, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, looking for a home for the contemporary decorative art that he and his wife, Anita, collect.

headline: As Millions Seek Work, an Overhaul in Retraining
text: TALK to a displaced worker who has just finished a retraining program, and chances are you’re talking to someone who still doesn’t have a job.

headline: Helping Veterans Find Civilian Jobs
text: MANY veterans are finding that jobs in this difficult economy require skills and training they do not have. Government data shows a higher unemployment rate for recent veterans than for the general population.

headline: Foundations With a Limited Life
text: TRADITIONALLY people who set up private foundations — either during their lifetimes or through an estate plan — envisioned an entity that would carry on their philanthropy for generations. But lately, some founders or their immediate successors are spending their full endowments and closing down. Other donors are creating new foundations with a limited life span.

headline: Young Activists Practice Their Pitches for Nonprofits
text: THE recruits at boot camp are getting their final briefing before going into action.

headline: Fly-Fishing Group Offers an Escape From the Hospital
text: THE South Platte River in Colorado ran cold and clear that Sunday, clear enough even for Rhonda Carey to see the fish she was trying to catch. The wind was so strong, she recalled, that the volunteer who was helping her had to hold on to her hip-waders to keep her upright.

headline: Yahoo Hires a Time Inc. Ad Man
text: Yahoo has hired Wayne Powers, a former Time Inc. executive, to revive its slumping as sales business as its North American ad sales senior vice president.

headline: Women’s Group Cites 12 Districts in Title IX Complaint
text: A women’s legal group filed complaints Wednesday with the federal education department alleging that 12 school districts nationwide  including New York, Chicago and Houston  are violating federal law by failing to offer equal opportunities to boys and girls who play high school sports.

headline: Photo Sharing on the Go Is the Latest Hot Investment Niche in Silicon Valley
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In Silicon Valley, the three words on the tips of everyone’s tongues are mobile, social and local.

headline: H.P. to Pay $16 Million to Settle Suits
text: WASHINGTON  Hewlett-Packard has agreed to pay $16.25 million to the federal government to settle whistle-blower lawsuits alleging that contractors working for the company lavished meals and gifts, including yacht trips and Super Bowl tickets, on school district officials in Texas to win contracts for computer equipment.

headline: Would the South Really Leave?
Times Will Rank E-Book Best Sellers
text: In an acknowledgment of the growing sales and influence of digital publishing, The New York Times said on Wednesday that it would publish e-book best-seller lists in fiction and nonfiction beginning early next year.

headline: For Now, a Rebel Just Wants to Fit In
text: NASHVILLE

headline: Knicks and Fans Honor Lee on His Return
text: In five years as a Knick, David Lee became an elite rebounder, a skilled scorer, an All-Star and a fan favorite. But points came more easily than victories, so when Lee was asked, upon his return, to share his best moments, he was stumped.

headline: Telescope Is Behind Schedule and Over Budget, Panel Says

headline: Decision Near on Site of Terrorism Trial
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Wednesday that the Obama administration was “close to a decision” on a trial for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused of planning the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Mr. Holder’s remark to reporters prompted both Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York, to repeat their opposition to a 9/11 trial anywhere in New York State. Most Republicans have said the 9/11 defendants should be tried by a military commission at Guantánamo Bay; Democrats have been divided, with some asserting that a federal criminal trial is the right forum. Mr. Holder’s comments came as a federal jury in Manhattan began deliberations in the case of the first former Guantánamo detainee, Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani.

headline: Administration Asks Court to Let ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Law Stand
text: The Obama administration said the Supreme Court should let the military continue to bar openly gay and lesbian people under the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, arguing that a change in the law should come from Congress, not the courts. The acting United States solicitor general, Neal Katyal, the administration’s top courtroom lawyer, urged the justices on Wednesday not to reinstate a federal judge’s order that had temporarily suspended the law. Virginia A. Phillips, a federal judge, declared the law unconstitutional in September, and a Republican gay rights group is seeking to put that ruling into effect immediately. A federal appeals court put Judge Phillips’s order on hold.

headline: Lichtenstein Tops Warhol in Auction at Christie’s

headline: Russia: Journalist Is Convicted of Slander
text: A crusading Russian journalist who was crippled in a brutal beating two years ago was convicted on a criminal slander charge on Wednesday. Despite criticism from rights groups, prosecutors in a Moscow suburb, Khimki, had refused to drop the charge against the journalist, Mikhail Beketov. A judge found him guilty of slandering the Khimki mayor, Vladimir Strelchenko, by accusing him of involvement in blowing up Mr. Beketov’s car. Mr. Beketov was fined a nominal amount, which was then suspended. Mr. Beketov made the comments at issue well before he was beaten. No one has been arrested in that crime.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow Is Country-Stronger Than Expected
text: In case you missed Wednesday night’s broadcast of the Country Music Association Awards or Jon Caramanica’s take on the event in Thursday’s New York Times, here’s our brutally expedient wrap-up on the night: something something Miranda Lambert, yada yada yada Brad Paisley, blah blah blah Taylor Swift, et cetera et cetera Gwyneth Paltrow sang with Vince Gill. That’s correct: Ms. Paltrow, the Academy Award-winning actress and lifestyle guru, was backed up by Mr. Gill for a performance of “Country Strong,” the title track from a coming movie in which she plays a down-and-out country musician. Mr. Caramanica wrote that the surprise of Ms. Paltrow and Mr. Gill’s collaboration was “that she didn’t need his steadying hand nearly as much as some of the night’s other performers.” We’re in no position to judge because we’re still astounded her cover of “Bette Davis Eyes” charted in Australia, and that was 10 years ago.

headline: Maison Bellaish’s Home Away From Home
text: “On the store’s opening day Daria Werbowy stumbled in and fell in love with the collection,” said Victor Bellaish, the designer behind Maison Bellaish. “Who could ask for a better first customer?” Since its inception in 2006, the young Tel Aviv-based brand’s whimsical and romantic pieces were available by appointment only; but the recent opening of an outpost in New York’s Meatpacking district at 36 Little West 12th Street will change all of that. Silk dresses, blouses, and meticulously adorned made-to-order lace and crystal evening gowns come out of a nostalgic art-nouveau atelier within the minimally decorated boutique. “I am able to build more of a relationship with the Bellaish woman in an intimate salon,” said the designer, who is known for being on-hand to personally fit every client. “Maison Bellaish is home to the boundless woman. She doesn’t need to be trendy because she knows a beautiful fabric and a great shape.”

headline: Asked & Answered | Anna Sui
text: For three decades the designer Anna Sui has tickled a hard-nosed industry with unabashed imagination and the kind of fairytale twinkle that is straight out of childhood ballerina boxes and teenage diaries. At their most fanciful, her clothes summon a dream of fun-loving womanhood, of idols and heroines: Janis Joplin, Marie Antoinette and Marisa Berenson on the dance floor, all in a single collection. But reverie hardly explains Sui’s loved and labored métier. She started her eponymous collection in 1981 while working a day job, and opened her New York boutique in 1992 – the first of 300 sales outlets – just a year after her first runway show. Since 1997, Sui has also parlayed licensing deals in cosmetics, accessories and spin-off clothing lines that extend from Turkey to Japan. A new anthology published by Chronicle Books suggests that the lynchpin of her unique career is encyclopedic curiosity as much as commercial acumen, studied process and a deep respect for the techniques and traditions of her craft.

text: I’m not quite sure whom I’d call the odds-on favorite to capture the Republican presidential nomination in 2012. But I have a pretty good idea of who I’d bet against.

headline: Fewer Veterans to Honor on Their Day
text: The number of military veterans living in New York City has shrunk by one-third since 2000, according to the census. They now constitute just 3.6 percent of the population over 18 years old, compared with 5.7 percent a decade ago.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Teams With Syfy Channel
text: In a rare partnership for a Broadway show, the coming musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has struck a deal with Syfy, the “imagination based” cable outlet formerly known as the Sci-Fi Channel, to be the show’s lead media partner for television and Internet commercials, promotions and contests.

headline: Fox Business Network Hires Lou Dobbs
text: Showing a willingness once again to open its checkbook to lure big names, the Fox Business Network said on Wednesday that it had hired Lou Dobbs, the former CNN anchor, to head a daily program.

headline: Met Says Levine Is ‘Much Better’ After Illness Forces Withdrawal
text: James Levine, the music director of the Metropolitan Opera, withdrew from a performance of “Don Pasquale” at intermission Wednesday night because of a stomach virus, the Met said. Joseph Colaneri, an assistant conductor at the house, stepped in and led the final act. The Met said on Thursday that Mr. Levine, 67, was “much better” and planned to conduct the opera on Saturday, as scheduled. Mr. Levine has suffered a series of health problems in past years, most recently back trouble that resulted in spinal surgery in April. The problems have forced him to cancel many performances at the Met and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, where he is also music director.

headline: Madison Square Park, 10:50 A.M.
text: Luis Rosario, who was wounded in Vietnam, before the beginning of the Veterans Day parade.

headline: After Saying ‘Ciao,’ College Board Brings Back A.P. Italian
text: Next year, high school students will again have the opportunity to take the Advanced Placement Italian Language and Culture program, which was suspended last year, just four years after it began, because the level of interest did not, apparently, justify the cost.

headline: Stealing Mother Nature’s Thunder
text: HIROSHI SUGIMOTO is often venerated as a Zen master of film photography. But in “The Day After,” an exhibition that opened Nov. 6 at the Pace Gallery in Chelsea, he has assumed a new persona — that of a wild and visionary scientist.

headline: If They Can Make It Here
text: RICH BRILLIANT WILLING

headline: Grants Awarded for Preservation of New York Sites
text: Eight projects to save historic and culturally significant sites in New York City have been awarded grants by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced. The recipients include the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts in Manhattan, and the Louis Armstrong House Museum and the Free Synagogue of Flushing, both in Queens. The grants, which range from $2,000 to $10,000, were financed by Robert and Elizabeth Jeffe, longtime supporters of historic reservation. Ms. Jeffe is a board member at the trust.

headline: For Mayor of White Plains, a Trial and an Unclear Future
text: WHITE PLAINS  Most of the time, the talk around the coffee shops in this Westchester County city has more to do with work, family, weekend soccer games or where to shop or eat. In the past nine months, though, local politics have crept into the conversation, after a domestic violence scandal involving the mayor became public.

headline: Singer Undergoing Renovation
text: THE view from Josh Groban’s apartment, on a high floor of the Time Warner Center overlooking Central Park, invites description in a real estate agent’s breathless terms: stately, majestic, inspiring. Very Josh Groban, in other words, though this operatic crooner, who moved to New York from his native Los Angeles a couple of months ago, seemed to play down the parallel on a recent afternoon.

headline: Quote Unquote | Display of Affection
text: –Leigh Lezark tells The Telegraph how she redecorated to accommodate the gifts Karl Lagerfeld has given her. Maybe she uses the light bulb shoes as a lamp.

headline: Vermont Yankee Reactor Restarts
text: The Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, shut down on Sunday night because of a small leak of cooling water, reconnected to the New England grid at 5:18 Thursday morning.

headline: Mush From The Wimp
text: A bit of old history keeps running through my head these days. Maybe things like this and this explain it.

headline: Enter the Art Gallery at Your Own Risk
text: The New York City police have arrested 20 people on various charges related to trying to enter the abandoned subway station that is home to the formerly secret guerrilla exhibition of underground street art that was revealed to the public last month.

headline: No Changes Now in Rules for Web Access in Europe
text: BERLIN — Europe has sufficient legal safeguards in place to prevent the Continent’s telephone operators from selectively managing consumer access to the Internet and no new restrictions are needed, the European commissioner responsible for telecommunications said Thursday.

headline: Is Groupon Good for Small Businesses?
text: A few months ago, a Groupon coupon arrived in my in-box from Jeffrey’s Restaurant and Bar, a long-standing premier dining destination in Austin. My immediate reaction — after savoring the vision of bellying up to a half-priced plate of crispy oysters on yucca chips with habanero-honey aïoli — was, “Wow, will discounting be good for this brand?”

headline: Lamb and Rice Stuffed Cabbage
text: Mark Bittman rolls cabbage leaves with lamb and rice, and serves it with tomato sauce.

headline: French Minister Details Terror Cell
text: PARIS  One of five people arrested this week on suspicion of plans to commit acts of Islamic terror in France was “ready to die for the cause,” a top French official said late Wednesday.

headline: Coffee Cocktails
text: Images of coffee cocktail at the Randolph on Broome.

headline: Tipsy Diaries: Beans With Booze
text: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, explores how coffee and liquor mix at the Randolph in SoHo.

headline: Attention Sports Fans: N.H.L. Is Playing Hockey
text: We interrupt our regularly scheduled programming for an update on the N.H.L.  for those of you watching most major American networks, yes, the season started a month ago  and the absolutely riveting slow-speed pileup that is the New Jersey Devils.

headline: Greek Jobless Rate Hit Record High in August
text: Greece’s jobless rate rose to a record 12.2 percent in August, while the nation’s progress in reducing its deficit appeared to slow, government data showed Thursday.

headline: Red Rooster Harlem, Still Not Ready, Offers an ‘Amuse-Bouche’
text: “This isn’t even a preview, it’s an amuse-bouche,” Marcus Samuelsson said of a three-hour bash Wednesday night for 300 invited guests at Red Rooster Harlem, his coming restaurant on Lenox Avenue near West 125th Street. Though the $2 million, 100-seat Red Rooster was scheduled to open two months ago, its estimated time of arrival is now late November to early December, a spokesman for Mr. Samuelsson said. The party was “a chance to see how the space works,” Mr. Samuelsson said.

headline: Greater Firepower, Fewer Shots
text: There were about 29,000 police officers on the job in New York City in 1971, compared with the roughly 35,000 officers employed today. Officers in 1971 carried six-shot revolvers, not the sleek 16-shot semiautomatic pistols that hang from the waists of most of today’s officers.

headline: A Panel Discussion on the New York Taxi of Tomorrow
text: On Tuesday night, the Design Trust for Public Space sponsored a panel discussion about the future of the New York taxi at the Museum of the City of New York. The trust was also the sponsor of Taxi 07, which issued policy proposals about the taxi industry in New York and displayed eight concept vehicles at the New York auto show in 2007.

headline: Crippled Cruise Ship Reaches Shore
text: SAN DIEGO  They arrived at the dock just after 8 a.m., hanging off the balconies at every level, clapping and cheering, looking something like a boatload of refugees eager to debark in a prosperous land. Here, after all, they would be able to get hot showers, toilets that flush and fresh food.

headline: Aide’s Comments Cause Stir as White House Discusses Tax Strategy
text: 12:41 p.m. | Updated White House officials  met on Thursday morning with allies from several progressive organizations to discuss strategy for the battle over whether to extend the Bush-era income tax rates, and the session took on added interest after reports circulated that the administration might cave in to Republican demands on the issue.

headline: Seneca Seeks Proxy Fight at Dynegy
text: Seneca Capital, Dynegy’s largest shareholder and a staunch opponent of the energy company’s proposed $4.7 billion takeover by the Blackstone Group, on Thursday made good on its promise to mount a proxy fight against the company.

headline: Spiking Coffee, Opening Eyes
text: Is it supposed to snap you to attention or slide you deeper into your buzz? Help you wind down or get you wound up? I’ve never really understood spiked coffee. In hitching caffeine (a stimulant) to alcohol (a depressant), it strikes me as a curiously self-canceling experience. Like wearing sun block to a tanning parlor. Or eating a Krispy Kreme on an elliptical.

headline: IHT Luxury Conference | Christopher Bailey
text: In a conversation with Suzy Menkes, at the IHT luxury conference in London, Burberry’s Chief Creative Officer Christopher Bailey discusses staying relevant in the digital world, shoe malfunctions, and the philosophy behind the company’s signature trenchcoat.

headline: When Portland Picks at Top of Draft, the Law of the Land Is Murphy’s
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  Benjamin Rash purchased the custom-made Trail Blazers jersey specifically for the game on Nov. 4. It bore a cruel, David Stern-unapproved reminder of Portland’s past and a link to its present.

headline: If You Were Asked About Chancellor’s Job, Tell Us
text: In many ways and in many words, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said that his surprise choice of Cathleen P. Black for the new schools chancellor was a result of a wide-open search for the most qualified candidate.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Chicago Tribune: Vending-machine moguls are protesting after a new Food and Drug Administration report estimated that workers will have to spend 14 million hours per year to comply with new calorie-count sticker laws. – Glenn Collins

headline: Nets to Be Partners With Team in Springfield, Mass.
text: In another sign that the Nets’ new owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, is willing to pay to enhance the franchise’s infrastructure, the organization struck a deal to become the single affiliate partner with the N.B.A. Development League’s Springfield Armor.

headline: Stalled South Korea Trade Deal Is Setback for Obama
text: SEOUL, South Korea  From Seoul to Washington, business leaders, foreign policy analysts and diplomats were convinced that President Obama would wrap up a free trade accord during a meeting with President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea on Thursday.

headline: Play About Martin Luther King Now Aiming for Broadway Next Fall
text: The much-anticipated Broadway production of “The Mountaintop,” Katori Hall’s acclaimed play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the eve of his assassination, is now looking likely for fall 2011, with Samuel L. Jackson (“Pulp Fiction”) and Halle Berry (“Monster’s Ball”) poised to star, according to two executives involved in the production.

text: Updated | 9:03 p.m.

headline: Controversial Radio Host Declines D.C. Job
