headline: The Role of Experience in the F1 Title Showdown
text: I have been thinking for a while that Fernando Alonso probably has an advantage over Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel in the fight for the drivers’ title because Alonso has won it twice, and the other two are going for a first-time title.

headline: The Role of Experience in the F1 Title Showdown
text: I have been thinking for a while that Fernando Alonso probably has an advantage over Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel in the fight for the drivers’ title because Alonso has won it twice, and the other two are going for a first-time title.

headline: 2012 Debate Planning Begins
text: In a repeat of the last presidential election cycle, the Ronald ReaganPresidential Library and Museum is planning on hosting the firstRepublican primary debate of the 2012 cycle with NBC News andPolitico.

headline: Name This Cocktail
text: At the Randolph at Broome, a downtown bar whose proprietors are tracing a bold new frontier in coffee cocktails, there are five coffee cocktails, tapping such spirits as rum, bourbon, cognac and Cherry Heering, a liqueur. I write about these cocktails in the latest installment of the Tipsy Diaries.

headline: TimesCast | November 11, 2010
text: Iraq keeps Maliki in power; the debt commission and the White House on YouTube.

headline: Renaissance Hotels Starts Concert Series
text: Hotel perks usually come in the form of chocolates with turndown service, free Wi-Fi or a breakfast buffet. Now Marriott is offering a nontraditional perk: concerts.

headline: ‘Heroin Mill’ Raided on West 43rd, Authorities Say
text: The authorities called it a “mill,” conjuring images of journeymen cranking out their wares for market or sawing huge logs or elves making cookies, but for the word that preceded it: heroin.

headline: Theater Talkback: Thinking About ‘Gatsby’ After Seeing ‘Gatz’
text: I finally got Gatzed last weekend.

headline: Q&A: Adding Angkor to a Vietnam Bike Trip
text: I’m taking a two-week bike trip from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City (with some driving) in February. Is it feasible to add a trip to Angkor Wat from Hanoi (before the bike trip) or Ho Chi Minh City (at the end)?

headline: A TV Show for O’Donnell?
text: Is a television show next for Christine O’Donnell, the failed Republican Senatecandidate in Delaware?

headline: Wines of The Times: Cotes du Rhone
text: It is such a familiar wine, almost a synonym for a not-too-fancy French red. Yet few wines can match Côtes du Rhône in exemplifying the myriad changes that have transformed the French wine industry in the last 20 years.

headline: On Deficit Proposals, a Failure of Will and Not Ideas
text: Forgive me if my expectations are low that Congress will soon adopt any of the latest recommendations for getting the country’s fiscal house in order. But we’ve seen all these ideas before.

headline: In Vermont, Taking the Roads Less Traveled
text: WOODSTOCK, Vt. — The last time I left the safety of marked roads was in a desolate area of Baja California. My husband was at the wheel of a 4x4, and I was trying to hide my terror from our two schoolchildren as we scraped over rocks and teetered near cliffs. We hadn’t seen a soul in four hours, and we were lost. I was taking stock of the ice chips just in case. For me ever to try “jeeping” again, there had to be a powerful incentive.

headline: Madison Square Park, 11:20 A.M.
text: Joshua Berrios of the Air Force Reserves, waiting to march in the Veterans Day Parade.

headline: Ristretto | Roaster of the Year
text: If you go by conventional wisdom, coffee is to the Pacific Northwest and the foggier parts of Northern California what high school football is to Texas: they’re better at it because of coaching, culture and an advantageous gene pool. But anybody who follows coffee knows that the rest of the country has its share of talent. Just look at Conscious Coffees of Boulder, Colo., one of two roasters named Roaster of the Year last week.

headline: Doubts Rise on Bedbug-Sniffing Dogs
text: If any heroes have emerged in the bedbug epidemic sweeping households, movie theaters, retailers, schools, offices, you-name-it nationwide, it is surely bedbug-sniffing dogs.

headline: The Volt Recharges My Batteries
text: I’ve been fascinated by the Chevy Volt since the day I heard about the concept.

headline: Ariel Sharon to Be Moved Home
text: JERUSALEM  Ariel Sharon, who had a major stroke while prime minister of Israel nearly five years ago and has since been in a coma in a hospital room, is expected to be moved to his ranch in the Negev Desert in the coming days.

headline: MetLife to Stop Offering New Long-Term Care Policies
text: MetLife announced Thursday that it plans to discontinue the sale of new long-term care insurance coverage.

headline: Tangled Web of ‘Rubicon’ Unravels at AMC
text: Days after ordering a new season of its hit horror series “The Walking Dead” AMC has swung its scythe at another original drama, announcing on Thursday that it would not pick up more episodes of its conspiracy thriller “Rubicon.”

headline: Exploring Lenovo’s Pathway to the Future
text: With rivals Hewlett-Packard and Dell making headlines in the acquisitions market this year, the Chinese computer maker Lenovo reminded investors this week that it was also in the hunt.

headline: Fed Efforts to Revive Economy Find Critics
text: Can you remember when the Federal Reserve was above criticism? When politicians vied for Alan Greenspan’s favor and fell all over themselves praising his wisdom?

headline: Pogue’s Posts: The Volt Recharges My Batteries
text: On his blog, David Pogue tests out the Chevy Volt, which has fascinated him since the day he heard about the concept.

headline: Inzaghi’s Goal Poaching Days May Be Over
text: A week after Filippo Inzaghi scored twice in the Champions League against Real Madrid, setting three career scoring records, his season is over and his career in jeopardy. Inzaghi, a 37-year-old A.C. Milan forward, hurt his anterior cruciate ligament and damaged the meniscus in his left knee in his team’s 3-1 victory over Palermo on Wednesday.

headline: Inquiry Revived in Beating of Russian Editor
text: MOSCOW  Law enforcement authorities on Thursday unexpectedly reopened the investigation into the brutal beating of an outspoken newspaper editor whose case had come to symbolize the dangers facing journalists in Russia.

headline: ‘Simpsons’ Renewed by Fox for a 23rd Season
text: “The Simpsons” was renewed for another season on Fox on Thursday, allowing the animated series to surpass the 500-episode mark.

headline: The Morning Skate: The Kovalchoke
text: Sometime in the future, when the story of the Devils’ Ilya Kovalchuk era is written, this may be the signature moment…

headline: Karachi Counterterrorism Office Is Bombed
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  Armed attackers stormed a police compound in a heavily guarded quarter of central Karachi on Thursday night, detonating a car bomb in a direct strike at the government’s counterterrorism forces.

headline: How’s That Outdoorsy Stuff Working for Ya?
text: Sarah Palin says her new series on TLC is not a reality show, and she has a point. The show is not an outdoorsy version of celebrity-dysfunction shows like “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” or “The Hasselhoffs.”

headline: Drowning in a Sea of Health Complaints
text: The patient was a classic “worried-well” type of patient — a thin, 50-year-old educated woman with a long litany of nonspecific, unrelated complaints and tight worry lines carved into her face. She unfolded a sheet of paper on that Thursday morning in my office with a brisk snap, and my heart sank as I saw 30 lines of hand-printed concerns.

headline: Noah Takes Garnett Off Pedestal
text: It can be a disappointing truth: when you’re an adult, meeting a childhood idol can be a letdown. Your kid imagination made the athlete or performer out to be something that wasn’t grounded in reality.

headline: BBC Journalists Call Off Strike
text: BBC journalists have called off a strike scheduled for next week, saying on Thursday that management had agreed to meet with union leaders to try to resolve a dispute over proposed pension cuts.

headline: Open Books: Street View and Love Edition
text: Say what you will about the privacy concerns raised by Google Street View, it does provide one valuable service besides the ability to virtually visit Johannesburg: catching criminals in the act.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: For Cats, a Big Gulp With a Touch of the Tongue
text: It has taken four highly qualified engineers and a bunch of integral equations to figure it out, but we now know how cats drink. The answer is: very elegantly, and not at all the way you might suppose.

headline: Dallas Coach Hyndman Finds Success in the Pros
text: Schellas Hyndman spent 24 years as the men’s soccer coach at Southern Methodist University before jumping to the pro ranks as coach of F.C. Dallas in 2008. In three seasons with the Major League Soccer club, he transformed the perennial also-ran into a playoff team, the first time since 2007, and has Dallas on the verge of its first M.L.S. Cup appearance. On Thursday, those accomplishments were recognized when Hyndman was named the league’s coach of the year.

headline: British Politician Arrested for Twitter Joke
text: An English politician was arrested on Thursday for joking on Twitter that a columnist he disagreed with should be stoned to death.

headline: For ‘Rock Band,’ Final Gig at Viacom
text: 4:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: Dear FloFab: The Kitchen Dropped My Dinner
text: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Las Vegas Casinos Are a Last Bastion for Smokers
text: LAS VEGAS  The notice on the door to the hotel-casino was emphatic. “The Westin Casuarina is a Smoke Free Environment. Thank you for not smoking.” Just beyond, four people were hunched over slot machines the other afternoon, wisps of cigarette smoke swirling around them as they happily puffed away.

headline: Popcast: Shyne, Josh Groban and More
text: Whatever happened to Shyne, the rapper and former Sean Combs protégé who spent much of the last decade in prison? This week on Popcast, The Times’s music podcast, Dina Kraft, a reporter in Israel, talks about tracking Shyne to Jerusalem, where he has begun a new life as an Orthodox Jew.

headline: Cocoa Beach
text: Chocolate lovers will soon find plenty to satisfy their sweet tooth on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia. In December, the upscale British chocolatier Hotel Chocolat (which has a Stateside flagship on Boston’s Newbury Street) will make good on its name by opening a boutique resort on Rabot Estate, its 140-acre cocoa plantation in the shadow of the twin-peaked Pitons. The hotel will offer guests the full chocolate-making experience, including taking part in the cocoa harvest while learning about the company’s philanthropic program to benefit local farmers. ‘‘The idea is to let our customers have the same experience that we have every time we step onto the estate,’’ says Angus Thirlwell, who co-founded the company 17 years ago with Peter Harris. Should chocolate-making wear thin, guests, who stay in contemporary West Indian-style cottages, can also hike Gros Piton, embark on a fruit-tasting safari and dine on dishes like sautéed prawns with chocolate tapenade.

headline: Greenlight’s Target of Scorn: The Fed
text: David Einhorn, manager of the hedge fund Greenlight Capital.

headline: Miller’s Chances of Victory Dim as Alaska Senate Write-In Count Begins
text: Results from the first day of tallying write-in ballots in Alaska suggest that Senator Lisa Murkowski, who ran a write-in campaign after being defeated in the Republican primary by Joe Miller, is very likely to win another term.

headline: How Cats Lap
text: Scientists studied the physics of feline drinking.

headline: How Broken Must College Football Be to Fix It?
text: It is time for my annual foray into the lower depths of higher education  that is to say, the business of Bowl Championship Series football as perpetrated on or near centers of learning.

headline: A Slaughtered Tiger Tally
text: At least 1,069 tigers have been killed by poachers over the last decade, according to an analysis of seizures of tiger parts by Traffic International, a wildlife protection group based in Britain. Less than 3,500 tigers are thought to remain in the wild.

headline: Madison Avenue ‘Salutes’ Veterans
text: For years, retailers have marked Veterans Day with sales. Now, other types of consumer marketers are starting to sponsor advertising campaigns timed to the holiday.

headline: Cholera Spreads to the Haitian Capital
text: An outbreak that had been largely confined to the countryside has now begun to spread in the teeming capital filled with overcrowded, unsanitary earthquake survivor camps.

headline: When a Bedbug Find Is a Dog’s Main Meal Ticket
text: Bedbug-sniffing dogs have been lauded for their radar-like ability to detect bedbugs that are hidden from human sight. But there have been growing concerns about “false positives” — when a dog incorrectly signals that bedbug are present — within the pest-control industry, and from consumers, too.

headline: Defector Aided in Thwarting Russian Spies, Article Says
text: MOSCOW  A Russian newspaper reported Thursday that a senior official in Russia’s Foreign Intelligence Service had provided the information that enabled the United States to break up a ring of Russian sleeper spies in June.

headline: Death of a King; Cautious King Took Risks In Straddling Two Worlds
text: King Hussein of Jordan, who died yesterday at 63, successfully straddled two worlds in more than four tumultuous decades on the throne.

headline: Dow Jones Finishes Above 1,000
text: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,000 mark yesterday for the first time in history.

headline: Bradley Names U.S. Roster for South Africa Trip
text: United States Coach Bob Bradley announced his roster for the Americans’ friendly against South Africa in Cape Town later this month. He decided to give five players who have never before played for the national team an opportunity.

headline: Cooking Light’s No-Meat Thanksgiving Meal
text: As one of the most popular food magazines in the country, Cooking Light pays attention when readers start clamoring for a particular type of food. And lately, it seems, they’ve been asking for more vegetarian dishes.

headline: The Quiet Side of Being a Soldier’s Other Half
text: “WHY do movies always show dead people with their eyes closed?” asks my husband from the living room couch. We are halfway through “The Hurt Locker.”

headline: Japan’s Farmers Oppose Pacific Free-Trade Talks
text: IWAMIZAWA, Japan  Atsushi Kono considers it the gravest threat to his family’s farm in a century of rice-growing: a free-trade initiative that could dismantle Japan’s sky-high protective farming tariffs, finally opening up the country to cheap, foreign produce.

headline: With Pieces in Place, Rangers Still Need Overtime
text: If ever there were a game the Rangers were going to win, it was Thursday night’s.

headline: Bush Memoir Gives Short Shrift to His Pardon Record
text: WASHINGTON – Former President George W. Bush tucked a paragraph into his newly published memoir “Decision Points” about how he decided to handle a late flurry of pardon-seekers who used special access to the White House to press their cases:

headline: For Years a Constant, the Giants’ Line Is Now a Patchwork
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the upper left corner of his locker, center Shaun O’Hara has taped a yellowing newspaper photograph of the Giants’ offensive linemen sitting on the sideline, from left tackle to right tackle.

headline: Theater Listings: Nov. 12 — 18
text: Theater

headline: 'Elf' on Broadway
text: Sebastian Arcelus and cast members perform the number "Christmastown." (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Seeing Things | Doug Aitken’s “House”
text: The artist Doug Aitken has a lot going on: new pieces; the installation of an important early work; a new house; and the staging of an art/music happening for the upcoming benefit gala at The Museum of Contemporary Art, to name a few of his current projects. As he explains it, “a lot of directions in my work merged like a meteorite and created friction.”

headline: Taking a Dream for a Few Spins
text: I WAS the youngest of three and the only girl in a family in which football was king, so life itself was a contact sport. So it should be no surprise that I was drawn to kinder, gentler physical activities (and those that involved sparkly costumes). But when I asked to add figure skating to my list of weekly activities, my mother said no. She thought ballet, tap, jazz, gymnastics, violin lessons and Brownies were enough.

headline: House Tour: Nyack, N.Y.
text: HOW MUCH $695,000. Taxes: $17,663.

headline: From House of Tiffany, a Line of Pottery
text: Louis Comfort Tiffany promoted his leafy and floral ceramics with the same hyperbole that he used for his glass lampshades and windows. His ads described his pottery vases and lamp bases as “entirely different from anything heretofore shown.” He had such faith in their market potential that when hundreds of dollars’ worth of pots went wrong in the kiln one afternoon, “Mr. Tiffany is not discouraged and has gone at it again,” the staff designer Clara Driscoll wrote to her family in Ohio.

headline: Cuomo Names Transition Team
text: Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Thursday who would lead his formal transition efforts as well as the membership two committees of transition advisers, encompassing a wide cross-section of business, labor and political leaders.

headline: Ford’s Trick TracKey for the 2012 Mustang Boss 302
text: Ford says the idea behind the TracKey, an ignition key that alters the engine management system in the 2012 Mustang Boss 302 to turn it into a street-illegal racecar, came during an all-night brainstorming session between Mustang team members. I wonder how many Bond movies they watched that night.

headline: Schools Wary of Prep Powerhouses in Football
text: CLIFTON, N.J. — The fans in the home-team rooting section were stunned when visiting Don Bosco Prep called a timeout with about two minutes left in the first half in an attempt to regain possession of the football.

headline: Operation “Dragon Strike”
text: American soldiers are taking part in an operation to drive the Taliban from the southern part of Zhari District in Kandahar.

headline: Conan Ratings Slip, but He Leads in Younger Viewers
text: 3:50 p.m. | Updated On his third night as a cable star on TBS, Conan O’Brien saw his ratings slip again, but not as much as they had from night one to night two.

headline: A New Star in the Tablet Space
text: Surf the web, take photos and get app-happy with Samsung's Galaxy Tab. But please don't call it an iPad.

headline: Modern Minstrelsy: Exploring Racist Stereotypes in Literature and Life
text: Overview | What are the roots and legacy of minstrelsy and the Scottsboro Trials? How can stereotypes be used not only to reinforce a bias, but also to satirize that very bias? In this lesson, students learn about the minstrel tradition, consider how it echoes through stereotypes of African-Americans today and explore the legacy of black stereotypes and the Scottsboro Trials in popular culture, history and literature.

headline: A Slice of Life. Or Three!
text: Reading may be the cheapest way to travel this holiday. And you can plan a European excursion with the help of eight contemporary fiction writers at the New Literature From Europe festival, sponsored by the French Embassy in the United States. The festival begins on Tuesday with “Haunting the Present,” a reading by each of the authors, who include the French writer and film director Philippe Claudel (“I’ve Loved You So Long”) and, from Poland, Olga Tokarczuk (“Primeval and Other Times”). Panels and discussions continue on Wednesday and wrap up on Thursday with a second reading from each author in his or her native language, followed by a reception. (Times and locations vary: 212-439-1447, newlitfromeurope.com; free.)

headline: The Burger Wars Continue
text: Escalating Manhattan’s quality-burger wars, Schnipper’s has signed a lease in 1 Madison Avenue on the north side of East 23rd Street, virtually across the street from the original Shake Shack in Madison Square Park. Read more on Diner’s Journal »

headline: Help for Veterans’ Assisted Living Costs
text: With only a fraction of veterans using Veterans Affairs benefits and health care services, many senior veterans and their families may not be aware of a benefit that could cover some of the costs of living in an assisted living community.

headline: Facebook Chooses North Carolina for New Data Center
text: Following in the footsteps of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft, which are building ever-growing networks of data centers, Facebook said Thursday that it will build a new data center in Forest City, N.C. This will be the second data center that Facebook is building from the ground up. Its first center in Prineville, Ore., is under construction and is expected to open next year. Facebook also leases data center space — and in some cases entire data centers — in several other locations, including Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: Homegrown, With a World View
text: Young designers are now the focus of a New York City initiative to provide mentors and new retail concepts. Others are trying to save the garment district, where many factories have closed or laid off workers and raised prices. Fabric costs are up, especially for cotton, and just about everyone who deals with manufacturing in China knows you can’t get a minimum of anything: 1,000 blouses maybe, but not 100. Department stores threaten to cancel orders if a delivery is late. Meanwhile fast-fashion companies reap the rewards of being nimble and democratic while grabbing the ideas of others. Prestige labels hold on to their heritage. And consumers wonder: Where’s your app?

headline: Viewpoints: Wall St. After the Elections
text: The New York Times’s Joe Nocera and Andrew Ross Sorkin talk about the recent midterm elections, and what the result means for Wall Street. Will the Republican-controlled House of Representatives chip away at the financial reforms championed by the Obama White House?

headline: A Different Way to Cook Meat
text: My wife, Jackie, and I had something to celebrate a couple of weeks ago, which we did in part by going out to dinner at our favorite fancy restaurant, Jean Georges. The final course was loin of lamb with a crust of ground dried black trumpet mushrooms, and — apart from the fact that it was a terrific recipe, a version of which you can read in “Jean-Georges: Cooking at Home with a Four-Star Chef” by Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Mark Bittman — it was just so perfectly cooked: glistening bright red against the black of the coating, edge to edge, with no gray stratum near the outside. I was dazzled by the precision.

headline: Choosing a Headmaster, With a Lot of Care
text: The Ethical Culture Fieldston School announced on Wednesday that Damian J. Fernandez, an international relations scholar and top administrator at the State University of New York Purchase College, would become its new headmaster.

headline: Fill-In | Vice President Biden and ‘The Onion’
text: Fill in the blanks in this article about how the satirical newspaper The Onion writes about Vice President Biden. Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: They Must Be Giants
text: ‘If you think big,’’ says the tag line for the 1,000-acre Baha Mar resort about to break ground in the Bahamas, ‘‘think bigger.’’ Sound ridiculous in a recession? It’s more of a harbinger than you’d imagine, at least in the travel world: led by Las Vegas’s CityCenter and the Marina Bay Sands Singapore, a new wave of mega-scale complexes that were conceived during the boom have recently opened their doors, with several more in development, from the Alps to Abu Dhabi. ‘‘I think it’s the future,’’ says Andy Cohen, executive director of the architecture firm Gensler, which worked on CityCenter and has a similar mixed-use project brewing in Shanghai. ‘‘Whether it’s sports, entertainment or retail, the ability to have all that variety in one place is key. People want choice.’’

headline: If Mets Want Beltran to Waive Clause, He’ll Listen
text: Heading into the final season of his seven-year contract, Mets center fielder Carlos Beltran said on Thursday that he would listen to a request from the team to waive his no-trade clause.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from South Korea, Saudi Arabia and Russia .

headline: Mehldau Is a Jazzman In a Classical Mood
text: Brad Mehldau, a star in the jazz world, has lately been asserting himself in classical precincts as well. He has written song cycles for Renée Fleming and Anne Sofie von Otter, and both singers have recorded those works with Mr. Mehldau at the piano. His solo and ensemble recordings have touched on his classical leanings too. They show him grappling with formal notions of structure and thematic development, and seeking a balance between the precisely defined gestures of composed music and the freedom and spontaneity of improvisation.

headline: New Chancellor’s Political Donations Tell a Mixed Tale
text: She gave $1,000 to Senator John McCain when he ran for president in 2000. She donated $500 to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s Senate campaign in 2004. And, since 2003, she has poured $3,500 into the re-election bids of Representative Henry A. Waxman of California.

headline: In Kutna Hora, Near Prague, Contemporary Art Amid Medieval Charm
text: THE sun streamed down on the hilly, cobbled streets of the Czech town of Kutna Hora, but I didn’t feel its warmth. I was 130 feet underground in a dark, dripping, medieval mine shaft, clutching a 50-year-old hydroxide lamp. Ahead of me, my claustrophobic fiancé, Tod, identifiable by the gleam reflecting from his hard hat, navigated the narrow, chilly hand-carved passages.

headline: If You Go
text: By car, you can get from Prague to Kutna Hora in about an hour by driving east along the E50 and E65 highways. Trains run regularly from Prague’s Hlavni Nadrazi and Masarykovo Nadrazi, but the 97-koruna trip (about $5.40 at 18 Czech koruna to the dollar) can take under an hour or almost two depending on whether you catch the express.

headline: The Hair Box
text: Haircuts and shaves have been available at a storefront in SoHo for over 100 years, though the prices have gone up a bit.

headline: Arrest Made in Shooting Over Candy Bar
text: Tips to the Crime Stoppers hotline led to an arrest on murder charges in the Bronx Wednesday, the police said.

headline: Ancient Roman Shrine, Restored, Reopens to Public
text: ROME — The Temple of Venus and of Rome – once one of Rome’s most majestic shrines – reopened to the public on Thursday after a long restoration. “This temple has been both a school and course of study for many,” said Claudia Del Monte, who began working on the restoration 23 years ago and directed the project.

text: Pop

headline: On the Trail of Green Rocks
text: George E. Harlow, curator of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, has been studying jadeite for many years and has returned to the fault line that is the Motagua Valley in Guatemala. This is the first of two posts from Dr. Harlow.

text: Movies

headline: Media Matters Chief Says He Will Lunch with Murdoch
text: Who’s coming to lunch with Rupert Murdoch? It’s David Brock, the chief executive of Media Matters, which exists in large part to criticize Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation.

headline: A Straight Razor, a Warm Towel, a Fading Art
text: OUTSIDE the Hair Box, a green storefront rooted on Spring Street, the red, white and blue candy-striped pole was motionless. Inside, Georgiy Ibragimov, 50, draped a seersucker barber cloth over Michael Hirshoren, who had just eased into one of three worn leather chairs.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 12-18
text: Jazz

headline: Other Options for Puff Pastry
text: In my column on Wednesday, I wrote about the buttery joys of puff pastry, which is, along with butternut squash, Brussels sprouts, and newly picked Honeycrisp apples, one of my favorite autumn ingredients. I know what you’re thinking, and it’s true that technically puff pastry isn’t seasonal– you can buy it any time of the year. But if you’ve ever tried to roll out puff pastry in a humid New York summer, you’d understand my point. It’s best saved for sweater weather. So I like to do my bit for the seasonal cuisine movement by eating loads of puff pastry in the cooler months. Here are a few of my favorite ways to bake with puff pastry.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 12-18
text: Dance

headline: For Eloise’s Mother, Life Wasn’t All Dandelions
text: “I’ve discovered the secret of life,” Kay Thompson, the eccentric entertainer and “Eloise” author, once said. “A lot of hard work, a lot of sense of humor, a lot of joy and a lot of tra-la-la!”

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 12-18
text: Classical

headline: What We’re Reading: Bernanke, Unsung Hero
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Seeking Guidance on Dodd-Frank’s Diversity Clause
text: As Wall Street scrambles to comply with the regulations of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, one little-noticed provision has executives scratching their heads.

headline: Tumult and Triumph in Black and White
text: Too bad Fidel Castro cannot come to New York to see “Cuba in Revolution,” an intensely absorbing exhibition at the International Center of Photography. It would warm his heart and make him pine for the glory days of the late 1950s and early ’60s, when his tiny, swashbuckling band of soldier intellectuals overthrew the corrupt government of Fulgencio Batista and prevailed over the forces of corporate capitalism and organized crime. The improbable, undeniably stirring tale of the rise and triumph of the Fidelistas is told by 180 pictures made by 30 photojournalists, including native Cubans like Raúl Corrales and Alberto Korda and international stars like Henri Cartier-Bresson and Burt Glinn.

headline: Major Gift of Furniture to National Gallery of Art
text: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has been promised one of the most impressive collections of American furniture still in private hands, along with a group of Dutch old master paintings and watercolors by seminal American artists like Winslow Homer and Childe Hassam.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Unstoppable'
text: Tony Scott, the director of “Unstoppable,” discusses a sequence from his film.

headline: Amazon Under Attack for Sale of Pedophile Book
text: Whether they like it or not, most technology companies, including Apple, Google and Amazon, are no longer simply technology companies, but are also content creators and curators.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from South Korea and Saudi Arabia, and at Veterans Day commemorations.

headline: Native Son
text: On his first visit home to Taiwan since Michelle Obama catapulted his name into the fashion stratosphere, the designer Jason Wu was greeted by paparazzi, velvet ropes and tons of fans. Here, ‘‘the glory of Taiwan,’’ as Wu is now known in his birthplace, talks about his return to Taipei, where change is in the air but the old ways aren’t forgotten.

headline: Frank Bruni on Ippudo
text: The restaurant Ippudo is where many of New York’s most devoted fans of ramen, the Japanese noodle soup, practice their devotion.

headline: Iraqis on Political Deal: Meet the New Boss…
text: BAGHDAD — As Iraqi lawmakers moved fitfully toward seating a new government this week, reactions around the country were swift, emotional and — like everything else here — staunchly divided.

headline: Fleeting Liaisons and Missed Connections
text: The choreography of Eryc Taylor is sincere, well intentioned, earnest, inoffensive, old-fashioned, neat and forgettable. His hourlong program of five pieces on Wednesday at Joyce SoHo was called “Pushing Boundaries,” but it is hard to know what boundaries were being pushed here that were not pushed more memorably several decades ago.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 12-18
text: Art

headline: Playing the Renegade With Eroticism or Rage
text: Sanctified art movements aside, most artists worthy of the name are loners and renegades. They operate without licenses — or Ph.D.’s — striving to be themselves as only they can, as clearly and intensely as possible.

headline: Crack Open a Bud And Sway Existentially
text: “Four more years!” Joey Truman shouts at the beginning of “now and nowhere else,” a performance work by Iver Findlay and Marit Sandsmark. Mr. Truman is shirtless, wearing jeans and clutching a Budweiser, his bleached hair glistening. (He has just rubbed lotion in it.) In short, he doesn’t seem the type to care much about political rhetoric, yet he repeats the line several times; his body ripples in spasms. Loosely cupping his hands as if they were holding marbles, he quivers back and forth: a boxer’s moves, deconstructed.

headline: Google Presents New Image Ads to All Advertisers
text: Google‘s bread and butter has been search ads — the few lines of text that show up alongside search results that are based on the keywords that people search for. But for some advertisers, especially online retailers, those aren’t necessarily the best type of ads.

headline: Interview: Lena Dunham
text: Lena Dunham, the director, writer and star of "Tiny Furniture," discusses how she crafted the film.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 12-18
text: Around Town

headline: Viewpoints: Wall Street After Elections
text: Columnist Joe Nocera and DealBook Editor Andrew Ross Sorkin talk about what the recent election means for Wall Street and financial regulation.

headline: Doing the Loco-Motion, Somewhat Slowed Down
text: Lynda Carter, the onetime Wonder Woman, isn’t the first performer to lose her bearings in pursuit of that elusive quality known as hip. “Wicked Cool,” the misleading title of her new show, her third in four years at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, might be an effective headline in a fragrance ad  or not. But it doesn’t describe a program dominated by songs from the 1960s and ’70s or the busy arrangements for an overbearing pop quintet and two backup singers who threaten to drown her out.

headline: Spare Times: For Children for Nov. 12-18
text: ‘RAPTORS IN FLIGHT’

headline: Dominick Dunne’s Comfy Chair and a Jaguar Named Audrey
text: PERHAPS no life was more intensely scrutinized by Dominick Dunne, the gimlet-eyed chronicler of the rich and infamous, than his own. In the offices of his Connecticut and Manhattan homes, framed Vanity Fair and TV Guide articles edged up against portraits of him aside political and Hollywood bigwigs. Autographed books, inscribed by Truman Capote, Jackie Collins, Jimmy Carter and Andy Warhol  his signature sealed with a Campbell’s soup can  lined Dunne’s shelves. Even his furniture had tales to tell.

headline: Arctic Drilling Poses Untold Risks, Study Concludes
text: Now that the moratorium on deep-sea oil and gas drilling has been lifted by the Obama administration, the battle for the Arctic is heating up again.

headline: British Bankers, Your Employers Are Listening
text: Britain’s financial services watchdog isn’t kidding around when it comes to stamping out leaks and market abuse.

headline: As Complex as the Music She Plays
text: IT seems safe to predict that the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will play a run of concerts with the New York Philharmonic in 10 years or so, as she did in 2000 and as she is doing again this season, as artist in residence. After all, unless she were finally to act on occasional vague hints of an early retirement, Ms. Mutter, now 47, should still be at the height of her considerable powers.

headline: Girl Undefined: Post-College but Pre-Real World
text: Pitched unsteadily if shrewdly between honest self-reflection and squirmy narcissistic indulgence, the low-budget indie “Tiny Furniture” is one of the bigger itsy-bitsy movies to hit this year. It was written and directed by the newcomer Lena Dunham, who also plays the leading role of Aura, a recent college graduate who returns to her family’s TriBeCa loft and promptly tries to crawl back in the womb. What makes this womb without apparent view especially notable is that Ms. Dunham’s own mother, the artist Laurie Simmons, plays Aura’s mother, while her real sister, Grace, plays Aura’s on-screen sibling.

headline: ‘Driving Miss Daisy’ in Talks to Extend
text: The producers of one of Broadway’s biggest hit plays of the fall, “Driving Miss Daisy,” are talking to stars Vanessa Redgrave and James Earl Jones about continuing in the show through the spring rather than close on Jan. 29 as planned, according to people on the business side of the production. They said they expected resolution one way or another soon.

headline: Esprit de Corps at a Shelter for Veterans
text: On Thursday morning, Luis Crossman, 61, slipped his still-lean, 61-year-old body into a faded green jumpsuit and zipped it up. He pulled on his black army boots and put on his aviator shades and black cowboy hat. He tied a kerchief around his neck.

headline: E.U. Responds to Iran About Talks on Nuclear Program
text: BRUSSELS — Talks on Iran’s nuclear program moved a step closer Thursday as the European Union foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, agreed to one of two dates for discussions suggested by Tehran, a diplomat said, although Ms. Ashton proposed an alternative location.

headline: A Senator Secedes – Reluctantly
text: Charleston, S.C., Nov. 12, 1860

headline: Keeping Score: Viewing the N.B.A. Through a Statistical Lens
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: Where Hair Is King, Until It’s Cut
text: Outside the Hair Box, a green storefront rooted on Spring Street, the red, white and blue candy-striped pole was motionless. Inside, Georgiy Ibragimov, 50, draped a seersucker barber cloth over Michael Hirshoren, who had just eased into one of three worn leather chairs.

headline: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Identity
text: PHILADELPHIA  Not far from where the National Museum of American Jewish History is opening its new building on Friday for a weekend of celebrations, the Liberty Bell can be seen with its biblical inscription: “Proclaim liberty throughout all the land unto all the inhabitants thereof.” The balconies of this $150 million museum overlook Independence National Historical Park, where the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution were signed. The National Constitution Center is on the other end of the park, and next month, just across the mall, the President’s House  the executive mansion where George Washington and John Adams lived when Philadelphia served as the nation’s capital  will be the site of a museum, with a focus not just on liberty, but also on slavery.

headline: I Think I Can: Trying to Stop a Crazy Train Hurtling to Disaster
text: The picture book “Big Bigger and Biggest Trucks and Diggers” comes with what its publisher describes as “an action-packed 30-minute DVD so children can watch their favorite machines at work, digging, hauling, and dumping.” Although it clocks in at 68 minutes longer and features big trains instead of big trucks — along with a long-haul star in Denzel Washington — “Unstoppable,” the latest from Tony Scott, brings to mind those popular peewee entertainments that allow youngsters to explore the world of backhoes and soil compactors. Or as “Big Bigger and Biggest” promises, “the biggest machines in action!”

headline: Draw for 2011 Copa America
text: For the ninth time since it was first played, as the South American championship in 1916, Argentina will host the Copa América, July 1-24.

headline: Still Waiting: An Update on Still-Unresolved Races
text: Election Day was over a week ago, but there are still a number of unresolved contests around the country. By popular request, here’s a recap of where things stand. In almost every one of the races listed below, local officials have not finished – or have not started – counting absentee and provisional ballots.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Unstoppable’
text: Sugar puffs and potato flakes. Those were the two main ingredients the director Tony Scott used to simulate grain spraying out into the sky when a train is hit in a scene from his new film “Unstoppable.” Mr. Scott discusses some of the techniques he used to shoot the action sequence involving colliding trains, a helicopter and some harrowing stunt work. Read Manohla Dargis’s review of the film here.

headline: Checking Out, and Donating, Too
text: The customer swiped his loyalty card at the Safeway supermarket on Market Street in San Francisco last month, and a message appeared on the display: Care to make a donation to fight breast cancer today?

headline: The Controversial Whitney Museum
text: WHITHER the Whitney? Yes, it’s got a swell building designed by Renzo Piano under way in the meatpacking district, to be finished in 2015. But what about its structure at 75th and Madison, where Jacqueline Kennedy attended the ribbon-cutting in 1966? Ornery and menacing, it may be New York’s most bellicose work of architecture.

headline: Clyde Summers, Advocate of Labor Union Democracy, Is Dead at 91
text: Clyde W. Summers, a law professor who played a pivotal role in writing the 1959 federal law that guaranteed democratic rights to union members, died on Oct. 30 at a retirement home in Germantown, Pa. He was 91.

headline: Shooting to Top the Charts Again
text: The investor J. Christopher Flowers made billions by investing in Shinsei Bank of Japan, but it remains to be seen if he has made new deals to match that.

headline: Battle Lines Drawn Over Medicaid in Texas
text: A week after newly emboldened Republicans in the Texas Legislature floated a radical cost-saving proposal  opting out of the federal Medicaid program  health care experts, economists and think tanks are trying to determine just how serious they are, and if it would even be possible.

headline: Jewelry and Tableaus in the Same Tent
text: For the second year in a row the dependable design fair Modernism has teamed up with the younger Art20, giving visitors to the Park Avenue Armory a concentrated look at 20th-century art and design. The marriage of these two fairs has allowed both to ride out a difficult economy. It has also nudged painting and sculpture into close contact with furnishings, jewelry and decorative objects, producing a kind of friction that rarely occurs in museums.

headline: Questions in Joliet Area About Coal-Ash Threat
text: The blue house is small and weathered, but for Leon Bilbrew, it is his castle. His hunting dogs are in cages in the yard, and the walls inside his Joliet home are lined with pelts of beaver, albino raccoon and skunk that he has trapped. He keeps beehives and sells the honey at farmers markets.

headline: Week 10 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 10. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Pressure Under Grace
text: A relative of mine recently married a devoutly religious woman. Dinner at their home is preceded by holding hands and saying a short blessing. I get it: their place, their rules; no problem. But recently, at a restaurant, they grabbed their neighbors’ hands and waited for everyone to do the same  which we all uncomfortably did  then bowed their heads for a moment of silence. Could I have refused?

headline: Drawing Funny
text: This is the ninth in a series.

headline: Weimar Film: Shadows, Yes, but Also Light
text: German cinema of the Weimar years has given us some of the most famous images in film history: Cesare the somnambulist (Conrad Veidt) loping through the crooked alleys of “The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,” the proud hotel doorman (Emil Jannings) reduced to a quivering washroom attendant in “The Last Laugh,” the robot Maria (Brigitte Helm) coming to life circled by rising rings of electricity in “Metropolis.”

headline: 2 Tea Party Favorites Vie for Leadership Job
text: The new House leadership position that Republicans created just for freshman will likely inject a Tea Party voice into high-level decision-making as soon as the next Congress convenes.

headline: In West Chelsea, a High Line Boomlet
text: THE view of West Chelsea from the roof of 540 West 28th Street, a new condominium at 11th Avenue, prompts a somewhat irrational question: what housing crash?

headline: The Dancers Still Kick, the Soldiers Still Topple
text: The enduring success of the “Radio City Christmas Spectacular,” high-kicking for 78 years, is partly from the appeal of women’s legs. Obviously. The palatial Art Deco theater also adds crucial glamour. Then there’s the benefit of having both Santa and the baby Jesus onstage, the most commercially viable double act since Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick.

headline: Margarito and Camp Apologize to Trainer
text: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  For months, Antonio Margarito talked about how his fight Saturday against Manny Pacquiao would help restore his reputation. Instead, his sullied reputation took another hit this week.

headline: Earl G. Graves Lists Scarsdale Estate
text: NOT long after the August 40th-anniversary celebration for his pioneering magazine, Black Enterprise, Earl G. Graves, one of the country’s most prominent black businessmen, has listed his 21-room colonial home on five acres in Scarsdale, N.Y., for $11.5 million.

headline: In Chengdu, China, Remaking Sichuan Food
text: IN a private room in a mysterious little restaurant in Chengdu, my fellow diners goaded me to eat the turtle. It was soft-shelled, they said — as if that made it more enticing. They laughed and joked in Chinese, which I do not speak. Eating turtle grows a man’s bank account, my translator said. I didn’t get the meaning at first. Then it sunk in.

headline: A Culinary Awakening in Chengdu
text: In the belly of Sichuan, a new food scene is growing.

headline: Global Warming and Common Sense
text: “People are going to die,” pipes a child’s voice at the beginning of “Cool It,” Ondi Timoner’s cacophonous portrait of the Danish economist Bjorn Lomborg, whose 2001 book, “The Skeptical Environmentalist,” earned him the ire of the green movement and an accusation of scientific dishonesty. That accusation didn’t stick, but Mr. Lomborg’s reputation as a global-warming denier has been tougher to shake off.

headline: On the West Side, New Condos with an Old Look
text: GREGG WOLPERT, the developer of a new 76-unit condominium on the Upper West Side called the Laureate, did not have to look far to come up with a style for the building. He says he merely had to glance out his bedroom window in the Apple Bank at Broadway and 73rd Street.

headline: Sprawling Cinema, Tamed to a Stage
text: Were it not for the gorgeous costumes — sweeping silken kimonos and samurai armor made of glistening black patent leather — Ping Chong’s “Throne of Blood,” a new production from the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, would be as boring to look at as it is to listen to.

headline: Fehr Sets Meeting With the Canucks
text: Donald Fehr was scheduled to meet with the Vancouver Canucks players on Friday, the last of 30 meetings he is conducting with the players of every N.H.L. team ahead of their vote on whether to approve him as executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association.

headline: Web
text: The origins of our Webified age were hardly auspicious. Two decades ago, Tim Berners-Lee, a British software programmer at the CERN physics-research laboratory outside Geneva, was sketching out a global system for sharing information over the Internet. A March 1989 document that he drafted with the drab title “Information Management: A Proposal” had met with minimal internal interest. Berners-Lee’s group leader, Mike Sendall, was mildly intrigued and allowed him to keep tinkering on the project, calling it “vague, but exciting.”

headline: A People’s History
text: More photos from the National Museum of American Jewish History.

headline: Assertive Chinese Held in Mental Wards
text: LOUHE, China — Xu Lindong, a poor village farmer with close-cropped hair and a fourth-grade education, knew nothing but decades of backbreaking labor. Even at age 50, the rope of muscles on his arms bespoke a lifetime of hard plowing and harvesting in the fields of his native Henan Province.

headline: The (Un)Making of an Art World Satirist
text: “Modern art is a con. I am the world’s greatest con artist.”

headline: 36 Hours in Seoul
text: HASTILY rebuilt after the Korean War, Seoul is shedding its once-gritty image to become one of Asia’s most glittering metropolises. Under its design-obsessed mayor, Oh Se-hoon, the city has been spiffed up with everything from sleek bus shelters to decked-out bridges. What’s more, it was named this year’s World Design Capital by an international design alliance. But that’s just the beginning. Seoul has a booming contemporary art scene, fashionable stores throughout the urban landscape, and a thriving pop and youth culture that now rivals that of other Asian capitals like Tokyo.

headline: A Weekend in Seoul
text: Hastily rebuilt after the Korean War, Seoul is shedding its once-gritty image to become one of Asia’s most glittering metropolises.

headline: Even After 30 Years, the Film of the Moment
text: When it was first shown in the United States in 1980, Jean-Luc Godard’s “Every Man for Himself” was greeted as a new beginning for a filmmaker who had spent the last decade exploring the foreign land known as video. Mr. Godard himself, who as a young man had worked in the Paris publicity department of 20th Century Fox, helped pave the way for his return to cinema with a big promotional push for what he called his “second first film.” The first (feature) was of course “Breathless.”

headline: A New Look at the Horrors in Rwanda
text: “Shake Hands With the Devil,” Roger Spottiswoode’s plodding dramatization of the mass slaughter in Rwanda, is not to be confused with Peter Raymont’s superb, similarly titled documentary.

headline: Renegade Painters
text: A look at new exhibitions of works by William N. Copley and Peter Saul.

headline: Netanyahu and Clinton in Extended Talks on Mideast
text: WASHINGTON  In a marathon day of meetings in New York on Thursday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton worked to salvage peace negotiations that stalled last month over Israel’s refusal to extend a freeze on settlement construction in the West Bank.

headline: ‘Radio City Christmas Spectacular’
text: Scenes from the 2010 production.

headline: J. R. Ewing Shot Down Communism in Estonia
text: Imagine growing up in the Estonian capital city, Tallinn, during the cold war and discovering “Dallas” transmitted by television from Helsinki across the Gulf of Finland. Life in the 1970s was drab in Estonia, then a Soviet republic under the thumb of Moscow.

headline: Yes, There’s a Shortfall; That’s the Starting Point
text: How big is the state’s budget shortfall? It depends on who’s doing the math.

headline: Romantic Dissatisfaction and Career Frustration
text: Plumbing yuppie fears may not be your first choice of an evening’s entertainment, but “Helena From the Wedding” has a little more to offer than many films of its type. Among its achievements is the kind of comfortable, shaded acting we expect from seasoned professionals and a script (by the director, Joseph Infantolino) that almost scarily captures the cadences of whining white privilege.

headline: Past Lives Wrapped in Mystery, Present Ones in Limbo
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Selling Ford Around the World, From Detroit
text: THE senior creative executive at Team Detroit, the consortium of WPP units that works on the Ford Motor account in North America, is getting a new role with a worldwide focus.

headline: Cultures United to Honor Separatism
text: Corte, France

headline: ESPN Baseball’s Inevitable Change
text: In early 2002, when the John Madden-Pat Summerall team called its final N.F.L. game together, they celebrated and reminisced about a 21-season partnership that began at CBS and ended at Fox. Madden was off to ABC’s “Monday Night Football” and Summerall stayed at Fox for one more full season.

headline: The Logistician of the Holocaust

headline: A Republican for Higher Taxes

The former boy-wonder budget director in the first Reagan administration and the architect of Reagan’s supply-side economic policies, Stockman has been very busy lately rejecting the tax-cutting recommendations of Republicans in Washington and arguing that we must get our fiscal house in order or watch our way of life continue its decline. As an “imperialist power,” he says, America is in danger of being at “sundown.” Stockman, who turned 64 on Wednesday, has always been ahead of the curve on tax and fiscal issues, and it appears that he is ahead of it again this time, too.

headline: Congo Republic: Amid Polio Outbreak, Groups Begin Immunization Campaign
text: International aid organizations said Thursday that they were starting a campaign to immunize three million people in three countries to fight a new outbreak of polio. The service organization Rotary International said it would give Unicef and the World Health Organization $500,000 total for the campaign, set to begin Friday in Pointe Noire, a coastal city where about 100 people have died in an outbreak that appears to have an unusually high mortality rate. From there, they will spread out to the rest of the country, neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo and Angola, with the goal of vaccinating three million people of all ages by year’s end. Normally, polio drops are given only to small children, but many teenagers and adults in central Africa are unprotected.

headline: The Resilient Brain
text: Those whose familiarity with Oliver Sacks extends only to his vivid book titles — “The Island of the Color­blind,” “An Anthropologist on Mars,” “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat” — may picture his writing as a gallery of grotesques, a parade of the exotically impaired. Sacks, a practicing neurologist, does specialize in case studies of highly unusual patients. But even as he entertains and diverts with his dramatic tales, Sacks has always been up to something else: he is gently educating us about the frailties and flaws — and the strengths and capacities — of “normal” people, those whose afflictions are of the most ordinary sort. You may never have confused your spouse for an item of outerwear, but have you ever failed to recognize the face of an acquaintance? Fumbled for a word that eluded your grasp? Read a sentence three times and still didn’t get it?

headline: Tip of the Week: Locking Up Your Screen
text: Need to step away from your computer for a few minutes and don’t want anybody snooping around your screen? In most recent versions of Windows, you can just press the Windows key and the L key to quickly put up the login screen — which will not go away until the computer’s password is entered. Once you type in the password, the login screen goes away and Windows picks up right where you left off with your open files and programs.

But put him on a stage with a piano, the Roots and the rapper Biz Markie, as “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” did on Thursday, and what you get is a cover of the Biz’s “Just a Friend” that isn’t cynical or satirical, just exuberant and fun. headline: Post-Tea-Party Nation
text: Republicans lost the presidency in 2008 in large part because of the worst economic crisis since World War II. Republicans have now regained the House of Representatives for the same reason. In the interval, Republicans ferociously attacked the Obama administration’s economic remedies, and there certainly was a lot to attack. But the impulse to attack, it must be recognized, was based on more than ideology; it also served important psychological imperatives. Not since Jimmy Carter handed the office to Ronald Reagan — arguably not since Herbert Hoover yielded to Franklin Roosevelt — had a president of one party bequeathed a successor from another party so utter an economic disaster as George W. Bush bequeathed to Barack Obama. And while the Bush administration took wise and bold steps to correct the disaster, the unpopularity of its Troubled Asset Relief Program bequeathed the Obama administration a political disaster alongside the economic disaster.

headline: Housewives of God
text: Priscilla Shirer’s marriage appears to be just the sort of enlightened partnership that would make feminists cheer. On an average morning in their house in suburban Dallas, Shirer and her husband, Jerry, are up around 6:30, fixing breakfast for their three small boys. While Priscilla, 35, settles in to work at home and care for their 2-year-old, Jerry, 42, shuttles the older two children to school and heads to his office. He spends much of the day negotiating her speaking invitations and her book contracts. In the afternoon it’s often Jerry who collects the boys from school. Back home, Priscilla and Jerry divide chores and child care equally. “He will most often jump in and do the dinner dishes,” Priscilla says. “We don’t have, ‘these are wife tasks and these are husband tasks.’ . . . Kids are not a wife-mommy thing.”

headline: The Most-Hated Son
text: Last winter, after more than three decades of silence, I desperately wanted to see my mother before it was too late. Not to make amends, really. I wanted to see her once and not be afraid. I had been courting her in recent years, sending flowers, fruit and candy for her birthday and holidays, asking to visit. She acknowledged my gifts with terse handwritten notes. She sent back the designer jelly beans with the scrawl “I prefer dark chocolate.” In the past, she ignored me completely, or her response ended with “you stupid idiot.” We were making progress. Yet she still refused to see me.

headline: Think About Pink
text: A friend of mine’s 12-year-old daughter has taken to wearing a bracelet, one of those rubber, Lance Armstrong-style affairs, that says on it, “I ❤ Boobies.”

headline: Walgreens Tackles ‘Food Deserts’
text: Among students of the contemporary metropolis, “food deserts” have become a widely known problem. The term is generally used to describe urban neighborhoods where there are few grocers selling fresh produce, but a cornucopia of fast-food places and convenience stores selling salty snacks (though, strictly speaking, the term can be applied to rural or suburban areas, too). Often the problem afflicts low-income areas abandoned or shunned by food businesses that focus on better-off consumers; the residents of food deserts, apparently, are not providing enough profit to be offered more healthful grub. These are places where the market for nutritious sustenance has essentially failed.

headline: Studies in Hyperreality
text: The rearview mirror looked odd, even ominous. It spread nearly a yard across the top of the taxi’s windshield.

headline: The Anti-Antibiotics Doctor
text: When my husband and I planned a trip to Machu Picchu and the Galapagos, tour leaders warned that medical facilities would be limited and advised us to bring any medicine we might need, including antibiotics. Although my husband frequently gets bronchial infections, his doctor refused to write a prescription for antibiotics, asserting that it was unethical to provide a medication to someone not actually ill. As it turned out, my husband developed pneumonia, and the trip was ruined. Was this doctor overly rigid? NAME WITHHELD, NEW JERSEY

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Midtown Goes Downtown
text: The new titles on the manga list this week all belong to VIZ Media and illustrate the diversity of their publishing line: a romance in “Otomen,” demon-slaying in “D.Gray-Man” and a slice-of-life story about trying to make it in the manga industry in “Bakuman.”

headline: Hameo
text: A hammy cameo.

headline: Letter: The Playboy and His Power Games
text: Chip Brown’s article about the New Jersey Nets’ owner, Mikhail Prokhorov, was fascinating, but it omitted a strand of the billionaire Russian’s life story that could have been illuminating. In addition to his roles in banking and industry, Prokhorov has been president of the Russian Biathlon Union for over two years, and he is credited with turning around a moribund organization tarnished by doping. It would have been interesting to read more about Prokhorov’s work in that sport, since the Nets seem to be in need of a similar reversal.

headline: As a Neighborhood Shifts, the Chain Stores Arrive
text: It was one thing when a Duane Reade opened last year in a new tower on the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But the resistance got vocal when a second one opened its doors last week  on Bedford Avenue, the throbbing heart of Williamsburg’s shopping district.

headline: A Review of ‘Cool It’
text: In Friday’s Times, our colleague Jeannette Catsoulis reviews “Cool It,” the new documentary about the Danish economist Bjorn Lomborg, whose 2001 book “The Skeptical Environmentalist” challenged mainstream thinking about the threats posed by global warming.

headline: Letter: The Cancer Sleeper Cell
text: I was transfixed reading Siddhartha Mukherjee’s article. I thought I was reading an account of my own daughter’s epic saga with cancer. Two years ago, two days before her 36th birthday, Rachel was given a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a rare soft-tissue cancer that can be associated with a cancer predisposition syndrome called Li-Fraumeni (L.F.S.). As in the case of the psychologist mentioned in the article, Rachel, too, had been nearly asymptomatic. Following an airplane trip from Philadelphia to Albuquerque, she had an edema in her legs that her internist attributed to long periods of sitting on planes. Initial tests revealed nothing unusual. When the edema persisted, more tests were ordered, and the CT scan showed Stage 4 cancer. We were told that her cancer could be “managed” but not cured.

headline: Letters: The New Momism
text: Momism may be a “clever strategy in a season of populist rage,” as quoted in the Judith Warner’s column. I get that. Michelle Obama and Sarah Palin, both overtly proud of being mothers and often using that status for political gain, have even more in common than the article implied. They both live with their children’s fathers, have adequate income, college education, power and advantage. The status they have achieved, regardless of how, is their common denominator. But at a time when America’s poor mothers are struggling to feed, educate and keep their children safe, sometimes without the support of a partner, being a mom elicits a whole different meaning for millions of women the article never mentions. Being a grizzly for them means fighting with the “welfare folks” who may have inadvertently canceled their food stamps; standing up to an absentee landlord when the heater breaks in the middle of winter; or figuring out how to manage a lottery system so her kid can get into the one decent magnet school in her city.

headline: Protecting Yourself From the Cost of Type 2 Diabetes
text: ONE in 10 Americans has diabetes, and if present trends continue, one in three will suffer from the disease by the year 2050, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Already this incurable, chronic and often debilitating illness costs the country’s health care system a staggering $174 billion a year.

headline: The Cost of Diabetes Care
text: Today’s Patient Money explores the various costs associated with diabetes as well as suggestions for how patients can save money on their care.

headline: Letter: Questions for Garry Wills
text: I question why Garry Wills would portray himself as “a grumpy old man” throughout his interview, saddening all of us who are well aware of his journalist’s eye for detail when he has written about others throughout the years. For those of us who have followed Wills, read his words, his books and his opinions, we would have hoped his responses would enlighten us. Sadly, he comes across as rude, lessening our estimation of the man.JOAN LARSEN Park Forest, Ill.

headline: Letters: Good News, Bad News
text: I was troubled by Rob Walker’s slipshod correlation in his otherwise fascinating examination of the Gap’s recent logo problems. In seeking to argue that the publicity generated by the logo might be good for the company’s sales, he cites a recent paper in Marketing Science that found that negative book reviews in The New York Times bolster obscure authors’ sales and hurt established authors’ sales. The bad publicity, the paper argues, serves to increase awareness of the book, which in turn fuels sales. Walker’s analogy with the Gap’s logo issues, however, is poor, and comparing apparel and books is a mismatched venture at best. In the analogy, Gap jeans are novels, but a more accurate publishing parallel would be an imprint redesigning its logo, something that most likely has never caused much of a stir outside of publishing house offices. Why? The Gap has builta brand on its logo, while books are judged one product at a time. Although his theories on publicity are interesting, Walker’s apples-and-oranges argument is a blatant attempt to place a scientific basis behind his theories on the Gap’s logo.

headline: Young Manhattanite Is a Beacon on the Blog Scene
text: ON THE SCREEN In a list on its home page, the group blog Young Manhattanite offers 13 definitions of itself, including “a random Tumblr page” and “blogging Illuminati.” Both are accurate, as is this: YM is a cipher of insider chatter. “It is like a nuclear launch code,” admits its founder and lead blogger, Andrew Krucoff.

headline: Letter: Creeper! Rando! Sketchball!
text: It was with great dismay that I read Ben Zimmer’s recent On Language column on the new wave of slang sweeping today’s college campuses. In particular, I was appalled when my last name — Rando — was associated with “unfamiliar, suspicious or anxiety-producing outsiders.” I have spent a good part of my life carefully concealing this fact from my friends and co-workers, building a sterling reputation as someone who can be trusted and embraced by society. My cover is now blown irrevocably. Yet I ask for no apologies and expect no sympathy. My only hope is that people around the world use this as a cautionary tale; slang is not something to be taken lightly.

headline: Letter: Funeral for a Friend
text: In regard to Virginia Heffernan’s Medium column, I also mourn the demise of the analog telephone, along with the etiquette and manners that went with it. The days when people were out in public and simply unavailable for phone calls seem like a long-ago dream. Today, you are subjected to everyone’s business, both private and professional, at all times and with little regard to the people around them. The greatest loss is that with e-mail and texting, you can’t hear someone’s voice, emotion and inflection in a conversation — definitely a step backward, not forward.

headline: Friday Reading: The Bedbug Detection Industry
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Letter: Cutting the Cord
text: I’ve heard countless stories of teens being insufferable on the eve of their college departure, butting heads with parents (especially moms). This is the first time I’ve heard of a mom instigating the trouble, and I applaud Renée Bacher’s Lives column for its honesty in the matter.

headline: Letter: The Art of Social Change
text: Kwame Anthony Appiah makes the wonderful point (Oct. 24) that if Westerners and Europeans were more culturally sensitive to local contexts and worked with villagers rather than “parachute in with Western values and ideas,” change might be better adapted to local needs. I’m glad Appiah uses foot binding in China as his chief positive example of change rather than female genital cutting (F.G.C.) — not “mutilation,” as your subtitle suggests. I remember being in Kenya in 1980 when women from that country came back from the U.N. conference on the status of women in Copenhagen, angered by Western women’s cultural insensitivity to what Kenyan (and other African) women viewed as their issue. Female circumcision is limited to northern Africa and along the eastern coast. It was rarely seen in central and southern Africa. It is time that The Times Magazine adopted the more appropriate term “cutting,” which both Appiah and Nicholas Kristof use in their articles, rather than the socially charged term “mutilation.” Times reporters have changed over the past 10 years and adopted F.G.C. as the operative term. It’s time the magazine followed suit.

headline: Letter: Questions for Melinda Gates
text: I kept waiting for Deborah Solomon (Oct. 24) to capture the essence of Melinda Gates: her deeply informed and joyful hands-on immersion in her philanthropies. Instead, Solomon’s tough and relevant questioning crossed over into the snarky and superficial. All the other remarkable aid workers written about in the same issue were treated with seriousness, without the apparent bias of being seen through a prism of immense wealth. I was very sad to see Melinda Gates diminished in this way.

headline: Wanderlust | Patch NYC in Boston
text: Patch NYC has come a long way since its debut collection, 15 years ago, of crocheted hats made by the mother of John Ross, the brand’s co-owner. The company has grown over the years to include both fashion and home items, all with a modern twist on a vintage look. Enough, in fact, to fill a store, which opened in the South End of Boston two weeks ago. “Our collection had expanded into a lot of new categories, and we wanted a space where we could show everything together,” explained Ross, referring to himself and his co-owner, Don Carney. “We found an ideal space in the back of a brick-lined courtyard in our favorite Boston neighborhood, and it felt like a perfect location to create a Patch NYC world.” That world includes the company’s jewelry, scarves, candles and pillows, along with original art by Carney,  who hails from Boston. Also in the mix are a selection of porcelain from the Brooklyn-based designers Klein Reid, ceramic sculptures by the Boston-based artist Steve Murphy and vintage decorative objects and Indian textiles. Ross and Carney’s mothers are still involved — they’re currently working on framed needlepoint art that will be sold at Barneys.Patch NYC, 46 Waltham Street, Boston; (917) 292-2640.

headline: The Week Ahead: Nov. 14-20
text: Classical

headline: Letter: End-of-Life Duty
text: Randy Cohen’s advice to the celebrity spokesperson (Oct. 24) regarding the employer that he or she discovered had unfair labor practices here and abroad was dead on and succinct — quit your job. However, he failed to explore a nobler and more elegant solution. The celebrity in question could use his or her status as a spokesperson to effect change in the company’s labor policies. Either publicly or privately, the celebrity should let the company know that he or she is not comfortable promoting a company whose practices are inhumane and simply ask them to change these practices. A win-win for all. The company gets P.R. brownie points for being conscientious, laborers are provided a more lucrative and safe working environment and the celebrity remains employed.

headline: Adam Pinsker, Manager and Adviser of Arts Groups, Dies at 79
text: Adam Pinsker, an arts administrator who managed orchestras, chamber music ensembles and dance troupes and who successfully advised dance companies on how to survive by professionalizing their management, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: In Iran, Hailing Detroit With Vintage V-8’s

Then, despite good-natured banter between the drivers, an unspoken challenge is made. Finally, a tire-smoking showdown ensues.

headline: A Despot’s Garage Is Open for Tours
text: THE Shah of Iran, who ruled from 1941 until he was overthrown in a 1979 revolution, was an auto aficionado with a taste for European classics and exotics. During his authoritarian reign, he assembled a large collection — how large is anybody’s guess — that included vehicles specially built for him.

text: 10:55 a.m. | Updated

headline: It’s Not Over Till the Svelte Mama Sings
text: EARLY this fall the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard stood beside the grand piano in the Central Park West apartment of Edith Bers, her voice teacher since her Juilliard days, inhaled deeply and revealed her latest accomplishment: taut, well-defined abs. Admirable by any standard, they were all the more impressive because on May 17 Ms. Leonard gave birth to Teo, her son with her husband, the New Zealand baritone Teddy Tahu Rhodes (famous for his own steely six-pack).

text: Joe Girardi is confident the Yankees will improve their roster in the off-season and he is eager to help recruit big-name free agents like Cliff Lee.

headline: Running for President of Haiti, but Stumping in U.S.
text: BOSTON  It was a typical late-October campaign event, with spectators straining to see a candidate, talk of change and pleas for support, but with one major difference  no one in the room could cast a ballot in the election.

headline: EADS Chief Sees Future in Emerging Markets
text: PARIS  Countries in Europe are tightening their budgets and imposing austerity measures. But Louis Gallois, who runs the largest European aerospace and military contractor, is not worried.

headline: Timeless Stories in Period Costume
text: Forget the ’fros, the saffron robes and the 60-cent taxi meter drop, the Horn & Hardart, the Doubleday and the showroom on Broadway with Chevelles for sale. Paul McDonough‘s “New York City, 1973-1978” summons all these memories for anyone old enough to recall when city buses were green. But the pictures are really not about memory. They are, instead, timeless narratives, perfectly current in their story line. They are suffused with detail and a lot of wit. They repay close examination. And you can see them on Lens.

headline: Muscle Cars in Iran
text: Classic-car events attract considerable attention in Iran.

headline: Friday: Did I Make Money This Week?
text: This week, as I explained last Friday, I’m writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

headline: Forgiving the Unforgivable?
text: Some relationships are truly beyond repair. And yet, even then, we try. In the Lives column in The New York Times Magazine this weekend, Frederick Woolverton writes about the 30-year silence between him and his mother, who, he says frankly, “hated me.”

headline: Emanuel to Make It Official
text: CHICAGO – If there is any shred of doubt left about whether Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, is running for mayor of Chicago, it will be erased on Saturday, when Mr. Emanuel is scheduled to announce his candidacy.

headline: Icahn Raises Dynegy Stake and Offers Credit Line
text: 4:24 p.m. | Updated Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in Dynegy and will extend the company a $2 billion line of credit if its proposed takeover by the Blackstone Group is rejected and other financing cannot be obtained, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Potluck
text: Mark Kurlansky is among our most intelligent, prolific and literate writers about food: not cooking, not restaurants, but food. “Cod: A Biography of the Fish That Changed the World” and “Salt: A World History” are both comprehensive, valuable and as entertaining as food nonfiction gets. And Kurlansky ranges even wider. He’s written a popular history of the Basques, a book on baseball and one on European Jewry. “Edible Stories” is his third work of fiction.

headline: The Best 5-4 Team in the N.B.A.?
text: With two losses on its home court in three days — to Boston on Thursday and to Utah in overtime on Tuesday — the Miami Heat is 5-4.

headline: Back to the City
text: In 1974, Armistead Maupin, then a young journalist, covered a story on a Safeway supermarket in San Francisco that had become a popular pickup spot. Local customers, gay and straight, were not, as it turns out, shopping only for wheat bread and alfalfa sprouts, nor were they willing to talk to a reporter. Undaunted, Maupin created his own spokeswoman: a fictional young Midwesterner named Mary Ann Singleton.

headline: Hello, Columbus
text: Lean, tattooed and hunky in the way of a young Henry Rollins, Brian Reaume is living the life of a gay indie Brooklyn or Bay Area artist. He lives in what real estate agents call a ‘‘transitional’’ neighborhood, in a house filled with midcentury furniture and quirky art by him and his friends. In a small shop on a funky strip of cafes, bars and galleries, he sells his paintings along with the vintage housewares that he collects with the shop’s co-owner, Nancy Carlson, who lives upstairs. Two years ago he created ‘‘There’s No Truth in Silence,’’ an installation in his studio — which is among a warren of artists’ spaces in an old warehouse — that drew thousands one weekend with its controversial use of the American flag, a swastika, a cross and a chair emblazoned with the word ‘‘fag.’’

headline: Farmers’ Water Deals Stir Debate
text: Two farmers in California’s San Joaquin Valley are proposing to do with their water rights what farmers around the country have done for decades: sell them  to developers.

headline: Reading ‘Hot Rod’ in Tehran
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Jim Koscs writes about car enthusiasts in Iran, with a special focus on the Tehran Café Racers, an affiliate of a club based in Florida. In what may come as a surprise, a number of the cars treasured by the club’s members are American muscle cars:

text: I RECENTLY drove 1,500 miles in the new Audi A8. But I’m not sure anyone noticed.
