text: Sony announced the latest — and hopefully, last — release date for its Gran Turismo 5 driving simulator for the PlayStation 3. The game will hit store shelves on Wednesday, Nov. 24. And with less than two weeks to go, there’s a pretty good chance that this latest release date will stick.

headline: For Freshmen House Members, Which Orientation to Choose?
text: Newly elected members of Congress are arriving in Washington this weekend for the equivalent of freshman orientation – but which orientation to attend?

headline: O.K., Seriously — Who Was Interviewed for Chancellor’s Job?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he searched for the best possible schools chancellor before picking Cathleen P. Black, the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines. But so far, we haven’t heard the names of any others who were in contention. Indeed, The Times has been unable to turn up any evidence that the mayor considered anyone besides Ms. Black, a complete outsider to the world of education, to replace Joel I. Klein.

headline: Obama Abroad: Ways to Teach About the President’s Asia Trip
text: Note: Our Friday lesson plans focus on an important interdisciplinary topic in the news each week, and this week the big news is President Obama’s ten-day trip through India, Indonesia, South Korea and Japan.

headline: Carrots: Raw, Roasted, Baked and Simmered
text: Whenever I buy a bunch of carrots, I end up eating them just as they are — raw, crunchy and delicious. But this week Martha Rose Shulman inspires us to get more creative with carrots, a versatile vegetable that can be used to create nutrient-rich sauces, salads, soups and even cake.

headline: Forget Decades and Distance. It’s Still Giants-Dodgers.
text: The Giants’ recent World Series victory may have brought pure joy for many San Francisco-ites, but for fans of the Giants who once watched the team at the Polo Grounds, the victory was double-edged.

headline: 2011 Audi A8
text: For people who appreciate the subtle exterior, the A8 is a terrific drive.

headline: Contenders for Title Take Top Four Spots in Abu Dhabi Practice
text: The first practice sessions of the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix set the stage perfectly for the last race of the season, which will decide the title among four drivers. The four remaining contenders finished in the top four spots, and interestingly, the man with the least chance to win the title, and therefore the one who has the least amount of pressure this weekend, was also the fastest man on track on Friday.

headline: Contenders for Title Take Top Four Spots in Abu Dhabi Practice
text: The first practice sessions of the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix set the stage perfectly for the last race of the season, which will decide the title among four drivers. The four remaining contenders finished in the top four spots, and interestingly, the man with the least chance to win the title, and therefore the one who has the least amount of pressure this weekend, was also the fastest man on track on Friday.

headline: Afghanistan: Change You Can’t Sit and Talk About
text: CHAHAR DARA, Afghanistan — When President Obama gave his major speech on Afghanistan a year ago, he called not only for sending an additional 30,000 American troops to the war, but also for expanding the role of civilian experts in rebuilding the nation’s shattered government and economy. A new policy was born: “the civilian surge.”

headline: ‘Garfield’ Creator Apologizes for ‘National Stupid Day’ Cartoon
text: Garfield may hate Mondays, but Thursday wasn’t a banner day for that cartoon cat, either. Jim Davis, the creator and author of “Garfield,” apologized for a comic strip published on Thursday that some readers said was insensitive to the Veterans Day holiday.

headline: A Head Start for Fabio Trabocchi Downtown
text: When Villa Pacri opens in the meatpacking district on Nov. 23, Fabio Trabocchi, formerly of Fiamma, will be consulting chef. But until then Mr. Trabocchi will be working on the menu[pdf] downstairs in the more casual La Gazzetta.

headline: Who Sets China’s Monetary Policy?
text: My column this morning mentions how upset the Chinese are with the Federal Reserve, but it does not discuss one very good reason they have to be upset: Ben Bernanke‘s monetary policy is not what China needs these days. It needs to tighten, as is shown by rising inflation there.

headline: Ralph Lauren and the Digital Age
text: David Lauren, Senior Vice President of Polo Ralph Lauren, tells Suzy Menkes about future plans for his father's global company and strategy for what is now the biggest store, its e-commerce website.

headline: The Baker’s Apprentice: Brownies
text: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with Dorie Greenspan, a food writer and the author of several cookbooks, including the recent “Around My French Table.”

headline: Spheres of Influence
text: Timothy Garton Ash specializes in what he calls (quoting George F. Kennan) the “history of the present.” He is a historian with the journalist’s urge to be there, and a journalist with the historian’s knowledge of where he is. These qualities have made him one of the most reliable and acute observers of the past present, able to report on events as a witness and, simultaneously, assess them with a coolness of judgment that almost always holds up over time.

headline: For Some, Tough Entry Into G.M.’s I.P.O.
text: Individual investors who want to buy a piece of the new General Motors when it goes public next week may be out of luck.

headline: Miami’s Big Three Stumble Along
text: It’s kind of a shame really, that the Miami Heat has started the season 5-4, having been thumped twice by the Celtics already. The Big Three had such potential to be the N.B.A.’s hated villain. LeBron James’s universally hated free agency reality show was sublime; getting people to scowl at the otherwise likeable Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh was genius. The forever-gelled Pat Riley lurking in the background? Oliver Stone couldn’t have constructed this better. But now, they’re stumbling along like a band of misfits and it’s impossible to conjure up anything close to mass indignation. It’s more like a mass yawn.

headline: Italian Cultural Groups Stage Protest
text: ROME — Hundreds of Italian cultural institutions took part in a nationwide protest on Friday against a series of measures passed recently that critics say will stifle cultural development in Italy.

headline: Week 11 College Football Matchups
text: It’s getting down to it. Only a couple of weeks of college football left. Pay attention people. Soon it will be February and you will be cold and wishing college football was still on. Makes me kind of sad to even type that. This week maybe without a signature blockbuster game, but it’s got plenty of conference action.

text: SEOUL, South Korea  It could have been far worse.

headline: Weekend Competition: Lying to Children
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the lies they have told to children.

headline: Anthony Gets Hot, Future With Nuggets Still Murky
text: Carmelo Anthony is used to rumors. He can handle the speculation about his future, but he doesn’t want the whispers affecting his Denver Nuggets teammates.

headline: The Mind of a Disease
text: All patients begin as storytellers, the oncologist Siddhartha Mukherjee observes near the start of this powerful and ambitious first book. Long before they see a doctor, they become narrators of suffering, as Mukherjee puts it — travelers who have visited the “kingdom of the ill.”

headline: Mean Girls and Bad Mommies
text: One of the most refreshing scenes in the movie “The Kids Are All Right” comes when 15-year-old Laser has it out with his jerky pal, Clay. They trade a barbed sentence or two, shove each other, and then bam! With a punch to the face, the friendship is over.

headline: Gina Lollobrigida. Need We Say More?
text: The Most Beautiful Woman in the World walked into Harry Cipriani on Fifth Avenue in black boots and a riding-hood-red cloak, and for the only person in the room expecting her, it perhaps was a trick of the imagination, but it seemed as if the whole restaurant lost its train of thought for a second. Then it righted itself, and the maître d’hôtel hustled over, and the woman became wrapped in warm Italian greetings and air kisses before finally removing her big sunglasses.

headline: Film of Paul Bowles Short Story Rediscovered
text: The tale had all the hallmarks of a baroque Paul Bowles short story, set among the remaindered possessions of Bowles himself: a film director gets a call from a stranger, who says he has stumbled across an original print of the filmmaker’s long-lost first film in a windowless Tangier apartment, coated in dust and insect powder. The director, Sara Driver, at first thought the call might be a joke, but for reasons almost as strange as fiction, she kept listening.

headline: Curator’s Choice | Tim Gunn for Ahalife
text: Ahalife, the two-month-old Web site that offers its readers one guest-curated item every 24 hours, includes departments like Dress Me, Optimize Me and Design Me.

headline: Twentysomethings, Getting By in New York
text: Four young New Yorkers discuss their creative strategies for making ends meet while still managing to have fun.

headline: New and Living in the City
text: Twenty-something transplants discuss their moves to New York and how they’re adjusting to their adopted city.

headline: 20-Somethings Living the Small Life in New York Apartments
text: For New Yorkers in their 20’s, a postage-stamp bedroom in a shared walk-up in an iffy neighborhood is a lucky find. Who cares about home when there’s a big city out the door?

headline: The Price 20-Somethings Pay to Live in the City
text: ABE CAVIN QUEZADA, a 22-year-old aspiring music producer, lives with two roommates in a three-bedroom apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Mr. Cavin Quezada, who works as an unpaid intern at Electric Lady Studios in Greenwich Village, has kind words for his building, a renovated tenement near Marcus Garvey Boulevard, and for his apartment, for which he pays $500 a month and has a 10-by-6-foot bedroom. But as for the neighborhood, he is less enthusiastic.

headline: A Challenger for Steele as Head of R.N.C.
text: The Republican Party’s embattled chairman, Michael S. Steele, has drawn his first, but  perhaps not his last, challenger: Saul Anuzis, the former Michigan party chairman who made it to the final rounds of voting when Mr. Steele was elected nearly two years ago.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CLEOPATRA: A Life,  by Stacy Schiff (Little, Brown, $29.99.) It’s dizzying to contemplate the ancient thicket of personalities and propaganda Schiff penetrates to reconstruct the Macedonian-Egyptian queen in all her ambition, audacity and formidable intelligence.

headline: Inside the List
text: ROYAL FLUSH: Keith Richards’s well-reviewed “Life” is sitting pretty, if that’s the word, at No. 1 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. Meanwhile, a pack of new celebrity books is nipping at its heels. “Unbearable Lightness,” the actress Portia de Rossi’s memoir of her anorexia, enters at No. 3. (De Rossi may be the first prime-time television star to score a blurb from Jonathan Safran Foer.) Ricky Martin’s “Me” plops down at No. 5, trailed by the confessions of Howard Stern’s producer, Gary Dell’Abate, “They Call Me Baba Booey.” (Funny, that’s what I call Ricky Martin.) And then there’s “Autobiography of Mark Twain, Vol. 1,” from the biggest celebrity in 19th-century America (No. 9), and “Cleopatra,” Stacy Schiff’s biography of the Ptolemaic tabloid queen, new at No. 11.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FOOTNOTES IN GAZA, written and illustrated by Joe Sacco. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) Sacco’s reputation for combining graphic artistry and investigative reporting was established with “Palestine” and “Safe Area Gorazde.” “Footnotes” reconstructs two long-forgotten mass killings of Palestinians during the Suez crisis of 1956, when the Israeli Army swept into the Gaza Strip. “Sacco’s gripping, important book . . . stands out as one of the few contemporary works on the Israeli-Palestinian struggle likely to outlive the era in which they were written,” Patrick Cockburn wrote in the Book Review.

headline: Spy vs. Spy
text: Inside the Central Intelligence Agency, it came to be known as “The Italian Job,” a botched operation in 2003 that snatched a radical cleric off a Milan street in broad daylight and spirited him to Egypt, where he says he endured months of torture at the hands of his Egyptian jailers.

headline: A Good Day to Die
text: In the Indian wars of the 1870s, Sioux tribesmen used a tactic against the United States Cavalry known as a “brave run” or a “dare ride.” An Indian warrior would gallop close to the American soldiers, drawing their fire. The purpose was partly practical — to get the soldiers to waste their ammunition — and partly psychological — to taunt. The Sioux sometimes showed their contempt for their enemies by appearing naked or nearly so, displaying their genitals and buttocks. Then the Indians would close in. “Soldiers always tried to keep an enemy at bay, to kill him at a distance,” Thomas Powers writes in “The Killing of Crazy Horse,” his richly textured account of clashing civilizations on the Great Plains during the late 19th century. “The instinct of Sioux fighters was for exactly the opposite: to charge in and touch the enemy with a quirt, bow or naked hand while he was still alive. There is no terror in battle to equal physical contact — shouting, hot breath, the grip of a hand from a man close enough to smell.” The whites were repulsed by the smell of Indians — “an odor resembling a mixture of smoked beef, muskrat and polecat,” according to a correspondent for Frank Leslie’s Illustrated Weekly quoted by Powers; “a pungent, musty odor something like that of combined smoke and grease,” Lt. William Philo Clark, a cavalry officer, wrote. For the Sioux “who wanted nothing to do with whites, visceral differences like smell were only the beginning,” Powers writes. The Indians particularly resented white treatment of Indian women. “Many whites beat or abused Indian women, exploited them sexually after capture in battle, and sometimes bought them for cheap trinkets and liquor and later cast them aside.”

headline: The Hipster in the Mirror
text: A  year ago, my colleagues and I started to investigate the contemporary hipster. What was the “hipster,” and what did it mean to be one? It was a puzzle. No one, it seemed, thought of himself as a hipster, and when someone called you a hipster, the term was an insult. Paradoxically, those who used the insult were themselves often said to resemble hipsters — they wore the skinny jeans and big eyeglasses, gathered in tiny enclaves in big cities, and looked down on mainstream fashions and “tourists.” Most puzzling was how rattled sensible, down-to-earth people became when we posed hipster-themed questions. When we announced a public debate on hipsterism, I received e-mail messages both furious and plaintive. Normally inquisitive people protested that there could be no answer and no definition. Maybe hipsters didn’t exist! The responses were more impassioned than those we’d had in our discussions on health care, young conservatives and feminism. And perfectly blameless individuals began flagellating themselves: “Am I a hipster?”

headline: The Ancestral Home
text: Unlike memoirs that are secretly novels, “Who Occupies This House” admits it’s a novel pretending to be a memoir, a family scrapbook that includes photos, newspaper clippings, posters, letters, diaries, short autobiographies and more. The spaces between these documents are filled by a 60-something Manhattanite who, after 9/11, feels compelled to research, reconstruct and occasionally simply imagine several generations of her Irish-American forebears, some of whom lived and died in a house in Pelham, N.Y.

headline: Original Sins
text: I come from Chattanooga, a city on the Tennessee River that sits on and near land that was taken from the Cherokee Nation and that saw some of the most significant fighting of the Civil War three decades later. It is impossible to grow up there without a sense of historical immediacy. As a child I would feed ducks in a pond outside the house from which Chief John Ross was driven, and more than once I found Minié balls from the Battle of Missionary Ridge in our yard.

headline: Cat and Mouse
text: There once was an 80-year-old father of eight, the contours of whose life bore an uncanny resemblance to those of the noted German writer, political activist and public intellectual Günter Grass; his children even remembered accompanying him to a Nobel-like gala in Stockholm, complete with tuxedos and velvet gowns.

headline: Japan’s High-Speed Trains Lines Expand
text: Japan’s high-speed bullet train system is expanding, reducing transit time to tourist attractions in remote corners of the country.

headline: Tudor Jones Doubts Fed’s Bond Buying
text: Paul Tudor Jones, the successful currency trader, says that fixing the “gross misalignment” of China’s currency against the dollar would do more to lower unemployment in the United States than the recent move by the Federal Reserve to buy large quantities of Treasury bonds.

headline: Barclays to Reimburse Gay Workers for Health Benefit Tax
text: Gay people who are lucky enough to work for employers that extend health benefits to their same-sex partners are still at a disadvantage: they must pay an extra tax on the value of those benefits that heterosexual married couples do not pay.

headline: After a Life in Law, Focusing on Simple Pleasures
text: For more than 30 years, Neil L. Selinger had his hand in major securities litigation cases that played out in New York courts. He represented several municipal pension funds in the case against WorldCom, the telecommunications company that reported some $11 billion in false profits. He helped to obtain a nearly $80 million settlement for investors of Philip Services Corp., a Canadian resource recovery company. In 2007, Mr. Selinger stepped away from the practice of law to pursue his interest in writing and volunteer endeavors.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Emperor of All Maladies’
text: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjee’s biography of cancer, “The Emperor of All Maladies”; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: The Luke Walton Rule
text: In the last round of collective bargaining negotiations in 2005, a novel clause was included in the final agreement that came to be known as the Amnesty Clause. It allowed N.B.A. teams to designate one of the outstanding contracts on their payroll as being exempt from the end-of-season luxury tax calculations. For example, if a team had a payroll of $256 billion dollars against a luxury tax threshold of $40 billion, and one of their players was earning $220 billion alone, using the amnesty clause on that player would then put that team under the luxury tax threshold (as their payroll for luxury tax purposes was now considered to be only $36 billion). The player still got his money, and the teams got the reprieve — everyone, indeed, was a winner.

headline: Blocking, Tackling and Studying Diseases
text: STANFORD, Calif.  Owen Marecic is known for bone-crushing tackles and bleeding the clock, so it was strange to hear him talk about becoming woozy while watching knee replacement surgery as part of a summer internship at Stanford Hospital.

headline: Two-Match Ban for Mourinho
text: Never at a loss for words, either on the touchline or cast as a cheeky puppet in a long-running satire, Real Madrid Coach José Mourinho drew a two-match ban from the Spanish federation on Friday. Mourinho was sent off last Wednesday in Madrid’s 5-1 win over Murcia in Spain’s Copa del Rey after insulting Referee Jose Luis Paradas Romero.

The space, small to begin with, was so jampacked with furniture, the roommates barely had space to move around.

headline: Support Grows for Expansion of Ozone Treaty
text: This week I reported on a push by a number of nations to expand the scope of the Montreal Protocol, the treaty designed to deal with the degradation of the Earth’s ozone layer, to begin to address global warming. Several countries, including the island nation of Micronesia, joined by the United States, Mexico and Canada, are proposing to phase out a family of industrial chemicals known as hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, which have a minimal effect on the ozone layer but are highly potent greenhouse gases.

headline: Peripheral Vision
text: One recent, drizzly Sunday, I met the artist Vik Muniz at his Ipanema home to drive from Zona Sul, the beachy, bathing-suited Rio of Copacabana lore, to the less renowned poorer part of the city in the north. As we whizzed up Avenida Brasil through an area called Mare, Muniz indicated a cluster of favelas arrayed around a public pool called Piscinão de Ramos and quipped, ‘‘You have to think of Rio as St. Tropez — surrounded by Mogadishu.’’

headline: An Indian-Spiced Thanksgiving
text: For years, fans of cookbook author Madhur Jaffrey have complained to her that Indian cooking seems too complicated. As a result, Ms. Jaffrey decided to create a cookbook filled with some of the most simple Indian dishes she could find or create.

headline: It’s After Midnight? Let’s Get This Party Started
text: IT used to be that when the band went home, the guests were right behind them, but at Linda Moschello’s wedding next June, the real party is not expected to start until after the reception. Around midnight, her guests at the Palace at Somerset Park in Somerset, N.J., are to be ushered into a pseudo nightclub in the hall’s west ballroom, complete with lounge furniture, colored lights and walls hung with white fabric. The finishing touch: servers passing out tequila shots.

headline: ’60s Hollywood: Power Shifted (or Did It?)
text: THE story of what is often called New Hollywood, the era of the easy riders, raging bulls, to borrow the title of Peter Biskind’s 1998 best seller, has been told numerous times. It goes something like this: By the early 1960s the old studio system was in shambles, run by old men who, out of touch with the times-they-are-a-changin’, were churning out pricey duds like “Cleopatra” to shrinking, indifferent audiences.

headline: Bite-Size Indies in Competition on Your Couch
text: THE Times Square throng was thinning on a recent, about-to-be-rainy Sunday evening when the JumboTron outside the W Hotel sparked to life. “Film Festival in a Box,” it announced. And then the movies, short films with titles like “Laundry” and “Pete’s Beach” and actors the crowd had never heard of, started. The effect was immediate: Tourists actually lowered their cameras. Theatergoers stopped checking prices at the TKTS booth. The lost looked up from their street maps. They watched. They tried to listen. They madly dialed the 800 number they were told would provide audio. Failing that, they even talked to one another.

headline: Glenn Beck Sees George Soros as Iran Does
text: As my colleague Brian Stelter reports, the Fox News host Glenn Beck was accused this week of deploying “a symphony of anti-Semitic dog whistles” in his lengthy attack on the political activities of George Soros, a billionaire investor and philanthropist Mr. Beck repeatedly described as a “puppet master” who “collapses regimes.”

headline: Glad Bags
text: “We told children to think about how pictures tell a story like in fairy tales,” says the Marni designer Consuelo Castiglioni about the latest chapter in her ongoing project to help underprivileged children. “We hoped to stimulate their creativity and make something that could be sold with the proceeds going back to bettering their hospitals and schools.” The three resulting tote bags feature vintage Marni prints on one side and drawings by children from East Asia and South America on the other. Eighty percent of the proceeds will go to children’s developmental programs geared toward learning and creativity. “It seemed like the natural thing to do around the holidays,” adds Castiglioni. “To celebrate the innocence of a child’s imagination.”

headline: Therapy? Not His Cup of Tea
text: IN a season that trumpeted the return of Debra Winger, it is the Indian actor Irrfan Khan who has generated some of the loudest buzz on HBO’s “In Treatment.” Mr. Khan, familiar in this country from the movies “The Namesake” and “Slumdog Millionaire,” and something of an idol in his own, has applied his soulful gaze and talent for nuance to the role of Sunil, a Bengali widower in his mid-50s who reluctantly enters therapy after being transplanted from Calcutta to Brooklyn to live with his son and American daughter-in-law.

headline: A Bollywood Star on the Couch
text: Irrfan Khan, whose name is typically preceded by “the great Indian actor,” arrived at The New York Times recently with the aplomb of a rock star. A mini-entourage of handler and groomer trailed Mr. Khan, best known in this country for “The Namesake,” “Slumdog Millionaire” and “A Mighty Heart,” while his driver waited outside. During an interview in the cafeteria, fans broke in to pay their respects. As he waited by the elevator bank, women shyly asked to have their pictures taken with him. Mr. Khan politely granted the requests.

headline: Some Early Returns on Early Admission

headline: Number of Uninsured Rises, Report Says
text: The number of uninsured adults in the United States continues to rise, with one in four adults under 65 reporting they were without health insurance at some point in the last year, according to a recent report from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: A Slow Renaissance for a Struggling Neighborhood

headline: Study Ties Ovarian Cancer and Hormone Therapy
text: More bad news about postmenopausal hormone therapy: a new European study reports that women who take the hormones are at significantly increased risk for ovarian cancer, which is rare but often fatal.

headline: Cindy McCain Breaks with  Her Husband in Gay Rights Video

Of course, that writer, George Steinbrenner, ultimately went on to bigger and better things.

headline: Theater Groups Team Up to Help Playwrights Develop Works

text: IF ever a building could be said to have a defining characteristic, it’s the small co-op on Sullivan Street in West SoHo wreathed by a fat wisteria vine.

headline: Militant Gets Life Sentence in Lebanon
text: CAIRO  A Lebanese military court on Friday sentenced 24 people, including Omar Bakri Mohammed, the Syrian-born militant who was barred from Britain in 2005, to life in prison for belonging to a terrorist group and inciting violence.

headline: Just Don’t Call It A Gala
text: For his first MoCA Gala, Jeffrey Deitch, the museum’s newly installed director, will not be serving up rubber chickens to a crowd of women in ball gowns and men in monkey suits. Instead, he gave full creative license to the Los Angeles artist Doug Aitken, who promises to hijack the polite (read: dull) concept of a museum benefit dinner and turn it into a real happening. Here, Aitken dishes up a sneak peek of the event which takes place Saturday, November 13.

headline: Northern Lights to Be Heard, Not Seen
text: Into each concertgoer’s life a little uncertainty must fall. For a presenter the key challenge is not simply to offer the unfamiliar, but also to provide a context in which an audience can approach and appreciate it. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center demonstrated the right way to do it on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: A Verdict on Controlled Oil Burns and Cancer Risk
text: Fumes from oil burned by spill-response teams in the Gulf of Mexico did not contain enough cancer-causing chemicals to pose a risk to human health, two new studies from the Environmental Protection Agency conclude.

headline: New Terrain for Barefoot Riverdancer
text: Some performers are forever associated with one production, so that you never expect to see them in any other context or even on the street. When the Irish step-dancing phenomenon “Riverdance” first traveled the world in the 1990s, its female lead was the redhead Jean Butler.

headline: The Importance of the Milton Robson Car Collection Auction
text: With the economy showing some signs of a pulse, blue-chip prewar classic cars and European sports cars have shown some renewed vitality in the market. At the Monterey auctions in August, $172 million worth of collector cars exchanged hands. “In the upper end of the market there is a great deal of liquidity,” Robert Ames, a commercial real estate investor and car collector in Portland, Ore., said at the time.

headline: Ground Time for the Flockless Bird
text: Pavel Zustiak’s latest dance begins, as many seem to these days, with slightly sinister underpinnings: there is a darkened, empty stage and an ominous grumble of an electronic score. But his opening creates some spooky distance for a reason. Mr. Zustiak’s new piece, “Bastard,” the first part of a trilogy, “The Painted Bird,” is loosely inspired by Jerzy Kosinski’s novel of that title about a boy making his way through Europe during World War II.

headline: A Language of Their Own, Tinged With Funk
text: Henry Threadgill played a long new work on Thursday at Roulette for the first of his three nights there. It was called “In Frontispiece,” written for his semi-jazz band Zooid with the Flux String Quartet, and it was messy on the ears.

headline: Daisy Khan, an Eloquent Face of Islam
text: DAISY KHAN had never seen so many Jews in her life. The year was 1974, and Ms. Khan, an awkward, artistic 16-year-old who had just emigrated from India to the suburban Long Island enclave of Jericho, N.Y., was attending her first day of school in America.

headline: Watchlist: A New Look at Web Video
text: Beginning this Sunday in Arts & Leisure, a new column called Watchlist will sample the vast and largely uncharted world of Web video — not dancing Filipino prisoners or Baby Bob Marley, but the thousands of online serials, Webisodes, cartoons, talk shows, newsmagazines, reality shows and other formats that have sprung up over the last decade as a quick-and-cheap parallel world to television and film. The first column looks at current works like the serials “Riese” on Syfy.com and “Kids Reenact” at Babelgum.com, Larry Fessenden’s audio-drama project “Tales From Beyond the Pale” and the latest episode of Lisa Kudrow’s “Web Therapy.”

headline: Look of the Moment | V.B.’s Tangerine Dream
text: The Look: A dress that gives new meaning to the words juicy couture.

headline: A Soldier’s Torment in Vietnam and at Home
text: How is this for a story with operatic potential? A prisoner of war held for nearly a decade returns home to find that his wife has moved on, his nation has changed beyond recognition, and he is unable to find his bearings in the society he fought to defend. It is Monteverdi’s “Ritorno d’Ulisse in Patria” in reverse: the story of the returning warrior, but in this thoroughly modern version, everything has gone wrong, and redemption is out of reach.

headline: Ban on Gays in the Military Stays in Effect
text: The military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy restricting openly gay, lesbian and bisexual people from serving will remain in force while a legal challenge is considered by a federal appeals court, the United States Supreme Court declared Friday.

headline: Qing Dynasty Relic Yields Record Price at Auction
text: LONDON  As treasure-in-the-attic stories go, the 18th-century Chinese vase sold at a suburban auction house in outer London on Thursday night will be hard to beat.

headline: Dostoyevsky’s ‘Sick Man’ Hits YouTube
text: Guess who’s getting ready for his YouTube close-up?

headline: A Guide to the Cosmos, in Words and Images Dazzling and True
text: In his new book "Far Out, A Space-Time Chronicle," photographer and journalist Michael Benson has reprocessed images from the Hubble Space Telescope and other telescopes to take readers on a lush tour of some of time's creations.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Haiti and Pakistan.

headline: Here Comes Rhymin’ Simon, on a Different Label
text: Coming pretty soon to a record store near you (if you are lucky enough to have a record store near you): a whole bunch of deluxe reissues of Paul Simon albums, with a different record company logo on them.

headline: Gaines, Livingston and the Defining Power of YouTube
text: In basketball, sometimes the stories write themselves.

headline: ‘Nightly Business Report’ Cuts Jobs
text: “Nightly Business Report, ” the business newscast on PBS, laid off eight people on Friday, or about 20 percent of the staff, in the first major change since it was acquired in August by a new company, NBR Worldwide.

headline: Six House Races Remain in Limbo
text: Representative Ben Chandler has been declared the winner – again – of his close House race in Kentucky. But six other House races remained in limbo Friday, meaning some incumbent Democrats will be on hand for the lame-duck session next week unsure about whether they will return in January for the 112th Congress. And some potential Republican freshmen will arrive for orientation uncertain about whether they will ultimately serve in Congress next year.

headline: Finding a Bed Among Central Park’s Trees
text: There is no shortage of places in Manhattan where visitors can spend the night. Luxury hotels offer lavish suites that can run thousands of dollars, and youth hostels have beds for as little as $20. At least one flophouse survives on the Bowery. And, of course, there is couch-surfing — countless travelers bunk with old friends or near-strangers for little more than an owed favor.

headline: Antiques Books
text: Antiques trade promoters are running ads lately headlined “Every Collector Add a Collector.” Enthusiasms can spread, in other words, if sellers and buyers talk up their obsessions. In that spirit of sharing, this season’s most entertaining books about antiques reveal how owners have learned about the sweep of history by buying one type of useful or decadent object.

headline: Coffee Table Books
text: One of the best things about Antonia Fraser’s new memoir, “Must You Go? My Life With Harold Pinter,” is watching this warm and literate couple trade books, and sometimes perform readings, on birthdays and holidays. When it came to celebrations, printed words were never far from their minds.

headline: Sleeping in Trees
text: Cory and Dana Foht, twins from Florida, have spent some 20 nights over the past two months 25 feet up the side of a tall American elm tree in Central Park.

headline: Twitter’s Biz Stone Talks About Growth and Local Ads
text: Biz Stone, a co-founder of Twitter, and Sean Garrett, the company’s director of communications, visited The Times this week to talk about the current state of Twitter and plans for the company over the next few years.

headline: For Dinner Tonight: Los Angeles
text: It’s pretty clear that most of the thought, time and money spent on “Skyline” went into the fabrication of the alien creatures who descend on Los Angeles and start feeding on humans at a pace reminiscent of the afternoon rush at In-N-Out Burger. These extraterrestrial locavores — they consume their food right where it’s harvested — are a cross between the Alien and Audrey the man-eating plant in “Little Shop of Horrors,” except that they come in sizes ranging from large car to small building.

headline: ‘Smart’ Meters Draw Complaints of Inaccuracy
text: NOLANVILLE, Tex.  Sgt. John Robertson 2nd, an Army mechanic at nearby Fort Hood, is fuming about the so-called smart electric meter his local utility has installed on the side of his tidy, 1,800-square-foot home.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Emperor of All Maladies’
text: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjee’s biography of cancer, “The Emperor of All Maladies”; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Emperor of All Maladies’
text: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjee’s biography of cancer, “The Emperor of All Maladies”; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Emperor of All Maladies’
text: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjee’s biography of cancer, “The Emperor of All Maladies”; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: A Painstaking Devotion to Preserving Lancias
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Art Books
text: Digital may be destiny, but when it comes to holiday gifts a printed book in hand is still worth a thousand e-books bobbling around in the ether. Why? The luxe factor.

headline: In Match Between Computers, a Costly Blind Eye to the Odds
text: The 14th World Computer-Bridge Championship was held last month in Philadelphia. Seven programs from six countries, including Bridge Baron and Moose Bridge from the United States, played a preliminary round robin. This was followed by semifinals, from which the two most successful programs over the last decade reached the final, Jack from the Netherlands and WBridge5 from France.

headline: Group Says Camel Packs Lure the Young
text: R.J. Reynolds is introducing special-edition packs of Camel cigarettes that play off the images of cities that have a hip image — drawing fire from antismoking groups who say they are marketing to youth.

headline: Graphic Books
text: It’s been another exciting year for graphic books. It began in January, when Yen Press announced it would print 350,000 copies of its adaptation of the novel “Twilight” by Stephenie Meyer. Readers later witnessed the struggles of a Jewish rug maker in “Market Day,” by James Sturm. They were treated to Dash Shaw’s stylized “Bodyworld.” And they met the misanthrope known as “Wilson” in the latest from Daniel Clowes. The year closes with a mix of social issues, superheroes, slackers and Shakespeare.

headline: Replacement Parts, Built From Scratch
text: Much of the work requires an eye for detail.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Files Suit Against M.L.B.
text: Budweiser’s decades-long connection to Major League Baseball frayed Friday when the giant brewer’s parent company, Anheuser-Busch, alleged in a federal lawsuit that baseball reneged on an agreement reached earlier this year to extend the beer maker’s sponsorship.

headline: ‘Mentalist’ Lifts CBS
text: “The Big Bang Theory” and “The Mentalist” topped the ratings on Thursday as CBS racked up another No. 1 night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Mentalist” delivered the evening’s largest audience with 13.8 million viewers. “Grey’s Anatomy” (11.1 million) and “Private Practice” (8.3 million) helped ABC finish second on the night while Fox eked out a third-place finish with “Bones” (9.1 million) and “Fringe” (4.8 million). NBC was fourth, attracting its most viewers with “The Office” (7.7 million).

headline: New Details on Full-body X-Ray Scanners
text: How safe are those full body scanners being used at airports?

headline: Suddenly the Cold War Is a Cool Event
text: I never play games twice. But Call of Duty: Black Ops has made a very happy liar out of me.

headline: Reuniting (if With Issues) and Why It Feels So Good
text: Television has been broadly feminized for so long now  from the catfight agendas of the reality universe to the women’s-magazine sensibility of the morning news shows  that any network marketed specifically to women has had to find new ways to patronize its audience.

headline: White Light Festival
text: Violinist Gidon Kremer with Kremerata Baltica in the New York premiere of "Silent Prayer" on Thursday, part of the White Light Festival.

headline: Mixing Spirituality With a Bit of Fun
text: The overarching, some might say overreaching, theme of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center is to explore music as an expression of spirituality. As the festival continues, the participating artists keep coming up with intriguing choices of musical works that invite listeners to look inward, including two programs on Thursday night.

headline: Proposal Recommends Charging Admission at the Smithsonian
text: In New York, a visit to the Museum of Modern Art will set you back $20, but down in Washington, the Smithsonian Institution, which is 70 percent federally funded, has long been free. That would change under a proposal by the national commission charged with reducing the deficit. In a draft report Wednesday, it recommended that the Smithsonian’s federal appropriation be cut by $225 million, or roughly 30 percent, and that the institution make up the loss by charging a $7.50 admission fee.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 12
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a terror trial; small businesses in Astoria, Queens, and Mount Morris, N.Y.; and Veterans Day.

headline: The Cerebral Set Picks Up a Paddle
text: Under most circumstances a celebrated young novelist and a well-known bookseller would be close allies. But for a few minutes on Wednesday night, Jonathan Safran Foer, the author of “Everything Is Illuminated” and “Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close,” and Nancy Bass Wyden, the proprietor of the Strand bookstore, were heated rivals as they faced off across a Ping-Pong table in the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center.

headline: A Brewery, Behind the Scenes
text: Some food- and beverage-producing plants discourage visits by the public; others grudgingly tolerate them. Then there is Cottrell Brewing Company in Pawcatuck, which is so welcoming that the bottom of its six-pack holders depict a roadmap with directions to the brewery. “Tours are available,” the text reads. “Please call for details.”

headline: A Bustling Scene With Classic Italian Fare
text: DARIEN’S culinary landscape has been changing lately — for the better. And the convivial  Scena Wine Bar & Restaurant, a creation of the Siguenza brothers, Vicente and Kleber, who also own Cava in New Canaan and 55 Degrees in Fairfield, fits right into the general upswing.

headline: Young, Gifted and Outrageous: Can Odd Future Survive Popularity?
text: When Tyler, the Creator speaks, should you listen?

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 12
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Butternut Squash Salad
text: Mark Bittman makes a simple yet scrumptious raw vegetable salad.

headline: A Movable Feast, Popping Up Anywhere
text: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J.

headline: iPad Apps That Provide Recipes and Avoid Strife
text: Anyone who has prepared a Thanksgiving family dinner knows that the emotional minefield is laid long before the turkey goes in the oven. I speak of the annual quandary over whose recipe to use. Is it going to be Mom’s pumpkin pie or your mother-in-law’s? Either way, you risk offending half the family.

headline: Nonprofit Fund’s Grant Process Is Audited for Possible Conflicts
text: The inspector general with oversight of the federal government’s Corporation for National and Community Service is looking into the grant process of its Social Innovation Fund, a $50 million program meant to expand promising nonprofits.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 12
text: More Photographs

headline: Court Ruling Limits Scope of State Law on Terror
text: After Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney, successfully used New York State’s antiterrorism law to prosecute a gang member who had killed a 10-year-old girl in a gun battle, he said the verdict was significant in determining an appropriate punishment for someone who had “snuffed out” the life of an innocent child.

headline: Brussels Sprouts Aplenty
text: Perhaps brussels sprouts, which are now in season, are better seen than eaten. With high-end florists reaching for fruits and vegetables (Lady apples with chrysanthemums! Artichokes with roses!), stalks of brussels sprouts are enjoying a kind of decorative vogue, and millions of grateful children are relieved to see them anywhere but on their plates.

headline: Where the Ambience Is Adjustable
text: THE first time my family and I entered Somers 202 Restaurant & Grill, it was through the bar — a boisterous, fun room with six flat-screen televisions tuned to sports and plenty of folks enjoying the restaurant’s full menu as well as its drinks. We went on to the dining room, and I kept the vibe up by ordering a delicious açaí martini from the specialty martini list (which manages to surprise with unusual choices like Pom and lemon basil). We continued the casual mood with two appetizers — three flavorful little sliders on sweet buns and spicy chicken wings — and a crispy brick-oven pizza with succulent shrimp.

headline: Raw Butternut Squash Salad With Raisins and Ginger
text: 1 butternut squash (about 1 1/2 pounds), peeled, seeded and grated

headline: Vegetables for Thanksgiving, Served Natural and Raw
text: ALTHOUGH I’m not suggesting you bite into a raw hunk of butternut squash or gnaw on a head of cabbage (though the latter can actually be pleasant), there’s great pleasure to be found in feasting on autumn vegetables served raw, with a minimum of preparation. With a little shredding, grating, chopping, slicing or mincing, the tough, sometimes starchy character of late fall vegetables yields, allowing their robust flavors to take center stage.

headline: A High-Water Mark for Profits
text: The work force may still be struggling, but corporate profits appear to be heading toward a record (nominal) high, according to a new analysis from Deutsche Bank‘s economics research team.

headline: A Deficit of Respect
text: Here’s this week’s Beltway Best-Seller:  Read it while it’s hot.

headline: Drought in the Amazon, Up Close and Personal
text: Thursday, Nov. 11

headline: Judge Considers Case of Mel Gibson’s Leaky Court File
text: LOS ANGELES — At a hastily called session here on Friday, a family court judge was briefed by lawyers in the Mel Gibson paternity case about what appeared to be information leaked from a confidential court file to the Web site TMZ.com.

headline: Zest, Heat and Aroma, by the Jar, Pouch or Bin
text: HUNTINGTON STATION, N.Y.

headline: Using Root Vegetables Raw
text: The end of warm weather doesn’t mean the end of fresh, local, even raw vegetables. Check out this week’s Minimalist column and see how to use fall vegetables like beets, Brussels sprouts and butternut squash in simple, raw dishes. You might even want them on your table at Thanksgiving.

headline: With Words on Muslims, Opening a Door Long Shut
text: BERLIN

headline: An Affordable Lunch on a Day of Culture
text: This spinoff of Marc Murphy’s Landmarc bistro in TriBeCa opened in 2007 and offers one of the few reasonably priced dining options at the Time Warner Center, home to some of the city’s most expensive restaurants. Furnished in sleek dark wood and glass, the room overlooks the foot of Central Park and attracts a lively crowd of tourists, shoppers, Lincoln Center patrons and media insiders with its French- and Italian-inspired menu. On Wednesday, the diners included two friends in town for one of their regular cultural excursions.

headline: From Pornography to Real Estate Mogul
text: “I HAVE never made a deal in the rain,” said Fredrik Eklund, standing in bright sunlight in a $2.8 million apartment on the Bowery that offered 360-degree views of seemingly every landmark in New York City. “People need to see a place in good weather to appreciate it.”

headline: To Greenmarket, to Greenmarket
text: Leonard Lopate is the host of a radio talk show,  covering subjects like crafting and quantum physics,  that is broadcast every weekday from noon to 2 p.m. on WNYC. Mr. Lopate, 70, spends Sundays with his girlfriend, Melanie Baker, an artist with whom he lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. That is the day that they usually restock the pantry with a visit to the local greenmarket and split the chores — and share the crossword puzzle. SARAH MASLIN NIR

headline: Flu Shots: No Panic, Just ‘No’
text: Was it only last year that flu shots were the latest have-to-have-one, don’t-know-where-to-get-one obscure object of consumer desire? With fears of an H1N1 pandemic on the horizon, the city even busted out the PODs — “points of distribution” designed to be activated during public health crises like bioterrorism or nuclear fallout.

headline: Hard Times in Camden
text: The South Jersey city of Camden has long been a national symbol of urban blight.

headline: In Camden, New Troubles on Top of Old
text: CAMDEN, N.J.  This city closed its dilapidated central library in the 1980s and never provided the money for restoration or demolition. So the landmark building rots on its weed-choked lot, with most of the roof caved in and a large tree growing up through its middle. “It could be a metaphor for the city,” said Jerome Szpila, the city library director.

headline: 101 Quick and Simple Dishes for Fall
text: The filmmaker Gary Leib's animated recommendations for the best meals to make at home this season.

headline: Dropping the Balls
text: THE cast of the Big Apple Circus burst into the tent for the show’s opening number, clad in confetti-bright colors. The big band’s trumpets shrilled, and the performers separated by gender into Sharks- and Jets-style packs, snapping and dancing.

headline: Kanye West Was Coached for ‘Today’ Interview Gone Awry
text: Kanye West can usually be counted on to say what’s on his mind, but the rapper had some extra help formulating those thoughts when he was interviewed on NBC’s “Today” show this week: he hired the public relations firm Rubenstein Communications to coach him on his response to former President George W. Bush, and the firm and the rapper are no longer working together following Mr. West’s feud with “Today,” according to several people familiar with the arrangements of the interview.

headline: Queso Fundido With Chorizo, Jalapeño and Cilantro
text: Time: 25 minutes

headline: A Dip to Sustain the Cook Till Thanksgiving Dinner
text: FOR the cook, Thanksgiving Day lunch is usually had standing over the stove  maybe a handful of chips, a few crackers, or marshmallows that haven’t been baked into casseroles or pie, a nibble on a fingernail and a few swallows (or glasses) of wine. Who has time to eat when there’s a mountain of food to cook?

headline: Shunning Life as a Performer, to Write the Songs
text: Old Brookville, N.Y.

headline: Wallenberg’s Heroism Becomes a Musical
text: Annette Jolles says that until seven years ago she knew almost nothing about Raoul Wallenberg.

headline: Bored at Work? Try Creepypasta, or Web Scares
text: THERE is a video gaining steam on YouTube called “The Scariest Picture on the Internet (REAL).” Aside from a short introduction, the bulk consists of a single, still image of a painting set to ominous music.

headline: The Perils of Psychoanalyzing Mugabe
text: Imagine a modern-day Macbeth, haunted by the ghost of Banquo, attempting to sort out his blood-stained fears with the help of a therapist.

headline: The Pinks and Purples of an Exotic Eden
text: In the 18th century, artists went to Rome. Or, if they could afford it, on a whole Grand Tour of Europe. By the 19th century, art travel had gone global: the French painter Eugène Delacroix went to North Africa, the Americans Frederic Church and Winslow Homer to South America and the Caribbean. And John La Farge, a New Yorker who grew up in a French-speaking family, headed for the South Pacific, spending nearly a year there before Gauguin had even arrived.

headline: Playing Favorites, Day and Night
text: PAZ DE LA HUERTA, 26  an actress (most recently in “Boardwalk Empire” on HBO); a SoHo native; a model and a muse to Zac Posen, the designer and a fellow St. Ann’s alumnus  recently shared a week of wardrobe changes with Chloe Malle, who conducted and condensed this interview.

headline: To Dad, Life Is a Game, a Really Ugly One
text: The teenager’s-dad character in Howard Meyer’s “Welcome: This Is a Neighborhood Watch Community” has a name, Harris Campbell, but I like to think of him simply as Hedge Fund Guy. Maybe it’s the way his eyes light up during a telephone conversation when he says, “You think we have grounds?” For Hedge Fund Guy, life is just a series of opportunities to sue, cheat or generally get the better of his fellow man. As played by David Deblinger, he is effectively unlikable from Day 1.

headline: This Time, Cavett Answers the Questions
text: “HOW did that happen?” Dick Cavett asked, sounding amused, and a bit surprised, as he contemplated the date of his upcoming appearance on Friday at the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: A Dance Display to Remember
text: JULIA RITTER, chairwoman of the dance department at the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, compares the school’s DancePlus Fall event to a historic rock show.

headline: Rebuilding Lags in Pakistan Area After Offensive
text: DRUSHKHELA, Pakistan  People here felt a surge of optimism last year when the military declared the Swat Valley cleared of Taliban insurgents, who had bullied their way to power by publicly whipping and beheading opponents.

headline: Lost Generation in Swat Valley
text: The Pakistani government has yet to rebuild any of the 159 fully destroyed schools that were bombed by the Taliban. As a result, students are furious.

headline: The State of Schools in Swat
text: What happens to a generation of students who miss two to three years of school because of war?

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: In this Sunday’s Travel section, Seth Kugel tries to visit Los Angeles on $100 a day. Turns out the best way to do that is on two wheels, on a rented bike. The trip “afforded me a more unfiltered view of Los Angeles than I would have gotten behind the wheel,” he wrote, “buffered from my surroundings by a windshield and a loud radio.”

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Acquisition of Tina Brown
text: The partnership of Newsweek and The Daily Beast may be billed as a simple 50-50 joint venture, but many agree that the real target for the struggling weekly magazine is Tina Brown.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Crunch Time in the SEC
text: There is plenty happening off the field in the Southeastern Conference, but on the field Saturday there is no bigger game than South Carolina at Florida. The Gamecocks, led by Steve Spurrier, will head into the Swamp against the resurgent Gators. Whichever team is victorious will be the champion of the SEC East and secure a spot in the conference championship game. On the other side of the SEC, Alabama will try to get back on the winning track when it takes on Mississippi State, which has rapidly improved under Dan Mullen. In other action, Missouri will look to remain in second place in the Big 12 North when it hosts Kansas State, Syracuse hopes to become bowl eligible when it travels to Rutgers, and Florida State and Clemson face off in a key Atlantic Coast Conference Atlantic Division game.

headline: In the Remote Pacific, Glimpses of Pristine Corals
text: Thursday, Nov. 4

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Prudential Sells Stock to Raise $1 Billion
text: Prudential Financial sold stock at $54.50 a share, below Thursday’s closing price, to raise about $1 billion to help pay for two units it is buying from the American International Group. Prudential sold more than 18.3 million shares, according to Bloomberg. Prudential agreed on Sept. 30 to buy AIG Star Life Insurance and AIG Edison Life Insurance, two Japanese businesses, for $4.8 billion.

headline: The Ways of Empathy
text: It seems that just about everybody has had experience with babies or bullies — or both. Which is why the commentary that followed this week’s Fixes column about Roots of Empathy — an organization that decreases bullying by bringing babies into school classrooms — was so rich, personal and detailed. At the end of the column, I asked readers if they had ideas for ways to reduce bullying. Many offered suggestions about organizations, techniques and books (some of which I list at the bottom of this column), but many more readers reflected on their own experiences having witnessed bullying or the surprising effect babies can have on children and teenagers.Christine, from Montpelier, Vt., (35), recounted her experiences driving a school bus accompanied by her baby boy in a car seat behind her. When necessary, she would place “unruly students” ─ mostly in grades four through eight ─ near her, as well. “[T]hey started to ask to sit in the front … so that they could play and read and talk to him during the ride. I observed that they softened and gentled with my son and seemed to feel safe expressing that tender side of their natures.”

headline: Gov. Perry to Lead Republican Governors
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, the country’s longest-serving governor, expects to be named the new chairman of the Republican Governors Association, his spokesman said Friday afternoon.

headline: A Relentless Opponent Stalks the Locker Room
text: On Saturday, when Penn plays Harvard at Franklin Field, much will be the same as a year ago. A share of the Ivy League title will be at stake  Harvard (4-1 in the league) must beat Penn (5-0) to get the tie  and the teams return 26 starters combined.

headline: Quad Q&A: Siena’s Ryan Rossiter
text: The Siena senior Ryan Rossiter was named the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference preseason player of the year last month. When the Saints’ season begins Saturday against Vermont, Rossiter, a Staten Island native, will attempt to become the program’s third straight postseason player of the year, following Kenny Hasbrouck and Alex Franklin. “Tenacious, intelligent, hard worker” was how Siena Coach Mitch Buonaguro described Rossiter at the league’s media day, adding that he was a “terrific person” and a “wonderful player to coach.”

headline: Training Grounds for a Chancellor?
text: A COMMON complaint from teachers is that people believe they are experts in education just because they once went to school. Cathleen P. Black, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s choice to head the New York City school system, has less direct experience working in education than any chancellor or superintendent in a major city in memory. But she, too, has been to school. Here is a look at three schools Ms. Black knows best:

headline: Facebook to Start an E-Mail Service
text: Facebook has more than 500 million users around the world. And Americans spend more of their time online with Facebook than with any other Internet company, including Google and Yahoo.

headline: On His First Day, Iraq’s Parliament Speaker Was Tested by Own Alliance
text: BAGHDAD  It was not long after Osama al-Najafi officially became the top Sunni politician in Iraq that he faced his first crisis: dozens of Sunni lawmakers abruptly walked out of Parliament.

headline: Mayor Will Push Senators to Pass 9/11 Health Bill
text: Hoping to generate last-minute momentum for a long-stalled health care bill for ground zero rescue workers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to travel to Washington next week to lobby several crucial Republican senators who are believed to be undecided.

headline: Myth of Baseball’s Creation Endures, With a Prominent Fan
text: The old chestnut about Abner Doubleday’s inventing baseball in a cow pasture in upstate New York has been so thoroughly debunked that it has taken a position in the pantheon of great American myths, alongside George Washington’s cherry tree, Paul Bunyan and Johnny Appleseed.

headline: How Cities Pick School Chiefs, for All to See
text: It is not always pretty. It may resemble a beauty pageant or a paintball contest more than a government exercise to determine how to go about educating a generation of children. But despite the unusual secrecy surrounding New York City’s recent search for a convention-defying schools chancellor, other cities have managed to get unorthodox results through more orthodox means.

headline: Scotland Yard Move Stirs Questions on Phone-Hacking Case
text: LONDON  Scotland Yard said Friday that it had sent a new file on allegations of phone hacking by the newspaper The News of the World to the Crown Prosecution Service, which reviews police files for possible criminal prosecutions. The newspaper, one of Britain’s most highly circulated publications, is owned by News International, part of Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire.

headline: Two More Defendants in Galleon Case to Cooperate
text: Thomas Hardin and Franz Tudor, two defendants in the Galleon Group insider-trading case, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors after pleading guilty last year to conspiracy and securities fraud, the United States attorney’s office said. Mr. Hardin is a former trader at Lanexa Global Management. Mr. Tudor worked at Galleon. The Securities and Exchange Commission said it sued Mr. Hardin, Lanexa and Mr. Tudor over insider trading that netted profits of about $715,000. More than 20 people have been charged in two insider trading cases involving the Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Homeless, but Hoping for a Return to College
text: Like many people his age, Steve Demain checks his Facebook page, reads the news, writes e-mails and surfs the Web on his laptop. But unlike a typical 20-year-old with a laptop, Mr. Demain is homeless.

headline: The Burning Bush They’ll Buy, but Not ESP or Alien Abduction
text: Practically anything goes at the American Academy of Religion’s annual conference, where scholars of dozens of religions convene annually to debate, relate and on occasion mate. Conversation ranges from the Talmud to tantra, from Platonism to Satanism. This year, from Oct. 30 to Nov. 1 in Atlanta, nearly 5,000 people attended panels including “Seeking New Meanings of God and Dao” and “Madness, Smallpox, and Death in Tibet.”

headline: Focusing on Next Step, Tea Party Rallies Congressional Freshmen

headline: France: National Railway Apologizes for Its Role in Deporting Jews in War
text: France’s national railway, the S.N.C.F., has issued its first public apology for its involvement in the deportation of tens of thousands of Jews to Nazi death camps during World War II. Guillaume Pepy, left, the railway’s director, expressed the company’s “profound sorrow and regret for the consequences of its acts” in a statement released last week but first reported Friday. “The Nazis and their French (Vichy) collaborators directed these terrible actions, determining the composition of the trains, the types of wagons and even the train schedules,” Mr. Pepy said. The statement, published in English, came after lawmakers in California and Florida moved to block the S.N.C.F. from winning contracts for high-speed rail projects in their states if it did not recognize its role in the Holocaust. From 1941 to 1944, the S.N.C.F. shipped 76,000 French and other European Jews to the French-German border in 76 railcars originally designed for cattle. German trains later took the prisoners to Nazi death camps.

headline: Russia: Brutally Beaten Journalist Regains Consciousness, Wife Says
text: Oleg Kashin, 30, a journalist savagely beaten a week ago, regained consciousness on Friday, though he was still breathing on a ventilator, his wife said. Mr. Kashin, a reporter for the daily newspaper Kommersant, was attacked by two men outside his apartment. They used a metal club hidden in a bouquet of flowers. “His grip is strong,” Mr. Kashin’s wife, Yevgenia Milova, wrote on her Facebook page. About 400 protesters gathered Thursday to demand that Mr. Kashin’s assailants be found, and opposition groups were planning another event on Saturday. State-controlled television devoted unusual attention all week to the attack on Mr. Kashin, and President Dmitri A. Medvedev told reporters that the assailants would be found “no matter who is behind it  right-wing, left-wing or centrist forces.”

headline: Newsweek’s Printing Press Was a Top Draw for Diller

headline: Ireland: Vatican Sending Team to Check Effectiveness of Its Response to Abuse
text: The Vatican offered new details on Friday about its investigation into how effective its response to the sexual abuse scandals in Ireland has been. It said it was sending a team of prelates and nuns to four archdioceses in Ireland to verify that procedures instated to respond to abuse cases and assist victims have been effective. The team, it said, would not interfere with the activity of local officials or commissions set up by the Irish Parliament after the government issued two scathing reports of systematic abuse by clergy members and a widespread cover-up.

headline: 3 Republicans Say Report on Spill Was Manipulated
text: WASHINGTON  Three Republican senators demanded Friday that the White House explain last-minute editing changes to an Interior Department report on the BP oil spill that falsely implied that a group of independent experts had endorsed a political decision to temporarily halt all deepwater oil drilling.

headline: Lincoln’s Mailbag
text: The election of Nov. 6 was big news, to put it mildly. In the days following, newspaper headlines screamed it from one city to another, across the not very united states. As Adam Goodheart wrote earlier, the telegraph allowed the results to be known nearly as quickly as we would know today. Now, thanks to another marvel of technology — the Internet — we can see the private telegrams and letters that Lincoln himself was seeing, as Americans exhaled and realized, to their amazement, that he had pulled it off. In the days following the verdict, an enormous range of Americans, from all walks of life, wrote to their president-elect to express their feelings about where the country was headed. These letters present a remarkable documentary portrait of a nation at a crossroads.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Files Suit Against M.L.B.
text: Budweiser’s decades-long connection to Major League Baseball frayed Friday when the giant brewer’s parent company, Anheuser-Busch, alleged in a federal lawsuit that baseball reneged on an agreement reached earlier this year to extend the beer maker’s sponsorship.

headline: Colleges Reporting Rise in Early Applications
text: With some colleges permitting students to wait until Nov. 15 to file early applications for next year’s freshman class, it is too soon to draw broad conclusions on whether such programs continue to grow in popularity over all. And yet, those selective colleges with Nov. 1 deadlines are beginning to release results. Among those with binding early decision programs  in which those applying have consented to attend if admitted  Northwestern is reporting that early applications increased by 24 percent, to about 2,100, when compared with last year; submissions to the University of Pennsylvania are up 18 percent, to 4,557; Duke and Johns Hopkins are each up by nearly 14 percent, having received 2,282 and 1,314 applications, respectively, and Rice is up about 15 percent, with about 1,000 early applications. Among colleges with nonbinding early action programs  in which those accepted can wait until spring to make their decisions  early applications to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are up about 15 percent; the University of Chicago, 18.5 percent; Georgetown, nearly 9 percent, and Boston College, 7 percent. For a more complete, running tally, go to nytimes.com/thechoice.

headline: The Trouble With Long-Term Care Insurance

headline: Russia: President Seems to Confirm Report on Ring of Sleeper Spies
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Friday appeared to confirm a report in a Russian newspaper that said that the United States had arrested a ring of Russian sleeper spies in June based on information from a senior Russian official who later defected. The newspaper, Kommersant, reported on Thursday that the official had worked in Russia’s Foreign Intelligence Service. Asked about the article at the Group of 20 meeting in South Korea, Mr. Medvedev did not dispute it, saying that it was not news to him. He declined to say how the government would respond to the security lapse, but said that an inquiry was under way. “The relevant lessons will be learned,” Mr. Medvedev said.

headline: Henryk Gorecki, Polish Composer, Is Dead at 76
text: Henryk Gorecki, a renowned Polish composer whose early avant-garde style gave way to more approachable works rooted in his country’s folk songs and sacred music and whose Symphony No. 3  an extended lamentation subtitled “Symphony of Sorrowful Songs”  sold more than a million copies on CD in the 1990s, died on Friday in Katowice, Poland. headline: After Party’s Rout, a Blue Dog Won’t Back Down

In fewer than two seasons  and after a few too many interceptions  he was replaced as the team’s starting quarterback. ESPN described him as one of the all-time draft busts.

headline: In Japan, Volleyball Leaps to a Nationwide Passion
text: TOKYO  When Yoshie Takeshita of Japan goes up to block spikers 40 centimeters (16 inches) taller, she is lifted by an arena full of fans chanting her name and a banner in Japanese telling her, “159 cm is awesome.”

headline: Iraqi Lawmakers Approve an Outline for Power Sharing
text: BAGHDAD  A day after one of Iraq’s leading politicians declared on television that power sharing was dead, the nation’s fractious parties all met in a tranquil session of Parliament on Saturday, where they approved an outline for forming a partnership government. The session proceeded even though the politician, Ayad Allawi, had announced that his bloc would not participate in the government.

text: “Isn’t loyalty a two-way street?”

headline: A Calmer Market? Not for Long Bonds
text: AN implicit goal of the Federal Reserve’s plan to buy $600 billion in Treasury debt is to stabilize the market. But this unconventional plan may mean even greater uncertainty for at least one group of investors: those who own long-term government bonds.

headline: San Francisco School Administrators Schemed to Take Money, Documents Say
text: A group of San Francisco Unified School District administrators, including an associate superintendent, engaged in a long-running scheme to funnel district money into their personal bank accounts via nonprofit community organizations, according to internal documents.

headline: A Curtain Call, Please, in the Skies
text: AS longtime readers know, the Haggler spends most of his time hectoring companies about their flaws and incompetence, but that doesn’t mean he is oblivious to superb service. Indeed, the Haggler likes to think of himself as a connoisseur of superb service  and, every once in a while, he celebrates it.

headline: Indonesia Resists the Anti-Smoking Tide Elsewhere
text: The video of a chain-smoking 2-year-old boy in Indonesia went viral last spring, making the country an abject poster child for unbridled cigarette use among its young citizens. The pudgy little boy, Ardi Rizal, smoked up to two packs a day, and his parents, who had started him at 18 months, said he threw tantrums if denied. Recently he went through rehabilitation, NBC reported in a segment this month.

headline: Zsolt Erdei, Hungarian Boxer, Makes Comeback
text: Zsolt Erdei wished his wife and 4-year-old son a good night, put down his cellphone and picked up a lunch menu at Andre’s Cafe, a tiny Hungarian restaurant on the Upper East Side.

headline: Commander in Iraq Assesses Foe and Friend
text: BAGHDAD — The senior American military commander in Iraq, Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III, said on Saturday that the Sunni insurgency in Iraq had “an impressive ability to regenerate capability here,” despite American and Iraqi successes targeting the leadership and financing of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia and other terrorist networks.

headline: Cigarette Giants in Global Fight on Tighter Rules
text: As sales to developing nations become ever more important to giant tobacco companies, they are stepping up efforts around the world to fight tough restrictions on the marketing of cigarettes.

headline: Attack on Russian Journalist Stirs Online Allies
text: MOSCOW — Two years ago, Oleg Kashin was sitting in a sleek little coffee shop around the corner from the Kremlin when a novelist walked in and punched him in the face.

headline: Neptune on a Shortboard
text: Four days before Kelly Slater won a record 10th world surfing title this month in Puerto Rico, his chief rival, the three-time world champion Andy Irons, was found dead in a Dallas hotel room at age 32.

headline: A Life in the Mine (Canary Not Included)
text: I WORK at the Elk Creek Mine, 40 miles from my home in Delta, Colo. I come from a small community where many of the girls in my high school class chose the health care field. That path never appealed to me. Growing up, I was a tomboy and hung out mostly with the guys. I’m athletic, and I played rough. I’ve never been afraid to get dirt under my nails, so no one who knows me was surprised that I went into mining.

headline: The Hungarian Connection
text: MY grandparents emigrated from a small farming village in Transylvania, part of Romania, to Budapest, Hungary, a bustling city. My parents moved from Hungary to Sweden. I’ve lived in five countries besides the United States.

headline: Taking Care in Raising a Rookie
text: The cautionary tale will be just across the field from Sam Bradford on Sunday. Like the Rams’ Bradford, the 49ers’ Alex Smith was chosen first in his N.F.L. draft class and freighted with the enormous financial and emotional investments that franchises make in bright young quarterbacks.

headline: Browns’ Unnamed Quarterback Shapes Up as No Mystery to the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It did not make headlines because he did not wear a blond wig and have a pillow under his T-shirt at the time, but Rex Ryan took a little shot last week at Eric Mangini, his ever-cautious predecessor as the Jets’ coach.

headline: Pointed Words From Rolle Help to Sharpen Focus
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  They were 12 minutes 58 seconds that pivoted the Giants’ season, but safety Antrel Rolle has said all along that he was just speaking his mind.

headline: NATO Seeks Afghan Police in the South
text: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  Gen. David H. Petraeus, the overall commander of coalition forces in Afghanistan, is moving to sharply increase Afghan police forces drawn from villages in southern provinces, and is employing the help of former mujahedeen commanders to recruit them, NATO officials said.

headline: He Stars for Duke, but He’s Not Detested
text: DURHAM, N.C.  As the most valuable player in the N.C.A.A.’s Final Four, co-captain of the defending national champion and a leading candidate for player of the year in 2010-11, Kyle Singler no doubt tops all college basketball players in magazine cover shots this fall.
