text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: A Memorable Line, Fact or Fable, Lives On in Legend
text: The fictional character Huckleberry Finn assessed Mark Twain, the author who created him, by noting, “There was things which he stretched, but mainly he told the truth.”

headline: A Gay Nascar Fan Is Finding a Growing Audience Online
text: Michael Myers grew up in Spartanburg, S.C., the middle of Nascar country, but his parents were not stock-car-racing fans, so he was not one, either. He went to his first race, the 1998 Coca-Cola 600 at Charlotte Motor Speedway, because he received free tickets.

headline: O.K., You Fix the Budget
text: Imagine that Democrats and Republicans somehow came together and agreed on a grand bargain to cut the deficit.

headline: Behind The Times’s Deficit Project
text: My column that’s running with The Times’s new interactive deficit puzzle offers some detail about the methodology behind the project. This post will provide much more detail. (There is also a collection of posts on the project.) As the calculator says, we encourage readers to come up with their own deficit solution and post it online.

headline: In One Moment in Afghanistan, Heroism and Heartbreak
text: Three years and three weeks ago. Dusk was falling fast on the Korengal Valley. We were crouched on a shrub-laden plateau some 8,000 feet up in the mountains. The soldiers were exhausted and cold. We’d been sleeping in ditches for five nights. Insurgents were everywhere.

headline: Who Will Stand Up to the Superrich?
text: IN the aftermath of the Great Democratic Shellacking of 2010, one election night subplot quickly receded into the footnotes: the drubbing received by very wealthy Americans, most of them Republican, who tried to buy Senate seats and governor’s mansions. Americans don’t hate rich people. They admire and often idolize success. But Californians took a hearty dislike to Meg Whitman, who sacrificed $143 million of her eBay fortune  not to mention her undocumented former housekeeper  to a gubernatorial race she lost by double digits. Connecticut voters K.O.’d the World Wrestling groin-kicker, Linda McMahon, and West Virginians did likewise to the limestone-and-steel magnate John Raese, the senatorial hopeful who told an interviewer without apparent irony, “I made my money the old-fashioned way  I inherited it.”

headline: Sirens, Egyptian and Equine
text: It has not been a stellar year for women in politics.

headline: A Star College Quarterback Is Worth ...
text: Revelations that the father of Cam Newton, Auburn University’s star quarterback and a leading Heisman Trophy candidate, may have sought as much as $200,000 from recruiters has reignited the debate over whether college athletes ought to be paid.

headline: Suu Kyi's Release Sparks Celebration
text: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi appeared before the crowd of thousands outside her home in Myanmar, waving and taking flowers from supporters on the day of her release from house arrest.

headline: I Believe I Can Fly
text: Reading the headlines these days, I can’t help but repeat this truism: If you jump off the top of an 80-story building, for 79 floors you can think you’re flying. It’s the sudden stop at the end that tells you you’re not. It’s striking to me how many leaders and nations are behaving today as though they think they can fly  and ignoring that sudden stop at the end that’s sure to come.

headline: Here’s a Woman Fighting Terrorism. With Microloans.

headline: French Cabinet Quits to Prepare for Reshuffling
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, beginning a long-postponed reshuffle of his government, on Saturday accepted the resignation of Prime Minister François Fillon and his cabinet.

headline: Urban Forager | One Tasty City Mushroom
text: Each fall brings up new unexpected surprises in the city for the amateur mycologist: hen-of-the-woods mushrooms growing under giant oak trees; a patch of honey mushrooms sprouting within throwing distance of unsuspecting joggers; giant puffballs sitting on Brooklyn hillsides. A few weeks ago I started discovering enoki mushrooms — first on tree stumps in upper Manhattan, then again on Staten Island.

headline: Two Decades in Confinement
text: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy opposition leader in Myanmar, has spent 15 of the last 21 years under arrest.

headline: Next, the Skull and Crossbones
text: Imagining the dire warning labels of the future. Three takes.

headline: Reader Comments on Microfinance in Pakistan
text: My Sunday column is about Roshaneh Zafar and her microfinance organization, Kashf, in Pakistan. I’ve been frustrated to see so much American money pouring into the Pakistani army, accomplishing nothing as far as I can see, while economic development has been starved. As I wrote in my previous column, the best way for America to create jobs and promote the business sector in Pakistan would be to ease tariff barriers on Pakistani garment exports (Pakistan is a huge manufacturer of socks and similar products). But economic development programs like Kashf are also a mechanism to create jobs, boost civil society and undermine extremism.

headline: Try Something Hard: Governing
text: Many Americans who voted this fall expressed a deep mistrust of government. House Republicans’ triumphalist vows to tie up the Obama administration with nonstop investigations and obstructionist budget crimping are not going to allay those voters’ concerns  or solve any of the country’s problems.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Fighting Words
text: As the Obama administration was trying to revive Israel-Palestinian negotiations, Israeli plans to build 1,000 units of housing on contested land in East Jerusalem became widely known last week. The plans were published by Israel Nov. 5 and were widely reported on Monday by an Israeli newspaper.

headline: A Journey From Lawmaker to Lobbyist and Back Again
text: WASHINGTON  When Cooper Industries, a century-old manufacturing company based in Texas, moved its headquarters to Bermuda to slash its American income tax bill, it had to turn to a Washington insider with extraordinary contacts to soothe a seething Congress.

headline: Where Will the G.O.P. Go Digging?
text: WITH the Republican takeover of the House, Representative Darrell Issa of California will become the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, Capitol Hill’s top watchdog panel. As the lead Republican on the panel the last two years, Mr. Issa, a hard-charging, quick-witted former car-alarm company owner, has been the Obama administration’s most aggressive antagonist on spending under the $787 billion economic stimulus package. Starting in January, armed with the power to call hearings and issue subpoenas, he will play lead conductor to the new majority’s other committee chairmen in investigating what he says is a “long list” of oversight targets.

headline: What the Director Needs
text: James Clapper Jr., the relatively new director of national intelligence, is trying to claim the authority that the independent Sept. 11 commission said was essential to protecting the United States. Speaking at a conference this month, he disclosed a “conceptual agreement” with Defense Secretary Robert Gates to take over $53 billion of the $80 billion annual intelligence budget that has long been the Pentagon’s domain.

headline: After Midterms, Even Opposites Can Sound Alike

headline: The Faces Change for the Knicks, but the Results Don’t
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donnie Walsh, the Knicks’ president, envisioned a struggle, but witnessing it was a whole different matter. The Knicks, he said on Saturday, are still a work in progress, which has been the case for what feels like an eternity.

headline: Democrats Reach Accord on Leadership in the House
text: WASHINGTON  Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina agreed Saturday to fill a new leadership position when Democrats become the House minority party next year, averting a fight that threatened to divide lawmakers still reeling from severe midterm election losses.

headline: Richard Bing, Pioneering Heart Researcher, Dies at 101
text: Dr. Richard J. Bing, a pioneering cardiologist whose research led to new understandings of blood flow, congenital heart disease and the mechanics of the heart, died on Monday at his home in La Cañada, Calif. He was 101.

headline: Spokes | A Struggle to Stay Upright (and Cool)
text: I know how to ride a bike. I’ve been doing it for about 25 years now. But I recently found myself wobbling down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, trying to get the knack of pedaling again. I was riding, or at least trying to ride, while practically lying down.

headline: Penn Tops Harvard for Share of Ivy Title
text: PHILADELPHIA  Pennsylvania won at least a share of its 15th Ivy League championship Saturday by routing Harvard, 34-14, but Quakers Coach Al Bagnoli made sure to point out afterward that this had not been just another championship season.

headline: Now, Will China Get It?
text: American economic leadership seems to be on its heels. At the meeting of 20 leading economies in Seoul last week, China resisted Washington’s demands to stop manipulating its currency and rallied Germany and Brazil to criticize the Federal Reserve’s plan to inject billions into the economy. G-20 leaders also shrugged off an American proposal to set targets to reduce trade surpluses and deficits, calling instead for vague guidelines.

headline: Deaths in County Jails Raise Calls for Health Care Standards
text: Robert Foster did not budge when a Gregg County jailer slid open the bean hole to deliver his lunch one day last August. The obese inmate was sprawled on the floor, his breakfast untouched. When the jailer opened the door, a stench wafted out of the cell. Mr. Foster’s flesh was cold. He had no pulse.

headline: Psychologist in Terror War Is Subject of Complaint
text: The decision about whether an architect of Bush-era interrogation tactics will keep his license as a psychologist is in the hands of a Texas government agency.

headline: Texas G.O.P.’s Inescapable Truth: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is Us
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Pat’s Pick
text: I admit I was dubious. Parking near an elevated section of Interstate 10 and picking my way along a sketchy, near-downtown Houston street, I was on the verge of backpedaling when I got my bearings: Oh, I recognize these warehouse lofts and art studios. Stepping into Latin Bites Café, I found a jubilant mood, as customers chatted and sipped their B.Y.O.B. wine. There’s nothing like stumbling on a cool hole-in-the-wall to make you feel smug.

text: With the Mets looking to conduct their second round of interviews for managerial candidates next week at the general managers’ meetings in Orlando, Fla., Terry Collins and Bob Melvin are expected to get callback interviews, and they may be the only ones who get them.

headline: Auburn Ignores Allegations and Steamrolls Over Georgia
text: AUBURN, Ala.  Auburn quarterback Cam Newton has been stalked by news reports that his father shopped him to Mississippi State, asking for money for his son to play football. The rumors seemed to be everywhere over the past two weeks, except inside Jordan-Hare Stadium.

headline: As Glaciers Melt, Science Seeks Data on Rising Seas
text: TASIILAQ, Greenland — With a tense pilot gripping the stick, the helicopter hovered above the water, a red speck of machinery lost in a wilderness of rock and ice.

headline: Reading Earth’s Future in Glacial Ice
text: Researchers have been startled to see signs of rapid melting in Greenland and Antarctica, but lack data to precisely calculate how much flooding could result.

headline: Thought of Shifting Police Officers Reopens Debate
text: As city elections approach, Superintendent Jody Weis’s proposal to shift more police officers to crime-ridden areas has reignited an intense debate among aldermen.

headline: A Nighttime Epiphany on Sea Level
text: As I report in Sunday’s Times, many climate scientists are frustrated by the lack of good information about the status of the world’s land ice. Yet they have nonetheless come to an informal consensus about the extent to which the sea may rise in the course of this century: roughly three feet.

headline: Win Over Amherst Is Perfect for Williams
text: For Williams, a season could not end any better.

headline: Q. and A. With Brian Leetch
text: Brian Leetch helped the Rangers win the Stanley Cup in 1994, when he became the only American-born player to win the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the N.H.L. playoffs. He was twice awarded the Norris Trophy as the league’s top defenseman and was inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame in Minnesota in 2008 and the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto in 2009.

headline: Under a New Scoring System, Fewer Ties and Drawn Games
text: A two-year-old scoring system may be the solution to two problems that have long bedeviled chess.

headline: Obama Calls Arms Treaty a Priority
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan  President Obama ended a 10-day diplomatic and economic journey through Asia on a personal note Sunday, visiting a colossal copper Buddha that he had seen as a 6-year-old boy, then headed for Washington to confront the lame-duck Congress on Monday. He told President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia here that his “top priority” on foreign policy for the Congressional session is ratification of their new arms control treaty, which is stalled in the Senate.

headline: With Sound Investments, Harp Company Endures
text: In a recession that shuttered longtime manufacturers, reshaped whole industries and sent millions of people looking for work, one might expect a company that makes $100,000 harps to be wobbling at the knees, if not toppled over by now.

headline: Mayor Daley Pitches Chicago in Asia, but Who Is Buying?
text: Soon after announcing he would not run for another term, Mayor Richard M. Daley went on a trip to Asia that he said was aimed at rounding up investors for infrastructure projects in the city.

headline: Exposé Hits Hard at Death Penalty System
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

headline: Love and Dirty, Sexy Ducats
text: They belong to worlds that, in the normal course of events, would never intersect. But Shakespeare, as the creator of their universe, saw fit to let their paths cross just once. And when Portia finally meets Shylock, in Daniel Sullivan’s absolutely splendid production of “The Merchant of Venice” at the Broadhurst Theater, the collision lights up the sky.

headline: Raw Statistics Belie a Crackdown on Gangs
text: On West Street in North Oakland, a short residential block within the borders of Oakland’s gang injunction zone, a bloodstain marks a spot on the sidewalk where a woman was killed last month in a drive-by shooting.

headline: Twain Found His Calling in San Francisco Stories
text: Gary Kamiya wrote this clumn for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Winfield Street Slides
text: Hidden by trees near Esmeralda Avenue in Bernal Heights is a semi-secret joy ride where daredevils can propel themselves. The adjoining 40-foot Winfield Street Slides were constructed by local volunteers in the late 1970s, with city assistance.

headline: Two Candidates Stand Out in Mets’ Search
text: With the Mets looking to conduct their second round of interviews for managerial candidates this week at the general managers’ meetings in Orlando, Fla., Terry Collins and Bob Melvin are expected to get callback interviews, and they may be the only ones who get them.

headline: Councilman Opposes Appointee for Schools
text: The head of the City Council’s education committee and a vocal critic of mayoral control is now speaking out against the mayor’s choice of Cathleen P. Black to oversee New York City schools.

headline: Lone Isaksen Dies at 68; Dancer of Fierce Elegance
text: Lone Isaksen, a Danish-born ballerina who brought a distinctive mix of traditional classical training and fierce projection to contemporary works in American companies like the Harkness Ballet and the Joffrey Ballet, died on Nov. 2 at her home in Manhattan. She was 68.

headline: Netanyahu Agrees to Push for Freeze in Settlements
text: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has agreed to push his cabinet to freeze most construction on settlements in the West Bank for 90 days to break an impasse in peace negotiations with the Palestinians, an official briefed on talks between the United States and Israel said Saturday evening.

headline: Vows: Jeremy & Antonette
text: Jeremy Cohen and Antonette Balestreri met in college as aspiring artists. They fell in love while performing and creating a musical together.  Ever since, theater and music has inspired their romance.

headline: Philip Carlo, Who Wrote About Killers, Dies at 61
text: Philip Carlo, who produced novels and nonfiction accounts of serial killers and hit men before writing about his own struggles with disease, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 61.

headline: Oregon Holds Off California to Stay Perfect
text: BERKELEY, Calif.  There are quirks to a football game at the University of California that make it a quintessential Berkeley experience. There is an announcement before the game advising fans where to exit in case of an earthquake. And on a knoll perched over Memorial Stadium  known as Tightwad Hill for fans considered too cheap to buy tickets  the fans watching the game are known to produce plumes of marijuana smoke.

headline: Robbins Barstow, Home-Movie Maven, Dies at 91
text: Robbins Barstow, a Connecticut man who, movie camera whirring, documented every aspect of his family’s life for decades, yielding a vast body of work that formed the cornerstone of the recent home-movie revival and has lately garnered a huge following online, died on Nov. 7 at his home in Hartford. He was 91 and previously lived in Wethersfield, Conn.

headline: College Football Replay: Nov. 13
text: The week in college football saw a star performance by Auburn’s embattled quarterback and a rare win from Notre Dame.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 14
text: Expect a healthy helping of lame-duck politics and fiscal discipline on this week’s talk shows, with a side of nostalgia. Continuing to promote his new book, former President George W. Bush appears on CNN Sunday evening.

headline: Bruising Win by Pacquiao Pits Speed Over Size
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As Manny Pacquiao bruised, bloodied and disfigured the face of Antonio Margarito late Saturday inside a boxing ring at Cowboys Stadium, he turned a far larger man into another small obstacle on his march toward history.

headline: Myanmar Dissident Calls for Change
text: YANGON, Myanmar  On her first full day of freedom after more than seven years of house arrest, Myanmar’s pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, demonstrated the enduring power of her popularity on Sunday, drawing thousands of jubilant supporters to a rally at which she pledged to lead them in a struggle for political change.

headline: Less Surprise, More Spice at the Off-Camera Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES — By and large, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences did it again — made a success of its now-annual, teary, easygoing, slightly off-color dinner show, the Governors Awards.

headline: Obama and Asia-Pacific Leaders Vow to Work Toward Freer Trade
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan  President Obama and other Asia-Pacific leaders wrapped up a two-day meeting on Sunday with sweeping pledges to rectify global economic imbalances and move toward creating a regional free-trade zone, but with few concrete gains.

headline: A Museum’s Bounty at London Art and Antiques Fair
text: Roaming the numerous exhibitions at the Winter Fine Art and Antiques Fair (Olympia Exhibition Center, Hammersmith Road, www.olympia-antiques.com), running from Nov. 15 to 21, might very well remind visitors of a world-class museum. A cornucopia of impressive and unusual works offered by 140 prestigious British dealers, the show is offering for sale John Singer Sargent’s romantic painting “Head of a Woman with Gold Earring” (on sale for £1.7 million, or about $2.6 million) and Francis David Millet’s tender work “A Girl on a Marble Garden Seat Playing a Lyre,” as well as a large selection of more conventional antiques.

headline: Santonio Holmes, the Jets’ Difference Maker
text: In conventional terms, Jets receiver Santonio Holmes hasn’t made a huge impression with the Jets this season. He couldn’t make any impression at all in the first four games — he was serving a suspension. In the four games he has played, he has had 15 catches for 245 yards, with no touchdowns and with one clumsy fumble in which he ran into a teammate’s back.

headline: Sarkozy Appoints a More Rightist Cabinet in Reshuffle
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France reappointed François Fillon the country’s prime minister and named a new, more rightist cabinet on Sunday, a day after Mr. Fillon and the previous government resigned.

headline: One on One: Tim Wu, Author of ‘The Master Switch’
text: Tim Wu, the Columbia law professor who came up with the term “net neutrality” in a research paper, has just written a new book, “The Master Switch: The Rise and Fall of Information Empires,” published by Knopf. The book chronicles the rise and fall of companies that develop new technologies, and discusses the future of the Internet. The following Q&A is an edited version of an interview with Professor Wu:

headline: 3 Credit Cards Without Foreign Exchange Fees
text: Attention international travelers: there are a few more credit cards worth tucking into your wallet before you take off.

headline: Somali Pirates Free British Couple for Ransom After More Than a Year in Captivity
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  A British couple who had been kidnapped by Somali pirates and held in captivity in a remote, sweltering patch of central Somalia for more than a year was finally released, Somali officials said Sunday, apparently after a ransom was paid.

headline: No, Really – Nobody Cares About the Deficit
text: Via Steve Benen, a post-election poll shows essentially nobody, regardless of party affiliation, making the deficit a priority.

headline: Is ‘Peak Oil’ Behind Us?
text: Peak oil is not just here — it’s behind us already.

headline: Announcing the Subway Announcement Lady
text: The next time you are standing there waiting for the subway, late for work and worried your boss will notice, think of this: The voice that tells you a train is two stations away, and then one station away, is up in Maine, about as far from the Penobscot River as you are from the front of the train. When it finally comes.

headline: AOL Creates a Hub for E-Mail
text: It’s not uncommon for Internet users to have multiple e-mail accounts – one for personal messages, another for online shopping and perhaps a third for registering with various Web sites. The strategy helps to protect privacy, but it also causes frustration because people have to log in to several in-boxes.

headline: Live Analysis: Jets 26, Cleveland 20, OT Final
text: The Jets won a thrilling and draining game in overtime against the Browns on Sunday.

headline: Death Panels and Sales Taxes
text: I said something deliberately provocative on This Week, so I think I’d better clarify what I meant (which I did on the show, but it can’t hurt to say it again.)

headline: Deficit Remains Focus of National Attention
text: Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, a member of the bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt, warned Sunday that America “will become a second-rate economic power” unless it begins to deal with that debt.

headline: 'The Merchant of Venice'
text: Photos from the Broadway production starring Al Pacino and Lily Rabe.

headline: A 90-Day Bet on Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM  The pledge by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to push for a new, one-time-only freeze of 90 days on settlement construction in the West Bank represents a bet by the Israelis and the Americans that enough can be accomplished so that the Palestinians will not abandon peace talks even after the freeze ends.

headline: N.H.L. Rule on Hits to the Head Survives a Review
text: As medical research teams announce increasingly alarming findings on the consequences of head trauma in sports, the N.H.L.’s Rule 48 continues to come under scrutiny. That new rule mandates a major penalty and game misconduct for a lateral or blindside hit of an opponent in which the head is the target or the principal point of contact, or both.

headline: Live Analysis: Cowboys 33, Giants 20, Final
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Halfway through their schedules, the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys arrived at Sunday heading in opposite directions. The Giants were winners of five straight, while the Cowboys were simply hoping for their first win since a new coach was installed to help salvage a lost season.

headline: Ireland Rejects European Bailout Efforts
text: BRUSSELS — European ministers worked over the weekend on a financial rescue plan for Ireland, as pressure mounted on Dublin to seek a bailout to prevent the markets from spreading turbulence to other European countries, officials said on Sunday.

headline: Enduring All Tests, Time Included
text: “The only runner who could beat him was Seabiscuit,” said Louie Zamperini’s coach at the University of Southern California, as this track star, who had competed in the 1936 Berlin Olympics, trained for the 1940 Olympics in Tokyo. But a deeply unfunny thing happened to him on the way to Japan. The 1940 games were canceled. Mr. Zamperini became an Air Force lieutenant. And he wound up going to Japan not as a miler but as a savagely abused prisoner of war.

headline: Parents Die, and Twins Turn Creepy
text: It’s hard to buy a sinister tale set in an isolated house on the edge of the woods when it looks as if it’s been staged in a discount corner of Crate & Barrel. White sofa and shag rug don’t exactly spell menace.

headline: Unusual Antics Unfold in a Church Basement
text: Topped with a dollop of thick whipped cream, the luxurious hot chocolate at Blue Marble Ice Cream in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is an event in itself.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Metaphors
text: Despite rumors to the contrary, there are many ways in which the human brain isn’t all that fancy. Let’s compare it to the nervous system of a fruit fly. Both are made up of cells, of course, with neurons playing particularly important roles. Now one might expect that a neuron from a human will differ dramatically from one from a fly. Maybe the human’s will have especially ornate ways of communicating with other neurons, making use of unique “neurotransmitter” messengers. Maybe compared to the lowly fly neuron, human neurons are bigger, more complex, in some way can run faster and jump higher.

headline: Anatomy of a Number: 'Elf'
text: The composer Matthew Sklar and the lyricist Chad Beguelin narrate a look at a number from the new Broadway musical.

headline: On One Play, a Life Is Forever Changed
text: On Oct. 16, Chris Norton ran onto the field as part of Luther College’s kickoff unit in the third quarter of a game against Central College, a rival in Division III’s Iowa Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. Norton, an 18-year-old freshman defensive back at the tiny liberal arts college in northeast Iowa, raced down the sideline, a blur of arms and limbs.

headline: Through the Seasons With Glass and Vivaldi
text: When the violinist Robert McDuffie asked Philip Glass to compose a concerto for him, he had a plan that would ensure performances beyond the premiere. What he wanted was a companion piece for Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons” that could be performed on its own or with Vivaldi’s popular set of programmatic concertos.

headline: Jets Win in Overtime for Second Week in a Row
text: CLEVELAND  Santonio Holmes never doubted that the Jets were going to beat the Cleveland Browns. Even when the clock showed 24 seconds left in overtime, he said he did not lose faith.

headline: BHP Withdraws Potash Takeover Offer
text: Geoff Howe/Bloomberg News

headline: A Collaboration Embraces the Sacred and the Saxophone
text: At the heart of the White Light Festival, the ambitious, multidisciplinary performing-arts series now at Lincoln Center and a few satellite locations, is the idea that art can illuminate the presence of the ineffable. An agnostic might argue that Lincoln Center’s real aim is to nudge the invisible hand of commerce. Both notions were evident during two events presented under the White Light banner on Friday night.

headline: Philharmonic at Carnegie: What a Difference a Hall Makes
text: As a running story line, the badness of the acoustics at Avery Fisher Hall is exaggerated. The hall is far from ideal, and a renovation is planned (though to what extent has yet to be decided). Still, on any given night, when the New York Philharmonic is at its best, the sound of the orchestra comes through with brightness, clarity and presence.

headline: Long Braids That Bind to an Indian Identity
text: Tom Pearson and Donna Ahmadi ended their split bill on Thursday night with their backs pressed together, slowly spinning under the fading lights. They stared out at the surrounding audience impassively, maybe even a bit defiantly, while she undid one of her dark braids and he twirled a red hoop on one arm.

headline: The Older Side of Hollywood Gets Its Due
text: LOS ANGELES  It was a wistful, aging Hollywood that showed up on Saturday night to honor both its own and some outsiders at the second annual Governors Awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

headline: Cool Restraint Leading the Way to Explosiveness
text: With three seasons behind her and a fourth under way, Marin Alsop appears to have settled in comfortably as the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, and the orchestra itself seems to have mellowed. The relationship started unpromisingly when it was announced in 2005, with some players protesting Ms. Alsop’s appointment. But it warmed up as Ms. Alsop, the musicians and the orchestra’s management quickly addressed pressing problems like expanding the audience and trimming a longstanding deficit.

headline: Putting Some Muscle in Chopin Along With the Poetry
text: Anyone who went to Garrick Ohlsson’s recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening thinking of Chopin’s music as the perfumed effusions of a dreamy, sickly Romantic must have been jolted out of that assumption by Mr. Ohlsson’s muscular playing.

headline: Sweat, Tears, Rubies and a Song
text: Inspired by the Yiddish short stories of I. L. Peretz (1852-1915), the National Yiddish Theater  Folksbiene is mingling modern arts and the mythic past in two one-act allegorical pieces, one starring the gifted Rafael Goldwaser. Mr. Goldwaser, a longtime actor with the Habimah Theater in Israel, now runs a troupe in France that also aims to employ multimedia techniques as it mixes tradition and innovation.

headline: Neil Young Tribute to Draw Familiar Faces
text: Patti Smith, the  Roots and Mason Jennings will perform at a tribute concert to Neil Young on Feb. 10 at Carnegie Hall. Michael Dorf, founder of the Knitting Factory and the owner of City Winery, has put together the seventh in his series of concerts to benefit six music-education nonprofit organizations. Others scheduled to appear include Vernon Reid, DeVotchKa, Shawn Colvin, Bettye LaVette, Bebel Gilberto, Aimee Mann, Larry Campbell and the Cowboy Junkies.

headline: Seeking a Shutout Against the Rangers
text: When St. Louis goalie Ty Conklin shut out the Rangers, 2-0, at Madison Square Garden last Sunday, it was the first time the Blues had blanked the Rangers, going all the way back to the Blues’ founding in 1967.

headline: Monday: Crossword Golf
text: Years ago, when I used to commute into New York City on the train, I’d sometimes play “crossword golf,” a simple game I concocted to add an extra challenge to early-week puzzles. I’ll explain how it works, but first today’s debut by Emily L. Lilly.

headline: Footnotes
text: Rajiv Joseph’s play “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo” has found a theater for its Broadway run this spring, the producers announced. As previously reported, Robin Williams will make his Broadway acting debut in the production, which is to be directed by Moisés Kaufman (“33 Variations”), at the Richard Rodgers Theater. Previews begin on March 11, with the official opening on March 31. ... Another star has joined the cast of Chekhov’s “Three Sisters,” which is scheduled to run this winter at the Classic Stage Company. The theater announced that Jessica Hecht would join Maggie Gyllenhaal and her husband, Peter Sarsgaard, in the production, to be directed by Austin Pendleton. Previews begin on Jan. 12, with an opening scheduled for Jan. 27.

headline: ‘Megamind’ Remains a Box-Office Hero
text: “Megamind,” left, has legs. For the second weekend in a row, this DreamWorks Animation picture was No. 1 at the North American box office, selling an estimated $30.1 million for a total of $89.8 million and vanquishing worries about its staying power. “Unstoppable,” starring Denzel Washington (20th Century Fox) was second with $23.5 million. Some analysts had expected more from the movie, about a runaway train and made for roughly $100 million, because it garnered strong reviews. The Robert Downey Jr. comedy “Due Date” (Warner Brothers) was third with $15.5 million for a total of $59 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Skyline” (Relativity Media) opened in fourth place with about $11.7 million. While marketed like a blockbuster, “Skyline,” an effects-driven science-fiction thriller, was made for a bargain-basement price of $10 million. The fluffy comedy “Morning Glory” (Paramount Pictures) was in fifth place with $9.6 million ($12.2 million total), a poor result for a picture with two major stars, Diane Keaton and Harrison Ford. Negative reviews and a crowded marketplace were probably to blame.

headline: Computer Programs Battle for Bragging Rights
text: After 49 of the 64 boards in the final of the World Computer-Bridge Championship in Philadelphia last month, WBridge5 from France led Jack from the Netherlands by 32 international match points.

headline: Suu Kyi Addresses Thousands
text: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi used her speech to call for freedom of speech in Myanmar and urged her supporters to stand up for their rights.

headline: Rangers Win Amid a Brawl, a Return and a Hat Trick

headline: For Pacquiao, Next Step Is Unclear
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  By early Sunday, Manny Pacquiao looked more like a beaten fighter than a history-making one. Bruises dotted his face above a lip fattened by Antonio Margarito. Pacquiao gripped the lectern tenderly, his left hand swollen some twice its normal size.

headline: Wrestling Pendulum Swings Farther East, Toward Cornell
text: It is the first weekend of November, and a light snow glazes narrow country roads that zigzag through miles of cornfields. On a sprawling campus that overlooks this rural scene, the country’s top-ranked college wrestling team is in a gym working out with an eye on a national championship.

headline: At Cornell, Arena Proves Sport’s Value
text: Cornell University’s wrestling coach, Rob Koll, calls his on-campus wrestling center “a fraternity house without the vices.” It has a $35,000 sound system that would be the envy of any party scene. There are 40 custom-made maple lockers for the brothers of this frat, in addition to two whirlpools, a study hall, a lounge, a fitness room and walls that are lined with the portraits and pictures of the building’s past inhabitants.

headline: Oklahoma Surprise: Islam as an Election Issue

headline: Theodore W. Kheel, Labor Mediator, Dies at 96
text: Theodore W. Kheel, who was New York City’s pre-eminent labor peacemaker from the 1950s through the 1980s, a mediator and arbitrator sought after by both City Hall and the White House to help avert or end strikes of crippling consequence, died on Friday. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: For Emanuel, Obstacles in Path to Chicago Mayor
text: CHICAGO — Rahm Emanuel pulled off his suit jacket and led a parade of television cameras down 26th Street the other day, carrying himself — with his confident wave to passing cars and his unswerving message for the microphones — every bit like this city’s next mayor, and not so unlike its current one.

headline: Seeking a Free-Agent Bargain Who Will Pay Off

In 2009, it was Mark Teixeira, who had just signed an eight-year, $180 million contact with the Yankees. In 2010, it was Aubrey Huff, who had just signed a one-year, $3 million deal with the San Francisco Giants.

headline: Record-Setting Track Star Wes Santee Dies at 78
text: Wes Santee, a record-setting track star who never ran the sub-four-minute mile expected of him and whose running career was ended by a suspension for accepting too much expense money, died Sunday at his home in Eureka, Kan. He was 78.

headline: A Superabundance of Velocity
NBC Ad Urges Recording News
text: Of all the news commercials on the networks this year, one running this fall for “NBC Nightly News” might be the most unorthodox. In it, the anchor Brian Williams recommends that people record the 6:30 p.m. newscast if they will not be home in time to watch live.

headline: Obama Returns, Facing Unpredictable Congress in a Lame-Duck Session
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama returned from Asia on Sunday to face the new post-election reality at home: in an unpredictable lame-duck session of Congress starting Monday, emboldened Republicans are poised to try to force an extension of the Bush-era tax rates for the wealthy and block action on a variety of domestic and foreign initiatives.

headline: Cholera Deaths Up in Haiti, With Worst to Come
text: MEXICO CITY — The death toll in Haiti’s cholera epidemic has reached more than 900, the government reported Sunday, as aid groups rushed soap and clean water to a disaster-wracked population to fight the disease.

headline: Eras Collide: Kennedy on iPad
text: There are outtakes from one of John F. Kennedy’s last television interviews, a lengthy appearance on “The Huntley-Brinkley Report.” There is a scene in Fort Worth as the president cheerfully accepts a gift of a cowboy hat, but declines to try it on for the cameras. There is even a rare glimpse of an impeccably dressed Jacqueline Kennedy happily smoking a cigarette, at a dinner party in Australia.

headline: Timeline: Legal Path to Lawsuit Lending
text: Investors are pouring money into other people’s lawsuits, hoping to share in the winnings. The practice once was banned in most states. But those barriers have been eroded by the rising cost of litigation, and investors hungry for new and profitable frontiers.

headline: Investors Put Money on Lawsuits to Get Payouts
text: Large banks, hedge funds and private investors hungry for new and lucrative opportunities are bankrolling other people’s lawsuits, pumping hundreds of millions of dollars into medical malpractice claims, divorce battles and class actions against corporations  all in the hope of sharing in the potential winnings.

headline: Shadows Follow Newton Into Spotlight
text: As the college football season enters its finishing kick, there are four major events left on the calendar. There is No. 2 Auburn’s game at No. 10 Alabama on Nov. 26, the Southeastern Conference championship game between Auburn and No. 17 South Carolina on Dec. 4, the Heisman Trophy ceremony on Dec. 11 and the Bowl Championship Series title game on Jan. 10.

headline: BHP Billiton Drops Bid for Potash
text: BHP Billiton said on Sunday that it withdrew its $38.6 billion unsolicited takeover offer for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the world’s biggest producer of a key fertilizer ingredient, after the Canadian government blocked the potential deal.

headline: Attacker That Sharpened Facebook’s Defenses
text: A friend on Facebook suggests that you watch an amazing or funny or sexy video. The link may seem innocuous enough. But with a few simple clicks, you could end up infecting your PC with the Koobface worm.

headline: Gerry Adams to Run for Seat in Ireland
text: LONDON  After 40 years of participation in Irish republican politics in the British-controlled counties of Northern Ireland, Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, said Sunday that he planned to shift the focus of his political activity to the Irish Republic and seek election there.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include retail sales for October and business inventories for September (Monday); the Producer Price Index for October and industrial production and capacity utilization for October (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for October and housing starts for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index, and leading economic indicators for October (Thursday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 10
text: Images from the Giants’ 33-20 loss to the Cowboys.

headline: The World as He Finds It
text: On Wednesday David Axelrod, President Obama’s top political adviser, appeared to signal that the White House was ready to cave on tax cuts  to give in to Republican demands that tax cuts be extended for the wealthy as well as the middle class. “We have to deal with the world as we find it,” he declared.

headline: Depression, a Cruel Bully
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ethics in the New House
text: As he approaches the duties of speaker of the House, Representative John Boehner is generously asking one and all for ideas on “how we can make this institution function again.” Mr. Boehner did not mention dysfunction, but that’s apparently in the works, too, according to reports that he will likely dismantle the quasi-independent Office of Congressional Ethics.

headline: Investing in Our Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Donald S. Kellermann, Who Led Public Research Group, Dies at 83
text: Donald S. Kellermann, who gained wide attention as a young newspaper reporter by committing a crime so that he could report on life in jail, then went on to help start an influential public opinion research organization, the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 83.

headline: Grand Disillusion
text: Up in the soft blue night sky at Grand Central Terminal, the heavens have been improved upon. The ceiling’s gold-leaf constellations were not considered bright enough, so their fiber-optic stars are now LEDs. Castor, Pollux, Pisces, Pegasus dazzle 125 feet above the main concourse.

headline: Safer Social Security
text: Social Security is not the key fiscal problem facing the nation. Payments to its beneficiaries amount to 5 percent of the economy now; by 2050, they’re projected to rise to about 6 percent. Over the same period, federal health care costs will increase six times as much.

headline: The Party of No
text: By offering up their joint recommendation last week for balancing the budget, the co-chairmen of Barack Obama’s fiscal commission didn’t solve our deficit problem once and for all, or clear a path through the political thickets facing would-be budget cutters. But Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson performed a valuable public service nonetheless: the reaction to their proposals demonstrated that when it comes to addressing the long-term challenges facing this country, the Democrats, too, can play the Party of No.

headline: A Culture of Carelessness
text: Though its final report is two months away, the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill is beginning to confirm what we already suspected and feared. The April blowout on the Deepwater Horizon was not some unfortunate occurrence. It was the result of a series of bad decisions by companies less concerned about safety than about finishing a project that was over budget and 38 days behind schedule.

headline: Immigration Hardball
text: Republicans will have the next two years to set the immigration agenda in the House of Representatives. If their legislation looks anything like their campaign ads, there will be no way for illegal immigrants to get right with the law and no real solution to the problem of illegal immigration. Just a national doubling-down on enforcement, with still more border fencing and immigration agents, workplaces locked down, and states and localities setting police dragnets on what always was  and still ought to be  federal turf.

headline: Aid Fuels Change of Fortunes on Silk Road
text: KASHGAR, China  The brochure promised “a piece of heaven,” but Shangri-La, a half-built apartment complex on the dusty outskirts of this oasis town, was hardly that. The landscape was parched, and the most notable sign of life was a pack of goats chewing their way through a mound of trash.

headline: Sports Replay: Nov. 14
text: A look at the day in sports, including some nice moves and some blunders.

headline: How Smoky Plume in Sky Drew the Eyes of the World
text: Gil Leyvas has been a photojournalist on board a television news helicopter for more than a decade. He has seen countless airplanes and their wispy contrails. What he saw — and recorded — near Los Angeles on Nov. 4 and 8 looked nothing like the trail from an airplane. It looked, to him, like the launching of a missile.

headline: A Media Veteran Joins Clear Channel
text: 8:42 a.m. | Updated As expected, Clear Channel on Monday named Robert W. Pittman as a senior adviser for its radio business, and confirmed that he will make an investment in the company.

headline: T.C.U. Sees  Boise State Catching Up in B.C.S. Rankings
text: One week after pounding Utah in Salt Lake City and seemingly taking control of the No. 3 slot in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, Texas Christian saw everything fall apart. Although No. 4 Boise State still trails No. 3 T.C.U. in the B.C.S. standings, the Horned Frogs’ lead took a significant hit. T.C.U. leads Boise State by a margin of .897 to .863, but that is one week after leading, .925 to .866.

headline: Embarrassed Last Week, Patriots Do the Humbling

It was hard to tell what had Brady upset. He was barely touched by the Pittsburgh Steelers, who possess one of the most harrowing defenses in the N.F.L. And the expectations for the running game against a defense that had not yet allowed a 75-yard game had to be minimal.

headline: Sorting Through the Government Data Explosion
text: In May 2009, the Obama administration started putting raw government data on the Web. It started with 47 data sets. Today, there are more than 270,000 government data sets, spanning every imaginable category from public health to foreign aid.

headline: When Do You Remember Learning a New Word?
text: There are many places in The New York Times to learn new words every day. Not only will almost any article you read in The Times introduce you to several “SAT-level” words, but The Learning Network has a Word of the Day feature, the Magazine section features a weekly On Language column, and the Opinion section has a blog called Schott’s Vocab. Tell us about a time you remember learning a new word, whether it was recently or long ago. What was the word? How did you learn it? In general, how do you think vocabulary should (or shouldn’t) be taught in school? Why?

Rangel, Democrat of New York, on 13 charges of unethical behavior took a stunning turn Monday morning when Mr. Rangel walked out of the hearing 40 minutes after it began, complaining that it would be unfair to continue the process because he could no longer afford a lawyer.

headline: A Simple Plan
text: ‘‘Western paper turns away the light, while our paper seems to take it in, to envelop it gently, like the soft surface of a first snowfall,’’ wrote the Japanese author Jun’ichiro Tanizaki in ‘‘In Praise of Shadows,’’ his 1933 manifesto on the aesthetic differences between the East and West. His observations on subtlety, the play of light and dark, and, for that matter, all things Japanese, have lately been on the minds of Alexa Adams and Flora Gill, the design duo behind the label Ohne Titel. ‘‘While I was reading his work, I felt like I was experiencing this slice of traditional Japanese aesthetics visually,’’ Adams says. Adds Gill, ‘‘It’s almost a goal toward perfect design, which as designers we’re always searching for.’’ In their spring 2011 collection, the pair softened their usual aggressive silhouettes with nods to the Orient: striped ribbed knitwear inspired by the Japanese woodblock print artist Utagawa Kuniyoshi, linen tie-front pants, jackets with kimono-style volume in the sleeves. The two recently made their inaugural trip to Japan, traveling to Kyoto to take in tea ceremonies, ancient temples and Noh theater. As Tanizaki saw it, the purity of great modern design comes, first, with an appreciation for the old.

headline: Roundup: Surveys Find Increases in Chinese Students at American Universities, and Millionaire College Presidents
text: “The number of Chinese students studying in the United States surged 30 percent in the 2009-10 academic year, making China, for the first time, the top country of origin for international students,” Tamar Lewin writes in today’s Times, citing “Open Doors,” the Institute of International Education’s annual report.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Pity the robo-signer: These videotaped depositions show the Kafkaesque absurdity of their jobs, representing companies they cannot remember, claiming addresses they have never seen and signing documents they do not understand.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: No More Secrets
text: To begin the discussion of Sunday’s episode of “Dexter” off topic, I’d like to level a complaint about Harrison’s sleeping situation. Not only is Dexter’s son inexplicably still sleeping in the living room in a Pack ‘n Play, apparently he also doesn’t wear pajamas.

headline: For Frequent Fliers, a Radiation Risk in the Skies
text: Despite recent concern about whether airline passengers get a potentially dangerous dose of radiation from the new security scanners at the airport checkpoints, the real risk is after you board the plane, according to two new publications.

headline: ‘How to Succeed’ Rounds Out Its Broadway Cast
text: A Broadway newcomer, Rose Hemingway, will play one of the most coveted ingénue roles of the season, Rosemary Pilkington, opposite Daniel Radcliffe’s J. Pierrepont Finch in this winter’s revival of the Frank Loesser musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” the producers announced on Monday. Ms. Hemingway appeared in the Donmar Warehouse production of “Parade” in Los Angeles last year. Also new to the cast is Christopher J. Hanke (“In My Life”) as Bud Frump, the role that won a featured actor Tony Award for Charles Nelson Reilly in the original production, which ran from 1961 to 1965 and won seven Tonys in all (including best musical) as well as the Pulitzer Prize in drama.

headline: Video of Kidnapped British Couple’s Journey to Freedom After a Year With Somali Pirates
text: Although it is a long way from their home in suburban England to the Somali bush, throughout their long ordeal, Paul and Rachel Chandler — a retired British couple released on Sunday, 13 months after they were kidnapped by Somali pirates — were a surprisingly frequent presence on British television.

headline: Win Doesn’t End Cowboys’ Troubles
text: There was a moment late in the Dallas Cowboys’ rebirth against the Giants on Sunday when Jason Garrett was presented with another teaching moment in what is going to be two months of them. David Buehler’s field-goal attempt sailed wide with 5 minutes 45 seconds remaining, and the Cowboys’ tentative steps back from the precipice and toward, well, mediocrity threatened to end up in a face plant.

headline: Numberplay: Egg Drop Soup
text: A few weeks ago we did a pizza puzzle involving a bet between two fictitious math graduate students. That week we also had the Gathering for Gardner “Celebration of Mind” on what would have been Martin Gardner’s 96th birthday. At the enjoyable little gathering that I hosted, we actually had New Haven pizza. Coincidentally, a real Yale mathematics graduate student presented a classic puzzle that involved another of my favorite foods — eggs. Here it is.

headline: Porto Party
text: Bustling with commerce, the design-savvy city of Porto, Portugal, plays a convincing Milan to Lisbon’s Rome. (Its pristine beaches, 10 minutes from downtown, give it a touch of Malibu, too.) And suddenly the city’s long-neglected downtown — with its vertiginous hills and elegant spires towering over the Douro River — is all the rage again. Sleek new galleries, restaurants and boutiques have the old cobblestone streets buzzing anew.

Though Sugarland, the best-selling award-winning country music act, is now the duo Kristian Bush and Jennifer Nettles, Ms. Hall, a singer-songwriter who founded the group, has obtained a settlement from her former bandmates after suing for profits she said she was owed after she left, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Truck Stop | Austin’s Moveable Feast
text: Like other cities around the country, Austin, Tex., recently tightened its rules for its ever-expanding mobile-food contingent. New regulations include needing to provide proof of a state sales tax permit, passing a fire-department inspection and filing an itinerary of truck routes. (Apparently Twitter doesn’t count.) Despite these new regulations, the food-trailer scene is still thriving: the city estimates that there will be 1,620 mobile food vendors by the end of 2011; in 2006, there were only 648. Here are a few highlights:

Read and leave comments on our live-blog coverage of the hearing. »

By living among the animals and quietly recording their interactions, she was able to show that the chimp world included love, hate, fear, jealousy, tool use, brutality, even warfare. I spoke with Dr. Goodall last month at Western Connecticut State College, where she was giving a lecture, and then later by telephone. A condensed version of the conversations follows:

headline: The Money Trail
text: While checking in at the hotel that first afternoon in the French Alps, I met a fine, terrier-like dog named Al Capone. He was admirably groomed, pearl coat nearly glowing, and he proceeded through the lobby with such aplomb — did he realize that he stood only a foot and a half? — that I was filled with immediate admiration for him, if not a scintilla of envy. Judging by the clientele here, his owner might have been a Russian oligarch, a Euro titan or a celebrity scion of some sort, and so could only offer me a wan smile and a few brief words. But that was to be expected. Women sashayed past in ski outfits that would have cost your average proletarian a month’s wages; men sat by the fireplace drinking bottles of Cognac whose sticker price resembled that of a compact car. And Al Capone followed his curious nose, snuffling for nonexistent crumbs, until he bumped up against my alien, American shoe.

headline: The Triumph Of Reagan Over Friedman
text: Brad DeLong is exercised, and rightly so, over the fact that some good economists have joined the crazies in signing the Republican anti-QE letter. How is this possible? he asks. After all, we’re not even talking about Keynesianism here, we’re talking about monetarism — at least in terms of the spirit of the thing. For Friedman’s whole case against the Fed was not, fundamentally, about monetary aggregates; they were just intermediate targets. It was that the Fed was supposed to do whatever it took to avoid an economic plunge, and didn’t. So calling on the Fed not to act now is a betrayal of Friedmanism as well as Keynesianism.

George Washington bid his officers farewell at the end of the Revolutionary War, appears to be on the horizon: the museum associated with the tavern has been closed to accommodate the “final renovations” on the restaurant, according to a sign taped to the door.

headline: M.R.I.’s Help Fight High Risk of Cancer

headline: Fire in the Dancers’ Heels and Flares From the Guitarists’ Hands
text: Some performances of flamenco feel inauthentic: too arty, too unspontaneous, too choreographed. That feeling never once arose at ¡Flamenco Festival Gitano!, presented over the weekend by the World Music Institute at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University. Enough approving calls of “olé!” came from the audience, even after subtle feats of musicianship, to make both performances feel intimate. The programs will be repeated this week in Boston and Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The General’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at the 1927 silent film “The General,” a movie that “turns the intractable and cruel laws of physics into cinematic poetry,” he says. The film was written by, directed by and stars Buster Keaton. Although Mr. Keaton was usually associated with comedies, Mr. Scott sees “The General” as more of an action movie, “one of the purest and, still, one of the best of its kind,” he says. Have you seen “The General?” Please share your thoughts on this and other Buster Keaton films.

You can rehearse and rehearse such moments, but at their best they flow from instinct and risk-taking.

headline: Lincoln Center Scrambles After Visa Problems
text: Visa problems have forced Lincoln Center to delay the culminating performances of its White Light Festival, dedicated to transcendence in music, until next week. “The Manganiyar Seduction,” which was scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, will now take place on Monday and Tuesday. Manganiyars are a caste of Indian musicians of Muslim origin from western Rajasthan state whose songs celebrate Hindu deities. Jane Moss, Lincoln Center’s vice president for programming and the organizer of the festival, said that visa applications were made in May and that about half of the 50-member troupe involved in the show had received visas by Oct. 13, but the rest were sent for further review by State Department officials. By Friday a dozen members still had not received visas, so the performances were postponed. Word came over the weekend that the remaining visas had been granted. The Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center was available Monday and Tuesday for the shift. Tickets can be used for the new dates, refunded or exchanged.

headline: A Jamesian Pays Tribute in a Retelling
text: Cynthia Ozick, whose sixth novel, “Foreign Bodies,” has just been published, is still in the thrall of Henry James. He was the idol of her youth and also, she has said, its ruination. At the age of 22, she once wrote, she “became” Henry James: “Even without close examination, you could see the light glancing off my pate; you could see my heavy chin, my watch chain, my walking stick, my tender paunch,” she said. She wrote her master’s thesis on James’s late novels, including one, “The Ivory Tower,” that James never finished and that most people have never heard of.

headline: Bats Gauge Sounds With Neural Teamwork

So far, the accommodations have been great, and the people are swell. If you will have me, I will try my best to make your blogsperience a special one. headline: Cats’ Superior Drinking Habits Make Me Love Dogs

headline: Mr. Rangel Walks Out
text: The investigation of Representative Charles Rangel for violation of Congressional fund-raising rules has been going on for two years. The hearing before the House ethics committee — which Mr. Rangel insisted would exonerate him — has been scheduled for weeks. Yet on Monday, the day the hearing began, Mr. Rangel demanded a delay, claiming he needed to raise money for a new lawyer. When the committee refused, he walked out the door and into a new embarrassment.

headline: Two Easy Moves for the Lame Duck

It also needs to approve two food-related measures that are badly needed to protect the nation’s health. The good news is that a version of each has already passed one chamber, and both have strong bipartisan support.
