headline: To Help With a Diagnosis, Software That Spots Patterns
text: Autonomy, Britain’s largest software maker, is an intriguing company. Founded in 1996, Autonomy traces its origins to research done by its co-founders, Michael Lynch and Richard Gaunt, computer scientists from the University of Cambridge. The company’s software technology is adept at making inferences based on probabilities as it sifts through all kinds of data, not just in databases, but also text, e-mail, Web pages, voice and video — so-called unstructured data.

headline: Why Are We Going Blind in Space?
text: It has got to be the coolest student job on the planet — or for that matter, in the solar system.

headline: Healthy Capitalism
text: I applaud Nicholas Kristof for decrying the disturbing levels of inequality that exist in the United States (“Another banana republic,” Views, Nov. 10). But I wish he would have pointed out that a major cause of this economic polarization is the weakness of the nation’s labor movement. It is no coincidence that it was in the mid-1970s that the U.S. began to move toward becoming a less equal society; this is the same time that the labor movement was weakened by corporations. Until the U.S. labor movement gets better organized, the economic polarization will likely continue.

headline: Pressure Grows on Ireland to Accept Rescue From Europe
text: With its political survival at stake, the Irish government was locked in discussions with its European partners and the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday over a financial rescue package intended to support Ireland’s failed banks, a top official from the European Union said.

headline: Boies Schiller Dismisses 3 Lawyers
text: Three lawyers who until recently worked at Boies, Schiller & Flexner, the firm founded by the famed trial lawyer David Boies, have had a tough couple of weeks.

headline: Shares Drop on Wall Street Amid Global Worries
text: Worries about Europe’s debt crisis and possible moves by the authorities in Asia to slow fast-paced growth there swept the world’s markets on Tuesday and pushed stocks in the United States sharply lower.

headline: Alec Baldwin Is Mark Twain: Reports of His Depth Have Been Greatly Exaggerated
text: Among the fun facts we learned about Mark Twain from PBS’s broadcast honoring Tina Fey as the 2010 recipient of the Kennedy Center’s Mark Twain Prize for American Humor: they didn’t call him Samuel Langhorne Clemens for nothing (thank you very much, Betty White), and the quintessential American satirist and creator of Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn bore a remarkable resemblance to Ms. Fey’s “30 Rock” co-star Alec Baldwin. (He’s also eerily familiar with modern technology.) But in a world where Tracy Morgan and Thomas Jefferson are dead ringers, we suppose anything’s possible.

headline: Murkowski Says Palin Lacks ‘Intellectual Curiosity’
text: 8:51 p.m. | Updated

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Who will foreclose on the foreclosers? In the case of David Stern’s notorious Florida law firm, it was Bank of America that came knocking.

headline: Studies Find Success in Use of Privacy Icons
text: One of the biggest areas of contention in the online privacy debate is whether online advertisers have the ability to regulate themselves sufficiently. Privacy advocates claim that privacy policies are not enough to inform consumers about an advertiser’s data collection practices because they are complex documents that users don’t read.

headline: Are the Jets Great or Just Good?
text: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

headline: Digital Keys for Unlocking the Humanities’ Riches
text: A history of the humanities in the 20th century could be chronicled in “isms”  formalism, Freudianism, structuralism, postcolonialism  grand intellectual cathedrals from which assorted interpretations of literature, politics and culture spread.

headline: Digitally Mapping the Republic of Letters
text: As the historian Dan Edelstein explains in the video above, he and his colleagues have used today’s digital technology to reconstruct the network of Enlightenment correspondence that linked thinkers like Locke, Voltaire and Rousseau.

headline: Up at the Villa
text: At summer’s end, for more than a century, a group of Americans have traveled to a hilltop in Rome. They are invariably an eclectic bunch — scholars of antiquity, architects nursing ambitious projects, artists and designers of various disciplines — who have each been selected to spend a year living at the American Academy in Rome, a lush compound overlooking the city’s storied spires and ancient basilicas. Known as the Rome Prize, the fellowship is considered one of the most prestigious and envy-inducing within the world of the humanities and fine arts.

headline: A Royal Wedding in the Age of Austerity
text: Updated | 4:34 p.m.  As my colleague Sarah Lyall reports, Britain’s royal family announced on Tuesday that Prince William, the heir to the heir of the British throne, plans to marry his longtime girlfriend, Kate Middleton, next year.

headline: Drug Companies Pursue Personalized Medicine Approach
text: Personalized medicine – often described as providing the right drug to the right patient at the right time – has long been considered an ideal. But it is also a threat to some pharmaceutical companies wedded to the idea of blockbuster drugs that could be taken by potentially all patients with a given disease.

headline: The Mirror of the Soul Confirms the ID, Too
text: The New York Police Department has begun photographing the irises of people who are arrested in an effort to prevent escapes as suspects move through the court system. [NYT] The new program was instituted after two prisoners arrested on serious charges tricked authorities into freeing them by posing at arraignment as suspects facing minor cases. (Also see The Daily News and The New York Post .)

headline: Climate Skeptic Seeks Energy Committee Chairmanship
text: In January, the Republican Party will take control of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, giving the new majority considerable influence over federal energy policy and climate change regulation and legislation. By virtue of seniority, Fred Upton of Michigan is considered the likeliest candidate to head the committee.

headline: Wendell August Forge
text: A fire destroyed this metals design gift store in Pennsylvania, but the owner was able to rebuild in a matter of months. He credits the rapid turnaround to Christianity and community support.

headline: Shorter Limit to Limited Run: ‘La Bête’ to Close Five Weeks Early
text: After bombing on Broadway the first time around in 1991, David Hirson’s play “La Bête” has fared better with the critics and at the box office in its current revival, yet has not emerged as the smash hit that the producers had hoped for. They announced on Monday night that the revival would close on Jan. 9, five weeks ahead of schedule.

headline: Pai Ma Pi
text: Chinese term used to describe flattering those in a position of power – literally, “stroking the horse’s bottom.”

headline: Carroll Wins England Call-Up Despite Barroom Bust-Up
text: A week after we asked who would provide goals for a defanged England team against a still sputtering France, Manager Fabio Capello offered an answer: Andy Carroll will get his first cap for the national team after a goal-drenched start to the Premier League season. The Newcastle striker will be one of three debutants for England at Wembley on Nov. 17. Carroll will be supported in midfield by Jordan Henderson of Sunderland while Arsenal defender Kieran Gibbs makes his first start.

headline: 55 Questions for Students
text: A list of 55 Student Opinion questions we’ve asked since the school year began. Invite your students to come and post comments on any of them!

headline: Hudson Tunnel’s Demise Cheers Some Businesses
text: As someone who designs fancy hats for women to wear to horse races, Christine A. Moore says she tends to see “the silver lining in everything.”

headline: A Mechanical Manifesto
text: So David Brooks claims that

headline: Ireland’s Big Mistake
text: I’ve been thinking about the ongoing Irish mess, and I suddenly realized the true nature of Ireland’s big mistake.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Rising Number of Uninsured
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Apple Begins Selling Beatles Downloads
text: After years of stalled negotiations, the effort to bring the Beatles’ music into the download age finally began to come together on July 14  Bastille Day.

headline: Nissan Will Sell 500,000 Electric Cars a Year by 2013, Says Chief
text: On the eve of the market debut of the Nissan Leaf electric car, Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of the Renault-Nissan alliance, said the only constraint on sales for the next three years will be how many battery packs the factories could churn out.

headline: Beatles for Sale: Here’s What You’ll Pay
text: As expected, Apple has announced that the Beatles music is finally up for sale.

headline: Sunny Predictions for the Electric Car Market
text: The chief executive of the Renault-Nissan alliance predicts that sales of the Nissan Leaf will reach 500,000 units a year in 2013, Matt Wald reports on the Wheels blog.

headline: Where Did God Go in Afghanistan? An Atheist Writes.
text: Kathleen Johnson is the Vice President of American Atheists and founder of the Military Association of Atheists and Freethinkers. She is a veteran of the Iraq and Afghanistan conflicts and retired as a First Sergeant after more than 20 years service. She is now a Department of the Army civilian. This is her response to the At War post ‘Where Did God Go in Afghanistan?’ by Capt. Michael Cummings.

headline: Wary of Demanding Lead Role, ‘Spider-Man’ Producers Eye Use of Backup
text: The producers of the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” are planning to tap the cast member Matthew James Thomas to serve as an alternate for the leading man, Reeve Carney, in the role of Peter Parker/Spider-Man for as many as two performances a week after the show opens, executives involved with the production said on Tuesday.

headline: Michelin Stars Come Out for Chicago, a Day Early
text: The Michelin guides’ inspectors are supposed to surprise restaurateurs. But in Chicago it was Michelin officials who were most surprised, after a user on Yelp, who claimed to have received the guide early, revealed the company’s star ratings for the city on Monday, about two days before they were to be announced.

headline: Obama Should Focus On Executive Powers, Liberal Group Says
text: President Obama should refocus his administration to concentrate on executive actions he can take independent of Congress, after two years in which voters have become disgusted with the “sausage-making”of legislation, according to a report released today by a liberal policy group.

headline: Fete Accompli | Model Behavior
text: Celebrities, schmlebrities. Models can still draw in a crowd. Witness the event Model Behavior, held on Friday at Christie’s for the nonprofit organization One Frickin Day. The idea was to ask some of the world’s top models to donate one “dress they have worn on the red carpet,” says the co-founder and model Elettra Wiedemann. “The money raised goes towards buying solar panels and equipment for clinics in Haiti and Rwanda.”

headline: Dolan Chosen as President of U.S. Bishops’ Group
text: BALTIMORE  The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops elected Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York to be its president on Tuesday in a surprise move that reaffirmed the conservative direction of the Roman Catholic Church in America.

headline: After Cracking Down on Debt Collectors, New York State Is Now Set to Hire Them
text: In these hard times, New York’s future governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, has made a point of standing alongside consumers who are down on their luck. As attorney general, he conducted a statewide crackdown on debt collectors who ran afoul of consumer protection laws, and his office encouraged consumers with their own tales of woe to contact it.

headline: Never Interview on a Cloudy Tuesday; It’s Bad Luck
text: As the private school admissions process rolls into full gear, so, too, does the parental rumor mill, churning out dubious claims about the meaning of each move a school makes as the anxious mothers and fathers of applicants seek to read the tea leaves of their child’s academic future.

headline: For Treasury, a Hidden Cost for Helping G.M.
text: I’ve somewhat modified my contention that the government had done nothing in the automotive bankruptcy cases that secured lenders had not been doing for years.

headline: The Rookies Are Coming
text: We’ve reached the point in the season when many teams are looking to reshape their rosters. And with trades tough to come by and virtually no talent available via free agency, that means hockey fans can expect to start seeing some rookies called up over the next few weeks.

headline: Los Angeles Auto Show: New Models and New Lineups
text: LOS ANGELES — Automobile shows are usually about introducing new models. The script is changing for this year’s Los Angeles Auto Show in that some brands — Chrysler, Dodge and Lotus among them — are wiping the slate clean and introducing new lineups.

headline: Hospital Errors Plague Medicare Patients
text: The Times reports this morning on a study finding that one of every seven Medicare beneficiaries who is hospitalized is harmed as a result of problems with the medical care there. These errors affect 180,000 patients annually and cost the government $4.4 billion a year.

headline: Paul Calello of Credit Suisse Dies at 49
text: 2:51 p.m. | Updated Paul Calello, the chairman of the investment bank at Credit Suisse Group who helped navigate the Swiss bank through the financial crisis, died on Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 49.

headline: Senate Leader Deals Blow to President on Arms Treaty
text: President Obama’s hopes of ratifying a new arms control treaty with Russia this year appeared to unravel on Tuesday as a Senate Republican leader moved to block a vote in what could be a devastating blow to the president’s most tangible foreign policy achievement.

headline: Google Sees Rules Violations in Limits on Internet Access
text: With China evidently in its sights, Google has released a policy paper contending that countries that limit Internet users’ access to information providers outside their borders violate their World Trade Organization commitments.

headline: Rangel’s Ethics Violations
text: Updated, 12:47 p.m. | A House ethics panel has convicted Representative Charles B. Rangel of all but one of the 13 ethics violations he faced, for offenses ranging from accepting a rent-stabilized apartment from a Manhattan developer to failing to pay taxes on rental income from his Dominican villa to raising charitable donations from companies and corporate executives who had business before the committee he led.

headline: McNabb Extension Raises Questions and Eyebrows
text: In today’s scandal-a-minute age, it’s difficult to produce truly surprising news in sports, the kind that makes you rub your eyes and ask everyone within earshot whether you could possibly be reading it right. Sadly, even most mayhem does not register on the shock meter. Massive marital infidelity by Mr. Perfect? An eyeroll, at most. In that vein, the Redskins performed something truly remarkable on Monday, stopping the sports world in its tracks, if only momentarily.

headline: Billy Reid, Designer, Wins Major Fashion Award
text: When the actress Carey Mulligan announced last night that Billy Reid had been voted the winner of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner for 2010 — in front of a crowd that included the designers Michael Kors, Olivier Theyskens, Jason Wu, Zac Posen and Alexander Wang; the “True Blood” stars Stephen Moyer and Anna Paquin; the ubiquitous Kim Kardashian; and the evening’s co-chairwoman Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue — there was a brief, seemingly stunned silence, followed by a burst of enthusiastic applause and whoops and hollers from the back of the room, from which the 46-year-old designer shakily made his way toward the stage.

headline: More Sideline Fireworks in Detroit
text: Yes, you’ve heard this before: Pistons starting forward Tayshaun Prince and Coach John Kuester are arguing.

headline: Sam Gold, Director of ‘Circle Mirror,’ Joins the Roundabout Team
text: Sam Gold, the director of two Off Broadway productions that received major praise last season, Annie Baker’s plays “Circle Mirror Transformation” and “The Aliens,” has been named an associate artist of Roundabout Theater Company, where he directed its current black box hit “Tigers Be Still.” That production has been extended through Nov. 28 but is now sold out, Roundabout said on Tuesday in a statement announcing Mr. Gold’s appointment.

headline: Rangel Violated Ethics Rules, Committee Finds
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, was found to have violated 11 of the 13 ethics charges against him, a Congressional panel announced today after deliberating for less than 24 hours.

headline: The State of the Mets, According to Paterson
text: Gov. David A. Paterson knows a thing or two about facing a crisis, and more than a few things about his favorite baseball team, the Mets, who have been in crisis mode since their colossal collapse in September 2007. Last Thursday, Mr. Paterson, attending a fund-raising event in Harlem, gave his 2010 Postseason State of the Mets address to an audience of one reporter.

headline: Israel Exempts E.U. Pilots From Security Program
text: An Israeli security program that requires commercial pilots on airlines from some countries, including the United States, to transmit special identification clearance codes before entering Israel’s airspace will not be enforced on pilots with airlines based in the European Union, aviation officials say.

headline: New Details on McNabb’s Contract
text: Donovan McNabb isn’t necessarily the Washington Redskins’ quarterback of the future after all, ESPN has reported –- and it has nothing to do with the Redskins’ implosion against the Philadelphia Eagles on Monday night.

headline: Danish Bakery Chains Turn Carbohydrates to Gold
text: COPENHAGEN — In Denmark, a country famed for its pastry, baking is serious business. And in recent years, two bakery chains, Lagkagehuset — which translates as The Cake House — and Emmerys, have proved that in hard economic times carbohydrates are as good as gold here .

headline: Trout Serving in America
text: Yes, officer, I was going too fast. I’m sorry. I have to get to Iacono’s before they close and I wasn’t paying attention.

headline: Owner of ‘Lipstick Building’ Seeks to Reorganize
text: The owner of the landmark Lipstick Building in Manhattan — also known as ground zero for the $65 billion Ponzi scheme of Bernard L. Madoff — filed for Chapter 11 reorganization on Monday.

headline: 2010 CFDA Awards
text: The fashion set gathered for the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards at Skylight Studios in New York.

headline: A Social Experiment and a Failed Blog-to-Book Proposal
text: Facebook may have e-mail now, but in Upper Manhattan the real social media development on Monday was the start of the “social experiment” at Columbia University.

headline: Previewing the L.A. Auto Show
text: A glance at some of the notable cars to be shown at the 2010 auto show in Los Angeles.

headline: A Poet Well Versed in Grief
text: Born to a family who ran a funeral home in small-town Michigan, the poet Thomas Lynch began pondering aging and death at a young age, as a child leafing through the gory pages of his father’s mortician texts.

headline: On Our Radar: Diesel Shortage Hits China
text: Surging demand for diesel fuel leads to shortages of the fuel throughout China. The Chinese government is rationing electricity with the goal of meeting energy efficiency and environmental goals by the end of the year, spurring demand for diesel-powered generators. [Financial Times]

headline: First Look | Bergdorf’s Holiday Windows
text: On Monday afternoon, Bergdorf Goodman’s display guru David Hoey gave The Moment an exclusive peek at the department store’s holiday windows, which won’t be unveiled until later this week. As Hoey drew up the heavy tarps covering each of them, a crowd of flash-happy tourists appeared (not to mention our very own Bill Cunningham, who was on the street, as is his wont). Still works in progress, the windows are being pored over by a team of artists. Hoey oversees the whole production, the culmination of a year’s efforts, and he often can be seen on Fifth Avenue, instructing his minions. Can they hear him through all that glass? “If I stand exactly at 14-and-a-half inches from the window, the glass becomes a natural megaphone and they can hear me perfectly,” he says. This year the windows are dedicated not so much to the act of travel as the fantasies that trip-taking might engender: flying horses, flying machines, and a journey to the moon. Bergdorf’s best windows over the past two decades are collected in a new $550 hand-made book by Assouline, part of its exquisitely crafted “Ultimate Collection,” which weighs a ton and goes on sale this week at Bergdorf and bergdorfgoodman.com.

headline: New Senate Leadership, a Lot Like the Old
text: New Congress! Same leaders. More or less, anyway.

headline: When Parents Intervene With Bullying
text: Two reports from around the country raise the question: How far should a parent go when their child is bullied?

headline: House Panel Finds Rangel Guilty
text: A House panel on Tuesday found Representative Charles B. Rangel guilty of 11 counts of ethical violations, ruling that his failure to pay some taxes, improper solicitation of charitable donations and failure to accurately report his personal income had brought dishonor on the House.

headline: Army-Notre Dame Stirs Yankee Stadium Ghosts
text: To understand how universally significant the Yankee Stadium football games between Army and Notre Dame once were, it is worth revisiting World War II’s Battle of the Bulge. During the winter of 1944-45 in Belgium, American troops were surrounded and being infiltrated by English-speaking German spies dressed as American soldiers.

headline: TimesCast | November 16, 2010
text: Rangel found guilty; medal of honor awarded to a living soldier and The Beatles come to iTunes.

headline: New Voting System for Hall May Benefit Steinbrenner
text: Thirteen days after George Steinbrenner’s death in July, the National Baseball Hall of Fame altered the procedures for voting on executives, managers, umpires and longtime retired players by its veterans committee in a way that seemed to favor the Boss’s swift election next month.

headline: Boeing and Airbus Waver on Reworking Their Smaller Jets
text: The latest high-stakes maneuvering by Boeing and Airbus does not involve their top-of-the-line models, the 787 Dreamliner and the A380 jumbo jet, but instead their aging smaller workhorses.

headline: Sasha Frere-Jones, New Yorker’s Music Critic, Will Be Editor at News Corp.’s iPad Newspaper
text: Sasha Frere-Jones, a music critic at The New Yorker, will become the culture editor of The Daily, the  News Corporation’s so-called iPad newspaper, which is  in development, according to two people involved in the project who did not speak for the record because the hiring had not been announced. Mr. Frere-Jones had no comment.

headline: The Renault F1 Title Victories
text: With all the praise for the Red Bull chassis designed by Adrian Newey and for Sebastian Vettel, the young man who drove the chassis to the drivers’ title, there is a little something that has been taking bows in the wings, a little invisible to the audience, it seems to me.

headline: The Renault F1 Title Victories
text: With all the praise for the Red Bull chassis designed by Adrian Newey and for Sebastian Vettel, the young man who drove the chassis to the drivers’ title, there is a little something that has been taking bows in the wings, a little invisible to the audience, it seems to me.

headline: Fete Accompli | RxArt 10th Anniversary
text: The powers that be and spree came out for RxArt’s 10th anniversary celebration Monday night at the Art Directors Club. The organization, started by Diane Brown in 2000, helps to bring original art work into health care facilities around the country. Brown, a former private dealer and indefatigable force, has enlisted the likes of Jeff Koons, Rob Pruitt and Will Cotton to create art that inspires and gives hope to patients, families and medical staff alike. Her do-gooding paid off as a glittery crowd of artists and A-listers including James Franco, Terry Richardson, Jenny Shimuzu and the multitasking Simon de Pury, who D.J’ed and served as the event’s auctioneer, showed up to imbibe and bid on some impressive works of art. All for a very good cause, indeed.

headline: Yahoo Adds Daily Deals
text: Yahoo is joining the bandwagon of local daily deals. On Tuesday, Yahoo said that it teamed with more than 20 daily deal sites – including Groupon, the best known among them – to make the offers available to Yahoo’s millions of users.

headline: Merchants of Misery
text: The attack on the Fed for having the temerity to actually try to do something about the economy continues. Now Republican politicians are pointing out that the Fed has failed to reduce unemployment — and therefore, it should no longer even try to do anything about unemployment, and focus only on price stability. And this makes sense because ….?

headline: Packard Factory’s Last Tenant Soon to Leave
text: DETROIT — A city long pockmarked by the hulks of shuttered factories will soon get another one when the giant, historic Packard plant loses its last tenant.

headline: American Speech: A Dozen with a Black Cat, a Pair of Hobos and a Fin (1960)
text: by Jessie Ryon Lucke, North Texas State College

headline: Knicks President Has Hip Surgery
text: Donnie Walsh, the Knicks’ team president, had surgery to repair his right hip Tuesday morning and is expected to spend a few days in the hospital before starting a rehabilitation program at home.

headline: The Sandwich Generation: A Live Event
text: Your Money’s coverage of the unique problems facing the sandwich generation – those stuck financially supporting both aging parents and adult children — continues with a live event at the New York Times building on Dec. 1.

headline: Art that Looks Backward
text: A New York University photography professor will have a camera surgically implanted in the back of his head for several months as part of an art project commissioned by the government of Qatar, The Wall Street Journal reported. The project, called “The 3rd I” and organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, will involve the camera taking pictures at one-minute intervals with the images being streamed to a computer database and then appearing in different sequences, some in real time, on monitors in an exhibition space in Doha between December and May.

headline: Bush and Cheney Reunite at Library Groundbreaking
text: DALLAS – Joined by an all-star cast from his days in the White House, former President George W. Bush plunged a shovel into dirt on Tuesday and kicked off construction of his presidential library.

headline: Difficult Issues Clamor for Advocate’s Attention
text: BANGKOK  The jubilant throngs that greeted Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy leader, this past weekend in Myanmar confirmed that her huge popularity remains intact. But as she steps gingerly back into the swirl of political combat, she confronts difficult realities that will limit her ability to translate that popularity into fundamental change.

headline: U.P.S. Impostor Seeks to Take, Not Deliver, Police Say
text: Sign here, please — and then stick ’em up.

headline: Turnover on the First Lady’s Staff
text: Midterm staff turnover hits the first lady’s office: Michelle Obama’s chief of staff, Susan Sher, is returning to Chicago after the first of the year, the White House announced on Tuesday.

headline: Winter Sonata
text: With vivid folklore and a Bergmanesque landscape, Sweden’s Dalarna is a fairy tale come to life.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bangladesh, Guinea and Britain.

headline: Q&A: Fiftieth Birthday in British Virgin Islands
text: My wife and I are going to the British Virgin Islands in January for my 50th birthday. We’re bare boating a ’47 catamaran and have several couples onboard. What are the “do not miss” party spots around the islands as well as adventures that we must do?

headline: Bruins Goalie Tim Thomas Back on Track
text: Maybe it’s an every-other-year thing with Boston Bruins goalie Tim Thomas.

headline: Climate Lessons From a Master Mediator
text: I got to know Ted Kheel over the final decade of his remarkable life, which ended at age 96 on Sunday. To get a sense of the man and his accomplishments, including his mediation of tens of thousands of disputes (that’s not a typo), read The Times obituary and click on the brief “Last Word” discussion above, in which he discusses the core challenge of conflict resolution.

headline: Blackstone Raises Its Offer for Dynegy
text: Nov. 17, 8:11 a.m. | Updated Dynegy said on Wednesday that it has accepted Blackstone’s new $5-a-share offer and urged shareholders to approve the deal. The new proposal carries a $16.3 million breakup fee. Shareholders are set to vote on the deal at 11 a.m. Eastern time.

headline: ‘I Was Deprived of Due Process’
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel released a statement Tuesday afternoon deploring a Congressional panel for convicting him of 11 ethics violations after a hearing conducted in his absence. Mr. Rangel walked out of the hearing Monday morning minutes after it began, saying that he could not afford a lawyer. Here is his statement, unabridged:

headline: Nicole Kidman Renting Out West Village Condo
text: The actress Nicole Kidman has listed her West Village condominium for rent for $45,000 a month. The full-floor apartment is in the south tower of Richard Meier’s two Perry Street buildings, the architect’s first foray into Manhattan residential real estate.

headline: Iran Calls German Journalists Spies for Reporting on Stoning Case
text: As Reuters reports, an Iranian judiciary official said on Tuesday that two German reporters, who had traveled to Iran posing as tourists to interview the son of a woman sentenced to death by stoning, have been charged with espionage.

headline: ‘Glee’ Reality Show Sets Its Casting Calls and Ground Rules
text: If your fondest aspiration in show business is a recurring role on “Glee” you could pursue it by toiling for years in semi-obscurity until you finally catch the attention of Ryan Murphy. Or, if you’re more the instant-gratification type, you could try out for “The Glee Project,” an Oxygen reality series that was announced over the summer and which on Tuesday revealed the dates and locations for its open casting calls as well as its eligibility requirements.

headline: Macy’s Wants to ‘Wake Up’ Black Friday
text: As retailers gear up to woo budget-conscious consumers for the holiday season, the traditional distinctions between discount and department stores are getting fuzzier.

headline: Week 11 in Fantasy Football: The Waiver Wire
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 11. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: New York State Ranks Last for Voter Turnout
text: Despite contests for every statewide office for the first time in decades, a smaller share of eligible voters turned out two weeks ago in New York than in any other state. New York turnout was lower than in any midterm election for at least three decades.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Manhattan User’s Guide: In tiny yellow letters, the Web site’s “hot list” of restaurants open on Thanksgiving in Manhattan and Brooklyn – Glenn Collins

headline: Apple and the Beatles: A Long and Winding Road
text: As long as the Beatles and Apple have co-existed, fans of both have wondered: when are these crazy kids finally going to get together?

headline: Currency Fight With China Divides U.S. Business
text: ZHUJI, China  For American business, the United States currency dispute with China is a two-sided coin.

headline: A Big Task: Attempting to Solve the National Deficit
text: Overview | What is a budget deficit? How big is the current national deficit, and how can it be fixed? In this lesson, students use The Times’s Budget Puzzle to develop their own approach to solving the national deficit and write letters to Congressional representatives arguing for their favored approaches.

headline: The Real Meaning of Inheritance
text: In his Sandwich Generation special report essay, “A Child’s Legacy Is More Than Money,” Paul Sullivan wrote that inheritance isn’t necessarily just about simply passing down money. Rather, he noted that it’s also about passing down life tools like good judgment and passion.

headline: ‘Dracula’ Will Rise Off Broadway, With a Count by Way of Italy
text: New York theater’s last major attempts at vampire shows — the Elton John musical “Lestat” in 2006, “Dracula, the Musical” in 2004, and the musical “Dance of the Vampires” in 2002 — were among the biggest Broadway flops of that decade. But the monster success of the “Twilight” book and film series — about young love between a well-coiffed vampire and a pretty, sulky human — since 2008 has led to a host of movies, television series, and books featuring vampires.

headline: Royals Show Little Affinity for Rank as They Take Spouses
text: PARIS — The Facebook page looks like any other — give or take a fancy royal crest. But the father happens to be Prince Charles, who put out a simple online announcement that William, his son, is to marry his long-term partner, Miss Catherine Middleton, less formally known as Kate.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 16
text: A view of the day in sports, with a lot of action at the Asian Games in China.

headline: Nations Face Off Warily on  Bluefin Tuna
text: International fisheries conferences don’t necessarily make for high drama. But a meeting that opens on Wednesday on the fate of the Atlantic bluefin tuna could leave some officials, including those of the host country, squirming in the spotlight.

headline: Green Mashed Potatoes
text: Mark Bittman mashes potatoes with dandelion greens — arugula, watercress, escarole, radicchio, spinach, mustard, turnip greens, collards or kale can stand in — and bakes til the dish is golden brown.

headline: Paterson Is Set to Approve Deal on an Indian-Run Casino in the Catskills
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson is poised to sign off on an Indian-owned casino development project in the Catskills, state officials said Tuesday, opening the door to the state’s first full-fledged casino in close proximity to New York City.

headline: Investors Set for Dynegy Fight
text: The Blackstone Group raised its offer for Dynegy, amid stiff opposition from two of the energy company's biggest shareholders.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles
text: Readers shared photos and memories of appearing in or attending the holiday classic “The Nutcracker.”

headline: Beet Salad With Garlic-Walnut Sauce
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates a nearly mess-free technique for roasting beets, which can then be tossed with a basic dressing.

headline: Vain Glorious | Gym Equipment That’s Molto Bello
text: What: Technogym, an Italian purveyor of high-concept fitness equipment, has just set up shop on American  shores with a sleek SoHo showroom practically spitting distance from Design Within Reach, Kartell, the Alessi flagship and Armani Casa. (Giorgio Armani, for the record, is reportedly a proud owner of Technogym’s mirrored Kinesis system.)

headline: An Award-Winning Chef Reinvents the Classics
text: Stuffing, cranberry sauce and mashed potatoes are standard fare at most Thanksgiving celebrations. But in the hands of an award-winning chef like Daniel Humm of Eleven Madison Park in New York City, these ordinary dishes can become the talk of the table.

headline: Top R.N.C. Strategist Resigns, Condemning Steele
text: The top political strategist at the Republican National Committee resigned his position on Tuesday and delivered a scathing condemnation of the party’s chairman, Michael Steele, declaring that new leadership is urgently needed if Republicans hope to win back the White House.

headline: Stir-Fried Sweet Potatoes
text: Mark Bittman makes an easy side dish with grated sweet potatoes, brown butter and sage.

headline: Barley 'Risotto' With Turkey
text: Mark Bittman uses leftover Thanksgiving turkey in a hearty dish that replaces arborio rice with hearty barley.

headline: Lance Armstrong Doping Inquiry Intensifies
text: Federal investigators and antidoping officials from the United States, including the federal agent Jeff Novitzky, have intensified their investigation of Lance Armstrong and are in France to meet with antidoping officials and members of Interpol, according to a person briefed on the investigation who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: In the Heartland, Still Investing in Coal
text: Lively Grove, Ill.

headline: Walnut Tart
text: Mark Bittman skips pecan pie in favor of a traditional French walnut tart.

headline: Sunset for a Solar Subsidy?
text: When the economy hit the skids in 2008, one of the casualties was the federal government’s main mechanism for subsidizing renewable energy, tax credits.

headline: Students Point Radar Guns and Learn a Lesson
text: The Bloomberg administration wants to teach New Yorkers about the dangers of driving over the speed limit. Its latest weapon? Kids with radar guns.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Of Mice and Ballet Men
text: With the Times dance critic Alastair Macaulay about to embark on a marathon of coast-to-coast productions of “The Nutcracker,” we asked readers to share their memories — in words and photos — of the holiday ballet.

headline: Cabbage Salad
text: Mark Bittman uses cabbage — a crisp and flavorful alternative to tasteless winter lettuce — in a salad with a distinctive crunch.

headline: DVDs
text: The big development in home video for this holiday season is the surge in 3-D releases, which will finally give all those early adopters something to play on their expensive new systems. By the end of the year 36 stereoscopic titles will be available, according to the Digital Entertainment Group, a trade association, including Imax documentaries and classical music offerings.

headline: Frank Gehry (a Part Owner) Helps Develop a Landmark
text: It’s not every day that Frank Gehry designs lobby furniture for an office building.

headline: No-Knead Bread
text: Jim Lahey, the owner of Sullivan Street Bakery, shows Mark Bittman how to make his no-knead bread, a simple method that produces a loaf with incredible flavor and an enviable, crackling crust.

headline: President of World Chess Federation Responds to Readers’ Questions
text: The president of the World Chess Federation says he hopes to open a chess academy in New York City in the near future and double the number of people who play chess worldwide. And, yes, he believes that the game was invented by extraterrestrials.

headline: Apple Approves Google Voice iPhone App
text: 5:05 p.m. | Updated  to add Apple comment.

headline: Democratic Congressman Defends Debt Commission
text: WASHINGTON — Since releasing their preliminary report last week, Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson, the co-chairmen of President Obama’s fiscal commission, have been about as popular in the capital as the stinkbugs that recently swarmed the place. But they have at least one admirer in Earl Blumenauer, the cerebral Democratic congressman from Oregon, who took to the House floor today to urge his colleagues on the left to reconsider their almost universal hostility toward the plan.

headline: Displaced in the Desert
text: How developers deal with a host of protected plants and animals like the desert tortoise has become crucial to getting vast renewable energy projects built.

headline: Landmarks Panel Approves Change to De Niro’s Hotel
text: As an actor, Robert De Niro has made a name for himself playing characters who lash out at authority.

headline: Asked & Answered | Samuel Bourdin
text: Now on view at the French Embassy (located at 972 Fifth Avenue, at 79th Street) are about 30 rarely seen black-and-white prints by Guy Bourdin. The works evoke the same spirit of his wildly iconic color photographs, except that they are distilled to their essence — maintaining their boldly graphic nature, and imaginative discourse, and packed full of playful elegance. Also on display is a slide show of Bourdin’s recently released monograph, “In Between,” published by Steidl Dangin. The exhibition was largely made possible by the perseverance of Shelly Verthime, the show’s curator, and Guy Bourdin’s son Samuel Bourdin. Samuel endured many challenges gaining control of his father’s estate to be able to exhibit the works freely and worldwide. T caught up with him to find out more about his insights about  his father and to congratulate him on the show, which closes Dec. 10.

headline: Brussel Sprouts With Bacon and Figs
text: Mark Bittman cooks Brussels sprouts with bacon and figs — a combination made in heaven.

headline: Concerns as Solar Installations Join a Desert Ecosystem
text: NIPTON, Calif.

headline: Popovers
text: Mark Bittman makes easy popovers, custard-like on the inside, golden brown and crisp on the outside.

headline: Pricing Used Goods for Sale
text: When you want to sell a used good, figuring out how much to sell it for can be a laborious process involving checking multiple sites and sources online.

headline: Women’s Pro League to Play Another Year
text: Women’s Professional Soccer will live to play a third year.

headline: New Attorney General Asks for Hiring Advice
text: The New York attorney general-elect, Eric T. Schneiderman, will have a big role in policing Wall Street, and on Tuesday he tapped several prominent Wall Street lawyers and senior aides of predecessors to help him find staff lawyers to do the job.

headline: The Politics of Simpson-Bowles (II)
text: Via Reihan Salam, Steve Teles tries to game out the likelihood of the deficit commission’s recommendations leading to an actual bipartisan deal of some sort:

headline: Medal of Honor for Bravery in Afghanistan
text: In an emotional ceremony today, President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor to an Army staff sergeant who placed himself in the line of fire in Afghanistan to try to save his fellow squad-mates and to protect and comfort a dying American soldier.

headline: G.M. Expands I.P.O. by 31%; U.S. Stake Cut Even More
text: Nov. 17, 7:52 a.m. | Updated General Motors confirmed in a regulatory filing that it was expanding the size of its initial public offering by about 31 percent, with the Treasury Department and the United Automobile Workers union selling more shares.

headline: There Will Be Fuel
text: HOUSTON

headline: Alumni Interview, The Home Version
text: When I conduct one of my alma mater’s alumni interviews with a prospective student, I draw from a long list of questions. Over a cup of tea or a latte, I’ll ease the student in, trying to get a glimpse of some nonapplication material — some trait or passion that will help me get to know them just a little better “off paper.”

headline: Spill Commission Defends Its Top Lawyer
text: The panel named by President Obama to investigate the BP Deepwater Horizon blowout on Tuesday rejected a call by a consumer activist group for the resignation of its chief counsel, Fred H. Bartlit Jr. The group, Consumer Watchdog, said that the panel should dismiss Mr. Bartlit because his law firm, Bartlit Beck Herman Palenchar & Scott, once represented Halliburton, one of the companies involved in drilling the BP well.

headline: Florida Governor Will Seek Pardon for Jim Morrison
text: “This is the strangest life I’ve ever known,” Jim Morrison sang on one of the hits he recorded with the Doors, but his afterlife continues to astound, too.

headline: Comcast Defends Merger in Response to Sanders
text: Comcast released a statement Tuesday in response to a letter that Senator Bernie Sanders,  Independent of Vermont, sent to the Federal Communications Commission seeking to block the upcoming takeover of NBC Universal by Comcast.

headline: Hong Kong Official Stands Up for U.S. Dollar
text: A top official with Hong Kong’s monetary body put to rest on Tuesday any concerns that the Hong Kong dollar would be delinked from its American counterpart, saying that China’s renminbi did not meet the criteria needed to be an anchor currency.

headline: Diesel, Cleaner, Is Set to Make a Comeback
text: WHEN Kenneth Ray Earley, a sophomore at the University of Missouri-St. Louis, went looking to replace the gas-guzzling, 1998 Chevy Silverado he’d inherited from his family, fuel efficiency, he said, was top of mind. He looked at Honda’s Civic and Fit models, as well as a Chevy Cobalt and the Toyota Prius hybrid.

headline: At VPL, Wispy Clothes for Your Inner Ballerina
text: MOST new Manhattan boutiques tend to be pigeonhole-able into one of two categories. One of two decorative objects will be present, either literally or in spirit, which will harmonize all other aesthetic notes: (1.) stuffed white peacocks; or (2.) vintage leather medicine balls.

headline: RIM Is Not App-Happy
text: Jim Balsillie, chief executive of Research In Motion, doesn’t see apps as a key part of the mobile Internet. “You don’t have the make the Web an app,” he said at the Web 2.0 conference in San Francisco Tuesday. “I don’t need a YouTube app to go to YouTube.”

headline: When Uranium Outshines Gold
text: EARLIER this month, Global X Funds of New York announced plans for two exchange-traded funds  one for gold stocks, the other, uranium. Initially, Bruno del Ama, its chief executive, figured he knew which would capture the market’s attention. After all, gold prices have surged in recent months.

headline: Rachel Comey | Dressing for the Expected
text: The designer Rachel Comey and her boyfriend, Sean Carmody, are two months away from having their first child, and the mom-to-be is bumping up her wardrobe accordingly. “The maternity trend seems to be not buying any clothes,” Comey says with a laugh. “That excludes the flea market, because it’s been fun to shop and try on shapes that I wouldn’t normally try on now that my body is so different.” Comey, who is known for her flirty prints and cool shoe designs, transformed a thrift shop cat suit into a pair of cool trousers. Day wear has become jumpsuits, overalls and stretchy knits, especially knit dresses paired with a sharp tailored blazer from Ellsworth for a more defined shape. “With my changing body and changing lifestyle, I am also changing my need for clothing to be practical for a woman’s body at any stage,” she says. We are looking forward to see how this new sensibility plays out in Comey’s next collection. Great expectations indeed.

headline: Naked Lusts and Natural Painkillers: Portrait of a Literary Outlaw
text: “Death smells.” That pronouncement, delivered by William S. Burroughs with the granite hauteur of a smirking Grim Reaper begins “William S. Burroughs: A Man Within,” Yony Leyser’s sympathetic documentary portrait of the formidable proto-Beat author of “Naked Lunch.”

headline: F.D.A. Panel Backs Drug for Lupus
text: What could become the first new drug approved to treat lupus in more than half a century moved a big step closer to the market on Tuesday by winning an endorsement from a federal advisory committee.

headline: G.O.P. Gains on Capitol Hill May Not Advance Nuclear Power
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Maple Pear Upside-Down Cake
text: Mark Bittman updates the canned pineapple upside-down cake with more sophisticated, seasonal flavors.

headline: Safety Inspectors to Assess More ‘Spider-Man’ Flying Sequences
text: State safety inspectors are scheduled to visit Broadway’s Foxwoods Theater on Wednesday to assess more flying sequences that director Julie Taymor has conceived for the forthcoming musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” a New York State Department of Labor spokesman said on Tuesday.

headline: New Archbishop Represents a Shift for the Church
text: Archbishop André-Joseph Léonard has taken a self-imposed vow of public silence until December, but his conservative comments are still managing to rile the flock, from Roman Catholics in the pews and bishops to Prime Minister Yves Leterme of Belgium.

headline: Neil Young’s Hybrid LincVolt Survives Fire
text: Neil Young’s much touted custom-built series hybrid, the LincVolt, was damaged in a fire on Nov. 9 while it was being recharged in a warehouse where the vehicle was stored.

headline: The Football Rivalry and the Baseball Stadium
text: The first college football game in the new Yankee Stadium will be held Saturday and feature Notre Dame and Army, who played nearly every year from 1925 to 1946, in games that were like today’s Super Bowls.

headline: Solar Storm Risks Bring Disaster Plans
text: ON a March night 21 years ago, a storm brought Quebec’s electric power grid to its knees.

headline: Unlikely Alliance Results in an All-Electric RAV4
text: It was over glasses of red wine on a May evening in Palo Alto, Calif., that Akio Toyoda, president of Toyota, and Elon Musk, founder of the electric vehicle start-up company Tesla Motors, first talked through the particulars of a partnership they had just announced.

headline: Some Exceptions to the Rule, but Pipelines Are Safer
text: UNDERGROUND oil and gas pipelines are an often-forgotten part of the nation’s energy infrastructure  until problems occur. This year has seen a spate of attention-getting accidents. In San Bruno, Calif., a gas pipeline exploded in a residential area in September, killing eight people. In Texas, two gas pipeline accidents within a day of each other in June killed three people. In Michigan, an oil pipeline ruptured this summer, spilling hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into a river.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bangladesh, Saudi Arabia and Britain.

headline: Comptroller Expects Another Good Year on Wall Street
text: Although Wall Street’s payroll is shrinking, its profit machine is alive and well.

headline: The Benefits of Solar With the Beauty of Trees
text: DAVIS, Calif.

headline: Wyndham Plans TRYP Hotel in New York
text: Midtown Manhattan will get a brand-new hotel next spring when TRYP by Wyndham unveils its first property in North America. The TRYP New York City-Times Square South is scheduled to open in April at 345 West 35th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

headline: Health Care and Bailout Votes May Have Hurt Democrats
text: I’m giving a speech tonight at St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., (it’s nice to see some snow on the ground!) which has necessitated my taking a little bit of a step back and reviewing what happened two Tuesdays ago.

headline: Dan Rather to ‘Sum Up’ in a Memoir
text: Dan Rather will write a wide-ranging memoir about his journalism days, a book planned for release by Grand Central Publishing in spring 2012, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Catholics in Belgium Start Parishes of Their Own
text: BUIZINGEN, Belgium — Willy Delsaert is a retired railroad employee with dyslexia who practiced intensively before facing the suburban Don Bosco Catholic parish to perform the Sunday Mass rituals he grew up with.

headline: Bacon From Provence, Wearing a Fringe of Herbs
text: The bacon deluge has yet to be exhausted. Now there is a new bacon with an unusual and very felicitous flavoring: herbes de Provence. Unlike bacon made with the more commonplace boosters, like pepper or sugar, these porky, subtly smoked strips fringed with thyme and such are indeed richly herbaceous. They do wonders in a sandwich with mild Cheddar, alongside an omelet filled with goat cheese, in a spinach salad or to wrap filet mignon or medallions of monkfish.

headline: A Timer for Turkey Roasting
text: Pop-up turkey timers often lead to overcooked disasters. The reason was clear after I called a manufacturer: the timers are set to pop when the meat is 180 degrees, by which point it is hopelessly dry.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Pomp and Pu Pu and All That Noise
text: REMEMBER Trader Vic’s in the Plaza Hotel, all dark wood and sweet drinks, steel guitar and Polynesian dreams? Donald Trump closed the restaurant in 1993 when he bought the hotel, calling it “tacky,” but it had 25 years under its grass skirt before that day. Trader Vic’s served pu pu platters and mai tais to generations of New Yorkers delighted to dream of the South Pacific and all its naked, willing charms.

headline: Dining Calendar, Nov. 17 to 21
text: Help for a Queens Co-Op

headline: Pizza Goes to France on the East Side
text: Adil Fawzi (shown in the white jacket) and Anthony Raggiri (in black), owners of Bistro 61, grabbed a nice double storefront a block or so from their restaurant and have turned it into a little French market, Marché du Sud.

headline: Is It Time for an Oil Change in the Kitchen?
text: WHAT’S the best oil for everyday frying? Some markets where I shop offer more than a dozen oils, from argan and avocado to tea seed and walnut. I’d long figured that the choice is a matter of taste and price. I usually use canola oil because it’s neutral in flavor, a good source of omega-3s and inexpensive. Like soy oil, it costs about a dime a tablespoon, whereas extra-virgin olive oils can run well over a dollar.

headline: FoodParc
text: OF all the big ideas packed into FoodParc, a food court that slices through the ground floor of the new Eventi Hotel on Sixth Avenue (between 29th and 30th Streets), the most riveting is the design. The elliptical columns and white banquettes are from the mind of Syd Mead, the designer behind “Blade Runner” and “Tron.”

headline: Apple Green-Chili Pie With Cheddar Crust and Walnut Streusel
text: Adapted from Chile Pies and Ice Cream, San Francisco

headline: Pie to Cupcake: Time’s Up
text: San Francisco

headline: Bakeries That Will Do the Pie Baking for You
text: Suppose you’d rather let someone else do the baking? Here are some bakeries that will allow New Yorkers to fetch and carry instead of roll and crimp:

headline: Reviewing the Hurricane Club
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: A Star Who Needs Help, or at Least a Hand
text: Don’t you hate it when puppets make eye contact and just glare at you? This is especially unnerving when the puppet is life-size and looks like Marlene Dietrich in her later years.

headline: Leaders’ Meeting Is Off, but Still On
text: When President Obama said he would like to meet with legislative leaders this Thursday to discuss tax policy and other matters, apparently he failed to synch his smart phone with that of Senator Mitch McConnell.

headline: Take the No. 7 to Secaucus? That’s a Plan
text: Ever since Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey killed an expensive plan for a new commuter rail tunnel to Manhattan, the Bloomberg administration has been working on an alternative: run the No. 7 subway train under the Hudson River.

headline: U.S. Ends Inquiry of UBS Over Offshore Tax Evasion
text: The Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday dropped its legal push to force the Swiss bank UBS to disclose the names of scores of American clients suspected of offshore tax evasion, but the agency said it was ramping up its scrutiny of other banks.

headline: It’s a Big Night in the Country for a Family to No Manners Born
text: When the curtains part at Theater 80 at the beginning of “Ghosts in the Cottonwoods,” a backwoods melodrama written and directed by Adam Rapp, a naked young man covered in glaring red welts stands before us. Also onstage is a woman administering homespun first aid by sucking the leeches from the young man’s flesh, spitting each into a bucket with a tinny clank.

headline: Acoustics Meet Excess on Road to Who Knows Where
text: Sufjan Stevens went from God to nearly Gaga at the Beacon Theater on Monday night, the last show in his latest American tour. He began, banjo in hand, with “Seven Swans,” a folky song about visions out of the Book of Revelation. Two hours later, in “Impossible Soul,” he was wearing a silvery costume complete with a shiny headdress, a drum machine was pounding, his backup singers were shimmying, balloons were dropped from the ceiling and Mr. Stevens was singing “Do you wanna dance?”

headline: Sweet Potatoes Wrapped in Prosciutto
text: Mark Bittman makes a Thanksgiving appetizer that you can prepare in advance.

headline: 1953 Politics, Paranoia and a Family Torn Apart
text: It’s probably significant that John Osborne never kept a copy of “Personal Enemy,” the play he wrote in 1953 (with Anthony Creighton) three years before storming the barricades of sedate postwar British drama with “Look Back in Anger.”

headline: Turkey Curry
text: Mark Bittman uses leftover Thanksgiving turkey in a dish flavored with Indian spices.

headline: Courting Women, Playboy TV Puts Emphasis on Intimacy
text: LOS ANGELES — Playboy TV is putting (some of) its clothes back on.

headline: An Israeli Novelist Writes of Pain, Private and Public
text: MEVASSERET ZION, Israel  In the middle of David Grossman’s latest novel, “To the End of the Land,” now out in English, the main character, a middle-aged Israeli Everywoman named Ora whose son has gone off to battle with the Israeli Army, stands with her ex-lover atop Mount Meron in northern Israel and looks out at the Hula Valley.

headline: Pampered Critics? No, Critics in Pampers
text: WATCHING a critic watch a show to gauge his reactions and then speculate on how he’ll review it is a dubious occupation best left to theater press agents. But when the “critic” in question is unlikely ever to file a review because he still has his baby teeth, there’s nothing to do but guess at his “review” of a theatrical experience, in much the same way all parents of toddlers constantly search the moods and whims of their young charges: Bottle? Diaper? Intermission?

headline: To Boldly Go Beyond the Limits of Sacred Music
text: Spirituality is in the eye of the beholder and, perhaps as important, in the ear: a truism embraced by the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center. But whereas many of the events included in the series have featured performances of explicitly sacred works, “Credo,” a concert presented at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle near Lincoln Center on Monday night, stood as a bold departure. At the heart of this event were new compositions by members of Sigur Ros, an Icelandic alternative-rock band not known for espousing any particular creed.

headline: Dunkin’ Brands Adds to Debt
text: The buyout barons behind Dunkin’ Donuts are partly cashing in. Nearly five years after one of that era’s most aggressive leveraged buyouts, Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Thomas H. Lee Partners are adding onto the debt on Dunkin’ Brands, which owns the doughnut chain and the ice cream retailer Baskin-Robbins. They are taking out a $500 million dividend in the process. The equity holders may get a short-term buzz, but debt investors should beware.

headline: A Precious Haul of Toxic Snapper
text: Thursday, Nov. 11

headline: A Roundabout Route to Columbia’s Coaching Job
text: In the dimly lighted subterranean office inhabited by Kyle Smith, Columbia’s new men’s basketball coach, a videocassette from his playing days at Hamilton College rests behind his desk. He has yet to watch it.

headline: Young Ballet-Makers Elaborate on Technique
text: For a low-key, low-budget event featuring relatively unknown dance-makers, the Young Choreographers Showcase at the Manhattan Movement & Arts Center on Sunday night included an impressive number of stars and an enviable buzz. Ballet luminaries studded the audience, and a crowd waiting for ticket returns considerably delayed the start of the program.

headline: Songbook Standards Flavored With Barbecue in an Escargot Cafe
text: A decade ago who would have thought that a Texas growl would supplant la-di-dah elegance at the Café Carlyle as the holiday season approaches? That growl belongs to Steve Tyrell; the lofty airs were those of Bobby Short, the much-missed jazz piano man who died in 2005.

headline: After an Adventure in Newspapers, a Publisher Returns to P.R.
text: BRIAN P. Tierney is leaving the world of media to return to his roots in marketing communications.

headline: A Free-for-All at Dynegy
text: As hard as it is to run a public company, it may be even more difficult to sell it.

headline: Explaining the Modern World and Keeping It Short
text: In his happily provocative new book of aphorisms, the fiscal prophet and self-appointed flâneur Nassim Nicholas Taleb aims particular scorn at anyone who thinks aphorisms require explanation. And he differentiates the aphorism from the equally short-form sound bite by noting that the aphorism enhances knowledge while the sound bite shrinks it.

headline: Bush and Cheney, Together Again at Groundbreaking
text: DALLAS  With the turn of a shovel and a few turns of phrase, former President George W. Bush culminated an elaborately orchestrated return to the public stage on Tuesday with a presidential library groundbreaking and a reunion with former Vice President Dick Cheney.

headline: Hit Is Still Affecting Player and League
text: Eight months after Pittsburgh’s Matt Cooke delivered a blind-side check to the head of Boston center Marc Savard, the effects linger.

headline: Bryant Park Finds Bright Spots Amid the Gloom
text: When the technical school Katharine Gibbs shut its doors last year at 50 West 40th Street, it appeared to be another blow for the tiny Bryant Park office submarket. The blocks that bracket the 9.6-acre park were already facing the partial departure of HSBC, a longtime anchor tenant; a largely vacant landmarked office tower; and the fire sale of a stalled development site.

headline: Was Roy Halladay Good? It’s Unanimous
text: Voting for baseball’s major awards must be completed before the first game of the playoffs. This means that Roy Halladay earned every first-place vote for the National League Cy Young Award — and then pitched the game of his life.

headline: Boehner Gives Freshmen More Goodies
text: John Boehner, the presumptive new speaker of the House, has gone out of his way to be nice to his incoming freshmen, even offering them added positions usually reserved for more senior folks. But now he has gone beyond offering his new housemates fresh towels and fancy soap and has practically moved them into the Congressional equivalent of the master bath.

headline: Finally, Google Voice for iPhones
text: Well, one of the weirder mysteries of the modern tech age finally ended Tuesday. Oh, it was never solved—it just ended.

headline: Senate Parties Keep Leaders for New Session
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats and Republicans kept their leadership teams intact Tuesday while House Democrats gathered behind closed doors to assess what misfired in elections that cost them at least 60 seats and control of the House.

headline: Video Gallery: Thanksgiving Cooking With Mark Bittman
text: A collection of Minimalist column videos for Thanksgiving recipes, and other dishes that would fit perfectly within a turkey feast.

headline: Panel on Deficit Proposes Smithsonian Charge Fees
text: Admission to the museums of the Smithsonian Institution (above, the National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum), which is 70 percent federally financed, has long been free. That would change under a proposal by the national commission charged with reducing the deficit. In its draft report last week it recommended that the Smithsonian’s federal appropriation be cut by $225 million, or roughly 30 percent, and that the institution make up the loss by charging a $7.50 admission fee. The Smithsonian’s spokeswoman, Linda St. Thomas, said by telephone that the Smithsonian had studied the idea of charging admission several times in recent decades and rejected it. “The regents have said repeatedly we don’t want to charge admission because it then makes it difficult for all people to come and visit the collections, which in theory are held in trust for the American people,” Ms. St. Thomas said. She pointed out that because the Smithsonian is federally financed Americans are in a sense already paying to visit through their taxes.

headline: F.B.I. Seeks Wider Wiretap Law for Web
text: WASHINGTON  Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, traveled to Silicon Valley on Tuesday to meet with top executives of several technology firms about a proposal to make it easier to wiretap Internet users.

headline: Dancers Lift ABC
text: The remaining four couples on “Dancing With the Stars” competed in a 90-minute episode on Monday as that ABC reality show topped the night’s ratings with 20.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other program came close to matching that audience as ABC easily led the night over all. CBS placed second, garnering strong ratings for its sitcoms “Two and a Half Men” (14.1 million) and “Mike & Molly” (12.3 million) at 9 and 9:30. Fox was third, earning 10.8 million at 8 for “House,” but only 6 million at 9 for “Lie to Me.” NBC was fourth.

headline: Footnote
text: James Conlon, music director of the Los Angeles Opera, has extended his contract for two more seasons, through 2013, the company announced. Its general director, Plácido Domingo, recently extended his term for a similar period.

headline: Yahoo in Four Words
text: What is Yahoo? That’s the question Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo’s chief executive, gets incessantly in Silicon Valley, where technology industry insiders closely follow her company’s struggles and second-guess the direction it is headed this month.

headline: F.B.I. Questions Ex-Quarterback in Cam Newton Inquiry
text: The various inquiries into the recruitment of Auburn quarterback Cam Newton continued Tuesday. Federal and state officials met with former Mississippi State quarterback John Bond in Mississippi, and news emerged that the N.C.A.A. spoke with a former Mississippi State employee with knowledge of Newton’s recruitment.

headline: Jim Crow on West Broadway
text: New York, Nov. 17, 1860

headline: In B.C.S., No Reward for Sportsmanship

headline: Publicist in Hollywood Is Fatally Shot Post-Premiere

headline: Music Boxed Sets

This year fans can collect John Lennon’s entire 1970s solo career, all of Michael Jackson’s video clips, all of Elvis Presley’s master recordings and all of Bob Dylan’s 1960s albums in vintage mono mixes, not to mention the entire output of the techno producer Plastikman. Perhaps recording companies are recognizing the ever-expanding capacity of digital storage on portable music players, all those extra gigabytes awaiting more music. Perhaps they’ve decided to release these substantial physical packages before consumers completely abandon the CD.

headline: Holiday Music

Or even more rarely, something not thrilling, but bracing; not all holiday experiences are cheerful. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times look for meaning, and hidden presents, in this year’s crop of holiday releases. JON CARAMANICA

headline: Too Good to Check

This was an important “story.” It underscored just how far ahead of his time Mark Twain was when he said a century before the Internet, “A lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its shoes.” But it also showed that there is an antidote to malicious journalism — and that’s good journalism.

headline: Phys Ed: The Workout Enigma
text: Recently, researchers in Finland made the discovery that some people’s bodies do not respond as expected to weight training, others don’t respond to endurance exercise and, in some lamentable cases, some don’t respond to either. In other words, there are those who just do not become fitter or stronger, no matter what exercise they undertake. To reach this conclusion, the researchers enrolled 175 sedentary adults in a 21-week exercise program. Some lifted weights twice a week. Others jogged or walked. Some did both. Before and after the program, the volunteers’ fitness and muscular strength were assessed. At the end of the 21 weeks, the results, published earlier this year in Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise, were mixed. In the combined strength-and-endurance-exercise program, the volunteers’ physiological improvement ranged from a negative 8 percent (meaning they became 8 percent less fit) to a positive 42 percent. The results were similar in the groups that undertook only strength or only endurance training. Some improved their strength enormously, some not at all. Others became aerobically fitter but not stronger, while still others showed no improvements in either area. Only a fortunate few became both fitter and more buff. As the researchers from the University of Jyvaskyla wrote with some understatement, “large individual differences” exist “in the responses to both endurance and strength training.”

headline: Ukraine: Kiev Mayor Removed From Power
text: The mayor of Kiev, known for his impulsive behavior and political stunts, was effectively removed from power on Tuesday by Ukraine’s president, who has been seeking to tighten political control over the country. The mayor, Leonid M. Chernovetsky, left, had seemed to survive in office because Ukraine’s squabbling political factions did not know how to handle him and could not agree on a successor. But the president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, who was elected this year, ousted Mr. Chernovetsky as head of the city’s administration and appointed a senior municipal official, Oleksandr Popov, to succeed him. Through a quirk in the law, Mr. Chernovetsky will continue for now as nominal head of the city, but Mr. Popov will wield the authority, officials said.

headline: The Philippines: Powerful Family Is Accused in More Killings
text: Members of a powerful political family in the southern Philippines whose leaders have been charged in the 2009 massacre of 57 people are implicated in dozens of other killings that date back decades, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Tuesday. No one in the Ampatuan family, long a dominant political force in Maguindanao Province, was charged in the older killings, whose victims included political opponents and their relatives, public officials, people whose land the family wanted, and members of the Ampatuans’ own organization who disobeyed orders, the report said. Andal Ampatuan Jr., son of the family patriarch, is on trial for the Nov. 23, 2009, killings in Maguindanao, whose 57 victims included about 30 journalists and media support staff members who were with a group of people on their way to file candidacy papers for a political rival of Mr. Ampatuan.

headline: Iran: France Protests Assault of a Diplomat at a Concert
text: Plainclothes Iranian security forces violently assaulted a high-ranking French diplomat in Tehran, French officials said Tuesday after summoning Iran’s ambassador to France in protest. Iranian forces arrived unannounced outside a Persian music concert at an official French residence in Tehran on Monday, turning away or arresting young Iranians invited to the event, according to the Foreign Ministry. The diplomatic officer was struck in the head as he tried to intervene. A French official, speaking on condition of anonymity in keeping with government policy, said the Iranian authorities had in recent weeks asked that foreign embassies and missions in Tehran inform them of any cultural events they intend to hold, a request with which the French have complied. The episode on Monday was thus a “trap,” the official said.

headline: The Palin Network
text: On the night of the midterm elections earlier this month, Sarah Palin stayed up until 3 in the morning. From her hotel bedroom in Manhattan, she and her husband, Todd, followed the returns while she wrote e-mails on her iPad — congratulating winners, consoling losers — while reading others from people who wanted her to know that they had cast their vote for her daughter Bristol on “Dancing With the Stars” the evening before. Like much of her recent life, Palin’s day had been replete with reminders of the clout she had rapidly acquired. She had spent most of her time ensconced at the Fox television studios, though she managed to squeeze in a jog in Central Park — which she promptly chronicled on Twitter: “Beautiful!” Also at the studios was her fellow Fox News contributor Karl Rove, who had recently questioned in a British newspaper whether Palin’s new reality TV series, “Sarah Palin’s Alaska,” made her appear Oval Office-worthy. The building was abuzz over what would ensue when the two would inevitably bump into each other. The moment came after Palin finished a segment with the anchor Bret Baier and saw Rove lingering stageside with Brit Hume, a Fox colleague, holding a well-marked copy of “Alaska for Dummies” — a prop clearly intended to mollify Palin. She laughed, used her phone’s camera to take a picture of Rove with the book, traded brief hellos and then left the studio without mentioning Rove’s earlier comment.

headline: A Look Inside Palin World
text: In his cover story on Sarah Palin in this Sunday’s New York Times Magazine, the writer Robert Draper takes an intimate look inside Palin World and talks to the potential 2012 presidential contender about everything from her love of Twitter (“I just tweet; that’s just the way I roll,” Ms. Palin said) to whether she is weighing a run for the White House. “I am,” Ms. Palin said. “I’m engaged in the internal deliberations candidly, and having that discussion with my family, because my family is the most important consideration here.” Ms. Palin went on to say that there weren’t meaningful differences in policy among the field of Republican hopefuls “but that in fact there’s more to the presidency than that.”

headline: For Saudi Women, Biggest Challenge Is Getting to Play
text: After the 18-year-old Saudi equestrian Dalma Malhas won a bronze medal in show jumping at the first Youth Olympic Games in Singapore in August, she was singled out for praise by Jacques Rogge, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, in a news conference at the Games’ conclusion.

headline: AT&T: Your (Original) Social Network
text: Facebook is a mere infant compared with another social networking colossus that came earlier.

headline: Because the (Late) Night: Springsteen Rocks Jimmy Fallon
text: First of all, who else but Jimmy Fallon would have Bruce Springsteen walk onto his set to the theme song from “Who’s the Boss?” And who else but Mr. Fallon would invite him on for the entire show and then proceed to perform his (affectionate) impression of Mr. Springsteen straight to his face? Nobody, that’s who. Yes, Mr. Fallon, looking even more excited than when he got to introduce Guns N’ Roses at the 2002 MTV Video Music Awards, devoted nearly an hour to the Boss, who’s out hawking an album of “Darkness on the Edge of Town” rarities and outtakes called “The Promise.” In his interview segments (the first of which appears above), Mr. Springsteen came across as a pretty gosh-darn regular kinda guy: He has an awkward relationship with his brother-in-law! He’s perplexed by modern technology! And on top of that, he stuck around to perform two songs with Mr. Fallon’s house band, the Roots. But why are we sitting here jibber-jabbering when you could be watching video from the show?

headline: Cap-and-Trade Exchange Calls It Quits
text: The only national carbon cap-and-trade exchange in the United States is shutting down because of Congressional inaction on limiting emissions, company officials say.

headline: Quad Q&A: George Dohrmann
text: George Dohrmann, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, is a senior writer at Sports Illustrated. His newly released book, “Play Their Hearts Out: A Coach, His Star Recruit and the Youth Basketball Machine,” delves into the murky world of A.A.U. basketball, focusing on a star player, Demetrius Walker, and the coach who discovered him, Joe Keller. Walker’s dream is to make it to the N.B.A., while Keller’s is to become a basketball power player. In a phone interview, Dohrmann discussed what led him to want to write the book and what he thinks of A.A.U. basketball after spending eight years in its orbit.

headline: Cadillac Urban Luxury Concept Unveiled Ahead of L.A. Auto Show
text: Introduced on Wednesday: Cadillac Urban Luxury Concept

text: I read the news today: China is considering price controls to rein in surging inflation.
