text: –Will Roger Altman of Evercore succeed Larry Summers?

headline: Black Played Role in Schools’ Cola Wars
text: What we’re reading on this bright autumn morning, which could be one of the last warm days of the season. High in the low 60s.

headline: The Dark Ages, Returned In Full
text: There’s a famous passage in Schumpeter’s writings during the Great Depression, in which he lays out the extreme liquidationist position, arguing not just against the use of fiscal policy to fight unemployment but even against monetary policy, lest it get in the way of the “work of depressions”. That passage has been held up by many people as an example of the wrong-headedness that prevailed at the time. Here it is:

headline: Beijing’s Focus on Food Prices Ignores Broader Inflation Risk
text: HONG KONG  China took steps Wednesday to control rising prices at the most basic consumer level. But Beijing faces a severe challenge in preventing higher global commodity prices from igniting broader inflation that could threaten China’s streak of powerful economic growth.

headline: Merck’s New Cholesterol Drug Shows Promise
text: Merck has a potential blockbuster in anacetrapib, an experimental cholesterol drug that dramatically increases HDL, or “good” cholesterol even as it lowers LDL, the “bad” cholesterol.

headline: U.S. Consumer Prices Tame in October
text: Consumer prices inched up in October, driven almost entirely by rising gasoline costs, according to government statistics released on Wednesday.

headline: Homework Was Never Quite Like This: Gwyneth Paltrow Does ‘Glee’
text: Forget “Love and Other Disasters.” Forget “Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow.” Forget “Running With Scissors,” forget “Iron Man”s 1 and 2, forget GOOP and forget that she named her first-born child Apple. To watch Gwyneth Paltrow on “Glee” Tuesday was like being transported back to the late 1990s, when she could do no wrong and to see her on a screen was a guarantee of a compelling performance (and maybe the possibility of seeing her decapitated head in a box).

headline: The Frat Pack
text: Sometimes the most incongruous partnerships yield the most inspired results. Case in point: J. Press, known for its preppy sportswear for men, has teamed up with Urban Outfitters. While J. Press has a history steeped in Ivy League lore, its partnership with the hipster powerhouse might be just the thing to loosen up its staid image. Conversely, Urban Outfitters’s disheveled-chic aesthetic could benefit from a bit of polishing. The J. Press designer Mikito Takeshima sprinkled some references to “Happy Days” and “Animal House” into its classics and, faster than you can say “toga party,” a pairing worthy of the coolest slacker at Yale was born: a collection of trim wool slacks, plaid bomber jackets, blazers with gold hardware, slim button-down oxfords in faded hues and plush crew necks. Add some WASP-y accessories (rep ties and nautical belts) and you’ll be on your way to graduating with a major in style with a minor in effortless cool. J. Press for Urban Outfitters will be available starting Nov. 19.

headline: Postwar Growth and the Debt
text: I didn’t have room for more history in this morning’s column, but Austan Goolsbee, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, points out that the 1990s were hardly the only time when rapid growth brought down the budget deficit and the national debt.

headline: Michael Findlay, Former Merrill Banker, Joins Moelis
text: The boutique investment bank Moelis & Company has added Michael Findlay, who was previously a head of corporate broking in Europe at Merrill Lynch, to its growing London office.

headline: Pheneticizing
text: Alternative term to “racial passing” that “shifts the focus from the viewed to the viewer.”Reviewing Wayde Compton’s “After Canaan: Essays on Race, Writing and Region,” for Quill & Quire, Adebe DeRango-Adem argued:

headline: Google Strikes Deal With French Publisher
text: PARIS — Google said Wednesday that it had reached a deal with the publisher Hachette Livre, which has broken ranks with its French rivals and agreed to allow Google to scan thousands of out-of-print books for its digital library project.

headline: A Record Low for Inflation
text: Score one for the Federal Reserve, which some economists have accused of jumping the gun on deflation worries.

headline: Wednesday Reading: What’s in the Deficit Reduction Plans
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Barnes & Noble Shareholders Back Poison Pill
text: Shareholders of Barnes & Noble on Wednesday approved a shareholder rights plan that would limit stakes in the company to 20 percent.

headline: Ernest Cole: Photographer
text: Images from the exhibition in South Africa.

headline: Houses of the Holy
text: In the quiet and untouched state of Tamil Nadu in southern india, T goes looking for the soul of the country.

headline: Homecoming for Stark Record of Apartheid
text: JOHANNESBURG  When he was only in his 20s Ernest Cole, a black photographer who stood barely five feet tall, created one of the most harrowing pictorial records of what it was like to be black in apartheid South Africa. He went into exile in 1966, and the next year his work was published in the United States in a book, “House of Bondage,” but his photographs were banned in his homeland where he and his work have remained little known.

headline: For the Desert Tortoise, a Threat and an Opportunity
text: In an article in The New York Times on Wednesday, I write about how the fortunes of big solar power plants in the desert Southwest can hinge on the way developers handle imperiled wildlife in the path of their projects.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Buys Ladish for $778 Million
text: Allegheny Technologies, a maker of specialty metals products, said on Wednesday that it had acquired a rival, Ladish, in a cash and stock deal worth about $778 million.

headline: L.I. Study Rebuts Perceptions on Immigrant Workers
text: The growing immigrant population on Long Island has made a disproportionately large contribution to the region’s economy, with immigrants employed across the spectrum of occupations and more than half of the immigrant labor force holding white-collar jobs, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Mideast Talks May Hinge on Fiery Rabbi
text: Ahead of a delayed Israeli cabinet vote on a proposal to freeze West Bank settlement construction for 90-days in order to restart peace talks, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and opponents within his own governing coalition are both trying to win the support of two ministers from an ultra-Orthodox party who appear to hold the crucial swing votes.

headline: FIFA Report Finds Enough Risk All Around
text: On the day the United States national team defeated 2010 World Cup host South Africa, 1-0, and Argentina beat Brazil by the same score in Qatar, FIFA released details of a report that finds fault with both the American and Qatari bids to host the 2022 World Cup.

headline: The Money Gap in the Climate Fight
text: 11:56 a.m. | Updated A core scene from “Jerry Maguire,” in which a football star challenges his agent to get serious, holds the same message poor countries have placed directly in the face of the world’s established industrial powers in climate treaty negotiations that resume next month: “Show me the money.”

headline: Rangel’s Fall, as Dickens Would See It
text: The House ethics panel weighing Charles B. Rangel‘s fate left little doubt Tuesday about whether Mr. Rangel took part in unethical conduct. But one crucial sidebar remains unresolved: Was Mr. Rangel’s situation with his former lawyers really like something out of the Dickens novel “Bleak House”?

text: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Chevrolet Camaro Convertible

headline: Selig Is Happy Mets Took His Advice on Alderson
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — It has been understood for weeks that Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball,  encouraged the Mets to hire Sandy Alderson as their general manager after they fired Omar Minaya on Oct. 4. But on Wednesday Selig disclosed how strong his endorsement was.

headline: Disinflation Continues
text: Allan Meltzer wept (and so did Glenn Beck, but he always does):

headline: Coach Returns to Alabama Long After Fleeing Bryant’s Shadow
text: ATLANTA  Threats against his wife. A rock crashing through his office window. An administration that he thinks pulled the chair out from under him.

headline: G.M.’s Competition for Biggest I.P.O. Ever
text: As seemingly everyone in the business world counts down to the pricing of General Motors’ highly anticipated initial public offering, it is worth placing the stock sale in context.

headline: Supply Side Rabbits
text: Kevin O’Rourke is confused. He points out that optimists about Ireland’s outlook assert two things:

headline: Here’s to the UConn Women’s Streak
text: As college basketball kicks off its season in earnest with a day so saturated with games to remind us that, yes, television will go along with just about any gag, including round-the-clock games, we are reminded that while almost everything else about the sport changes from year to year, we can be comforted (or annoyed, depending on your point of view) by the constant that is the Connecticut women’s program. And Geno Auriemma’s hair.

headline: Now Shopping | Very Vignelli
text: For the fall issue of T Design, I wrote the Timeless page on Massimo Vignelli’s supersized, supergraphic Stendig calendar of 1966. It started me thinking about other vintage but evergreen designs from Vignelli’s office, where he and his wife and partner, Lella, have been frequent collaborators. Arguably their best-known product design is their plastic dinnerware for Heller. Now produced only in white (brightly colored older versions can bring high prices on the secondhand market), the stacking plates, bowls and mugs look as snappy — and are just as practical — as when they first appeared in 1964. From $10 to $12 per piece at the Conran Shop.

headline: Republican House Gain Now at 61 Seats
text: The Republican triumph in the House of Representatives has grown a little wider, with the party now capturing 61 seats in this month’s midterm elections. The latest victory comes in Illinois’s Eighth Congressional District, where Representative Melissa Bean, a Democrat, conceded to Joe Walsh, a Republican.

headline: Dynegy Postpones Vote on Blackstone Takeover Bid
text: The energy company Dynegy said Wednesday that it had postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $4.7 billion takeover by the Blackstone Group after the firm raised its bid in the face of opposition from two big Dynegy shareholders.

headline: For California, a New Month, a New Deficit
text: LOS ANGELES  Five weeks after the Legislature passed a budget that promised to close a $19 billion budget shortfall, California has sunk back into yet another fiscal crisis, this time facing a $26 billion gap that is posing a major new challenge for the incoming governor, Jerry Brown, and seems almost certain to force deep cuts in a state already reeling from three years of financial turmoil.

headline: Activist Artist Goes on Trial in Beijing
text: BEIJING  In a case that has galvanized the Chinese arts community, a prominent artist who helped lead a short-lived demonstration along the nation’s most politically hallowed thoroughfare went on trial Wednesday on assault charges that supporters say are aimed at punishing him for his political activism.

headline: Hulu Drops Prices to Compete With Netflix
text: In a compromise of sorts with its television network parents, Hulu is lowering the price of its TV subscription service to $7.99 a month from $9.99.

headline: Murkowski Wins Alaska Senate Race
text: ANCHORAGE — Senator Lisa Murkowski won a historic victory on Wednesday in her long-shot run for re-election as a write-in candidate.

headline: Paul Jacobs at Alice Tully Hall
text: Paul Jacobs, chairman of the organ department at Juilliard, re-inaugurated the Alice Tully Hall 4,192-pipe Kuhn organ with a performance of J.S. Bach’s "Clavier-Übung III."

headline: Another Accolade for Austan Goolsbee
text: Austan Goolsbee, the chairman of the President’s Council of Economic Advisers, can add yet another plaudit to his highly decorated résumé: one of Salon’s sexiest men of the year.

headline: Keeping Calm: Politics, Business and Sports Edition
text: First it was New York magazine, which floated the exceedingly hypothetical idea that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg could be singularly responsible for making Sarah Palin president. That is, if he ran as a third-party candidate.

headline: Murkowski Heads Home
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski flew home to Alaska on Wednesday, and could claim victory as early as Wednesday evening in her historic write-in bid for re-election, William Yardley reports.

headline: 'Phil Ochs: There But for Fortune'
text: The trailer premiere of the documentary "There But for Fortune," about the musician Phil Ochs.

headline: Disque D. Deane, Real Estate Investor, Dies at 89
text: Disque D. Deane, a financier and real estate investor who at one time controlled the General Motors Building, shopping centers in New York, Massachusetts and Georgia, and the nation’s largest federally subsidized housing complex, Starrett City in Brooklyn, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Boston. He was 89.

headline: Yao on the Mend, Again
text: It’s the proverbial good news-bad news situation for injured Houston Rockets center Yao Ming. The happy news is, his sprained left ankle doesn’t appear to be nearly as serious as his litany of other foot injuries.

headline: Praising Second Place
text: Two follow-ups to the conversation here last week about whether to ground a child who brings home less than an 85 on her report card.

headline: Bail in Insider Case Set at $3 Million
text: A French doctor accused of illegally leaking sensitive material about a clinical drug trial to a hedge fund manager will be held on $3 million bail, a magistrate judge said on Wednesday.

headline: Bean Counters to the Rescue!
text: Gail Collins: David, did you do the budget puzzle in The Times on Sunday? I really enjoyed seeing if I could eliminate all the shortfalls for the next 20 years. (Thank you, David Leonhardt and Co.) The first time I did it, about two-thirds of my savings came from increased tax revenue rather than spending cuts. But in the end, I got it down to 50-50. How about you?

headline: Report Faults BP and Contractors for Rig Explosion and Spill
text: WASHINGTON  Inadequate training and supervision of key personnel aboard the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig and a lack of focus on safety were among the factors that contributed to the explosion that killed 11 workers and sent millions of barrels of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday by a team of scientific experts.

headline: 2012 VW Eos: If at First You Don’t Succeed, Get a Face-Lift
text: Introduced on Wednesday: 2012 Volkswagen Eos

headline: From Ancient Rome to a Valley in Virginia: More Digital Humanities Projects
text: A majority of academics may view with suspicion what’s come to be called the digital humanities, but as I explain in this article (the first in a series on how technology is changing scholarship), the new alliance of techies and fuzzies is producing all sorts of experiments in presenting information.

headline: Long Missed and Awaited, Tully Hall Organ Greets Its Public
text: Lincoln Center could have been forgiven if it had gone a little crazy in celebrating the reinstallation of the lovable Kuhn organ in the renovated Alice Tully Hall, now the only pipe organ in a major concert hall in New York. From the time of the instrument’s removal in 2006 until it was finally put back in place in recent months, fearful, not to say paranoid, organ fanciers greeted the center’s repeated assurances that the instrument would return in all its glory, and then some, with unalloyed skepticism.

headline: Gotham Chronicle: Sharp Eye, and Pencil
text: IF there is a single constant in the creative world, it is that fame has a nasty habit of disappearing overnight. One prime example is the cartoonist Denys Wortman, who from 1924 to 1954 contributed six drawings a week to The New York World and its successors.

headline: Get Me Redraw!
text: Denys Wortman, a New York reporter who drew, is being rediscovered.

headline: Social Coupons and Small Businesses, Part 2
text: Last week, I wrote about Ron Weiss and his experiences using a Groupon discount at Jeffrey’s Restaurant and Bar, in Austin. (If you haven’t seen it, the post ignited a lively debate on the uses and misuses of Groupon.)

headline: Consumers Say They’ll Spend More This Christmas
text: A holiday spending boost — which many retail stores desperately need to put them in the black — may be in the cards this year, at least if a recent survey of consumers is to be believed.

headline: Expanded Return Periods for Those With Buyer’s Regret
text: American Express recently announced a new service that gives shoppers  180 days to  return eligible purchased goods. It also covers certain return shipping and restocking fees.

headline: Brooklyn Winery Opens in Williamsburg
text: BEFORE Duane Reade landed on Williamsburg’s shore, the trucker-hatted and ironically T-shirted drank cheap beer in cavernous spaces along North Eighth Street.

headline: An Aid Worker Writes: Afghanistan, Disability, and the West’s Limiting Labels
text: KABUL — I’ve learned that Afghans are prone to pragmatism when it comes to what we Westerners refer to as disability. Despite what you might think, our obsession with identity politics doesn’t play very well in Afghanistan, at least about this it doesn’t.

headline: Museum of Modern Art Gets on the iPad App Bandwagon
text: Ab Ex now has its own app. In conjunction with its “Abstract Expressionist New York” exhibition, the grand tour through the Museum of Modern Art’s holdings of (mostly) New York School masterpieces, the museum has just released its first application for the Apple iPad, which is rapidly becoming a museum-going staple.

headline: Interview With the President of the World Chess Federation, Part 2
text: After his recent re-election as president of the World Chess Federation, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov offered to answer questions from readers of The Times about the federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fédération Internationale des Échecs), and about his plans for the future of the game. Part one of the interview appeared Tuesday and addressed the federation’s plans to build a chess center in New York City and the recent election. This is part two. Part three will appear Thursday.

headline: The Takeaway: Cavett Talks
text: Dick Cavett appeared on “The Takeaway” to discuss his show and his new book, and reflect on a little-known fact: his time as gold-medal state gymnastics champion in Nebraska.

headline: TimesCast | November 17, 2010
text: The Europe debt crisis looms; Cable news stars defend their journalistic integrity; and a first look at another installment in the series "A Year at War"

headline: House Democrats Won’t Delay Leadership Vote
text: House Democrats today rejected a call to delay leadership elections, clearing the way for Nancy Pelosi to return as party leader.

headline: Your Comments on ‘Clicking’ in Class
text: 1:52 p.m. | Updated For an interesting coda on this discussion, scroll to the bottom of this post, where Professor Bill White, the subject of the original article, provides the results of a survey on the efficacy of clickers that he conducted with his students — using their clickers, of course.

headline: Revisiting a Republican Deficit Plan
text: In the last week, two different bipartisan groups have released their plans for reducing the deficit, and a liberal coalition in Washington will soon do the same. Arguably the first in this spate of deficit plans came from Representative Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican now in line to become chairman of the House Budget Committee.

headline: Rep. Ryan on His Medicare Plan
text: The following was submitted by Representative Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin. More on Mr. Ryan’s plan to change Medicare and reduce the deficit is here.

headline: On Our Radar: World’s Largest Biodiesel Plant Opens in Singapore
text: What is being billed as the largest biodiesel plant in the world started production this week in Singapore. Operated by Neste Oil, the plant has the capacity to produce 800,000 metric tons of fuel per year. The fuel is made from vegetable oils or a combination of oils and waste animal fat sourced from the food industry. [Marketwatch]

headline: Contemporary in Luxembourg
text: This 550-square-meter house with an indoor pool is in Luxembourg, just outside the city center. It’s on the market for 3.9 million euros (about $5.3 million)

headline: Accused Arms Dealer Pleads Not Guilty
text: A man accused of being one of the world’s most prolific arms dealers swaggered into a Manhattan courtroom on Wednesday, sizing up his surroundings after a two-year fight between the United States and Russia over his extradition from Thailand.

headline: A Business Creator Sees Big Returns From Social Media
text: Asked to name the world’s wealthiest entrepreneurs, few people would think of Eric Lefkofsky, who is 40 and keeps a deliberately low profile in his hometown of Chicago. But Mr. Lefkofsky has an impressive entrepreneurial track record, one that recently led Forbes to estimate his wealth at $750 million.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Warning Over Alcoholic Energy Drinks
text: The Food and Drug Administration cracked down Wednesday on four manufacturers of caffeinated alcoholic drinks, giving them 15 days to stop adding caffeine to the products or stop selling them altogether.

headline: New Director for  Schomburg Center Named
text: Khalil Gibran Muhammad, a history professor at Indiana University, has been named the new director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture,  to begin in July 2011. New York Public Library officials made the announcement on Wednesday, ending a sometimes contentious search.

headline: Out of Work, Spider-Man Gets Advice From Bloomberg
text: A team-up is often called for when superheroes face problems too big for them to handle on their own. In a new comic book, Peter Parker, the alter ego of Spider-Man, gets a little help from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to deal with one of his toughest foes: unemployment.

text: 2:07 p.m. | Updated  This post was updated to clarify Microsoft’s pricing model around the Azure for science services.

headline: Academy Tallies Missteps by Gulf Drillers
text: Initial findings have been released by the panel convened by the National Academy of Engineering to assess decisions, or the lack of them, that led to the deadly oil rig explosion and gulf gusher. Unsurprisingly, there are strong signs that concerns about money outweighed concerns about sources of risk. The full report will be issued next year.

headline: On the Record: Praise for Burris
text: When Roland Burris, a Democrat from Illinois, was appointed to the United States Senate in late 2008, a cloud of impropriety hung over his selection, and not even fellow Democrats were eager to welcome him into their ranks. But now, as Mr. Burris’s time in Congress is coming to an end, Senate Democrats had nothing but kind words for him in Tuesday’s Homeland Security hearing about closing gaps in air cargo security.

headline: Klein’s Waiver, and the City’s Chief Street Monitor

headline: An N.B.A. Move That Crossed an Ocean
text: Growing up, Roger Mason Jr. practiced the moves that were created by America’s basketball imagination. There was the crossover dribble, with the player moving the ball from one hand to the other, and the fadeaway jump shot, with the player leaping backward while shooting to create distance from the defender. But only after he became a professional did Mason decide to expand globally, adding fakes and feints and other moves that were manufactured elsewhere.

headline: Building Relationships, Capturing Lives
text: Rachel Mummey, 27, has been an intern at The Palm Beach Post since October. Last week, Mummey, a School of Visual Communication graduate student at Ohio University, was named College Photographer of the Year. Her story, “For Better or For Worse,” about Bernard and Mary Triplet, won an award from Pictures of the Year International. For the last year, Ms. Mummey has been photographing low-income families from Chicago who relocated to Iowa City. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited.

headline: Free Rides, Minus the Smoking Tires, Courtesy of ‘Top Gear’
text: To promote the premiere on Sunday of the American version of the BBC program “Top Gear” on the History channel, free rides in several hot cars were offered around Bryant Park and Times Square in Manhattan on Wednesday. (More details about the new show will be in the Automobiles section of The New York Times on Sunday.)

headline: House Democrats Re-Elect Pelosi as Their Leader
text: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California, was re-elected on Wednesday to lead the Democrats in the next Congress, despite her party’s loss of more than 60 seats and its majority control of the House in the midterm elections.

headline: Warner Music Reports Fourth-Quarter Loss
text: The Warner Music Group posted a $46 million loss in its fourth quarter as increased digital sales were not enough to offset declines from CDs.

headline: Mets’ Manager Interviews Proceed in Orlando
text: ORLANDO — The Mets are gathering their final four managerial candidates at the Waldorf Astoria and will begin the second round of interviews Wednesday afternoon. They expect to get all four interviews completed by Thursday afternoon.

headline: Cuomo Seeks Court’s Help in Undecided Senate Races
text: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo is asking the state’s chief judge to expedite the handling of the three undecided State Senate races to avoid a leadership stalemate when the next legislative session begins in January.

text: Workers of the world unite and bemoan the end of the “buddy punch.”

headline: U.S. Lags in Reducing Traffic Fatalities, Report Shows
text: The debate over which countries produce the best drivers will continue unabated, but the National Research Council weighed in Tuesday with an opinion about which countries have the safest drivers — and the news is not good for Americans.

headline: Coal Plants, Rising and Retiring
text: While many believe that far stricter regulation of carbon dioxide emissions is inevitable in the next few years, coal plants are still under construction around the country, as I wrote in The New York Times on Wednesday. Plans for even more plants have been scrapped, partly because of the recession. Keeping score can be tough.

headline: Asked & Answered | Claire Denis
text: On November 19, the French director Claire Denis’s latest film, “White Material” opens in New York. It’s her 10th feature and, like her first and fifth films, “Chocolat,” (1988) and “Beau Travail,” (1999), it was shot in Africa, where she grew up. You can usually recognize a Denis production due to its minimal dialogue, evocative sense of place, long, lingering shots, non-linear narrative flow and intense focus on complex human relationships. These are provocative slow burns that leave unanswered questions in their wakes. We asked Denis to answer a few.

headline: A New Genre of Photo Apps Competes for Time
text: Given a few minutes of extra time, I like to jump into a methodical game of app hopscotch on my iPhone, skipping between the square icons looking for something to catch my attention.

headline: Kucinich Makes Bid for Oversight Committee
text: Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, a two-time long-shot Democratic presidential candidate, is known for ideas that come out of left field.

headline: Coup Attempt by Military Is Reported in Madagascar
text: JOHANNESBURG  Military officers in Madagascar on Wednesday proclaimed that they had seized the government. The mutinous group included some of the same men who had taken over the country last year and handed power to the president they now seek to topple.

headline: An E-Book Bonanza: 12 Saramago Novels
text: In another digital publishing experiment Houghton Mifflin Harcourt will publish 12 of José Saramago’s novels — plus a novella — in an e-book collection for $36.

headline: Biology in Film: Using Animation to Study Cell Structure
text: Overview  | How can animations help convey the dynamic nature of cellular processes? What can we learn from animation that cannot be learned as easily from still images? In this lesson, students watch high-definition animations that depict the processes of DNA transcription and translation, and then write voice-over scripts.

headline: ‘Rational Discussion of Climate’ on Capitol Hill?
text: Maybe it’s the nature of lame duck congressional sessions. Maybe it’s Democrats seeking ways to reach out to Republicans before the shift in power in the House.

headline: RockMelt: The User Manual
text: Last week, a start-up company called RockMelt unveiled a free browser for PCs and Macs, customized for people who live on Facebook, Twitter and other social-networking sites. RockMelt has gotten a lot of attention, because the company’s management and investors include several of the “Netscape mafia” who built the first widely successful browser in the early 1990s, including the Silicon Valley wunderkind Marc Andreessen.

headline: Ailes to Kurtz on Donations and Obama’s ‘Belief System’
text: Some people in the television world were outraged when Keith Olbermann donated money to three Democratic candidates ahead of the midterm elections, prompting a short suspension by MSNBC. Roger Ailes was not among them.

headline: For Euro Nations, There Are Strings Attached
text: FRANKFURT  Even as British officials and other Europeans bear down on a resolution to Ireland’s debt crisis, there is a lingering unease in the markets about whether one or more countries might eventually bolt the currency union.

headline: Going to Market in the Shadow of G.M.
text: The initial public offering of General Motors has been getting all the headlines and dominating the airtime on the financial news networks. But what about the other companies that are scheduled to go public on Thursday?

headline: Boehner Officially on the Path to Be Speaker
text: House Republicans, fresh off their tremendous victories this month, have given the official nod to John A. Boehner of Ohio, setting him on the path to be speaker of the House for the 112th Congress.

headline: Guilty Plea in Cantor Threat Case
text: A Philadelphia man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to threatening Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the No. 2 Republican in the House, earlier this year.

headline: Yep, It’s Regressive
text: Jon Chait takes another look at Bowles-Simpson, this time with numbers from the Tax Policy Center, and is disillusioned. As I surmised, it redistributes income upward: the bottom 80 percent of families would pay higher taxes than they did in the Clinton years, while the top 20 percent — and especially the top 5 percent — would pay less; not what you’d call shared sacrifice.

headline: An Iranian Director’s Impassioned Defense
text: At his trial in Tehran last week, Jafar Panahi, an internationally celebrated Iranian filmmaker who supported opposition protesters after last year’s disputed presidential election, accused the authorities of sending the message: “You will repent if you don’t think like us.”

headline: HomeAway Returns to the Super Bowl
text: Another advertiser has identified itself as a sponsor of Super Bowl XLV, to be broadcast on Fox on Feb. 6.

headline: White Light Festival: A Commercial Endeavor
text: Over the past several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. The classical music critics and a reporter are discussing the merits of the festival, music and transcendence on ArtsBeat. Read all posts.

headline: Debating Social Security’s Cost of Living Adjustment
text: You could almost hear the collective groan from Social Security recipients after they learned that their benefits would not increase in 2011 because of the low rate of inflation.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Wendell August Forge
text: On March 4, Wendell August Forge, a family-owned company that makes and sells metal giftware, booked the largest order in its history — for commemorative tickets to be given away the next month by the Pittsburgh Penguins at the last regular-season hockey game played at Mellon Arena.

headline: Kanye West, Still Unfiltered, on Eve of Fifth Album
text: KANYE WEST prefers his narratives linear, uninterrupted, undistressed. That’s why, when he’s been in the news media lately, his interlocutors have largely stayed out of his way. On everything from radio shows to record-label-sanctioned conference calls simulcast on the Internet, the pattern has been pretty much the same: Mr. West speaks until he is done, and only then does someone ask another question.

text: Had to post this eventually.

headline: Mark Bittman’s Sustainable Thanksgiving
text: The New York Times food writer Mark Bittman sometimes calls himself a “less-meatarian’’ to explain how his diet has changed over the years.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: YouTube: Parathas, the Indian flat bread, take to the air. – Nick Fox

headline: In the Examination Room, an Effort to Prevent Financial Abuse
text: Can doctors and other medical professionals be trained to spot elderly patients who are at risk of being ripped off?

text: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Ford Focus Global Touring Car race car

headline: Vain Glorious | Sweet (Smelling) Charity
text: Who: Six designers (Alexis Mabille, Mary Katrantzou, Juun J., Rad Hourani, N. Hoolywood and Ohne Titel) and six perfumers (Rodrigo Flores-Roux, Shyamala Maisondieu, Natalie Gracia-Cetto, Christophe Raynaud, Stephen Nilsen and Yann Vasnier).

headline: Fearing Terror Threat, Germany Raises Security
text: Germany dispatched heavily armed police officers and bomb-sniffing dogs to train stations, airports and key landmarks on Wednesday as a new picture emerged of the terrorist threat that had already provoked security alarms relating to Britain and France.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Do Not Disturb Kanye West
text: On the cover of this week’s Arts & Leisure Jon Caramanica looks at the rapper Kanye West, who is capping off weeks of controversy with a new album, “My Beautiful Dark, Twisted Fantasy,” out on Monday on Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam. While the album is “terrific,” as Mr. Caramanica writes, “that doesn’t matter nearly as much as it should, at least partly because of Mr. West’s insistence on his own greatness. By not allowing for responses to his work other than awe, the value of the work itself is diminished; it becomes an object of admiration, not of study.” Read his story here.

headline: Google TV, Usability Not Included
text: Google Mail. Google Phone. Google Voice. Google News.

headline: Lemon and Lime from Quincy Jones
text: Quincy Jones knows subtle: his arrangements for Count Basie and Frank Sinatra on “Fly Me to the Moon” were subtle. His Oscar-nominated scores for “In Cold Blood” and “The Color Purple” were subtle. O.K., so maybe “Thriller,” the album he produced for Michael Jackson, wasn’t so subtle.

headline: Is Pelosi America’s Most Unpopular Politician?
text: House Democrats voted Wednesday to keep House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California as their leader, despite  a challenge from Representative Heath Shuler of North Carolina, a Blue Dog Democrat.

headline: Plan to Extend No. 7 Train Surprised the M.T.A.
text: The Bloomberg administration stunned the city’s transportation establishment on Tuesday evening as reports trickled out about an ambitious plan to extend the No. 7 subway train under the Hudson River and into New Jersey.

headline: Older Job-Seekers More Willing to Take a Pay Cut
text: We recently wrote about the latest survey report on displaced workers from Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers. Now the Sloan Center on Aging and Work of Boston College has drilled down deeper into the data to investigate the differences between older and younger unemployed workers, given that older workers have tremendous trouble finding re-employment once they have become displaced.

headline: Andrews Adds to Giants’ Injury Worries
text: Giants offensive lineman Shawn Andrews, who started the past two games at left tackle in place of the injured David Diehl, did not practice on Wednesday because of his own nagging back injury.

headline: Bloomberg Rallies Business Leaders Behind Black
text: Hoping to fend off skepticism about his choice for schools chancellor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has turned to a familiar and reliable ally: the business community.

headline: New Releases on DVD
text: AVATAR Eight months after the first home video release here’s another edition of the James Cameron blockbuster, which contains three different cuts — the original theatrical version, a “special edition rerelease” that is 8 minutes longer and a “collector’s extended cut” that adds 16 minutes to the original. Still no 3-D, though. (Fox, Blu-ray, $54.99; standard definition, $34.98; PG-13)

headline: Cellphone Carriers Try to Control Signal Boosters
text: When Sean Kirkland, an executive vice president for sales and marketing for a company that plans corporate meetings and events, moved into a new house in San Diego last year, he loved everything about the place.

headline: Repackaged Favorites on DVD
text: THE AFRICAN QUEEN Long unavailable on home video, John Huston’s 1951 romantic adventure, starring Katharine Hepburn as a starched missionary and Humphrey Bogart as a grizzled riverboat captain, returns in a handsomely restored print. (Paramount, two-disc Blu-ray commemorative edition, $57.99; two-disc standard definition, $50.99; Blu-ray, $39.99; standard definition, $25.99; not rated)

headline: A Bear Fights Soros and a Bullish Tide on InterOil
text: Is InterOil a great way to play Asia’s commodity boom or a overhyped company worth a fraction of its $3.4 billion market value?

headline: Medicare Panel Backs Prostate Drug
text: A federal advisory committee said Wednesday that there was adequate evidence that the drug Provenge prolongs the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer, an endorsement that makes it more likely that Medicare will pay for the $93,000 treatment.

headline: Tools to Do Your Travel Homework Before Booking
text: When online travel agencies started rolling out smartphone apps, I was dubious. Mobile phones are great for killing time or completing small tasks  not for sifting through pages of flight times and travel dates.

headline: Sharpening the Type in Windows 7
text: Q. I know you can adjust the ClearType settings in Windows 7 to make the type on the screen look sharper. But is it possible to save these settings and switch back and forth between two users with different sets of eyes and opinions about what looks best?

headline: Seasonal DVDs
text: BING CROSBY: THE TELEVISION SPECIALS, VOLUME 2 — THE CHRISTMAS SPECIALS A two-disc selection of our national crooner’s Christmas shows, ranging from the first, from 1961, to the final 1977 show, featuring Crosby’s duet with David Bowie, “Peace on Earth/Little Drummer Boy.” (Infinity Entertainment, $29.98, not rated)

headline: Midterms Threaten Obama’s Rail Plans
text: The Obama administration’s signature transportation initiative is almost always described as “high-speed rail.” But more than half of the $10.4 billion the administration has awarded for rail so far has not gone toward real bullet trains, but to build slower, conventional train lines that it hopes will form the foundation of a nationwide high-speed rail network.

headline: Quote Unquote | A Friend Indeed
text: –Karl Lagerfeld praises the social media interface’s design. I wish I was “friends” with Karl so I could “like” this statement.

headline: 2011 Porsche Cayman R: R is for Radical?
text: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Porsche Cayman R

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Social Networking in the Workplace
text: When social networking and the workplace meet, complex issues often arise. On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Bill Milani, a lawyer who represents employers, about how companies are addressing the social media boom — and what you might want to consider if you post to social media sites while at work. Mr. Milani, who teaches at the School of Industrial and Labor Relations of Cornell, says more companies are adopting or considering policies on social networking.

headline: Hunting for Looted Art in Paris
text: IN Room 38 of the Louvre’s Richelieu Wing hangs “The Astronomer” by the Dutch master Jan Vermeer. It is an exquisite painting. The stargazer sits before a celestial globe, his fingers spanning the constellation Pegasus. He wears a teal Japanese silk robe, a style favored by Dutch burghers in the late 17th century. He is lost in thought and bathed in a golden light.

headline: Skin Deep: A Late-Night Tanning Session
text: Self-beautifying options of the wee hours have expanded well beyond trims and manicures.

headline: G.M. Shares Surge on Market Debut
text: 4:20 p.m. | Updated Shares of General Motors surged on Thursday in their New York Stock Exchange debut.

headline: Seeking Clarity and Truth at a Drunken Reunion
text: The introduction of the supernatural doesn’t interrupt Heidi Schreck’s dining-room drama “There Are No More Big Secrets.” Talk of witches and spirits is woven into the fabric of the otherwise realistic world, which, like the plays of Annie Baker, whose “Circle Mirror Transformation” starred Ms. Schreck in a breakout role, includes lingering pauses between lovely bursts of offhand dialogue.

headline: Superstar Horse Is Retired With Hope She Bears Another
text: The great mare Zenyatta was retired Wednesday and will be sent in early December to her new home at Lane’s End farm near Versailles, Ky. Her owners, Jerry and Ann Moss, have yet to pick a stallion for her first date in the breeding shed sometime in 2011.

headline: In Panama, a Haven for Expats
text: ON a humid morning in Panama City earlier this year, three Americans, two Swedes, two Portuguese, two Irish and three Israelis sat down together for breakfast. The diverse group was united by a single interest: free pancakes, a standard perk at Luna’s Castle Hostel in the city’s historic district.

headline: Beauty House Calls in the Wee Hours
text: NEWSPAPER deliverers show up on your doorstep at dawn. At that hour, the woman you pay to spray you with a fake tan usually would not. But recently Tamar Vezirian of Gotham Glow arrived at a client’s apartment in Murray Hill in Manhattan to bronze her before a vacation. “She had to leave at 6 a.m. to go to J.F.K.,” Ms. Vezirian said. “So I tanned her, and then her car service picked her up and took her away.”

headline: When Dancing on Pointe Isn’t Hard Enough
text: While dance fans eagerly await the release next month of “Black Swan,” Darren Aronofsky’s melodrama about rival ballerinas, here’s a version of “Swan Lake” you won’t see often. It’s not new, but it has lately been making the rounds, wowing some balletomanes and horrifying others. You decide.

headline: Match Making | Just for Erdem Lovers
text: The British store Matches has stocked its virtual and digital racks with Erdem for quite some time now. Now the designer behind the brand, Erdem Moralioglu, has created an exclusive pre-spring collection just for the Matches Web site. The five pieces, available now through March 2011, come in an Erdem signature floral print and a range of styles including a jean blouse, a maxi skirt and a couple of dresses. “The special collection is targeted toward cocktail wear, hence the Deco feel to the pieces,” says Ruth Chapman, a co-founder of the store. Here is a sneak peek behind the making of this stellar match by the photographer Errol Rainey and featuring the model Valentine Fillol-Cordier.

headline: Need Solar Power? Buy a Garden Plot
text: In an article in the special Energy section of The New York Times on Wednesday, I write about a developer who wants to sell “garden plots” in a 15-megawatt photovoltaic farm in Davis, Calif., so that residents can go solar without having to cut down trees in the city’s urban forest to install rooftop arrays.

headline: DVDs for Cinephiles
text: CHAPLIN AT KEYSTONE 34 short comedies and a full-length feature (“Tillie’s Punctured Romance”) from Charlie Chaplin’s first year in motion pictures, presented in revelatory high-grade restorations. (Flicker Alley, $79.95, not rated)

headline: George H.W. Bush to Get Medal of Freedom
text: President Obama will present the Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor, to former president George H. W. Bush and 14 others with careers in politics, the arts, business and sports.

headline: Laurence Tribe Is Leaving Justice Job
text: After nine months as the Justice Department’s “senior counselor for access to justice,” Laurence H. Tribe, a prominent Harvard law professor and mentor to President Obama, will leave his position and return to Massachusetts early next month.

headline: Palin Tells Barbara Walters She Can Beat Obama
text: On the heels of a New York Times magazine article in which she acknowledges considering a run for president, Sarah Palin has told Barbara Walters that she believes she could defeat President Obama.

headline: ‘Police! Step Away From the Chess Table’
text: Updated, 6:10 p.m. | Wherever you find yourself in the city, there is probably an outdoor chess table nearby. According to the parks department, there are more than 2,000 public chess or checkers tables spread among 536 parks, offering the perfect spot to sacrifice a queen or promote a pawn.

headline: White Light Festival: Define Spiritual
text: Over the past several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. The classical music critics and a reporter are discussing the merits of the festival, music and transcendence on ArtsBeat. Read all posts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Indonesia, Myanmar and Israel.

headline: A Spanish Master
text: Still buzzing over Billy Reid’s win at the CFDA Awards and the news of the royal engagement, various fashion cognoscenti trekked up to the landmark townhouse occupied by the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute (684 Park Avenue, at 68th Street) to get a sneak peek at the exhibition, “Balenciaga: Spanish Master.” Oscar de la Renta, the Institute’s Chairman of the Board explained that the influences in his world “were very Spanish because even after his big success in Paris he still remained very Spanish as a person.” He went on to say that Balenciaga “was deeply influenced by all the culture and folklore of Spain from the religious to the gypsy and the flamencos and bullfighters.” T caught up with Hamish Bowles, who curated the show but who also has an impressive collection of Balenciaga all his own.

headline: Fashion on eBay, Spoken by Annabel Tollman
text: ANNABEL TOLLMAN, a celebrity stylist, has a simple message for clients like Scarlett Johansson, Anne Hathaway and the Olsen twins when it comes to fashioning head-turning looks. “Make a fairy tale and go and live in it,” she said.

headline: Playwrights Shuttle to TV and Back
text: ONE of the strangely enduring laments of the American theater concerns playwrights leaving for television. Critics and theater people regularly sigh about how the lure of riches hurts the growth of playwrights and contemporary drama.

headline: Senator Asks: Can’t Fox and MSNBC Just Go Away?
text: There’s a part of Senator Jay Rockefeller, Democrat of West Virginia, that would like to see Fox News Channel and MSNBC vanish.

headline: Steering With Knees, Cuffed Fugitive Drives Off in Police Car
text: The police were searching for a fugitive wanted for questioning in a Bronx shooting and other charges on Wednesday, after he escaped from police custody and — using his knees to steer because his hands were cuffed — sped off in an unmarked police car in Fort Lee, N.J.

headline: New Plugs for an Electric Car
text: The effort by the Chevrolet division of General Motors to familiarize drivers with the 2011 Chevrolet Volt — an electric car with a gasoline engine — is accelerating with additional commercials.

headline: Where Hepburn Might Shop
text: CHRISTINA FRENCH HOUGHTON’S great-great-great-grandfather was the legendary actress Katharine Houghton Hepburn’s uncle.

headline: Southern-Flavored Rock Comes to Town, Complete With a ’70s Feel
text: On the plus side Kings of Leon albums are improving. “Come Around Sundown” (RCA), which was released last month, is the band’s best and also its loosest. Gone is the underskilled tension of its early albums, which felt lashed together with twine. Finally, the group’s shaggy Southern rock boogie is beginning to feel earned and confident.

headline: Report Casts Doubt on Contador’s Claim
text: A Spanish newspaper reported that the World Anti-Doping Agency discredited Alberto Contador’s claim that tainted beef he ate caused him to fail a drug test at the Tour de France last summer.

headline: Just Your Conventional Mix of Rachmaninoff, High Kicks and High Heels
text: As an example of High Junk at its showiest, look no further than Complexions. The company  it bears the subtitle “Contemporary Ballet” and its artistic directors are Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson  is now installed at the Joyce for its annual season. On Tuesday’s opening night, all the choreography was by Mr. Rhoden; all was efficiently horrid.

headline: Want to Play Chess in the Park? It Could Be a Crime
text: Playing chess in New York City parks is a well established custom, so much so that the city has installed more than 2,000 tables among its 536 parks. But, if adults want to play on those tables — and those are typically the people who do — and those tables happen to be in a playground, the players may run into trouble. With the police. That is evidently what a group of players found out at the Emerson Playground in Inwood Hill Park in Manhattan.

headline: David Burke To Open a Restaurant in the James New York
text: David Burke has just signed on to do the restaurant in the James New York, a new hotel at Grand Street and Avenue of the Americas in SoHo. It is expected to open in February on a site, 32 Grand Street, that is essentially where the Moonstruck Diner used to be, Mr. Burke said.

headline: Mixing Old and New in Lebanon
text: The owners saw the potential in a “pile of rubble,” filling it with modern furniture and contemporary art.

headline: Focusing in on Dreams and Meditations
text: The young French pianist David Fray approaches music very seriously. Though his performances of works by Schubert and Bach on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall were musically refined and technically elegant, searching out the meditative qualities of the music was Mr. Fray’s top priority. In the first of Schubert’s Four Impromptus (D. 899), he immediately summoned the attention of his audience by playing the bare double octave that begins the piece with sternness and steely sound. But then, as the wistful theme began, Mr. Fray played it with such aching delicacy that the music seemed almost too sad to speak. As the piece evolved into haunting episodes with endless streams of repeated triplets, Mr. Fray revealed the music’s obsessive, hypnotic core even while playing with remarkably soft dynamics.

headline: India Microcredit Faces Collapse From Defaults
text: MADOOR, India  India’s rapidly growing private microcredit industry faces imminent collapse as almost all borrowers in one of India’s largest states have stopped repaying their loans, egged on by politicians who accuse the industry of earning outsize profits on the backs of the poor.

headline: Why I’m Soft On Sales Taxes
text: There’s a lot of backlash against the new Rivlin-Domenici proposal for suggesting a significant VAT — and people are right, sales taxes are regressive taxes. But while I haven’t had time to evaluate the whole thing, the sales tax itself isn’t a killing point in my view.

headline: Bristol Palin Survives
text: Despite posting the lowest scores from the judges for the third straight week, Bristol Palin survived another elimination round of “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday as she beat out the singer Brandy Norwood to advance to the finals. The ABC show garnered an impressive 17.2 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, enough to lift the network to second place on the night. CBS led the night as usual with 19.4 million viewers for “NCIS” at 8 followed by 15.8 million at 9 for “NCIS: Los Angeles.” Although Fox’s “Glee,” with a guest appearance from Gwyneth Paltrow, attracted the night’s top ratings among viewers 18 to 49, in total viewers the 8 p.m. episode drew a more modest 11.6 million as Fox placed third over all, ahead of NBC.

headline: In Beirut, a Town House Rises From Rubble
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon

headline: 2010 L.A. Auto Show
text: Highlights from the auto show in Los Angeles.

headline: Susan Boyle Returns to Top of Chart
text: Susan Boyle, below, has bumped Taylor Swift from the top of the Billboard album chart. But Ms. Boyle’s success is not nearly as splashy as it was a year ago, when her debut album broke sales records and went on to dominate the chart for weeks. “The Gift” (Syco/Columbia), Ms. Boyle’s second CD, which includes lush versions of holiday standards as well as gloomy-but-still-possibly-inspirational songs like Lou Reed’s “Perfect Day” and Leonard Cohen’s “Hallelujah,” sold 318,000 copies in the United States in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. That was far from the 701,000 her first album opened with last year, but it was enough to take the top spot from Ms. Swift, whose “Speak Now” (Big Machine) moved 212,000 in its third week out. Some new releases placed high on this week’s chart: the rapper Kid Cudi opened at No. 3 with 169,000 sales of his second album, “Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager” (Dream On/G.O.O.D./Universal Motown); Volume 36 of the pop compilation series “Now That’s What I Call Music!” bowed at No. 4 with 89,000; and Bon Jovi’s “Greatest Hits” (Island) opened at No. 5 with 88,000.

headline: Afraid, Betrayed, Mistreated and Optimistic
text: The camaraderie of the road filled the concert by the English band Mumford & Sons on Tuesday night at Terminal 5, finishing a long United States tour. Marcus Mumford and his band (whose members are not related to him) didn’t wait for their headlining spot to get onstage.

headline: Sunny Approach To Mordant Lyricist
text: The song lyrics of Lorenz Hart offer a singer any number of possible interpretive paths to follow. You can sink into their quicksand of wistful urbanity as Mary Cleere Haran does. Or lovingly deconstruct them as Karen Akers does. Or you can stand aside and admire their rhymes and polished turns of phrase as Stefanie Powers does in her New York cabaret debut, “Hart of My Heart,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. The Hart refers not only to Lorenz but also to Ms. Powers’s long-running television series, “Hart to Hart.”

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Some women love czars, while some find true love with a gay best friend. Others are drawn to those who behead kings, while the next gal will flee from a good thing. Some aren’t even women yet, just teenagers, taken in by creepy men. The stories in this month’s crop of new books belong to the women and the girls — and the men in their lives.

headline: Historian Will Direct Schomburg Center in Harlem
text: Khalil Gibran Muhammad, a history professor at Indiana University, has been named the new director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, to begin in July. New York Public Library officials made the announcement on Wednesday, ending a sometimes contentious search.

headline: Tea-Partying Like It’s 1860
text: On Nov. 8, 1860, the secessionists who published The Charleston Mercury greeted the news of Abraham Lincoln’s election as president with righteous defiance: “The tea has been thrown overboard, the revolution of 1860 has been initiated.”

headline: Merck Drug for Cutting Cholesterol Is Promising
text: Merck has a potential blockbuster in anacetrapib, an experimental cholesterol drug that increases HDL, or “good” cholesterol even as it lowers LDL, the “bad” cholesterol.

headline: 2011 Mercedes-Benz F-Cell Hydrogen Fuel-Cell Car
text: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Mercedes-Benz F-Cell

headline: G.M. Offering 'Well Scripted'
text: Jeremy Anwyl, the chief executive of Edmunds.com, told Dealbook that General Motors's management team deserves high marks for articulating a compelling sales message ahead of the company's I.P.O.

headline: European Debt Crisis Looms
text: The European Union and I.M.F. discuss steps to shore up Ireland's struggling finances.

headline: China’s Censors Misfire in Abuse-of-Power Case
text: BAODING, China  One night in late October, a college student named Chen Xiaofeng was in-line skating with a friend on the grounds of Hebei University in central China. They were gliding past the campus grocery when a Volkswagen sedan raced down a narrow lane and struck them head-on.

headline: A Microscopic View
text: Counting down the top 10 winners of the 2010 Olympus BioScapes photomicrography competition.

headline: Shopping With Vinny Dotolo and Jon Shook
text: The Los Angeles chefs and owners of the restaurant Animal shopped for serving pieces and accessories for a friends-only Thanksgiving feast.

headline: Steve Martin’s Sketch of the Art World
text: Walking down Madison Avenue on a sunny afternoon last week Steve Martin had the look of a movie star in thin disguise, wearing tinted glasses and a charcoal fedora that covered his familiar white head of hair.

headline: A Big Surge For a Program Named Jack
text: After 53 of the 64 boards in the final of the World Computer-Bridge Championship in Philadelphia last month, WBridge5 from France led Jack from the Netherlands by 33 international match points.

headline: Detainee Acquitted on Most Counts in ’98 Bombings
text: The first former Guantánamo detainee to be tried in a civilian court was acquitted on Wednesday of all but one of more than 280 charges of conspiracy and murder in the 1998 terrorist bombings of the United States Embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

headline: Tech Companies Venture Into Fashion
text: For tech companies, the latest trend seems to be selling trendy women’s clothing.

headline: Recipe: Winter Squash Pie
text: Could you make Claire Fountain’s traditional pumpkin pie with a can of processed orange mystery pulp? Of course, Ms. Fountain says — if you think you can live with yourself after. But you’ll need to turn in your C.S.A. badge and your copy of “The Omnivore’s Dilemma.”

headline: In the Senate, a Tweet and a Mystery
text: About 11 a.m. on Wednesday the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, tweeted a message chastising Congressional Republican leaders for delaying a meeting with President Obama that had been expected to take place on Thursday.

headline: Final Scenes From a Life of Bully Adventure
text: Theodore Roosevelt lived for 60 hale, hearty, prodigiously adventurous years. Edmund Morris has devoted more than half that time to writing a magisterial three-volume Roosevelt biography. He began by writing a screenplay about the young Roosevelt’s cattle ranching years in the Dakota Territory. This led to the biography’s Pulitzer Prize-winning first volume, “The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt,” in 1979. It took more than two decades for Mr. Morris to complete his installment about the Roosevelt presidency, “Theodore Rex,” which arrived in 2001.

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Dad’s Weird Suppers
text: Bacon ﬁsh is the kind of dinner that doesn’t lend itself to a recipe, but here’s how I made it, more or less. Last Saturday, a friend from Oregon came to visit, and we served him bacon and eggs for lunch around noon, with a quince crisp after. The eggs were full of spinach with a flicker of nutmeg, and the bacon was roasted in the oven, just before the crisp went in. This was bacon from real pigs, old-fashioned pigs, and a pound gave off nearly a cup of grease, for which I said silent thanks. I poured it off into a dish, where it now sits in the refrigerator, white and waxy, until I call it up for corn bread. But I didn’t wash the hotel pan I used because I thought it would come in handy for something. And it did when I found some glossy hake fillets for dinner. The oven went on low, the hotel pan went into the 325-degree heat just long enough to melt the bacon grease, the hake was swiped on each side in the slick of fat before going into the oven and 12 minutes later we were all eating bacon fish.

headline: Beauty Spots

It’s available exclusively at Nordstrom ($45 to $65).

headline: Daniel Libeskind on a New Show of Menorahs
text: Daniel Libeskind might be known to most New Yorkers as the architect who won the World Trade Center design competition. But to design aficionados, Mr. Libeskind, a Warsaw-born son of Holocaust survivors, is a veritable rock star, responsible for a variety of high-profile projects, from the Jewish Museum in Berlin to the extension of the Denver Art Museum. This week brings the unveiling of yet another project: the installation of an exhibition at the Jewish Museum called “A Hanukkah Project: Daniel Libeskind’s Line of Fire,” featuring 40 hanukkiahs (or menorahs) from the museum’s collection.

The few modern houses that exist are almost all in private hands and cannot be visited.”

text: An Israeli airstrike killed a Palestinian militant and his brother in their car in Gaza on Wednesday. The Israeli military said the target of the attack was the militant, Islam Yassin, a senior member of the Army of Islam, an extremist group inspired by Al Qaeda. Mr. Yassin’s brother, Muhammad, was also said to have been a member of the Army of Islam, according to Palestinian reports. The attack appeared to be similar to one earlier this month in which another leader of the group, Muhammad al-Nemnem, was killed. The Israeli military said that Mr. Yassin and Mr. Nemnem had been planning an attack involving the kidnapping of Israelis in the Sinai in Egypt. In 2006, the Army of Islam joined Hamas, which now controls Gaza, in capturing an Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, from an army base near the enclave. In 2007, the Army of Islam held Alan Johnston, a BBC reporter, hostage for 16 weeks.

headline: Fox Goes for Big Ten
text: Fox Sports acquired the rights to carry the new Big Ten Conference football championship game from 2011 to 2016. Financial details were not disclosed. The championship game was added this year when Nebraska joined the conference as its 12th member. The conference was then split into two divisions.

headline: Britain: Security Official Is Cleared
text: A senior official of Britain’s domestic security service was cleared by government prosecutors on Wednesday of complicity in the mistreatment of a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, Binyam Mohamed, in Pakistan in 2002. The prosecutors acted a day after the Justice Ministry announced a multimillion-dollar compensation deal under which 15 former Guantánamo detainees, including Mr. Mohamed, and one man still held there, agreed to drop lawsuits alleging complicity in torture and other abuse against MI5 and MI6, Britain’s domestic and foreign intelligence agencies. The compensation payments were explained in Parliament as part of a government plan to free MI5 and MI6 from the threat of extended litigation, and to protect relations between the British intelligence agencies and their American counterparts. Jonathan Evans, MI5’s director general, said in a statement that he was “delighted” with the decision not to prosecute the unnamed MI5 official. Prosecutors are still investigating the possible criminal prosecution of an MI6 officer for complicity in detainee abuse.

headline: National Book Award for Patti Smith
text: The rock musician Patti Smith won the National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday night for “Just Kids,” a sweetly evocative memoir of her relationship with the artist Robert Mapplethorpe and life in the bohemian New York of the 1960s and ’70s.

He knows he’s not allowed to eat these things, but like any 9-year-old, he hopes that somehow, this once, my wife, Evelyn, or I will make an exception.

headline: California: Whitman Pays Back Wages
text: Meg Whitman, who was defeated this month in the governor’s race, agreed Wednesday to pay $5,500 to settle a claim brought by her former housekeeper, Nicandra Díaz Santillán, whom Ms. Whitman employed for nine years but fired in 2009 after discovering she was in the country illegally. Tucker Bounds, a spokesman for Ms. Whitman, said that the accusations that Ms. Whitman and her husband stinted on wages were baseless, but that, “This is simply the most practical and cost effective way to put the issue to rest.”

headline: Texas: Murder Verdict Thrown Out
text: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals threw out the conviction of a man who has been on death row for 11 years, ruling Wednesday that the prosecution had withheld important evidence. The man, Richard D. Newton, was convicted of the kidnapping and killing in 1999 of Jesus Montoya, 20. Key to the conviction was the testimony of a second defendant, Julian Paul Williams, who was given a 10-year sentence. But last year, Dallas County authorities discovered a police questionnaire that Mr. Williams had filled out but that had never been turned over to the defense. In it, Mr. Williams asserted that he knew nothing of the killing, though he changed his story on the witness stand. Prosecutors must now decide whether to retry Mr. Newton.

headline: Stocks Surge Worldwide on the Prospect of a Rescue for Ireland
text: Stocks in the United States rose Thursday after Ireland indicated that it would seek billions in aid from international lenders to rescue its banks. That eased concerns about the health of Europe’s financial system and helped buoy investor sentiment globally.

headline: Paris Show Comments on Arab Politics and Art
text: It takes a supremely confident artist to take on so comprehensive and controversial a subject as the history of art in the Arab world. But Walid Raad, a Lebanese-born artist who lives and teaches in New York, has never shied away from challenges. In his last project, in collaboration with the Atlas Group, a fictitious, pseudo-collective/think-tank, he researched and documented the history of Lebanon between 1989 and 2004 with text and images, intentionally blurring the line between fact and fiction to underline the ambiguity and inadequacy of memory.

Mr. Assange has strongly denied the accusations.

headline: What to Dip?
text: My column on Wednesday was all about Thanksgiving dips that can pull double duty as ingredients for a harried cook’s lunch.  But even if you’re not up to a whole lunch, dips make excellent snacks for cooks because you can make them ahead, and steal little bites all day long while you whip up the rest of the meal. When I’m dip-sneaking before the guests arrive, I usually just use a spoon. Guests get a more refined spread. I like to mix it up, pairing old standbys with something new. Below are some of my favorite dippers. What are yours? I’d love to know.  The Usual Suspects:

headline: Interview With the President of the World Chess Federation, Part 3

Part one of the interview appeared Tuesday and addressed the federation’s proposal to build a chess center in New York City and the recent election. Part two was Wednesday and focused on the recent history of the world championship and Mr. Ilyumzhinov’s efforts to find long-term sponsors for chess. The final part of the interview is below.

headline: The Lights Fantastic

This year, the museum decided to focus on its own menorah collection — the largest in the world — and asked the architect Daniel Libeskind to design the installation. “A Hanukkah Project: Daniel Libeskind’s Line of Fire” opens Friday and runs through Jan. 30.

headline: So Why Aren’t You Opening Your Books, Jay?
text: I think it’s fair to say that most business owners think that open-book management makes sense for their business — at least at some level. Sure, there will always be skeptics, but it’s tough to argue with the 30 years of results that we’ve seen at SRC. At the risk of repeating myself, I believe that by opening the books and empowering everyone in our organization to have a say in how we approach the future, we have found a way to deal with the risk of operating a business and also share the rewards that come with success.

headline: Cablevision Exploring Spinoff of Rainbow Media

headline: Notes from the Underground | Emily King
text: Twenty-five-year-old Emily King, who already has a Grammy nomination to her name, took to the stage at Rockwood Music Hall to debut her new repertoire of soulful alternative R&B-esque pop songs. Supported by a full band and a back-up singer, King masterfully glided through an hour’s worth of material, bringing the tiny audience to cheers and whistles. Even her rendition of the Pointer Sisters’s classic, “Automatic,” carried her passionate sincerity and energy. King regularly performs at the venue for free.

headline: Erte, a Master of Fashion, Stage and Art Deco Design, Is Dead at 97

headline: As Vick Soars, Stigma of Conviction Fades

Vick, the Eagles’ starting quarterback, is one of the N.F.L.’s most electrifying talents and possibly its most valuable player in 2010. The fact that he is a convicted felon just more than a year out of prison simply makes him this season’s most complicated story.

Kennedy Bier

headline: Dale Carnegie, Author, Is Dead

headline: Iran Payment Found Diverted To Contras; Reagan Security Adviser And Aide Are Out
text: Washington, Nov. 25--President Reagan said today that he had not been in full control of his Administration's Iran policy, and the White House said that as a consequence up to $30 million intended to pay for American arms had been secretly diverted to rebel forces in Nicaragua.

headline: Carnegie Started as a Bobbin Boy
text: Until he was a septuagenarian, Andrew Carnegie believed that he was born in 1837. Then on a return visit to his native town in Scotland he learned that the date 1837 in the church records merely meant that the records were commenced in that year, and he was listed as a living child in the first census. He announced his correction of the date of his birth by clicking the news to his brother telegraphers on a miniature telegraph instrument at his plate at the dinner they were giving in his honor, supposing it to be his seventy-first when it was really his seventy-third birthday.

headline: On Chess, Rangel and Loko’s Dwindling Days
text: As Four Loko disappears from stores and the hoarding begins, a small group of New Yorkers organized on Facebook and gathered in Union Square on Wednesday night to mourn — not entirely seriously — the passing of the new drink that everyone loves to hate.

headline: Full 'Gas' Rationing Dec. 1 Ordered by the President
text: Washington, Nov. 26--President Roosevelt served notice tonight that, Congressional upheavals and sectional objections notwithstanding, the government must and would begin the nationwide rationing of gasoline to conserve rubber on Dec. 1, as scheduled.

headline: Charles M. Schulz, 'Peanuts' Creator, Dies at 77
text: Charles M. Schulz, the creator of ''Peanuts,'' the tender and sage comic strip starring Charlie Brown and Snoopy that is read by 355 million people around the world, died in his sleep on Saturday night at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif., just hours before his last cartoon ran in the Sunday newspapers. He was 77.

headline: Nurses’ Role in the Future of Health Care

As the days wore on, the surgeon in charge began consulting various experts until the once spare patient file became weighted down with the notes and suggestions of a whole roster of specialists.

headline: Live Blog: Committee Recommends Censure for Rangel
text: Update, 6:29 p.m. | The House ethics committee has recommended censure for Representative Charles B. Rangel for ethics violations. The vote was 9 to 1.

headline: Berlusconi’s Statue of Mars and Venus Are Made Whole Again
text: The statue of Mars and Venus that greets visitors to the official residence of Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, is a striking example of classical Roman sculpture but to certain observers it seemed incomplete. Dating back to 175 A.D., the representation of Venus was missing one of her hands, and her companion, Mars, was missing the very feature that some might say made him such a manly god of war. But the work at Palazzo Chigi in Rome has been restored to anatomical completeness, The Guardian reported: Venus now has all of her digits and Mars was given a new penis. The Italian newspaper La Repubblica said Mr. Berlusconi had requested the restoration of the statue, but Mario Catalano, the prime minister’s architect, told The Guardian, “I took the decision.” Mr. Catalano added that the replacement parts were attached using a magnetic system and were removable but declined to provide additional details.

headline: Tiger Woods Gets the Message Out
text: The message dropped into the Twitter pool like a little lob shot from out of nowhere  “What’s up everyone. Finally decided to try out twitter!”  and created waves like a cannonball. That’s because it came from an account long given up for irrelevant, the idea of Tiger Woods doing social media being as absurd as John Daly doing “Project Runway.”

headline: 12th-Grade Reading and Math Scores Rise Slightly After a Historic Low in 2005
text: Reading scores for the nation’s 12th-grade students have increased somewhat since they dropped to a historic low in 2005, according to results of the largest federal test, released Thursday. Average math scores also ticked upward.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Brooklyn Guy Loves Wine: Brooklyn Guy sits down for a Q. & A. with the wine importer Neal Rosenthal. – Eric Asimov

headline: Chinese Woman Imprisoned for Twitter Message
text: BEIJING  A Chinese woman was sentenced to one year in a labor camp on Wednesday after she forwarded a satirical microblog message that urged recipients to attack the Japanese Pavilion at the Shanghai World Expo, human rights groups said Thursday.

headline: Bush Tax Cuts: Reader Responses
text: In response to my post on the Bush tax cuts and slow growth in the last decade, Steve from San Jose writes: “the choice of 5-year periods seem slightly cherry-picked, since we were in a recovery mode in 2001 (and 2002?) How would the graph look if you showed years ending in 8-2 and 3-7?”

headline: Saying ‘I Love You, Man’ With Lots of Grooming
text: The human tendency to form close bonds with people other than kin may have primal roots. Researchers from Germany report in the journal Current Biology that male macaques exhibit a social bonding behavior similar to human friendship.

headline: The Higher Mass Transit Tax Benefit That’s Expiring
text: Last year, as part of the stimulus package, Congress nearly doubled the maximum amount workers could deduct from their paychecks, before taxes, to apply toward monthly mass transit commuting costs. That meant rail and bus commuters could deduct the same amount each month as commuters who drive and pay for parking.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Cyclists, don’t be afraid of a little chill in the air, especially when dressed in your best houndstooth check coats and wool vests for the Big Apple Tweed Fall Ride on Sunday. The organizers have devised a ride that combines old English style with bicycling, to create what they call “a unique and memorable social experience that pays homage to a timeless era.” Your ride fee, a $10 suggested donation, will go to Virginia’s House of Hope, a nonprofit group that helps New York families with food, clothing and social services. The ride begins at 11 a.m. at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, followed by a stop at the Brooklyn Circus, a clothing boutique in Boerum Hill, to find out who will be named the day’s “Most Distinguished Lad” and “Most Ravishing Lass,” among other contest titles. Bikers finish with a free brunch at the Flatbush Farm Restaurant in Park Slope, where live Gypsy jazz and Dixieland music will be played until 5 p.m. (Prospect Park, intersection of Flatbush Avenue and Prospect Park West; bigappletweed.com)

headline: Polls Show No Consensus on How to Address Major Issues
text: While voters appeared to send a clear message to the Democratic-controlled Congress on Election Day, new polls out this week find no apparent public consensus about how to deal with some of the key issues facing the country, and underscore the obstacles facing Congress as it tries to reduce the budget deficit.

headline: Theater Talkback: When the Stage Goes Two-Dimensional
text: One great and glorious advantage that the theater used to have over the movies was the third dimension. You knew that when you watched actors on stage that they were just as fully rounded – physically, I mean – as the people in the lobby at intermission. Actors on film, no matter how big they looked in 10-foot close-ups, were as hopelessly flat as the screens on which their images flickered.

headline: The Future of Nursing
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen explores the important role that nurses play in the health care system.

headline: The Texas Fix Is Unlikely for Ireland
text: Texas may not look much like Ireland. But at different times, each was deemed a model of rapid economic growth, envied and resented by neighbors. During those boom times, each had banks that went crazy, making so many speculative loans that the banking system was doomed when the bubble burst.

headline: Global Puck: What Women’s Hockey Needs

We’d like to take a walking tour of the city with a native, who would show us around. Perhaps a professional travel agent would be the right person? But we don’t want big groups of people.

headline: A Wave of Bank Prosecutions Is Unlikely
text: The inspector general of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation told The Wall Street Journal recently that the agency had opened criminal investigations into about 50 banks that had failed since the financial collapse in 2008. While that makes it sound like prosecutors will soon be filing charges against a number of bank executives, do not hold your breath waiting for a flood of prosecutions.

headline: A Whirlwind Start for St. John’s and Lavin
