headline: Georgina Bloomberg Buys Co-op on Central Park West
text: BEFORE being injured in a riding competition this month, Georgina Bloomberg, the younger daughter of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, was immersed in what even the most seasoned brokers would describe as a highly intense apartment hunt: She saw almost 150 properties in six months, before closing on a co-op on Central Park West on Thursday, according to someone with knowledge of the deal who was not authorized to speak publicly about it.

headline: House Republicans Back No-Earmarks Rule
text: Republicans in the House of Representatives voted on Thursday to ban the special-purpose spending provisions known as earmarks from being inserted in legislation in the next Congress. While the caucus has approved similar motions before, this time, because the new Congress will have a Republican majority, what they say now goes: Under the rule, House Democrats will not be allowed to insert earmarks either.

headline: My 10 Favorite iPhone Apps

headline: The Marrying Kind

I can only imagine the rewriting scramble that took place, given the long-planned topic of that cover. It pictures a generic bride and groom (with a tiny insert of the Royal Happy Couple) and the title “Who Needs Marriage?” Inside, the writer Belinda Luscombe explores how the role of marriage is changing — in society in general and in the shape it takes in individual households.

text: A flock of African pelicans lands in Siberia after being thrown off course by abnormally warm weather this autumn throughout Russia. “They just lost their way and went in exactly the opposite direction: Instead of Africa they somehow chose the Altai region,” a zoologist says. [Reuters]

headline: Afghan Hero Dog Is Euthanized by Mistake in U.S.

Target and two other dogs snarled, barked and snapped at the man, who detonated his bomb at the entrance to the facility but did not kill anyone.

headline: Will Congress Repeal the 1099 Expansion?
text: When we last checked in on efforts in Congress to roll back the expansion of 1099 reporting that passed as part of the health care overhaul, we found the parties deadlocked. Not on whether the new provision should be eliminated — both agreed that it should (at least in the House; in the Senate, Democrats proposed softening it rather than eliminating it). The argument, rather, was over how to pay for eliminating it. Now, in the wake of a disastrous midterm election, Democrats seem ready to avoid that fight by not paying for the repeal at all. But it is unclear that Republicans will go along.

headline: A Weekend in Cambridge, England
text: The storied university town has evolved into a sophisticated haven of museums, art galleries and cafe collectives.

headline: A Private Network for Recharging Cars
text: A utility with operations around Texas is planning a network of 50 to 150 charging stations for electric cars in the Houston metropolitan area to eliminate “range anxiety,” and is talking with Nissan, Toyota and others about offering auto buyers a package that includes network access and a home charger.

headline: 36 Hours in Cambridge, England
text: CAMBRIDGE, with its narrow medieval passageways and 801-year-old university, is more than just a college town. Students today are sticking around after graduation to run alternative art galleries and cafe collectives. The famous antiquities museum is proudly displaying contemporary works of art, and lively new restaurants and watering holes are rising to the standards of those down the road in London. Even the venerable university is throwing open its doors and admitting the common folk as hotel guests.

headline: Rental Car Company Rated Highest by Customers
text: Enterprise ranked highest in customer satisfaction among rental car companies for a seventh year in a row, according to a new J.D. Power and Associates study of customer satisfaction with airport car rentals.

headline: Dispute Over Dead Sea Scrolls Leads to a Jail Sentence
text: A man convicted of impersonating a New York University scholar in a debate over the Dead Sea Scrolls was sentenced on Thursday to six months in jail and five years’ probation.

headline: In Greenwich Village, Pop-Up Pizza
text: Artichoke Basille’s Pizza is adding more slices to its empire. Hot on the heels of its big new restaurant in Chelsea, Francis Garcia and Sal Basile, will satisfy those in Greenwich Village who need to take a break from making stuffing. On Wednesday (Thanksgiving Eve), they plan to open a small pizzeria mainly for takeout: 111 Macdougal Street (Minetta Lane). And if you need to wait for a table at Minetta Tavern, this may be the answer.

headline: A Dallas Chef Does Thanksgiving
text: Growing up in France, Chef Bruno Davaillon didn’t celebrate Thanksgiving. Now, as the executive chef of the celebrated Rosewood Mansion on Turtle Creek restaurant in Dallas, he has a new appreciation for the holiday.

headline: Reading List | Venice
text: Perhaps there’s something in the water — or, more to the point, in the canals —  that can explain the recent surge of architectural activity in Venice. Beyond the Biennale, which continues through Sunday, the Italian government is hoping to stem the sinking city’s rapid structural decay by  proposing to charge visitors, who number 20 million annually, about $1.40 upon entry. These events coincide with the release of three architecturally premised books about the crumbling city.

headline: As Ireland Nears Bailout, Portugal Waits in Wings
text: LISBON  As Dublin moves begrudgingly toward accepting a European Union bailout, attention is rapidly shifting to Portugal, the country perceived to be as weak a link in the euro zone as Ireland, though for different reasons.

headline: The Caucus: G.O.P. Plans for 2012
text: At the Republican Governors Association meeting in San Diego, one big question lingers:  Who might run for president? And Nate Silver examines Sarah Palin's shadow over the Republican race.

headline: ‘Lighthead,’ by Terrance Hayes: A.D.D. Poet Wins N.B.A. Poetry Award
text: Patti Smith may have been the big-name winner at last night’s National Book Awards (her memoir, “Just Kids,” took the nonfiction prize), but I was pleased to see that the poetry award went to Terrance Hayes for his fourth collection, “Lighthead,” which Stephen Burt reviewed for us in April.

text: Eight city public high school science and math teachers who engage their students with animation, epidemiological studies of the black death, billiards and field trips to waterways clean and befouled are to receive Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching Science & Mathematics today.

headline: Shawn Andrews Sits Out Practice Again
text: The Giants are uncertain who will play left tackle on Sunday with Shawn Andrews sitting out a second consecutive practice Thursday with soreness in his back. Andrews had started at left tackle the past two games in place of the injured David Diehl.

headline: Move to Cut NPR Funding Is Defeated in House

headline: Argentina’s Napa Valley
text: THE sunlight sliced through the clear glass of the gazebo-like restaurant at Familia Zuccardi, one of dozens of wineries located in the small town of Maipú, just outside the city of Mendoza, Argentina. The purple-red malbec and torrontés grapevines glistened in the early afternoon sun. Inside, a waitress poured us chardonnay as bread sticks and an appetizer of ham ravioli arrived. She brought a different chardonnay for the cannelloni filled with sweetbread. Then a hearty malbec, Argentina’s signature wine, accompanied the main course of baby goat rolls filled with sun-dried tomatoes and aubergine.

headline: Perceptions: UV Radiation Poses Hidden Risk for Skiers
text: Skiers, beware: you’re exposed to more ultraviolet radiation than you think. Hot chocolate at midday  preferably somewhere shady  may be a good idea.

headline: Hazards: Work Stress Raises Women’s Heart Risk, Study Says
text: Women who are stressed at work are more likely than other working women to have a heart attack or other forms of heart disease, a new study suggests.

headline: Brian Williams and Jimmy Fallon Team Up to Rib Future Boss

Roberts, chairman and chief executive of Comcast.

headline: Japan Pushing the Mob Out of Businesses
‘Client 9’ on the Oscar Documentary Short List;  ‘Joan Rivers’ Not

Not in the running are “Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work.” But the list includes many of the films that average film buffs would expect to be there. And that has not always been the case with the short list, which last year omitted “Tyson” and “Capitalism: A Love Story.”

headline: Christie Urges Republican Governors to Spend Political Capital
text: SAN DIEGO – Most of the chatter at the Republican Governors Association’s annual meeting here has focused on chest thumping over the party’s recent wins. So, during a panel titled “Good Policy = Good Politics,” most of the sitting governors encouraged newly elected state executives to trust their instincts and have faith that doing the right thing would only help them in the long run.

text: For anyone who considered Dennis Rodman or Ben Wallace to be the most egregious of one-dimensional rebounders,  Reggie Evans of the Toronto Raptors should end any debate.

headline: Hanging on for a Dear Way of Life
text: Early in Claire Denis’s powerful, agonized film “White Material,” you see a woman in a short pink dress, Maria — played by a sublime Isabelle Huppert — hanging off the back of a bus. The setting is a contemporary unnamed African country being torn to pieces by government troops, marauding rebels and the enduring ravages of European colonialism. As she holds on tight, her short-sleeved dress fluttering, the camera moves in close enough for you to see the muscles in Ms. Huppert’s thin arms popping, straining with the terrific effort that encapsulates the will to survive.

headline: Publicist Putting Away One of Her Caps
text: Sloane Crosley, the book publicist and essayist, said on Thursday that she would leave her job at Random House next month to focus on writing full time. “When it comes to book publishing, my colleagues are the most passionate people I have ever encountered outside of clinically insane religious zealots,” Ms. Crosley said in a farewell e-mail. “I thank them for their boundless support both inside the office and out.” Ms. Crosley spent nine years at Vintage/Anchor Books, part of Random House, while writing two well-received books on the side, “I Was Told There’d Be Cake” and “How Did You Get This Number.”

headline: Bowlmor Lanes in Former Newsroom
text: IN the dozen years I spent working in the newsroom of the historic New York Times building, just off Times Square, I must have contemplated my future a hundred times, a thousand times. Would I become a national correspondent? A foreign correspondent? An editor? Should I chuck journalism and embark instead on a career in interpretive dance?

headline: 2010 Los Angeles Auto Show: a Dearth of Diesels
text: 6 p.m. | Updated

headline: Bowlmor Times Square
text: Recently, though, there came exciting word from Bowlmor Lanes: Bowlmor was opening a new location in the Times Square district! In the old New York Times newsroom!

headline: Of Brunch and Its Avoided Discontents
text: E-mails spilled forth questions from nice people about birthdays and brunch, and I responded as best I could — with a few orders of pique on the side. As always, send your questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton.

headline: Alone When the Bedbugs Bite
text: A COUPLE of months ago when I woke up with small clusters of insect bites on my elbows, hands and knees, it happened to be the opening day of the first-ever North American bedbug summit, held in Chicago.

headline: Officials Ponder Gentler Ways to Handle Geese
text: Officials at Prospect Park are mulling ways to reduce the number of Canada geese at the park without actually killing them, ranging from coating goose eggs with oil, to forbidding the feeding of geese, to chasing them off with border collies patrolling from boats.

headline: Exotic Cars Roll Out to Promote U.S.  ‘Top Gear’
text: Years of efforts to produce an American version of the popular offbeat British television show about cars, “Top Gear,” are coming to fruition when the History cable channel presents the first episode of the United States “Top Gear” on Sunday night. To stimulate interest in the show, History is underwriting an elaborate campaign that is, not surprising, heavy on the Hemis and other exotic cars.

headline: CBS Owns the Night
text: “Survivor,” “Criminal Minds” and “The Defenders” lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday night as the shows led their respective time slots in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates “Criminal Minds” delivered the largest audience with 14.3 million viewers at 9 p.m. “Survivor: Nicaragua” garnered a somewhat more modest 12 million viewers at 8 while at 10 “The Defenders” attracted 9.4 million. NBC edged ahead of ABC to finish in second place over all, getting a boost from back-to-back episodes of “Law & Order: SVU” at 9 (7.6 million) and 10 (7.8 million). Fox ranked fourth.

headline: Time-Shifting Holidays
text: IT’S that time of year: the endless holiday parade of cooking, shopping, wrapping and congregating that in my family commences the Friday after Thanksgiving, when we sit down for a traditional meal of turkey, stuffing and canned-fruit compote  and concludes, well, the following day when we celebrate all eight nights of Hanukkah in one madcap afternoon.

headline: Q & A
text: Equal Treatment for All Shareholders

headline: Reforming Health Care Reform
text: Now is the time for bold attempts at bipartisan policymaking, apparently. In the wake of the Simpson-Bowles blueprint comes an even more detailed vision for deficit reduction from the Bipartisan Policy Center, which some of the liberal wonks who snarked at Simpson-Bowles have decided is a budget-balancing proposal they can get behind. (That’s a good thing, to my mind, because the B.P.C. report and Simpson-Bowles are both much closer to one another than either is to the current left-wing vision of how to bring the budget into balance.) Meanwhile, Wisconsin Republican Paul Ryan has persuaded Alice Rivlin, Bill Clinton’s former O.M.B. director, to join him in championing a sweeping overhaul of Medicare, which would transform the program from an open-ended entitlement into a means-tested system that provides vouchers to purchase health insurance.

headline: Fishing Nations Gain Ground on Bluefin
text: International fisheries officials have barely started their meeting to decide the fate of the endangered Atlantic bluefin tuna, but the European Union may have already torpedoed efforts to lower a hotly contested limit this year.

headline: Bad Guys Singing Of Love And Power
text: There are many reasons not to miss the production of Monteverdi’s “Incoronazione di Poppea” that opened the Juilliard Opera season on Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. Beyond the musical excellence and dramatic effectiveness of the production, it is inspiring to see a new generation of musicians so captivated by this seminal work, first produced in Venice in 1643. Monteverdi’s opera emerges vividly in this impressive production, as musically stunning as ever, with its all-too-pertinent tale of power grabs and political corruption driven by sex.

headline: Laurent Gras Says His New York Restaurant Will Take a Casual Turn
text: Laurent Gras, who just won three Michelin stars for his restaurant L2O in Chicago, a couple of weeks after he left it, has a few more details on his return to New York.

headline: Politics Podcast: Deficit Duels
text: Click to Listen

headline: A New Home for St. Ann’s Warehouse
text: St. Ann’s Warehouse, the Dumbo-based theater best known for presenting work from the Wooster Group and other downtown favorites, has been conditionally designated by the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation to become the primary tenant of the Tobacco Warehouse, located across the street from the theater’s current home.

headline: Racewalking Workouts in Central Park
text: AFTER the New York City Marathon and so much focus on running, walking workouts might seem passé, but racewalking can test even the most avid marathoner.

headline: After Reprimand, College Coach Receives Support From Soccer Peers
text: The Florida State women’s soccer team will play Saturday for a berth in the quarterfinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, having made a provocative tactical decision that raised intriguing questions about sportsmanship, integrity and the autonomy of a coach to choose a lineup.

headline: Seating All the Americas at the Same Table
text: BOSTON — Five years after breaking ground, the new Art of the Americas Wing at the Museum of Fine Arts here is opening on Saturday, and it’s a wow. Almost double-wow. Really good.

headline: From a Trojan War Hero, Lessons About Aging
text: Jonah Bokaer  the former Merce Cunningham dancer, a choreographer, co-founder of two arts spaces and, at 29, already the subject of a book  is clearly a man of many talents. But his most notable gift may be his instinct for picking the right collaborators. His new “Anchises,” which opened at the Abrons Arts Center on Wednesday night, is a subtle tour de force, a slowly accruing succession of images that owes its power not just to the chemistry of the exceptional performers and designers that Mr. Bokaer has assembled, but also to the rigorous focus that all bring to their task.

headline: Obama Hails G.M. ‘Success Story’
text: President Obama took a rare and welcome victory lap on Thursday, hailing General Motors’ return to the stock market as a sign that his controversial decision two years ago to bail out the beleaguered automaker has paid off.

headline: A Slow Rollout for Life-Care Communities
text: Port Washington

headline: Entertaining, Edifying And Reassuring Listeners
text: Whatever you were looking for when you attended a recital by the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, you most likely found it. Unless what you sought was evidence that Mr. Terfel’s rough singing and odd detachment as Wotan in the Metropolitan Opera’s season-opening “Rheingold” were cause for concern. If you were worried, Mr. Terfel set you at ease with a program that offered refinement and engagement in roughly equal measure.

headline: Karachi Turns Deadly Amid Pakistan’s Rivalries
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  This chaotic city of 18 million people on the shores of the Arabian Sea has never shrunk from violence. But this year, Karachi has outdone even itself.

headline: Coco Rocha Lowers Price on Condo in Gramercy Park Area
text: VOGUE.com featured a flattering and splashy photo spread last month of the model Coco Rocha’s Gramercy Park-area apartment, in a new feature on the celebrities of the fashion world  the magazine’s “favorite people”  and the places they live.

headline: From Poverty to Luxury
text: In the Basilicata region of Italy, hotels and restaurants built in caves that housed poor families in decades past are drawing tourists to a once impoverished region.

headline: When the Pratts Decamped for Manhattan
text: EVERYONE’S moving to Brooklyn! At least that’s what people have been saying for a dozen years, as young people migrate to Williamsburg and Greenpoint, and other neighborhoods Manhattanites had never heard of a few decades back. But the moving van was on the other foot a century ago, when Brooklyn residents were setting off for Manhattan. A good example of this is the Pratt family, builders of a string of mansions on Clinton Avenue. Impressive as they were, they could not hold the younger generation once they decided the action was across the river.

headline: Week 11 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. & A.
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 11. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Asian Art in Juxtaposition
text: Although the Art of the Americas installation is the main event, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is using the special exhibitions gallery in the new, Norman Foster-designed wing to spotlight another of its institutional strengths: Asian art. In 2006 the museum invited nine Chinese artists and a Chinese-American artist each to select a work from the collection and create a response to it. Both the pieces chosen and the new art have been assembled in an ingenious and engrossing show called “Fresh Ink: Ten Takes on Chinese Tradition” (through Feb. 13), organized by the museum’s curator of Chinese art, Hao Sheng.

headline: Prince Charles Dishes Dirt (the Organic Kind)
text: The heir to the British throne prunes brambles with a hand sickle and empties buckets of compost in “Harmony,” a documentary on NBC that showcases Prince Charles’s pet environmental causes.

headline: Developers Restore a Bowery Landmark
text: ONE of the first historic buildings to be awarded landmark status in the city, the Samuel Tredwell Skidmore House has been renovated and converted to 10 rental apartments.

headline: Keeping It Real: A Show Made of Fakes
text: Museums are letting the public in on some of their most embarrassing moments. Half a dozen exhibitions this year have revealed how forgers fooled curators, and a show of about 50 inauthentic or questionable objects dating back to a supposedly Sumerian statuette opens on Sunday at the Detroit Institute of Arts.

headline: An Old Hand Plucking At the Heartstrings
text: A gutsy soul singer backed by a band rooted in gospel, reggae and funk, playing songs about love, loss and faith  those are the parameters for a known quantity, the bluesy local bar band. Black Dub, led by the guitarist and producer Daniel Lanois, also fits the description. But in its concert on Wednesday night at the Bowery Ballroom, as on its new album, “Black Dub,” released by Jive, it warped nearly every expectation to make music that was far more volatile and haunted.

headline: Designed for Efficiency, New Computer Software at Health Dept. Misfires
text: In July, the San Francisco Department of Public Health started using an $11.2 million electronic medical records system, Avatar, that was designed to streamline billing and improve care for tens of thousands of clients. Thus far, however, it has brought administrative chaos to the mental health and substance abuse services in the city.

headline: Photography: A Coming-of-Age Story
text: Like other major American museums, the Metropolitan was slow to recognize photography, but Alfred Stieglitz gave it a big push in the right direction. In 1928 this Photo-Secession pioneer donated 22 of his own works to the Met. They were the first photos to enter the collection.

headline: Stripes of Intimacy Several Layers Over
text: A sizable crowd fills the Chocolate Factory’s narrow lobby, where the slanted floor affords partial views of both its white-brick theater and raw basement space. And the choreographer Anneke Hansen gives her audience something to look at: visible on the upper level are swinging arms that send bodies into seemingly casual turns. On the lower level, torsos line up in a row as feet execute crossover steps. There are brisk runs. Other dancers watch surreptitiously from a doorway, giving the experience the air of a studio visit.

text: Mr. Steiner is the president of the Steiner Equities Group in Roseland, N.J., which has developed retail and office space nationwide, including the expansion of AT&T’s research headquarters in New Jersey.

headline: Tawkon App Measures Phone Radiation
text: The debate over whether mobile phones emit cancer-causing radiation may rage on unabated, but even if you doubt the danger, you might like to know how much radiation you’re being exposed to.

headline: Dean Camp Courts Chicago Progressives
text: As the influence of ward organizations wanes amid the larger decline of patronage politics in Chicago, followers of Howard Dean are trying to provide a new model for progressive activism in Chicago.

headline: Split Pairing of Curators for 2012 Whitney Biennial
text: So much attention has been paid recently to the Whitney Museum of American Art’s eventual move to the meatpacking district in downtown Manhattan that it is easy to forget that curators are busy plotting the next biennial in their Upper East Side home.

headline: Something Blue
text: With the engagement of William and Kate still a topic of conversation, we, like everyone else, couldn’t help but ogle the future queen’s 18-carat oval blue sapphire ring from Garrard. The Issa dress might be sold out (along with the dream of marrying the future king of England), but there are plenty of accessories from the spring collections in what is surely to be the most regal shade of the season.

headline: Win Clears Gloom Over Notre Dame for a Day
text: As the final seconds of Notre Dame’s 28-3 victory over Utah ticked away in South Bend last Saturday, the Irish student section cascaded onto the field, as if swept along by an avalanche. Ebullient students danced among smiling players or rode piggyback through the Irish marching band as it entertained the departing crowd with robust repetitions of the Notre Dame fight song.

headline: App Smart Extra: Priceline Kung Fu for Android
text: New apps will convince you to try booking an airline ticket with your smartphone – or so I explain in Thursday’s App Smart column. And the new Orbitz app is good enough to challenge Kayak with hotel booking and car rentals.

text: Around Town

headline: Alternative Film Examined in ‘Radical Light’
text: In 1994, Rebecca Barten and David Sherman, an experimental filmmaking couple, began showing avant-garde films in a grungy space underneath their Mission District apartment. They built 10 unfinished pine benches that could seat two people apiece and cut a hole in the wall to fit a projector. The adjoining room, which housed the electric meter, became “the grotto”  a makeshift wine bar.

headline: Fed’s Stress Tests Have Shortcoming in Disclosure
text: The newly powerful Federal Reserve may have missed a trick. The central bank, charged under the Dodd-Frank overhaul bill with broad oversight of the banking system, is asking the 19 biggest American financial institutions to submit to a series of stress tests. That’s a good thing. The trouble is the regulator plans to keep the results and the criteria used in the tests private.

headline: A Quake, a Collapse and No Responsibility
text: In the overturned gray Volkswagen Beetle, under the dim glow of the dashboard light, Tom Mariani studied the still body of his wife beside him. “I was pretty sure she was dead,” he said of that night, 30 years ago this month.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wall Street and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from New York, Washington, Haiti and Colombia.

headline: Out of the Dark Shadows, Arty Toil and Trouble
text: The director Philip Ridley scares up a sinister-spooky atmosphere straightaway in “Heartless,” a horror movie that’s art-house aspirational and involves violence, madness, faith and the evil that men, demons or just filmmakers do. Set in a contemporary East London churning with dark shadows and inexplicable savagery, this digitally shot, visually murky movie is a muddle of tones ranging from the grotesque to the queasily comic to the absurd. Among the horrors paraded across the screen is a gang of toughs in hoodies who set innocents afire for no real reason other than that it suits the director’s overwrought imagination.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 19-25
text: Movies

headline: A Stumble on Wrigley Renovation, but Don’t Be So Quick to Scoff
text: When my first grader drops a thrown ball, he implores me for a “re-do.” It was the same for Tom Ricketts, the Cubs chairman, as he sought to avoid being a pinstriped public-policy piñata.

headline: New Home for American Art
text: A look at the new Art of the Americas Wing at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

headline: ’60s Sweatshop Girls Fighting Ford
text: Vivid, stirring and entirely predictable, “Made in Dagenham” is a grown-up feel-good movie plunked into a feel-bad age. Directed by Nigel Cole, whose 2003 film, “Calendar Girls,” told a similarly upbeat story of indomitable female pluck, “Made in Dagenham” is a feminist fairy tale based on actual events. Uplifting it may be, but to swallow it whole is to believe in happily ever after.

headline: The Bell Tolls for Waco, Caught in Election Day Seismic Shift
text: As it turns out, one of the biggest losers on Election Night wasn’t a Democrat. It was Waco.

headline: Have You Heard the One About the Rabbi Who Didn’t Memorize His Lines?
text: Usually an Off Broadway theater company trumpets its production starring an Academy Award winner. But not so the Culture Project with its production of Colin Greer’s play “Imagining Heschel,” running through Nov. 28 at the Cherry Lane Theater and starring Richard Dreyfuss (a 1977 Oscar winner for best actor in “The Goodbye Girl”) as the prominent 20th century Jewish theologian Abraham Heschel.

headline: In Italy, Luxury Transforms Caves Into Hotels
text: IT was early evening in Matera, a city in the southern Italian region of Basilicata, and swallows circled the sky, their melodious calls interrupted only by the clanking of bells worn by cows drinking from a stream deep within a canyon.

headline: Please Pass the Spotlight
text: Last year, my father manipulated a Thanksgiving invitation from my mother-in-law by whining that he had no place else to go. I love my father, but he is very self-centered, and he dominated the entire dinner conversation with stories about himself. I’d like to stop him from attending this year’s event so that my wife’s family can enjoy the day. How can I tactfully make that happen?

headline: An Everyman’s Guide to Engineering a Jail Break
text: One of the strictures of the old Motion Picture Production Code was that “methods of crime should not be explicitly presented” and that in particular, “theft, robbery, safe-cracking, and dynamiting of trains, mines, buildings, etc., should not be detailed in method.” The censors of the Hays Office did not want motion pictures to become teaching materials for criminals. “The Next Three Days,” a new thriller written and directed by Paul Haggis, is in many respects an old-fashioned movie, but it also amounts to a kind of cinematic “Illegal Activity for Dummies.”

headline: A Spectacle With a Message
text: The German artist Anselm Kiefer knows how to put on a show. The dour and dusty copse of art with which he has forested the vast Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea may elicit awe, skepticism or disdain  or perhaps a conflicted combination of all three. But its initial power is hard to deny.

headline: ‘Next Year in Jerusalem’
text: Images from a new exhibition of works by Anselm Kiefer.

headline: Life’s Work Is a Talmud Accessible to All Jews
text: JERUSALEM  In the 1960s, when a young Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz embarked on the mammoth task of translating the ancient Jewish texts of the Talmud into modern Hebrew and, even more daringly, providing his own commentary alongside those of the classical sages, the state of Israel was still in its teens, there were no home computers, and man had not yet landed on the moon.

headline: 2-D Avatar Is a Benchmark Blu-ray
text: If Avatar has become the 3-D theatrical release by which all others must be judged, then arguably the same can be said of the film’s 2-D Blu-ray Collector’s Edition, which went on sale last Tuesday.

text: A timeline of the life and career of the executive.

headline: A Meat Store Grandmother Would Love
text: A bell jangled as the young woman opened the door to G. Esposito & Sons Jersey Pork Store in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. In her 20s, fashionably hipsterish, she seemed unsure as she ordered.

headline: A Postwar Woman Foiled by Men
text: The marriage between film and theater is beginning to look like a shotgun affair, forced and loveless, at least on the evidence of the fall season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Thomas Ostermeier’s version of “The Marriage of Maria Braun,” the second entry in the double feature of films onstage at the Next Wave Festival, is roughly as tedious and precisely as pointless as last week’s — Ping Chong’s “Throne of Blood.”

headline: The Basics of Perfect Pie Crust
text: Melissa Clark shows how easy it can be to make a light and flaky pie crust.

headline: House Panel Recommends Censure for Rangel
text: WASHINGTON  The House ethics committee on Thursday recommended that Representative Charles B. Rangel be formally censured for ethical misconduct, the most serious punishment the House can mete out to a member short of expulsion.

headline: Reid’s Spokesman Is Leaving Senate
text: Jim Manley, a popular veteran among Senate communicators and the spokesman for Senator Harry Reid the past six years, is leaving the Senate after two decades and untold numbers of phone calls, news tips, denials, press releases, arguments, laughs and efforts to guide wayward reporters.

headline: Sport and Grim Reality
text: There must be chief executives and millionaire athletes in Austin, Tex., whom Bob Ray could make documentaries about, but he doesn’t seem to be interested. “Hell on Wheels,” from 2007, and the new “Total Badass,” playing in repertory at the ReRun Gastropub Theater in Brooklyn, focus on a lower-middle-class world where drugs, beer and tattoos compete for attention with paying the rent and getting the kids to school.

headline: Time Warner Cable to Test Cheaper TV Package
text: In an apparent attempt to retain cable customers who are thinking of canceling, or to woo back people who have already canceled, Time Warner Cable will start a trial of a lower-cost cable subscription package next week in New York City.

headline: Lingerie, Cone Bras and Odd Pregnancies
text: You don’t get much closer to drag heaven on earth than Everett Quinton in diaphanous baby-doll lingerie and kitten heels, transformed from ig’nant trailer-trash hausfrau into hardboiled alien sex slave.

headline: How Economic Brawn Transformed a Nation
text: It has often been noted that while the American union was established by the Revolution, the American nation was forged only upon the awful anvil of the Civil War. Far less noted, however, is that this nation’s extraordinary power and influence in the 20th century and beyond has been largely a product of the remarkable 35 years that followed the Civil War.

headline: An Odd-Couple Friendship
text: Fiction films with disability as a central theme (especially those that feature disabled actors) are not only tricky to assemble but also minefields to critique. Praise can sound patronizing and criticism cruel, the disability casting a bulletproof cloak of political correctness around the entire project.

headline: The Feast of Sacrifice in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqis this week are celebrating Id al-Adha, like millions of Muslims across the world. The festival, also known as the Feast of Sacrifice, is one of the principal holidays in the Islamic calendar and comes as a relief for a city that has been hit hard by bombs and killings in recent weeks. In large numbers, Iraqis flocked to Al Zawraa Park in the center of the capital, to enjoy carnival rides, cotton candy, a Ferris wheel and a boating lake.

headline: Burger With Apocalypse and Some Cheese Fries
text: Tension and incongruity make for an uneasy pairing in “Edgewise,” a bloody drama by Eliza Clark at Walkerspace.

headline: Balenciaga Exhibition Opening on Park Avenue
text: Nobody who buys a Ralph Lauren prairie skirt or cowboy jacket really thinks a personal history of the West informs the clothes. Mr. Lauren grew up in the Bronx. The late Alexander McQueen loved Scottish history, but in practical terms, the links were as crumbly as an old castle. Even for the most sensitive of designers, fashion changes too often to supply a narrative of a single place or culture.

headline: Growing Deficit, Measured in Wait Time at D.M.V.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,380 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Food, Family and Follies
text: A lifetime ago, which is to say in 1998, Aasif Mandvi performed “Sakina’s Restaurant,” a well-received one-man Off Broadway play he had been working on since 1991. A film inspired by it, “Today’s Special,” is now in theaters, helped no doubt by Mr. Mandvi’s current popularity as a satirist on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.” But fans of his pointed television commentary may find themselves, in growing confusion and alarm, asking what happened as they watch “Today’s Special.”

headline: From Russia Expert, a Gloomy Outlook
text: William F. Browder was speaking at Columbia Business School several weeks ago when he was asked a question he gets asked a lot: Where’s the next Russia?

headline: Allegations Complicate Heisman Trophy Voting
text: The 925 ballots for the 2010 Heisman Trophy were mailed Monday from New York. The voters, mostly journalists, have until Dec. 6 to return the ballot, although in recent years the vast majority have been submitted online.

headline: Inquiry Finds Corruption at Agency for Probation
text: BOSTON  The hiring and promotion practices of the Massachusetts Probation Department are rife with “systemic abuse and corruption,” according to an independent report released Thursday.

text: This film is designated as a Critics' Pick

text: “Balenciaga: Spanish Master” is an exhibition at the Queen Sofía Spanish Institute on Park Avenue.

headline: Diaper Wars: State Wants Bid Process for Vendors
text: Call it a bad case of adult diaper drama: Vendors of incontinence products are facing off against the state comptroller’s office over plans to competitively bid underpads, catheters and other supplies for Medicaid patients.

headline: Gearing Up for Distant Royal ‘I Dos’
text: MARIETTA, Ga.  In this Atlanta suburb 4,200 miles from London, Tina Barnes is already planning a wedding-watching party. Never mind that the bride and bridegroom have not announced a date.

headline: Tensions Between Companionship and Solitude
text: Willfully withholding and maddeningly enigmatic, “Nothing Personal” may be parsimonious with words, but its sights are almost embarrassingly effusive. Dwarfed but not diminished by the stupefying beauty of the film’s western Ireland location, the two leads act out a story as simple and ancient as the hills that surround them.

headline: Enough to Cause Art Lovers to Swoon
text: Boston

headline: Masked Military Man Is Superhero for Troops
text: WASHINGTON  Faster than a fleeting bullet point in an Army briefing slide. Able to leap Pentagon jargon in a single bound. While he’s not a classic superhero like the Man of Steel, he’s certainly a man of irony.

headline: Ex-Director of Miami Art Museum to Curate Biennale in China
text: Terence Riley, the former director of the Miami Art Museum, has been appointed chief curator for the 2011 edition of the Shenzhen & Hong Kong Biennale of Urbanism\Architecture. The appointment makes Mr. Riley the first non-Chinese curator for the event, which started in 2005.

headline: Passion at the Piano
text: “Regina Spektor: Live in London” — that’s what it’s called, and that’s what you get. Eighteen songs, performed in December 2009 at the Hammersmith Apollo, with an absolute minimum of onstage chatter and dollops of stylishly grainy, MTV-like filler: Ms. Spektor on the plane from New York, driving through London, applying makeup before the show. It’s perfectly tasteful, a fine showcase for her music and, more important, a fine promotional tool for the accompanying CD and DVD (which — surprise — contain four additional songs).

headline: Cynthia Ozick’s Homage to Henry James
text: Cynthia Ozick’s longstanding and perceptive enthrallment with Henry James once made her declare the “pivotal truth” of his last novels to be “not that he chooses to tell too little . . . but that he knows too much, and much more than we, or he, can possibly take in.” Among those books it is “The Ambassadors” that has most preoccupied Ozick, who admits that her first novel, “Trust,” published in 1966, was “heavily influenced by compulsive reading and rereading” of it.

headline: Saul Bellow’s Quest for the Vernacular Sublime
text: “We often stopped before a display of children’s shoes. My mother coveted for me a pair of patent-leather sandals with an elegantissimo strap. I finally got them — I rubbed them with butter to preserve the leather. This is when I was 6 or 7 years old, a little older than Rosie is now. Amazing how it all boils down to a pair of patent-leather sandals.” Saul Bellow recorded that ancient memory, stirred to it by play with his little daughter, in a letter on Feb. 19, 2004, when he was 88 years old. It is the last letter in this magnificent book. The old master died a year later.

headline: Republicans Rise to Power, With Enmity for Health Law
text: MADISON, Wis. — Until Election Day, when Wisconsin turned from navy blue to crimson red, this state aspired to lead the nation in carrying out the federal health care law and using its incentives to regulate and reshape the medical delivery system. The current governor, Jim Doyle, a two-term Democrat, praised the law as “a great benefit to Wisconsin.”

headline: Despite Daunting Illness, a Provider Forges Ahead
text: Linda Goldstein’s apartment is a treat for the eye: Framed portraits of divas  Diana Ross, Madonna and Barbra Streisand  anchor one wall, while mirrors in the shapes of stars, butterflies and spiky suns hang from another. Personal photographs from various eras perch on a bookshelf beneath a row of multicolored snow globes.

headline: Cost-Saving State Law Endangers Growth of Wind Industry
text: Chicago is the nation’s wind industry economic hub, home to about 80 wind companies from corporate headquarters to turbine component factories. Illinois has ample farmland well-suited for wind farms, and a law mandating that the state get at least 18 percent of its electricity from wind power by 2025.

headline: Bears’ Defense Overwhelms Ailing Dolphins in Shutout
text: Brian Urlacher and the swarming Chicago Bears defense allowed only 187 yards and a single third-down conversion Thursday night, winning 16-0 to send the injury-ravaged Miami Dolphins to their second home shutout in 40 years.

headline: Perry Makes It Clear, He Is Not Your Bush Republican
text: To the list of things for which Gov. Rick Perry shows contempt  Barack Obama’s leadership abilities, excessive federal regulation, coyotes that interrupt his morning jog  add this surprising one: George W. Bush’s brand of conservatism.

headline: Yankees Keep Cool, Lest Jeter Talks Boil Over
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ managing general partner, stood in a warm breeze in the portico outside the Waldorf Astoria hotel here Thursday and did his best to project a calm outlook regarding what still has the potential to be a stormy issue for his team.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Expanding Postseason to be Discussed
text: Commissioner Bud Selig said his 14-man committee to discuss on-field matters would meet at the winter meetings in early December to discuss expanding the postseason by two teams, an idea that seems to be without opposition.

headline: New Budget Director Confirmed
text: 10:41 p.m. | Updated  The Office of Management and Budget has a director again — and he looks familiar.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Bone Drug for Cancer Patients
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the use of Amgen’s bone drug denosumab as a treatment for cancer patients whose disease has spread to their bones.

headline: W. Howard Lester, Williams-Sonoma Owner, Dies at 75
text: W. Howard Lester, who in 1978 bought Williams-Sonoma, a small supplier of items for gourmet kitchens with four stores and annual sales of $4 million, and transformed it into a retail home furnishing and mail-order giant with 609 stores and annual sales of $3.4 billion, died Monday at his home in Indian Wells, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Extending a Subway Line, Linking 2 Worlds
text: At the corner of Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue, where the No. 7 train terminates in Flushing, Queens, a barrage of people chat in dozens of languages, jostling for space on the sidewalk. Steps from the subway is an international smorgasbord of restaurants and shops, most splashed with Chinese characters and Korean lettering.

headline: Maryland Attacker Flashes Skill That Defies Her Size
text: Seven years ago, the University of Maryland’s field hockey coach, Missy Meharg, noticed a group of high school students shooting around during halftime of a Terrapins game. One of them was ripping shots at the cage with a power that defied her age and size.

headline: Rattner Seeks Damages From Quadrangle
text: Steven L. Rattner’s antagonists include not only the New York attorney general but also Mr. Rattner’s former business partners.

headline: Struggling Islanders Revoke Blogger’s Credentials
text: Chris Botta, who publicized the Islanders for 15 years, had his credentials to cover the team on his blog revoked Tuesday, a day after the last-place franchise fired Coach Scott Gordon.

headline: Worm Was Perfect for Sabotaging Centrifuges
text: Experts dissecting the computer worm suspected of being aimed at Iran’s nuclear program have determined that it was precisely calibrated in a way that could send nuclear centrifuges wildly out of control.

headline: Echoing Obama, Bernanke Presses China on Imbalances
text: FRANKFURT  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, argued Friday that currency undervaluation by China and other emerging markets was at the root of “persistent imbalances” in trade that “represent a growing financial and economic risk.”

headline: The Chain of Energy
text: This is the tenth in a series.

headline: Cuomo Sues Rattner in Pension Case
text: The New York attorney general sued Steven L. Rattner in a kickback case. It came as Mr. Rattner settled charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Read the full article here.

headline: Punishment in the House
text: Censure is the most serious punishment the House of Representatives can mete out, short of expulsion. When members are censured, they must stand in the well of the House while the speaker reads a resolution rebuking them for misconduct.

headline: October Was New York State’s Best Month for New Jobs in Years, Data Show
text: Employers in New York State added more jobs in October than in any month in more than five years, as the state and New York City continued to rebound from the long recession faster than the rest of the nation, according to jobs data released on Thursday.

headline: Pat-Downs at Airports Prompt Complaints
text: In the three weeks since the Transportation Security Administration began more aggressive pat-downs of passengers at airport security checkpoints, traveler complaints have poured in.

headline: A Trailblazer With Her Eye on the Bottom Line
text: She grew up sheltered and privileged, in a middle-class Irish enclave of Chicago at midcentury, attending Catholic schools and riding horses at a country club where blacks and Jews were not allowed. Yet from age 28, she blazed a trail for working women, persuading male-dominated Madison Avenue to get behind an upstart magazine called Ms.

headline: Democrats Struggling to Make Any Headway
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut independent, said Thursday that he and other opponents of the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gay service members had secured the votes to authorize its repeal  provided that Senate leaders allow a free-flowing debate on the wider military policy bill that includes the repeal.

headline: House Republicans Block Unemployment Benefits Extension
text: The House failed to pass an extension unemployment insurance benefits for another three months Thursday afternoon. The vote was 258 to 154, short of the two-thirds needed for passage.

headline: N.Y.U. Scraps Plan for Tallest Tower in Greenwich Village
text: New York University abandoned plans to build the tallest tower in Greenwich Village on Thursday after the influential architect I. M. Pei made his opposition known, and is now proposing to build a shorter but bulkier building on a different site.

headline: An Unsealed Lawsuit Indicates Dell Hid Faults of Computers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Documents unsealed Thursday in a three-year-old lawsuit against Dell have raised more questions about how the company handled an unprecedented number of faulty computers sold to governments, schools and corporations from 2003 to 2005.

headline: List of Candidates at 4, Mets Begin Deliberating
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Mets’ front office staff concluded the interview phase of its search for a manager Thursday and huddled for about 45 minutes afterward to begin dissecting the four candidates. The process is expected to take about three days.

headline: Courting Hispanic Customers With Texts and Web Sites en Español
text: AS the Hispanic population in the United States continues to grow, major advertisers are seeking new ways to attract Hispanic customers. These advertisers are increasingly trying to deliver their message in Spanish through Web sites, special sites for mobile phones and texting campaigns.

headline: Ghailani Verdict Reignites Debate Over the Proper Court for Terrorism Trials
text: WASHINGTON  Fierce criticism erupted Thursday over the split verdict on terrorism charges against the first Guantánamo detainee to be tried in civilian court, casting new doubts on the Obama administration’s goal of trying cases against other prisoners in the civilian criminal justice system.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U. of California Will Raise Tuition by 8 Percent
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With none of the protest that marred previous meetings, the University of California’s Board of Regents approved an 8 percent fee increase on Thursday, the second straight year that students have faced higher tuition.

headline: G.O.P. Governors Gather, and Some Debate the Size of Their Deficits
text: SAN DIEGO  This is a really bad year, the would-be governor from South Carolina remarked. We’ve got huge problems, said her counterpart from Oklahoma. And from the governor-elect of Wisconsin: There are serious issues we have to deal with now.

headline: European Import Has Cars Spinning. Heads, Too.
text: Traffic is going in circles. Armed with mounting data showing that roundabouts are safer, cheaper to maintain and friendlier to the environment, transportation experts around the country are persuading communities to replace traditional intersections with them.

headline: Intelligence Bodies Faulted on Disclosure
text: WASHINGTON  The House Intelligence Committee said Thursday that it had found 16 cases since the 1990s in which the intelligence agencies failed to provide Congress with “complete, timely and accurate information” about their activities, as the law requires.

headline: The Debtor of the Western World
text: Dublin

headline: Thank the Courts
text: “America has reached a fork in the road, and the time has come to make a decisive choice,” Daniel J. Popeo, chairman of the Washington Legal Foundation, wrote this week in his monthly column in The Washington Examiner. The choice he posited was between continuing to endure judicial intervention in the conduct of the war on terrorism and “returning control over national and homeland security decisions to the executive and legislative branches.”

headline: The Hidden Costs of Extra Airport Security
text: I recognize that the outcry over the T.S.A.’s new security procedures — which has been both broad and deep in technology, travel and political blogs, but which has been less acute elsewhere in the country — has a bit of a Brooks Brothers Riot quality to it. That is because its effects are felt most manifestly among those relatively few Americans who have the means to travel (and the wherewithal to write about it).

headline: At Terror Trial, Big Questions Were Avoided
text: One of the striking aspects of the case of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the first former Guantánamo detainee tried in a civilian court, was how little the federal jury in New York City heard about the issues that had made his case so fiercely debated.

headline: Friday: Nixon Pal Rebozo
text: Once again, a contributor from our “comments” section, Barry Franklin, is sitting in as today’s guest solver. If that name doesn’t ring a bell, I’m sure his alias does, KarmaSartre.

headline: A Gaudy Swashbuckle Through History
text: Theatergoers looking to experience the wittiest part of John Guare’s “Free of Man of Color,” the spangled white elephant now rampaging at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, need only pick up a program. You know how practically every Playbill handed out on Broadway these days features a list of producers as long as Shaquille O’Neal’s arm?

headline: Requiem for Man Whose Ideas on Transit Aren’t Past
text: Theodore W. Kheel made his bones as a labor arbitrator, a reputation so sturdy that it obscured the trainload of ideas he had about how to transport New Yorkers around their city.

headline: Hong Kong: Bird Flu Checks Increase
text: Health authorities said Thursday that they were increasing their checks on poultry coming from mainland China and at farms and markets across the region after government officials confirmed the first case of bird flu in seven years in the territory. The region’s top health official said there was no increased risk of contracting bird flu after a woman was hospitalized here last weekend with a variation of the disease. The world’s first outbreak of bird flu among people occurred here in 1997 and claimed six lives.

headline: Audit Says Police Fall Short in Providing Interpreters
text: When Esther Jimenez called the police to her Staten Island home last year, she showed them the scratches on her arm. She told them that her husband had attacked her in front of their children. He had pushed her into a wall, she said, and knocked their youngest child from her arms.

headline: Azerbaijan: Blogger Is Released Early
text: An Azeri blogger who was imprisoned on dubious charges of hooliganism 18 months ago was released Thursday, a year early. The blogger, Adnan Hajizada, was arrested after he posted satirical videos slyly critical of the government, including one in which he played a donkey holding a news conference. After he and a fellow blogger, Emin Milli, were confronted by young men at a restaurant, the two complained to the authorities, only to have prosecutors open a criminal case against them. Many Azeris feared this was the beginning of a crackdown on online media, the last venue available to the opposition after television, radio and newspapers have backed off critical commentary. Mr. Milli remains in custody, with six months left in his sentence.

headline: Bloomberg Plans to Cut 10,000 City Jobs by 2012
text: Acknowledging the bleak financial future the city faces, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans on Thursday to eliminate the jobs of thousands of teachers and other city workers in the next two years.

headline: After Breakthrough Games, Gallinari Disavows Stardom
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Over the span of six quarters, played over two nights, in two time zones, Danilo Gallinari unleashed a small arsenal of offensive artistry: swift drives, clever fakes, fadeaways, dunks, layups, 3-pointers and a steady string of free throws.

headline: Men Plead Guilty in Ticket Conspiracy

headline: Repeal It. Now.
text: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, made the right call this week in pledging to push for repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy during the lame-duck session of Congress. The odds of ridding the country of the destructive ban on gay soldiers serving openly will diminish greatly in the next Congress when Republicans take over the House and gain strength in the Senate.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Axis of Depression
text: What do the government of China, the government of Germany and the Republican Party have in common? They’re all trying to bully the Federal Reserve into calling off its efforts to create jobs. And the motives of all three are highly suspect.

headline: Weekness and Endurance
text: Just over a week ago, Newsweek announced that it is going to merge with the online magazine The Daily Beast. Since then, cyberspace has echoed with pessimistic commentary about the future of this new entity. After all, why should anyone think that two money-losing organizations will start making money simply because they have banded together?

headline: With All Disrespect, Mr. President
text: There was supposed to be a bipartisan summit at the White House on Thursday, but only the Democrats showed up. The Republican leadership of the House and Senate somehow couldn’t find any time in their schedules to meet with the president of the United States. If this is what cooperation and mutual respect is going to look like over the next two years, then settle in for more trench warfare and far less progress.

headline: It’s Not Over
text: The recession that began in late 2007 ended officially in June 2009, but much of the country is still suffering.

headline: The Ghailani Verdict
text: The verdict in the first federal trial of a former Guantánamo detainee has unleashed the usual chest-thumping and fear-mongering from the usual politicians. They are disappointed that the defendant was only convicted of one count of conspiring to blow up American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998  a crime for which he will probably serve a life sentence.

headline: Germany: An Advance for Google
text: After months of public opposition, Google Street View went online on Thursday with panoramic images from 20 large German cities, including Berlin, Munich, Hamburg and Frankfurt. As a result of resistance from politicians and privacy advocates who said that the service violated privacy by providing detailed images of buildings and front yards, more than 244,000 residents  about 3 percent of the households in those cities  requested that their homes be blurred, as Google had offered.

headline: Minority Report
text: As the speaker of the House of Representatives, where Democrats just lost 60-odd seats as well as their controlling majority, you led your party into the worst electoral defeat in decades. And yet you chose to run for Democratic leader in the next Congress. Why not just step down?  Well, don’t forget that I led the party into the strong victories of ’06 and ’08. And now we are prepared to win again.

text: Jerry Garrett takes Jaguar's C-X75 for a spin.

headline: Financier Is Sued by Cuomo in Fraud Case

headline: Gates Urges School Budget Overhauls
text: Bill Gates, the founder and former chairman of Microsoft, has made education-related philanthropy a major focus since stepping down from his day-to-day role in the company in 2008.

headline: Nathan Oliveira, 81, Dies; Painted Human Conflict
text: Nathan Oliveira, a leading Bay Area artist who achieved national prominence fusing Abstract Expressionism and figuration in psychologically charged canvases that explored human isolation and alienation, died on Saturday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Lollapalooza Expands to Chile
text: Lollapalooza began in 1991 as a summer package tour, solidifying the idea of alternative rock as a commercial format. In 2005, it was reborn as a weekend event in Chicago. And next year Lollapalooza will begin its next phase, with a branch of the festival opening in Santiago, Chile.

headline: Earning the Trust of Haitians With H.I.V.
text: For the past nine months, Andre Lambertson and I have been reporting in Haiti, focusing mainly on H.I.V. and AIDS. At first glance, it seems to be a doubly depressing topic. As if the earthquake — with its death, displacement and lost limbs — were not enough, we’ve had to turn our attention to those who are even more vulnerable, and who, because of their disease, are often forced to live in the shadows.

headline: N. Korea Seen Working on New Reactor
text: SEOUL, South Korea  New satellite images of a North Korean nuclear site and a recent visit to the North by two American experts suggest that North Korea has started work on a new reactor.

headline: Blast Traps New Zealand Coal Miners
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  At least two dozen men were trapped underground after an explosion on Friday rocked the country’s largest coal mine in a mountainous region in the country’s South Island.

headline: Tip of the Week: Distinguishing Gmail Chat Accounts
text: Not sure if you are chatting with a fellow Gmail user on a computer or one running around on a mobile phone? The Green Robot can tell you. This experimental feature from Gmail Labs displays a small robot icon next to the names of chat buddies tapped in from their Android phones.

headline: NATO Agrees to Build Missile Defense System
text: LISBON  NATO leaders agreed on Friday evening to establish a missile defense shield that would cover all NATO member states, and on Saturday they expect Russia to agree to discuss the possibility of cooperating on the system’s development.

headline: Wall St., Though Tarnished, Still a Draw on Campus

headline: Sen. Mark Warner Seeks Influence at the Center
text: For years, Democratic Senator Mark Warner of Virginia nurtured a wonky, centrist brand as a businessman-turned-politician whose great skill was at deal-making with his partisan adversaries.

headline: The Lunch Box: A Sandwich on the Fly
text: Samantha Storey is trying to make her packed lunches less boring, one box at a time.

headline: How Much Reality Will ‘Homemade Millionaire’ Offer?
text: The latest in the spate of entrepreneurship-themed reality competition shows debuts tonight on the TLC channel and will feature female contestants exclusively. Eric Black, TLC’s director of production, said the program, “Homemade Millionaire,” was inspired by the frequent requests for guidance that show host Kelly Ripa received from women eager to develop and market their products. The entrepreneurs will compete for the chance to offer their wares on the interactive, multichannel retailer HSN, which reaches more than 94 million homes in the United States and had 2009 sales of more than $2.7 billion.

headline: Complaint Box | The Stupor Market
text: I remember fondly those weekly trips with my mother to the grocery store as a young boy. My father would drop us off, then wait in our black Chevy station wagon, reading the paper and smoking half a pack of Pall Malls.

headline: At Age 29 and Backed by a Brain Trust, Federer Digs In
text: PARIS  Not long ago, Roger Federer had no official coach. Now, intent on remaining a major force in the majors, he finds himself with two: Severin Luethi, his longtime confidant from Switzerland, and Paul Annacone, the former American player turned mentor who has worked with Pete Sampras and Tim Henman.

headline: Detonator at Namibian Airport Was a Test Device
text: BERLIN  Germany’s interior minister said Friday that a laptop case rigged with wires, a clock and a detonator found at a Namibian airport was really a mock bomb built in the United States to test airport security.

headline: A Call to Action on Ocean Acidity
text: States bordering water bodies that are becoming more acidic from the absorption of carbon dioxide should list them as impaired under the Clean Water Act, the Environmental Protection Agency declared in a memo this week.

headline: Despite Commodity Worries, Shares Bounce Back
text: Stocks ended slightly higher on Friday as encouraging reports about the prospects for an Irish financial rescue appeared to outweigh concerns about the prospect of slower growth in China.

headline: Agenda | Boom Boom Rooms, Part One

headline: E-Commerce Reaches Record Share of Retail Sales
text: E-commerce sales in the third quarter of 2010 accounted for 4 percent of total retail sales, according to a Census Bureau report released on Friday. That’s the highest share on record since the government began keeping track in 1999. (And, to be honest, it seems unlikely that e-commerce ever accounted for a higher share of retail sales pre-1999.)

headline: The Google Maps War That Wasn’t

headline: Band Practice
text: Jean-Luc Godard is one eminently quotable auteur. He said, “All you need for a movie is a gun and a girl.” And “my aesthetic is that of the sniper on the roof.” And also, “there is no point in having sharp images when you have fuzzy ideas.” This last quotation, while less famous, is a roundabout way of introducing Scott Sternberg, ex-Hollywood talent agent, film nerd and serious Godard fan. Not only was Godard’s 1967 film “La Chinoise” the inspiration for Sternberg’s fall 2009 collection, but his fashion label’s own name, Band of Outsiders, comes from the English title of Godard’s canonical 1964 film “Bande à Part.” Sternberg has himself shot all of the Band of Outsiders look-books with a Polaroid camera, which means he’s probably willing to take Godard’s axiom a step further: There’s no point in having sharp images when you can have fuzzy ones.

headline: Haves, Have-Nots and Health Care
