headline: Planning for Temporary Home Care After the Hospital Stay
text: ANNIE BRUMBAUGH has become a bit of an expert on recuperating at home. Over the last two years, the 65-year-old wardrobe consultant has had two serious operations on her foot, plus a bone graft, each of which left her homebound for weeks at a time. “This is not easy,” said Ms. Brumbaugh, who lives alone in Manhattan. “Most people have no idea what they are in for.”

headline: The Cost of Recuperating at Home
text: Even common surgical procedures, like C-sections and hip replacements, can involve longer than expected recuperation periods, but many patients aren’t prepared for the added cost, reports today’s Patient Money column.

headline: Abstract Expression
text: For her first artistic collaboration for the new brand Chance, the designer Julia Leach decided to work with the photographer Jarret Schecter, who is known for his documentary-style take on subjects as diverse as Romany Gypsies and the Russian countryside, shot from a trans-Siberian railway car. When Leach discovered his series “Stalking Paris,” she says, she was struck by the mood of the photos, which dovetailed nicely with her aesthetic for Chance — a mix of classic design and modern graphics. Instead of showing the typical touristy side of Paris, Schecter created an almost abstract view of the city— he photographed people walking with umbrellas from above, the shadows of chairs in the Luxembourg Gardens and the Eiffel Tower in a layer of mist. “His photos capture a Paris that’s not a postcard-perfect city,” says Leach, who served as the longtime creative director for Kate Spade. “It’s a raw Paris that shows history and modernity wrestling with each other.” The prints will be available starting today at  www.chanceco.com ($250 for each 17-by-24-inch unframed image from the limited edition of 250).

headline: U.S. Oil Imports Shrink, Yet Worries Loom
text: Good news on the energy security front?

headline: 4D Man
text: A new “archetypal” 21st-century man.

headline: China Restarts Rare Earth Shipments to Japan
text: HONG KONG  China resumed exports of crucial minerals to Japan on Friday for the first time in almost two months, Japanese government officials and an industry executive said.

headline: FrontPoint to Shut Health Care Fund
text: The hedge fund FrontPoint Partners will liquidate its $1.5 billion health care fund in the wake of allegations that a manager at the firm received insider information from a French doctor, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Bernanke Plays Offense
text: In a speech today in Frankfurt, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, brought out the big (rhetorical) guns. He:

headline: You Talkin' to Me?
text: Lauren LoGuidice, an actress, takes lessons from a voice and diction coach, Lynn Singer, to learn how to drop her Queens accent.

headline: Some Verdicts Just Make You Scratch Your Head
text: How could jurors convict Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani of conspiring to blow up buildings, but not of conspiring to murder the people in them?

headline: India Stocks Sink on Telecommunications Scandal
text: NEW DELHI  A widening corruption scandal that has touched India’s prime minister sent the country’s stock markets down sharply on Friday and threatened to tarnish the country’s image as a rising economic power.

headline: Payments Appreciated
text: In my solo medical practice, I treat children from diverse socio-economic backgrounds. I don’t participate in any insurance plans, but I routinely use a downward-sliding scale to help parents in financial difficulty afford care. Many of my patients come from families with extremely high net worth. A friend suggested I charge them more. Is it ethical to use the sliding scale in both directions? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: Agenda | Boom Boom Rooms, Part Two
text: Playing It CoolNothing draws a crowd like a boldface designer. Yet these five high-style hotels have managed to fly under the radar — until now.

headline: Unlearning to Tawk Like a New Yorker
text: ANDREW RAMOS always believed it made him more charming, an endearing characteristic integral to his identity. But, finally, after too many people mocked him, he began seeing a therapist.

headline: Friday Reading: Free Wireless Internet in the Sky
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: New ‘Don Carlo,’ That Ever-Changing Opera
text: TOMORROW evening, for the first time in more than 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera will unveil a new production of Verdi’s “Don Carlo.” The director is Nicholas Hytner, working with designs by Bob Crowley, both in their Met debuts. Roberto Alagna leads a starry cast as Don Carlo, the unstable son of Spain’s icy King Philip II. Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducts.

headline: More Than a Car, It’s a Co-Star
text: TESTED 2011 Suzuki SX4 SportBack

headline: City Critic: Slaughtering Your Turkey
text: If you consume a turkey, you should know where it comes from. Should you also participate in its death? The City Critic reports from a slaughterhouse in Queens.

headline: The Main Course Had an Unhappy Face ...
text: She was a beautiful bird, a Bourbon Red turkey whose rich brown feathers were flecked with white, and she had spent her days roaming free around an organic farm that overlooked the Hudson River. But as I stood watching her, she did not seem happy. Instead, with her almond eyes downcast, her subdued manner suggested a kind of forbearance.

headline: This Ballerina Found History In Her Footsteps
text: IT is not the typical academic who studies the political and cultural history of nations by trying to locate those histories within her body. Yet that was precisely the approach taken by Jennifer Homans, a former professional ballet dancer turned historian and critic, whose enormous new history of classical ballet, “Apollo’s Angels,” was published this month.

headline: 2011 Suzuki SX4 Sportback
text: The SX4 SportBack is a compact wagon that daydreams of being a rally car.

headline: New Roads = Traffic = Emissions?
text: This week I was in Kenya and ended up spending a lot of time sitting in traffic. Even at night, a trip to the Nairobi airport that should have taken 30 minutes took three times that. In reporting trips to large cities of the developing world, I have noticed that one feature most now have in common is this jarring traffic and attendant smog, from Nairobi to New Delhi to Beijing.

headline: Ann Beattie, Distilling Her Generation
text: One thing that this collection of short stories by Ann Beattie makes it possible to do is imagine your way into the head of a New Yorker fiction editor at the moment of discovery. Roger Angell turned down more than a dozen stories sent to the magazine over 22 months by a very young Beattie, who was then in the process of dropping out of a graduate English program. But he wrote encouraging rejections (“I hope you will let us see more of your work, and that you will address your future submissions directly to me”) and finally accepted “A Platonic Relationship” (“What I like most about the story is its sparsity. Almost everything except the essential has been done away with, leaving one with the vision of a Giacometti”). The story was published on April 8, 1974, when Beattie was 26 years old. Reading it all these years later, you may have to work a little to pick up the electrical currents pulsing beneath its dry, self-contained surface — Beattie’s style wasn’t called “minimalist” for nothing — but if you do, you will see some of what Angell must have seen.

headline: Up Front: John Adams
text: The composer John Adams reviews “Begin Again,” Kenneth Silverman’s biography of John Cage, in this issue.

headline: The Zen of Silence
text: John Cage was one astonishing individual. A composer we commonly associate with coin tossing, whose most famous piece called for the performer not to make a single sound, he upended long-held conventions about the listening process and prodded us to re-evaluate how we define not only music but the entire experience of encountering art. He was, in the words of Kenneth Silverman’s new biography, “driven by an ideal of nonmythic listening and seeing, of perceptual innocence”; his goal was to compose “a prelapsarian music untainted by history.”

headline: The Missing Piece
text: Suzanne Berne’s father lost his mother to cancer when he was still a small boy. Not only did she leave her children bereaved — she also left them perplexed: “We were told she was gone. No one ever said where.”

headline: The ‘O’ Word
text: We’d better address one textual issue up front, and without italics. This book opts for the iconic form: OK.

headline: Asked & Answered | David Armstrong
text: For “Mad About the Boy,” his new exhibition at Half Gallery, the photographer David Armstrong has sifted through more than 25 years of his archives looking for the male muses who have inspired him over the years. Appropriately for a photographer who has moved fluidly between fine art and fashion work, these muses are models, lovers and friends, and the photographs Armstrong has chosen to exhibit include classic black and white portraits, moody shadow-dimmed color images and cut-up contact sheets exhibited in scrapbooks. The Moment recently caught up with Armstrong for a tour through his personal archive.

headline: Leaving Money on the (Conference) Table
text: Thank you to everyone who took the time to comment on my recent posts. I’d like to share my reactions to a few of the comments. Because each day of the series had a different theme, I’ll address each day’s comments together.

headline: Week 12 College Football Matchups
text: The No. 1 and No. 2 teams are off this week, so don’t expect any earth-shaking changes at the top of the college football world this weekend. But do expect a lot of conference races to begin to sort themselves out and do expect some entertaining football. It’s a big weekend in the Big Ten, with Ohio State and Wisconsin jockeying for B.C.S. positioning, while Nebraska and Texas A&M meet up in what could be a very exciting Big 12 matchup. In the A.C.C., Maryland (yes Maryland) controls its own destiny in the Atlantic division, while Virginia Tech looks to wrap up the Coastal with a victory in Miami. There are also some great traditional rivalries on Saturday afternoon with “The Big Game” in Berkeley and “The Game” in Cambridge. There’s even a game at the new Yankee Stadium as Army and Notre Dame will square off on Saturday evening in the latest edition of one of the most historically important rivalries in college football. It’s getting down to it. Pay attention. Let’s get to the matchups.

headline: Race for House Office Space Begins
text: The race for space is on.

headline: Wrigley Set for Football, With Odd Ground Rules
text: CHICAGO  Saturday’s college football game at Wrigley Field between Northwestern and Illinois was shaping up to be an unusual game. But on Friday the Big Ten announced a series of safety-related changes that promise to make the game even more memorable, no matter its location.

headline: Cover to Cover: The Why and Wherefore
text: Justin Bieber

headline: Daddy’s Little Protagonist
text: Charles Elton’s first novel, “Mr. Toppit,” begins and ends with Luke Hayman, son of Arthur Hayman, an unsuccessful British screenwriter who has written an outlandishly popular series of children’s books called “The Hayseed Chronicles.” That Arthur’s brilliant career is posthumous, the result of the coming together of improbable people and a cement truck, is only one of the novel’s many ironies, some funny, others heartbreaking. (A few are forced: a June bug is ushered out of a bathroom in a tooth mug inverted on the ripped-off cover of “Seven Types of Ambiguity.”) Only wisps of the Hayseed books are shown directly, but occasional descriptions hint at what might have happened if Roald Dahl had invaded Narnia. The villain of the series, Mr. Toppit, is an unseen sinister force who sets cryptic tasks for its hero, Luke Hayseed, and is never satisfied.

headline: Reality TV Pours Itself A Cold One
text: AT this advanced reality-TV moment  what with shows about crab fishermen and cake decorators and extreme eaters it’s a little surprising that no one has gotten around to beer. A multibillion-dollar industry responsible for seemingly half the advertising on television, beer would appear to be a natural subject, not to mention a marketable one. As Stephen Reverand, a vice president for development at the Discovery Channel, framed it recently, “The planet is divided into rice cultures and bread cultures, but everyone makes beer.”

headline: Never Mind The Question, Here’s the Answer
text: “WRITERS have to know things,” Fran Lebowitz says near the start of “Public Speaking,” a new documentary about her. Well, not exactly about her  though she discusses her upbringing, there is no montage of a young Fran, astonishingly cigaretteless, at play as a child in New Jersey, and only a few clips of her early years in New York, as part of the downtown demimonde she chronicled for Interview magazine. The documentary, which has its premiere on HBO on Nov. 22, is about what Ms. Lebowitz, 60, knows. Which, as she will be the first to tell you, is a lot.

headline: Translating ‘Top Gear’ Into American
text: IRVINE, Calif.

headline: The Week Ahead: NOV. 21 — 27
text: Pop

headline: Welcome to the Casino
text: Two of our finest business journalists have written a thorough account of the origins of the financial crisis of 2008. More than offering just a backward look, it helps explain the most troubling business headlines of the moment, as well as those that are certain to come. For starters, there is the unfolding foreclosure-paperwork fiasco. Next up will be a clash over whether big banks should be forced to take back billions of dollars in contaminated mortgages they sold. Down the road, we will no doubt confront the danger of the next asset bubble inflating as a result of the Federal Reserve’s use of extreme monetary policy to stimulate the economy. These continuing and future problems are all symptoms of a larger syndrome whose origins Bethany McLean and Joe Nocera ably chronicle in “All the Devils Are Here: The Hidden History of the Financial Crisis.”

headline: In a Cult Bronx Film, Hints of Hip-Hop
text: In the summer of 1979, Gary Weis and six film crew members drove from Manhattan to the South Bronx every day for two weeks, a journey that each day left Mr. Weis in awe and despair.

headline: Pregame Huddle: How to Beat Oregon
text: California failed to pull off a big upset against Oregon, but they may have laid the groundwork for another team to knock off the No.1 team in the country.

headline: Waiting for the Next Act in the Madoff Inquiry
text: The Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission have filed criminal and civil complaints against two former employees of Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities, accusing them of providing the support needed for Mr. Madoff to pull off his huge Ponzi scheme.

headline: Reviewing the Bidding on the Climate Files
text: 9:10 p.m. | Updated One year ago today, I was immersed in preparations for covering the Copenhagen round in climate treaty negotiations when a Facebook message popped up from Steven Mosher, a marketing consultant and software developer in San Francisco.

headline: Shaking the Family Tree
text: This summer, an idealistic young New Yorker spent several weeks working with poor children in India. Just before she left, a little girl ran up and pinched her so hard she drew blood. When a translator asked why she’d hurt someone who’d been kind to her, the girl explained, “This way she won’t forget me after she leaves.” That startling child already knew the inscriptive power of pain.

headline: Reviewing the Suzuki SX4 SportBack
text: In this week’s Automobiles section, Jonathan Schultz evaluates the Suzuki SX4 SportBack, describing it as a “compact wagon that daydreams of being a rally car.” He continues:

headline: Zamperini’s War
text: While the body counts mount in Afghanistan and Iraq, another military tally, less wrenching and tragic but poignant nonetheless, quietly proceeds. Every day more than 700 veterans of World War II die, and with each one goes a story, or dozens of them. Laura Hillenbrand reached Louis Zamperini just in the nick of time — he was in his mid-80s when she found him, and 93 now— and it’s an excellent thing, for his is surely one of the most extraordinary war stories of all.

headline: A Preview of the American ‘Top Gear’
text: After months years of development, a teaser trailer, a “60 Minutes” special and a pilot episode for NBC that was not picked up, an American version of “Top Gear” will make its debut on Sunday on the History Channel. The History Channel’s show is at least the third attempt to begin an American edition of the wildly popular BBC show hosted by Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May.

headline: Palin to Start Book Tour as Details Leak Out
text: Sarah Palin, the political celebrity and former Alaska governor, will start her second book tour next week as she continues to tease the media about a possible presidential run in 2012.

headline: T.S.A. Screening Measures Draw Virtual Protests
text: The Transportation Security Administration’s new security measures to screen travelers at airports  have drawn complaints, including virtual campaigns by a few especially vocal critics who have called for protests that could disrupt Thanksgiving holiday travel.

headline: Five-Link Friday: Mayor of Nowhere Edition
text: It’s a beautiful fall Friday out there. So New Jersey Transit riders, now that you’re stopped, be sure to smell the roses, or at least admire the crisp, clear sky from your stalled train car window.

headline: Ireland Is Said to Discuss Bailout of Nearly $70 Billion
text: PARIS  The financial support program being discussed between Ireland and potential donors should amount to at least 50 billion euros, officials briefed on the talks said Friday.

headline: An Affair to Remember
text: Years after the death of loved ones, we may find ourselves dreaming that they are alive. How happy we are to see them, to hear their voices, to realize how absurdly mistaken we were to think them lost forever. Then we wake, remember the truth and feel a pang as sharp as any we suffered in the early days of mourning.

headline: The More Convenient Gift Card
text: It’s easy to forget to bring a gift card when you go shopping, and it’s simple, too, to lose track of gift cards received during holidays past.

headline: Allman Brothers Band Plans Announcement at Beacon Theater
text: Is the Allman Brothers Band ready to end its rambling and return to the Beacon Theater?

headline: K.K.R. in Talks for Del Monte
text: In 1989, after the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company closed its landmark $25 billion buyout of the food and cigarette giant RJR Nabisco, it swiftly moved to sell its food brands. Among the first sales was Del Monte, which K.K.R. offloaded to a group of private investors.

headline: Fete Accompli | Lanvin for H&M
text: On Thursday night, underneath the shabby opulence of a dozen or so sparkling chandeliers, mismatched and hanging at different heights from the ceiling of one of the ball rooms at the Pierre Hotel, an array of top models — Dree Hemingway, Siri Tollerod and Lindsey Wixson among them — wore one-of-a-kind versions of Alber Elbaz’s new Lanvin for H&M collaboration, slinking, flirting and vamping down the runway in bright patterned tights, amazing costume jewelry and gowns made up of sexy mishmashes of bows, ribbon and poofy fabric. Set against the Pierre’s rarefied setting, this didn’t feel like fashion for the masses so much as an exclusive collection narrowed down to its more tarty elements. It isn’t always clear exactly what brands dripping in luxury hope to get out of such dips into the more shallow end of the pool. But they clearly are getting something. And if there were any doubt, Anna Dello Russo, dressed in a hot-pink one-shoulder number, prancing under the bright lights with a poodle in tow, made things crystal clear: these were true Lanvin girls.

headline: Naked Irish Sleepwalker Wins Libel Suit
text: An Irish jury awarded nearly $14 million in damages on Thursday to a man who claimed that his former employers had slandered him by insinuating that he had made improper advances to a female colleague during a business trip.

headline: The New Great Game
text: Maps often reveal more about those who draw them than they do about the reality they purport to represent. The Mercator projections that typically hang on the walls of classrooms and Pentagon offices place the United States in the middle, separated from Europe to the east by the Atlantic Ocean and from Asia to the west by the vast expanse of the Pacific. Our preference for this perspective no doubt reflects a certain national egocentrism, but for the better part of the last two centuries it has also made a good deal of strategic sense.

headline: What if Captured Carbon Makes a Getaway?
text: The political clout of the fossil-fuel industries was driven home this year with the death of cap-and-trade legislation in Congress. Among those flexing their muscles was the coal industry, which is responsible for more than 45 percent of the country’s generating capacity.

headline: What We’re Reading: If Chinese Growth Slows
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: What If Campbell Was Still Sending E-mails?
text: The hits just keep on coming for N.H.L. director of hockey operations Colin Campbell. Earlier this week he was at the center of a storm when internal e-mails revealed that he had called Marc Savard a “little fake artist” and criticized calls made against his son Gregory.

headline: Who’s No. 1?
text: This is the 13th year of the Bowl Championship Series, the byzantine and unpopular system that is supposed to guarantee that the college-football season ends with a championship game between the sport’s two best teams. Comparing teams that usually do not play one another — there are 120 major college-football programs, and each one competes in just 12 games each season — was never going to be easy. Like three egg rolls served to a party of four at a Chinese restaurant, the portions never seem to divide up quite as neatly as they should. This year, for instance, four programs — Oregon, Auburn, Boise State and Texas Christian — have spent much of the season in contention for the two positions in the championship.

headline: Who Can Resist a Man Who Sings Like a Woman?
text: One afternoon last July, a small, anxious crowd gathered in the lobby of Amsterdam’s Concertgebouw, hoping for a glimpse of Philippe Jaroussky, the young French countertenor who was to give a Baroque recital later that night. Among them were a Japanese woman in a black-and-white houndstooth coat, carrying a candy-pink shopping-bag with a DVD of a Kurosawa film that she intended to present to him, and a Russian violin teacher from Bremen wearing a sapphire ball gown. This was the kernel of die-hard Jaroussky admirers who follow the singer around the world, posting live videos of his concerts on YouTube and commiserating on his fan sites with fellow devotees who’d been unable to get to Sydney or Basel.

headline: The Real Supermarkets of Orange County
text: In August, to be closer to my aging parents, my husband and I moved from Northern California to Orange County. My family settled there more than 30 years ago, not long after coming to the United States from Iran. I was 12, and the culture shock was pretty severe. There were moms in tennis skirts, dads in pastels, good-looking blond boys who surfed and good-looking blond girls who were born to wear bikinis. We were the only dark-haired people they’d ever met who didn’t speak Spanish. When I left for college, I told myself that I’d never live in such a homogeneous place again. Today the beaches are still beautiful and surfers still ride the waves, but the blonds are in the minority.

headline: Midterm Maneuvers
text: My daughter was looking at President Obama’s picture in the paper the morning after the midterm elections. “Daddy,” she asked, “why does he look so frustrated?” Explaining divided government to a 3-year-old turns out to be harder than you’d think. But she did seem to get the point that, while Obama was still the president, his job was about to become much more difficult.

headline: The Attention-Span Myth
text: We seem to know a great deal about attention spans, those constituents of character that have become the digital-age equivalent of souls.

headline: Letters: Slick on Slick
text: As a practicing trial lawyer, I was offended by Douglas McCollam’s article, which appears to define “trial lawyers” to be those who, like Tony Buzbee, actively seek to represent victims of mass or even individual disasters. While there are many such lawyers, there are at least as many trial lawyers who earn their livelihood prosecuting and defending business and personal disputes in the highest tradition of the bar. This is a much higher and more-noble end of the profession than readers would understand from McCollam’s description. Our legal system is unsurpassed (except possibly by Britain’s), and that is because, in no small part, of the skill and dedication of thousands of trial lawyers, who should not be tarred by the same brush as those depicted by McCollam.

headline: Letter: The Headache That Wouldn’t Go Away
text: We were disturbed to read, in Lisa Sanders’s Diagnosis column, about the reluctance to perform CT scanning due to concerns about fetal exposure to radiation. Head CT is considered safe in pregnancy, because the uterus is outside the area of radiation exposure and can be easily shielded with lead. Magnetic resonance imaging is also considered safe. On the other hand, undiagnosed and untreated neurologic disorders do put the mother and her unborn child at considerable risk. A seizure during pregnancy can be dangerous for mother and child.

headline: Weekend Competition: Crossword Clueless
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise self-solving crossword clues.

headline: 2011 Audi A7: Audi Joins the 4-Door Coupe Parade
text: Introduced on Thursday: 2011 Audi A7

headline: No Offense, Mariners, but ...
text: Today we shall sponsor a debate over just whose offense is the worst: the Miami Dolphins, the Seattle Mariners and U.C.L.A. being the featured contestants. With Miami led (nowhere) by a quarterback named Tyler Thigpen, the Mariners being so otherworldly bad that pitcher Felix Hernandez won the Cy Young Award in a landslide despite only 13 victories and the Bruins getting crushed in a game when the opposing quarterback outshined them with 68 yards, there are no wrong answers.

headline: Holidays After Divorce
text: Holidays are a reaffirmation of our families, and reminders of their imperfections. It’s a time to find strength in existing bonds, and also to mourn the ones we’ve lost.

headline: Glimpsing the Brain’s Powers (and Limits)
text: A once-living example of the most complicated object in the universe is mounted in a case at the beginning of the ambitious exhibition “Brain: The Inside Story,” which opens on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. And a sorry-looking object it is, if we put aside the symbolism and portentousness that have grown around it, and the research that barely has begun to dissect its innermost workings.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Absolute Morrison
text: The hardcover list has a double dose of Grant Morrison this week. The British writer takes on two of the biggest heroes published by DC Comics: Superman and Batman. In “All-Star Superman” Mr. Morrison took the Man of Steel, stripped him of years of continuity and came up with some ingenious adventures. This deluxe “Absolute” edition (at No. 4 on the list) reprints the 12 stories, illustrated by Frank Quietly, and includes bonus sketch material. In reviewing the second volume for The New York Times Book Review, Doug Wolk wrote, “Grant Morrison is one of the deftest superhero-comics writers of the moment.” He added, “Nearly every visual detail and line of dialogue has some subtler implication or resonance that emerges on rereading.”

headline: Obama and the Book of Job
text: Unfortunately for the powerful, the plight of the biblical Job is a story with perennial resonance. A man seemingly rich in the gifts life has to offer, happy and blessed, finds himself — unjustly, from his perspective — bereft. Protected and apparently invincible one day, he is buffeted as God turns his back on his former beloved, producing rage, confusion and self-pity. In the history of the American presidency, reversal happens time and time again: Lyndon Johnson declining to run four years after his landslide victory in 1964, George H. W. Bush losing re-election after winning the Persian Gulf war of 1991, Bill Clinton in the 1994 midterms, and now Barack Obama.

headline: Bar Mitzvah Studies Take to the Web
text: AT Eli Kapsack’s bar mitzvah, he chanted in the ancient tones of the Hebrew Bible about a sorcerer named Balaam, the angel of the Lord descending to earth and a talking donkey who tries to clue her owner in to the miracle at hand. He read the prayers for the Saturday morning service, and took his place as a religious adult, as Jewish children generally do at 13.

headline: 2011 Nissan Quest: Now Made in Japan
text: Introduced on Wednesday: Fourth-generation Nissan Quest minivan.

headline: Thais Show Resolve at Protest 6 Months After Crackdown
text: BANGKOK  Thousands of antigovernment demonstrators blocked a major intersection in the commercial heart of the Thai capital on Friday to mark the passage of six months since a bloody military crackdown on street protests.

headline: An Eye for an Eye
text: Whatever the weaknesses of their free-form plots, Walter Mosley’s crime novels are redeemed by the earthy vitality of his characters: an exuberant pageant of fast-talking rogues and unrepentant sinners, high-stepping women, sharp young blades and children wise beyond their years. Meanwhile, on the sidelines, are his philosophical old souls, shaking their heads and laughing at the parade of fools.

headline: Incivility Can Have Costs Beyond Hurt Feelings
text: COURTESY means a lot to me. I am keenly aware when someone fails to say please or thank you. Waiters or clerks who ignore me or respond snippily do so at their peril. My children know well my glare when they fail to give their bus or subway seat to an elderly person.

headline: Decline is a Choice
text: Bad news from ESPN:

headline: Video: How to Beat Oregon
text: California failed to pull off a big upset against Oregon, but they may have laid the groundwork for another team to knock off the No.1 team in the country. And was T.C.U.’s close victory as bad as the score says it was? Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg discuss on this week’s edition of the Pregame Huddle.

headline: Marriage and the Monarchy: Lessons From the British Royal Family
text: Prince William, second in line to the British throne, announced his engagement this week, immediately sparking a media frenzy, especially in the United Kingdom. We think the news brings up some interesting possibilities for teaching and learning across the curriculum, in history, media studies and economics.

headline: Blazers Stand by Ailing Oden
text: It’s hard not to feel empathy for Portland Trail Blazers center Greg Oden, who is facing his third career-threatening knee surgery in three years. He came into the league with much fanfare, selected by the Blazers as the No. 1 overall pick of the 2007 draft.

headline: Odey Plays a Familiar Role, the Contrarian
text: The London hedge fund manager Crispin Odey produced bumper profits for his investors by betting on bank stocks during the depths of the financial crisis.

headline: TimesCast | November 19, 2010
text: The Pope prepares to install 24 new Cardinals; Baghdad's Muslims celebrate the holy holiday of Id al-Adha; and Harry Potter inspires good.

headline: After the Fed’s Action, Watching Inflation’s Trajectory
text: THE core rate of inflation fell to a record low in the United States last month, rekindling fears of deflation and warnings that the Federal Reserve might have to take even more aggressive steps to keep inflation as high as it wants it to be.

headline: Paperback Row
text: CROSSERS,  by Philip Caputo (Vintage Contemporaries, $16.) The sins of the father are visited on the children in Caputo’s novel of drugs, desperation and illegal immigration. Set in the borderlands of the Southwest, “Crossers” revolves around a multigenerational feud between Arizona cattle ranchers and the audacious head of a Mexican cartel.

headline: Boehner Adamant: We’ll Oppose Partial Tax Relief
text: The House’s top Republican, John A. Boehner of Ohio, said that his party would firmly oppose any effort by Democrats to allow the Bush-era tax cuts expire on annual income above $250,000 for couples and $200,000 for individuals.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: LIFE,  by Keith Richards with James Fox (Little, Brown, $29.99.) Reading Richards’s autobiography is like getting to corner him in a room and to ask everything you always wanted to know about the Rolling Stones, and have him be completely honest with you.

headline: U.S. Women in Unfamiliar Place
text: It was not supposed to be this way.

headline: Senate to Vote on Banning Earmarks
text: The full Senate will vote on a proposed ban on lawmaker-directed spending items known as earmarks, as an amendment to a food safety measure that is currently being debated on the floor. But it will need the support of a super-majority of 67 senators to be approved.

headline: On Our Radar: Landrieu Drops Hold on Budget Nominee
text: Senator Mary Landrieu, Demcrat of Louisiana,  dropped her hold on Jack Lew, President Obama’s nominee for director of the Office of Management and Budget, on Thursday evening. Mr. Lew was confirmed by the Senate immediately after the hold was relinquished. Ms. Landrieu had blocked the nomination for nearly two months to pressure over concerns that drilling permits were not being issued quickly enough in the aftermath of the BP oil spill. [Politics Daily]

headline: Fighting the Closing of a High School on the Brink
text: A school bus driver honked and pumped his fist around 7:30 Friday morning, steering along Stillwell Avenue beneath the elevated D train. Outside the tree-lined campus of John Dewey High School, a swirling crowd of students, teachers and alumni cheered, many hoisting handmade signs.

headline: Lotus to Work on Next-Generation IndyCar for 2012
text: When General Motors officials announced last week that Chevrolet would resume supplying engines to the IndyCar Series in 2012, open-wheel-racing fans were delighted that Honda finally would have some competition. Now another motorsports giant is joining them.

headline: Inside the List
text: HIS TURN: Things might be a little less tense in Crawford this Christmas now that George W. Bush has his own No. 1 best seller. “Decision Points,” the former president’s new memoir, enters in the top spot, just as his wife’s “Spoken From the Heart” did last spring. But don’t worry, ladies, Laura Bush isn’t totally ceding the stage. Her memoir, which spent 12 weeks on the printed list, is still hanging around at No. 28 on the extended list, six months after publication.

headline: New “Daisy” Ad Warns Against Delay in Arms Treaty
text: More than 40 years ago, President Lyndon Johnson used images of a little girl, a daisy and a mushroom cloud to urge people to vote for him, saying the “stakes are too high.”

headline: Lead Producer of ‘Spider-Man’ Hit With Lawsuit by Live Nation
text: Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the troubled Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” is being sued for more than $5 million by his former employer, Live Nation Entertainment, over what that company says are violations of the deal they struck when he left in 2008.

headline: MSNBC Suspends Joe Scarborough for Campaign Donations
text: Joe Scarborough, a co-host of MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” was suspended for two days after he acknowledged making political donations that he had not disclosed to the network. For more, read the full post on Media Decoder.

headline: Why Are Women in Some Countries Oppressed?
text: There’s much debate about why women in some countries are presidents and business executives, and women in others are locked up in the home and beaten or brutalized if they try to stand up for themselves. Obviously the differences are rooted in culture, but there are diverse theories about why some cultures resulted in more emancipated women and others in more oppressed women.

headline: China Move Could Counter Fed’s Efforts
text: HONG KONG  China’s central bank unexpectedly announced on Friday night that it would require commercial banks to set aside a bit more money. It was the second such move by Beijing this month and the clearest sign yet that China means to counter the Federal Reserve’s monetary easing in the United States.

headline: Darvon Pulled From Market by F.D.A.
text: The painkilling drug propoxyphene, sold under the Darvon and Darvocet brands and used by about 10 million Americans last year, will be removed from the market because of serious heart risks, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday.

headline: Sept. 11 Workers Agree to Settle Health Lawsuits
text: After a wrenching seven-year battle, more than 10,000 workers who sued New York City over health damages they claimed after the 9/11 recovery efforts have approved a settlement, clearing the way for payouts totaling at least $625 million, lawyers said Friday.

headline: Wells Fargo Pays Citi $100 Million for Wachovia Claims
text: Nearly two years after Citigroup was outfoxed for the troubled Wachovia Corporation, Citi is walking away with an unexpected prize: a $100 million check from Wells Fargo to resolve claims that it had unfairly wrestled Wachovia out of Citi’s hands.

headline: Buy American? Upscale Investors Look Abroad

headline: Audi Hedges on New Models

Its volume seller, the A4, “is likely to receive a four-cylinder diesel engine by 2015,” an official was quoted as saying.

headline: It’s the Relationships, Stupid
text: THE director Edward Zwick has faced many challenges in his career. For his Civil War drama, “Glory,” he built an entire fort on a Savannah, Ga., beach and then laid siege to it. While shooting his domestic terrorism thriller, “The Siege,” he shut down the Brooklyn Bridge for an entire day. But these pale, perhaps, before the latest challenge he has set for himself: persuading men to shell out for a romantic comedy. That’s what people are calling “Love and Other Drugs,” even if the label is a loose fit. Adapted from Jamie Reidy’s best-selling memoir about the Viagra gold rush in the late 1990s, it stars Jake Gyllenhaal as a womanizing pharmaceutical representative who falls in lust, and then in love, with a beautiful young woman (Anne Hathaway) with Stage 1 Parkinson’s disease. It would be a plunge deep into disease-of-the-week territory, if not for the raunch — sex scenes, sex tapes, nudity, an orgy — that Mr. Zwick has seasoned the film with and that may leave some in the audience wondering whether they are watching a film about Viagra, or on Viagra.

headline: Water World
text: At the government’s request, the tribes that populate the remote Indonesian island of Sumba stopped hunting heads in the 1950s. Or at least that was what was supposed to happen. In reality, a head was lopped off in an intratribal war as recently as last March. ‘‘We had to stop sending people on trips to the waterfall for months until things settled down,’’ says Claude Graves, one of three Westerners living permanently on the island. Graves and his wife have spent the last 20 years building Nihiwatu, the most exclusive and lavish surf destination in the world. The hideaway resort draws ultrarich, über-athletic adventurers, who come to test themselves against a legendary wave and to be surrounded by one of the last Stone Age cultures on Earth.

headline: As Cheesemaking Blooms, So Can Listeria

headline: With Her, It’s Love at First Sound
text: When last heard from on a Broadway stage, in the blissful 2008 revival of “South Pacific,” Kelli O’Hara exultantly and repeatedly told the world, “I’m in love with a wonderful guy.” This weekend at City Center, in the somewhat-less-blissful Encores! concert production of “Bells Are Ringing,” Ms. O’Hara proclaims in her opening number, “I’m in love with a voice.” Having heard both these declarations, I can now say with confidence that if Ms. O’Hara chose to sing that she had fallen in love with a desiccated turnip, I would believe her unconditionally.

Ninety percent of the pizza looks as if someone came to New York, walked through Times Square, and said, “We’ll make pizza like that, because obviously the Americans prefer it.”

headline: A Gently Edited Classic, Pirate Included
text: OF all the types of apartments available in New York City, few are more iconic than the so-called Classic 6, the mazy configuration that includes two bedrooms, a dining room and a maid’s room, complete with its own bath. For decades, the Classic 6 was the ultimate symbol of gracious living, a vivid reminder of the style in which many well-heeled New Yorkers lived generations ago.

headline: Now Online | T Winter Travel 2010
text: T’s winter travel edition begins with a fairy tale, by way of a cover shoot in the snowy Swedish countryside. Then it’s off to another kind of winter wonderland: the high-rolling peaks of Courchevel (where’s there as much “ice” on the skiers as on the slopes). Ready for a thaw? There’s serious surfing on Sumba Island, home to some of the world’s best breaks and the ultimate eco-resort. For more beach time, we drop in on St. Lucia before heading to Rio, where the art scene is heating up. It’s a season of pilgrimages, too: In the temples of Tamil Nadu, India, Guy Trebay partakes in bathing rituals that give a whole new meaning to taking the waters. In Taipei, the designer Jason Wu goes home looking for inspiration for his next collection. And in Los Angeles, Frank Bruni eats his way through what has become America’s great food city. Wash it all down with the artisanal cocktails of Sydney, then sleep it off at the latest slumber spas. Plus: check into the hottest new hotels, from Buenos Aires to Bangkok.

headline: Weekend Fare

Call (212) 627-2308 to reserve.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Plenty to Play For
text: While Oregon, Auburn, Texas Christian and Boise State are firmly entrenched in the race for the national championship, there are a multitude of teams with one, two or three losses that still have plenty to play for. Ohio State has just one blemish on its record — a loss to Wisconsin — but it still has its eye on the Big Ten title and a Rose Bowl berth. The Buckeyes will need to win out, starting Saturday at Iowa, and get some help from the Badgers, but the goal is still a realistic one. Virginia Tech — which began the season with two losses, including an embarrassing defeat at the hands of James Madison — has won eight in a row and has its sights set on the A.C.C. title. Miami would love to give the Hokies their first conference loss. Nebraska is kicking itself for the egg it laid against Texas. If not for that, the Cornhuskers would be in the middle of the race for the national title. As it is, they will travel to College Station on Saturday to take on Texas A&M, which has won four in a row. Neither Arkansas nor Mississippi State is going to win the SEC, but both teams have enjoyed successful seasons. A win over the Razorbacks would get the Bulldogs to eight victories in their second year under Coach Dan Mullen. And, finally, there is Southern California, all but forgotten in the wake of the N.C.A.A. sanctions that followed the Reggie Bush mess. But Lane Kiffin has had the Trojans playing well of late. Now they will try to win at Oregon State, whose season has been a disappointment.

headline: When Helping Your Child Hurts

headline: Modern Italian Fare, With Warmth
text: FOR more than 40 years, the building at 15 New Street in Huntington has been home to an Italian restaurant. For decades, it was Orlando’s, a Huntington institution. The Iannucci family took over the premises 13 years ago, running Tello’s and then Mangiamo there. The family’s latest entry is Bel Posto, which opened in September.

headline: Driver of School Bus Arrested After Accusations of Sex Abuse
text: The driver of a school bus has been arrested on charges that he sexually abused three elementary school students in Queens, the police and prosecutors said Friday.

headline: The Old-School Style, Unafraid to Be Imperfect
text: The problem with the soul revival of the last few years has been precision, too much of it. The bass now has to sound like the bass then, except somehow more so. Same for the drums, the guitar, the keys, the vocals. It’s an idealized take on the past, so much feckless mimicry.

headline: Requiring Brokers to Put Their Customers First
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I wrote an open letter to Mary Schapiro, the chairwoman of Securities and Exchange Commission, on behalf of average investors.

headline: Christie’s and China: An Artful Diplomacy
text: SHANGHAI  Two months ago, during Asian Art Week, Christie’s auction house invited hundreds of wealthy collectors, scholars and art patrons to its New York headquarters in Rockefeller Center for what it described as a special exhibition and symposium about the rise of Chinese contemporary art.

headline: When the Pie Line Grows Long
text: Every Thanksgiving season has gotten “progressively worse” for Tod Wilson, the owner of Mr. Tod’s Pie Factory in Somerset. “But by that I mean better,” he added.

headline: Deep in the Flavor Pool, Korean Style
text: FOR many Westerners, Korean dining takes a degree of effort. It requires familiarity with the range of Korean casseroles, stews and hot pots. A comfort level with ingredients like intestines, bones or fish heads, and flavors heavy on the red chili pepper, garlic, vinegar and onion. Not to mention a dry cleaner after sitting around a grill.

headline: Setting the Bar Very High And Leaping Toward It
text: Julian Barnett sets the stakes high in the program notes for his new “Super Natural,” which opened at Dance New Amsterdam on Thursday night.

headline: Incoming House Members Pick Their Offices
text: Most people take a few weeks to find a home or office. Freshman House members had a few hours.

headline: Waves of Movement, Ever Flowing
text: As the fourth movement of a Brahms piano quintet begins, a man slides a woman along the floor. They’re both seated, and he  propelling them with his knees, her wrapped across his back  is treading backward. This image of effort and dejection, a strange, dreamlike response to the music, at once lodges in the head.

headline: From Bucks: The More Convenient Gift Card
text: From Jennifer Saranow Schultz, our colleague over at the Bucks personal-finance blog:It’s easy to forget to bring a gift card when you go shopping, and it’s simple, too, to lose track of gift cards received during holidays past.

headline: Pairing Wolfgangs From Two Eras
text: Many prominent musicians dutifully commission the occasional new piece, but the German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter genuinely seems to relish the challenge. She has commissioned and championed works from composers including Krzysztof Penderecki, Sofia Gubaidulina and André Previn.

headline: Spain’s R-Rated Election Campaign
text: Updated | Saturday | 10:21 a.m. Apparently desperate to pique the interest of young voters ahead of local elections in Catalonia scheduled for later this month, political parties in the Spanish region are engaged in what is starting to seem like a race to see which of them can get their entire campaign banned for excessive use of sex, violence or porn film soundtracks.

headline: Big Companies Hiring, Small Companies Aren’t, Gallup Finds
text: Despite the usual trope that “small businesses are the engines of job growth,” larger companies actually seem to be doing the most hiring these days, according to new Gallup survey data.

headline: Now Showing | Ann Agee
text: “Ann Agee: Rules of the Pattern,” at the Locks Gallery in Philadelphia until Dec. 30, offers a look at recent work by the artist, who is known for her playful, subversive treatment of traditional decorative porcelain archetypes, like blue-and-white patterns (which she has applied to ceramic sex toys, or an entire bathroom) or 18th century figurines (which she re-imagines in contemporary clothing, doing things like carrying shopping bags). In this show, Agee continues to give domesticity her own spin, in hand-painted and stenciled, large-scale “wallpaper drawings” that depict idealized interiors, and which allude to models as diverse as 19th century scenic wallpaper, Matisse’s “The Dessert: Harmony in Red,” and the spaces depicted in Roy Lichtenstein’s paintings. Along with a display of intricate white porcelain vases, the exhibition includes three works that are groups of hand-made porcelain platters and bowls arranged on a steel armature. Traditional pieces like this are decorated with floral patterns or pastoral scenes, but Agee’s depict modest domestic interiors, including everyday items like washing machines and stoves.

headline: 'Tiny Furniture' by Lena Dunham
text: A new indie film by Lena Dunham features her mother, the famous artist, Laurie Simmons.

headline: South Africa Fears Millions More H.I.V. Infections
text: DAVEYTON, South Africa  South Africa, already home to 5.7 million H.I.V.-positive people, more than any other nation, can expect an additional five million to become infected during the next two decades even if the nation more than doubles its already considerable financing for treatment and prevention and gives prevention a higher priority, according to a report presented here Friday to the country’s leading advisory body on AIDS policy.

headline: Earbuds With a Mic That Sound About Right
text: If you listen to music on your phone’s MP3 player, you have to make a choice. Either choose headphones that sound good, or headphones with a microphone on them.

headline: Bypass Planned for Leaky New York Aqueduct

headline: Satellite Radio Without the Clutter
text: Despite the crummy economy, 20 million people are still willing to plunk down between $7 and $17 per month to listen to satellite radio. That’s up from 18.5 million subscribers about one year ago, helped no doubt by an increased number of vehicles that leave the assembly line with satellite radio capability.

headline: Sweet Potato Pie: Tradition, Plus
text: SWEET potato pie is a lovely concept, for a variety of reasons: it beautifully marries sweet and savory, it uses a vegetable as the foundation of a dessert, its color is stunning and it’s creamy and crisp all at once.

headline: Getting Touchy at the Airport
text: Ah, Thanksgiving is almost upon us. We can look forward to a full belly, good wine, bad football and the worst travel day of the year. And in 2010, apparently, it will be the worst travel day in the history of mankind: “In the three weeks since the Transportation Security Administration began more aggressive pat-downs of passengers at airport security checkpoints, traveler complaints have poured in,” reports The Times’s Susan Stellin. “Some offer graphic accounts of genital contact, others tell of agents gawking or making inappropriate comments, and many express a general sense of powerlessness and humiliation …It remains to be seen whether travelers approve of the pat-downs, especially as millions more people experience them for the first time during the holiday travel season.”

headline: Potatoes With Crunch, Without the Cabin
text: A FEW years ago, I accidentally made perfect roasted potatoes.

headline: A Warning About Climate Change From a Departing Republican
text: An outgoing Republican congressman used a House science and environment subcommittee hearing this week as an opportunity to chide his party for its growing skepticism about the threat of global warming and to warn of missed economic opportunities in clean energy development if climate change is ignored.

headline: Fearless Preschoolers Lack Empathy?
text: THE GIST Fearless children are more unfeeling.

headline: Asked & Answered | Laurie Simmons
text: “Tiny Furniture” is Lena Dunham’s breakout indie, a picture so promising that, after its debut at the South by Southwest film festival in March, it landed Dunham, 24, work on both an HBO series with Judd Apatow and a film project with Scott Rudin. Last week, Apatow was in the audience at the Museum of Modern Art for the premiere of “Tiny Furniture,” and during a question-and-answer session afterward, he asked something of Laurie Simmons, who is Dunham’s mother, both in the movie and in real life. “Will you raise my kids?”

headline: Keeping Up Tradition, Sugar Plums and All
text: DOUGLAS MARTIN, the new director of the American Repertory Ballet, is no stranger to detractors of “The Nutcracker.” “People who’ve been dancing it their whole lives and have moved on to other things, or a new form of dance, will make a comment like, ‘Oh, that old thing?’ ” he said.

text: In last week’s blog post  on Tim Pawlenty, we noted that Mr. Pawlenty’s Google search traffic — which may be a reasonably good proxy for how much interest the candidate generates among the public at large — somewhat lags behind that of several other potential Republican contenders, such as that of  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

text: “I SAID, ‘We live so close, and we never hang out down here; we should be tourists for a day,’ ” she remembered later. “I played right into his hands.”

headline: Israel to Get Security Guarantees in Return for Freeze
text: WASHINGTON  A week after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton worked out an agreement for a 90-day freeze on Israeli settlement construction, the deal remains hung up in Mr. Netanyahu’s Cabinet, with Israeli and American officials haggling over details like how generous a subsidy the United States will give Israel for 20 advanced fighter aircraft.

headline: At Home, Jets Look for Noise and Hope to Roar
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – The Jets have won all five of their road games this year but are a plebeian 2-2 at New Meadowlands Stadium, where they will host Houston on Sunday.

headline: For American Women, It’s Win or Stay Home
text: The United States women’s soccer team, recognized as a world powerhouse for at least the past 20 years, must win a home-and-home total-goals series against Italy to qualify for next summer’s Women’s World Cup in Germany.

headline: Recipes for Holiday Side Dishes
text: Roasted potatoes with figs and garlic, Brussels sprouts with bacon, and other dishes that may just upstage the main course.

headline: As You Await Your Invitation...

headline: Art That Can Depict a Starvation Diet
text: From prehistoric cave paintings of beef on the hoof to Renaissance canvases depicting the Last Supper to Andy Warhol’s picture of a Campbell’s soup can, food has inspired art. But the most striking images in “Art and Appetite,” a small, thought-provoking exhibition of prints and photographs at the Davison Art Center, on the campus of Wesleyan University in Middletown, are less about food than they are about its absence.

headline: Fleeting Autumns, Captured on Canvas
text: Arriving at the Hudson River Museum on a golden afternoon about a week ago, I felt compelled to pull out my cellphone and take a picture. Right above my parked car, vivid scarlet branches were overlapped with chromium yellow ones, backed by a pure-blue sky; the colors seemed to insist on being noticed and recorded before the winter  or the next rainstorm  erased them.

headline: With Grit and Polish, Sanchez Emerges as a Leader
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Teammates often describe Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez more like a male model than a model quarterback. Inevitably, they mention his wavy black hair, handsome face, famous girlfriends. Pretty boy, they call him.

headline: Steve Israel to Lead Democrats’ Comeback Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday named Representative Steve Israel of New York to lead the House Democratic campaign committee into the next election, putting him in charge of the party’s effort to regain the majority it lost in November.

headline: Adults Behaving Childishly
text: THEY seem like such lovely people. With their nice clothes and their art books and their careers in fields like corporate law and “wealth management.” But children will be children, and one couple’s son has had a playground altercation with the other couple’s son, and teeth were lost. So now the adults are getting together to work it all out, in a civilized manner, over espresso.

headline: An Orphan in Her Teens, Determined to Get an Education
text: Ernestine Grant’s mother, Ethel, adored Christmas. And so it was not surprising that one morning a week before the holiday she was heading out of her Brooklyn apartment in search of additional gifts. Ethel Grant got as far as the door before she cried out for her husband and crumpled to the floor. She had been stricken by a massive stroke. She lasted a week in the hospital. She died on her beloved Christmas Eve.

headline: Mine Owner’s Flair Rankles Chilean Elite
text: CALDERA, Chile

headline: Canada Using M.L.S. to Improve Its Play
text: TORONTO  After the referee blew the final whistle in the Soviet Union’s 2-0 victory against Canada in the 1986 World Cup, Bruce Wilson, Canada’s 35-year-old captain, kept his sweaty No. 3 jersey, eschewing the ceremonial postgame shirt swap with his opposite number.

headline: Bomb Explodes Near Convoy of Iraqi Lawmakers, Killing a Guard
text: BAGHDAD  A roadside bomb exploded Friday morning beside a convoy carrying three members of Parliament in the northern city of Mosul. The lawmakers escaped without injury, but a bodyguard died in the attack, and two were wounded.

headline: Helen Boehm, the Princess of Porcelain, Dies at 89
text: Helen Boehm, a self-made businesswoman known as the Princess of Porcelain for her company’s elaborate sculptures, which have graced the coffee tables of royalty and heads of state for six decades, died on Monday at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 89.

headline: Robin Day, Designer Whose Work Graces Waiting Rooms, Dies at 95
text: Robin Day, perhaps Britain’s most influential furniture designer since World War II, whose spare, practical and affordable inventions were exemplified by the now ubiquitous “polyprop” chair, died Nov. 9 at his home in Chichester, England. He was 95.

headline: Patience at Notre Dame Despite a Trying Season
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  A year marred by bad luck and bookended by tragedies for the Notre Dame football team will, one way or another, come to a close in the coming weeks.

headline: Haitians Plunge Into Muck to Stem Cholera
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Duquesne Fils-Aimé, stripped to the waist, stepped gingerly into the canal, drawing stares of astonishment from the spectators above. When he ducked his head under the water  if one could call it that  an audible gasp rose from the crowd.

headline: Chamomile Tea and Legal Briefs
text: Weekdays are so hectic for New York State’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, 65, that he rarely has time for reading the endless motions, briefs and memos that go with the job. So a big pile of paper goes with him whether he and his wife, Amy, also a lawyer, spend Sunday in their East Side apartment in Manhattan or their home in Rye Brook in Westchester County, where they raised their two children, now 34 and 31. WILLIAM GLABERSON

headline: Cost and Goals at Center of Arms Treaty Debate
text: The standoff this week over ratification of a new arms control treaty centers on a simple phrase: nuclear modernization. Those two words conceal a little known, enormously ambitious plan to do nothing less than rebuild the nation’s atomic complex for the 21st century.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE SETAI FIFTH AVENUE, between 36th and 37th Streets, is the latest in a string of large luxury hotels built during the recession to open in recent months. Its sprawling penthouses rent for a very nonrecessionary $15,000 a night (rates for the rest of the 157 rooms and 57 suites start at $545).

headline: TV Channel Draws Viewers, and Threats, in Iran
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  In little more than a year, the Persian-language satellite television channel beamed into Iran by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a prominent Afghan family has rapidly become one of the most popular stations in the country.

headline: Ovechkin Ties Crosby, in DVDs Made
text: The season of Alex Ovechkin and Sidney Crosby is about to begin.

headline: Incoming Speaker Takes Commercial Flight, but Skips the Pat-Down
text: WASHINGTON — Representative John A. Boehner, the soon-to-be Republican speaker, pledged recently that he would fly commercial airlines back home to Ohio, passing up the military plane used by the current speaker, Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat. But that does not mean he will endure the hassles of ordinary passengers, including pat-downs and other new security screenings.

headline: No Boo-boos or Cowlicks? Only in School Pictures
text: Oliver Tracy showed up for his first-grade portrait with a crisp white shirt tucked into navy slacks, a striped tie slightly too long for his tiny frame, and not a lock of his sun-streaked blond hair out of place.

headline: Below 14th, Center Stage
text: A gallery of 12 stylish New Yorkers on bikes, part of a project documenting all 200 streets in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Rear Views, Downtown
text: ONE is wearing a couture gown, another just a pair of red underwear. One is lugging a huge bouquet of flowering rhododendrons on his shoulder, another a suckling pig. They are all riding bicycles in the middle of streets downtown, and they are all shown from behind, having passed by, headed toward some unknown destination — a party, a garden, a pig roast.

headline: Green Strategies for the Poorest
text: On Tuesday I wrote about the LifeStraw Family, an in-home water purification device. The product itself is interesting, but what I wanted to highlight in the column is how its manufacturer, Vestergaard Frandsen, is planning to make money with it. Not from the poor families who use it — they will give it away in western Kenya. Instead, the company plans to be paid in credits they can sell on the global carbon markets. In this system, credits are awarded to projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. They may then be then bought by polluting companies or governments to offset their own emissions. LifeStraw Family users no longer have to boil their water to make it safe to drink. Less boiling means fewer emissions.

headline: In Negotiation of Jeter’s Worth, Stock Is an Option
text: The haggling between Derek Jeter and the Yankees centers on what he should be paid for the next three, four or five years. What is a 36-year-old player worth coming off a subpar season?

headline: Thai Police Find 2,000 Illegally Aborted Fetuses
text: BANGKOK  Two thousand fetuses from illegal abortion clinics have been found hidden at a Buddhist temple here, igniting calls for stricter abortion laws in a nation that is both socially conservative and sexually tolerant.

headline: Like Black Friday, but Without the Fights
text: Black Friday, which in the retail industry refers to the day after Thanksgiving, has traditionally been the day that kicks off the holiday shopping season with big sales, store openings well before the first hint of daylight and the occasional fisticuffs over precious parking spots. But for some shoppers, a cheap cashmere sweater just does not justify taking an elbow to the rib at 6 a.m.

headline: SEC Suspends Vols’ Coach for First 8 League Games
text: In what could be a harbinger for stiffer penalties for rules breakers in college sports, the Southeastern Conference announced Friday that the Tennessee men’s basketball coach, Bruce Pearl, would be suspended for the first eight league games.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Republicans Stymie Democrats on Top Measures
text: WASHINGTON  Empowered by their election gains, Congressional Republicans are giving little ground to President Obama and weakened Democrats in the final weeks of the 111th Congress, imperiling Democratic efforts to pass major tax and spending legislation, unemployment aid and a nuclear nonproliferation treaty among other issues.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Lawsuit Claims ATP Knew Stars Were Tied to Betting
text: In 2007, as the Association of Tennis Professionals began a crackdown on gambling and disciplined five lower-ranked Italian players for making bets on matches, it knew that gambling accounts were maintained in the names of some of its top-ranked players, who bet on matches, and did not follow up and discipline them, according to evidence revealed in a federal lawsuit.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Pat Burns Dies at 58; Won Stanley Cup With Devils
text: Pat Burns, a tough-minded, tight-lipped coach of four National Hockey League teams who led the New Jersey Devils to a Stanley Cup title in 2003, his first season with the team, died on Friday in Sherbrooke, Quebec. He was 58.

headline: Naming of Alaska Winner Delayed
text: A federal judge in Alaska on Friday placed a conditional hold on the certification of the results of the contentious Senate race between Joe Miller and Senator Lisa Murkowski, telling the Miller campaign to take its legal challenges to state court.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Nevada Senator’s Parents Cleared in Election Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Election Commission on Friday dismissed a complaint charging that the parents of Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, violated election law by paying $96,000 in 2008 to the family of the senator’s former mistress.

headline: Yankees Make Cubs’ Pitching Coach Theirs
text: Larry Rothschild lives in Tampa, Fla., a mile or two from the Yankees’ complex. He can expect an easy commute now that he will be working there every day this spring.

headline: Senate Approves Payment of Black Farmers’ Claims
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Friday approved $4.55 billion to settle longstanding charges that the federal government had denied or underpaid aid to black farmers and mismanaged trust funds for American Indians.

headline: A New Look in Detroit for the Newly Public G.M.
text: DETROIT  It is out with the old and in with the new at General Motors as the federal government’s ownership stake in the company was cut in half this week. Even the automaker’s sign atop its corporate headquarters has gotten a makeover.

headline: For Judges, Lawyers and Fellow Jurors, the Challenges of Dealing With a Holdout
text: Two days before the jury at the embassy bombing trial of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani would reach a verdict, it seemed to be on the verge of a deadlock.

headline: Bloggingheads: Love Big Government?
text: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Melissa Clouthier of Liberty Pundits debate whether Americans want smaller government.

headline: Damage Worse Than Thought in Qantas Blowout
text: WASHINGTON  The A380 superjumbo aircraft whose engine blew apart on departure from Singapore on Nov. 4 was far more seriously damaged than initial reports indicated, with hydraulic and electric failures and serious damage to the plane’s skeleton, according to independent experts who examined newly available photographs of the jet and leaked accounts of the investigation.

headline: Indianapolis Honors Its Literary Native Son
text: INDIANAPOLIS  In Kurt Vonnegut’s novel “Cat’s Cradle,” the narrator meets a woman on a plane who is delighted to discover that he is from Indiana. Holding his arm tightly, she tells him, “We Hoosiers got to stick together.”

headline: Unions Yield on Wage Scales to Preserve Jobs
text: MILWAUKEE  Organized labor appears to be losing an important battle in the Great Recession.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Justice for Spill Victims, Like It or Not
text: A few days ago, I had breakfast with Kenneth R. Feinberg, the former pay czar and 9/11 fund administrator, who is now grappling with one of the most difficult assignments of his career: doling out as much as $20 billion of BP’s cash to residents of the Gulf Coast who suffered as a result of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

headline: Vatican Preparing New Guidelines to Deal With Sexual Abuse
text: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican announced on Friday that it was preparing a new set of guidelines to help bishops offer a “coordinated and efficient” response to sexual abuse, one that emphasizes protecting children, cooperating with civil authorities and careful selection of future priests.

headline: New E-Mails Delay Ethics Trial of Lawmaker
text: WASHINGTON  A newly discovered exchange of e-mails led the House ethics committee on Friday to delay its trial of Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat accused of helping steer bailout money to a bank in which her husband owned shares.

headline: Debt Rising, a City Seeks Donations in Michigan
text: DETROIT  A Michigan city is pleading with churches, schools and a hospital for donations to help cover its staggering budget deficit.

headline: Agency Failed to Oversee Deadly Race
text: LOS ANGELES  The federal Bureau of Land Management failed to enforce its safety regulations for an off-road race where a truck rolled over spectators, killing eight people.

headline: 2 Idle Towers May Test the Wind’s Power to Keep a Bit of Brooklyn Moving
text: About two years ago, Debra Salomon was on her way to the new Fairway market in Red Hook, Brooklyn, when she took a wrong turn and found herself on a windblown pier that had two 90-foot Eiffel-like towers rising into the sky for no apparent purpose.

headline: Britain: Adviser Resigns After Remarks on Recession
text: Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday first reproved then effectively dismissed a prominent economic adviser who gave an interview in which he said “the vast majority of people” in Britain “have never had it so good since this recession  this so-called recession  started.” The remarks by Lord David Young, 78, a multimillionaire businessman, were in an interview published on Friday in The Daily Telegraph in which he discussed Britain’s effort to impose 20 percent across-the-board cuts in government spending, its biggest peacetime cuts ever. Lord Young said many Britons had gained from historically low mortgage rates, allowing them to spend more freely on other things, thus buoying the economy through the banking crisis.

headline: Saturday: Grid Art
text: For the third and final day, we have a guest solver picked from our esteemed pool of Wordplay commenters. It’s John Farmer, who’s had 25 puzzles published in The New York Times. He also posts a new puzzle monthly on his Web site.

headline: Hunting for Returns Abroad
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan reports on a growing trend among well-to-do American investors: a hunt for investment returns abroad that they cannot find at home in the wake of the financial crisis and the recession.

headline: Panel on Pick for Schools Has Close Ties to Bloomberg
text: New York State’s top education official on Friday named an advisory panel of eight experts, at least half of them with strong connections to the Bloomberg administration, to help him decide whether to approve Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s controversial choice to run the city’s school system.

headline: The Next Mets Manager: A Handicapper’s Guide
text: In only a matter of days, if not hours, the Mets will make a decision about their next field manager. It has been a race that started with 10 entrants, with 4 of them then separating themselves from the pack. Most people think it’s now down to just two candidates, Terry Collins and Bob Melvin, and that they are heading for a photo finish.

headline: As M.V.P. of the Lee Trade, Knicks’ Turiaf Adds a Spark
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  When the Knicks sent David Lee to the Golden State Warriors in July, they got back one potential star, one injured shooting ace and a big man known mostly for his wild energy and his wild beard.

headline: Deportees Who Came Back Are Caught in Dragnet
text: In a four-day immigration dragnet stretching from the suburbs north of New York City to eastern Long Island, federal law-enforcement officers arrested 54 illegal immigrants with criminal records who had previously been deported but had secretly re-entered the country, officials said Friday.

headline: New Zealand: Explosion Traps Coal Miners
text: At least two dozen men were trapped underground after an explosion on Friday rocked the country’s largest coal mine in a mountainous region on the South Island. The authorities said it was too early to determine a cause of the explosion at the collapsed mine, operated by the Pike River Coal company near the town of Atarau. Before entering the mine, rescue teams were trying to make sure that vents were clear and that gas would not build up inside. Pike River Coal officials said the trapped miners had breathing devices that would last for 30 minutes and that were intended to provide time to get to a longer-lasting source of oxygen.

headline: Madagascar: Army Chief Holds Talks With Dissident Officers
text: The army chief of staff, Andre Ndriarijoana, held talks on Friday with dissident military officers who had tried to take over the government earlier in the week but are now holed up in their barracks. No resolution was announced. In the morning, the government had ordered civilians to evacuate the area near the barracks for their own safety. The island nation’s current president, Andry Rajoelina, was placed in power after a coup in March 2009, and there have since been a handful of efforts to oust him.

headline: The Southwest Way
text: No longer a start-up, Southwest seeks to balance growth and traditions as it approaches its 40th anniversary.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A False Target in Yemen
text: Cairo

headline: Opt-Out Illusion
text: Texas and several other states are flirting with the idea of dropping out of the Medicaid program and trying to shift most of the burden of providing health insurance for the poor to the federal government.

headline: How I Stopped Smoking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Let’s Rescue the Race Debate
text: “There is another class of colored people who make a business of keeping the troubles, the wrongs, and the hardships of the Negro race before the public. ... Some of these people do not want the Negro to lose his grievances, because they do not want to lose their jobs ... There is a certain class of race-problem solvers who don’t want the patient to get well.”

headline: Hiding From Reality
text: However you want to define the American dream, there is not much of it that’s left anymore.

headline: Mr. Paterson and the (Latest) Casino
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York has only a few weeks left in office. But that hasn’t stopped him from making a bad deal with an out-of-state Indian tribe to build a casino in the Catskills.

headline: The Zombie Jamboree
text: Zombies are in. This cannot possibly be a good sign.

headline: Honoring Liu Xiaobo
text: China’s autocrats have tried pretty much everything they can think of to stop the world from celebrating the courage of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned democracy activist. It tried to bully the Nobel committee into not awarding Mr. Liu this year’s Nobel Peace Prize. When the committee went ahead, China confined Mr. Liu’s wife to her home, barred others from attending the ceremony, and warned governments not to go.

headline: Roadblock for Arms Treaty
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Uproar Over Pat-Downs
text: Americans understand the need for security screenings at airports and are remarkably patient. So there is no excuse for the bumbling, arrogant way the Transportation Security Administration has handled questions and complaints about its new body-scanning machines and more aggressive pat-downs.

headline: Subway Signal Inspections Found to Be Falsified
text: Safety workers at New York City Transit falsified thousands of inspections of the track signals that direct trains in the subway system, deeming the signals safe even though those inspections had never taken place, according to an investigation by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Before Moving On, Minaya Would Talk With Alderson
text: Omar Minaya has had several offers since he was let go by the Mets on Oct. 4. But before joining another team he plans to meet with Sandy Alderson, his replacement as the team’s general manager, about the possibility of returning to the Mets.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,383 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

text: Posting will be intermittent at best.
