text: FRONT PAGE

headline: William Self, Television Producer, Dies at 89
text: William Self, a prolific producer who brought a long list of successful shows to television — “Daniel Boone,” “Peyton Place,” “Batman” and “M*A*S*H” among them — transforming 20th Century-Fox Television into a leading supplier of programming to the networks in the 1960s and ’70s, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 89.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.19
text: A look at the day in sports with championships in China, Spain and Madison, Wisc.

headline: Knicks Prevail in a Shootout With the Warriors
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The pace was frantic, the scoring incessant, the defense nonexistent. The shots flew and the scoreboard whirred, stopping only briefly when the ball became stuck on top of the shot clock. Even that was entertaining.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Veronica Harris
text: Veronica Harris fell behind on her rent because she lost her job. The Neediest Cases Fund helped her pay off her arrears.

headline: NATO Sees Long-Term Role After Afghan Combat
text: LISBON  NATO and Afghanistan agreed Saturday to the goal of a phased transfer of security responsibility to the Afghan government by the end of 2014, but NATO officials acknowledged that allied forces would remain in Afghanistan, at least in a support role, well beyond that date.

headline: The Weekend Word: Pushing for a New Start
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Classic Ad: General Motors, the Day After
text: Two cars race across an arid plain, hurling clouds of desert dust. A Casio keyboard goes silent as in tandem the drivers shift to neutral. The older car slows, then crawls to a stop; its driver emerges, still helmeted, and watches the newer model glide into the ashen distance.

headline: Playing on Thanksgiving, and Skipping the Turkey
text: Thanksgiving is one of my favorite holidays. Most families enjoy turkey, stuffing, mashed potatoes and the works. But my favorite part is all of the sides, like green bean casserole, broccoli casserole, collard greens and my mom’s famous chocolate chip cookies.

headline: How Yankee Stadium Got Ready for Football
text: So what will football in the new Yankee Stadium look like when Army and Notre Dame take the field tonight? The Fighting Irish and the Black Knights will be moving the ball from home plate to center field and back.

headline: Ride, Bernanke, Ride
text: In a speech Friday, Ben Bernanke asked for some help in the form of expansionary fiscal policy:

headline: Pope Elevates Cardinals in Festive Ceremony
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI elevated 24 new cardinals in a festive ceremony in St. Peter’s Basilica on Saturday, bestowing quadrangular red hats on the new members of a group that will one day elect his successor.

headline: A Forecast That Obama Could Love
text: THINGS are looking up for Barack Obama.

headline: Lottery Deal Bid Process Is Attacked
text: Citing performance problems and a perceived conflict of interest, critics blasted a decision announced Friday by the Texas Lottery Commission to renew a 10-year operations contract with the Gtech Corporation, the primary vendor for the state’s lottery since its 1992 inception.

headline: The Pain of Change at Boeing
text: ONCE upon a time, major American companies and their employees treated each other as family. The companies provided job security and lifelong benefits; in general, workers were loyal and engaged in their jobs, the occasional strike notwithstanding.

headline: Acrostic Made in a Blender
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Second Sunday puzzles don’t get enough respect, or at least enough attention. Acrostics, in particular, deserve a wider audience. Many regular crossword solvers I know regularly cross over to the next page when the Second Sunday puzzle appears. Maybe this incentive will help: the skills you hone on these puzzles will make you a better solver on the straight puzzles too. I know, I’m not talking about you or that throng whose biggest regret in life is that acrostics arrive but once a fortnight, but if you have a friend who could benefit from some congenial prodding, this is a good one to try. For one thing, it’s all about food, and you don’t have to be an EPICURE or a legendary chef like ESCOFFIER to appreciate that. Be sure to remind your friend that the puzzle is way easier if you do it on the computer.

headline: A Hint for the Final Passage
text: For the first time, Jim Sanborn, the creator of “Kryptos,” releases clues for the final section of the 865-character coded message in the sculpture.

headline: When Unemployment Hits, and Lingers
text: Joblessness in New York is not a recent phenomenon. Since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the city has been shedding jobs. But as recently as two years ago, the city’s jobless rate was 5.8 percent; it is now 9.3 percent, down from 10.6 percent in January.

headline: Zambia Uneasily Balances Chinese Investment and Workers’ Resentment
text: NKANDABBWE, Zambia  Hundreds of angry coal miners pushed toward the locked gate at Shaft 3, shouting and cursing as they neared the mine’s Chinese managers, who understood neither the English nor the Tonga words of the mob. As the workers butted up against the fence, the bosses grew more fearful and finally two fired their shotguns.

headline: Trying to Put a Price on Bank Errors
text: KUDOS to the Congressional Oversight Panel for publishing a thoughtful and thorough report last week on the mortgage documentation mess. It argued that, yes, in fact, these paperwork problems may have significant implications for banks, investors and the stability of the financial system.

headline: For an Online Marketplace, It’s Better Late Than Never
text: BACK in the deranged days of dot-com mania, a company called Ariba could do no wrong.

headline: Notepads That Keep You on the Same Page
text: THREE-BY-FIVE index cards, those hallmarks of research, may be fading away in these digital times, but the need to take notes endures.

headline: Irish Prime Minister Says Budget Plans Are Already in Place
text: ARRANMORE ISLAND — As Irish and European officials engaged in tense talks over the weekend on terms of a multibillion dollar rescue package, Ireland’s Prime Minister Brian Cowen asserted that the country’s low corporate tax rate and four-year plan to reduce the budget would not be substantially changed.

headline: Can QVC Translate Its Pitch Online?
text: WEST CHESTER, Pa.

headline: Can You Handle the 100-Day To-Do List?
text: This interview with Geoff Vuleta, C.E.O. of Fahrenheit 212, an innovation consulting firm in Manhattan, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Blur Between Spending and Taxes
text: SHOULD the government cut spending or raise taxes to deal with its long-term fiscal imbalance? As President Obama’s deficit commission rolls out its final report in the coming weeks, this issue will most likely divide the political right and left. But, in many ways, the question is the wrong one. The distinction between spending and taxation is often murky and sometimes meaningless.

text: Q.  You would like to find temporary work over the holidays. Where should you look?

headline: Leading From an Early Age
text: MY parents divorced when I was a toddler and too young to remember us living together. Alternating between them actually created dual privileges for me.

headline: Pushing 40, Southwest Is Still Playing the Rebel
text: Dallas

headline: Fast Times at Woodside High
text: A shift is taking place at the intersection of education and technology.

headline: Happily Adding to a Résumé of Eclectic Jobs
text: When the rest of us go to bed, Veronica Harris goes to work.

headline: For Musial, a Birthday and a Medal
text: Happy birthday, Stan Musial.

headline: A Stack of Bills, and No Paycheck or Savings
text: For Carol Ann Fuoco, 58, things are not the way they used to be.

headline: After a Landlord Dispute, Finding a New Home
text: Last June, Zaida Paris-Mendez was at the beauty salon when a neighbor called to tell her that people were moving things out of her apartment.

headline: In N.F.L., Expecting More Surprise Onside Kicks
text: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton called for an onside kick to open the second half of the Super Bowl in February. It caught the Indianapolis Colts off guard, changed the momentum of the game and stunned the football world.

headline: Students and Technology, Constant Companions
text: Students from Woodside High discuss their relationship to technology.

headline: Fear of Failure, and Mother, Motivated Falcons’ Star Receiver
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Five games into the 2006 season, Joenethia White answered the phone at her home in James Island, S.C., and heard the shamed voice of her son, Roddy.

headline: Nascar Has the Finish, if Not the TV Viewers
text: Trash talk, some petulant whining and a points race unlike anything Nascar has seen in years has given the sport exactly what it desperately needs heading into the final race of the 2010 season. There will be drama on Sunday at Homestead-Miami Speedway, with three drivers in contention for the championship and a realistic chance for somebody other than Jimmie Johnson to win the Chase for the Sprint Cup title.

headline: Umenyiora Resumes a Dominant Role
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The boldest statement that Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora has made all season can be read on the towel that hangs from his waistband at practices: “Greatness.”

headline: Father of Texans’ Cushing Stands Fast in Son’s Defense
text: Brian Cushing will play football Sunday at the Meadowlands, and his parents, Frank and Antoinette, plan to drive 20 minutes or so from their home in Park Ridge, N.J., to watch. They will sit with relatives of one of Cushing’s college teammates, Mark Sanchez.

headline: Study Suggests a Cholesterol Pill Benefits Kidney Patients
text: Patients with chronic kidney disease who took Vytorin, a cholesterol-lowering pill, had one-sixth fewer heart attacks, strokes or operations to unblock their arteries than patients taking a placebo, according to the results of a new study presented on Saturday.

headline: Original Decoding Charts for ‘Kryptos’
text: “Kryptos,” a sculpture on the grounds of the Central Intelligence Agency, has a secret code embedded in the letters that are punched into its four panels of curving copper. As the accompanying article points out, only three of its four messages have been deciphered.

headline: T.S.A. Grants Airline Pilots an Exception to Screenings
text: WASHINGTON  At least one group of air travelers will get a break from the body scans and pat-downs that have provoked a national outcry.

headline: Two Illinois Teams, but Wrigley Takes Sides
text: CHICAGO — The streets around Wrigley Field began to fill up Saturday afternoon with fans clad in Northwestern purple and Illinois orange. Inside, orange yardage markers were laid along the sidelines closest to the first-base line and deep into the right-field corner, where pads had been hung on the wall.

headline: Clues to Stubborn Secret in C.I.A.’s Backyard
text: It is perhaps one of the C.I.A.’s most mischievous secrets.

headline: In Wake of Losses, New Powers for a Political Master
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats engineered a leadership change in response to the election devastation, but the shakeup did not come in the House, where Nancy Pelosi held on to power in her caucus despite having lost more than 60 seats, the Democratic majority and the speaker’s gavel.

headline: Fighting Words
text: The House ethics committee recommended last week that Representative Charles B. Rangel be formally censured for ethical misconduct.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: A History of Dealing With Football’s Dangers
text: Months before the 1910 football season, a major series of rule changes defined the modern game. They established 15-minute quarters and allowed for substitutions. To address violence, they banned pushing and pulling, and the flying, or diving, tackle. To eliminate the deadly mass plays that hid brutalities from view, like rugby-type scrums that pushed the ball carrier forward, the rules required seven men on the line of scrimmage.

headline: Chuck Bednarik’s Hit on Frank Gifford Still Echoes
text: It’s an anniversary that Frank Gifford does not celebrate. Fifty years ago this weekend, as the Giants’ All-Pro running back, he lay crumpled at Yankee Stadium after having fumbled away a pass reception when blindsided by Eagles linebacker Chuck Bednarik late in a 17-10 loss. Unconscious, Gifford was carried off the field on a stretcher and examined. Wrapped in blankets with an ice-cold compress above his closed eyes, he was soon rolled on a gurney to an ambulance that hurried him to St. Elizabeth’s Hospital.

headline: Germany Seeks Suspects in Terrorist Plots
text: BERLIN  German law enforcement officials said on Saturday that they were looking for two suspected terrorists thought to be in or around the capital city in one of several investigations aimed at thwarting what the authorities believe are myriad plans by Islamic radicals to attack the nation.

headline: Cholera’s Second Fever: An Urge to Blame
text: If United Nations peacekeepers from Nepal are going to be blamed for bringing cholera to Haiti, it’s important to remember that the blame game for pandemics eventually involves everyone.

headline: Man Killed in Wrong-Way Crash on Major Deegan Expressway
text: A 42-year-old New Jersey man was killed early Saturday when a vehicle driven by a drunken driver going the wrong way on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx slammed into his car, the police said.

headline: Jeter Talks Shadowed by Yankees’ 2000 About-Face
text: Hardly an off-season goes by that the Yankees do not agree to a long-term contract with a star or two. It has been that way for some time now, although the winter of 2006 was something of an exception.

headline: Study Suggests a Cholesterol Pill Benefits Patients With Kidney Disease
text: Patients with chronic kidney disease who took Vytorin, a cholesterol-lowering pill, had one-sixth fewer heart attacks, strokes or operations to unblock their arteries than patients taking a placebo, according to the results of a study presented on Saturday.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Pursue Broad Insider Trading Inquiry
text: Federal authorities are at an advanced stage of insider trading investigations that could result in criminal charges or significant civil fines against Wall Street traders and executives, a government official said Saturday.

headline: The Pilgrims Were ... Socialists?
text: Ah, Thanksgiving. A celebration regardless of creed; a time for all Americans to come together after a divisive election year.

headline: Realclimate on the Climate Hack
text: Gavin Schmidt, the NASA climatologist and indefatigable curator of the Realclimate.org blog (photographed above by Keith Myers of The New York Times), has weighed in on the year of attacks, defense and reappraisal that he and dozens of other climate researchers experienced following the unauthorized release of folders containing hundreds of their e-mail exchanges and files last November.

headline: Fired Referee to Press Favoritism Allegation Against Campbell
text: A case that got Colin Campbell in trouble for vitriolic e-mails just will not go away.

headline: William and Kate: A Fairy Tale, Ending Unknown
text: LONDON — A girl meets a prince. The prince needs a wife. The glass slipper fits: she is young, dewy, inexperienced, eager — swept up and blinded by the romance of it all. He proposes within months. Their wedding is watched by 750 million people worldwide and features at least five clergymen, 3,500 guests and one spectacularly frothy pearl-encrusted wedding dress whose 25-foot train has to be stuffed into the bridal carriage, where it threatens to suffocate the bride.

headline: The Democrats’ Treaty Slump
text: WASHINGTON — To Walter B. Slocombe, there was something hauntingly familiar about the political sinkhole President Obama found himself in last week.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Prime Number
text: 261: The number of members of Congress who were millionaires last year, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, which analyzed Congressional financial disclosure reports. The number is a slight increase over 2008. Of those 261 millionaires, 55 were worth $10 million or more, and 8 were worth at least $100 million. Median wealth for all 535 members of Congress reached $911,000, up from $785,000 in 2008. Rules don’t require members to report certain assets, including their homes.

headline: My Florida Recount Memory
text: Ten years ago this month, all eyes were on Florida as lawyers, election officials and campaign workers bickered over the hanging chads and dimpled ballots, the suits and countersuits, that would determine whether the next president would be Al Gore or George W. Bush. The Op-Ed editors asked some of the people at the center of the recount to share their reminiscences.

headline: The Louvre Takes Its Tin Cup Out
text: Paris may have a claim on being the art capital of the world, but one of its most hallowed cultural institutions, the Louvre, has gone to the French public with its hat in hand. According to Agence France-Presse, the museum is asking the public to contribute money to help buy “The Three Grâces,” an exceptionally well-conserved 1531 work by the German painter Lucas Cranach the Elder.

headline: Beasley Is Proving to Be a Find for Timberwolves
text: In putting together three superstars, the Miami Heat may have discarded one.

headline: Why America Chases an Israeli-Palestinian Peace
text: JERUSALEM — Lt. Gen. Keith W. Dayton, who left Israel last month after overseeing the training of Palestinian security forces for five years, liked to tell the story of his first assignment in the Middle East. Charged with locating Iraq’s elusive weapons of mass destruction after Saddam Hussein was deposed in 2003, General Dayton found no weapons but kept coming upon something else inside Iraqi military barracks — drawings of Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem being squeezed by a serpent labeled Israel.

headline: How an Old Writer Learned a New Trick About Stats
text: With everyone from schoolchildren to retirees, laymen to scholars, seemingly doing a blog, it was a few months ago that my son and I thought we could provide interesting baseball perspectives writing from the same site  he being the professional ballplayer David Newhan, and I having written about baseball for almost 50 years, starting in 1961 when the expansion Los Angeles Angels joined the American League.

headline: A Quiet Man’s Arrival
text: Charleston Harbor, Nov. 21, 1860

headline: In Rare Cases, Pope Justifies Use of Condoms
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI has said that condom use can be justified in some cases to help stop the spread of AIDS, the Vatican’s first exception to a long-held policy banning contraceptives. The pope made the statement in interviews on a host of contentious issues with a German journalist, part of an unusual effort to address some of the harshest criticisms of his turbulent papacy.

headline: From Violin to Skateboard
text: At 42, Tony Hawk remains an icon to skateboarders one-quarter his age. He was widely regarded as the world’s best by the time he was a teenager, and has spent most of the past two decades building his name into the sport’s biggest brand, including video games, a skate company (Birdhouse Skateboards), a clothing line, even roller coasters. Hawk, a father of four, played himself on “The Simpsons” and skateboarded last year in the White House. Hawk, who lives near San Diego, was in New York recently to discuss his second book, “How Did I Get Here? The Ascent of an Unlikely CEO,” and “Tony Hawk Shred,” the latest in a billion-dollar line of video games.

headline: The Hunt for Jobs Sends the Irish Abroad, Again
text: DUBLIN  Antoinette Shields had a plan to keep her tall, blue-eyed son, Kevin, close at hand. When she took over her boss’s construction company in 2002, she hoped to retire at 55 and give her son the business.

headline: How Twitter Users Balanced the Budget
text: Here are the budget preferences of 6,989 Twitter users who posted solutions to our deficit puzzle.

headline: How Readers Chose to Fix the Deficit
text: Reduce the size of the military rather than reduce pay for noncombat members of the military. Impose a millionaire’s tax rather than cut deductions for high-income households. Cap the growth of Medicare spending rather than raise the eligibility age.

headline: Consumer Risks Feared as Health Law Spurs Mergers
text: WASHINGTON  When Congress passed the health care law, it envisioned doctors and hospitals joining forces, coordinating care and holding down costs, with the prospect of earning government bonuses for controlling costs.

headline: On TV, an Afghan Unit Tackles the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  They break up child suicide-bomber rings, take down drug lords and government ministers (even when they are the same thing) and kick in doors to rescue kidnapped diplomats  all with little or no help from the Americans and NATO.

headline: A Killing Set Honor Above Love
text: DOKAN, Iraq  Serving small glasses of sugary tea, Qadir Abdul-Rahman Ahmed explained how things went bad with the neighbors. It was not true, he said, that his brothers had threatened to drown his niece if she tried to marry the young man down the street.

headline: Storm Upon Storm for South Dakota
text: VIVIAN, S.D.  The storm slammed into this dusty prairie town with the clatter of falling bricks. Hail shattered windows, punched holes in roofs and mangled cars. The clumps of ice were left to melt, but one, an unusual spiked orb the size of a cantaloupe, was preserved in the freezer of an old ranch hand.

headline: Sunday: Having Aspirations
text: Clive Probert’s debut and sophomore puzzles ran several months ago in The Times. Both were daily puzzles, but apparently he had higher aspirations, some of which spilled over into today’s theme. He’s taken six common phrases and added an aspirate, or H sound, to one word in each. Real men don’t eat quiche and, according to Mr. Probert, they don’t heat it either.

headline: In Death, Burns Is Again a Top Twitter Topic
text: Pat Burns, who coached the Devils to the 2003 Stanley Cup and was a three-time N.H.L. coach of the year, died Friday. He succumbed to lung cancer two months after his death was erroneously reported the morning of Sept. 17, the word spreading widely by Twitter.

headline: Could She Reach the Top in 2012? You Betcha
text: “THE perception I had, anyway, was that we were on top of the world,” Sarah Palin said at the climax of last Sunday’s premiere of her new television series, “Sarah Palin’s Alaska.” At that point our fearless heroine had just completed a perilous rock climb, and if she looked as if she’d just stepped out of a spa instead, don’t expect her fans to question the reality. For them, Palin’s perception is the only reality that counts.

headline: Nuking the White House
text: WASHINGTON

headline: When Donations Go Astray
text: This holiday season, Americans will dig into their pockets for good causes. But these gifts will sometimes benefit charlatans or extremists, or simply be wasted.

headline: Now, for Some Leadership
text: If Congress fails to rein in the deficit, it will be because of a lack of political courage — not any shortage of ideas out there on how to get the job done.

headline: Russia’s Dictatorship of Law
text: Russia’s newly outrageous legal treatment of Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the former owner of the country’s largest oil company, is a reminder that Russia has yet to grasp the idea of equal justice under law  especially when the Kremlin decides someone is in the way.

headline: The Lesson From Mr. Rangel
text: It was painful watching Representative Charles Rangel face censure in the House last week. But the wounds were self-inflicted. The evidence proved that Mr. Rangel, a New York City Democrat, repeatedly and arrogantly cut ethical corners, solicited favors and failed to pay his taxes. He still might have skated if he hadn’t made a show of proclaiming innocence and demanding an investigation, finally rousing the usually somnolent ethics committee.

headline: Sweat | Bulging Biceps and Fractured Limbs
text: Every Thursday night at a single-family house in Bellerose, Queens, they file in the side door and down the stairs, men with ham-hock forearms, and a few sturdy women, too. They duck into a cramped basement room and gather around padded platforms equipped with handles for waging hand-to-hand combat.

headline: Lost Boys of Sudan Fill in the Blanks of Their Past
text: PHOENIX  It has been 10 years since Malek Deng and thousands of other young men known as the Lost Boys of Sudan left war behind for new lives in the United States. But a new digital archive of their refugee records is taking Mr. Deng and the others back to the harrowing days of their youth.

headline: Teaching for America
text: When I came to Washington in 1988, the cold war was ending and the hot beat was national security and the State Department. If I were a cub reporter today, I’d still want to be covering the epicenter of national security  but that would be the Education Department. President Obama got this one exactly right when he said that whoever “out-educates us today is going to out-compete us tomorrow.” The bad news is that for years now we’ve been getting out-educated. The good news is that cities, states and the federal government are all fighting back. But have no illusions. We’re in a hole.

headline: Take a Closer Look
text: Starting in 2012, cigarette packages and advertisements will have to carry new warning labels that pound home the message that smoking sickens and kills. The message isn’t new, but it will be presented in a bigger, starker format  including images of tobacco’s devastating effects  that should be harder to ignore than the tiny, text-only warning labels that have lost their punch.

headline: A Proposal to Reform Social Security
text: To the Editor:

headline: Security and Privacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Taxi Design
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Court for Veterans: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
text: To the Editor:

headline: Illini Find the Way at Wrigley
text: CHICAGO  When Illinois defensive end Clay Nurse forced a fumble by Northwestern quarterback Evan Watkins early in the first quarter at Wrigley Field on Saturday, his Illinois teammates looked momentarily confused.

headline: Romney, Weighing Run, Leans on State PACs
text: The fact that Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who is weighing a run for president in 2012, has an active political action committee in Alabama might seem puzzling.

headline: What We Must Do for Iraq Now
text: Washington

headline: Kickoff Return by a Tenacious Senior Sends Harvard Over Yale
text: BOSTON — Marco Iannuzzi, a 24-year-old senior wide receiver at Harvard with a wife and a 2-year-old daughter, broke his collarbone six weeks ago for the second time in his college career and was cleared to play against Yale only on Thursday.

headline: Colorado Scoring Tandem Takes Third Run at Dallas Defensive Duo
text: TORONTO  The tandem of Conor Casey and Omar Cummings was the most productive in Major League Soccer this season. The Colorado Rapids strikers combined for 27 goals  the most by two players in team history  and their partnership is peaking with a championship at stake here Sunday in the M.L.S. Cup.

headline: Messier Has Mixed Results in Pro Coaching Debut
text: The education of Mark Messier continues.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 21
text: As President Obama and other world leaders wrap up the NATO weekend summit meeting, White House officials fan out on the talk shows to discuss the coalition’s strategy in the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Exhausting String of Storms in South Dakota
text: South Dakota is nearing the end of an unusually punishing year of weather.

headline: Richard’s Glove, Kate’s Hand
text: Sandwich, England

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: North Koreans Unveil New Plant for Nuclear Use
text: WASHINGTON — North Korea showed a visiting American nuclear scientist earlier this month a vast new facility it secretly and rapidly built to enrich uranium, confronting the Obama administration with the prospect that the country is preparing to expand its nuclear arsenal or build a far more powerful type of atomic bomb.

headline: If the Game Is Not a Sport, It Certainly Can Be a Workout
text: The idea that chess is a sport seems to be gaining wider acceptance.

headline: Dining Out on Different Budgets
text: Views from readers, responses from the staff and thoughts from Arthur S. Brisbane, the public editor.

headline: Religious Donations Going Awry
text: My Sunday column is about charitable contributions, particularly by Christians, Jews and Muslims, that are well-intentioned but poorly thought out — and thus not nearly as effective as they might be. This is of course also a problem with secular contributions, but we’re entering a season for religious giving and I think this is a particular problem for religious charities because of a false assumption that a charity that shares one’s faith also shares one’s values and bona fides.

headline: Vows: Jason & Meredith
text: Jason and Meredith became fast friends as soon as Meredith boarded the school bus in fourth grade. Years later, their friendship turned into a romance that they were determined to keep alive.

headline: A Border Fact of Life: High-Speed Chases
text: On a quiet November morning, Trooper Johnny Hernandez patrolled the dusty back roads along the Rio Grande in Hidalgo County. In the back seat, his M4 rifle sat within arm’s reach. In the trunk, he stored a bulletproof vest.

headline: Will She or Won’t She? Hutchison Keeps Them Guessing
text: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column

headline: With Words on Paper, Independent Defies Trend
text: The threat came in 2002. Borders, the chain retailer of books and music, had announced plans to open a store a couple hundred feet from Austin’s largest independent book seller, BookPeople, but Steve Bercu, the chief executive, was not going down without a fight.

headline: With Oden Out, Roy Is Also Concern for Blazers
text: Most of the news coming out of Portland last week centered on another knee operation for the former No. 1 pick Greg Oden that will keep him out for the entire season. But more troublesome for the Blazers might be the knees of guard Brandon Roy.

headline: A Dilemma for Schools Seeking to Reform
text: On the eve of a Board of Education meeting in February where the death knell was to sound for five schools, Ron Huberman, the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools, granted an 11th-hour reprieve.

headline: In a Parallel Universe, Campaign Candor
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

headline: As Election Nears, Time to Remake That Sow’s Ear
text: John Quinn’s campaign Web site promotes how he is prepared to be the next alderman of the 41st Ward because of the 14 years he spent as a city employee, an experience that taught him “to navigate the intricate systems that make up city government.”

headline: A Soul Singer’s Life of Highs and Lows Soars Anew
text: Andre Williams sat drinking coffee in his usual corner booth at Roy’s Soul Food one morning last week. Despite the early hour, he was decked out in a black broad-brimmed hat, red satin shirt, cobalt-blue blazer, black slacks and two-toned leather shoes with spats.

headline: Bills Mount for Travel by Trustees of Pensions
text: Grappling with a $919 million shortfall and looming insolvency, six of nine trustees overseeing San Mateo County’s pension system needed an oracle. So they decamped to Honolulu last week for a conference that cost the retirement plan an estimated $23,570.

headline: City Wants America’s Cup, but Analyst Warns About Costs
text: For at least 43 days, Mayor Gavin Newsom proposes to turn San Francisco Bay into an arena for the America’s Cup, the world’s most prestigious yacht race. The water would be cleared of unauthorized boats and a no-fly zone imposed 6,000 feet above the Golden Gate Bridge, Fisherman’s Wharf and Angel Island.

headline: Love for Wynne in Toronto, Bitterness to Greet Cunningham
text: TORONTO – Fans of the local Major League Soccer club, Toronto F.C., have been some of the most enthusiastic supporters in North America, despite the underwhelming performance of the team.

headline: Internet Giants Foster, and Threaten, Innovation Economy
text: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

headline: Philippe Starck Streetlamps
text: Ten iron and aluminum columns with glass cyclopean eyes stand sentinel on Howard Street between Third and Fourth Streets, intersecting the Moscone Center in the South of Market district. At night, the lamps’ faces blaze with light as the necks swivel down, morphing into Parisian-style streetlights.

headline: Lottery Numbers
On the Set of “Eagle Four”
text: “Eagle Four” is a popular new police show on Afghanistan’s Tolo TV.

headline: Tantalizing Talent Is Stuck on the Bench
text: The search for Anthony Randolph and his ever-tantalizing talents led to a familiar resting spot: to the sideline at Oracle Arena in Oakland, Calif., to a row of seats lining the court, to the end of a crowded bench, lost but not forgotten.

headline: Gawker Ordered to Remove Palin Book Excerpts
text: When Sarah Palin found out that some Web sites had posted excerpts from advance copies of her new book, she took her lament to Twitter.

headline: Gawker Ordered to Remove Palin Book Excerpts
text: HarperCollins, publisher of “America by Heart,” is vigilantly protecting the book’s contents until it comes out on Tuesday. Read more on Media Decoder …

headline: Notre Dame Stages a Revival at Yankee Stadium
text: The black-and-white photographs of the illustrious rivalry between Notre Dame and Army came alive Saturday night in the Bronx.

headline: A Homecoming for a Few Rangers, and a Milestone for Their Coach
text: ST. PAUL.  The Rangers visit the State of Hockey only once every two years, so their 5-2 victory at the Xcel Center on Saturday was a treat.

headline: Qaeda Branch Aimed for Broad Damage at Low Cost
text: In a detailed account of its failed parcel bomb plot last month, Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen said late Saturday that the operation cost only $4,200 to mount, was intended to disrupt global air cargo systems and reflected a new strategy of low-cost attacks designed to inflict broad economic damage.

headline: Football at Yankee Stadium
text: The first football game at the new Yankee Stadium, and the first Army-Notre Dame game in the Bronx since 1969.

headline: In Knockout, Martinez Keeps Belt and Raises Profile
text: ATLANTIC CITY  The punch that floored Paul Williams, that landed square on his jaw and knocked him cold and momentarily appeared to knock him out, came in the second round on Saturday at the Boardwalk Hall. It came from the left hand of Sergio Martinez, courtesy of a short, quick, devastating left hook.

headline: Achieving a Healthful Digital Diet
text: Think of the Internet and other digital technology as food. Limit the intake of empty digital calories, and do not consume too much over all.

headline: Growing Up Digital, Wired for Distraction
text: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — On the eve of a pivotal academic year in Vishal Singh’s life, he faces a stark choice on his bedroom desk: book or computer?

headline: Giving Robots the Heavy Lifting
text: Jobs like stacking heavy boxes or fixing power lines can be dangerous, so why not give some of that work to robots?

headline: Blake Griffin Dazzles, but Knicks Beat Clippers
text: LOS ANGELES — One man stood between the Knicks and a successful trip Saturday night, though in truth Blake Griffin was not really standing or spending much time with his feet on the ground at all.

headline: FDR, Reagan, and Obama
text: Some readers may recall that back during the Democratic primary Barack Obama shocked many progressives by praising Ronald Reagan as someone who brought America a “sense of dynamism and entrepreneurship that had been missing.” I was among those who found this deeply troubling — because the idea that Reagan brought a transfomation in American dynamism is a right-wing myth, not borne out by the facts. (There was a surge in productivity and innovation — but it happened in the 90s, under Clinton, not under Reagan).

headline: At Berlin Museum, Reindeer, Art and Overnight Stays
text: One bed. Twelve live reindeer. Twenty-four canaries, eight mice, and two flies. Lots of Andy Warhol. Plenty of Joseph Beuys.

headline: After Months of Resisting, Ireland Applies for Bailout
text: DUBLIN — Ireland has formally applied for a rescue package worth more than $100 billion, after months of trying to survive its financial crisis with austerity measures and strict budgetary planning. The much-anticipated step gave a lift Monday to global stocks as well as the euro.

headline: Where A.T.M. Fees for Noncustomers Are Highest
text: Travelers to Seattle and certain other cities may want to make every effort to find and use their own bank’s A.T.M. Why? Banks in Seattle  and certain other cities on average charge noncustomers higher A.T.M. fees than the national average, according to a recently released Bankrate.com survey covered more generally in a recent Bucks post.

headline: How Do You Stop Michael Vick?
text: The Giants-Eagles matchup Sunday night has the feel of something pivotal for the N.F.C.

headline: U.S. Pursues Broad Insider Trading Inquiry
text: Federal authorities are at an advanced stage of insider trading investigations that could result in criminal charges or significant civil fines against Wall Street traders and executives, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports, citing a government official.

headline: Ireland to Pursue a Bailout
text: The Irish finance minister, Brian Lenihan, confirmed on Sunday that Ireland had formally applied to Europe and the International Monetary Fund for a bailout package, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. reports.

headline: How Is Technology Affecting Teaching and Learning?
text: Today’s installment of the Your Brain on Computers series is the article “Growing Up Digital, Wired for Distraction,” which looks at the challenges that technology presents for teaching and learning.

headline: In the Footsteps of the Museum’s Gorillas
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Air Force Slip Complicates Tanker Bids
text: The Air Force has made another potentially serious mistake in its effort to buy $35 billion of aerial tankers, by accidentally sending each bidder sensitive data about the other’s proposal, Pentagon officials said Saturday.

headline: DiCaprio Urges Apple to Aid Wild Tigers
text: Nov. 22, 11:45 p.m. | Updated Leonardo DiCaprio is donating $1 million to anti-poaching programs organized through the World Wildlife Fund, according to the group. There’s more in The Times on the allure of big cats, even as their numbers dwindle.

headline: Caught on Tape, a Snippet of Afghan Voting Fraud
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  On the audiotape, two men are heard speaking in Dari, with the distinct accent of the western city of Herat, as they negotiate terms for rigging more than a dozen races in Afghan’s parliamentary elections.

headline: From Some Teachers, Excitement About Classroom Tech
text: Megan Taber, a teacher at Culbreth Middle School in Chapel Hill, N.C., was taken by the instant gratification. She leads her students through a writing exercise at the beginning of each class, as they respond to a question she writes on a blackboard. In the past, they used notebooks that she would collect periodically. Then her school began using iPod Touches in class. Ms. Taber changed the routine so that the students submit their writing directly to a spreadsheet on her computer over a wireless network. She now responds to the work within minutes instead of weeks.

headline: A Movie Critic Loses Her Screening Privileges (But Gets ‘Em Back)
text: LOS ANGELES — Was it something I said?

headline: Jets 30, Texans 27, Final
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets are difficult to figure. After  two ragged overtime wins in two weeks, the Jets’ only consistency was their inconsistency. They showed explosiveness on offense, then sputtered. They looked stifling on defense, then struggled.

headline: Arms Bid Seen in New N. Korea Plant
text: American defense officials said Sunday that the revelation of North Korea’s new uranium enrichment facility confirmed longstanding suspicions that the country was seeking a second route to build atomic weapons. They dismissed the North’s claim that it was simply trying to build nuclear power plants denied to them by the West.

headline: Obama Considers Speech to Business Group
text: The White House and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are continuing their rapprochement by considering a speech by President Obama to the business group.

headline: Thousands Mourn Victims of High-Rise Blaze
text: SHANGHAI  More than 10,000 people gathered here on Sunday to mourn the victims of last week’s high-rise apartment fire that killed 58 people and injured about 70 others, exposing potential safety hazards in this city’s breakneck building boom.

headline: Spain’s Prisa Turns to a SPAC for Help
text: Struggling under 4.8 billion euros in debt, Prisa, the largest media company in Spain, is hoping shareholders will support a plan to return it to financial health this week by approving a shift from family ownership to control by a group of financiers, hedge funds and investment banks, Raphael Minder of The New York Times reports.

headline: Tax Filings Show Struggles for Guggenheim
text: The last two years haven’t been easy on New York museums, but they’ve been particularly challenging for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. In a disastrous 2008, the museum’s net assets declined by 25 percent.

headline: In the Footsteps of the Natural History Museum’s Gorillas
text: On the City Room blog, Shane Dixon Kavanaugh writes about a curator at the American Museum of Natural History who will travel to Africa for three weeks to try to find the exact site used to create one of that museum’s most well-known dioramas.

headline: Palestinian Leader Insists on Halt to Settlements
text: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Sunday that any American proposal for restarting Israeli-Palestinian negotiations must include East Jerusalem as part of a complete halt in Israeli settlement building.

headline: Wanderer in Bewitching, Fractious Land
text: Riven with violence and haunted by the dead and the missing, “Between Two Worlds” is a hallucinatory experience. The worlds in question could be a number of things — heaven and hell, peace and war, past and present; but in a film this vivid and this oblique, the cumulative thrust of the images is what pulls us through.

headline: Biden: What We Must Do for Iraq Now
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has contributed an op-ed for the Times in which he writes, “we are not disengaging from Iraq — rather, the nature of our engagement is changing from a military to a civilian lead.”

headline: Beyond Understanding
text: I ought to have known better than to have lunch with a psychologist.

headline: ‘Harry Potter’ Has $330 Million Debut Weekend
text: LOS ANGELES  The seventh Harry Potter movie opened to a jaw-dropping $330 million in global ticket sales over the weekend, underscoring the magical powers of the Warner Brothers marketing and distribution departments.

headline: Soccer’s Sparkle Missing From M.L.S. Cup
text: TORONTO — Is it bad luck, a conspiracy theory or just the sort of obstacles M.L.S. will have to overcome if it is to become a relevant part of the sport and the American sporting landscape?

headline: Counseling Women on Self-Respect Amid Tunes of Punky Rage
text: “I got dressed up for you,” a bubbly Kate Nash told her fans at Terminal 5 on Friday night, preening a little in a tight sequined outfit. But a few songs later she announced that she had an unspecified (and unseen) “wardrobe malfunction,” and shortly after that she disappeared offstage for a clearly unscheduled costume change, returning in a striped, oversize outfit.

headline: 104 Degrees of Spirited Dancing
text: Fans of New Chamber Ballet might use the word “intimate” to describe the company’s salon-inspired performances, which are held regularly at City Center Studios. But after a long evening watching choreography with no theatrical lighting in close quarters, a different word came to mind: “exposed.”

headline: Surprises From Someone Fans Thought They Knew
text: Glenn Branca’s sound comes in two parts: the thing itself — notes and chords and beats — and the effect.

headline: When Crowd Has Power of the Purse
text: If you had $10,000 to burn, which choreographer would you choose to support? This is the premise of “The A.W.A.R.D. Show!,” though the title doesn’t refer to the cash prize but is instead a rather torturous acronym: Artists With Audiences Responding to Dance. I’m not sure I know what that means, but it sounds ominous.

headline: In Family Court, a Reckoning for Gibson’s Career
text: LOS ANGELES  A family law judge here will soon decide how much time Mel Gibson will get to spend with his year-old daughter with the model-entertainer Oksana Grigorieva and how much money he should pay for the child’s support.

headline: Keeping Torch Songs Ablaze
text: Talk about wacky. When Andrea Marcovicci was 5, she recalls, her mother, Helen, a nightclub singer now in her 90s and still active, taught her to sing “The Man I Love.” In the Marcovicci home “Stormy Weather” was sung as a lullaby.

headline: Lawrence: Fresh Look at Warrior of Desert
text: Michael Korda’s long, sometimes secondhand but finally satisfying book about T. E. Lawrence starts in a strange way. He opens “Hero” in 1917, when Lawrence, an Englishman leading an Arab guerrilla force and using military tactics that proved to have enduring impact, devises the bold strategic move of attacking the port city of Aqaba, on the Red Sea, by approaching it from an unexpected direction. In the monumental film biography of Lawrence that Mr. Korda does his best not to mention, this is the very famous “Aqaba  from the land!” moment.

headline: Collins Is Mets’ Choice for Manager
text: 7:48 p.m. | Updated The Mets have chosen Terry Collins, their minor league field coordinator, as their new manager, according to three baseball executives who have been briefed on the subject. A Mets spokesman said the team had made a decision but would not announce it until the terms of a contract were worked out.

headline: Across the Table From a Well-Traveled Player
text: Which bridge player has traveled the most miles in his life?

headline: Conjuring Up Wondrous Sounds
text: The theory that young people are instinctively curious about new music got a boost on Friday night when Alan Gilbert conducted the first of this season’s Contact! concerts, the New York Philharmonic’s contemporary- music series, at Symphony Space. A sizable audience turned up at the 750-seat Peter Jay Sharp Theater, and younger people (the whole college-age crowd) were everywhere. No doubt some in the audience were drawn by the specific program, which intriguingly paired a new work by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonic’s composer in residence, written in homage to his influential teacher, the French composer Gérard Grisey, with a major score by Grisey, who died of a stroke at 52 in 1998.

headline: Jet Returns Safely to J.F.K. After Alert
text: A Moscow-bound jetliner that took off from Kennedy International Airport on Sunday afternoon returned to the airport for an emergency landing after there were reports that it was on fire and that the pilot had complained of engine problems, the authorities said.

headline: Opinions You Won’t Find on Twitter: Fran Lebowitz Talks
text: To many Americans — millions, really — the name Fran Lebowitz doesn’t mean much. But in certain precincts, vital to the cultural functioning of both coasts, she is famously a friend, a crank, a climber, a cautionary tale, an iconoclast and a mouth. In “Public Speaking,” Martin Scorsese’s enormously enjoyable and perceptive documentary about her, Ms. Lebowitz’s endearing narcissism is a study in the notion that arrogance and insecurity are largely two sides of the same cocktail coaster.

headline: Harlem Renaissance Man and His Family, Behind Closed Doors
text: The first act of “Knock Me a Kiss,” a dandy play about the ill-advised marriage of W. E. B. Du Bois’s daughter, is such rollicking fun that you may find yourself worrying at the intermission about whether there’s any way this production can successfully work itself around to the serious part of the story that you know lies ahead. But somehow it does, keeping its sense of humor but muzzling it just enough to allow some drama and poignancy to enter the mix.

headline: Isn’t It Rich? Isn’t It Loud? Xylophones for Sondheim
text: Razzle-dazzle isn’t a quality ordinarily associated with the music of Stephen Sondheim. But on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the New York Pops orchestra gave what Steven Reineke, its frisky music director and conductor, called Mr. Sondheim’s “last big birthday bash of the year,” there were moments when, if you closed your eyes, you could imagine you were at a parade.

headline: A Beethoven Warm-Up and a Liszt Workout
text: There were probably some disappointed Murray Perahia fans at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. Because of a hand injury Mr. Perahia withdrew last month from a tour that was to have included a Carnegie recital. But the London-based pianist Stephen Hough took his place, and it is hard to imagine that Perahia admirers went home unhappy after this exciting recital.

headline: Spiral Form and Other Compositional Modes of Fred Lerdahl
text: The engaging Composer Portraits series at the Miller Theater has highlighted the work of a wide range of composers, from the up and coming to the legendary. On Friday evening the spotlight was on Fred Lerdahl, a professor at Columbia University.

headline: Footnotes
text: “When Love Comes,” a low-budget family drama from the Taiwanese director Chang Tso-chi, was the winner of the Golden Horse Film Festival, considered the Chinese-language Oscars, on Saturday night in Taoyuan, Taiwan, The Associated Press reported. The film was nominated in 14 categories, including best director and outstanding Taiwanese film, and defeated the popular martial arts epic “Bodyguards and Assassins,” from the Hong Kong director Teddy Chen. ... About 20,000 people gathered on Saturday at Leidseplein Square in Amsterdam to protest the Dutch government’s plans to cut its arts budget, BBC News reported. The government said it would cut arts funds by more than $270 million over the next five years and raise taxes on theater, film and concert tickets to 19 percent from 6 percent.

headline: Norris Church Mailer, Artist and Ally, Dies at 61
text: Norris Church Mailer, a woman bred in the rural poverty of Arkansas who married Norman Mailer and managed his career and family life over three decades while carving out her own niche as a writer, died on Sunday at her home in Brooklyn Heights. She was 61.

headline: Historian and Actor Meet for Film About Lincoln
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Doris Kearns Goodwin and the Oscar-winning actor Daniel Day-Lewis, above, met on Friday in Springfield, Ill., to tour several historical sites, including the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, the Lincoln home, the Old State Capitol and the Lincoln-Herndon Law Offices, The State Journal-Register reported. Mr. Day-Lewis was preparing for the title role in “Lincoln,” a DreamWorks film to be directed by Steven Spielberg that is scheduled to begin production next fall, according to Kathleen Kennedy, who is producing the film with Mr. Spielberg. The screenplay, by Tony Kushner, who won a Pulitzer Prize for “Angels in America,” is based on Ms. Goodwin’s book “Team of Rivals,” about the president and his cabinet.

headline: Vivaldi for Amateurs Is Found in Collection
text: Two previously unknown violin sonatas by Vivaldi have been discovered in a collection of works by famous composers, including Handel, Corelli and Purcell, where they had been sitting unnoticed for 270 years, BBC News reported. The Foundling Museum in London discovered the pieces while cataloging the anthology, a 180-page portfolio of music compiled between 1715 and 1725 that had been donated in 2008 from the estate of Gerald Coke, a British businessman. “From their relatively simple technical demands, it appears the two sonatas were written by Vivaldi for amateurs,” Michael Talbot, the Vivaldi expert who authenticated the pieces, told the BBC.

headline: Monday: Meal Money in Manitoba
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s constructor, David Poole, brings us four slang terms for money that each happen to be a kind of food that each happen to have a variety identified by a prefixed location name. So, for example, that Manitoba meal money would be CANADIAN BACON.

headline: A West End Debut for Ellen Burstyn
text: Ellen Burstyn’s résumé spans Broadway to Hollywood, but this Oscar-winning actress still has another frontier to claim: the West End in London. Ms. Burstyn, below, will make her debut there in January at the Comedy Theater, playing Amelia Tilford in “The Children’s Hour,” by Lillian Hellman, BBC News reported. She will join a cast led by Keira Knightley (“Pride and Prejudice”) and Elisabeth Moss (“Mad Men”), who play schoolteachers whose lives are torn apart by a vicious rumor spread by Tilford and her granddaughter. Carol Kane, known for her role as Simka Dahblitz-Gravas on the 1980s television show “Taxi,” and Tobias Menzies, who played Brutus in the BBC-HBO television series “Rome,” have also joined the production, to be directed by Ian Rickson (“Jerusalem”). Previews begin on Jan. 22.

headline: Eagles 27, Giants 17, Final
text: An interception with a second left seals it for the Eagles — Eli Manning’s third pick and fourth turnover tonight. The Giants may have trouble deciding what to focus on tomorrow. Will it be the fact that the Eagles dominated them in the first half? Or the fact that they showed some grit, overcame that and took the lead when Philadelphia put the game on a platter for them by missing chances to pad its lead? Or will it be the fact that, once they had the lead, they threw it away by blowing their defense on a fourth-and-1 and giving up a 50-yard touchdown run? And then kicked away their final chance with three — three!! — turnovers in the closing minutes, including two on one drive? That will be for them to chew over in the postgame. Feel free to weigh in with your comments, and thanks for reading.Pregame: Live coverage and analysis of the Giants’ game against the Philadelphia Eagles at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia. headline: Ireland’s Paradise Lost
text: For an American tourist weaned on Gaelic kitsch and screenings of “The Quiet Man,” the landscape of contemporary Ireland comes as something of a shock. Drive from Dublin to the western coast and back, as I did two months ago, and you’ll still find all the thatched-roof farmhouses, winding stone walls and placid sheep that the postcards would lead you to expect. But round every green hill, there’s a swath of miniature McMansions. Past every tumble-down castle, a cascade of condominiums. In sleepy fishing villages that date to the days of Grace O’Malley, Ireland’s Pirate Queen (she was the Sarah Palin of the 16th century), half the houses look the part  but the rest could have been thrown up by the Toll brothers.

headline: What the Secret Donors Want
