text: The week’s biggest news may be this morning’s announcement from the Department of Health and Human Services about the final rules under the new health care law that dictate how health insurers must spend the premiums they collect.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Messy Relationships
text: A number of readers here in recent weeks have written in about problems of discontinuity on “Dexter” this season, and it seems that there was an issue on Sunday night’s episode, “Teenage Wasteland.” Astor resurfaces from Orlando with a new friend, who, it turns out, has been hit by her mother’s boyfriend. Lumen sees the marks on the girl’s stomach. The girls flee the house when the boyfriend shows up in Miami, prompting fears of a kidnapping.

headline: Monday Reading: Finding a Holiday Job
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Humana to Buy Concentra
text: Humana, the health plan company, agreed on Monday to acquire Concentra, a privately held health care company, for $790 million in cash.

headline: Netflix Introduces Streaming-Only Pricing
text: It looks as if the DVD is suffering another death rattle.

headline: It’s About Money, Not the Extra Games
text: By the time Week 11 is completed in most N.F.L. seasons, the only deadline that matters is the one six weeks away, when the playoff field is determined. But a more ominous deadline looms this week. Tuesday is the beginning of the final 100 days of the collective bargaining agreement, which expires March 3.

headline: Are Yankees Punished for Success in Awards Season?
text: Part of the disconnect some fans feel with sportswriters is that we don’t understand their perspective. How could we, without rooting for teams we cover? Yet almost all of us started as fans, and recalling those days can be instructive.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: —Irish minister’s car hits a protester after bailout request is announced.

headline: Expansion of Bike Lanes in City Brings Backlash
text: Over the last four years, the streets of New York City have undergone a transformation: More than 250 miles of traffic lanes dedicated for bicycles have been created, and several laws intended to promote cycling have been passed.

headline: Former Medill Students Protest Prosecution of Innocence Project
text: The Medill Innocence Project, part of the journalism department at Northwestern University, has spent years investigating suspicious prosecutions by the Cook County Attorney’s office. Now former students of the program say the project and its leader, David Protess, may be the target of one.

headline: Numberplay: Elevating Experiences
text: Gary Antonick

headline: Monday Matchup, Broncos at Chargers
text: Broncos (3-6) at Chargers (4-5)Monday, 8:30 p.m.Line: Chargers by 9.5

headline: What Do You Think of City’s Support for Biking?
text: New York cyclists have enjoyed the support of the city government in recent years as never before, and more new commuters and recreational riders have taken to the streets in response.

headline: Understanding AirPlay in Apple’s iOS 4.2
text: Update November 22, 2:11 p.m.: Added information regarding Airplay’s audio capabilities.As you may have learned already from my colleague Nick Bilton’s post, Apple on Monday released an upgrade to its iOS operating system that brings a number of iPhone functions (apps folders, multitasking, apps running in the background, for example) to the iPad.

headline: Bad Sunday to Be a Manning
text: This happens so seldom that you immediately start suspecting some weird “astrological retrograde moons in the wrong house” explanation, but Sunday was decidedly a bad day to be a quarterback named Manning. Not that Peyton and Eli’s N.F.L. teams do not often lose on the same day, but rarely do both of them make the spectacularly horrendous play that seals the loss on the same day: the elder Manning botching a chance at a game-tying field goal by throwing an interception against the Patriots and the younger one trying to one-up him by fumbling away the Giants’ chance to catch the Eagles.

headline: On Our Radar: 2010 May Set Emissions Record
text: Global carbon dioxide emissions may hit record levels this year, exceeding the previous high set in 2008, a new study estimates. Emissions have rebounded sharply this year in tandem with the recovery of the world economy. [Wired]

headline: It’s Thanksgiving; We’re Doomed
text: Let us now give thanks for Thanksgiving. Or not, as the case may be.

headline: Fete Accompli | Cherry Vanilla Dinner at the Royalton
text: Cherry Vanilla has more scoops for you. The infamous 70’s groupie, singer, writer and underground actress, who was also David Bowie’s publicist during his Mainman years, was in town over the weekend to celebrate the release of her autobiography, “Lick Me: How I Became Cherry Vanilla.” Among the downtown demimondaines and creative misfits who turned up to the dinner hosted for her by Tim Burton at Forty Four at Royalton on Saturday night were Patricia Field, Leee Black Childers, Kate Pierson of the B-52s, Agyness Deyn, Geordon Nicol, Greg K and Leigh Lezark. Seated next to Guinevere van Seenus (in vintage), Cherry held court, regaling her audience with stories about her myriad sexcapades, misadventures and all-around delish dish.

headline: Smile. You’re on Bus Lane Camera.
text: Candid camera can spur a smile. For drivers, bus-lane cameras may prompt a frown.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Food Institute (pdf): Prices are way up for turkey this year over last; pecans too. Celery, on the other hand, way down. – Julia Moskin

headline: HauteLook Brings Flash Sales to Facebook
text: Flash-sale Web sites that try to recreate the rush of a designer sample sale have largely relied on alerting their members to upcoming deals via e-mail notifications.

headline: Running New York’s Schools Once Came With a Nice House
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has played up Cathleen P. Black’s record of business success in nominating her to be the next schools chancellor. He has, perhaps wisely, omitted one asset Ms. Black brings to the job: a drool-inducing collection of homes in which to hold killer end-of-school-year parties. Ms. Black owns a Park Avenue penthouse with a gourmet kitchen, a five-bedroom Connecticut colonial and a Southampton weekend getaway.

headline: Q. and A.With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Are Small Businesses Really the Engines of Job Growth?
text: Our colleagues at the Economix blog have published a post that challenges the conventional wisdom that small businesses are the engines of job growth.

headline: Eurofile | Chic Eats in Paris
text: The surest sign that Paris has shrugged off its recession blues is the latest crop of gastro addresses to spring up in the city this fall. Not only do they offer fabulous food, they’re also drop-dead chic — a combination Parisians find irresistible.

headline: What We’re Reading: Fake Divorce
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: A Second Life for Italian Lingerie
text: A six-week initiative promoted by the Italian lingerie brand Intimissimi essentially exchanges one form of padding for another: used bras collected at its brand name stores throughout Italy will be recycled into insulated and soundproof panels used for construction.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Danielle Arceneaux joined the New York office of Cramer-Krasselt as vice president and director for public relations. She succeeds Deborah Radman, who left, the agency said. Ms. Arceneaux had most recently been a senior vice president at Kaplow Communications, New York, overseeing the Target account.

headline: What Did You Think About ‘Top Gear’?
text: The American version of “Top Gear” made its debut on the History Channel on cable last night. In reviewing the first three episodes — the only ones made available by the producers — Mike Hale of The New York Times wrote, “The result — for the person with a casual interest in cars, anyway — is a show that at this point lacks the character of the British original but is, particularly in its second and third episodes, reasonably entertaining by American reality-TV standards.”

headline: S.E.C. Smarter About Insider Inquiries, Official Says
text: Reports that authorities are at an advanced stage of insider trading investigations are the talk of Wall Street.

headline: Haslem Injury Potentially Devastating for Heat
text: There are few angles of the Miami Heat from which Udonis Haslem lies at the focus. After all, on a team that’s glowing with star power and expected to be dazzling, it makes little sense to concentrate on a player who is, in many ways, unspectacular. There’s nothing sexy about below-the-rim rebounds or jumpers from the elbow, but that doesn’t make Haslem anything less than invaluable for Miami.

headline: Michelle Obama Gets a New Communications Director
text: Michelle Obama announced on Monday that Kristina Schake, a former aide to California’s  first lady, Maria Shriver, and a co-founder of the California-based political consulting firm Griffin Schake, will be joining the East Wing as a special assistant to the president and the first lady’s communications director.

headline: Pumpkin: The Flavor of Late Fall
text: I never got around to carving a jack-o’-lantern for Halloween. I bought the pumpkin, yes, but then decided to save it for cooking. The day after Halloween, I cut it into chunks — about eight pounds — put them on foil-lined baking sheets, covered the sheets and roasted them at 425 degrees until they were very soft, which took about 1 1/2 hours. Then I spent the week making pumpkin recipes.

headline: Predicting the Economy, and Obama’s Re-Election Chances
text: Saturday’s Times had an  article by Jeff Sommer that highlighted the work of Ray C. Fair, a Yale economist who has designed a model to predict the outcomes of presidential elections based on a series of economic variables.

headline: One Giants Power Failure Explained
text: The blackout that plunged the New Meadowlands Stadium into darkness for more than 10 minutes during last Sunday’s Giants game against the Dallas Cowboys was not the team’s fault, officials said Monday.

headline: How to Get a Home Buyer’s Discount
text: With the home buyer’s tax credit now expired, here’s one way to still get an equivalent discount of sorts: ask your real estate agent to take it out of his or her commission.

headline: Twins’ Suicide Pact and the Columbine Connection
text: Twin sisters from Australia, who complained of bullying as teenagers, might have chosen to shoot themselves at a gun range outside Denver last week because of its proximity to Columbine High School, site of the 1999 massacre that became a global news event.

headline: Smashburger Is Coming to Town
text: Better burgers buffet Brooklyn!

headline: Choosing Between a Hard Rock and a Place
text: The idea that all the world’s a stage has grown only more powerful with the advent of reality TV, gossip Web sites and the mainstreaming of entertainment industry news. So it ought to be no surprise that marketers are trying to capitalize on the trend by having ads speak in the language of show business.

headline: Tanks to Afghanistan, a Soldier Writes
text: The United States military has announced that it will be sending a company of Marine Tankers to southwest Afghanistan, bringing a much-needed armor presence to an asymmetrical fight.

headline: Allman Brothers Band Gets Back the Beacon, and Gets an Apology Too
text: The Gypsy may fly from coast to coast and concert hall to concert hall, but back home he’ll always run. On Monday the Allman Brothers Band announced that it would return to its homestead at the Beacon Theater after a one-year absence, at a news conference during which Gregg Allman and his bandmates received a surprising apology from executives at MSG Entertainment, which runs the theater.

headline: Off the Menu: Villa Pacri
text: The soap opera that has been the opening of the multistory Villa Pacri complex continues.

headline: TimesCast | November 22, 2010
text: Obama wins support abroad for the Start Treaty; killing the invasive lionfish for sport; and answering readers' questions about a story on high schools' fight for the attention of tech-savvy teens.

headline: Off the Menu: Mas 2
text: Galen Zamarra, the chef and partner at Mas (Farmhouse) in Greenwich Village, plans to expand his brand with a second restaurant, Mas (La Grillade), in early summer.

headline: With Its Move, City Gives Chess Players a New Spot
text: The accidental chess rebels of Inwood Hill Park now have a legal place to play — as long as they bring their own boards.

headline: Dining at the New Bowlmor Lanes
text: No doubt you can work up an appetite flinging a bowling ball down the alley, so the 90,000-square-foot bowling complex in the former New York Times newsroom, off Times Square, has a 220-seat restaurant, Stadium Grill, with stadium-style seating and an 80-foot bar. The restaurant menu and the  menu available at the lanes are by David Burke.

headline: New Pick-Me-Ups at Kennedy Airport
text: Fliers headed to Rome or Milan might be looking forward to a cappuccino waiting on the other side. Now Italians should look forward to landing in New York, as two high-end coffee machines have popped up at Kennedy Airport.

headline: Industry and Government Were Unprepared for BP Spill, Study says
text: Government and the oil industry were both thoroughly unprepared for a deepwater blowout and oil spill like the one that occurred this year in the gulf, leading to significant delays in capping the well and major environmental damage, the staff of the presidential spill commission concluded in two reports published on Monday.

headline: Former Nazi Guard, 89, Dies Before Trial in Germany
text: BERLIN  A former Nazi guard accused of aiding in the murder of 430,000 Jews at the Belzec death camp  and of personally shooting dead 10 people  died in his home near Bonn before he could stand trial next year, German court officials announced Monday.

headline: Republican Bias Found in Polls That Exclude Cellphones
text: An analysis by the Pew Research Center of its midterm election polls found a pro-Republican bias in samples based on interviews conducted only by land-line telephones, compared with ones that also included cellphones. The finding sends a stark warning to pollsters across the country as attention turns to the 2012 presidential election.

headline: BBC and Discovery Channel Join Forces for ‘History of the World’
text: The BBC and the Discovery Channel, which collaborated in the past on “Planet Earth” and “Life,” are starting work on another joint documentary, “History of the World.”

headline: Scotiabank in Deal for DundeeWealth
text: Scotiabank plans to expand its asset management services with the acquisition of the 82 percent of the wealth management company DundeeWealth that it does not already own, the bank said on Monday.

headline: How Parents Can Prevent Bullying
text: September 19: Billy Lucas, age 15, of Greensburg, Indiana, hanged himself from the rafters of his family’s barn. September 19: Seth Walsh, 13, of Tahachapi, California, hanged himself from a tree in his yard. September 22; Tyler Clementi, 18, a Rutgers University freshman, jumped off the George Washington Bridge in New York City. September 23: Asher Brown, 13, of Houston, shot himself in the head. These four boys didn’t know each other, but they did have something in common. They’d been bullied and school, and one by one, they all apparently came to the same conclusion: If you’re gay or thought to be gay, life just isn’t worth living.

headline: Legislator Says Panel Member Should Be Removed
text: State Senator Eric Adams on Monday called for the removal of a member of the education panel evaluating Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s choice for the next city schools chancellor.

headline: In European Debt Crisis, Some Call Default Better Option
text: DUBLIN — Ireland has finally taken its medicine, accepting the financial rescue package European officials have been pushing for several weeks.

headline: Vikings Fire Childress as Season Gets Away
text: Perhaps the first sign this was going to be an off-kilter season for the Minnesota Vikings came when Coach Brad Childress dispatched three players on a private jet to beg Brett Favre to return for one more run at the Super Bowl, a season after the Vikings reached the N.F.C. championship game. Favre did return, but the chaos was only beginning.

headline: Jay-Z Deconstructs Himself
text: In the summer of 1978, when he was 9 years old and growing up in the Marcy housing projects in Brooklyn, Shawn Carter — a k a Jay-Z — saw a circle of people gathered around a kid named Slate, who was “rhyming, throwing out couplet after couplet like he was in a trance, for a crazy long time — 30 minutes straight off the top of his head, never losing the beat, riding the handclaps” of the folks around him, transformed “like the church ladies touched by the spirit.” Young Shawn felt gravity working on him, “like a planet pulled into orbit by a star”: he went home that night and started writing his own rhymes in a notebook and studying the dictionary.

headline: The Claim: Cellphones Can Cause an Allergic Reaction.
text: THE FACTS Talking on a cellphone for long periods can carry certain risks, like dirty looks from those around you. But allergies?

headline: Guilty Verdict in Chandra Levy Murder Case
text: WASHINGTON  A jury convicted a Salvadoran immigrant of killing Chandra Levy, the government intern whose relationship with Gary A. Condit ended his Congressional career and made her disappearance a national media sensation.

headline: Are You Allergic to Your Cellphone?
text: If you’ve noticed an itchy, bumpy rash along your jaw line, the culprit may surprise you. As today’s “Really?” column reports, you may be allergic to your cellphone.

headline: Sending Tanks to Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The byways of Afghanistan are still littered with burned and bombed out old Soviet tanks, T-55s too big and hulking to move economically, especially from their final resting places on narrow mountain roads and at the bottoms of deep gorges.

headline: Jimmie Johnson Wins Fifth Sprint Cup Title
text: Jimmie Johnson won his fifth Sprint Cup championship on Sunday, after finishing second in the season finale at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Florida, behind Carl Edwards.

headline: For a Cat, a Payback in a Shadowy Existence
text: Watch the full episode. See more Nature.

headline: Deficit Puzzle: Where’s the Fair Tax?
text: Yesterday’s Week in Review section published a whole bunch of charts showing how Twitter users chose to cut the deficit using our deficit puzzle. In an accompanying article, I also mentioned a few options that readers and bloggers told us they wish we had included in the puzzle.

headline: Warthen to Return as Mets’ Pitching Coach
text: Dan Warthen will remain as Mets pitching coach and will not be replaced by new manager Terry Collins’s good friend Dave Wallace, a former Mets pitching coach.

headline: Lessons in Inefficiency, Learned in Airports Around the World
text: I’M a problem-solver and pattern-recognizer. Traveling as much as I do is always an adventure. I have to admit that a lot of the time, I’m wondering how we actually make it from Point A to Point B since everything is so inefficient.

headline: Michael Savage to Write Two Thrillers
text: Michael Savage, the combative talk radio host, has signed a deal to write two thrillers for St. Martin’s Press, the publisher said on Monday. Until now Mr. Savage has stuck to nonfiction, with books like “Liberalism Is a Mental Disorder,” “The Savage Nation” and “The Enemy Within.” Mr. Savage, whose personal “manifesto” on his Web site calls for closing the United States’ borders, ending affirmative action and instituting a flat tax, attracts more than nine million weekly listeners to his syndicated radio show, according to Talkers magazine.

headline: In Family Court With Mel Gibson
text: 9:36 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — After a day of testimony and legal wrangling on Monday, the Mel Gibson-Oksana Grigorieva  battle in family court adjourned for the day, with plans to resume in front of Judge Scott M. Gordon on Dec. 15. According to one person who was briefed on the closed-door proceedings, and who spoke on condition of anonymity because of their sensitivity, Ms. Grigorieva testified but Mr. Gibson did not. The core issues — who will have custody of the couple’s daughter, Lucia, and under what terms — are not likely to be settled until early next year.

headline: SoFAS
text: Acronym for foods containing Solid Fats and Added Sugars.Reporting for The Monterey County Herald on the American Dietetic Association’s Food and Nutrition Conference, Barbara Quinn wrote:

headline: A Shift From Company Cars
text: Businesses are increasingly adopting car sharing as a cost-saving alternative for employee travel. Workers can step outside their company’s front door and into a car they can drive to a business meeting or sales call, and  during breaks or lunch hour  use for errands or shopping.

headline: Beyond Pumpkin Pie: Thankful for Dessert
text: All month long, Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving series has offered delicious no-meat dishes for your holiday table. Now, it’s time for dessert.

headline: Site Unseen: Comic-Con Ticket-Seekers Thwarted by Online Fiasco
text: Quick: Who’s the superhero with ticket-selling powers? Comic-Con is in need of some.

headline: Should Nations Bankroll Coal Plants Overseas?
text: My article in Monday’s Times examines how many countries and communities that block new construction of coal-fired power plants at home are enabling their use in the developing world by exporting coal to Asia.

headline: Islanders’ Drama Continues
text: To borrow a sentiment from the Bard, there is something very rotten indeed in New York Islander-land. Their losing streak has reached 13, and things remain bleak.

headline: N.F.L. Encourages Children to Go Out and Play
text: What better time to remind people to exercise than during the annual Thanksgiving gorge-fest?

headline: Wanderlust | Mexico City’s Common People
text: Monika Feldman used to walk by what she describes as “this magnificent house” — a 1940s Colonial-style mansion in Mexico City’s high-end Polanco district — every day on the way to Byzanz, the fabric shop she owns with her husband, Max. Now that building is home to their latest store, Common People, which they like to refer to as “a place to be filled by uncommon things for common people,” and that many other style watchers are calling Mexico City’s answer to Colette.

headline: A Prescription for Abdominal Pain: Due Diligence
text: The stomachache people look with some envy at the headache people.

headline: The Caucus: The New Start Treaty
text: President Obama has international support for Start, a nuclear treaty with Russia, but he has struggled in the last week to get Republican cooperation at home.

headline: Understanding Childhood Stomachaches
text: In today’s “18 and Under” column, pediatrician Dr. Perri Klass navigates the challenges of diagnosing and treating children with chronic stomachache. She writes:

headline: Behavior: Young Marijuana Users Pay Cognitive Price
text: Marijuana smoking often starts in adolescence  and the timing could not be worse, a new study suggests.

headline: Pakistani Sentenced to Death May Get a Pardon
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Christian woman who was sentenced to death by a municipal court for blasphemy against Islam could be pardoned by the president in the next few days, a senior government official said Monday.

headline: For the Briners, Thanksgiving May Start Today
text: The Thanksgiving Help Line I run here at Diner’s Journal doesn’t really get going until Wednesday afternoon, and doesn’t kick into high gear until Thanksgiving morning itself, but already the mail has started to pour in: mostly people freaking out about brine.

headline: A Web Retailer Starts Over
text: In July, She Owns It introduced readers to La Grande Dame, an online retailer of high-end, plus-size designer clothing for women. The post chronicled the start-up’s experiences with Google AdWords and search engine optimization and its eventual decision to cut Google’s pay-per-click advertising product from its marketing mix. Several readers commented that La Grande Dame’s Web site contributed to its S.E.O. challenges and urged an overhaul to address that issue and improve the site’s appearance and functionality. La Grande Dame took the comments — and similar ones from its customers — to heart, and unveiled its new site last week. “Our ultimate goal was to improve the user experience and make it easier for shoppers to find what they want,” said Catherine Wood Hill, La Grande Dame’s chief executive.

headline: Harvey Pitt Gives His Take on the Insider Trading Inquiry
text: A major insider trading inquiry is under way, and Harvey L. Pitt, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, says investment firms may be required to spend more time on compliance as a result.

headline: Manning Is Most Frequent Fumbler
text: Giants quarterback Eli Manning, constantly compared to his quarterbacking brother on the Indianapolis Colts, leads Peyton Manning in one unsung career statistic: fumbles.

headline: TimesCast: Obama and the New Start Treaty
text: In today’s TimesCast, a conversation about President Obama’s efforts to get enough votes in the Senate to ratify an arms treaty with Russia.

headline: Wired Up at Home to Monitor Illnesses
text: As an aging population threatens to overwhelm the nation’s hospitals and doctors, thousands of seriously ill patients are relying on computerized health trackers to help keep them safe at home.

headline: It’s Time for Recess: Just Keep on Moving
text: We all know by now that we should be getting 30 minutes a day of moderate to vigorous physical activity on most days. Yet for all the proselytizing, wheedling and cajoling, only about 5 percent of the population has bought into the program.

headline: A Man From Whom Viruses Can’t Hide
text: Dr. W. Ian Lipkin was spending the afternoon prowling his empire of viruses. The Center for Infection and Immunity, which he directs, occupies three floors of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University. Rather than wait for the elevator, Dr. Lipkin ran up and down the back stairs to move from floor to floor, leaning into the doorways of labs and glass-walled offices to get updates from a platoon of scientists.

headline: On a School Rooftop, Hydroponic Greens for Little Gardeners
text: Shakira Castronovo stood in a classroom at the Manhattan School for Children on West 93rd Street on a recent afternoon and hushed a squirming group of kindergartners perched around a blue carpet.

headline: Fungus Among Us
text: “Soma,” Carsten Höller’s enormous installation at the Hamburger Bahnhof — Museum für Gegenwart in Berlin, is quite a trip down the rabbit hole — complete with a host of special psychedelic effects and strange supporting characters. The title refers to the drink central to Vedic and greater Persian religious rites, the active ingredient of which some scholars believe was Amanita muscaria, a kind of psychoactive mushroom. Höller has constructed two long, fenced-in corrals with hay-lined floors, gigantic sculptures of magic mushrooms and an elevated, cushioned platform on which a limited number of visitors can sign up to spend the night. There are also freezers stocked with actual — enormous — samples of Amanita muscaria.

headline: Lessons of Hate at Islamic Schools in Britain
text: LONDON  A British network of more than 40 part-time Islamic schools and clubs with 5,000 students has been teaching from a Saudi Arabian government curriculum that contains anti-Semitic and homophobic views, including a textbook that asks children to list the “reprehensible” qualities of Jews, according to a BBC documentary broadcast on Monday.

headline: The Brown Apple
text: Q. What accounts for the difference among varieties of apple in how quickly slices turn brown?

headline: Behind the Facade, Post-Traumatic Stress
text: A soldier returns from war unable to get the images of battle out of his head. An earthquake survivor rides out long, anxiety-filled nights. A young woman in a pretty floral dress walks her dog along the streets of Manhattan.

headline: The Next Ailing Wild Cat in Apple’s Software Pipeline
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated Craig Packer, a University of Minnesota biologist whose specialty is Africa’s lions, read my posts on the tiger as an imperiled wild cat and Apple marketing icon and e-mailed a reminder of the troubles facing the world’s other uber-charismatic feline predator. I’ve added a couple of links for context:

headline: After the Nuclear Plant Powers Down
text: ZION, Ill.  Twelve years ago, Commonwealth Edison found itself in a bind.

text: The first time I met the eminent cosmologist Allan R. Sandage, who died Nov. 13 at 84, he refused to talk to me.

headline: Nissan Says Its Electric Leaf Gets Equivalent of 99 M.P.G.
text: DETROIT  The federal government has rated the Nissan Leaf, the battery-powered car scheduled to go on sale next month in five states, as getting the fuel equivalent of 99 miles a gallon, Nissan said Monday.

headline: ‘Tis the Season (for Law Firm Bonuses)
text: It’s a good time of year to be a lawyer at a large New York firm.

headline: Avoid the Investing Trap of Familiarity
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated Massey confirmed in a statement on Monday that it was conducting a review of strategic alternatives.

headline: Reptile’s Pet-Store Looks Belie Its Triassic Appeal
text: As a femur-shaped island paradise that snapped away from the Gondwana supercontinent some 80 million years ago, New Zealand is famously home to eccentric forms of wildlife that look like pets for a Hobbit.

headline: Video Shows Aftermath of Deadly Stampede in Cambodia
text: Updated | Tuesday | 1:00 p.m. At least 378 people were killed and hundreds more injured in a stampede at a festival in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, on Monday.

headline: H.P. Surpasses Forecasts With 5% Jump in Profit
text: For Léo Apotheker, his debut public appearance as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard could not have gone much better had he scripted it.

headline: Rookie Has U.S. Team Debut and Meets Mandela
text: The whirlwind trip to South Africa left Tim Ream in a bit of a daze, a good daze.

headline: From California, a Game Plan on Climate Change
text: As the push for national and international policies to arrest climate change was running into one obstacle after another, a separate discussion was coming to the fore: how to adapt to it.

headline: Housecalls of Another Sort
text: In Tuesday’s Science Times, Milt Freudenheim describes some of the high-tech medical devices now used to monitor the elderly in their homes.

headline: A Lesser-Known Work by Gilbert and Sullivan Tells a Tropical Tale
text: It’s not hard to understand what would entice the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players to stage “Utopia, Limited,” the penultimate collaboration between their namesake librettist and composer. The company regularly dusts off lesser-known works from the ingenious Gilbert and Sullivan canon. And this one, which on Sunday opened a season transplanted to Symphony Space because of renovations at the troupe’s usual home at City Center, in at least one respect seemed squarely of the moment.

headline: Studio Will Take Another Stab at ‘Buffy the Vampire Slayer’
text: 9:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: Critics' Picks: 'The Ice Storm'
text: A. O. Scott revisits Ang Lee's period film about the collapse of moral authority in a wealthy New York City suburb.

headline: Irish Leader’s Statement on Bailout and Elections After ‘Feeble’ Street Protest
text: Updated | 5:39 p.m. In a brief live address on Monday evening, Brian Cowen, the leader, or taoiseach, of Ireland’s government announced that he would not heed calls for his immediate resignation but intends to fight to pass a new budget next month and then call a general election for early next year.

headline: Postponing the Inevitable vs. Denying the Inevitable
text: The latest “Frontline” documentary comes with a blunt, no-one-was-aiming-for-lyricism title: “Facing Death.” The name and the accompanying promotional materials, with an image of a corpselike hand on a hospital bed, suggest a resurrection of the kind of tired and unwinnable debates that surrounded the case of Terri Schiavo. But the film, produced by Miri Navasky and Karen O’Connor, who paid such elegant tribute to the grim subject of mortuary work in “The Undertaking,” ambitiously explores the complex questions that arise about extending life when a patient is not merely in a persistent vegetative state.

headline: Splashed, but Not Drowned
text: The splash of scalding coffee was painful enough, but the real source of my anxiety was on the floor: My iPhone was soaking in a little puddle of java.

headline: (Virtual) Same-Sex Adoption
text: There is one corner of one realm it seems — one frequented by the same age group that struggles with bullying and exclusion — where homosexuality is just another matter-of-fact option.

headline: Hakeem Nicks Out 3 Weeks With Leg Injury
text: The pain is spreading for the Giants.

headline: Flu: Bird Flu Falls Off the Radar, but Cases Show It’s Still a Threat
text: In the wake of last year’s pandemic of H1N1 swine flu  which turned into far less of a global threat than had been feared  the world has largely forgotten about the H5N1 bird flu.

headline: Banks Face Big Test in New Capital Rules
text: Once again, what’s good for banks — and their shareholders — may not be so great for consumers. The Federal Reserve’s new stress tests, along with the new Basel III international rules on capital requirements, are aimed at ensuring that big banks are well capitalized and, in the United States, finally allowing them to raise dividends to shareholders.

headline: Philip K. Dick’s Masterpiece Years
text: POINT REYES STATION, Calif.  Half a century later, Anne R. Dick still remembers the sunny October day she met a clean-shaven 29-year-old Berkeley exile who had just moved to this rural enclave in west Marin County, thick with eucalyptus trees and brooding owls.

headline: A Voice of Post-Traumatic Stress
text: Most people associate post-traumatic stress disorder with military service during wartime. But increasingly, therapists are reporting that the typical patient with P.T.S.D. has experienced trauma in everyday life, reports Karen Barrow in today’s Science Times.

headline: In Cybertherapy, Avatars Assist With Healing
text: OTTAWA — His talk was going just fine until some members of the audience became noticeably restless. A ripple of impatience passed through the several dozen seated listeners, and a few seemed suddenly annoyed; then two men started to talk to each other, ignoring him altogether.

headline: More Bicycle Lanes
text: A look at the growth of New York City’s network of bike lanes over the past decade.

headline: Maverick’s Ainslie Tells the Short of It
text: Some hedge fund managers pen long, windy letters to their investors, musing about everything from the pernicious effects of quantitative easing (David Einhorn’s recent letter) to what America needs to do to lower unemployment: fix the renminbi-dollar misalignment (Paul Tudor Jones’s latest missive).

headline: Some Artist Favorites for Violin and Piano
text: In recent years the violinist and violist Pinchas Zukerman has often seemed afflicted with what could be called celebrity coasting syndrome. But on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Zukerman, who is also the music director of the National Arts Center Orchestra in Ottawa, seemed back in form, offering committed performances in a thoughtful partnership with the excellent pianist Yefim Bronfman.

headline: Printed Memories
text: “The studio is one big ice cream factory,” exclaims Gaby Basora, the designer behind Tucker. “Fabric and prints everywhere. Baby boys playing hide and seek under remnants.”

headline: Simple Gravy You Can Make Ahead
text: There's no need to wait until the turkey is done in the oven. Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make simple lumpless gravy that you can prepare anytime.

headline: Video Games: Joysticks to the World (and Kinect)
text: Now that millions of moms and other nongamer types are hooked on Facebook diversions like FarmVille and iPhone apps like Angry Birds (not to mention the legions of office workers still clinging to Minesweeper and Solitaire), the average age of people who play video games appears to be firmly north of 30.

headline: A Culture of Mathematics
text: Images of Babylonian mathematical tablets from an exhibition at New York University’s Institute for the Study of the Ancient World.

headline: A Vegetarian Thanksgiving, Even for Carnivores
text: No turkeys were harmed in the writing of this column.

headline: Plan to Bring Ship to West Side Hits Snag
text: New York City might not be the next home port for the S.S. United States, a historic luxury liner, if a casino development plan unveiled Monday in Philadelphia comes to pass.

headline: Higher Deductibles, Lower Spending
text: As more families find themselves enrolled in health plans with high deductibles, they are increasingly likely to delay or forgo medical care because of the out-of-pocket cost, a new study shows.

headline: White Light: Is It Driven by the Soul or by Sales?
text: Over the last several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. (The last festival event is “The Manganiyar Seduction,” a musical work in the Indian classical and folk traditions, on Tuesday at the Rose Theater; lincolncenter.org.) The classical music critics and a reporter at The New York Times discussed the works, transcendence and the merits of the festival on ArtsBeat. Here are excerpts from their conversation; the full text is at nytimes.com/artsbeat.

headline: Are Attractive People More Employable?
text: Are good-looking people more likely to get jobs? That depends whether you’re talking about men or women, according to a new working paper. From the abstract:

headline: An Exhibition That Gets to the (Square) Root of Sumerian Math
text: Papyrus, parchment, paper ... videotape, DVDs, Blu-ray discs  long after all these materials have crumbled to dust, the first recording medium of all, the cuneiform clay tablet of ancient Mesopotamia, may still endure.

headline: Casting Balanchine the Way the Master Did
text: WASHINGTON  When George Balanchine was alive, one of the many layers of the Balanchine adventure was casting. Each week when New York City Ballet would announce who was dancing what, fans would discover how he wanted to extend this dancer in ways nobody else had imagined, or which new dancer he wanted to test with a fresh challenge.

headline: Sour Notes for ABC
text: ABC’s broadcast of the 38th Annual American Music Awards on Sunday night saw a steep decline in its ratings compared with a year ago. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 11.7 million viewers tuned in to the show from 8 to 11, down from its 2009 audience of 14.2 million. ABC ranked third on the night, well behind the first-place NBC and its “Sunday Night Football” coverage of the New York Giants-Philadelphia Eagles game. Although final ratings were not available on Monday, the preliminary estimate for the game was roughly 25 million. CBS placed second over all, as “60 Minutes” (19.5 million) got a boost from the network’s afternoon football coverage. Fox was fourth.

headline: Spy Photo of 2012 VW Beetle, One of Oprah’s Favorite Things
text: Hear that? It’s the sound of a room of men and women (mostly women) screaming and hyperventilating after Oprah Winfrey told her studio audience that each one of them would receive a new 2012 Volkswagen Beetle, a car that won’t be released until next year.

headline: Now Come the T.S.A. Jokes
text: WASHINGTON — “Can’t see London, Can’t see France, unless we see your underpants.”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Ice Storm’
text: “Our Puritan ancestors gave us Thanksgiving,” says A. O. Scott in this week’s Critics’ Picks video. “They also passed down a rich tradition of sin, damnation and guilt.” These elements are present in Ang Lee’s drama “The Ice Storm.” The movie takes place on Thanksgiving weekend in 1973 and follows the intertwining lives and various infidelities of two families in a wealthy New York City suburb. While it is possible to look at these characters as a collection of sinners deserving of punishment, Mr. Scott sees the film a different way. “It’s about what it takes to live in a world where moral authority has collapsed,” he says. Have you seen “The Ice Storm?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Cape Wind Takes a Step Forward
text: Massachusetts utility regulators on Monday approved a contract under which a utility will buy half the electricity produced by Cape Wind, the proposed wind farm to be built in Nantucket Sound off the coast of Cape Cod, bringing the project substantially closer to construction.

headline: On the Fine Art of Restaurant Criticism
text: William Grimes, a former restaurant critic for The Times, offers an interesting perspective in response to my most recent letters column, Dining Out on Different Budgets.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: NE-YO

headline: An Exotic Predator Threatens the Keys
text: This video, shot in 2010, documents an earlier tournament intended to remove lionfish.

headline: In M.V.P. Voting, Votto Makes Pujols Second Best
text: Joey Votto knew he had a superb season for the Cincinnati Reds, one worthy of the National League’s Most Valuable Player award, but he said he did not check his statistics until it was over. Then he compared them with those of another slugging first baseman, Albert Pujols of the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: Florida Keys Declare Open Season on the Invasive Lionfish
text: KEY WEST, Fla.  Crawling through turquoise murk on the ocean floor near Tea Table Key, Rob Pillus glances at a half dozen lobsters that twirl their antennae in the fast-moving current. Mr. Pillus, an avid spear fisherman, would normally stuff the crustaceans into his mesh bag for dinner, but today he is after more exotic quarry: an invasive species called the lionfish that threatens to wreak havoc on this ecologically sensitive marine system.

headline: Google Docs and Microsoft? Word.
text: On TechCrunch today, Jason Kincaid reveals a new plug-in for Microsoft Office that allows users to sync up their work in the popular productivity suite with Google‘s cloud-based word processor and spreadsheet. Right now, the plug-in is only for corporate users of Google Docs, but expect a consumer version soon.

headline: Global Puck: N.H.L. Cool to Canada-Russia Summit Series Reprise in 2012
text: N.H.L. Deputy Commissioner Bill Daly said Monday that the league would not back a 40th anniversary renewal of the historic Canada-Russia Summit Series in September 2012.

headline: The Pope’s Words on Condoms
text: Excerpted from “Light of the World: The Pope, The Church and The Signs Of The Times,” an interview with Pope Benedict XVI and Peter Seewald. All rights St. Ignatius Press (2010).

headline: 'The Break of Noon'
text: David Duchovny performs an excerpt from Neil LaBute's new play. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Placenta Structure and Gestation Linked
text: Some mammals have a longer gestation period than others in part because of the structure of the mother’s placenta, according to new research published in The American Naturalist.

headline: Palin Rules Out Another Couric Interview
text: Sarah Palin has a message for Katie Couric, the CBS anchorwoman: Don’t even bother asking.

headline: Video: A First Look at ‘Spider-Man’
text: A video posted Monday on the Facebook page of the new Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” offers a glimpse of what to date has been one of the season’s biggest secrets: what does the show look like?

headline: For Jets Fans Who Left Early, Regrets and Recriminations
text: It was utter euphoria for New York Jets fans after Mark Sanchez drove the team downfield with less than a minute remaining and pulled out a miraculous victory over the Houston Texans at New Meadowlands Stadium on Sunday.

headline: Defenders of Earmarks Point to Urgent Needs That Would Not Be Met
text: ST. LOUIS  With their vote last week to support a moratorium on earmarks, House and Senate Republicans are taking aim at a popular target: the much-criticized system for distributing federal money that reflects politicians’ clout as much as the merits of projects in their districts.

headline: The Price of a Smile
text: Dentist and orthodontists have embraced a new technology in dental radiology. But some experts are concerned about excessive radiation exposure among younger patients.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Jovins Lin Dorestan
text: Mr. Dorestan was standing in the doorway of his home in Haiti when the earthquake struck on January 12, killing hundreds of thousands. He came uncomfortably close to being one of them.

headline: Small Player on Wall Street Carves Out a Niche
text: The energy industry’s love for shale gas has been in evidence in recent years. Companies like Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron have poured billions of dollars into deals to give them access to acreage in the Marcellus Shale and other shale formations.

headline: Growing a Forest, and Harvesting Jobs
text: IXTLÁN de JUÁREZ, Mexico — As an unforgiving midday sun bore down on the pine-forested mountains here, a half-dozen men perched across a steep hillside wrestled back mounds of weeds to uncover wisps of knee-high seedlings.

headline: Lincoln Speaks
text: The sphinx kept his silence as long as he could, even after his election to the presidency was established beyond all doubt. But though he tried to maintain the semblance of a normal life — he was observed buying hair tonic at the drug store on Nov. 10 — he was in the maw of history now. Every act, every word commanded attention as the storm clouds gathered.

headline: In Sliver of Indonesia, Public Embrace of Judaism
text: MANADO, Indonesia  A new, 62-foot-tall menorah, possibly the world’s largest, rises from a mountain overlooking this Indonesian city, courtesy of the local government. Flags of Israel can be spotted on motorcycle taxi stands, one near a six-year-old synagogue that has received a face-lift, including a ceiling with a large Star of David, paid for by local officials.

headline: Stampede in Cambodia Leaves Hundreds Dead
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  More than 300 people were killed and hundreds more were injured in a stampede at an annual water festival in Cambodia that the prime minister on Tuesday called the nation’s worst tragedy since the murderous Khmer Rouge regime more than three decades ago.

headline: Pope’s Comments on Condoms Sow Confusion
text: ROME  In a papacy troubled by communications missteps, Pope Benedict XVI’s unprecedented new book of interviews with a German journalist sought to clarify matters by going straight to the source.

headline: Adviser Pleads Guilty in Pay-to-Play Pension Scheme
text: Hank Morris, a central player in a pay-to-play scheme involving the New York State pension fund, will return $19 million to the fund as part of a plea agreement approved in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Monday.

headline: New Poll Suggests Shift in Public Views on T.S.A. Procedures
text: The White House has begun to push back on the notion that there is a massive backlash against the T.S.A.’s new security procedures, citing a CBS News poll, released last week, which had shown 4 out of 5 Americans in favor of full-body screening machines, which the government refers to as “advanced imaging technology”.

headline: New Trade Group’s Focus Will Be Marijuana Industry
text: DENVER  It is being called the green rush. With more states moving to legalize medical marijuana, the business of growing and dispensing it is booming, even as much of the rest of the economy struggles.

headline: Philip Hoffman, Fearless Surfing Pioneer, Dies at 80
text: Philip Hoffman, whose pioneering big-wave riding in Hawaii in the 1950s charted the way for surfing pilgrimages to Oahu’s North Shore from around the world, died on Nov. 10 in Mission Viejo, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Do Governors Influence Presidential Elections?
text: The Republicans’ ability to pick up governorships this year has been discussed as a potential setback for President Obama’s presumed 2012 campaign for re-election — the idea being that a state’s governor can use his or her own political operation to boost the chances of their party’s presidential nominee.

headline: For Harrah’s I.P.O., Investors Are Wary
text: Conventional wisdom holds that investors have poor memories: they can be duped every few years with variations on the same financial trick. Refreshingly, the market for initial public offerings may be prove to be an exception. In what’s shaping up as the year of the see-through public offering, or C3PO for short, a record number of companies look set to abort their market debuts as investors wise up.

headline: Affirmative Action in South Africa
text: Celia Dugger reports on how affirmative action policy at the University of Cape Town has turned into a national debate on how to erase racial divides that linger 16 years after the end of apartheid.

headline: Jon Miller Declines ESPN’s Radio Offer
text: Jon Miller, whose contract as the voice of ESPN’s “Sunday Night Baseball” was not renewed earlier this month, has declined ESPN’s offer to continue to call baseball on ESPN Radio.

headline: What to Expect in the Holiday Travel Chaos
text: THE day before Thanksgiving is usually the busiest air travel day of the year, as leisure fliers flood into the system and many business travelers wrap up road trips. Holiday periods always bring some uncertainty, especially if there’s bad weather. But now, the new procedures at security checkpoints have added to the confusion. So I thought some tips for travel during the holiday period might be in order.

headline: Israel Enacts Bill to Force Referendum on a Treaty
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s right-leaning Parliament approved legislation late Monday that could hamper the leadership’s ability to seal future peace deals with the Palestinians or Syria.

headline: Campus That Apartheid Ruled Faces a Policy Rift
text: CAPE TOWN  The University of Cape Town was once a citadel of white privilege on the majestic slopes of Devil’s Peak. At the height of apartheid, it admitted few black or mixed-race students, and they were barred from campus dormitories, even forbidden to attend medical school postmortems on white corpses.

headline: Medtronic to Buy the Rest of Ardian
text: Medtronic Inc., the heart device maker, said it would acquire Ardian, a closely held company developing a hypertension device that kills nerves near the kidney.

headline: Qantas Returns A380 Planes to Use
text: Qantas, Australia’s largest carrier, said it will begin to return its Airbus A380 superjumbo jetliners to service this coming Saturday, 23 days after the blow-out of an engine on one of the planes forced an emergency landing in Singapore.

headline: A Manager to Push the Mets in the Right Direction
text: Terry Collins was hot. This was 1998, when Collins was managing the Angels, a team with a grinder’s mentality that clawed for a division title all summer. The Angels had handily beaten the lowly Detroit Tigers one night, and Collins caught the highlights on cable. He did not like what he saw.

headline: In Texas Baseball Bankruptcy Case, an Annoyed Judge
text: On July 9, D. Michael Lynn, the judge in the Texas Rangers’ bankruptcy, called the lawyers in the case to his chambers. He was acerbic, witty and caustic. But most of all he was frustrated.

headline: Don’t Agree With Verdict? It’s Injustice!
text: Peter T. King, the Republican congressman from Long Island, and the Rev. Al Sharpton rarely land in the same paragraph, let alone on common ground. But those two quite different men seem to be of one mind when it comes to the American court system. Justice for them means getting the results they want. Anything else qualifies, by definition, as injustice.

headline: Dentists Embrace New Device
text: The cone beam CT scanner’s popularity has grown in part from misinformation about its safety and efficacy.

headline: A Safe Haven in Cartoon Confidants
text: For months, psychologists struggled to reach the eight year old boy in the burn unit of the Pediatric Hospital of Tacubaya, in Mexico City. He had been discovered in the basement of a house, tied to a water tank after being burned along the backs of both legs with a clothes iron by his uncle and aunt, who were later arrested. Every time an adult tried to talk about his abuse, the boy would turn away and repeat, “No, no, no, no.” One day, a therapist said to a colleague, “Nothing is working. Let’s try Dulas.”

headline: A Cheaper Plan at Netflix Offers Films for Online Only
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Netflix said Monday that it was introducing a subscription plan for customers who want to watch movies only online, underscoring yet another step away from its roots in DVD rentals by mail.

headline: A New Leader Confronts Catholics’ Disaffection
text: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York, elected president of the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops last week, said Monday that the bishops faced the urgent task of stopping the huge exodus of Roman Catholics from the church of their birth.

headline: City to Solicit Proposals on Bike Sharing
text: The Bloomberg administration is set to move ahead on Tuesday with plans to create a large-scale bike-sharing program that would make hundreds or even thousands of bicycles available for public use throughout New York City  a nimble, novel form of mass transit that has already become mainstream in cities like Washington and Paris.

headline: Viewers May Be Willing to Watch More Ads Online. Lots More.
text: VIEWERS of television shows on the Web have grown accustomed to 15- and 30-second commercial breaks  a fraction of the time given for commercials on traditional TV. Would they accept TV-style ad loads?

headline: Edwards and Holmes Are Making Headlines for the Right Reasons
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A pair of starting wide receivers obtained with considerable risk have rewarded the Jets. Neither Santonio Holmes nor Braylon Edwards will win any Mr. Congeniality awards, but in terms of productivity, in terms of value, they are becoming what the Jets envisioned when they acquired them.

headline: What Patients Might Want to Ask the Dentist About X-Rays
text: The Food and Drug Administration and other experts suggest asking the following questions in order to reduce radiation exposure:

headline: Radiation Worries for Children in Dentists’ Chairs
text: Because children and adolescents are particularly vulnerable to radiation, doctors three years ago mounted a national campaign to protect them by reducing diagnostic radiation to only those levels seen as absolutely necessary.

headline: Fed Adopts Political Tactics on Critics
text: WASHINGTON  Faced with unusually sharp ideological attacks after its latest bid to stimulate the economy, the Federal Reserve now faces a challenge far removed from the conduct of monetary policy: how to defend itself in a hyperpartisan environment without becoming overtly political.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Raid 3 Hedge Fund Offices
text: 8:42 p.m. | Updated

headline: In N.B.A. Union Chief’s View, a Lockout Is Imminent
text: An N.B.A. labor stoppage next summer is all but inevitable, and the players are preparing accordingly, the head of the players union said Monday.

headline: J. Crew Nears a Sale to Chairman and Buyout Firms
text: 9:15 p.m. | Updated J. Crew, the clothier of choice for the likes of Michelle Obama, is near a deal to sell itself for about $2.8 billion to the buyout firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Stampede Kills Hundreds in Cambodia
text: Thousands of people stampeded during a festival in the Cambodian capital, leaving hundreds dead and injured.

headline: Radiation in the Dentist Chair
text: A new scanning device that emits significantly more radiation than conventional methods is gaining popularity among dentists despite the potential risks to young patients, an examination by The New York Times has found.

headline: Loss of Nicks Is Another Hit to Giants’ Receiving Corps
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At the start of the season, the Giants had more receivers than they knew what to do with. Now they are hosting tryouts to try to help compensate for the loss of their top target.

headline: On the Economy, Some Credit Is Due
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Pilgrims’ America
text: To the Editor:

headline: College Costs, the Sequel
text: The questions readers put to my previous column on the supposed college cost crisis are best answered by economists. Accordingly, the editors and I have asked the economists whose book formed the basis of my remarks, Robert B. Archibald and David H. Feldman, to reply. — Stanley Fish

headline: Memories of Bush v. Gore
text: To the Editor:

headline: Deliberations Have Begun in Case Against DeLay
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Jurors began deliberating Monday in the money-laundering trial of Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader who was forced to resign five years ago after he was indicted here.

headline: Industries in Decline
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dim View of Betting on Start-Ups
text: “There’s too much money chasing too few deals.”

headline: Blocking Illegal Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sports Agent’s Loans to Poor Players Pose Concerns
text: The company of Scott Boras, baseball’s pre-eminent agent, provided tens of thousands of dollars in loans and payments to the families of poor Dominican teenage prospects, according to people with ties to Mr. Boras, raising questions about whether the company exploited the prospects and violated the rules of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

headline: New Rules Tell Insurers: Spend More on Care
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued new federal rules on Monday that will require many health insurance companies to spend more on medical care and allocate less to profits, executive compensation, marketing and overhead expenses.

headline: Pardon for Jim Morrison?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time to Revive Privacy Board to Protect Civil Liberties
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taliban Leader in Secret Talks Was an Impostor
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  For months, the secret talks unfolding between Taliban and Afghan leaders to end the war appeared to be showing promise, if only because of the appearance of a certain insurgent leader at one end of the table: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, one of the most senior commanders in the Taliban movement.

headline: At a Checkpoint, Terror Fears and Testy Travelers
text: BALTIMORE

headline: Miracle on 33rd Street
text: MAYOR MICHAEL BLOOMBERG and other dignitaries took up ceremonial sledgehammers and knocked over a ceremonial wall of blocks. This was last month, across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station, and the little drama was meant to symbolize the beginning of its end. Behind them were the wide stairs and Corinthian colonnade of the Farley Post Office, the intended home of Moynihan Station, a scheme that the mayor said “reflects the splendor and majesty of the city.” Representative Jerrold Nadler called the future station “a space worthy of New York.” Secretary of Transportation Ray LaHood was there to oversee this ridiculous impeachment as well. “Another step out of history’s shadow,” he said.

headline: Irish Debt Crisis Forces Collapse of Government
text: DUBLIN — The Irish government faced imminent collapse on Monday, only a day after it signed off on a $100 billion bailout, setting the stage for a new election early next year and injecting the threat of political instability into a European financial crisis that already has markets on edge.

headline: Group Offers Cuomo Ideas to Promote Openness
text: In cities and towns across New York and in hundreds of pages of policy documents, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo relished deconstructing the “dysfunction” of Albany during his campaign for governor.

headline: Sin and Taxes
text: This has been a great month for conversation. The Bipartisan Policy Center and the chairmen of the fiscal commission released big plans for reducing debt and reforming government. This has set off a deluge of interesting commentary about how we should govern ourselves in the coming century.

headline: Lawsuit Filed by Estate of Immigrant Killed on Long Island
text: The estate of the Ecuadorean immigrant who was stabbed to death in 2008 in a racially motivated attack in Patchogue, N.Y., filed a federal lawsuit on Monday, accusing Suffolk County, its Police Department and other agencies of violating his civil rights by failing to protect Hispanics in the same manner that they protected whites.

headline: Lottery Numbers
From Last Days With Angels to First Day at Citi Field
text: In the hours before his last game as a manager of a major league baseball team on Sept. 2, 1999, Terry Collins walked the streets of downtown Cleveland, ruminating over a way to end the dispiriting losing streak that had engulfed his splintered team, and what he would say to his players about it.

headline: State Didn’t Vet Advisers on Chancellor Pick for Conflicts
text: As new revelations surfaced about extensive ties between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and members of the panel evaluating his choice for school’s chancellor, state officials acknowledged on Monday that they did not screen the panel members for conflicts of interest or connections to the Bloomberg administration before appointing them.

headline: In California, Birth Defects Show No Link
text: SAN FRANCISCO  After an investigation, California officials said Monday that they could not determine a cause for nearly a dozen sometimes deadly birth defects in the small Central Valley town of Kettleman City, echoing preliminary findings the state announced earlier this year.

headline: Tuesday: Makeup of a Double Date
text: Oh, pooh. I’m not afraid of you. Why, you’re nothing but a pack of cards.— Alice

headline: Essence of Pinterland, a Terrain Both Warm and Flecked With Ice
text: What a joy to find actors so at ease with the uneasiness of Harold Pinter. In Karen Kohlhaas’s first-rate productions of Pinter’s “Collection” and “A Kind of Alaska” for the Atlantic Theater Company, five performers quietly send off distress signals with a fluency that leaves you grinning at such stylishly realized discomfort.

headline: Cameras Monitor Trespassing in Bus Lanes
text: Candid camera shots can create smiles. But for drivers who meander into bus lanes, new and unseen cameras are more likely to produce frowns.

headline: Rules of the Duel: When Facing Near-Certain Death, Employ an Impostor
text: Silly voices should be used sparingly in the theater, as they generally are in other realms of entertainment. There is a reason why the men of Monty Python and the various gagmeisters from “Saturday Night Live” deploy their comedy in sketch-sized doses. After listening to the shrill, artificial falsetto employed by Jeremy Strong in the title role of the new play “The Coward” for more than two hours, my ears were starved for silence. I felt as if I’d been listening to a musically challenged youngster in a long and unpromising first encounter with the flute.

headline: He’s Born-Again but Still Obnoxious
text: The road to salvation is flat and narrow in “The Break of Noon,” Neil LaBute’s single-tone study of a life after a near-death experience. In this new work from the prolific and undeniably talented Mr. LaBute, which opened on Monday at the Lucille Lortel Theater, the sole survivor of an office massacre (played by David Duchovny) hears the voice of God amid the carnage.

headline: Oil Spill Findings Released by Panel
text: WASHINGTON  The oil industry and the government were unprepared for a deepwater blowout and oil spill like the one this year in the Gulf of Mexico, leading to significant delays in capping the well and major environmental damage, the staff of the presidential spill commission concluded in two reports published on Monday.

headline: A Red-Carpet Jeweler Is Charged With Fraud
text: A Duchess of Newcastle diamond brooch, circa 1887. A gilded album commissioned by Marie Antoinette in 1781. A carved ivory, enamel and jeweled case made at the request of Czar Nicholas II in 1893.

headline: Losing a Leg, but Keeping His Drive to Succeed
text: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y.  Jovins Dorestan is lucky, and he knows it.

headline: David Nolan, 66, Is Dead; Started Libertarian Party
text: David Nolan, whose opposition to the Vietnam War and President Richard M. Nixon’s wage and price controls impelled him in 1971 to join with a few friends to found the Libertarian Party to fight against government power, died Sunday in Tucson. He was 66.

headline: 2010: The Year in Images
text: The optimism generated by a new face in the White House eroded through the year as wars, economic turmoil and natural disasters spread pain across the globe. There were bright moments, most notably the soccer World Cup in South Africa and the dramatic rescue of Chilean miners.

headline: A Gift From Long Ago
text: It was a half-century ago this month that John F. Kennedy won the presidency in a thrilling and heart-stoppingly close election against Richard Nixon. You’d probably be surprised at the number of Americans who are clueless about when Kennedy ran: “It was 1970, right?” “Wasn’t it in the ’40s, soon after the war?” Or whom he ran against: “Eisenhower?”

headline: Brian Marsden, Tracker of Comets, Dies at 73
text: Brian G. Marsden, who for decades was the go-to guy for thousands of stargazers when a comet or an asteroid would streak through the heavens  or, by his calculations, was supposed to  died Thursday in Burlington, Mass. He was 73 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

headline: Islamic Center Seeks 9/11 Recovery Grants for Lower Manhattan
text: The directors of the planned Islamic community center and mosque near ground zero have applied for grants from an agency tasked with helping Lower Manhattan recover from the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The request was for about $5 million, said a person with knowledge of the grant application.

headline: Germany: Reichstag Closed To Most Tourists
text: One of Berlin’s most popular tourist sites, the glass and steel dome and terrace of the Reichstag parliament building, was closed indefinitely to most tourists on Monday as part of Germany’s continued security crackdown, a parliamentary spokeswoman, Birgit Landskron, said. The decision to close those parts of the building, which offer stunning views of Berlin and attract thousands of visitors daily, was announced two days after the magazine Der Spiegel reported that Islamic radicals were planning a commando-style attack on the building similar to the 2008 raids in Mumbai, India, which left 170 people dead and 300 wounded. Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere criticized the report as “irresponsible speculation.”

headline: Rangers’ Del Zotto Struggles in Uneven Second Season
text: Rangers defenseman Michael Del Zotto was asked after a game this month how he had raised his plus-minus mark as high as plus-6 after a rookie season in which he had gone minus-20.

headline: Mexico: Doctor Mistakenly Killed By Police Seeking Assassins
text: An ophthalmologist in the Pacific state of Colima was accidentally shot dead by the police at a roadblock set up as part of the search for the assassins of an ex-governor, Colima’s governor said on Monday. He said officers shot Dr. Mario Eduardo Robles Gil, 56, when the doctor “made suspicious moves” in his S.U.V. at the roadblock near the home of former Gov. Silverio Cavazos Ceballos in the city of Colima. Mr. Cavazos was gunned down earlier Sunday by armed men who wounded the state’s economic development secretary.

headline: Massachusetts: Buyer Found for Wind Farm’s Energy
text: After five months of arguments, state utility regulators have approved a contract under which a utility, National Grid, will buy half the output of Cape Wind, which if built would be the nation’s first offshore wind farm. The initial price is 18.7 cents a kilowatt-hour, far above prevailing rates, but the state said that reduced pollution and stimulation of the economy made the price a good deal. The price could be lowered if the project gets a federal loan guarantee and its own costs fall. The per-kilowatt-hour charge will increase by 3.5 percent a year, for 15 years, and the company has the option of a 10-year renewal.

headline: Energy and the Lame Duck
text: This Congress’s record on energy and environmental issues is shameful. The Senate, paralyzed by Republican opposition and indifferent Democratic leadership, could not muster the 60 votes to pass legislation to reduce carbon emissions. It even failed to respond to the gulf oil spill.

headline: Treasury Hires Adviser on Sale of A.I.G. Stake
text: The Treasury Department has hired Greenhill & Company, a boutique investment bank, to advise it on the eventual sale of its holdings in the American International Group, according to a contract posted on the department’s Web site.

headline: The Power of the Hispanic Voter
text: Democrats were hurt in the midterm election by low turnouts or faltering support from voters who were young, black or female. But overwhelming support from Hispanic voters appears to have helped elect Democratic senators in Nevada, California, Colorado and possibly Washington State. Hispanic voters may have kept the Senate in Democratic hands.

headline: Our Constitutional Court
text: The Supreme Court ruling in the Citizens United case ranks with the woeful economy, the Tea Party and other forces that brought about tumultuous change in the recent elections. The case may prove more significant in the evolution of the court’s role in American law.

headline: Count the Ballots
text: Here we are, two weeks after the elections and five races in New York State still are not settled. Lawyers and party officials are camped out in boards of elections, and accusations of malfunctioning machines and flawed absentee votes grow more heated by the minute. It’s time to count the paper ballots. That is the best way to settle these disputes and get on with governing.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Palin for Real?
text: Jacob Weisberg, left, of Slate and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate Sarah Palin's cultural presence.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Hip Surgery Doesn’t Keep Knicks’ Walsh From Work
text: Donnie Walsh has a new right hip, an improving gait and an unambiguous message for anyone doubting his stamina: He is not retiring or slowing down and plans to be with the Knicks for the foreseeable future.

headline: Effort for Liberal Balance to G.O.P. Groups Begins
text: In what may prove a significant development for the 2012 elections, David Brock, a prominent Democratic political operative, says he has amassed $4 million in pledges over the last few weeks and is moving quickly to hire a staff to set up what he hopes will become a permanent liberal counterweight over the airwaves to the Republican-leaning outside groups that spent so heavily on this year’s midterm elections.

headline: Children’s Benadryl Tablets Recalled
text: Johnson & Johnson, the maker of health care products, has recalled about four million packages of cherry- and grape-flavored Children’s Benadryl allergy tablets and about 800,000 bottles of junior-strength Motrin caplets.

text: magnanimity •\ˌmag-nə-ˈni-mə-te\• noun

text: From the Asian Games to Monday Night Football, photographs from the day in sports.

headline: Myanmar’s Leading Dissident Reunites With Youngest Son
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Myanmar’s leading dissident, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was reunited with her youngest son on Tuesday after a decade-long separation during which she said she never felt that they had been apart.

headline: News Quiz | November 23, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: ‘Crisis Status’ in South Korea After North Shells Island
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean military went to “crisis status” on Tuesday and threatened military strikes after the North fired dozens of shells at a South Korean island, killing two of the South’s soldiers and setting off an exchange of fire in one of the most serious clashes between the two sides in decades.

headline: Investor Concern Persists in Euro Zone
text: PARIS — Investor concerns persisted Tuesday about the possible need for additional financial aid for countries in the euro area as Ireland prepared to release details of additional budget-cutting measures and Greece’s restructuring efforts met with approval from international lenders.

headline: Anglo Irish Bondholders Back Debt Swap
text: The Irish government’s plan to shift at least some of the burden of Anglo Irish Bank’s bad debt to bondholders has moved forward as one group has approved a deal that would leave the notes it holds worth one-fifth of their face value.

headline: ‘South of the Border,’ Unsettling Views
text: Julio Mitchel, 68, would be the first to admit that he is a bit prickly and has not been adept at managing his photographic career. His name is not branded. He doesn’t have a blog. There are no camera company sponsorships. And he doesn’t have gallery or agency representation.

headline: 29 New Zealand Miners Are Feared Dead
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  A second huge blast in a New Zealand coal mine on Wednesday would have killed any miners who may have survived an explosion days earlier, the authorities said.

headline: Church of England Opposes News Corp. on BSkyB
text: The Church of England says  it opposes the News Corporation’s plan to take control of the British satellite television provider BSkyB.

headline: How Do You Make the Best of Thanksgiving?
text: “Disastrously comical? Isn’t that the norm for Thanksgiving?” writes Florence Fabricant in her introduction to a Diner’s Journal blog post called “Dear FloFab: My Brother’s Girlfriend Hijacked Thanksgiving.” What cooking disasters and other comical moments have you experienced on Thanksgiving?

headline: Degrees of Separation From Climate Goals
text: In the weeks after the chaotic United Nations climate change summit meeting last December in Copenhagen, 140 nations endorsed the meeting’s goal of limiting the rise in global temperature from pre-industrial levels to 2 degrees Celsius or less in this century. Of those countries signing onto the so-called Copenhagen Accord, 85 made pledges to reduce their own greenhouse gas emissions and participate in international programs to help developing countries slow the rate of growth of their emissions.

headline: India’s Next Steps: Looking for a Stable Public Sector
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: At Paris Wine Salon, Swirling Small Producers
text: On the heels of the grape harvest, a special wine event will take oenophiles beyond their local liquor store to discover new vintages, regions and labels. The Salon des Vignerons Indépendants, which runs from Nov. 25 to 29 at Porte de Versailles (1 Place de la Porte de Versailles), will feature wines from over 1,000 small, independent producers.

headline: Cashman Speaks Mind a Second Straight Day
text: For Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, late November was not supposed to be devoted to an increasingly public standoff with the team’s star shortstop, Derek Jeter.

headline: Survivors of Stampede in Cambodia Recall Panic
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Injured survivors lay on the floors of hospitals here Tuesday, and the dead were loaded into coffins after one of the worst stampedes in recent years killed at least 378 people at a holiday celebration.

headline: Obama Heads to Kokomo to Tout Auto Bailout and Stimulus
text: If there was one message that appeared not to get through during the midterm elections, it was President Obama’s efforts to help the struggling economies of the industrial Midwest.

headline: Doing the Math on a Groupon Deal
text: I have been reading with great interest (especially here) the stories of retailers sharing their experiences using Groupon. For those of you not familiar with Groupon, the company partners with local businesses to send a daily coupon e-blast to its members. The members who buy the coupon get 50 to 70 percent off on a product or service, and Groupon splits the proceeds with the retailer — usually leaving the retailer with about 20 to 25 cents on the dollar of retail value.

headline: Ending Blackstone Talks, Dynegy Seeks New Buyer
text: 7:09 p.m. | Updated  Dynegy said on Tuesday that it would seek new takeover bids after it failed to gain enough shareholder support for a proposed $4.7 billion deal to sell itself to the Blackstone Group.

headline: ‘Exhausted’ Obama Supporter Loses Her Job
text: The political supporter who told President Obama that she was “exhausted” of defending him, becoming a voice for disappointed Americans this fall, has now become another casualty of the weak economy.

headline: A Winning, Cautious ‘Don Carlo’ at the Met
text: Though not without flaws, Verdi’s “Don Carlo” is the “Hamlet” of Italian opera. Every production of this profound and challenging work is a major venture for an opera company. The Metropolitan Opera has to be pleased, over all, with its new staging by the eminent English director Nicholas Hytner in his company debut, which opened on Monday and earned an enthusiastic ovation. No booing of the production team on this premiere night.

headline: South Korean Television Shows Damage From Exchange of Fire With North
text: Updated | 7:34 p.m. As my colleague Mark McDonald reports, North and South Korea exchanged artillery fire on Tuesday after dozens of shells fired from the North struck a South Korean island near the countries’ disputed maritime border. Officials in South Korea said two of their soldiers were killed, and at least 18 people were wounded, including three civilians.

headline: A Talent Burning Too Brightly, Too Young
text: London

headline: Conflict and Heartache in the I.C.U.
text: I’d be glad if a zillion people tuned in to watch “Facing Death,” an hour-long “Frontline” documentary airing on PBS Tuesday (at 9 or 10 p.m. in most places — check your local listings, or watch it online). I know that won’t happen; so many people still turn away from the subject. But half a zillion would be good, too.

headline: Namath Comments on Early Exits by  Jets Fans
