headline: Daily Pill Greatly Lowers AIDS Risk, Study Finds
text: Healthy gay men who took an anti-AIDS pill every day were well protected against contracting H.I.V. in a study suggesting that a new weapon against the epidemic has emerged.

headline: China Sets Tough Line in Climate Talks
text: BEIJING  Senior Chinese officials said on Tuesday that next week’s climate talks in Cancún, Mexico, would succeed only if the West agreed to transfer technology to developing countries like China and to take the lead in cutting emissions.

headline: Rattner Rails Against Cuomo
text: 9:50 a.m. | Updated When Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York filed charges against the financier Steven L. Rattner last week related to a kickback scheme involving the state’s pension fund, no one expected Mr. Rattner to take it sitting down.

headline: Wall Street Falls, Unsettled by Debt Crisis and Korea
text: Shares on Wall Street declined on Tuesday as heightened uncertainty over conflict in Asia and the debt crisis in Europe sent investors fleeing for safer assets.

headline: ‘Take a Lesson,’ Schwarznegger Says on Climate Change
text: California is just one of 50 states, but its economy, measured individually, is the eighth-biggest in the world, larger than that of Spain, Canada, Brazil, Russia, India or South Korea.

headline: Saudi Prince Says He Owns 1% of G.M.
text: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia is known for his big bets on companies like Citigroup. Now it seems he is swinging for the fences with General Motors.

headline: Yale and Peru Have Tentative Deal on Disputed Antiquities
text: For the second time in three years Yale University and the government of Peru have reached a tentative agreement on the return of a large group of artifacts excavated in 1912 at Machu Picchu by a Yale explorer.

headline: HAMPing Europe’s Periphery
text: The markets don’t seem impressed by the Irish bailout — nor should they be. As I read it, European policy makers are still — still! — viewing the crisis as a confidence problem, not a fundamental problem.

headline: Corporate Profits Were the Highest on Record Last Quarter
text: The nation’s workers may be struggling, but American companies just had their best quarter ever.

text: There they were, just as the man had said they would be, just as they were almost every night: two brown boots.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Where the Coyotes Dance and the Bats Roam
text: It’s too bad most of the nation’s “Nutcracker”s are all performed on the same few days of November and December; I could probably see a different one every day of the year. I’d already researched a wide range of productions when planning my “Nutcracker” marathon, which began last week.

headline: British Royal Wedding Set for April 29
text: LONDON  The date and location have been set: the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton is to take place on April 29 at Westminster Abbey.

headline: Sabotaging QE
text: When short-term interest rates are up against the zero lower bound, whatever power the Fed has to influence the economy comes largely from its ability to affect expectations. This is true even for Bernanke-style quantitative easing: you can’t really push down longer-term yields unless the market believes that you’re going to keep buying until the rates are where you want them. It’s even more true when it comes to credibly raising expected rates of inflation.

headline: Off the Menu: Fish Tag
text: The name of Michael Psilakis‘s new restaurant, Fish Tag, opening on Monday at 222 West 79th Street, refers to the little metal or plastic label attached to each whole fish as it is delivered to the restaurant. Only Mr. Psilakis does not have any whole fish, head and tail included, on his menu. He said that whole fish might be offered as a special.

headline: New Yorkers Are Wary of Black as Schools Chief, Poll Finds
text: While Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has steadfastly pressed the case that Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive, is qualified to become the city’s next schools chancellor, many New Yorkers seem to strenuously disagree.

headline: Portrait of the Author as a Very, Very, Very Young Man
text: When you were 9 years old you probably spent your time, what, wondering whether Superman could outrun the Flash and which typewriter keys to press in what order to produce naughty words? (O.K., that’s what we were doing.) Meanwhile, at that same age, a budding author who would later come to be known by his full name, David Foster Wallace, was already exploring multiple identities and experimental forms of fiction.

headline: We Three Things | Follow the Grid
text: Grids might be the musical scales of the visual arts, the underlying metric by which space is paced, measured and intuited. We are confronted by grids every day, in design, science and nature. No surprise, then, that grids are a support system and an inspiration to many artists and craftspeople.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –John Gutfreund tells TheStreet that authorities now take a “laissez-faire,” attitude toward criminal activity. “It’s not necessarily a rule of law and order as it once was. Now whatever you do you can get away with,” he says.

headline: Pushing Back Against Bike Lanes
text: Tuesday will be balmy, with highs in the 60s, but overcast with a good chance of showers.

headline: J. Crew Shares Pop; Could Another Buyer Surface?
text: J. Crew shares are up significantly in premarket trading on Tuesday, following DealBook’s scoop that the company is near a deal to sell itself to its chief executive and its former owner.

headline: What a Search Warrant Means
text: The execution of search warrants at three hedge funds marks a significant escalation of the government inquiry into insider trading. By using a search warrant rather than a grand jury subpoena, prosecutors have signaled there is a good chance that securities laws were violated, and they want evidence gathered quickly and in a way that avoids the possibility that some material might be destroyed.

headline: A Line in the Sea Divides the Two Koreas
text: Updated | 5:21 p.m. The residents of South Korea’s Yeonpyeong Island, who rushed to air-raid shelters on Tuesday as they came under attack from North Korea, are well aware that they live on the edge of a geopolitical fault line. The island is in disputed waters claimed by both countries, just two miles from the so-called Northern Limit Line, a maritime border the North has never recognized, and only eight miles from the North Korean coast.

headline: Is It Big Brother or Just an Algorithm?
text: A reader just wrote to complain. In Gmail, he wrote, “I have attached photo,” but then clicked Send without actually attaching anything. A message popped up: “You wrote ‘I have attached’ in your message, but there are no files attached. Send anyway?”

text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: F.D.I.C. Says Many Small Lenders Are Still at Risk
text: Even as the nation’s biggest banks have rapidly recovered, hundreds of small lenders remain at risk, according to the government’s latest report card on the financial industry.

headline: U.S. Home Sales Fell Sharply in October

headline: Macy’s Can Give Thanks Its Parade Is on a Thursday
text: The city’s parades have felt the sting of cost-cutting this year. In February, citing the need to trim overtime costs, the Police Department announced that parades would have to shorten their length by 25 percent. Organizers grudgingly obliged. The first-to-be-affected Tartan Day parade, celebrating the nation’s Scots, gamely trimmed its route by three blocks, to 10. The National Puerto Rican Day Parade lost seven blocks. The Gay Pride parade lost 16.

headline: Art on the Scale of the Climate Challenge

headline: Where a Bird Played Sax, Now Others Find Refuge
text: There are two signs in front of 151 Avenue B, a row house in the East Village facing Tompkins Square Park. One is a bronze plaque identifying the building as a former home of the jazz legend Charlie Parker, who lived in the ground-floor apartment from 1950 to 1954.

headline: Australia Drops Criminal Investigation of Paul Hogan
text: While it may not be the best time to be an actor who has lived in Australia – Russell Crowe’s latest movie just tanked, and let’s not even get started on Mel Gibson – things are looking up somewhat for Paul Hogan. On Tuesday Australian officials said they had dropped a criminal investigation into the finances of Mr. Hogan, the “Crocodile Dundee” star who shaped 1980s-era America’s perception of the Land Down Under, The Associated Press reported.

text: At the Dot Earth blog, Andy Revkin describes a series of art installations organized by the advocacy group 350.org to call attention to the global nature of the climate change challenge. Some of them are visible from space.

headline: Behind the Poster: A Grown-Up Alice in ‘Wonderland’
text: Lewis Carroll’s Alice gets an extreme makeover in the coming Broadway musical “Wonderland.” The show, which is to begin performances at the Marquis Theater on March 21, is about a frazzled children’s book writer named Alice who travels to a place called Wonderland in an attempt to revive her relationships with her estranged husband and distant daughter.

headline: Theater Books
text: The ephemeral nature of theater makes it hard to give gifts that will endure even as long as a tie or a bottle of cologne, but this fall has seen a handful of new theater-related books that make fine gift choices for a footlight addict.

headline: After J. Crew, Who’s Next?
text: With the J. Crew sale to TPG Capital, Leonard Green & Partners and Millard S. Drexler now official, investors and analysts are already looking forward to the next possible buyout in the retail industry.

headline: With Southwest, Microsoft Takes Photos on the Fly
text: In another example of its efforts to behave more like a consumer marketer, Microsoft is teaming up with Southwest Airlines for a holiday promotion that will take place in 26 airports around the country as well as online.

text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 12. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Hockey’s Code Uncovered
text: Every fan has heard about hockey’s unwritten code — the set or traditional rules of engagement that determine when, who and how players are expected to fight. Most players follow it. A few dare to break it. But everyone knows about it.

headline: Good Touch, Bad Touch, T.S.A. Touch
text: As parents of young children prepare to join the throngs at the nation’s airports on the upcoming Mother of All Travel Days, there’s a new complication. In addition to remembering to pack snacks and toys and diapers, worrying about changing those diapers on a plane with no table in the restroom, and averting the glares of other travelers as your own toddler melts down, now there is another potential obstacle between you and your turkey — the new T.S.A. screening procedures.

headline: Now Curating | Olivia Palermo for Boutiques.com
text: Last week, Google unveiled its e-commerce fashion venture, Boutiques.com, at the heart of which are online stores curated by celebrities and tastemakers. The Moment asked Olivia Palermo, whose boutique is already the second most followed, about her involvement with the much ballyhooed new site. “The process was a ton of fun,” Palermo said, “but I actually spent hours playing with it. It’s quite addictive!” No stranger to online shopping, Palermo has mostly been browsing on net-a-porter.com and matchesfashion.com for Giambattista Valli, Christopher Kane and the French label Maje to feature in her boutique, her goal being to make scouring the racks easy and accessible for shoppers with similar taste. “Whether it’s a Marchesa gown straight off the runway or a basic Topshop piece, everything is at your fingertips,” she says. She appreciates Google’s complex algorithms, which show browsers alternative items should the ones they want be unavailable or too pricey. The downside? “It’s accessible and free — until you start buying all the items you find.”

headline: Steven Rattner Dishes on the Chevrolet Volt
text: Steven L. Rattner, as President Obama’s former auto bailout chief, worked with General Motors as it struggled to find its footing amid a bankruptcy reorganization in 2008. During that time, the company was also developing the Chevrolet Volt, an innovative plug-in hybrid car that is going on sale soon.

headline: Theater Tickets

So why not take a more forthright route and let some masters of eloquence — playwrights and the accomplished actors who interpret them on Broadway — deliver your message for you? Here, some alternative ways of saying it with tickets.

headline: For One Day, the Chancellor Pick Was a Principal

Black, the chancellor-nominee of New York City’s public schools and the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, has been criticized for her lack of experience in her new field, 10 years ago, she got something of an education in education — at least eight hours’ worth — at what is now Junior High School 125 Henry Hudson.

headline: Tanks to Afghanistan: The More Things Change…
text: The New York Times, Aug. 27, 1980“Hundreds of Soviet tanks and other vehicles based near Kabul were reported rolling toward Sarobi.”

headline: Tanks to Afghanistan – Analysis
text: From Kabul to Kandahar, the Afghan countryside is dotted with the burned-out hulks of Soviet tanks. They are an obvious reminder of failed strategy, a nimble foe able to outfight big armored vehicles on rough terrain, and a lost war.

headline: Nontraditional Black Friday Deals
text: It seems Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals increasingly aren’t just about televisions, toys and appliances. Here are a host of nontraditional items you may be able to find discounts on this weekend.

headline: Erruh in duh Noo Yawk Times
text: OK, not sure it’s exactly an error. But I finally caught up with this piece on unlearning your New York accent, and it has people pronouncing water “wattuh”.

headline: Another Longtime Democratic Congressman Concedes
text: In an upset in southern Texas, Blake Farenthold, a former radio show co-host with no experience in politics, has officially beaten Representative Solomon P. Ortiz, a Democrat who has held his seat in the 27th Congressional District, a Democratic stronghold, since 1982. Mr. Ortiz had demanded a recount after trailing Mr. Farenthold by roughly 800 votes on Election Day; a six-county recheck did not significantly alter the results. Mr. Farenthold’s victory brings the Republican gains in the House of Representatives to at least 62 seats.

headline: The Twitterverse Reacts to Its Inability to Purchase Kanye West Tickets
text: Even faster than the spread of the news that Kanye West would be playing a hitherto-unannounced show at the intimate Bowery Ballroom in Manhattan on Tuesday night was the speed with which those tickets sold out on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: TimesCast | November 23, 2010
text: North and South Korea exchange artillery fire; American  companies have their most profitable quarter ever; and News Corps invests in an iPad-only newspaper.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Mary Wells
text: While not every Motown aficionado thinks Chris Clark got all the obscurity she deserved, there is other glue that binds. No one disputes that romanticizing the eat-or-get-eaten early days of the label’s artists was a great act of myth building. Diana Ross’s father got so tired of hearing what a rough childhood she had in Detroit’s Brewster Projects, he told one of her biographers how nice the lawns and courtyards there were. “The apartment we were in had three bedrooms, a full basement, a living room, kitchen and dinette,” Fred Ross said. “It wasn’t so terrible at all, believe me.”

headline: Q&A: Spending the Holidays in Africa
text: Q.

headline: What’s Baffling Is Nastiness of Jeter Talks
text: Hal Steinbrenner and Casey Close agree that Derek Jeter is a classic Yankee. So let’s look to a classic movie for guidance on the mess that has become Jeter’s contract negotiations.

headline: Fraud Inquiries Focus on Public-Works Hiring in New York
text: Two of the nation’s major construction companies are under federal investigation, suspected of defrauding government programs on some of the biggest public-works projects in and around New York City, according to people briefed on the inquiries.

headline: Irish Leader Beats Back Early Move to Oust Him
text: DUBLIN  As fears about Ireland’s political stability rattled Europe on Tuesday, the party of Prime Minister Brian Cowen brushed aside calls for his immediate ouster on Tuesday and urged the government to approve wrenching budget- and deficit-reduction plans in order to secure a $100 billion bailout from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Chic Peek | Nicki Minaj Interview
text: T’s Online Director Horacio Silva grills hip-hop sexplosion Nicki Minaj this morning about “Pink Friday,” her new CD and limited-edition MAC lipstick of the same name (and her feud with Lil’ Kim). Log on next Friday to read the interview and to watch an exclusive behind-the-scenes video of Minaj being photographed by the legendary Paul Jasmin for T’s Holiday 2010 issue.

headline: Nevada Retains Highest Unemployment Rate
text: With a jobless rate north of 14 percent, Nevada had the highest state unemployment in the country once again last month, according to a Labor Department report.

headline: After Condom Remarks, Vatican Confirms Shift
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI clearly acknowledged on Tuesday that the need to prevent diseases like AIDS could outweigh the church’s long opposition to the use of condoms.

headline: Condoms, Catholicism and Casuistry
text: Amid the ongoing furor surrounding Pope Benedict’s comments about condom use in his latest book-length interview with Peter Seewald, it’s worth noting that this isn’t the first time that Seewald and Benedict (then Joseph Ratzinger) have discussed the question of contraception. In their first interview, published as “Salt of the Earth” in 1996, Seewald asked Ratzinger if he understood why so many Christians find the Church’s teaching on birth control so incomprehensible. The then-cardinal replied as follows:

headline: Yankees Won’t Offer Arbitration to Jeter
text: The Yankees have decided not to offer salary arbitration to shortstop Derek Jeter, according to two people in baseball briefed on the matter. The two spoke on condition of anonymity because they did not want to jeopardize their access to sensitive information.

headline: Partisan Rift Mires Product Safety Database Plan
text: For decades, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has gathered a trove of complaints about potentially dangerous products, from cribs to Chinese-made drywall. But for the most part, the information has not been made public because of a federal law that requires a manufacturer’s approval before it can be released.

headline: Somalis in Twin Cities Shaken by Charges of Sex Trafficking
text: MINNEAPOLIS  When the girl now identified as Jane Doe 2 came under their control in 2006, at age 12, the Somali Outlaws and the Somali Mafia gangs set a firm rule: Their members could have sex with her for nothing; others had to pay with money or drugs.

headline: A Baby Incubator Made From Car Parts
text: It is said that coffee, Coke and cigarettes can be found anywhere in the world. The presence of another C — car parts — recently led a team of industrial designers, doctors and rural heath care experts to conceive a device that could significantly lower infant mortality rates in developing nations.

headline: Burris May Join the Chicago Mayor Mix
text: CHICAGO – There may be an unlikely addition to the long list of people who wish to replace Mayor Richard M. Daley, who has ruled this city for two decades. Supporters of Roland W. Burris, who is packing up his United States Senate office this week to come home to Chicago, have filed the necessary paperwork for him to seek the city’s top job.

headline: Cancun, Congress and Hard Climate Facts
text: In a news conference in Washington on Monday, Todd Stern, the Obama administration’s lead negotiator in talks aimed at a new climate treaty, provided some insights into issues and (limited) opportunities that will shape the next round of negotiations, which begins in Cancun, Mexico, at the end of the month. (I learned about the briefing through the Earth Journalism Network, which you can follow on Twitter.)

headline: Chancellor Nominee Has Sold Her Connecticut Home
text: As Cathleen P. Black endures scrutiny of her proposed appointment to become New York City’s next schools chancellor, she has one less house to escape from the pressures of her appointment this holiday weekend.

headline: Collins Begins Job With a Nod to Leyland
text: Terry Collins introduced himself as the Mets’ 20th manager on Tuesday by saying, “I’m not the evil devil that people made me out to be.” The Mets and their fans will tolerate a dark side if Collins is the man to reverse the franchise’s steep decline since it was one victory from the World Series in 2006.

headline: American Speech: The Language of Traffic Policeman (1962)
text: by Don Dempsey, San Diego State College

headline: Report: Banks Selling Off More Troubled Assets
text: Banks across the country are increasingly unloading toxic investments as stronger capital levels allow the institutions to clear their books, according to a report issued Tuesday.

headline: Fed Debated a Target for Inflation
text: WASHINGTON  Nearly three weeks before they announced a $600 billion effort to shore up the economy, Federal Reserve officials debated whether to adopt formal targets for inflation and long-term interest rates, and whether the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, should “hold occasional press briefings.”

headline: Police Arrest Suspects in Plot Against Belgium
text: BRUSSELS  In a series of early morning raids, the police in three European countries arrested 11 people on Tuesday, saying that some were part of an international jihadist group planning a terrorist attack in Belgium and that others were members of a Chechen group.

headline: USA Network Extends Tolerance Campaign
text: The cable channel USA Network is sharing details of how it plans to extend Characters Unite, a public service campaign that seeks to promote tolerance and respect while fighting discrimination.

headline: Adrien Brody Prevails in Horror-Film Lawsuit
text: Not coming soon to a theater or video store near you, by order of a federal court: the Dario Argento horror movie “Giallo,” which one of its stars, Adrien Brody, has successfully blocked from distribution or sale in the United States, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Cambodia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Cambodia, South Korea and Algeria.

headline: Airgas Gets January Meeting Invalidated
text: The Delaware Supreme Court unanimously reversed a lower court holding on Tuesday that Airgas shareholders had properly amended their bylaws to have the next annual meeting on Jan. 15.

headline: The M.V.P. and the Missing Month
text: As Ben Shpigel of The Times reports, Josh Hamilton of the Texas Rangers collected 22 of 28 first-place votes in balloting announced Tuesday to win the American League Most Valuable Player award, beating Miguel Cabrera of Detroit, who received five, by 96 points. Robinson Cano of the Yankees finished third, and Toronto’s Jose Bautista, who earned the other first-place vote, finished fourth.

headline: Monthly Record Seen for Chinese Coal Imports
text: After my Monday article on the striking growth of coal exports to China and the implications for greenhouse gas emissions, I heard from Commodore Research and Consultancy, a New York-based firm that tracks the flow of coal to China on a week-by-week basis.

headline: Babies on Airlines: Safety Seats Are Safer Than a Lap
text: SHOULD babies be buckled into a safety seat on airplanes instead of sitting in their parents’ laps?

headline: General Greene’s Morgenstern to Open Goat Town in the East Village
text: Nicholas Morgenstern, who just sold his interest in the General Greene in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to his partner, will open Goat Town on Dec. 2 with Joel Hough, a former chef de cuisine at Cookshop. The restaurant will move into the space that had been Butcher Bay and Seymour Burton in the East Village.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Chowhound: A lively thread, started by a home cook facing a 35-pound turkey. – Julia Moskin

headline: No Bomb Found at Boston Airport After Evacuation
text: Bomb-sniffing dogs alerted authorities to a suspicious package on Tuesday in the Delta Cargo building at Boston Logan International Airport, forcing the evacuation of the building, airport officials said.

headline: S Is for Self-Promoter: Cookie Monster Wants to Host ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: If “Saturday Night Live” can extend a hosting invitation to Scarlett Johansson – who didn’t even have a new project to promote on her most recent go-round – then why not Cookie Monster, who is out there busting his blue fur on “Sesame Street” five days a week? In this latest video from Sesame Workshop (which we were pointed to by Mashable.com), that lovably greedy Muppet makes his best case for why he deserves the nod, sending up “S.N.L.” segments like “MacGruber” and “Weekend Update,” and giving a musical performance in the guise of Monster Gaga. Most shrewdly, Cookie Monster also remembers to thank the “S.N.L” executive producer Lorne Michaels in his closing credits.

headline: Your Worst New York Apartments, Remembered Fondly
text: Two weeks ago, Constance Rosenblum wrote about several 20-something New Yorkers who were struggling to live comfortably in the city’s rental market and asked readers to share their stories and photos of terrible New York apartments.

headline: Corporate Profits Hit Record High
text: New numbers from the U.S. Commerce Department show record-breaking corporate profits this quarter.

headline: Obama, in Indiana, Says Jobs Policy Worked
text: KOKOMO, Ind.—President Obama came to this manufacturing town in the Midwest on Tuesday to say that his jobs agenda and economic policies were putting the economy on the right track.

headline: Deal for J. Crew Allows It to Go Shopping
text: J. Crew is on sale for the holidays.

headline: What Really Happened? Comparing Stories of the First Thanksgiving
text: Overview | Why are there so many different interpretations of what happened on the first Thanksgiving? What values do the various versions reflect? In this lesson, students will examine different versions of the story of the first Thanksgiving, evaluate the evidence that supports each version and discuss why the history of Thanksgiving is so contentious.

headline: Aggrieved Fliers Ask, ‘What Now?’
text: As if air travel could get any worse.

headline: U.S. Firm in Support of South Korea
text: WASHINGTON — In response to the artillery exchange between North and South Korea, the Pentagon on Tuesday stuck closely to a carefully calibrated diplomatic script offered overnight by the White House.

headline: There’s Sweeps Week, and Then There’s Palin Week
text: For the blossoming Sarah Palin media empire, this week is the busiest to date.

headline: Beatles Sales Strong, But Not Blockbuster, So Far
text: The Beatles on iTunes are a hit. Sort of.

headline: A Steep Drop in Ratings for ‘Sarah Palin’s Alaska’
text: As Sarah Palin prepared to start a book tour Tuesday for her next best-seller, “America by Heart,” there was sobering news about one of her other products, a reality show called “Sarah Palin’s Alaska.”

headline: Ireland’s Debt to Foreign Banks Is Still Unknown
text: Ireland is deeply in debt to British and German banks, but just how much is a mystery. Is it hundreds of billions, as official figures suggest? Or are the sums more modest, as many banks insist?

headline: Salazar Aims to Streamline Offshore Wind
text: Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar announced a broad-based initiative on Tuesday aimed at accelerating the development of offshore wind power projects on the Outer Continental Shelf along the nation’s Atlantic coast.

headline: Hamilton Named M.V.P. Of the American League
text: Josh Hamilton missed 25 of the Texas Rangers’ final 30 games because of two broken ribs. His absence during the stretch run barely mattered to voters from the Baseball Writers’ Association of America, who followed a forceful precedent set last year with Joe Mauer of Minnesota, Hamilton’s predecessor as the American League’s most valuable player.

headline: 'Metamorphosis'
text: A scene from a reimagining of the Kafka novel from Vesturport Theater of Reykjavik and the Lyric Hammersmith of London. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Holiday Party Treats
text: A collection of appetizers that can be prepared in 20 minutes or less. Recipes by Mark Bittman.

headline: The Latest on the White House Staff Shuffle
text: President Obama’s top political advisers are planning an earlier-than-expected swap even as the White House moves to reshape the administration’s economic team.

headline: A Luxury Leader Shies From an Unwelcome Suitor
text: PARIS  In the world of luxury brands, Hermès International has cultivated an image of purity by remaining true to its roots, shunning the mass production and outsourcing that many rivals have employed to improve profitability.

headline: Using Public Spaces as a Potty
text: As the mother of two sons, I have been grateful more than once over the years for the things that are easier about boys.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Cambodia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Cambodia, South Korea and Algeria.

headline: Analyst Tells Why He Rebuffed the F.B.I.
text: One of the figures in the government’s widening investigation of suspected insider trading discusses how he was visited by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He says he refused to cooperate in the investigation, and he asserts that as a result of having to disclose his involvement, his business “has been destroyed.”

headline: Ex-Chief of Comverse to Forfeit Nearly $48 Million
text: 7:51 p.m. | Updated  Jacob Alexander, the one-time chief of a telecommunications software maker who fled to Namibia to avoid charges related to stock option backdating, has agreed to forfeit nearly $48 million to settle a civil action by federal prosecutors.

headline: Because the Fat Lady Has to Eat
text: LINCOLN RISTORANTE is a large and glittery Italian restaurant that opened this fall under a swooping grass roof on the campus of Lincoln Center at a reported cost of $20 million, under the direction of the chef Jonathan Benno and his partners, the Patina Restaurant Group.

headline: Reviewing Lincoln Ristorante
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Krakatau Eruption From Space
text: NASA has released a photograph taken by its Earth Observing-1 satellite of the ongoing eruption at Anak Krakatau, one of many active Indonesian volcanoes, but one of particular interest because of its explosive history.

headline: 'Don Carlo'
text: Marina Poplavskaya and Roberto Alagna in an excerpt from Verdi's opera. (Video courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera)

headline: Unwelcome Spotlight Follows Tennessee Coach
text: Tennessee came to Manhattan this week hoping to alter the narrative of negativity surrounding Coach Bruce Pearl, shifting the focus to the Volunteers’ play on the court, not their issues off it.

headline: Tackling Mini-Med Policies
text: The recent decision by the Obama administration to allow health insurance companies to continue to sell so-called mini-med policies, those plans that sharply limit coverage, remains controversial. The plans, which often cap benefits at just a few thousand dollars a year, do not comply with some of the new rules under the federal health care law.

headline: Eviction of Palestinian Family, After a Legal Battle, Underlines Tensions Over Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli police officers evicted a Palestinian family from their home in a predominantly Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem on Tuesday morning, and a group of Jewish settlers moved into the property at night.

headline: U.N. Reports Decrease in New H.I.V. Infections
text: Fewer people are being infected with the virus that causes AIDS than at the epidemic’s peak, but progress against the disease is still halting and fragile, the United Nations’ AIDS-fighting agency reported Tuesday.

headline: Dwight Garner’s Top 10 Books of 2010
text: THE BEST OF IT: NEW AND SELECTED POEMS by Kay Ryan. Kay Ryan’s poems are as slim as runway models, so tiny you could almost make them Twitter messages. They are also, as it happens, riddled with heartbreak and loss, and possess an essential gawkiness that, despite their wit, draws you close. Ms. Ryan’s poems are, in 2010, about as good as American poetry gets. (Grove, $24)

headline: Michiko Kakutani’s Top 10 Books of 2010
text: LIFE by Keith Richards with James Fox. Written with uncommon candor, eloquence and humor, this electrifying memoir channels its author’s love of music, even as it creates an indelible portrait of the era when rock ’n’ roll came of age. It’s a book that does a high-def, high-velocity job of conjuring the past, be it the author’s small-town childhood or the madness that was life on the road with the Rolling Stones — a book in which Mr. Richards has magically translated the fierce emotion of his guitar playing to the page. (Little, Brown & Company, $29.99)

headline: Janet Maslin’s Top 10 Books of 2010
text: THE IMPERFECTIONISTS by Tom Rachman. This debut novel by a former journalist is a splendid original, the hilarious yet wrenching half-century story of a newspaper’s rise and fall. But this book is bigger than the life cycle of any one profession. Mr. Rachman structures his story so wittily and unpredictably that figuring out where it’s headed is half the fun. (Dial Press, $25)

headline: Choosing Favorites From the Books of The Times
text: We three daily book critics for The New York Times don’t make 10-best lists at the end of each year. Instead we make lists of favorites, and selecting them is harder than it sounds. They’re about gut feelings. Brass tacks. Guilty pleasures. What each of us might actually send, lend or recommend to a friend.

headline: Art and Commerce
text: For those not in the market for a million-dollar Warhol, there’s Exhibition A, a new online art platform offering limited edition pieces by big-name artists — all in a nicely priced range from $100 to $500. Each week, the Web site’s creators, Bill Powers, Cynthia Rowley, Laura Martin and Gabby Munoz, will offer new editions of work from the likes of Terence Koh, Richard Phillips, Geoff McFetridge and Rene Ricard. While some of the artists will offer a set number of signed works, others will offer open editions for a limited amount of time (usually between two and four weeks). Though the flash sales require budding art enthusiasts to think quickly on their feet, it allows “people new to collecting a point of entry that isn’t super scary on the financial side,“ Powers said.

headline: Apple Computer Sells for $213,600 at Auction
text: This month, I wrote about an Apple-1 computer that was set to be auctioned for $150,000 by the auctioneer Christie’s. The bidding is now closed, and the computer that debuted in 1976, for $666.66, built by Steven P. Jobs and Steve Wozniak, Apple’s co-founders, sold for $213,600.

headline: Hanukkah Recipes
text: Recipes for potato latkes, babka, jelly doughnuts and other holiday classics.

headline: Pentagon Reassigns 2 Officials in Mix-Up Over Confidential Tanker Data
text: The top Air Force general said Tuesday that he had reassigned two officials who had mistakenly sent confidential data to the companies bidding for a $35 billion tanker contract.

headline: Republican Senator Says Arms Treaty Isn’t Tough Enough
text: 6:55 p.m. | Updated The top Republican on the Senate intelligence committee said Tuesday that he opposes ratification of a new arms control treaty with Russia because he considers its verification measures inadequate, dealing a blow to President Obama’s chances of winning approval this year.

headline: The Energy Chain
text: James McMullan demonstrates how to see relationships between parts rather than just pieces of the body. Video by Drew Beebe.

headline: In Insider Case, the Odd Couple Won’t Meet
text: 7:43 a.m. | Updated Next Tuesday, the Franklin & Marshall College alumni association will hold a discussion at the Waldorf Astoria hotel on Park Avenue entitled “American Finance: Where Do We Go From Here?”

headline: CNBC: Interview with John Kinnucan
text: The founder of Broadband Research LLC, John Kinnucan, is one of the figures in the series of ongoing inquiries into insider trading. He spoke to CNBC's "The Strategy Session" about why F.B.I. agents approached him to cooperate in the investigation, and why he turned them down.

headline: Back to the Castle, Where It’s All About the Hair
text: To watch “Tangled,” in three dimensions or two, is like entering a familiar old neighborhood that has been tastefully and thoroughly renovated. Not gentrified, exactly, and certainly not razed, but modernized.

headline: A Brooklyn Civics Lesson, Offered in Word and Song
text: As subjects for musical comedy go, it would be hard to fathom anything less promising than the legal intricacies of the concept of eminent domain. Or, for that matter, the socioeconomic diversity of the crazy quilt of Brooklyn neighborhoods. The great Stephen Sondheim himself might find it tricky work to make lyrical magic of the relationships among the various civic entities charged with approving land-use deals in New York City.

headline: 'In the Footprint'
text: Photos from the new show by the Civilians.

headline: ‘Tonight Show’ Says It Will Credit Bloggers for Taylor Swift Montage
text: When Rich Juzwiak saw a series of video clips that Jay Leno played for Taylor Swift on Monday’s broadcast of “The Tonight Show,” showing the country star reacting with similar expressions of surprise to a series of awards-show victories, he knew it looked more than familiar: he argued on his blog that the “Tonight Show” segment was taken directly from a similar Web video he made with a colleague. And now NBC says it will acknowledge the work of Mr. Juzwiak and his co-worker on Tuesday’s “Tonight Show.”

headline: A News Corp. Newspaper, Minus the Paper
text: Related: A News Corp. Newspaper, but Not in Print

headline: Charlie Rose Show: Rattner Blasts Cuomo
text: Troubled financier Steve Rattner criticized New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo's lawsuit, saying he had no evidence beyond what the Securities and Exchange Commission had already presented.

headline: Wall Street Regains Its Swagger
text: Two years after the financial crisis, the moneyed elite of finance finally feel they can exhale. There are signs that wallets are beginning to open up, DealBook reports.

headline: Collins Officially in Race to Head R.N.C.
text: Gentry Collins, the former Republican National Committee official who recently blasted Michael Steele’s leadership as chairman, announced in an e-mail today that he will seek Mr. Steele’s job.

headline: Know What to Expect Before Your Trip
text: Traveling during the holidays this year can mean long lines snaking through security checkpoints, delayed flights and airport parking lots with no space to leave the car.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Opens Audit of Rental Car Repairs
text: Citing troubling reports of injuries and deaths in rental cars, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has begun investigating whether millions of rental cars are being fixed when they are recalled for safety problems.

headline: Artifacts | Ghost Dance
text: People in the art world love an off-site exhibition. A decrepit theater, an abandoned warehouse, an old church, a darkened cave — anyplace that isn’t a white-cube gallery — only adds to their adventure in art, and the more underground it is the better. Try six feet under.

headline: Education Chief Raises Doubts on Pick by Bloomberg
text: The candidacy of Cathleen P. Black, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s choice to be chancellor of the New York City schools, was in jeopardy on Tuesday as both a panel weighing her credentials and the state official who will determine her fate expressed deep doubts about her readiness for the job.

headline: Video: Developing ‘Tangled’
text: For the 50th animated film from Walt Disney Pictures the filmmakers made the transition from hand-drawn animation to 3-D CG animation, while keeping the traditional look and feel of a Disney movie. Here, the directors Nathan Greno and Byron Howard narrate a look at the process of bringing one scene from the film to life. Read more about the journey of “Tangled” to the big screen.

headline: Ai Fiori Is Set to Open on Monday
text: On Monday, Michael White, this season’s energizer bunny, opens Ai Fiori, his grand Italian restaurant with flavors of the Riviera.

headline: For Women Amid Waves, Shared Fears and Rhythm
text: Bright, appealing dance is the signature of the Alpha Omega Theatrical Dance Company, which has existed for an impressive 38 years. It is directed now by Enrique Cruz DeJesus, a former member of the Eleo Pomare Dance Company and the choreographer of two pieces on Sunday’s night’s program at the Manhattan Movement & Arts Center.

headline: Pregame Huddle: Defining Week in B.C.S.
text: The annual Iron Bowl between Auburn and Alabama is one of the showdowns this week that will shape the B.C.S. rankings.

headline: The Palins Ensure They Stay in the News
text: For the booming Sarah Palin media empire, this week is the busiest to date.

headline: Report Suggests Problems With Iran’s Nuclear Effort
text: Atomic inspectors reported Tuesday that Iran mysteriously stopped feeding uranium into thousands of centrifuges at its main enrichment plant this month, and independent experts suggested that the computer worm suspected of being aimed at Iran’s nuclear program had caused the spinning machines to break down.

headline: Muslim Troupe Arrives With Splash and Age-Old Ecumenical Traditions
text: Over the course of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center, the notion of music as a conduit to spirituality has taken a variety of forms: individual contemplation, communal praise, the physical discipline of dance, a rock star’s beatific charisma. With “The Manganiyar Seduction,” which arrived belatedly at the Rose Theater on Monday night after a visa-related delay, came still another facet of spirituality: communion with God achieved in a manner embracing the sensual and the ecstatic.

headline: London Underground | Art Meets Fashion
text: Just when you don’t think you can’t visit one more pop-up store, along comes one that is not only inspired, but relevant, too. House of Voltaire, in the heart of Mayfair, is a temporary store that was opened by the South London contemporary arts space Studio Voltaire to finance its artist program and education work.

headline: Iran Lawmakers Complain About Ahmadinejad
text: TEHRAN  Iranian Parliament members recently sent a letter detailing a long list of complaints against President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad to Iran’s powerful Guardian Council, Iranian news media have reported, marking a new phase in an effort by traditional conservatives to rein in the administration and reassert the powers of Iran’s legislative body.

headline: A Strong Showing for ‘Dancing With the Stars’
text: While the Palin brand lost some ratings luster on TLC on Sunday night with a stark decline in viewers for “Sarah Palin’s Alaska,” it continued to be a strong draw Monday night on ABC as a crowd that even surpassed football fans turned up to watch the first half of the “Dancing With the Stars” finale.

headline: Privacy Groups Fault Online Health Sites for Sharing User Data With Marketers
text: QualityHealth is a popular health Web site with more than 20 million registered users that offers online medical information and e-mail newsletters on a variety of topics, including diabetes, allergies, asthma and arthritis.

headline: Small-Town Girl Trades Her Naïveté for Lingerie
text: The old bump and grind receives a squeaky-clean workout in “Burlesque,” a backstage tease-o-rama about life in and out of corsets and garters. Sparkly and smiley and thoroughly goofy (sleepy and dopey make appearances too), the story turns on an Iowan refugee for whom the Big Time means doing the hoochie-coochie in a Los Angeles club. There, where the dancers are dollies with Pilates physiques, the mistress of ceremonies should be Alan Cumming (who shows up now and again, giggling on the sidelines), but turns out to be Cher, trying her darnedest to play older and wiser but without, you know, the wrinkles and gray.

headline: SAP Ordered to Pay Oracle $1.3 Billion
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A clash of technology titans and two of the most powerful executives in Silicon Valley ended on Tuesday with a $1.3 billion federal jury award against SAP for stealing software from Oracle to try to woo away customers.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Starts to Emerge From Secrecy
text: Nine years in the making, the moment came on Saturday to try running through the first act of the new musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” without stopping. As the band struck up an ominous tune that wailed like an ambulance siren, the enormous stage curtain rose to reveal a young woman dangling under a mock-up of the Brooklyn Bridge. Above her appeared a masked man, clad in skin-hugging tights, red and blue and all-American.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: The Chancellor’s Official Job Description: What a Difference 8 Years Make
text: Last week, in asking the state education commission to give Cathleen P. Black a waiver from the state law requiring that school district leaders have certain education credentials and experience, the Bloomberg administration had to file a description of the chancellor’s job she has been tapped to fill. City Room compared that job description, basically a list of bullet points, to the one City Hall submitted in 2002, when it asked for a similar waiver for Joel I. Klein.

headline: Gaining an Edge in Female Rap Race
text: It’s virtually impossible to think of Kesha as anything other than a star manqué. At the American Music Awards on Sunday night, her affect was a lot of Lady Gaga, a little bit of Rihanna, maybe some Lita Ford. Her  performance of “Take It Off” and “We R Who We R” was Daft Punk by way of Mad Max.

headline: Dance-Struck Little Girls: Run! Run in Horror!
text: Come and meet these dancing feet. If you dare.

headline: 'The Red Shoes'
text: Photos from the show by the Kneehigh Theater Company.

headline: ‘Don Carlo’ at the Metropolitan Opera
text: Photographs from the new staging of Verdi’s opera, directed by Nicholas Hytner.

headline: A Young Viagra Salesman Sees Lust Turn Into Love
text: Since most romantic comedies take place in a perky, generic present, you may be surprised to see a note in the opening titles informing you that the action in “Love & Other Drugs” starts in 1996. Why so specific? Is there some world-historical event looming on the horizon that will change the characters’ lives forever? Or does the director, Edward Zwick, simply want to evoke a bygone-but-not-too-distant era when a young person could have a lot of fun and make a lot of money without worrying too much about whatever it is young people nowadays worry about (war, terrorism, recession, Facebook)?

headline: Power Struggles and Riddles, in Romance and Political Intrigue
text: The name of the Albanian novelist Ismail Kadare regularly comes up at Nobel Prize time, and he is still a good bet to win it one of these days. He writes in a language that is not English. He comes from a country that most of us know next to nothing about, where he was oppressed not just by a run-of-the-mill totalitarian but by the bizarre and paranoid Enver Hoxha. He is fluent in the styles of modernism and postmodernism both. And, an unlooked-for bonus, he is seemingly incapable of writing a book that fails to be interesting.

headline: Innocent Man, Releasing His Inner Mime
text: IT doesn’t get more gee-whiz wholesome than Steven Banks. Boyish, middle-aged and suburban, he married early, swore off alcohol and drugs, and works as a writer for “SpongeBob SquarePants.” If that’s not vanilla enough, his e-mail address includes the name of a character from “The Music Man.” (More on that particular passion later.)

headline: Pale Male Takes a Star Turn
text: This meeting of the “fellowship of the bench” was called to order at 10:04 a.m. at the bench, facing Conservatory Water, the model-boat basin in Central Park.

headline: From Tooth Fairy to High-Speed Human Tank
text: “Faster,” a turgid, ultraviolent parable of revenge and forgiveness, is as muscle-bound as its monosyllabic antihero, Driver (Dwayne Johnson), an indestructible human Superman with a metal plate in his head. Released from prison after serving time for a bank robbery, this high-speed tank runs over anything in his path or shoots it on the spot. Befitting his name, he has a knack for driving a car in reverse into oncoming traffic and at the last second spinning the vehicle 180 degrees and rocketing forward.

headline: A Breathless Boccherini, an Unnerving Shostakovich
text: The Moscow Virtuosi lived up to their name on Sunday afternoon, offering dynamite performances for a large and enthusiastic, mostly Russian-speaking audience at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Messing With J.R., Take Four
text: Not so fast, J.R.

headline: In 12 Plays, 150 Years of Afghan History
text: BY the time the seven-plus hours of “The Great Game: Afghanistan” have concluded (over three successive nights or in one all-day weekend marathon), audiences will have received a vigorous crash course on a country that has gotten relatively little attention in the West even in the midst of a war that has taken more than 1,300 American lives.

headline: Unwrapping Red Tape to Find the Gift of Family
text: TARAZ, Kazakhstan  He was first placed into their arms nearly a year ago, an underweight 9-month-old baby in a gray sweatshirt. They were at an orphanage behind a crumbling housing project here in Central Asia, unimaginably far from their home in suburban Philadelphia, but immediately, they knew that they did not want to let him go.

headline: The Interplay of Politics and the Heart
text: “Kawasaki’s Rose,” the new film from the Czech director Jan Hrebejk, is the chronicle of two betrayals, separated by three decades and a revolution. In the busy, placid present, Ludek (Milan Mikulcik) is cheating on his wife, Lucie (Lenka Vlasakova), who is undergoing tests and then treatment for what turns out to be a rare but nonfatal disease. Ludek informs her of his affair (with Radka, a younger co-worker played by Petra Hrebickova) with a grating mixture of insensitivity and concern, his cowardice and selfishness marking him as a thoroughly ordinary modern man.

headline: Bird of Prey and His Adoring Fans: A New York Love Story
text: When the red-tailed hawk known as Pale Male landed in New York City, he would experience some of the things New Yorkers hope to avoid (homelessness, the wrath of a co-op board) and a few they can only fantasize about (the attention of Mary Tyler Moore, sex on the terrace of Woody Allen’s penthouse). Chronicling close to two decades in the bird’s — and its fan club’s — eventful life, “The Legend of Pale Male” is a sugary, aggressively anthropomorphized story of one avian interloper and a whole bunch of human obsessives.

headline: A ‘Dynasty’ Diva Regales Us With Her Own Life Stories
text: Behold Joan Collins! The ur bitch goddess and resplendent proto-cougar (on the prowl long before that noxious term was invented) is doing her thing in the flesh at the ballroom of Loews Regency Hotel. Would that thing be singing? Dancing? Acting? None of the above, unless acting means embodying a woman named Joan Collins who has the blessing and the curse of being confused with Alexis Carrington, her notorious, shoulder-padded alter ego on “Dynasty.”

headline: Jeter’s Predictable Predicament
text: Tyler Kepner, who covers baseball for The Times, has an excellent article on the contract negotiations between the Yankees and their Hall of Fame shortstop, Derek Jeter. Few players have had a more harmonious relationship with their employer than Mr. Jeter, who has rarely caused controversy in his 16 seasons with the Yankees. But the contract negotiations have turned ugly, as Mr. Kepner reports, with both Mr. Jeter’s representatives and Yankees management having provided their fair share of juicy quotes to the media.

headline: A Dystopian Aftertaste to Those Sugarplums
text: There are a few things that “Nutcracker” fans need to know about the new holiday extravaganza “The Nutcracker in 3D,” which, according to the production notes, was “inspired by the beloved ballet.” First, there’s no ballet, though there is a rudimentary waltz on ice skates.

headline: Driving to See Geological Traffic Accidents
text: George E. Harlow, curator of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, has been studying jadeite for many years and returned earlier this month to the fault line that is the Motagua Valley in Guatemala. He previously wrote two posts about his expedition. Here is his summary of the remainder of the trip.

headline: Sarkozy Called Journalists ‘Pedophiles’
text: Updated | Wednesday | 9:16 a.m. Apparently enraged by allegations of scandal that he has dismissed as “ridiculous” and “grotesque,” French President Nicolas Sarkozy exploded during an off-the-record briefing last week, calling the reporters present “pedophiles,” the French magazine L’Express reported on Monday.

headline: Loving Coffee Without Being a Drip
text: THE crimes that can be hung on the automatic drip coffee machine are many, not all of them petty misdemeanors. It hogs counter space. It sends a wash of water too indiscriminate over a hillock of grounds too large. And its oversize carafe often overheats its contents, turning your morning upper into an acrid downer.

headline: Tiella
text: 1109 First Avenue (61st Street), Upper East Side; (212) 588-0100, tiellanyc.com.

headline: Smoked Soy Sauce
text: The penetrating allure of smoke does not require a grill.

headline: Searching for Ingredients Beyond the Garden
text: The ingredients that chefs are seeking out are not the ones everyone can order; they’re the ones that few have ever heard of.

headline: A Lineup Change at Sushi Yasuda
text: THAT Naomichi Yasuda, among the hundreds of sushi chefs in New York, is one of the very few who is known by name gives a clue as to why so many connoisseurs took personally the news that he would be moving to Tokyo by the end of January. It’s like telling a Yankees fan that Derek Jeter is about to retire.

headline: Chefs Look for Wild Ingredients Nobody Else Has
text: LAST Thursday, Adam Kopels walked into Torrisi Italian Specialties in NoLIta, opened his messenger bag and pulled out Ziploc bags filled with wild greens he had gathered on the North Fork of Long Island, near where he lives. Mario Carbone, one of the restaurant’s chefs and owners, sat with Mr. Kopels and sorted through clumps of baby peppercress and sheep sorrel, red bay and shepherd’s purse. The two picked up some sea rocket, a plant that grows only on exposed dunes, and crunched through the peppery leaves.

headline: Kasha Varnishkes With Confit of Gizzards
text: Adapted from Mile End, Brooklyn

headline: In Battery Park City, Another Option for Stocking the Pantry
text: Battery Park City has a well-stocked 4,500-square-foot market that even more well-provisioned neighborhoods might envy. One owner is Edmund Choi, who started Marché Madison. The manager, Ken Jackson, held a similar post at Fairway.

headline: Seafood Raised on Land
text: The Local Ocean fish farm in Hudson, N.Y., may be an aquaculture game-changer, raising saltwater fish, mostly sea bream (similar to porgy and orata), in tanks on land.

headline: Barbarescos That Are Good Now, but Just Wait a Bit
text: LET’S face it, if you haven’t gotten your Thanksgiving plans together by now, then you must be the sort of last-minute organizational genius who needs no help. So let’s look past the holiday to the future, to something much more fun to contemplate. May I suggest Barbaresco, the 2005 vintage?

headline: For Executives Seeking Absolution, a Double Standard
text: This is a tale of two worlds.

headline: To Revive Jewish Dishes, Some Cooks Look to the Shtetl
text: GROWING up in Montreal, Noah Bernamoff had an issue with his mother’s kasha varnishkes.

headline: Life Expectancy in China Rising Slowly, Despite Economic Surge
text: A quick quiz: Which of the following countries has had the smallest increase in life expectancy since 1990  Bangladesh, China, Pakistan, South Korea or Sudan?

headline: Why Do Bank Results Slump in the 4th Quarter?
text: We all know that retailers make all their money in the final quarter of each year. But why are banks much more likely to report losses in the fourth quarter than in any other quarter?

headline: Why Do Bank Results Slump in the 4th Quarter?
text: We all know that retailers make all their money in the final quarter of each year. But why are banks much more likely to report losses in the fourth quarter than in any other quarter?

headline: ‘Dancing’ Tops ‘Skating’
text: Part 1 of the “Dancing With the Stars” finale topped the ratings on Monday night, but ABC’s nearly two-hour series premiere of “Skating With the Stars” struggled to duplicate the success. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 23.3 million viewers tuned in to “Dancing” during the 8 p.m. hour. The show also extended 13 minutes into the 9 p.m. hour in an effort to attract viewers for the start of ABC’s new skating show. The network garnered 19.4 million viewers from 9 to 9:30, but “Skating” earned just 8.3 million from 9:30 to 11 and only 6 million viewers in its final half-hour. Still, for the night ABC outperformed second-place CBS with its comedy lineup and “Hawaii Five-0” (12.1 million). Fox was third and NBC fourth.

headline: Five City Officers Cleared in Shootings of Bystanders
text: Five New York City police officers involved in a shootout with a suspect in Harlem in 2005 cannot be held negligent in the wounding of two bystanders, the state’s highest court ruled on Tuesday, ending a five-year legal battle before it went to trial.

headline: Thanksgiving Ritual Gives Rangel a Respite
text: Last week, he stormed out of a crucial hearing in Washington and nearly broke down when he was found guilty of ethical violations involving his finances and fund-raising.

headline: Classical Music
text: So much for the death watch on the major classical record labels, and on the CD itself. If the New York Times classical music writers’ choices for records of the year are any indication, at least one of the traditional majors scored a significant comeback this year: Deutsche Grammophon, which claims 6 of the 25 places. Harmonia Mundi, which has become a major player in recent years despite a generally more specialized repertory, comes in second, with 4. But excellent recordings keep coming out from smaller sources as well, and they dot the list that follows. JAMES R. OESTREICH

headline: Afghanistan May Indict Voting Officials
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The government of President Hamid Karzai threatened on Tuesday to indict two top election officials, on the eve of the announcement of the final results from the country’s September parliamentary elections.

headline: Johnson Is Nascar’s Dynasty of One
text: Jimmie Johnson was whisked from one New York television studio to another Tuesday to talk about his fifth straight Nascar Sprint Cup championship, which, he said, has turned out to be a little different from the first four  or since people started saying he is bad for racing.

headline: BBC’s Popular Media Player Going Global
text: More than three years after it was rung up as a immense success in Britain, the BBC’s super-sophisticated media player, the iPlayer, will begin streaming both television and radio globally next year, including in the United States.

headline: Church Has Role in Newton Inquiry
text: NEWNAN, Ga. — As the N.C.A.A. investigates the recruitment of Auburn’s star quarterback, Cam Newton, a central figure in the unfolding story is his father, Cecil Newton Sr., and the church he runs not far from their home in Atlanta.

headline: Experiments in Field Philosophy
text: Back in September, Joshua Knobe of Yale University, writing here at The Stone, outlined a new experimental approach to doing philosophy in his post, “Experiments in Philosophy.” Philosophers, he argued, have spent enough time cogitating in their armchairs. Knobe described how he and a group of like-minded colleagues in the discipline have undertaken a more engaged approach, working with cognitive scientists and designing experiments that will “test” people’s intuitions about traditional philosophic puzzlers such as the existence of God, the objectivity of ethics and the possibility of free will. The result: new, empirically-grounded insights available to philosophers and psychologists.

headline: Another House Democrat Concedes
text: Make that an even 63 – for now at least.

headline: The Mets’ New Manager Has Some Fans in Buffalo
text: It never hurts when looking into an audience of hard-core skeptics to also see the smiling faces of true believers, of people who go back with you more than two decades and who would board a plane on a day’s notice to endorse you with insights that few others could have.

headline: Turning Around an Indian State
text: SHERGHATI, India  Out in the flat, dusty plains of eastern India, Nitish Kumar stood before several thousand farmers at a recent campaign rally and described his turnaround of India’s poorest and once most ungovernable state, Bihar. Law and order had been restored. Roads and bridges had been built. More women were holding elective office and fewer and fewer girls were dropping out of school.

headline: The Sound of Lincoln’s Silence
text: Less than a month after Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency, the nation’s reigning bible of technology, Scientific American, shone a startling new light on the incoming chief executive. Lincoln, it revealed, was an inventor. Eleven years earlier, he had secured a federal patent (the first and only for a president) for a device to buoy up imperiled ships over dangerously shallow rivers. Amid a growing secession crisis already awash in comparisons to foundering ships of state, the invitation to metaphor must have seemed irresistible.

headline: Big Hits, No Flags
text: One player was tackled square in the face with the helmet of an onrushing opponent. Another, fighting for one last yard, took a polyurethane bash to the head. Still another player spent 10 minutes mostly motionless among dozens of praying players before medics carried him away on a stretcher after a helmet-to-helmet hit.

headline: Scientists Back Early Government Report on Gulf Spill
text: An early government assessment of the fate of the oil from the BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico that was criticized as overly optimistic by some independent scientists was largely accurate, according to a revised report by federal scientists released Tuesday.

headline: Subway Extension Draws Support, if Not Financing
text: Extending the No. 7 subway line to New Jersey is an idea that seems to pick up support among government officials with each passing day. But the $5.3 billion question is: Who would pay for it?

text: The island that was shelled by North Korea on Tuesday lies in disputed waters.

text: Sandy Alderson addressed several items of business at the Mets’ news conference to introduce Terry Collins as the new manager on Tuesday, including that he hopes to speak to the former general manager Omar Minaya soon about serving the team in some capacity. Minaya has offers from a half dozen other teams.

headline: At a 2008 Stop, Obama Promotes His Policies
text: KOKOMO, Ind.  President Obama came to this manufacturing city in the Midwest to make the case for the effectiveness of his economic policies, telling workers that the return of jobs to auto plants in the area is a harbinger of a nationwide recovery.

text: He is hailed as a paragon of timeless male beauty. His face is likened to the chiseled visages of Antonio Banderas, David Beckham and Ricky Martin. He is called, without irony, “a sizzling stalwart.”

headline: Brooklyn Actor Held in Killing of His Mother
text: In a rampage loud enough to be heard by alarmed neighbors, an actor killed his mother with a three-foot sword early Tuesday in their apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, the police said.

text: Injured survivors lay on the floors of hospitals in Cambodia after one of the worst stampedes in recent years killed at least 378 people at a holiday celebration.

headline: South Koreans and U.S. to Stage a Joint Exercise
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama and South Korea’s president agreed Tuesday night to hold joint military exercises as a first response to North Korea’s deadly shelling of a South Korean military installation, as both countries struggled for the second time this year to keep a North Korean provocation from escalating into war.

headline: Telling Consumers What’s Inside
text: S. C. JOHNSON wants to step up its “green” game with advertising intended to convey to consumers a commitment to disclose the ingredients of its familiar household cleaning products, like Glade, Pledge and Windex.

headline: Real Estate Investors Look to the Future, and See Signs to Buy Apartment Towers
text: At the start of the year, David Neithercut, the chief executive of Equity Residential, a real estate investment trust, set a target of $1 billion to spend on apartment buildings across the country. By the middle of this month, after buying 15 properties that included a troubled condominium tower in San Diego and three apartment buildings in Manhattan, Mr. Neithercut had invested $1.4 billion.

headline: U.S.G. and P.T.A.
text: For me, the most frightening news in The Times on Sunday was not about North Korea’s stepping up its nuclear program, but an article about how American kids are stepping up their use of digital devices: “Allison Miller, 14, sends and receives 27,000 texts in a month, her fingers clicking at a blistering pace as she carries on as many as seven text conversations at a time. She texts between classes, at the moment soccer practice ends, while being driven to and from school and, often, while studying. But this proficiency comes at a cost: She blames multitasking for the three B’s on her recent progress report. “I’ll be reading a book for homework and I’ll get a text message and pause my reading and put down the book, pick up the phone to reply to the text message, and then 20 minutes later realize, ‘Oh, I forgot to do my homework.’ ”

headline: A Very Risky Game
text: North Korea is again bullying its way into the headlines. On Tuesday, it shelled a South Korean island, killing two South Korean soldiers. Earlier this month it flaunted a new plant that could allow it to significantly increase the size of its nuclear arsenal.

headline: After Years Caught Up in Violence, a Second Chance to Reflect on Fate
text: Words flowed from Raheem Watson in a stream, thick with assurance, buttressed by years of quiet introspection. But one question gave him pause, forcing his gaze down to his lap.

headline: In J. Crew Buyout, an Effort to Gain a Retail Visionary
text: The buyout firms that are paying $3 billion for J. Crew are not just bidding on the retailer’s array of sequined blazers and gingham work shirts. They are trying to acquire the man whose vision inspired them: the company’s chairman and chief executive, Millard S. Drexler.

headline: Large Banks Still Have Financing Advantage
text: What happened to ending “too big to fail?” That was one objective of the financial overhaul bill, the Dodd-Frank Act, that was passed this year. Central to the legislation were rules intended to make big banks less exciting and safer. It also created an authority meant to smoothly wind down even the largest institutions without greatly disrupting the financial system.

headline: Pentagon Report Cites Gains in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The United States and its partners are making modest gains in some key areas of Afghanistan, but the insurgency is still strong and expanding across the country, a Pentagon report to Congress this month has concluded.

text: Note: When this puzzle is done, read the eight circled letters clockwise, starting with square No. 24, to identify this puzzle’s theme.

headline: Politicizing Airport Security
text: In their eagerness to pin every problem in America on President Obama, prominent Republicans are now blaming his administration for the use of full-body scanners and intrusive pat-downs at airports. Those gloved fingers feeling inside your belt? The hand of big government, once again poking around where it should not go.

headline: No Time to Wait for Justice
text: It is only a day’s difference, but the Pentagon’s decision to release its report on gays in the military next Tuesday instead of Wednesday lends a significant sense of urgency to a Congressional vote on the verge of collapse. If there is any hope of repealing the military’s discriminatory “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, legislative action must begin immediately. Even an extra day can mean a great deal.

headline: News Corp., After Hiring Klein, Buys Technology Partner in a City Schools Project
text: Greg Gunn and Larry Berger met as Rhodes scholars at Oxford University and, after stints teaching computer skills and mathematics to children in Harlem and Stamford, Conn., they came upon an idea: create a business that would put technology in the hands of teachers and into classrooms.

headline: Terry Collins Discusses Past as He Takes Mets Job
text: Eleven years’ worth of waiting for a third chance to manage in the major leagues came bursting forth at a Citi Field podium Tuesday after Terry Collins was introduced as the 20th manager of the Mets.

headline: Theater Owner Is Charged With Fraud
text: A businessman who once ran a chain of New York City cinemas was arrested on Tuesday and charged with orchestrating a scheme to steal a half-million dollars from investors in his theaters, the authorities said.

headline: Saving the Wild Tiger
text: A century ago, there were an estimated 100,000 tigers living in the wild. Now there are perhaps 3,200 left. The best chance  probably the only remaining chance  to save them from extinction is being worked out during a five-day summit meeting this week in St. Petersburg, Russia, staged by Prime Minister Vladimir Putin and Robert Zoellick, president of the World Bank. The meeting includes representatives from major conservation groups and all 13 nations with tigers living in the wild, including India, Indonesia, Thailand and Russia.

headline: As Anger Over Body Scanners Grows, Their Developer Comes to Their Defense
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Thirty years ago, Martin Annis devised an X-ray technology for body scanners that unsettled some people. He had so much trouble finding a woman to test the machine on that he had to pay a family member $20 to try it.

headline: Report Finds Low Graduation Rates at For-Profit Colleges
text: A new report on graduation rates at for-profit colleges by a nonprofit research and advocacy group charges that such colleges deliver “little more than crippling debt,” citing federal data that suggests only 9 percent of the first-time, full-time bachelor’s degree students at the University of Phoenix, the nation’s largest for-profit college, graduate within six years.

headline: Buenos Aires, the Frugal Way
text: Graciela, Ofelia and Pedro from Patagonia stood around the counter with me in Buenos Aires, chomping on pizza slices and trying to explain  why Argentines dine so late. It was 8 p.m. and they were snacking on their way home from work to tide them over before dinner. We were at Guerrin, an institution where you get to know the strangers standing next to you because you’re in close quarters and there’s nothing to do but talk. (My primary rule for lone travelers: always talk to strangers. At the very least you could end up with a bit of conversation over pizza. At best, you end up getting set up on a blind date. But more on that later.)

headline: With a Swagger, Wallets Out, Wall Street Dares to Celebrate
text: Exuberance made a comeback this year at Josh Koplewicz’s annual Halloween party. More than 1,000 people packed into a 6,000-square-foot space at the Good Units night club in Manhattan, a substantially larger crowd than in the last several years. The open bar was sponsored by Russian Standard vodka, and Mr. Koplewicz, an investment analyst at Goldman Sachs, was able to snag a big headliner: the hip-hop star Lil’ Kim, who performed dressed in a black cat costume.

headline: Remake of Obama Economic Team Broadens Scope
text: WASHINGTON  The departure of a number of administration officials is giving President Obama broader scope to remake his economic team even as the White House prepares to carry out a long-planned shuffle involving two of his closest political advisers.

headline: Jennifer Grey Wins ‘Dancing With the Stars’
text: Nobody puts Baby in the corner, but you can put her in the winner’s circle: Jennifer Grey, the “Dirty Dancing” star, was named the winner of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday night, fending off a late challenge from her fellow competitor Bristol Palin.

headline: New Zealand Mourns Miners After Second Blast
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  A second huge blast in a New Zealand coal mine would have killed any survivors of the initial explosion, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Felton Seals Knicks’ Four-Win Streak
text: The emotions came first, then the pain and finally some combination of physical and mental fatigue. Raymond Felton pushed through it all, pushed through traffic and put himself exactly where he wanted to be.

headline: Boras Says Player’s Loans Are Part of ‘Goodwill Story’
text: Scott Boras, baseball’s most prominent agent, said Tuesday that his company had indeed made loans of $70,000 to a young Dominican prospect and that they were actually part of “a goodwill story” and within the rules for agents set out by Major League Baseball’s players union.

headline: G.O.P. Gets 2 More Seats; Democrats Hold On to 1
text: Republicans have officially racked up two more victories in House races with the concessions of Democratic incumbents in Texas and New York.

headline: The Thanksgiving Help Line Is Open for Business
text: And maybe you’re already reaching for the Valium as if they were Tic Tacs, worried that the brine isn’t working or is working too well, or that Aunt Katie’s going to start crying the way she did last year, not five minutes into the house and still stinking of the Virginia Slims she hotboxed out on the sidewalk before working up the nerve to come in. Do you not know what to do with that murderous-looking butternut squash? What about these blessed chestnuts or that balky oven, this weird desire of your father’s for apple pie, this command of your cousin’s for ham? Did you make the Ruhlman stock yet? Get going!

headline: The Shoppers’ Republic of China
text: Most Chinese spend little on consumer items, but when people do buy, they buy big.

headline: Phys Ed: The Benefits of Weight Training for Children
text: Back in the 1970s, researchers in Japan studied child laborers and discovered that, among their many misfortunes, the juvenile workers tended to be abnormally short. Physical labor, the researchers concluded, with its hours of lifting and moving heavy weights, had stunted the children’s growth. Somewhat improbably, from that scientific finding and other similar reports, as well as from anecdotes and accreting myth, many people came to believe “that children and adolescents should not” practice weight training, said Avery Faigenbaum, a professor of exercise science at the College of New Jersey. That idea retains a sturdy hold in the popular imagination. As a recent position paper on the topic of children and resistance training points out, many parents, coaches and pediatricians remain convinced that weight training by children will “result in short stature, epiphyseal plate” — or growth plate — “damage, lack of strength increases due to a lack of testosterone and a variety of safety issues.”

headline: Final Settlement Phase Starts for BP Oil Spill
text: Now comes the hard part.

headline: In China, Cultivating the Urge to Splurge
text: When the Wuqi International Hotel was completed this spring, it immediately dominated the modest skyline of Wuqi, a small city in north central China. The hotel stands 21 stories tall and is wrapped in gleaming gray metal, with two glass elevators running up the outside. On a recent stay there, I had a clear view of the nearby mountains from my 19th-floor room.

headline: Gawker Agrees Not to Repost Palin Excerpts
