headline: Anxiety in Seoul as Civilian Deaths Are Reported
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The forests on Yeonpyeong Island were still ablaze on Wednesday afternoon when news broke that rescuers had recovered the burned bodies of two civilians, casualties of the ferocious artillery exchange a day earlier between North and South Korean military units.

headline: Chalmers Johnson Dies at 79; Criticized U.S. Role in World
text: Chalmers Johnson, an Asian studies scholar who stirred controversy with books contending that the United States was trying to create a global empire and was paying a stiff price for it, died Saturday at his home in Cardiff-by-the Sea, Calif. He was 79.

headline: William Hohri Dies at 83; Sought Money for Internees
text: William Hohri, a veteran of a World War II internment camp for Japanese-Americans who became the lead plaintiff in a politically charged class-action suit that claimed $27 billion in damages for internees, died Nov. 12 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Brazil: Gangs Battle Police in Rio de Janeiro Slums
text: The police raided more than a dozen slums in Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday in an effort to quell violent attacks by gangs that have raised questions about security in the city chosen to host the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Olympic Games. Heavily armed criminals have blocked busy streets, robbed drivers and burned at least nine cars since Sunday, according to the police and the Brazilian news media. The Rio State secretary of public security, José Mariano Beltrame, said the attacks were a retaliation by gang members for a government program to pacify violent slums, in part by installing a special community police force.

headline: Canada: Court-Martial for a General
text: The former commander of Canada’s troops in Afghanistan will face a court-martial, the defense department said Tuesday. The commander, Brig. Gen. Daniel Ménard, was relieved of his command in May for “inappropriate conduct” involving a female officer. He faces two charges under military laws concerning fraternization, and four charges of obstructing justice under criminal law. Earlier, General Ménard was fined more than $3,000 for accidentally firing an automatic rifle just before boarding a helicopter with Canada’s top military commander.

headline: Greece: Group Says It Sent Parcel Bombs
text: A Greek extremist group, Conspiracy of the Cells of Fire, has claimed responsibility for parcel bombs this month that caused one injury and widespread alarm, the police said Tuesday. In a letter to the news network Indymedia, two of the seven suspected members of the group who have been arrested said it had sent parcel bombs to President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, the International Court of Justice in The Hague, and the Belgian and Mexican Embassies in Athens. The Greek police also found 10 other explosive devices.

headline: 1,000 Yards Later, It’s O.K. to Ask, Who Is That Guy?
text: Atlanta’s Roddy White and Denver’s Brandon Lloyd have more than 1,000 receiving yards through 10 games, the first receivers with that level of production since 2007. Both have scored seven touchdowns this season. Both are 29 years old. But that’s where the similarities end.

Will you be one of them?

headline: Report Issued on Deadly Cambodia Stampede
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Investigators in Cambodia said Wednesday that a stampede that caused the deaths of 350 people who were suffocated or crushed Monday night was probably touched off by the slight swaying of a short suspension bridge packed on the last evening of an annual water festival.

headline: A Thanksgiving Arrangement
text: Not all flower arrangements need a vase — especially come Thanksgiving, when you can tap fall’s bounty for a cool still life. It could be arranged on your mantel, or a maybe a sideboard, or even a centerpiece for your dining table (if there’s room). I can arrive at my friends’  house with a bag of produce from the market and a few items from my garden and do up an arrangement quickly and easily while sipping a drink. Here’s how you can, too.In the example here, I’m using white pumpkins — one big, several small — plus bittersweet vine, lady apples, small pears and a few  leaves. Persimmons and quince would have made this grouping that much better, for the fuzz and color they bring. Ultimately, it’s all about the mix, the color palette and a balance of big and small, linear and round.

Kate Valk and Elizabeth LeCompte of The Wooster Group, Oskar Eustis of The Public Theater, the puppeteer Basil Twist, and the musical comedian Reggie Watts  are among its subjects.

headline: Seeing Things | More Wine
text: The Winter 2010 issue of T Design & Living contained a preview of the exhibition “How Wine Became Modern: Design and Wine 1976 to Now” at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. The exhibition opened last weekend, and while drinking wine in museum galleries is strictly prohibited, the design of the show brings wine into the galleries in other, ingenious ways. The museum’s architecture curator, Henry Urbach, collaborated on the installation with the New York architecture firm Diller Scofidio and Renfro, whose design for “The American Lawn: Surface of Everyday Life,” a 1998 exhibition at the Canadian Center for Architecture, convinced him that the architects would help bring something “as banal as fermented grapes” to life. For their part, the architects were intrigued by the idea of tackling a subject that’s not traditional museum fare. Elizabeth Diller, one of the firm’s partners, said, “Certain aspects of the story of wine’s transformation were more obvious — the branding of wineries with star architecture, design of stemware, labels, etc. — while it was less apparent how to present the experiential aspects of wine.”

headline: Visualizing the Busy Skies
text: On America’s busiest travel day, it’s worth pulling back — or up — to marvel at how the globe has been so thoroughly knitted by aviation. About 2 million Americans are in the air on a typical day. In 2009, 4.796 billion passengers traveled through the world’s airports. A dizzying variety of products flows through the skies worldwide (the impact on commerce from the eruption of one volcano in Iceland illustrated this). And of course less welcome things move this way, as well. It’s very likely that a jet carried West Nile virus to North America in 1999.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Celebrating the Season
text: Thanksgiving is Thursday, but the real holiday for college football fans comes on Friday. The day’s slate features three games (Auburn at Alabama, Arizona at Oregon, Boise State at Nevada) that have the potential to seismically shift the national championship race. Even if the Auburn, Oregon and Boise State win on Friday, Saturday offers plenty of intrigue. The Big Ten and Big 12 South have plenty of meaningful football left to play, with Michigan State at Penn State, and Oklahoma at Oklahoma State headlining the action in their respective conferences. And will also be plenty of interest in games that involve ranked teams that don’t have a chance to win their conference (Louisiana State at Arkansas), in-state rivals (Florida at Florida State) and long-time foes who have seen better days (Notre Dame at Southern California). It’s a holiday week, so take time to celebrate with perhaps the best weekend of the college football season.

headline: A Weekend in Fort Lauderdale
text: While a smattering of lively bars still dot the beach, the former spring break haven has grown up.

headline: 36 Hours in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
text: FORT LAUDERDALE continues to mature beyond its spring-break days, with posh resorts now rising along the beach. Meanwhile, Las Olas Boulevard, the lively commercial strip that links the beach to downtown, has welcomed an array of new boutiques and restaurants. Sure, a smattering of raucous bars still dot the beach, and the rowdy clubgoers of Himmarshee Village can be three deep in the middle of the week. But at the end of a sunny, water-logged day, the resort town now offers a sophisticated evening that doesn’t involve neon bikinis and syrupy daiquiris.

headline: Riddle of the Wind at New Meadowlands Stadium
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A familiar wind blew across the Meadowlands from the north at about 25 miles an hour on a recent weekday afternoon. It kept flags snapped at full attention and knocked over metal barriers in the parking lot. It was the type of wind known to blow fiercely around the old football stadium and swirl unpredictably inside it, making the former home of the Giants and the Jets a notoriously difficult place to punt, pass and kick. At times, it was like playing inside a vacuum canister.

headline: ASSEMBLY VOTES PALESTINE PARTITION; MARGIN IS 33 TO 13; ARABS WALK OUT; ARANHA HAILS WORK AS SESSION ENDS
text: The United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday a proposal to partition Palestine into two states, one Arab and the other Jewish, that are to become fully independent by Oct.1. The vote was 33 to 13 with two abstentions and one delegation, the Siamese, absent.

headline: Louisa M. Alcott Dead
text: BOSTON, Mass., March 6.--Miss Louisa M. Alcott died this morning. Coming so soon after the death of her father the suddenly announced decease of Miss Alcott brings a double sorrow to the many friends of the family, while the loss of this talented writer will be felt far and wide among the many readers of her favorite books. For a long time Miss Alcott had been ill, suffering from nervous prostration. Last Autumn she appeared to be improving and went to the Highlands to reside with Dr. Rhoda A. Lawrence. She drove from there into town to visit her father on Thursday last, and caught a cold, which on Saturday settled on the base of the brain and developed spinal meningitis. She died at the Highlands early this morning. Miss Alcott was born on her father's birthday, and it is singular that she should have followed him so soon to the grave.

headline: Trained for Battle, Now Operating a Small Business
text: In November 2004, during Justin Bajema’s second tour of duty in Iraq, his LAV-25 infantry fighting vehicle was hit by an improvised explosive device. Surrounded by heavy machine-gun fire, he was pinned under 28,000 pounds in a drained canal for 40 minutes. “It threw my vehicle in the air like a toy,” he recalled. “I almost lost my leg, almost bled out and died.”

headline: Venice in Winter
text: I HADN’T been back to Venice in years when I found myself there on assignment. It was November; the city’s scattered trees had begun to turn brown. The light, as always, was beyond compare and there was a watery chill in the air. I loved it immediately.

headline: Enjoying Winter’s Chill in Venice
text: Let the summer crowds have July. The city slows down to reveal its soul to a visitor with sweaters, boots and a book.

headline: On a Day of Peace in Belfast, Faiths Join to Cheer Clinton
text: Belfast, Northern Ireland, Nov. 30 -- President Clinton ranged across a remarkably transformed Northern Ireland today, promising the once bitterly hostile Catholic and Protestant communities that if they persevered in their search for peace, 'the United States of America will proudly stand with you.'

headline: Churchill Dies at 90 At Home in London
text: LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 24--Sir Winston Churchill is dead.

headline: Boyle Album Picks Up Steam
text: With a strong second week of sales Susan Boyle’s holiday album, “The Gift,” leads an almost entirely new crop of titles on Billboard’s album chart. “The Gift” (Syco/Columbia) had 335,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a gain of 5 percent over its first week — and since second-week drops are the norm for new albums this suggests that Ms. Boyle’s will have staying power.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. “Not if I could avoid it”: Hillary Clinton regarding a full-body pat-down, or Hillary Clinton on whether she’ll see “Burlesque”?

headline: Video: ‘Spider-Man’ on ’60 Minutes’
text: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” will get some national exposure on Sunday night when “60 Minutes” takes a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the technologically complex musical, which is directed by Julie Taymor and has music by Bono and The Edge of the rock band U2. Lesley Stahl, the “60 Minutes” correspondent, started following the development of the show 18 months ago; the curtain goes up on the first preview on Sunday at 6:30 p.m., a half-hour before the program is to air on CBS.

headline: Fewer New Yorkers Get Health Insurance Through Employers
text: In the depressing-but-not-surprising category, a recent study finds that the percentage of New York state residents who get health insurance through their jobs has dropped considerably, from 69 percent in 2003 to 58 percent in 2009.

headline: 12-Nation Pact Makes Antarctic Science Reserve
text: Washington, Dec. 1--A region equal in area to Europe and the United States combined was made into a preserve for scientific research today, immune from political and military strife.

headline: Gerard Swope, 84, Ex-G.E. Head, Dies
text: Gerard Swope, former president of the General Electric Company and onetime chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, died yesterday at his home, 161 East Seventy-ninth Street. He was 84 years old.

headline: A Chinese Minister on Chinese Health
text: Tsung-Mei Cheng, a health policy expert at Princeton (who’s quoted in my column on Wednesday), interviewed Chen Zhu, China’s health minister, for the journal Health Affairs in 2008. Health Affairs has removed its normal gate from the interview for a week, for anyone who wants to hear about China’s health system from a top Communist Party official.

headline: Apple and Cider Live On to See Another Thanksgiving
text: He could hardly say his lines with a straight face, but President Obama pardoned two turkeys on Wednesday morning, saying “it feels pretty good to stop at least one shellacking this November.”

headline: Hirotaka Inoue | Natural Wonder
text: “I was conditioned to try to become a doctor just as my father – I even majored in Political Science in college,” said the jewelry designer Hirotaka Inoue during a visit to T’s offices. The transition from political theorist to jeweler started in Paris where Inoue studied how to select and set stones before returning to Japan working for a jewelry firm. Designing his own line in 2009, Inoue’s first collection, available at the Nolita boutique Eva (355A Bowery, between Third and Fourth Streets, (212) 925-3890), showcases his intricate craftsmanship and his whimsical nature. One of his creations is a new beige-colored gold. “It’s not flashy but a very chic choice of metal – it took six months to get the right percentage of silver, copper and some platinum to make the sand gold color,” he says. More playful designs include the Vanité collection of skull charms ($477 and up), some with black diamond teeth accents, to the classic Serpent and Naja rings (starting at $550), featuring intricate scaling detailwork. Inoue says, “My jewelry can change its color like a chameleon – classic to funny to cool to chic.”

headline: The Barbershop Renaissance
text: EARLIER this month, Tristan Chirico was trying to do some last-minute errands in New York before flying back to Jordan and his job teaching theater at a prep school there. The most pressing item on his list was a haircut.

headline: Maria Callas, 53, Is Dead of Heart Attack in Paris
text: Maria Callas, the soprano whose intensely dramatic portrayals made her the most exciting opera singer of her time, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home in Paris. She was 53 years old.

GAS LEAK IN INDIA KILLS AT LEAST
410 IN CITY OF BHOPAL
text: NEW DELHI, Dec. 3 -- Toxic gas leaking from an American-owned insecticide plant in central India killed at least 410 people overnight, many as they slept, officials said today.

headline: Anna Freud, Psychoanalyst, Dies in London at 86
text: Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud and an eminent psychoanalyst in her own right, died at her London home today at the age of 86, her family said.

headline: Out of the Crucible of Civil War, Franco's Iron Hand Forged a Modern Spain
text: One of the most durable, canny and empirical of modern dictators, Francisco Paulino Hermenegildo Teodulo Franco y Bahamonde became master of Spain as a result of a military conspiracy, a dash of luck, timely help from foreign corporations, the influence of the Roman Catholic hierarchy and crucial armed assistance from Hitler and Mussolini.

headline: UNO Bill Approved By Senate, 65 to 7, With One Change

headline: Dig Out Those Pocket Combs
text: IN the last couple of years, the tops of men’s heads have provided one of those ironies that make fashion so endearingly silly. It started in the late 1990s, when fashionably antifashion guys began leaving their hair messy and matted, as if they had just rolled out of bed. A product even appeared called Bed Head to help naturally neat hair fall into a perfect rat’s nest.

headline: Please Don’t Eat the Mothballs
text: Look out for mothballs packaged to resemble delicious Chinese candies. They’re poisonous, to humans as well as, presumably, moths. That’s the message from the federal Environmental Protection Agency, which says that an importer in Brooklyn tried to bring the product, Fuji Lavender Moth Tablets, into the country.

headline: Suicide Attack Strikes Shiites in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen  A suicide car bomb ripped through a convoy of civilians traveling to a Shiite ceremony in northwestern Yemen on Wednesday, killing 17 members of the Houthi clan and leaving 5 wounded, officials said.

headline: Artifacts | ‘Squeeze’ Therapy
text: A woman’s work is definitely never done in a Mika Rottenberg video. I mean really never. The women in her latest, “Squeeze” — one of the bigger attractions in Chelsea right now — submit to the drudgery of their assembly-line labors without a peep, as if that were all life was about. Seen in Arizona and India and confined to a spa-from-hell in Rottenberg’s Harlem studio, they pick lettuce, collect rubber sap, stretch it into latex, massage sore hands and manufacture blush from the scrapings of their own reddened cheeks. And all they get out of it is more work.

headline: On Will Saletan’s Abortion Compromise
text: Speaking of contraception-related debates, Slate’s Will Saletan recently made yet another attempt to persuade the pro-life movement to champion contraception and sex education instead of focusing on throwing up legal impediments to abortion. He and I have been over this ground many times before. (You can read my response to an earlier iteration of his argument here, with follow-ups here and here and here.) But this time, Saletan pushed things a bit further, by suggesting that his own side should “reconsider the legality of second-trimester abortions.” He quoted the pro-choice historian David Garrow, speaking at the Princeton conference on abortion that occasioned Saletan’s reflections, and making what seemed to be a substantial concession on this front. Here’s Garrow:

headline: In Argentina, Touring the Tigre Delta
text: THE stunning belle-époque building that houses the Museo de Arte Tigre in the Tigre Delta of Argentina opened as a social club a century ago, when rich bohemians would visit the region to give themselves a respite from Buenos Aires. The building eventually fell into disuse before reopening as a museum in 2006, newly refurbished with marble, bronze and stained glass as part of a municipal improvement project.

Will her dress vie in splendor with the satin-and-pearl confection that Diana, Princess of Wales, wore on her wedding day? Most urgently, who will design it?

headline: A Spanish Bailout Would Test Europe’s Strained Finances
text: MADRID  Europe so far has survived the bailout of Greece. The financial rescue of Ireland also is manageable. Even if Portugal becomes the third country to succumb and seek aid, as many people widely predict, it is unlikely to push Europe to the financial brink.

headline: Searching for Authentic Thai Cuisine

headline: Authentic Thai Cuisine Moves in From Sidewalk Stalls
text: “CAN you breathe?” I asked my husband who, panting and flushed, seemed to be having a heart attack. I wasn’t faring much better. Tears streamed down my cheeks as I used our menu to whip up a breeze from the sultry city air at Bo.lan, an attractive and ambitious Bangkok restaurant. The dish was hot. Very hot. But I couldn’t resist going back for more.

headline: R&R Challenges for the Camouflage Set
text: DURING eight tours of duty in Iraq and Afghanistan over nine years, Air Force Maj. Zach Barker flew numerous AC-130 gunship flights, gathering intelligence and providing fire support for ground troops. When the time came for some R & R, he didn’t choose to decompress on a secluded beach. He went trekking, kayaking and white-water rafting. And for his final midtour leave in 2008, he climbed Mount Kilimanjaro.

headline: Choosing the 100 Notable Books of 2010
text: Today, we published our 100 Notable Books of the Year online (they will appear in print on Dec. 5). The task of choosing them ­— or rather of excluding other superb books — grows harder each time. Consider it in terms of arithmetic: If we limited ourselves to a single work of fiction and nonfiction chosen from each of the issues published since Dec. 6, 2009, when the previous Notables list appeared, we would exceed our self-imposed limit.

headline: What’s in a Name? Fashism’s Founder Explains

headline: A Street for Adults in Orlando
text: INTERNATIONAL DRIVE in Orlando, Fla., a shaded boulevard lined with inexpensive hotels, theme restaurants and sundry entertainments (most notably, SeaWorld), is already one of many areas in the city dedicated to keeping children happy. But to many adults traveling without kids  certainly a sizable chunk of the millions who attend events at the nearby Orange County Convention Center  the attraction of I-Drive, as it’s known, has been limited to a handful of bewilderingly large shopping malls.

headline: America’s Funniest Airport Screening Videos
text: Just in time for the holidays, a new genre of home movie is sweeping the nation, or at least YouTube: the bizarre security checkpoint pat-down video. Fueled by hysteria over new screening techniques at America’s airports, an informal competition seems to have started, the aim of which is to film the funniest, or most outrageous, or most outrageously funny example of over-reach, or under-reach, by an employee of the Transportation Security Administration.

headline: Squinkies Maker Savors Demand for Holiday’s Hot Toy
text: Midway through last year, as analysts tried to predict where the economy was going, the toy maker Bill Nichols decided he had the answer. He bet that the economy would still be so shaky this holiday season that a bargain-priced plastic toy would take off.

headline: Our Far-Flung Correspondents
text: Oh, it’s coming up roses and daffodils over here at Diner’s Journal. I suppose at some newspapers and newsgathering organizations the Thanksgiving questions would mostly concern the proper preparation of yams and apple pies. We get those, to be sure, but also much more.

headline: Restaurant Review: Têtedoie, in Lyon, France
text: Long a gastronomic darling of French food critics, the city of Lyon still pulses with the work of adventurous chefs. Earlier this year, it was a startling reinvention by the celebrated Christian Têtedoie that dominated headlines.

headline: Newly Arrived | Chinti and Parker
text: The eco-minded label Chinti and Parker, by the London-based cousins, designers and co-founders Anna Singh and Rachael Wood, is making its way across the pond and into the American market. The label got the attention of Natalie Massenet from the  luxury site Net-a-porter.com, which will carry an exclusive capsule collection. Singh and Wood took a detour to T’s offices for a brief chat. “We’re not complete granolas,” said Wood with a laugh. Equipped with their third season and Net-a-porter selections, Wood said, “our core value is that we are very particular about our fabrics.” That translates into organic jerseys and cashmeres in a variety of weights, like flimsier feels for a sexy slouch trouser and weighty textiles for a more structured dress.

headline: Soldier Shatters the Smug Peace on the Home Front
text: It’s not uncommon for a foreign drama to change before it opens in New York. If the play is not in English, it’s often translated. Culturally specific details are massaged out; elements are changed to appeal to an American audience. When “Copenhagen” transferred from London, for instance, the sound of the nuclear explosion became louder. Broadway likes its bombs big.

headline: Casement Windows Are Architects’ New Darling
text: FOR a long time, mullioned steel casement windows, the gridded kind that swing out like a door, had fallen out of fashion. They leaked badly, and a stiff wind could blow out their panes or knock their hinges askew. Over the years they have been replaced in many buildings by single-pane aluminum casement or double-hung windows.

headline: U.S. Firms Up ‘Critical Habitat’ for Polar Bears
text: The Interior Department designated 187,157 square miles of Alaskan seas and lands as critical to the survival of the polar bear on Wednesday. More than 95 percent of it is offshore, including some areas that may have large undersea oil deposits.

headline: F.H.A. Rule Changes for Mortgage Borrowers
text: HOME buyers with sketchy credit who are unable to qualify for conventional mortgages may now find it more costly and difficult to obtain loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

headline: Kyl Lays Out  Objections to Arms Treaty
text: 5:14 p.m. | Updated The Obama administration’s plans to modernize the nation’s nuclear weapons complex remain inadequate and should be further refined before the ratification of a new arms control treaty with Russia, the lead Senate Republican negotiator said on Wednesday.

headline: Small Club, Big Star, Short Notice
text: It started, as all huge-star-in-tiny-Manhattan-club concerts must, with a ticket rush and a spike in Craigslist prices. In the middle of the story there was lots of pushing and shoving at the door followed by an hour and a half of celebrity spotting and electrifying music, and it ended with a bewildering rant: a classic Kanye West event, in other words, for the lucky few who got to see him perform late Tuesday night.

headline: Getting the Crunch From Cilantro
text: Anybody who’s too lazy to pluck cilantro (or parsley) leaves off their stems before chopping knows that there’s plenty of flavor in those stems — which is one reason they go into the stockpot or a bouquet garni.

headline: Borrowed for ‘Tonight,’ Credited Later
text: When Rich Juzwiak saw a series of video clips that Jay Leno played for the country star Taylor Swift on Monday night’s broadcast of “The Tonight Show,” depicting her reacting with repeated expressions of surprise to a series of awards-show victories, he knew it looked more than familiar. He argued on his blog that the segment had been taken directly from a similar Web video he made with a colleague. The result: NBC acknowledged the work of Mr. Juzwiak and his co-worker on Tuesday’s “Tonight Show.”

headline: Traveler of the Day
text: This is Thembi the hedgehog. He was encountered on the tarmac this afternoon at Kennedy International Airport, aboard a Delta flight bound for Burlington, Vt.

headline: Wild Tigers on a Crowding Planet
text: The first International Tiger Conservation Forum has wrapped up in St. Petersburg, Russia. Dignitaries and participating organizations pledged new support for controls on poaching, efforts to limit tiger-human clashes in populous areas and steps to conserve habitat, with money coming both from the 13 countries where tigers still roam and nations whose citizens desire a world with room for wild tigers. (Money is coming from individuals, as well, including $1 million from Leonardo DiCaprio, who was enthusiastically greeted by the meeting’s host, Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.)

headline: With Facebook Claiming the Word ‘Face,’ Some Alternatives
text: Facebook is a few steps away from getting a trademark on the word “face” with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, according to a document discovered by the technology blog TechCrunch, which it wrote about on Tuesday.

headline: Militaristic Undercurrents Amid Britten’s Seascapes
text: Before conducting the Juilliard Orchestra in Britten’s “Four Sea Interludes” from “Peter Grimes” at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening, Nicholas McGegan said from the stage that it was “a very special day for music lovers,” being both Britten’s birthday and the feast day of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of music. Britten would have been 97 this year, Mr. McGegan added, still younger than the American composer Elliott Carter, who turns 102 next month.

headline: The Last Blacksmith on Blacksmith Street
text: Nguyen Phuong Hung is the last blacksmith on Blacksmith Street in the rapidly modernizing ancient quarter of Hanoi.

headline: Recipe Redux: Fyrstekake (Royal Cake), 1963
text: Midcentury Scandinavian food never had the second life that Scandinavian furniture did. And if you’d like to know why, imagine the opposite — a world in which we savor salted herring and forget about Saarinen tables. No! But if we were to bring back just one worthy dish, I’d vote for fyrstekake, also known as royal cake.

headline: Living In | New Cassel, L.I.
text: The residential blocks of this central Nassau County hamlet are lined with World War II-era Capes, high ranches and split levels.

headline: ABC a Champion, Too, Thanks to Bristol Palin
text: ABC got everything it wanted out of its “Dancing With the Stars” finale Tuesday night: a huge audience, up about 25 percent from last year, and a winner that most of the show’s legion of fans will most likely feel is worthy.

headline: Kate the Great
text: Everyone wants a piece of Kate Moss. A kitten heel short of most modern glamazons, Moss has been one of the most in-demand fashion models for two decades — and one of the most talked about. Now there’s a bit more of her to go around. For the past year and a half, Moss has been collaborating with James Danziger, of Danziger Projects, on curating a portfolio of 11 images of her by 11 of her favorite photographers. The result, a limited edition of 30 portfolios designed by Ruth Ansel and priced from $75,000 each (the figure is expected to go up as the series sells out), is being exhibited for the first time at the Pulse art fair in Miami Dec. 2 to 5. The images, by a stellar lineup of fashion and art world luminaries, including Chuck Close, Juergen Teller and Annie Leibovitz, showcase not only Moss’s preternatural beauty but also her undeniable versatility. The Moment recently phoned Moss at her country home in England.

headline: Enticing Readers to a Long Road With Sudden Shocks of Self-Recognition
text: At first you might wonder why the stories seem so disturbingly familiar. An alienated traveler, wandering through a deserted landscape, forges a brief, doomed relationship with an inscrutable, black-clad stranger. The same traveler, seemingly incapable of finding meaningful human connection, futilely scrambles after a remote possibility of romance. Years later the traveler, now middle aged yet still dissatisfied by his inability to engage meaningfully with others, discovers that he is powerless to alter the fate of a self-destructive friend.

headline: A Play’s Miners Dig for the Meaning Behind Their Art
text: If you love painting or think you could, consider seeing “The Pitmen Painters,” the British play by Lee Hall that the Manhattan Theater Club is presenting on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. It tells the true story of a group of northern England miners who joined an art appreciation class in 1934, but it is really a tutorial in looking at art, especially painting.

headline: Study Finds No Progress in Safety at Hospitals
text: Efforts to make hospitals safer for patients are falling short, researchers report in the first large study in a decade to analyze harm from medical care and to track it over time.

headline: Just Be Thankful It Didn’t Happen to You

headline: Skin Deep: Beauty Gift Guide

headline: Beauty Gifts for All Ages
text: SKIN creams, scents and cosmetics usually make reliable and affordable holiday gifts, but they also can go horribly wrong, as anyone who has had a baby-powder-scented body-splash gift set idling on her latrine for years can attest.

headline: Theater Talkback: Giving Thanks in a Thankless Season
text: A distinct gloom has descended upon conversations among those of us whose business it is to attend the theater as often as some people turn on the television set. By which I mostly mean critics, although I do number among my friends a few obsessive civilians who see almost as much as I do. As the fall season dwindles to a close, the general opinion is that this has been an unusually grim and often grueling couple of months for New York theater, with the more hollow-eyed and enervated among us even suggesting that it’s the worst season in memory.

headline: Letters: Crybabies
text: To the Editor: “Please Refrain From Tantrums Onboard” (Nov. 14) discusses how crying infants disturb other passengers during flight but says virtually nothing about why infants cry and what can be done about it. I have interviewed hundreds of parents who traveled by air with infants. Some of my findings:

headline: Tornadoes of Anarchy and AutoTune
text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  Of the many troubling things at Brokencyde’s show at the Crazy Donkey here Monday night, the most troubling were the apologies. They came from Mikl, one of the group’s vocalists, who was apologizing for his voice, his fatigue, his limited range of movement, for the fact that maybe he’d started off the show a little drunk but was more engaged now.

headline: 3 Numbers to Rate Volt’s Fuel Economy
text: DETROIT  Shoppers trying to determine the fuel efficiency of the Chevrolet Volt will see a window label that offers multiple ratings for different driving patterns, General Motors said on Wednesday.

headline: Evolution of a Beard
text: How Abraham Lincoln went from a clean-shaven candidate to a bearded president.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 24
text: A view of the day in sports, from the Asian Games to chilly football in Canada.

headline: Art Inflation: Macy’s Murakamis
text: It is not uncommon for people to react with awe to their first up-close encounter with a balloon from the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. But when Takashi Murakami saw his contributions to Thursday’s event, he bowed. Twice.

headline: Selling History With ’50s Pulp Pow and Punch
text: The rendezvous was set for 2 p.m. sharp at Cafe Sabarsky on the teeming island metropolis of Manhattan. This Old World outpost was dark and silent as a tomb  except for the music, lively chatter and oversize windows. Near the bar sat a white-haired gentleman in black and a vivacious blonde with a slash of blood-red lipstick. On the table in front of them lay a plate of spätzle mit schwammerln and a knife that glinted like the sharpened steel of a scimitar. Actually, the only thing it was used for was butter, as the team at this cafe, the brother and sister team of David and Margaret Talbot, save the gore for print. They are the mild-mannered creators of a new book series called “Pulp History,” rip-roaring nonfiction tales with enough purple prose, gory illustrations and va-va-va-voom women to lure in even reluctant teenage male readers.

headline: World ‘Dangerously Close’ to Food Crisis, U.N. Says
text: Global grain production will tumble by 63 million metric tons this year, or 2 percent over all, mainly because of weather-related calamities like the Russian heat wave and the floods in Pakistan, the United Nations estimates in its most recent report on the world food supply. The United Nations had previously projected that grain yields would grow 1.2 percent this year.

headline: A TV Vote Seasoned With Politics
text: It must be embedded in the Palin genetic code. Sarah Palin made a virtue of inexperience in the 2008 presidential campaign, baiting her critics for being elitist. On “Dancing With the Stars,” so did Bristol Palin.

headline: Somali Pirates Convicted in Virginia
text: Five Somali men, who were captured by the U.S. Navy in April after they shot at an American guided-missile frigate off the coast of Africa, were convicted of piracy by a federal court in Virginia on Wednesday.

headline: A Hamlet on the Long Road to Renewal
text: “IT’S been a long, long, long journey,” said Bishop Lionel Harvey, the president of the Unified New Cassel Community Revitalization Corporation. When he took over as senior pastor of the local Baptist cathedral 12 years ago, what he found in this 1.5-square-mile unincorporated wedge of the otherwise well-heeled Long Island town of North Hempstead was blight.

headline: Big Night for ABC
text: With the two-hour season finale of “Dancing With the Stars” averaging more than 24 million viewers, ABC easily won the night, even as its 8 o’clock episode of “No Ordinary Family” (7 million) struggled opposite its competition, including CBS’s “NCIS” (18.8 million) and Fox’s “Glee” (10.4 million), with a guest appearance by Carol Burnett. CBS placed second on the night, earning solid results for “NCIS: Los Angeles” (14.9 million) and “The Good Wife” (10 million). Fox was third, and NBC ranked fourth with “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10 (6.8 million), followed by “Parenthood” (4.5 million).

text: At first, there is something unsettling about skulking around a store with a cellphone, using it to scan bar codes and check prices. The behavior is novel enough to draw glances from other shoppers and, more to the point, occasional glares from store clerks.

headline: Official Objections to Emanuel Candidacy
text: CHICAGO – Rahm Emanuel has made it perfectly clear that he wants to be mayor of this city. Now the question is: Does he qualify?

headline: Charting a Friendship Through a Lifetime of Films
text: If you squint a little, “Break Ke Baad” doesn’t look much different from an average — in 2010, perhaps slightly above average — Hollywood romantic comedy. This being an Indian movie, the stars are more attractive but less naturally funny than the Hollywood norm.

headline: It’s Getting Hot in Here
text: But things could be worse, as you shall see. I’m off to review a restaurant and then get some sleep. Please come back in the morning and check in often. Happy Thanksgiving, one and all.

headline: Bon Voyage | A New Line From Azzaro
text: Since she joined the Azzaro French luxury brand as artistic director eight years ago, Vanessa Seward has brought it out of the exclusive realm of fancy-wear and into every-wear — pieces that meet the sundry needs of the everywoman. Not that she is opposed to the glamour. “It was an unconscious move for the line,” says the designer and new mom. “I think having a baby brought a youthfulness, freshness and versatility to the collection.” As she revisited the generations of inspirational women before her, photographs from the 1930s of her grandmother and friends vacationing along the Tigre River in Argentina resurfaced. “Their clothing were all the things I wanted: timeless, comfortable and pretty,” she says. The Voyage capsule collection, Azzaro’s latest diffusion line, is designed with comfort and a more carefree agenda in mind. It includes wrinkle-free materials like jerseys, knits and cashmere, introduced in sophisticated separates (think playsuits and pantsuits) and dresses, like a wrap model with embroidered cord detail. “The Azzaro woman is a woman that shows her femininity,” Seward says. “Nowadays women don’t have to be in a power suit to be in power.”

headline: Hitchcock Would’ve Had a Web Site
text: IN June 1941 a moviegoer named David Stephens wrote the director Frank Capra a letter about the his film “Meet John Doe.” Although Mr. Stephens worried that writing the letter might make him late for work, the force of his feelings kept him scribbling until 3 a.m. “All this talk of pessimism that all high school graduates get must be wrong,” he wrote. “We are told that we go out to meet a cruel, hard, debasing world, of men that will cut your heart to sunders if they possibly can.”

headline: Novelist’s Self-Portrait, Distilled on Screen
text: IN this country Mordecai Richler is probably best known for the movie “The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz,” based on his novel of the same name. (With Lionel Chetwynd, he also wrote the screenplay.) But for some unaccountable reason Richler, who died in 2001, was immensely popular in Italy, where was last novel, “Barney’s Version,”was a best seller. And in his native Canada he was a national institution, cherished because of the way he indiscriminately poked fun at Canadians in general, but especially the Jews, the French separatists and the Anglophile nationalists, who were locked in mutual antagonism.

headline: A Renter With Piano-Sized Issues
text: THOUGH she had rented in both Boston and Pittsburgh, Vivian Choi had no idea what she would be facing in a hunt for an apartment in New York.

headline: Breaking Into the Smartphone (Risks Included)
text: Keith Medenblik is captivated by the iPhone. He bought his first iPhone, the 3G model, two years ago. A year later he upgraded to a 3GS and more recently to Apple’s newest creation, the iPhone 4.

headline: DeLay Is Convicted in Texas Donation Case
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Tom DeLay, one of the most powerful and divisive Republican lawmakers ever to come out of Texas, was convicted Wednesday of money-laundering charges in a state trial, five years after his indictment here forced him to resign as majority leader in the House of Representatives.

headline: Gay ‘Progressive’ Republican on Air in Iowa
text: It’s never too early to test the waters – especially for an openly gay “progressive” Republican trying to snag the party’s 2012 presidential nomination.

headline: A Small Apartment Where Simplicity Reigns
text: The owner of a high-end cleaning service in New York lives in a spare apartment decorated entirely in white.

headline: A Tiny White Apartment for a Pared-Down Life
text: SEEING photos of the pristine white apartment of the home-cleaning queen Barbara Roche Fierman  an apartment so dust-, dirt- and stain-free it appears no human could possibly live there  makes a reporter think dastardly thoughts.

headline: A Reprieve for Missing 9/11 Plaintiffs
text: Some 9/11 workers who did not accept a settlement offered by the city by last week’s deadline will have another bite at the apple: the federal judge overseeing the cases has appointed a lawyer to help those who may want to opt into the settlement after all to make that choice by Dec. 17.

text: Four questions for Tatsugo Yoda, owner and founder of Aloha Rag; Janice Huminska has opened a shop in NoLIta; Diane Von Furstenberg’s trench coat; and more.

headline: The Lessons of 10 Years of Talking Tech

headline: O.K., Hippos, Grab Your Tutus
text: FOR generations now “Fantasia” has been both faulted for its highbrow pretensions and derided as low-brow kitsch, frequently by the same critics and sometimes in the same sentence. But this 1940 animated feature from Walt Disney remains unassailable, a cultural artifact that stands beyond simple categorization, perhaps Hollywood’s closest brush with the avant-garde.

headline: The Pacifier Gets an Upgrade: Apps and Gadgets to Soothe the Baby
text: I ACQUIRED my first piece of baby-related technology two months ago, just a few hours after the birth of my son. My wife, baby and I were all still in the hospital, and the baby  who looked a bit less confused than my wife and I about this new state of affairs  seemed to need help getting to sleep. After a bit of trial and error, I found that he appeared to be comforted by a gentle, continuous shushing sound near his ear. But how long could I keep shushing? Wasn’t there some easier way?

headline: ‘Greatest American Houses’ in a Page-by-Page Tour
text: What makes Dominique Browning’s and Lucy Gilmour’s book, “Living Architecture: Greatest American Houses of the 20th Century” (Assouline; $75), different from the hundreds of other coffee-table books about homes like Frank Lloyd Wright’s Fallingwater? The photographs. They are stunning, and so plentiful they allow the reader to imagine living, breathing and eating in the homes.

headline: 16-Year-Old Who Needs Transplants Opens Richardson’s Heart
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On the phone from Texas Children’s Hospital in Houston, 16-year-old Tyler Nelson sounded worried. Only he never mentioned cystic fibrosis, which he was born with, or lung and liver transplants, which he desperately needs.

headline: All Is Sparkly for Tiffany
text: Europe may be burning and the United States is smoldering, but the comfortably off are splurging on their blue-boxed trinkets. Tiffany & Company is reaping the benefits, posting double-digit sales growth across the globe in its third quarter, most notably in Europe where receipts rose 22 percent in the period. Together with a bright outlook, that suggests well-heeled and aspirational consumers are not expecting another painful downturn.

headline: An East Village Guy, Up in Lights
text: A FEW minutes before the premiere of “The Break of Noon,” the Neil LaBute play that opened Monday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in the West Village, the actress Téa Leoni scooted up to Gillian Anderson. The star of the play is David Duchovny, Ms. Leoni’s husband and Ms. Anderson’s former co-star on “The X-Files.”

headline: Celebrating Hamptons Homes and Italian Design
text: The East Hampton Historical Society’s 2010 House and Garden Tour will open with a cocktail party on Friday. The tour will take place the next day. It includes six homes, the oldest of which is a 1920s colonial revival designed by Aymar Embury II; the newest is a shingle-style house completed this year and designed by Barnes Coy and Associates of Bridgehampton, N.Y. In between is Michael Katz’s home, above, designed in 1965 by Daniel Chait, the architect who renovated the Queens Museum of Art in 1964. “This is not your typical Hamptons cottage,” said Mr. Katz, an interior designer who bought and restored the house in 2007. “It was kind of bohemian. The ceiling has a glass skylight that runs the entire length of the house.” Information: easthamptonhistory.org or (631) 324-6850.

headline: Holiday Decorations in Gold
text: THE United States has gone off the gold standard, but to the party designer David Monn, gold is still the standard by which glamour is measured. To spruce up a home for holiday entertaining, Mr. Monn has a particular fondness for it.

headline: In SoHo, a New Outpost for High-Style Outdoor Furniture
text: Anyone who has lounged poolside at an expensive resort is likely to be aware of Dedon. The company’s minimalist outdoor furniture has graced stylish spaces as varied as La Mamounia in Marrakesh, Morocco, and the W South Beach hotel in Miami Beach, Fla. And as of last week, Dedon could also be found in SoHo, at the company’s first retail showroom.

headline: An Empty House Where Time Stands Still
text: ON a neighborly block in Mobile, Ala., an old brick house with a weathered slate roof sits on a sun-beaten lawn. Leading to the front door with the blue-green shutters on each side  Mom varied the color a few times  are three steps and a small porch.

headline: Shepard Fairey Puts His Mark on a Miami Restaurant
text: Shepard Fairey, the artist responsible for the Barack Obama “Hope” poster, has created a series of murals for the Wynwood Kitchen and Bar, a restaurant opening on Friday in Miami, just in time for the DesignMiami fair next week. Mr. Fairey’s work, which dominates and defines the restaurant’s space, is a combination of screen-printed and painted images pieced together into a kind of mosaic. “The W.P.A. posters are definitely one of the inspirations,” Mr. Fairey said. “And propaganda art.”

headline: Alberto Alessi on Everyday Appliances and Big Ideas
text: Clad head to toe in black and carrying a black zippered attaché case, Alberto Alessi sat in the lobby of the Gramercy Park Hotel one morning this week looking every bit a member of the Italian design intelligentsia. Mr. Alessi, who is the president and director of marketing strategies and design management of Alessi S.p.A., a company started by his grandfather Giovanni in 1921, was in town after the opening on Sunday of “Alessi: Ethical and Radical” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. The exhibition documents the company’s collaborations since 1955 with Ron Arad, Michael Graves, the Campana brothers, Ettore Sottsass, Philippe Starck, Alessandro Mendini (who also designed the exhibit) and others.

text: The holiday season begins this week, and for those looking to keep the calories in check or burn off the extra stress of family visits and air travel, the New York Times Tech Talk team takes a look at apps and gadgets that can help. The roundup includes a discussion of MP3 players that have integrated pedometers, stand-alone fitness trackers and smartphone apps that let you record your workouts and calories.

headline: Robert B. Daugherty, Who Helped Irrigate the Plains, Dies at 88
text: Robert B. Daugherty, a Nebraska businessman who helped transform the rural landscape into a patchwork of circular fields by popularizing a means of irrigation that used a pipe on wheels pivoting around a central point, died on Wednesday at his home in Omaha. He was 88.

headline: The Film Projectionist Who Looks Away

Micherdzinski was home in Yonkers with his wife, Mary Ann, watching the original black-and-white version of “The Night of the Living Dead.” Mr. Micherdzinski, 67, has been a film projectionist since 1968, so this seemed a bit like a pizza-maker going out for a holiday meal and wolfing down a dozen slices of Sicilian, but no.

headline: Suffering, Haitians Turn to Charismatic Prayer
text: The pastor likes to sing in tongues on his daily walk around the park. Certain women in his parish say so many Hail Marys on their own that he no longer assigns them the prayers as penance for sins; instead, he may prescribe a pedicure. On a Saturday night in the basement of his mostly Haitian church in Queens, in a bare white room vibrating with hymns and exclamations, a young woman may find herself channeling the Holy Spirit to reveal news from Haiti.

headline: State and City Had Fruitless Talks on Deputy to Aid the Chancellor Pick

headline: Knicks Reach Milestone; They’re a .500 Team

headline: Bless the Orange Sweet Potato
text: As we all prepare to gain a few pounds over Thanksgiving, I promise not to be a buzz kill wagging my finger about starva ... well, never mind. You see, this is that rarest of birds: a happy column about hunger.

headline: A Jury Convicts Tom DeLay
text: After a year of increasingly depressing news about the unbridled, unaccountable influence of big money in political campaigns, a Texas jury stood up for honesty in campaign finance on Wednesday and convicted Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, of money laundering. Unfortunately, there are now many new ways for politicians to commit acts similar to those for which Mr. DeLay was convicted, all of them perfectly legal.

headline: Close Your Eyes and See With Your Heart
text: Marcus Yam, 26, was born and raised in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. He had a degree in aerospace engineering when he decided to pursue photography. He is now a regular contributor to The Times, has worked for The Washington Post and The Associated Press and is finishing his thesis at the Ohio University School of Visual Communication. This conversation, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

headline: The Mayor and the Chancellor
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg scored a huge victory for New York City public education in 2002 when he won control of the school system, but parents and state officials often complained that outside voices were not heard. On Tuesday, a panel of state educators essentially upbraided him for failing to listen to those who wanted a professional educator as the system’s new chancellor.

headline: Thanksgiving Scripture
text: In 1936, with the Great Depression persisting, the governor of Connecticut issued a Thanksgiving Proclamation so inspiring that people in the state learned it by heart as if it were scripture. It was common then to memorize stirring speeches and other texts, but not public decrees. The proclamation’s message and 2010’s turmoil make this a very good year to re-read the document.

headline: Belgium: Talks Remove Obstacle to W.T.O. Membership For Russia
text: Russian and European Union negotiators said Wednesday that they had resolved crucial differences on trade, removing a significant obstacle to Russia’s long-delayed plans to join the World Trade Organization. After talks in Brussels, the two sides issued a joint statement saying they were confident their deal would “greatly facilitate the overall process of accession of Russia to the W.T.O.” The two sides resolved differences over tariffs on the export of raw materials, including timber, and railway freight transit.

headline: Brazil: Economic Team Named
text: President-elect Dilma Rousseff assembled her new economic team on Wednesday, nominating Alexandre Antonio Tombini, left, an economist and Central Bank official, to succeed Henrique Meirelles as head of the Central Bank. Mr. Meirelles had rejected another term at the Central Bank unless he were given full autonomy to set monetary policy, as he has had since he assumed the position in 2003, according to Brazilian news media. Nominating Mr. Tombini, 46, and keeping Guido Mantega as finance minister, a decision that she also announced Wednesday, suggest that Ms. Rousseff will stay the course of economic policy set by her predecessor, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

headline: Gratitude the Hard Way
text: An aspect of Thanksgiving I’ve always had trouble with is the part about giving thanks. I’m not against gratitude, but things to be grateful for just don’t naturally spring to mind.

headline: The Incredible Flying Nonagenarian
text: On the third floor of the Montreal Chest Institute, at McGill University, Olga Kotelko stood before a treadmill in the center of a stuffy room that was filling up with people who had come just for her. They were there to run physical tests, or to extract blood from her earlobe, or just to observe and take notes. Kotelko removed her glasses. She wore white New Balance sneakers and black running tights, and over her silver hair, a plastic crown that held in place a breathing tube.

headline: Ingrid Pitt, Horror Star Who Survived Nazis, Dies at 73
text: Lovely and voluptuous, the actress Ingrid Pitt was given a choice early in her film career: pornography or horror. Ms. Pitt, who had spent her childhood in a Nazi concentration camp, later scoured Europe in search of her vanished father and still later was forced to flee East Germany a step ahead of the police, chose horror. It was a genre she knew firsthand.

headline: No Wall-Busting, Please

headline: South Korea Reassesses Its Defenses After Attack

headline: Once Coveted, Now Orphaned
text: LAST month was the end of the line for yet another American automotive brand. Assembly plants produced the final vehicles to carry the Mercury nameplate, an unceremonious end for a marque that had been introduced in 1939 as an upscale companion for basic Fords  but more recently allowed to atrophy to little more than a selection of lightly modified Ford sedans and S.U.V.’s.

headline: Give Thanks It’s Not Raining Yet

Sat on the platform for 45 minutes waiting with the whiners trying to get to Penn and wondering if they should leave the station and go find a yellow cab, reading the tabs and realizing how different my life is from theirs.

headline: Taking Bets on the Royal Dress
text: The British royal family may not be the media’s only compass, but the needle certainly moved at the announcement that Prince William and Kate Middleton will wed, on April 29 at Westminster Abbey. Goodbye “Strictly Come Dancing,” luminaries in the broken-down zoo of celebrity … hello Kate! You sensed a collective surge of relief in the young lady’s direction — that her wedding might be good not only for the downsized economy but also maybe good for the country as a whole.

headline: Junking Junk Food
text: Earlier this month, Sarah Palin showed up in Bucks County, Pa., with “dozens and dozens” of cookies, suggesting that the state’s schoolchildren risked losing the right to the occasional classroom treat because of a high-minded anti-sugar edict from the board of education. Pretty much everything about the setup was wrong. Pennsylvania wasn’t, as Palin tweeted, in the midst of a “school cookie ban” debate. And the school she turned into a photo op wouldn’t have been subject to such a ban had one existed; it wasn’t a public school but a private Christian academy. And while Palin might have been seizing an opportunity to “intro kids 2 beauty of laissez-faire,” she wasn’t just visiting with schoolchildren but was delivering a paid speech at a fund-raiser.

headline: The King’s English, Albeit With Twisted Tongue
text: British films that make it to American screens these days often fall into two distinct niches: life is miserable and life is sweet (to borrow a title from the director Mike Leigh, who oscillates between the two). Given its quality headliners and high commercial profile (ding-dong, is that Oscar calling?), it’s no surprise that “The King’s Speech,” a buddy story about aggressively charming opposites — Colin Firth as the stutterer who would be king and Geoffrey Rush as the speech therapist — comes with heaping spoonfuls of sugar.

headline: You Are on Your Own, Little Ones
text: This is the last set of questions I’m answering today. I need to get back to Kings County to whip up some gravy for the turkeys my friends and family made while I was at work. We’ll have a drink or two, eat a huge meal, take a walk down the damp streets in the dark and watch a movie, just as President Washington intended. Thanks for playing along. You may of course continue the conversation in the comments below. Recipes for leftovers will be in great demand tomorrow, after all.

headline: ‘Elling’ to Close on Broadway
text: So much for little-known Norwegian comedies surviving on brutal commercial Broadway. The new play “Elling,” which opened on Sunday and stars Denis O’Hare (a Tony Award winner for “Take Me Out”) and Brendan Fraser (“The Mummy” movies), will close this Sunday after 22 previews and nine regular performances, a spokeswoman for the production said on Thursday.

headline: Habitats | Lower East Side

headline: 375 Square Feet? Just Think of the Possibilities!
text: TO reach the apartment where Daniel and Dasha Faires live, you pass through the vestibule of a small century-old brick building on Ludlow Street and head down a dingy tile-lined hallway. But hang a left near the trash can, and you will find something amazing.

headline: Constructing Happiness With a Carnal Ghost
text: A small movie with a full heart, “Undertow” takes an old idea — the loving, lingering ghost — and gives it reverberant, resuscitated life. The story unwinds gracefully and with slow-building emotion in a tiny seaside village in remotest Peru, where, save for a few modern conveniences, people live much as they probably did decades earlier, pulling fish from the sea and bound by communal interdependence. There, a young fisherman, Miguel (Cristian Mercado), awaits the birth of his first child, an event that fills him with so much happiness that he shares his bliss generously with his beloved wife and his more adored male lover.

headline: In Many Configurations, Trio Tackles the Moderns
text: The classical offerings at Le Poisson Rouge usually explore either experimental corners of new music or the growing part of the repertory that borrows liberally from rock and jazz. But the club’s laid-back atmosphere makes it an appealing place to hear more conventional programs too, and on Wednesday evening, the Parnas/Kohlberg Trio presented a straightforward overview of the more conservative side of the 20th-century repertory, with a brief foray into the early 19th century along the way.

headline: Acrobatics Amid Flakes: It’s Cirque du Snowfall
text: In the finale of “Wintuk” the audience disappears in a nor’easter of crepe-paper snowflakes. Until then, though, the wonderment of Cirque du Soleil’s fourth (and final) holiday visit to the cavernous Theater at Madison Square Garden occurs despite, not because of, the seasonal trappings.

headline: Chalk Up Wednesday to CBS
text: “Survivor” and crime-show repeats lifted CBS just ahead of ABC to lead the ratings on Wednesday in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates CBS’s rerun of “Criminal Minds” delivered one of the night’s largest audiences, with 9.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., building on the 8 million who tuned in to the network’s “Survivor: Nicaragua” at 8. At 10 p.m. a repeat of CBS’s “Defenders” won the time slot with 7.3 million viewers, finishing ahead of ABC’s “Primetime” with 6 million. ABC ranked second, benefiting from new episodes of “Modern Family” at 9 (10.5 million) and “The Middle” at 8 (8.2 million). NBC finished in a virtual tie for third with Fox.

headline: Billy Joel Has Hip Surgery
text: Billy Joel, the 61-year-old Grammy-winning singer and songwriter, is recovering from double hip replacement surgery, according to his spokeswoman, Claire Mercuri, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Mercuri told People magazine on Wednesday that Mr. Joel had undergone surgery on both hips last week to correct a congenital condition, and that he was doing “extremely well.” There was no word about when Mr. Joel might return to any of his numerous projects. He recently wrapped up both a concert tour with Elton John and promotion for the documentary “The Last Play at Shea,” which tells the story of Mr. Joel’s relationship with Shea Stadium, including the last two concerts he played there in 2008 before the stadium was torn down. In April Mr. Joel told Rolling Stone magazine that he was working on “thematic music, orchestral music” that could be used for new songs, a film score or the television show “Glee.” “I was in chorus in high school, so I know what that stuff’s all about,” he said. “I love stuff like that.”

headline: Ana Maria Matute Wins Cervantes Prize
text: The novelist Ana Maria Matute has won the Cervantes Prize, the leading literary award for works in Spanish, Agence France-Presse reported. “I am happy, enormously happy,” Ms. Matute, 85, said at a news conference in Spain on Wednesday. “I take it as a recognition, if not of the quality of my work, then at least of the effort and dedication that I have devoted to writing throughout my life,” she said. Ms. Matute’s novels, like “School of the Sun” and “Soldiers Cry by Night,” are known for their lyrical style and reflect the themes of social injustice and oppression experienced by the Spanish during the rule of Franco and the aftermath of the Spanish Civil War. King Juan Carlos will present Ms. Matute with the award, which comes with a $167,000 prize, on April 23, the anniversary of the death of Cervantes, in Alcala de Henares, Cervantes’ birthplace. Ms. Matute is the third woman to win the prize, which is administered by the Spanish Ministry of Culture.

headline: Bruce Willis, the New Face of Russian Banking
text: Bruce Willis’s next big role won’t be in Hollywood, or even the United States. Mr. Willis, 55, has been recruited by a Russian bank to be the face of its new advertising campaign, BBC News reported. According to a statement from Trust Bank, Mr. Willis will be featured in ads over the next year, replacing the bank’s former spokesman, the Russian weight lifter and actor Vladimir Turchinsky, who died in 2009. The bank said it chose Mr. Willis because he embodied its slogan of “trust and dignity.“ On Monday the campaign’s first posters went up in Moscow, featuring a picture of Mr. Willis with the slogan “Trust is just like me, but a bank.”

headline: Construction Has Halted at Los Angeles Museum
text: The directors of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art have ordered work to stop on the second phase of a three-part, $450 million renovation and expansion plan until they can raise more money, The Los Angeles Times reported. The decision to halt the project was prompted by a report on the museum’s finances issued by Moody’s Investors Services last week. The report showed that while the museum retained its A2 investment rating, considered a good credit risk, on its $383 million in construction bonds, a negative rating was expected in the future should it be unable to maintain a certain degree of liquidity. Construction costs and a drop in private donations during the recession have both taken a toll. The museum is hoping to raise an additional $100 million in donations before continuing work. Under Phase 1 the Broad Contemporary Art Museum and the BP Grand Entrance were opened in 2008 and the Resnick Exhibition Pavilion in September. The second phase will turn a former department store into new offices and galleries. Specifics about the third phase, which involves renovations to older buildings, have not yet been disclosed.

headline: Swing Dancing in Queens, Free Dancing at Ailey
text: If the darker nights have you missing the long days of summer, you don’t have to hide inside. Instead you can head to the Bohemian Beer Hall in Queens, where a little denial and a lot of jive have meant the extension of its Sam Adams Summer Sunday Swing nights through the winter. This week the Solomon Douglas Swingtet will keep things jumping from 7 to 10 p.m. Free swing lessons are open to everyone, but the free drinks are only for those hep cats and kittens decked out in zoot suits or other period threads. (29-19 24th Avenue, Astoria, Queens; 718-274-4925, bohemianhall.com; $5 cover charge.)

headline: Agency Sold by One Private Equity Firm to Another
text: Apax Partners has agreed to acquire Advantage Sales and Marketing from J. W. Childs Associates and BAML Capital Partners, the latest large leveraged buyout in which a company would pass from one private equity group to another. The deal values Advantage at about $1.8 billion, according to a person close to the deal who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss it publicly. Apax will acquire about 85 percent of the company, with Advantage’s existing management owning the rest. Advantage, based in Irvine, Calif., is a leading sales and marketing agency for consumer goods, working with clients like J. M. Smucker and Johnson & Johnson to maximize the value of their brands. The company has about $1 billion in annual revenue and is expected to generate about $180 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization this year, according to this person. J. W. Childs and BAML Capital Partners, formerly Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, acquired the closely held Advantage in 2006 for $1.05 billion. The firms are expected to make roughly three times their cash investment on the deal, which is expected to close by year-end.

headline: 2 Brothers Will Rule in Wisconsin

headline: Twentysomethings in Memphis
text: Kentucker Audley’s $17,000 third feature, “Open Five,” has a shape to it, as well as a look and a rhythm, and at that price, those are accomplishments. The coherence of the story, about four twentysomethings hanging out and hooking up during a weekend in Memphis, and the relative polish of the camerawork and editing may indicate either growth or capitulation on Mr. Audley’s part, depending on your point of view. They certainly reflect a valuable contribution by the better-known director Joe Swanberg, who served as cinematographer.

headline: Court Rules Against Candy Labeled ‘Pure Chocolate’
text: Italian rules allowing candy makers including Nestlé to label their products as “pure chocolate” breach European Union law, the bloc’s highest court in Luxembourg said. The law “makes no provision for the sales name ‘pure chocolate,’ ” the court said. Allowing an extra sales name for chocolate that contains no vegetable fat “is likely to mislead consumers and thus interfere with their right to obtain correct, neutral and objective information.” Chocolate rules have led to legal battles since 1973, when Britain, Ireland and Denmark joined the European Union in resisting standards that required chocolate to contain only cocoa fats. Under the old rules, countries like Italy were allowed to block imports of chocolate made with alternative fats.

This is a great improvement over the stingy BP operation he replaced.

headline: Description Is Prescription
text: One hundred years ago, Leo Tolstoy lay dying at a train station in southern Russia. Journalists, acolytes and newsreel photographers gathered for the passing of the great prophet. Between 3:30 and 5:30 on that freezing November morning, Tolstoy’s wife stood on the porch outside his death chamber because his acolytes would not let her in. At one point she begged them to at least admit her into an anteroom so that the photographers would get the impression she was being allowed to see her husband on his final day.

text: In 2009, when Kanye West interrupted Taylor Swift’s MTV Video Music Awards acceptance speech to say Beyoncé should have won the award for best female video, perhaps he planted an idea with prime-time programmers. Thanksgiving night brought successive specials by Ms. Swift, at 8 p.m. on NBC, and Beyoncé, at 9:30 on ABC. Both featured billowing golden hair, live performances and pop image-polishing: Ms. Swift as careful as could be, Beyoncé confident enough to loosen up.

headline: Friday: Action and Adventure
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Some solvers prefer the crosswords with themes that we see Sunday through Thursday. Others like the so-called “themeless” puzzles that arrive on Friday and Saturday. But why should we have to choose? The fun of the themeless crossword is not the lack of a common thread. It’s the joy of all the great clues and answers that can emerge when constructors are unconstrained by having to symmetrically fit four or five (or more) similar entries into a tiny grid. If you can make a great Friday puzzle and squeeze in a theme to tie it together, then everyone wins. Gary Steinmehl accomplishes just that today. It’s statistically a typical Friday, the clues are delightfully nefarious, and three long answers are names of Z-full action/adventure films.

headline: Texas A&M Stakes Claim as Leader in Pharmaceuticals
text: One hundred miles from the nearest major city, where there was nothing but flat earth seven months ago, a 145,000-square-foot facility has sprung up on the Texas A&M Health Science Center campus. Starting in January, its cavernous rooms will be filled with racks of tobacco-like plants expected to produce as many influenza vaccines in a single month as a traditional lab does in one year, at a fraction of the cost.

headline: Canada: Orthodox Church Leader is Charged With Sexual Assault

The allegations against the archbishop, Kenneth William Storheim, who is known as Archbishop Seraphim within the church, date back 30 years, according to a statement issued last month by the church. The police declined to give any details about the charges, citing a publication ban.

headline: Frank Fenner Dies at 95; Tracked End of Smallpox
text: Frank Fenner, an Australian scientist who played an important role in the World Health Organization’s decade-long campaign to eradicate smallpox and who made the official announcement, in 1980, that the disease had been conquered once and for all, died Monday in Canberra. He was 95.

headline: Poland: Three Men Charged In Theft of Auschwitz Sign
text: Two Polish citizens and a Swede have been charged with crimes connected to theft of the infamous “Arbeit Macht Frei” sign at the Auschwitz concentration camp, prosecutors in Krakow, Poland, said. The German-language sign, which hung over the camp’s gate and whose words mean “Work Sets You Free,” was stolen Dec. 18. The Swedish suspect, Anders Hogstrom, a former neo-Nazi leader in his homeland, was extradited to Poland in April. He and the two Poles, who have been identified only as Andrzej S. and Marcin A., could face up to three years in prison.

headline: Pakistan: Court’s Help is Urged in Blasphemy Death Sentence
text: The Pakistani government has asked the lawyers for a Christian woman who has been sentenced to death for blasphemy against Islam to seek exoneration from a High Court. The federal minister for minorities, Shahbaz Bhatti, said the woman, Asia Bibi, 45, should try to get her death sentence overturned by the Lahore High Court before the president considers a pardon. Ms. Bibi is the first woman in Pakistan to be sentenced to death for blasphemy. She is accused of denigrating the Prophet Muhammad after fellow agriculture workers protested that a Christian had been asked to bring them a container of drinking water.

headline: France: New Search for Wreckage In 2009 Air France Crash
text: The French government said Thursday that investigators would mount a fresh search for the wreckage of an Air France jet that crashed in the mid-Atlantic 18 months ago. The effort, which is expected to begin in February, will follow three previous attempts by the government, Air France and Airbus, the manufacturer of the plane, an A330-200. All 228 passengers and crew members were killed when Flight 447 went down in heavy thunderstorms while flying from Rio de Janeiro to Paris on June 1, 2009. The searches yielded more than 600 pieces of debris, but the flight recorders have not been found.

headline: Canada: Asylum Overturned for White South African
text: The Federal Court of Canada overturned the refugee status granted to a white South African who said that he faced persecution, discrimination and possibly death because of his race if he returned home. The decision, which was released on Wednesday, ordered a new hearing by the Immigration and Refugee Board for the South African, Brandon Huntley. His initial success with the board was controversial in Canada, and the South African government filed a formal protest. The court acknowledged that violence and crime were widespread in South Africa, but it found that Mr. Huntley did not demonstrate that previous attacks against him were racially motivated.

headline: Taking Flight
text: It has never been done, what Jennifer Homans has done in “Apollo’s Angels.” She has written the only truly definitive history of the most impossibly fantastic art form, ballet, this most refined, most exquisite art of “aristocratic etiquette,” this “science of behavior toward others,” as a 17th-century ballet master put it, in which lovely young women perch upon their 10 little toe tips (actually, it is ­really just the two big toes that alternately support the entire body’s weight: think about it) and waft about where the air is thinner — but heaven is closer. She has taken this world where wilis, virgins, sylphs, sleeping princesses, the “women in white” embody the eternal — the eternally unattainable — and set it into the fabric of world history, and we see, miraculously, their pale tulle and satin pointes peeking out from the crevices of war, of revolutions, of political machinations, and on the ­stages of the monarchies and empires of the kings and czars who gave birth to this improbable art.

headline: Tip of the Week: Undoing Undo
text: The keyboard shortcut for Undo — also known as Control-Z in Windows or Command-Z on a Mac — has saved many Microsoft Word files from accidental deletions or unintended formatting over the years. But what if you move too quickly and actually meant to keep the text or formatting the way it was? In Word, the cure for a premature Undo command is Control-Y or Command-Y, which repeats your last action before you “undid” it.
