headline: Men of Words
text: In 2010, we lost four towering figures in the world of words. They all shared a deep and abiding love of the English language, though they expressed that love in distinctly different ways. Two made impassioned public cries against perceived abuses of English, while two others worked meticulously behind the scenes to record the ever-evolving richness of the linguistic landscape.

headline: Vanity Unfair
text: I used to anticipate each issue of Vanity Fair with an enthusiasm that bordered on frantic. I’ve been hoping to remember that buzz now that I have the lustrous-looking Vanity Fair app for my iPad.

headline: Highfliers
text: In March 2008, Gulfstream Aerospace, the maker of private jets, announced that it was working on its biggest, fastest and most luxurious model yet: the G650. The list price, $64.5 million, would set an industry benchmark. Given the direction of the global economy since, the timing seems pretty bad. But the private-jet business is unusual. Gulfstream, a division of General Dynamics, has held up fairly well through the Great Recession and recently announced surprisingly strong quarterly sales figures. The G650, meanwhile, made its first flights last year, and even though its F.A.A. certification process will take another year or so, Gulfstream already has contracts to make these planes for about 200 customers, which means that if you’d like to sign up right now, the earliest you would get yours is 2017.

headline: Attention: Deficit
text: As a billionaire investor who has been fixated on the federal deficit for years and was secretary of commerce under President Nixon, are you surprised to see deficit-reduction become such a hot topic this fall?  Well, I don’t want to end up in self-aggrandizement here. I do have a large number of people saying, You’ve been talking about this long-term problem for 20 years, and it’s here.

headline: The Professor of Micropopularity
text: ON A MONDAY evening in September, James Schamus and a dozen students in his graduate seminar in film theory at Columbia University were discussing the dialogues of Plato. Each participant who spoke called on the next speaker, and Schamus gave the group plenty of leeway to tussle with the text, but every once in a while he raised his hand and intervened to guide the conversation. The course was called Seeing Narrative, and the discussion centered on Plato’s skepticism about the ability of any visible thing to represent ideal truth — a skepticism that, say, a bunch of beautiful images strung together in a movie could communicate the perfect, invisible idea of Beauty.

headline: Killing a Dead Horse in Ireland
text: Two years ago, when I found myself temporarily retired by a jobless universe, I moved back in with my parents, who live on a farm in Ireland. Many a stressed-out New Yorker would kill for the chance to unwind in an emerald paradise remote enough that a strange car passing up the road was a thrill, but I found myself floundering, unable to make peace with the fact that I was no longer a contributing member of society.

headline: Letters: Lives
text: I was deeply touched by Frederick Woolverton’s disclosure of being the ‘‘most-hated son’’ and having testified at his 10-year-old sister’s custody trial. He talked about the horrors of living with his alcoholic mother and the culture of fear that permeated the existence of his siblings. Until this reading I had not ever heard of another situation similar to my own. I testified at a custody trial at age 12 along with two other siblings, to choose which parent with which to spend the rest of my childhood. Fifty years later, we remain puzzled at the estrangements and disconnections from one another. This pivotal stage of court appearances changed much in our lives and ultimately, I believe, drove my brothers and sister and I apart. Not fully understanding why, I think Woolverton touched on issues that I can now reflect on, shake out and perhaps present to willing family members. Thanks to this article, my family might be willing to take another look at a time that we’ve all tried in our own ways to bury. Dianne Murphey Keystone Heights, Fl.I thank Frederick Woolverton for his Lives essay and The Times Magazine for publishing it. In a world with so much hurt and where many parent-child relationships are complicated by addiction, Woolverton is able to transcend his own past and be kind to his mother (and as a mental-health professional, help others with addiction). Although the author doesn’t believe that he forgives his mother, his treatment of her shows that at least part of him has forgiven — even if he will never forget.Betsy Garman Washington I was touched by Frederick Woolverton’s desire to reconcile with his elderly mother. Most of us understand his desire for closure, made more pressing by his mother’s age and frailty, though many would not share his ability to be so gracious in that situation. But it troubled me to read of his decision to visit his nursing-home-bound mother unannounced, since she ‘‘couldn’t communicate’’ and ‘‘could no longer refuse me.’’ The nursing-home culture change movement teaches us to respect individuals’ autonomy, however we feel about their choices. A broken relationship between mother and son is an extreme example of a choice; but it is, nonetheless, a choice. No matter her past behavior, Woolverton’s mother became the vulnerable one in their relationship. Rosa BaierProvidence, R.I.

headline: Letter: The Hacker Who Went Into the Cold
text: James Verini’s amazing story of Albert Gonzalez’s cybercrimes underplays the fact that they were possible only because of lax security measures. Gonzalez’s targets left consumers’ financial information out in the open for anyone with know-how to steal. Gonzalez’s techniques were not novel — unsecured wireless networks and S.Q.L. injections are notorious within the technical community as gaping security holes. Clearly, his actions were illegal and unethical, but institutions that process millions of transactions each day must take a modicum of responsibility for failing to protect against well-known means of attack. The victims — individual consumers, taxpayers and affected businesses — should expect no less.

headline: Full Disclosures
text: My same-sex partner and I are legally married in another country, a marriage not recognized by our state or (obviously) federal government, with significant negative consequences to our modest financial situation. My partner would be eligible for some government aid if she applied as a single person, but it feels disingenuous to do so, because as a family, we make well above the poverty line. In some sense, however, the government owes us this money since it unjustly disregards our marriage. Should she apply? NAME WITHHELD, PORTLAND, ME.

headline: Letter: On Language
text: Ben Zimmer may be thankful that the worldwide Web has developed in a highly decentralized fashion, but similar comforting beliefs have always been a core element of spider-web imagery. The 15th-century Burgundian chronicler Jean Molinet named the French king Louis XI the “universal spider” because of his political cunning: his opponents didn’t realize they were trapped until it was too late. Let us hope the modern Internet doesn’t live up to its name.

headline: Letter: The Ethicist
text: In Randy Cohen’s column “The Anti-Antibiotics Doctor,” he finds it “disturbingly conservative” when a doctor refuses to prescribe “standby” antibiotics to a patient with frequent “bronchial infections” planning a trip to Peru. As infectious-disease physicians, we respectfully disagree. Indeed, the overprescribing of antibiotics is disturbingly common, especially for respiratory infections of viral origin, which make up the vast majority of these “bronchial infections.” (Antibiotics do not work against viruses.) This overuse leads to antibiotic resistance, a dangerous and very real phenomenon. The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta has been trying for years to educate the public and physicians about the risks of misusing antibiotics. Antibiotics are a nonrenewable resource: for this reason and others, they are not available over-the-counter in our country. In many South American countries like Peru, antibiotics are available over-the-counter, contributing to widespread resistance in these countries. Doctors that prescribe antibiotics only when really indicated — “anti-antibiotics doctors,” in Cohen’s words — are actually the ones helping the most to keep these “wonder drugs” effective when they are really needed.

headline: Letters: Think About Pink
text: Thank you to Peggy Orenstein for articulating a sentiment about breast-cancer awareness that I had not quite found the words to express. When I was 12 years old, my sister and I tried to beat chemo to the punch by cutting off all of our mother’s thick, unruly brown hair in the weeks after she began intensive treatment for Stage 2 breast cancer. There’s nothing cute or fun about being a young girl and seeing your beautiful, vibrant mother suddenly lose the trappings of her health and femininity, and knowing that it’s only the beginning of a long and harrowing ordeal. But her sense of humor, courage and quiet dignity were — and still are — fully intact, and that’s what really matters.

headline: Radical Constitutionalism
text: Of the newly elected Tea Party senators, Mike Lee, a 39-year-old Republican from Utah, has the most impeccable establishment legal credentials: the son of Rex Lee, a solicitor general under President Reagan, he attended law school at Brigham Young and later clerked for Samuel Alito on the U.S. Court of Appeals and then the Supreme Court. But on the campaign trail, especially during his heated primary battle with the three-term Republican incumbent Bob Bennett, Lee offered glimpses of a truly radical vision of the U.S. Constitution, one that sees the document as divinely inspired and views much of what the federal government currently does as unconstitutional.

headline: Letters: Idea Lab
text: What a sensible article by David Frum! His observations are rooted in historical reality and eschew the ideological ranting of the Republican right wing. If such views were to prevail among the Republican leadership in Congress, I have no doubt that the next two years could see a constructive partnership between the president and Congress. Then, perhaps we might have a contest between Mitt Romney and Barack Obama in 2012, in which the main issue would be: who can best lead America out of the darkness and into the light? But I fear that the Republican leadership is more intent on settling scores than on following Frum’s advice.

text: Happy Cathie Black Friday. Attention fair-weather shoppers: any lingering rain should cease by 1 p.m., according to the Weather Channel.  Here’s what we read.

headline: Europeans Striving to Calm Nerves in Markets
text: MADRID  Officials across Europe scrambled on Friday to speed measures aimed at easing the fears of investors even as borrowing costs flirted with new highs in the euro zone’s frailer countries.

headline: The Instability of Moderation
text: Brad DeLong writes of how our perception of history has changed in the wake of the Great Recession. We used to pity our grandfathers, who lacked both the knowledge and the compassion to fight the Great Depression effectively; now we see ourselves repeating all the old mistakes. I share his sentiments.

headline: Fear and Lawyering Up on Wall Street
text: James B. Stewart, in his book “Den of Thieves,” described the mood when the Securities and Exchange Commission announced its historic $100 million settlement with Ivan Boesky for insider trading: “Paranoia swept Wall Street.”

text: 3:08 p.m. | Updated The bailout of Ireland arrived hand in hand with a panicky pullout of bank deposits, providing yet more proof of how hard it is for financial institutions to brace themselves against panics and crises.

headline: Friday Reading: Figuring Out College’s Cost
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Cash Registers Will Ring Before Wedding Bells: The First William-Kate Book Is Out
text: And so it begins.Ten days after the announcement of the engagement of Prince William and Kate Middleton, the first of an expected rash of books about their relationship was published in Britain on Friday, The Associated Press reported. “William and Kate: A Royal Love Story,” by James Clench, The Sun newspaper’s royal reporter, was published by HarperCollins and The Sun, both owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation. It is due to be published in the United States on Dec. 17, well in advance of the couple’s April 29 wedding at Westminster Abbey for those who just cannot wait for that frothy spectacle.

text: A network of the world’s leading medical academies on Friday urged nations to adopt policies to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas pollutants because it would have a salutary effect not just on the planet but on human health.

headline: Formula One Season Review, and a Todt Interview
text: The Formula One season is getting longer and longer — it’s nearly December, yet the season has only been over for 2 weeks. And next year it will go on even longer still.

text: Medical credit cards, marketed through doctors, dentists and even veterinarians, offer consumers a chance to spread out large payments over many months, often with promises of zero interest and other attractive options. But the cards may not be such a bargain, explains Walecia Konrad in today’s Patient Money column:

headline: Health Law Faces Threat of Undercut From Courts
text: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration presses ahead with the health care law, officials are bracing for the possibility that a federal judge in Virginia will soon reject its central provision as unconstitutional and, in the worst case for the White House, halt its enforcement until higher courts can rule.

headline: Built to Last
text: The title of this hefty volume is a little misleading. It doesn’t select anything, strictly speaking, but merely assembles the stories from William Trevor’s last four collections, so that in effect it’s a sequel to the huge edition of his collected stories that came out in 1992. Together the two books add up to almost 2,000 pages of short fiction — an enormous, Kiplingesque quantity of work — and they are more than ample proof that Trevor is one of the two greatest short-story writers working in English right now. The other is Alice Munro, and no one else is even close.

headline: Only Collect
text: As Woody Allen used to be indistinguishable from Manhattan, so Steve Martin has long been associated with Hollywood. Big-budget romantic comedies; tuxedoed pratfalls at award ceremonies; a long-running genial middle age. Banged out between screenplays, wives and ­banjo-playing sessions (there seems no form of entertainment he hasn’t mastered, though he abandoned stand-up comedy years ago), Martin’s first novel, “Shopgirl,” centered on a winsome employee at the Beverly Hills Neiman Marcus glove counter. His second, “The Pleasure of My Company,” was about an obsessive-­compulsive lonely-hearts in Santa Monica. Both explored sharp corners of the soft-focus world he usually inhabits.

headline: Flyers’ Three-goalie Circus Led by Bobrovsky
text: Perhaps Philadelphia’s goalie situation is the new-school hockey spin on the tale of Goldilocks and the three bears.

headline: FrontPoint Investors Ask for $3 Billion Back
text: FrontPoint Partners, a $7 billion hedge fund under fire for allegations that a manager there benefited from insider information, has received about $3 billion in redemption requests, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Pinning the Loss on Someone
text: We interrupt the shopping frenzy of Black Friday to console the N.F.L. teams that lost on Thursday in varying degrees of ridiculousness, to whom it must feel like a very black Friday.

headline: How the N.H.L. Tackles Scandals: A Flowchart
text: Gary Bettman and the N.H.L. took some heat this week when it became clear that the league would take no action as a result of the Colin Campbell e-mail scandal. Many observers accused the league of ignoring the controversy.

headline: The Oft-Examined Life
text: Nora Ephron’s new book of essays is titled “I Remember Nothing,” but that’s a sop. She remembers everything, and while some of the material in this book is tantalizingly fresh and forthright, some of it we’ve seen before. Which doesn’t mean it’s not just as entertaining the second or even third time around, offered in each new iteration with a few more spicy details. Which is all just another way of saying: Does Carl Bernstein lie awake at night wondering how the hell his ex-wife of so many years ago (they were divorced in 1980) turned his marital indiscretion into a multimedia juggernaut spanning the decades?

text: Instead of carving a pumpkin, Martha Rose Shulman decided to cook it up. The result is a week-long pumpkin feast, with recipes for every time of day.

headline: Eighth Ave. and 39th St., Thanksgiving Eve, 8 P.M.
text: Bridget Farrison, 45, was sitting on the corner as commuters rushed to the Port Authority and tourist families bustled by. She said she had spent years working these streets as a prostitute to pay for her crack addiction. She said she had recently met a good man who was convincing her that she should clean up her life.

headline: Adam and Eve Return to Prado
text: Albrecht Durer’s 1507 oil paintings of Adam and Eve are back on display at the Prado Museum in Madrid after a two-year absence to allow for the restoration of the works, Agence France-Presse reported. The restoration was completed by an international team of experts in a project coordinated by the Prado and the Getty Foundation in Los Angeles.

headline: Fruitful Talent Who Made Art World Multiply
text: Robert Rauschenberg, the subject of a chock-a-block time capsule of a show at Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, was an optimist and a doer. He not only did what artists normally do: make paintings, sculptures, prints and photographs. He also did the work of performers, musicians, philanthropists and career politicians.

headline: A Headlong Life
text: For my paternal grandfather, born in 1884, Theodore was the Great Roose­velt. He always regretted he’d been too young to vote for him in 1904, rushed to the polls to do so when Roosevelt ran as a Bull Moose in 1912 and to the end of his long life proudly called himself a “progressive Republican” in honor of his hero. For my father, who was born in 1910 and first went to the polls in the midst of the Great Depression in 1932, Franklin was the Roosevelt to admire; to him, the younger Roosevelt’s dead fifth cousin seemed shrill and overwrought, a perpetual adolescent.

headline: Skepticism Stays as Glazer Family’s Teams Rebound
text: This time a year ago, the Glazer family was a piñata for sports fans on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.

text: AFTER several years of decline, this is shaping up to be the year in which the problems of America’s banks began to recede.

headline: Champions League Chalkboards
text: This is Goal’s second installment of a feature that offers statistical and graphic representations of select matches (courtesy of OPTA) from the European Champions League. At the end of each week when matches are played, the editor of zonalmarking.net will provide analysis powered by the Total Football iPhone/iPad app, which is available at totalfootballapps.com and the iTunes App Store. Similar chalkboards can be found on the Web site of The Guardian and at zonalmarking.net.

text: The leftovers from the Jets’ 26-10 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals on Thanksgiving did not have much shelf life. Even in a victorious locker room at New Meadowlands Stadium, there was less reflection and more focus on what was ahead.

headline: Up Front: Geoffrey C. Ward
text: Over the course of a phenomenally prolific career, Geoffrey C. Ward has written more than a dozen scripts for public television documentaries; articles for Vanity Fair, Smithsonian, The New York Review of Books and numerous other publications; and a shelfful of books, including biographies of Franklin Roosevelt and Jack Johnson.

headline: TimesCast | November 26, 2010
text: Two small businesses still facing the fallout from BP's oil spill; and a conversation with the distributor of BP's $20 billion fund.

headline: Your Deathbed Financial Instructions
text: In this weekend’s “Your Money” column, I profile Gordon Murray, a  Wall Street banker who is dying and had a late-in-life conversion to the religion of passive investing. He believes that no one can predict what the financial markets will do over the long haul and has written a book giving people instructions on how to invest in a more sensible fashion, say using mutual funds from companies like Vanguard or Dimensional Fund Advisors, where he was once a consultant.

headline: Tip, Tip, Tip
text: My daughters and I have been going to the same hairstylist for 10 years. She doesn’t own the salon. Recently, she’s taken on an assistant who applies the color after our stylist mixes it; then the stylist cuts our hair. Our bills are over $200. Do we have to tip the assistant, as well as the stylist and shampoo girl? I know she works for tips, but don’t we all? Shouldn’t the stylist be responsible for paying her?

headline: This Old World
text: Three of the four people who care for my 94-year-old grandfather in his home near Washington were born outside America. None migrated to the United States to do this kind of work. But all remain, and earn a decent living, thanks to senior citizens like my bionic Pop-Pop, a retired doctor powered by a pacemaker and a defibrillator.

headline: This Weekend’s Top European Matchups
text: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

headline: Desert Song
text: For a squeamish, atheistic, arachnophobic Easterner — one who, as a child, slept guarded by a stuffed owl to scare away all the pythons and black widows of Washington, D.C. — reading Leslie Marmon Silko’s memoir, “The Turquoise Ledge,” was a disconcerting experience. Silko’s book is less an autobiography than an exploration of her relationship with the natural and spiritual worlds — and it’s a very close relationship. In her house in the Tucson Mountains, pack rats make a home in the copy machine, a rattlesnake hides under the chaise longue, spiders are welcome and the appearance of a grasshopper is seen as a sign from Lord Chapulin, the Grasshopper Being.

headline: Fairy Tales, Royal and Otherwise
text: EVEN though I write about weddings, I have never fully understood people’s fascination with them.

headline: Throwing Punches in a Church Basement
text: NEW YORK is full of closed doors, hidden communities and secret places. We pass by them all the time, without a hint of what lurks within, above or, in this case, below.

headline: Marco Rubio: Catholic or Protestant?
text: Marco Rubio, the charismatic senator-elect from Florida, is in many ways similar to other Cuban-American politicians from his home state: conservative, Republican and a “practicing and devout Roman Catholic,” in the words of his spokesman, one who “regularly attends Catholic Mass” and “was baptized, confirmed and married in the Roman Catholic Church.”

headline: Those Undulating Swan Arms? Not So Easy to Do
text: TEN years of serious training and then five more toiling in the ranks. That’s how many years of dedicated study it takes on average to become a principal ballerina at a top company. But Hollywood isn’t willing to wait. So when several actresses signed up to portray professional dancers in new movies, they had to play a very intense game of catch-up.

headline: One Size Doesn’t Fit …
text: Many of the reactions to my writing, both in comments here and more generally, seem to be along one of the following lines:

headline: Binary Breakthrough
text: “You know the story of the invention of the computer?” one character asks another midway through Jane Smiley’s best-selling 1995 novel “Moo.” The speaker, an animal scientist, dreams of striking it rich by pioneering a new dairy-farming technology. To that end, he hopes to pry major grant money out of the agricultural industry, and he wields the history of the computer as both cautionary tale and crowbar. “The short version,” he explains, “is that the guy at Iowa State who invented the computer in the late ’30s never patented a thing. . . . And the university . . . forgot about the old machine, and threw it out.”

headline: Animal Lovers, Beware of Ownership Costs
text: PEOPLE love their pets, but how often do they think about the costs? The question is akin to asking which child we love more.

headline: Next Financial Crisis May Start in Washington, Says Bair
text: You can add one more item to the list of problems keeping Sheila C. Bair up at night. The nation’s capitol, she fears, will be ground zero of the next financial crisis.

headline: Explaining Norfolk’s Creeping Tides
text: Some readers responded skeptically to my Friday article about how Norfolk, Va., is handling encroaching seas. Many argued that auxiliary factors that I highlighted in my article like the compacting of landfill and natural land sinkage explained Norfolk’s problems in full and dismissed the notion that global sea rise played a role.

headline: Elhaam Yavari and Mat Steel
text: ONE of the many things Elhaam Yavari and Mat Steel have in common is almost zero body fat. He is the lead guitarist for Your Vegas, a British pop band, and his jeans seem barely wider than guitar strings. She is a petite D.J. with ringlets in her dark hair and eyes the color of Coca-Cola; she tiptoes about in ballet slippers and, when typing on a computer or telephone, doesn’t make a sound.

headline: Fifth Ave. and 54th St., 10:24  A.M.

headline: A Home Field Advantage for ‘In the Heights’
text: It was one of the best performances in the history of Tony Awards telecasts: Lin-Manuel Miranda accepting in 2008 for best score for “In the Heights” by delivering a speech of lyrical rap, in the style of his character Usnavi from the musical, and then pulling a small Puerto Rican flag from his pocket and dedicating the award to the homeland of his parents and relatives.

headline: Path of Least Resistance
text: One of my favorite songs is “Les Chemins de l’Amour” by Francis Poulenc, a great composer who could turn his hand to anything from high operatic tragedy in “Dialogues of the Carmelites” to a boulevard ballad like this one, and when I used to cover the Tour de France, I would play the original recording by the adorable Yvonne Printemps as I pottered along one route nationale or another. Then one day I glanced at the liner notes and saw when and where it was made: Paris, November 1940. While my parents’ generation in London nightly awaited the air-raid sirens, across the Channel, the bands still played.

text: Television

headline: What Evil Lurks
text: “From the start — even before a young man I can now hardly comprehend started writing ‘The Long Walk’ in his college dormitory room — I felt that the best fiction was both propulsive and assaultive,” Stephen King writes in a chatty afterword to “Full Dark, No Stars,” his new collection of longish stories. “It gets in your face.” As if we didn’t know.

headline: Darth Vader No Match for James Bond
text: Darth Vader, zero. James Bond, $437,000.An original Darth Vader costume — a jet-black helmet, mask and armor — did not sell at auction Thursday while the Walther air pistol held by Sean Connery in a 1963 James Bond film fetched 277,250 pounds (or $437,206) at Christie’s in London.

headline: You’re O.K., but I’m Not. Let’s Share.
text: IF, like me, you are not in the habit of sharing highly personal tidbits of your life with 148 strangers for 13 hours a day, three days in a row, then let me, uh, share with you what that experience feels like. It feels like intergalactic jet lag, or like someone has pumped your head full of a global weather system, heavy on the cumulonimbus. Some of the 148 strangers were crying so much, they looked as if they had been boiled.

headline: We Should Dance While We Can
text: WE have reached that recognizable wedding-reception moment when the D.J. queues up “Brown Eyed Girl,” the groom’s great-aunt grinds down to the floor in her silk pantsuit, and then needs a lift up. The caterers have replenished the empty steam trays with cheeseburger sliders, and the bridesmaids have removed their shoes. Anything could happen.

headline: Statesman, Fixer
text: Felix Rohatyn’s memoir, modestly titled “Dealings: A Political and Financial Life,” is the sort of vaulting success story that makes one yearn for the big-hearted America of the mid-20th century, a less mean and more innocent time when not every career seemed calculated and not every banker was a subject of scorn, and when the country welcomed enterprising immigrants.

headline: Diet: Good-for-You Things Come in Orange
text: Eat your carrots. And have some leftover pumpkin pie.

text: A dojo for training in the traditional Japanese martial arts, secluded in the basement of the New York Buddhist Church.

headline: ‘Spider-Man': Turn on the Commercials
text: Given that the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is the most expensive in history, at $65 million and counting, it comes as no surprise that the producers are willing to spend money on two flashy commercials that will be broadcast on cable and network television in the New York area starting on Monday.

headline: Aging: Unsteady on Your Feet? Try Moving to Music
text: Elderly people in a new study cut their risk of falling by more than half after they took classes in eurhythmics, an exercise-and-music program designed for young children.

headline: What Was I Thinking?
text: In “Self Comes to Mind,” the eminent neurologist and neuroscientist Antonio Damasio gives an account of consciousness that might come naturally to a highly caffeinated professor in his study. He emphasizes wakefulness, self-awareness, reflection, rationality, “knowledge of one’s own existence and of the existence of surroundings.”

text: A look at two small businesses in Louisiana seven months after the Gulf oil spill.

headline: Obama Gets 12 Stitches in Lip
text: 5:14 p.m. | Updated 4:46 p.m. | Updated President Obama had to get 12 stitches in his upper lip after getting a blow from an opposing player’s elbow during a basketball game Friday morning, White House officials said.

headline: The Voyager
text: Writing in The Atlantic last year, presumably while finishing work on “The Passages of H. M.,” a novel based on the life of Herman Melville, Jay Parini declared that the historical novel “has become our primary form of fiction.” The present, he speculated, “can seem too bright, too close,” requiring “the filter of memory” to sort out and deliver the profound insights readers hope to find in novels. Going a step farther, he argued that it is in fiction like Gore Vidal’s “Lincoln” or Russell Banks’s “Cloudsplitter” that “one gets ‘real’ history.”

headline: At Least the ‘Weed Man’ Is Honest. Or Is He?
text: “Stop right there,” barked the officer stationed next to the X-ray machine at the entrance to 1 Police Plaza.

headline: Veritas Returns
text: Veritas, the high-end wine-centric jewel box in the Flatiron district, will reopen on Tuesday with a bit more reasonably priced.

headline: The Man Who Would Be Taliban
text: Turnabout is fair play. That’s as true in Afghanistan, where “fair play” is a rather flexible concept, as it is anywhere. “In any place where they fight, a man who knows how to drill men can always be a king” insisted Dravot, one of the two Europeans in Kipling’s “Man Who Would Be King” who manage to hoodwink an Afghan tribe into believing in their royal status, at least for a while. Indeed, historically, Westerners of dubious character have had a knack for bluffing their ways to positions of prominence during times of strife. Consider Dravot’s real-life inspiration: Josiah Harlan, an American charlatan who in 1848 declared himself the prince of Ghor in central Afghanistan. (One of Harlan’s descendants, a horror-movie actor, is convinced that the royal title remains in the family.)

headline: Russian TV Kowtows to Kremlin, Critic Says
text: MOSCOW — A well-known television personality on Thursday used the occasion of an awards ceremony to deliver a blistering critique of Russian television, saying its journalists had bent so completely to the will of the government that they were “not journalists at all but bureaucrats, following the logic of service and submission.”

headline: A ‘Crazy Bad’ Day in Beijing
text: Last week I wrote about the global environmental impact of rising coal exports to China. Sea shipments of thermal coal, used for heating and electricity generation, are skyrocketing, undermining attempts to tamp down the growth of global greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Giants’ Andrews Hospitalized With Back Pain
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants may turn to their third left tackle this season after the travails of their banged-up offensive line worsened when Shawn Andrews was held in a hospital Thursday night into Friday afternoon with back pain.

headline: The Devils’ Playground
text: For most Americans, who remember World War II as beginning in 1941, it is necessary to recall that Europe had succumbed to an infatuation with violence long before the United States entered the conflict. Timothy Snyder, a professor of history at Yale, compels us to look squarely at the full range of destruction committed first by Stalin’s regime and then by Hitler’s Reich. Each fashioned a terrifying orgy of deliberate mass killing.

headline: An American in Peru, Out of Jail but in Limbo
text: LIMA, Peru

headline: Our Unlettered Landscape
text: “We come to books,” David L. Ulin writes in “The Lost Art of Reading,” “to be challenged and confounded, made to question our assumptions.” With this principle in mind, here is the news that Ulin brings in this slim, meandering book: that reading is “an act of contemplation”; that such an act becomes more difficult in “our overnetworked society, where every buzz and rumor is instantly blogged and tweeted, and it is not contemplation we desire but an odd sort of distraction”; that the analphabetic anger of anonymous Internet comment threads is emblematic of a “degraded cultural conversation” in which “the ability to carry out a logical argument” has been lost; that technology brings a boon but also a burden: “We are never disconnected, never out of touch”; and lastly, coming full circle, that in this “landscape of distraction,” reading becomes not just an act of contemplation but one of “resistance.”

headline: Failure to Communicate
text: In Iraq, the United States Army often lacked the Arabic translators desperately needed to decipher documents captured from insurgents who were planting hidden explosive devices that killed and maimed American soldiers by the hundreds. In New York City, the opening of a charter school where pupils might master the intricacies of Arabic was all but thwarted by vociferous critics, many of them vocal supporters of Israel, who made it sound as if a terrorist training camp was opening in Brooklyn.

headline: C.I.A. Agents, Blowing Their Own Cover
text: This summer, a former spy who calls himself ­Ishmael Jones got into trouble with his old bosses at the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Skipping the Stores on Black Friday
text: When I was younger, I used to love going to the stores on Black Friday, braving the mall crowds, buying an item or two and viewing all the holiday decorations.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FOREIGN BODIES,  by Cynthia Ozick (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) This nimble homage to Henry James’s “Ambassadors,” in which an American heads to Paris to retrieve a wayward son, brilliantly upends the theme, meaning and manner of its precursor.

headline: That 2BR Frame of Mind
text: Two-bedrooms are back in demand, after a wallflower period when smaller, or larger, places were commanding the attention. Prices are coming back, too.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Natalie Portman, ‘All Good Things,’ Arhoolie Records and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE COMPLETE STORIES OF J.G. BALLARD. (Norton, $24.95.) Ballard, who died in April 2009 and is perhaps best known for the novels “Empire of the Sun” and “Crash,” was once praised by Kingsley Amis as “the brightest star in British postwar SF.” The 98 stories collected here span an entire creative life, one spent relentlessly exploring the desolate landscapes and nightmare metropolises of what Ballard called our “visionary present.” Each story “is like a dream more perfectly realized than any of your own,” Jonathan Lethem wrote in the Book Review. “Ballard is simply a master story writer.”

headline: An Industrial Project That Could Change Myanmar
text: DAWEI, MYANMAR — The vast, pristine stretch of coastline here is almost deserted, save for fishermen hauling their bountiful catches onto white-sand beaches. But a deal signed this month would transform these placid waters into a seaport for giant cargo ships. Cashew nut groves and rice fields would be plowed under and replaced with a warren of factories, refineries and an expansive coal-burning power plant.

headline: Inside the List
text: SCHOOL OF RAP: Why is every self-respecting pop star suddenly clamoring to play the New York Public Library? First, Keith Richards shows up to confess his youthful dreams of becoming a librarian. Now, Jay-Z — whose “Decoded” hits No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week — checks in to talk hip-hop and philosophy with Cornel West.

headline: After Del Monte, Who’s Next on the Shopping List?
text: The buyout of Del Monte Foods is the latest in a series of multibillion-dollar deals in the food industry this year, including the $19.5 billion takeover of Cadbury by Kraft Foods, and Coca-Cola’s $13.6 billion purchase of Coca-Cola Enterprises’ North American operations.

headline: Art Basel Miami’s Big-Buzz 10
text: ART BASEL MIAMI BEACH, that bacchanal disguised as the Western Hemisphere’s most prestigious art fair, takes place Dec. 2 to 5. Once again, there will be a dizzying whirl of glamorous dinners, hush-hush viewings and after-hour soirees — a Herculean scavenger hunt crammed into four days. To help, here are 10 must-do spots to schmooze, party, dine and, oh, see art.

text: WASHINGTON  President Obama had to get 12 stitches in his lip after getting a blow from an opponent’s elbow during a basketball game Friday morning, White House officials said.

text: A look at the new PBS series on Korean food featuring Marja Vongerichten, the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten's wife.

headline: The Making of Fashion’s Latest ‘It’ Girl
text: ON a recent afternoon at the Bowery Hotel, over a burrata caprese salad, green beans and a Coke, the British television host, model and pop-culture phenomenon Alexa Chung was explaining her hair color, which often calls to mind a grown-out dye job. “I said ‘I want to look like Kurt Cobain,’ ” said Ms. Chung, 26. “I said, ‘I’m going to America and they’re going to try and make my hair shiny and I don’t want it. I want to look like Kurt Cobain.’ ”

text: The British television host, model and pop-culture phenomenon sets her own definition of style, and moves in various fashion circles.

text: Visitors to the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade may have been surprised to learn that not only were there only 30 shopping days left till Christmas, there were also only 177 days left until the world ends.

headline: Palin Debate Aside, Does ‘Dancing’ Need Electoral Reform?
text: The TV tuner at the Silver household is usually stuck on politics, sports, or — if truth must be told — “The Real Housewives of Atlanta.” So I can’t acknowledge having spent much time watching “Dancing With the Stars” this year. From what little I caught, it was clear that each of the 12 couples on the show were far more capable dancers than I ever might be. (I’m saving my reality television karma for when CNBC debuts “Spreadsheet Idol.”)

text: The founder of and the editorial director for Refinery29.com chronicles what she wore for a week.

text: CHRISTENE BARBERICH, 41, is a founder of and the editorial director for Refinery29.com, a fashion and shopping Web site in TriBeCa. She consults for brands including Yves Saint Laurent, Prada Beauty and Nike.

headline: Mayor and State Reach Deal to Pave Way for Schools Chief
text: The state’s education commissioner, David M. Steiner, and the Bloomberg administration have reached a deal that will allow Cathleen P. Black, a media executive, to become the next schools chief.

headline: From the Former Eastern Bloc, Wielding Color
text: SOON after entering the common studio space at the Universitatea de Arta si Design in Cluj Napoca, Romania, Livia Straus spotted a dreadlocked young man working alone in a corner. “All of his canvases were facing the wall,” recalled Ms. Straus, the director and co-founder with her husband, Dr. Marc Straus, of the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill. “And, of course, if a canvas is facing the wall, I want to see it.”

headline: ‘Robert Rauschenberg’
text: The Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea is putting on a survey of the prolific artist's career.

headline: The Nominees for the 2010 World XI
text: FIFA and FIFPro this week released the list of 55 players who are on its list to be included in the 2010 World XI squad that will be announced on Jan. 10.

headline: Demand Returns for 2-Bedroom Apartments
text: TWO-BEDROOM apartments have long been the workhorse of the New York City real estate market, accounting year after year for the largest percentage of apartments sold.

text: This week’s App Smart column arms you with a few good apps for finding the best prices on your next shopping trip.

headline: To Help Donors Choose, Web Site Alters How It Sizes Up Charities
text: Charity Navigator, perhaps the largest online source for evaluating nonprofit groups, recently embarked on an overhaul to offer a wider, more nuanced array of information to donors who are deciding which organizations they might help.

headline: A New Push to Rescue Xanadu Mall Project
text: Lenders and state officials in New Jersey are desperately trying to cobble together the second rescue of Xanadu, one of the nation’s largest, most expensive and still incomplete retail and entertainment malls.

headline: A ‘Ring’ Returns: Scala’s ‘Rheingold’ at Symphony Space
text: For me and perhaps others who overdosed on Robert Lepage’s new production of Wagner’s “Rheingold” at the Metropolitan Opera this fall, a repeat showing of a “Rheingold” from the Teatro Alla Scala in Milan, originally broadcast live in May and to be presented at Symphony Space on Sunday afternoon, provides relief of a sort from any remaining withdrawal pangs. The film, seen in a preview this week, also reopened windows on staging possibilities obscured in my case by a three-pronged experience of the juggernaut Met production (the opening, on big screens in Times Square through a teeming rain; the third performance, in the house; and the fourth, via HD broadcast at a theater in Ellsworth, Me.

headline: Singer for Whom the Hard Knocks Were All Gifts
text: Baby Jane Dexter might be considered a bad girl of cabaret, blending the occasional nightclub standard into a frothy emotional mixture of pop and rock songs, always with her eye on the unsuspecting audience.

headline: Grown-Up Granita
text: Mark Bittman makes a cold, sweet cocktail with gin and sorbet.

headline: In Iraq, ‘We’re Still Getting Hit’
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE WARHORSE, Iraq — Soldiers were playing football in the sunset of a long day and a longer war, their shadows tilting across fields of packed dirt. It was Monday, and this base in Diyala Province had the casual air of a heavily armed college campus:

headline: Pop Queens on TV, One Careful and One Exuding Confidence
text: In 2009, when Kanye West interrupted Taylor Swift’s MTV Video Music Awards acceptance speech to say Beyoncé should have won the award for best female video, perhaps he planted an idea with prime-time programmers. Thanksgiving night brought successive specials by Ms. Swift, at 8 on NBC, and Beyoncé, at 9:30 on ABC. Each featured billowing golden hair, live performance and pop-image polishing: Ms. Swift as careful as could be, Beyoncé confident enough to loosen up.

headline: Drug Maker Cited on Quality Issues
text: Months after McNeil Consumer Healthcare, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, recalled millions of bottles of Tylenol and other over-the-counter drugs, the division is still plagued with manufacturing flaws, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: ‘Apollo’s Angels’
text: Chapter 1: Kings of Dance

headline: A Sophisticated Slushie
text: THERE are three things I love about this cocktail: it has gin in it (always a good thing), it takes less than a minute to make (ditto) and it doubles as dessert. What’s not to love?

headline: A Collaboration Far More Than the Sum of Its Parts
text: Early in the 20th century, soloists occasionally assembled programs that were part recital, part chamber performance. That hybrid approach had fallen out of favor by the 1950s, but Xiayin Wang’s collaboration with the Fine Arts Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening suggested that it might be worth reviving.

headline: Small Latkes, Large Toppings
text: ABOUT a decade ago I held a Hanukkah party with more people than I could fit around my dining table. I wanted to serve latkes, but the ones I typically made were saucer size, requiring plates and forks. That’s when it occurred to me to serve hors d’oeuvres-size instead.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 26
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a school garden, a tattoo artist and Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: The Big Surprise Is Saved for the Groom
text: Last week Time magazine in association with the Pew Research Center released the results of a survey on the state of American marriage, which found what all but the purveyors of giddy popular culture already know: the institution is in decline. Among men and women in their 20s in 2008 only 26 percent were married (as opposed to 68 percent in 1960). Moreover, a full 39 percent of those questioned said they believed marriage was becoming obsolete, which in itself indicates that no one aspiring to a certain kind of reality-television stardom was even interrogated.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Look at a Classic
text: An adaptation of “The Little Prince,” the 1943 parable by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, is new to the hardcover list this week. This version of the tale, about a pilot who crash lands in the desert and meets an enigmatic young boy, was translated by Sarah Ardizzone and written and illustrated by Joann Sfar.

headline: Good Day for Parade
text: This year’s Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade attracted its best television ratings since 2004. Although final audience figures were not available on Friday, Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates from local markets nationwide show NBC’s parade broadcast up roughly 2 percent from a year ago, when 22.3 million viewers tuned in. During prime-time on Thursday, however, network television drew meager ratings for mostly repeats and concert specials. Fox led the night by a slim margin, benefiting from an audience of more than 15 million viewers between 8 and 8:30 p.m. because of an overrun of its football coverage. Following it “The Simpsons Movie” averaged about five million viewers for Fox. CBS placed second over all with comedy repeats from 8 to 10 and a rerun of “The Mentalist” (7.6 million), which won the 10 p.m. hour ahead of “The Apprentice” on NBC (3.4 million) and the last hour of ABC’s special “Beyoncé’s I Am ... World Tour,” which drew 4.1 million from 9:30 to 11. NBC finished fourth behind ABC, with 4.4 million viewers for “Taylor Swift: Speak Now” at 8 and “NBC’s People of the Year 2010” at 9.

headline: ‘Full Dark, No Stars’
text: From “A Good Marriage” in “Full Dark, No Stars”

headline: Self-Referential in Its Own Right
text: Four characters are onstage, in conversation. Jeff turns to his colleague and says, with courteous concern, “Susan, you’re quiet.”

headline: How the Sugarplum Fairy Presides Depends on the ‘Nutcracker’ Narrative
text: Tradition in America has it that performances of “The Nutcracker” begin only after Thanksgiving. Not so, however, for the two productions this year with which I’ve begun a sampling of the nation’s “Nutcrackers.” They also demonstrate two quite separate versions of the ballet’s story.

headline: Honors for Alumnus of ‘Saturday Night Live’ Band (Guess When)
text: BOB CRANSHAW’S name may not be familiar to many people, but his bass playing is. Anyone who can hum the “Sesame Street” theme song knows it — he played on the recording — and so does anyone who watched the early years of “Saturday Night Live,” when he was in the house band.

headline: Masters of Math, From Old Babylon
text: If the cost of digging a trench is 9 gin, and the trench has a length of 5 ninda and is one-half ninda deep, and if a worker’s daily load of earth costs 10 gin to move, and his daily wages are 6 se of silver, then how wide is the canal?

headline: Music Publisher BMG Buying Chrysalis in $168 Million Deal
text: In a deal between two of the world’s largest independent music publishers, BMG Rights Management has agreed to acquire Chrysalis for £107.4 million ($168.6 million), the companies announced on Friday.

headline: In a Sleepy Russian City, Not All Welcome a Cultural Revolution
text: PERM, Russia  This homely city on the edge of the Ural Mountains  once a place of political exile  is the unlikely forum for a furious, even bitter, debate about the role of culture in public life.

headline: Which Black Suit to Play First? One Is Right, the Other Wrong
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  The premier event at the Fall North American Championships taking place here is next weekend’s Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams. The defending champions are Nick Nickell and Zia Mahmood of New York; Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill.; Bob Hamman of Dallas; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla. They will be trying for a “threepeat” (excluding Katz, the replacement for Richard Freeman, who died in June 2009).

headline: One ‘Nutcracker,’ but Many Interpretations
text: WITH its annual profusion of year-end performances across Long Island, “The Nutcracker” is one of the sure signposts of the season. Yet even a dependable chestnut like this one undergoes change — as shown, for example, by recent developments at the Eglevsky Ballet.

headline: Dramas to Color, Cut and Produce
text: The Ugly Stepsisters gape as Cinderella triumphs, surrounded by explosions of flowers and jubilant floating fairies.

headline: Russia: Stalin Called Responsible for Katyn Killings
text: Russia’s Parliament on Friday approved a statement holding Stalin responsible for ordering the 1940 murder of more than 20,000 Polish officers in a forest near the village of Katyn. Against the protests of Communist Parliament members, the State Duma acknowledged that archival material “not only unveils the scale of his horrific tragedy but also provides evidence that the Katyn crime was committed on direct orders from Stalin and other Soviet leaders.” The Soviet government argued that Nazis were responsible for the massacre, a stance that created a passionate division between Poland and Russia. This year, however, Moscow has taken a series of steps to patch up a relationship that had become an obstacle to European integration.

headline: Thrills and Chills (Except for the Guy Behind the Elephant)
text: Marc Chagall once wrote that the circus seemed to him “like the most tragic show on earth.”

headline: Bowl Streak For Rutgers Is Ended In a Rout
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  His team was losing by three touchdowns and most of the crowd had gone home Friday when Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano suddenly stopped pacing the sideline, fished a pen out of his pocket and scribbled notes. He had another problem to solve.

headline: Precarious Survival on the Lower East Side
text: Memories of the sounds and smells of the synagogues of Julio Mitchel‘s childhood in Havana led him to document the dwindling Jewish presence on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in the 1980s. While his upbringing influenced his decision to photograph the neighborhood’s Jews, he believes that the images are about more than a single culture.

headline: Burgers Selling Fast, but the Restaurant Is Not
text: ATLANTA  As real estate deals go, the sale of Ann’s Snack Bar may be a true test of the value of cult food in a bad economy.

headline: The Fading Cry of ‘Bingo!’
text: Nostrand Bingo Hall in the Midwood section of Brooklyn is among 10 remaining venues for the game in New York City.

headline: The Give and Take of Liar Loans
text: Did you hear the one about Countrywide Financial demanding that mortgage originators buy back many of the so-called stated-income loans that it had purchased from them during the late great housing bubble?

headline: Newton Leads Auburn to Comeback Win
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  The mischievous sound operators at Bryant-Denny Stadium tried to establish a theme for No. 9 Alabama’s game against No. 2 Auburn on Friday afternoon during pregame warm-ups. When the embattled Auburn quarterback Cam Newton took the field, the songs “Take the Money and Run” by Steve Miller and “Son of a Preacher Man” by Dusty Springfield filled the speakers  not-so-subtle reminders of the N.C.A.A.’s investigation into Newton’s recruitment.

headline: Bingo in the Blood
text: LIKE other regulars, Cynthia Klivan got there early, needing a couple of hours to get settled. She had to claim her preferred seat by the snack bar. Then she had to unload her supplies from her pink bingo bag  her daubers to mark her paper sheets with circular smudges, her transparent tape to hold the sheets together so they would not disperse, her bingo chips for the lap boards and the magnetic wand that scoops them up. She likes to grab breakfast  rye toast and a cup of coffee  to refuel before play begins.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 26
text: Images of cultural events from this week.

headline: New Jersey’s Tiniest Towns Fight Push to Merge
text: TETERBORO, N.J. — At 1.1 square miles, this town is smaller than Central Park — smaller even than Teterboro Airport, which spills past its borders. It has no schools, no police or fire department, far more aircraft than residents, and a bone to pick with the Census Bureau.

headline: Pat-Downs: Enhanced but Hardly Thorough
text: It does not take much to come face to face  or hand to buttock  with the controversial inner cordon of our nation’s antiterrorist strategy. You don’t have to break into Langley or crack open an encrypted file. All you have to do is snake your way through the airport security line, then step up to the person monitoring the metal detector or the full-body scanner and say, “Manual, please.”

headline: Lounging With a Complexion Queen
text: Dr. Patricia Wexler, she of the snowy complexion and stiletto heels, belongs to that clique of dermatologists with faces as familiar as those of their famous clientele. (She keeps Christie Brinkley, among others, incandescent.) Dr. Wexler, 58, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Dr. Eugene Wexler, 60, a cosmetic surgeon, and two bichons frisés. Sunday is often the day when the Wexlers spend downtime with their two daughters and their grandson. ROBIN FINN

headline: Enjoying the Herring-Sashimi Connection
text: In a multicultural, polyglot city with seemingly boundless options for ethnic dining, this temple of Scandinavian cuisine stands out as much for its refined cooking and namesake beverage as for its celebrity investor and former chef, Marcus Samuelsson, an Ethiopian who grew up in Sweden. The dining room in the Park Avenue Tower on East 55th Street offers precisely composed plates during the week, but on Sunday serves a traditional smorgasbord brunch for $48 a person, which covers a beverage and all the herring, meatballs and pyttipanna (hash with fried eggs and beets) you can eat. Last weekend, the crowd included two friends catching up on business and life.

headline: Microsoft Recruits Santa for Free-Photos Program
text: Now your children can get that squirming-in-Santa’s-lap experience at the airport instead of the mall, courtesy of Microsoft. The company has teamed up with Southwest Airlines to give travelers the chance to take photos with Santa at 26 airports nationwide.

headline: Excerpts From the Ethnic Press
text: Crime is to newspapers what bread is to the human meal: a staple across continents and cultures. During the past month, a Caribbean paper in New York reported on sex trafficking involving minors; a Mexican daily carried an article about a brutal beating of a pizza deliveryman; and an Arab-American publication chronicled reaction to a campaign to arm bodega owners. KIRK SEMPLE

headline: Saudi Arabia Arrests 149 Qaeda Suspects, Many With Ties to Yemen, Over 8 Months
text: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia announced Friday that it had arrested 149 suspected militants from Al Qaeda over the past eight months, including many with ties to Yemen.

text: Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade signals the city's turn from autumn — and the stylish looks that abound — to winter coats.

headline: How to Judge a Dance Contest, Accurately
text: Last night, Nate Silver announced to readers that he would take advantage of a post-midterms lull in political news to explore issues in sports, culture and other subjects.

headline: U.S. Shuts Down Web Sites in Piracy Crackdown
text: In what appears to be the latest phase of a far-reaching federal crackdown on online piracy of music and movies, the Web addresses of a number of sites that facilitate illegal file-sharing were seized this week by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, a division of the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Debt Crisis Highlights I.M.F.’s Renewed Role
text: WASHINGTON  Ireland’s reluctant acceptance of a bailout supported by the International Monetary Fund is the latest in a string of developments since 2007 that have thrust the monetary fund into a new position of authority and prominence.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,388 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Robert B. Daugherty Dies at 88; Helped Irrigate the Plains
text: Robert B. Daugherty, a Nebraska businessman who helped transform the rural landscape into a patchwork of circular fields by popularizing a means of irrigation that used a pipe on wheels pivoting around a central point, died on Wednesday at his home in Omaha. He was 88.

headline: Ann's Snack Bar
text: Kim Severson traveled to Atlanta, Georgia to taste Ann Price's famous "Ghetto Burger."  She opened her restaurant in 1972 and has since operated by her own rules to produce burgers worth waiting for.

headline: Betty Jean Lifton Dies at 84; Urged Open Adoptions
text: Betty Jean Lifton, a writer, adoptee and adoption-reform advocate whose books  searing condemnations of the secrecy that traditionally shrouded adoption  became touchstones for adoptees throughout the world, died on Nov. 19 in Boston. She was 84 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Shipping Christmas to the Caribbean
text: Barrels full of gifts, and everyday items, too, are sent to relatives and friends in the Caribbean.

headline: Crises Shake German Trust in Euro Zone
text: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel has tried to assure business leaders and investors that Germany is committed to a strong, stable euro, while at the same time assuring the German public that it is time to get tough with investors and demand that other euro zone nations fix their finances.

headline: Jeter Said to Be Asking $23 Million to $24 Million a Year
text: Derek Jeter’s agent, Casey Close, is currently asking the Yankees to agree to a new contract of either four or five years at $23 million to $24 million a year, according to a person in baseball who had been briefed on the matter.

headline: G.M. Finds a More Receptive Public
text: McHENRY, Ill.  One of the year’s biggest weekends for car dealers is also doubling as a coming-out party for General Motors, just a week after the company shed the government’s majority ownership. Evidence is emerging on car lots that consumers are starting to feel more positive about G.M. and less angry about the billions of dollars in federal aid it received.

headline: Second Rail-Equipped Drug Tunnel Found at Mexican Border
text: LOS ANGELES  Federal investigators discovered a sophisticated cross-border tunnel Thursday in an industrial part of San Diego. The half-mile tunnel was the second found this month equipped with rail tracks and carts to funnel drugs to and from Tijuana, Mexico.

headline: Profusion of Insiders Aid Gov.-Elect in Transition
text: When Andrew M. Cuomo named members to his transition committees this month, he described them as experienced leaders with broad experience in the public and the private sectors, selected to help him recruit the best and brightest New Yorkers to his new administration.

headline: A Hidden Beauty
text: Karma Lounge is one of the prettiest adult watering holes around. The entrance is a bit hidden along the walkway leading to the Old Croton Aqueduct, but Karma’s seclusion is part of its appeal. Inside, polished dark and light woods, brick niches and dramatic draped fabrics provide a Zen-like backdrop for minimalist floral arrangements, gentle candlelight and subdued pictures of geometric textile designs.

headline: Hartford’s A.H.L. Team Adopts Whale Heritage
text: HARTFORD  Bringing the Hartford Whalers back to this city is a task that could be described as difficult at best, hopeless at worst. But Howard Baldwin has a unique qualification for the job: he brought the Whalers here in the first place.

headline: Giants’ Shawn Andrews Is in Hospital With Back Pain
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants may turn to their third left tackle this season after the travails of their banged-up offensive line worsened when Shawn Andrews was held in a hospital with back pain.

headline: Cuisine in Flux? Yes. But Don’t Change It All!
text: AFTER two happy visits to Blackboard Bistro, in Carmel, I read the following blog post, from early November, on the restaurant’s Web site: “The Bistro is taking a poll, would you like to see the organic part of the restaurant flourish and stay on track, or would you want to see more of a gastro pub style menu, please vote and give us your feedback??”

headline: Colleges Tell High Schools Logos Are Off Limits
text: Glades Day School sits on the edge of swampland in Belle Glade, Fla., and its headmaster, Dr. Robert Egley, often drives past alligators lazing in canals on his way to work. When the school was founded in 1965, its location made the Gator an ideal mascot, and its logo, aside from being green and gold, was nearly identical to the University of Florida’s.

headline: From Queens Busboys to Manhattan’s Big Time
text: They were four friends celebrating: two of them brothers, two of them like brothers. Early this week, in their new, gleaming restaurant at Park Avenue and 39th Street, the four men, their ages ranging from 29 to 35, circulated, smiling nervously, dressed in jackets and their best-pressed shirts. They moved restlessly among the leather booths of the Park Avenue Tavern as friends and family, many of them in from Rockaway Beach, sampled the food. Had Grandma tried the crab cakes? Would their old basketball buddy, still boyish but now in a priest’s collar, like another beer?

headline: Brazil Military Says It Cornered Rio Drug Gangs
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  Police and Brazilian Army soldiers, struggling to take control of a second huge slum complex here, were fired on by drug gangs on Friday, but by nightfall they had managed to trap the traffickers inside, a military spokesman said.

headline: Slices of Childhood, Melted and Mobile
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Not Just Hamburgers
text: Jennifer Anicito, 34, of Plainview, sat at a table at the Burger Spot, a 20-seat, order-at-the-counter cafe in Garden City, and offered a bite of burger to her 3-year-old son, Daniel.

headline: McCartney Wants to Coach in Boulder Again
text: BOULDER, Colo. — Bill McCartney said he weighed the same, at 70, as he did in 1982, when the University of Colorado hired him to rebuild its sunken football program.

headline: Death and Dancing Coexist on Haiti’s Tense Streets
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  One body gets a light kick and tumbles into the pit.

headline: Pan-Asian Classics, Packed With Flavor
text: NO Long Islander who likes Chinese food has to be told that the opening of a new Chinese restaurant is practically unheard of on the Island these days. Chinese restaurateurs are still here, and they still open restaurants, but they don’t serve Chinese food exclusively.

headline: On Nassau Street, the Present Closes In on a Bikini-Clad Past
text: The sign inside Nassau Bar raises more questions than the single one that it attempts to answer. It reads: “No Pictures of Bartenders.”

headline: Secrets Shared Must Be Handled With Care
text: When I was in Mexico City last month doing research on the Antenas program – the subject of my Fixes column earlier this week — I had the opportunity to sit in Antenas’ room and have a conversation with the animated character used by psychotherapists to communicate with children. I found the effect surprising. Antenas, guided by a therapist named Elsa Molina in the next room, began by asking me simple questions, as he does with all children. Antenas asked: “Why did you come to Mexico City?” I replied, “I’m a writer and I’m doing research.” Antenas asked: ‘What is a writer?’

headline: Veteran Detective Charged With Attempted Murder
text: A veteran detective assigned to the mayor’s security team was charged on Friday with attempted murder, accused of shooting a man while off duty and then failing to report it, prosecutors said.

headline: A Lifelong Caregiver, Always With a Smile
text: Until Sept. 11, 2001, Dianne Romano was the one doling out charity, not the one receiving it.

headline: More Than Moussaka
text: At Think Grill, a sleek, casual spot in Union, there is typical Greek fare, like moussaka and spanakopita. But there are also all-American dishes, like ribs and macaroni and cheese.

headline: Northern Italian Classics, and Some Surprises
text: IN the vast continuum of Italian restaurants stretching across New Jersey, places like D’Oro in Chatham are instantly familiar yet oddly hard to pull off: authentically Italian but neighborhoody in spirit, reliably satisfying but eager to surprise, ambitious in the kitchen but not too far beyond the comfort zone of well-worn classics like veal scallopine and penne alla vodka.

headline: Architects Take On Museums in Doha and Abu Dhabi
text: I.M. Pei, Frank Gehry, Norman Foster and Jean Nouvel discuss their work in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Building Museums, and a Fresh Arab Identity
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  It is an audacious experiment: two small, oil-rich countries in the Middle East are using architecture and art to reshape their national identities virtually overnight, and in the process to redeem the tarnished image of Arabs abroad while showing the way toward a modern society within the boundaries of Islam.

headline: Adriana Kertzer and Barry Goldman
text: Adriana Kertzer and Barry R. Goldman were married Saturday evening at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Jo Hirschmann officiated.

headline: Jennifer Breeden and Joedan Okun
text: Jennifer Ann Breeden, a daughter of Josie Chao-chih Breeden and Douglas T. Breeden of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married at her parents’ home Saturday to Joedan Charles Hampton Okun, a son of Melva Fager Okun and Michael G. Okun, both of Carrboro, N.C. The Rev. David Harvin, a Methodist minister, officiated, and Will Okun, a brother of the bridegroom and a Universal Life minister, took part in the ceremony.

headline: Benjamin Zumsteg, Michael Leamer
text: Benjamin Brett Zumsteg and Michael Drucker Leamer were married Tuesday in the Town Hall of Darien, Conn. Mary Pugh, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Grace Fan, Thomas Delatour Jr.
text: Grace Fan, the daughter of Evelyn Du of Shanghai and Felix Fan of San Francisco, was married Friday to Thomas Russell Delatour Jr., a son of Grace W. Delatour and Mr. Delatour Sr. of Dallas. The Rev. Crystal D. Walker, a minister of the Church of God and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed a Methodist ceremony at the home of the bridegroom’s parents.

headline: Erin Thomas and Anthony Garvan III
text: Erin Lorraine Thomas and Anthony Nicholas Brady Garvan III were married Saturday at the Buccaneer Hotel in Christiansted on St. Croix in the Virgin Islands. Louise L. Leard, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Carol Skriloff, Pierce Starr
text: Carol Lee Skriloff and James Pierce Starr were married Friday at the Four Seasons Resort on Peninsula Papagayo in Costa Rica. William B. Muñoz, a notary public there, officiated.

headline: Sharon Elghanayan, Jon Corzine
text: Sharon M. Elghanayan, a psychotherapist, and Jon S. Corzine, a former governor of New Jersey, were married Tuesday evening in Mr. Corzine’s apartment in Hoboken, N.J. Judge Edward McBride of the Camden County branch of the Superior Court of New Jersey officiated at a ceremony that was primarily led by Chief Justice Stuart Rabner of the New Jersey Supreme Court. Before taking their current posts, Judge McBride was the governor’s chief of staff and Justice Rabner was New Jersey’s attorney general.

headline: Irina Vaysman, Corey Bobker
text: Irina Vaysman, a daughter of Rosa Vaysman and a stepdaughter of Roman Betega of Brooklyn, was married Saturday evening to Corey Brett Bobker, a son of Tina W. Bobker and Dennis S. Bobker of Livingston, N.J. Cantor Anna S. Berman officiated at the Palace at Somerset Park in Somerset, N.J.

headline: Tiffany Slaughter and Jed Freeland
text: Tiffany Slaughter and Jed Freeland were married Wednesday evening by the Rev. Richard Walsh at St. Margaret Mary Catholic Church in Winter Park, Fla.

headline: Agnes Pasternak, Michael Zaro
text: Agnes Jennifer Pasternak, a daughter of Eva E. Pasternak and Ivan Pasternak of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to Michael Toby Zaro, a son of Keri Zaro and Stuart D. Zaro of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Mayor and State Reach Deal on a Schools Chief
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached a deal Friday to save the tottering candidacy of Cathleen P. Black to be the next chancellor of New York City schools, agreeing to appoint a career educator who started as a classroom teacher to serve as her second in command.

headline: Bloggingheads: No Mo' Loko?
text: Corby Kummer, left, of The Atlantic and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate the government action against Four Loko.

headline: A Bully Finds a Pulpit on the Web
text: SHOPPING online in late July, Clarabelle Rodriguez typed the name of her favorite eyeglass brand into Google’s search bar.

headline: The Power of Failure
text: Despite the very dire consequences of the latest financial crisis that Wall Street perpetrated on the world, America cannot seem to shake its infatuation with Wall Street bankers and traders.

headline: On an Edge of Brooklyn, New Hopes for a Park in Neglect
text: The hangar on the edge of Floyd Bennett Field has the familiar, post-apocalyptic look of urban decay, with “Danger Keep Out” spray painted in red across one of the building’s doors.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Saturday: Aging Establishment
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — We finally have a real themeless puzzle this week. On Saturdays, the test for me is whether the clever answers are worth the extra effort of solving such hard clues. I found this one utterly charming, except for one answer that made me wince. First, the highlights, and are there ever a lot of them!

headline: Death Sentence Is Upheld in Cheshire Murder Case
text: A judge on Friday upheld the death sentence of the man convicted in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Educator in Chief
text: Under the deal reached between New York City and the state, the city school system will have a chief academic officer, who will have extensive responsibilities, including many that the top official in a school district would typically carry out:

headline: An Eclectic Shopping Hub Wonders What’s Next
text: A trickle of shoppers wandered the repaved sidewalks of the Fulton Street Mall one recent evening, under new streetlamps, a model the city calls the “Fulton Pole,” and freshly planted Kentucky coffee trees. They walked past the pizzeria that will close soon to make way for a Shake Shack, Danny Meyer’s hyper-popular hamburger chain, and past the workers putting the mannequins in the windows of Aeropostale, the teenage clothing store that opened last week.

headline: The Man With Credentials To Complement the New Boss’s
text: When it comes to education credentials, Shael Polakow-Suransky fills a lot of the holes in Cathleen P. Black’s résumé. He is a byproduct of a public school system, and his idea of climbing the career ladder was to start as a mathematics teacher and work his way up to become a top executive in New York City’s Department of Education.

text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Mark Twain’s Big Book
text: Mark Twain’s autobiography  Volume 1  released in mid-November, is an enormous hit, apparently much to the surprise of its publisher, the University of California Press. Bookstores across the country and online retailers sold out almost immediately, never mind that it’s a work of sobering scholarship and more than 700 pages of very small print.

headline: The Arbitration War
text: Unexpected wireless charges are a chronic affliction of life on the grid. The industry triggers more complaints from consumers than any other. AT&T Mobility, by consumer rankings, is the worst. Its performance in a case the Supreme Court heard recently has done nothing to improve that reputation.

headline: Outstanding Debt From 9/11
text: Surely there is one more Republican in the United States Senate willing to do the right thing for the brave Americans who rushed to help at the ground zero site after the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Memo to Albany: It’s Your Job
text: Gov. David Paterson has called legislators back to Albany on Monday to tidy up a few matters before Andrew Cuomo, the governor-elect, takes office in January. So far, the prospects look bad.

headline: Winning the Class War
text: The class war that no one wants to talk about continues unabated.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Iraq’s Troubles Drive Out Refugees Who Came Back
text: BAGHDAD  A second exodus has begun here, of Iraqis who returned after fleeing the carnage of the height of the war, but now find that violence and the nation’s severe lack of jobs are pulling them away from home once again.

headline: Neediest | When A Caregiver Needs Help
text: Dianne Romano is the principal care giver for her mother, who has Alzheimer's, and her brother, who has a brain injury. When Ms. Romano was evicted, The Neediest Cases Fund helped.

headline: A Super Bowl With Black Eyed Peas. Are You Pleased?
text: Sure, Jets-versus-Patriots is a good debate, but there are more profound things to discuss.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Begin Joint Naval Exercises
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States and South Korea began naval exercises on Sunday that were meant as a warning to North Korea for recent provocations, including last week’s deadly artillery attack on a island populated by South Koreans in the Yellow Sea.

headline: When Bankers Met Their Waterloo
text: Napoleon Bonaparte, in response to a request for a bailout of Banque Recamier:
