text: It seems that I have to raise my game: Brad DeLong manages to bring Friedrich Nietzsche into a discussion of the failure of macroeconomic policy.

headline: We Model Nutria Fur in Brooklyn
text: Leanne Shear, an occasional City Room contributor, was invited to model so-called guilt-free fur in Brooklyn last weekend. She had never walked a runway before. Here is her report:

headline: Afghan Police Building Hit by Bombers in Uniforms
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two suicide bombers wearing police uniforms blew themselves up inside the police headquarters of Paktika Province in southeastern Afghanistan on Saturday, killing at least 10 officers and wounding 13 others, according to NATO officials and the emergency physician on duty at the hospital where some victims were taken.

headline: Griffin Dunking His Way Into the Spotlight
text: Before the season, ESPN’s Sports Guy, Bill Simmons, was mocked for declaring that Blake Griffin, the Clippers’ rookie power forward, was already among the league’s best players. Seventeen games into his N.B.A. career, Griffin, right, seems to be living up to that prediction.

headline: F.B.I. Says Oregon Suspect Planned ‘Grand’ Attack
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — A Somali-born teenager who thought he was detonating a car bomb at a packed Christmas tree-lighting ceremony downtown here was arrested by the authorities on Friday night after federal agents said that they had spent nearly six months setting up a sting operation.

headline: Legacy Need Not Divide Jeter and the Yankees
text: Babe Ruth? Really?

headline: Diagramless Chops
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — One of the keys to solving diagramless crosswords is to be even more willing than usual to give up answers you feel certain of. It also, and this will surprise nobody, pays to read the clues. Let me give you a few examples.

headline: Demonstrators in Ireland Protest Austerity Plan
text: DUBLIN  After a week that brought Ireland a pledge of a $114 billion international rescue package and the toughest austerity program of any country in Europe, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to Dublin’s streets on Saturday to protest wide cuts in the country’s welfare programs and in public-sector jobs.

headline: Putting Down Textbooks to Provide for Triplets
text: Devon Armstrong and Winifred Oldham do not hear the doorbell anymore. They say they get eight hours of sleep each night but barely have the energy to rise from the couch when company arrives. And though cheerful and polite, they wear the dreamy, shell-shocked expression familiar to anyone who has learned to tune out the persistent wailing of a newborn. Or three.

headline: Taking Lead, Iraqi Premier Vows to Forge Government
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki sought Saturday to show he was in control of a tenuous new governing coalition, saying that he would have “the decisive word” in forming a new Iraqi government, and would move forward with or without potential allies.

headline: Boise State Drops Out of Race as Season Nears Finish Line
text: As last call loomed at barrooms on the East Coast early Saturday, one kicker’s gaffes changed the complexion of the race for the Bowl Championship Series title game.

headline: When the Software Is the Sportswriter
text: ONLY human writers can distill a heap of sports statistics into a compelling story. Or so we human writers like to think.

headline: Finance Ministers to Set Irish Bailout Terms
text: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers will gather here Sunday to complete a multibillion-euro bailout for Ireland as financial markets waited to see if a restructuring of Irish banks would mean losses for bondholders.

headline: Taxing the Rich: It’s All Relative
text: IT’S not just Tea Party activists who are angry about taxes. A much larger and more diverse group appears outraged that Congress is considering allowing the Bush tax cuts to expire at year-end for families earning more than $250,000 and for individuals earning more than $200,000.

headline: Defensive? It Leads to Destructive

headline: Poland, Lacking External Enemies, Turns on Itself
text: WARSAW  It was 9:30 at night, under a chilly, steady rain. The Presidential Palace glowed brightly in the background as a cluster of men and women huddled under umbrellas, saying prayers, holding small wooden crosses against their bodies, facing a large picture of Jesus Christ on the cross and a lighted statue of the Virgin Mary.

headline: Don’t Just Tell Us. Show Us That You Can Foreclose.
text: AFTER examining their foreclosure practices for flaws in mortgage documentation and other procedures, many of the nation’s largest banks have resumed  or will soon resume  trying to evict defaulted borrowers.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Bristol Palin finished third on last week’s finale of “Dancing With the Stars,” behind Jennifer Gray and Kyle Massey, but not before she had this to say:

headline: Donald Nyrop, Who Led Northwest Airlines, Dies at 98
text: Donald W. Nyrop, a former federal airline regulator who went on to run Northwest Airlines with a keen focus on keeping costs down and improving safety, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Edina, Minn. He was 98.

headline: U.S. Presses Iceland Over Whale Meat Trade
text: The Obama administration has strongly criticized Iceland for resuming international trade in the meat from its expanding hunt for fin whales, the second largest whale species and one still listed as endangered under the United States Endangered Species Act. Here’s a summary and statement issued this week by the Department of Commerce:

headline: Bond Between Generations, With Football on the Side
text: The bond between grandmother and grandson began with vacations through the American countryside when he was 5. Later, she took him to Europe and beyond.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Prime Number
text: 50: The percentage increase, in inflation-adjusted dollars, that graduating college students in 2008 borrowed compared with their counterparts in 1996, an analysis of National Center for Education Statistics data found. More college students are borrowing (60 percent in 2008 versus 52 percent in 1996) and they’re borrowing more ($23,000, compared with $17,000 in 1996), according to the analysis by the Pew Research Center’s Social and Demographic Trends project.

headline: As San Francisco’s Mayor Departs, a Handful of Votes Will Usher In a New One
text: SAN FRANCISCO — This is a city of some 815,000 people, about 49 square miles and exactly one World Series championship. And how many votes does it take to get elected mayor?

headline: U.S. Expects Soccer’s Rise if It Hosts Cup in 2022
text: Interest in soccer has grown considerably in the United States since it hosted the 1994 World Cup. Major League Soccer is on solid footing, having just completed its 15th season of competition. And American television viewership for the quadrennial World Cup final now outdraws the average audience for the World Series.

headline: Broncos Fined for Videotaping 49ers’ Practice in London
text: Three years ago, the videotaping scandal called Spygate convulsed the New England Patriots and captivated the N.F.L., as the integrity and success of one of the game’s premier franchises and coaches were questioned when it was revealed that the Patriots had illicitly recorded opponents’ hand signals during games.

headline: To Fight Climate Change, Clear the Air
text: AS the curtain rises tomorrow in Cancún, Mexico, on the next round of international talks on climate change, expectations are low that the delegates will agree on a new treaty to reduce emissions that contribute to global warming. They were unable to do so last year in Copenhagen, and since then the negotiating positions of the biggest countries have grown even further apart.

headline: Penn Says Farewell to 50 Years of Echoes
text: PHILADELPHIA  C. T. Alexander was not a public-address announcer. He was the Voice of Franklin Field, and at the University of Pennsylvania, that qualified him as a celebrity.

headline: On Global Warming, Start Small
text: THE conference on climate change that begins tomorrow in Cancún, Mexico, will be the 13th such annual meeting since 1997, when the Kyoto Protocol, the first and only international agreement to place a cap on emissions of greenhouse gases, was written. This year there will be no such treaty. Why not? Excuses will abound, but finger-pointing misses the crux of the matter, which is that climate change is the most complicated and challenging problem mankind has ever faced.

headline: Assault on a Formidable Passing Peak
text: In the days before playing San Diego, Denver Coach Josh McDaniels declared Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers the best deep-ball passer he had studied  startling praise, given that the Broncos faced Peyton Manning and the Colts this season.

headline: They Are Not Like Ireland. Really.
text: Last week Ireland joined Greece as the second country in the euro zone to get a bailout — to the grand sum of $100 billion.

headline: An Almanac of Extreme Weather
text: Rushford, Minn.

headline: Back Then: 1950
text: On June 25, 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea. The Times’s Richard J. H. Johnston filed this report from the battle zone on July 13:

headline: From 8-Point Bucks to a 3-Point Stance
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rich Seubert has a Super Bowl ring from the Giants’ victory against the New England Patriots after the 2007 season. His off-field accomplishments are celebrated with a collection of deer skulls.

headline: At 63, It’s Time for a Career Move
text: WALDWICK, N.J.  Lada St. Edmund made men’s hearts flutter as a 17-year-old go-go dancer on the NBC musical variety show “Hullabaloo” in 1965. On black-and-white and even some color televisions, she was a 5-foot-3 ½-inch bundle of energy perched in a cage, arms swinging, hips shaking, blonde hair bouncing, the fringe on her minidress flying.

headline: Oregon Bomb Plot
text: A Somali-born teenager was arrested for allegedly plotting to bomb a crowded Christmas tree lighting ceremony in downtown Portland, Oregon.  NBC's Pete Williams reports.

headline: Bridging Present and Future
text: MY father was a first lieutenant in the United States Army who spoke Japanese. After World War II, the Army sent him to Japan as part of the occupation, and I was born there.

headline: Adam Carolla, World-Class Complainer
text: IN this episode, a Haggler first. The column welcomes a guest ranter  Adam Carolla, of radio (“Loveline”), TV (“The Man Show”) and podcast fame (“The Adam Carolla Show,” an iTunes chart topper). Most recently, he was the author of “In Fifty Years We’ll All Be Chicks,” which was briefly perched ahead of Mark Twain’s autobiography on the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: How Bad Apples Infect the Tree
text: A FEW years back, a Silicon Valley executive  I will call her Ruth  told me about her experiences working in a mean-spirited office. Ruth said her colleagues repeatedly put her down, interrupted her and glared at her, and shot down her solutions to problems while offering few ideas of their own.

headline: Is the Fed’s Plan Working? Look Abroad
text: HOW will you know whether the Federal Reserve’s plan to reinvigorate the economy by buying Treasury debt is working?

headline: Farewell, Digital World. (It’s All for a Cause.)
text: ON Wednesday, Kim Kardashian is going to die a little. So is her sister, Khloé, not to mention Lady Gaga, David LaChapelle, Justin Timberlake, Usher, Serena Williams and Elijah Wood.

headline: Senator Lugar Charts His Course Against the Winds
text: WASHINGTON  Mavericks are not in vogue these days on Capitol Hill, a place where hyper-partisanship and obduracy seem to be their own rewards.

headline: Still the Best Congress Money Can Buy
text: SO America’s latest crisis  until it wasn’t  was airport screeners touching our junk. As this long year lurches toward its end, we all agree that something has gone wrong in America, and we’re desperately casting about for a coherent explanation for our discontent, if not a scapegoat. Alas, the national consensus that the T.S.A. and full-body scans might be the source of all evil fizzled in less than a week. Most everyone got to Grandma’s house for Thanksgiving without genital distress.

headline: Some Very Creative Economic Fix-Its
text: We are not going to shop our way out of this mess.

headline: Asking China to Act Like the U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — A fundamental tenet of foreign policy says that nations will seldom voluntarily act against what they have determined, for whatever reason, to be their own national interest.

headline: Madoff Relatives Sued for $69 Million
text: The trustee seeking to recover money for people who were defrauded by Bernard L. Madoff filed lawsuits Friday against investors, employees and Madoff family members.

headline: Got to Get This Right
text: On Nov. 19, Rasmussen Reports published results from a national telephone poll that showed that 47 percent of America’s likely voters said the nation’s “best days are in the past,” 37 percent said they are in the future. Sixteen percent were undecided. Just before President Obama was inaugurated, 48 percent said our best days were still ahead and 35 percent said they had come and gone. This is a disturbing trend.

headline: Pro Hockey Takes Shot at Legitimacy in Brooklyn
text: The New York Aviators, a minor league hockey team based in Brooklyn, lost their first three games of the season on the road. After another long bus ride  from Chenango, N.Y., to Alexandria Bay near the Canadian border  they arrived later than expected for a game against the Thousand Island Privateers.

headline: A Woman. A Prostitute. A Slave.
text: Americans tend to associate “modern slavery” with illiterate girls in India or Cambodia. Yet there I was the other day, interviewing a college graduate who says she spent three years terrorized by pimps in a brothel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: A’s for Good Behavior
text: A few years ago, teachers at Ellis Middle School in Austin, Minn., might have said that their top students were easy to identify: they completed their homework and handed it in on time; were rarely tardy; sat in the front of the class; wrote legibly; and jumped at the chance to do extra-credit assignments.

headline: Streak Ends With the Knicks Feeling Out of Sorts
text: Amar’e Stoudemire’s mood had been ruined long before he unwittingly spilled a protein shake at his locker stall. The sight of pinkish goop in his designer shoes just served as a final, lasting irritant.

headline: An AIDS Advance, Hiding in the Open
text: In the war against AIDS, a new weapon has emerged.

headline: A New Generation of Robotic Weapons
text: Several manufacturers and research facilities are changing the face of the battlefield with robots designed to help transport equipment, gather intelligence and attack enemy forces.

headline: The Catholic Church, Condoms and ‘Lesser Evils’

headline: Untenable Judicial Ethics

headline: Note to Hugh Prather

headline: Group Votes to Keep Fishing Levels of Bluefin Tuna Stable
text: PARIS — International fisheries negotiators agreed Saturday to maintain the 2011 catch of endangered Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic bluefin tuna at essentially the same level as in 2010, eliciting a stinging rebuke from conservationists, who had been calling for a fishing moratorium.

headline: Power Line Project Faces Challenges in California Valley

The wind is so powerful that west of town, signs on an Interstate display the number of miles remaining in which drivers will face dangerous winds, like signs that give the distance to the next city.

headline: Margaret T. Burroughs, Archivist of Black History, Dies at 95

headline: A Shining Moment

We haven’t had one this big since Caleb Madison’s “Book Binding” in March (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Today there are 171 clues to work through. That’s 30 more than in a typical Sunday.

headline: New Chairman Seeks More Power for Watchdogs

With the right procedures, he wrote, it is possible to ensure “evenhanded, rational and consistent imposition of death sentences under law.”

headline: Willingham Filmmakers Will Speak for the Dead
text: Yes, this is West 11th Street, Corsicana, Texas. It’s about 10 o’clock in the morning. Those are the arson investigators, and they’ll soon decide that I set this house on fire and burned my three young children to death just before Christmas 1991. But before you hear it all distorted or blown out of proportion, maybe you’d like to hear the facts, the whole truth. The governor likes to quote my own defense attorney about how I am  or should I say: was  “a monster.” Because, you see, I was executed six years ago when he wouldn’t grant a stay.

headline: Jews Expect Proposed Ban Won’t Stop Circumcision

headline: A Note to Readers: The Decision to Publish Diplomatic Documents
text: The articles published today and in coming days are based on thousands of United States embassy cables, the daily reports from the field intended for the eyes of senior policy makers in Washington. The New York Times and a number of publications in Europe were given access to the material several weeks ago and agreed to begin publication of articles based on the cables online on Sunday. The Times believes that the documents serve an important public interest, illuminating the goals, successes, compromises and frustrations of American diplomacy in a way that other accounts cannot match.

headline: Melancholy Reflection of Faint Shadows
text: Repetition and constraint fascinate José González, the Swedish songwriter who led Junip at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night. Mr. González’s two solo albums presented him as a disciple of British folk modernizers like John Martyn, Nick Drake and Bert Jansch. They were skeletal productions for voice, acoustic guitar and very little else, setting modal tunes to nimble, meticulous picking, and they quietly sold more than a million copies worldwide.

headline: Okinawa Re-elects Opponent of U.S. Base
text: TOKYO  Voters on the southern Japanese islands of Okinawa re-elected a governor on Sunday who campaigned for the removal of an American Marine base there, throwing a wrench into a deal between Japan and the United States to relocate the base and posing a challenge for the United States as it grapples with a response to North Korean aggression.

headline: The Irish Non-bailout
text: So, a credit line at 5.8 percent interest. Considering that Ireland was able to borrow at that rate as recently as mid-September, and was falling off a cliff then, why is this supposed to solve the problem?

headline: Giants Finish Strong and End a Skid
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was only halftime of a single game, but in the Giants’ locker room, it felt like the fourth quarter of a once-promising season collapsing into mediocrity.

headline: A New York Tale of Art, Money and Ambition
text: “An Object of Beauty” follows the New York art world climb of Lacey Yeager. She is a charismatic character yet a very odd one to have emerged from the imagination of Steve Martin. Although Lacey is treated as this book’s main source of fascination, it’s less interesting to look at her point-blank than to look at her while wondering what Mr. Martin sees.

headline: Lacking All Conviction

headline: When a Skinny Singer Crooned to Knock Your Bobby Socks Off

headline: Familiar Americana, but Still Full of Life
text: When “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” landed in theaters in the early 1850s, it quickly became ubiquitous. “One of the first things it did,” wrote Henry James, who saw it repeatedly, was “to flutter down on every stage, literally without exception, in America and Europe.”

headline: Disney Spins ‘Tangled’ Hair Into Box-Office Gold
text: Four wide-release movies arrived at already crowded multiplexes over the Thanksgiving holiday, and three of them  “Burlesque,” “Love & Other Drugs” and “Faster”  appeared to be in tryptophan torpors. But Rapunzel, above, came to the rescue at the weekend box office: “Tangled,” an updated take on the long-haired princess, performed sharply better than expected. “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1” (Warner Brothers) was No. 1 at the North American box office for a second week, selling about $76 million in tickets over the five-day holiday period for a new domestic total of $220 million. “Tangled” (Walt Disney Studios) sold about $69 million, validating Disney’s controversial decision to play down this film’s musical and princess elements in marketing materials; strong reviews and premium-priced 3-D screenings also helped. DreamWorks Animation’s “Megamind” (distributed by Paramount) was third with $17.6 million for a new total of $130.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “Burlesque,” a musical starring Cher and Christina Aguilera that Sony Pictures Entertainment backed with a hefty marketing campaign, was fourth with about $17 million. Denzel Washington’s runaway-train thriller, “Unstoppable” (20th Century Fox), took fifth place in its third week with about $16 million for a total of over $60 million. Opening out of the Top 5 were “Love & Other Drugs,” a romantic comedy from 20th Century Fox starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Anne Hathaway that took in $14 million, and “Faster,” a thriller from CBS Films and Sony that had about $12 million in sales. “The King’s Speech,” a drama from the Weinstein Company that is considered an Oscar contender, opened in four theaters to $349,791, a total that is considered quite strong for such a limited release.

headline: Brubeck’s Back, Conserving Resources
text: Dave Brubeck made his way to the Blue Note stage with apparent effort on Friday, the first night of a sold-out weekend run. “My doctors told me I’m rushing things,” he said, a little breathlessly, once he had reached the piano bench. He didn’t go on to explain that he had undergone heart surgery in October, when he received a pacemaker, or that a handful of other concert dates had been postponed. He was back and eager to proceed, and that was what mattered, judging by the ensuing clatter of grateful applause.

headline: Galleries Join Virtual Fair
text: Organizers have announced that 139 art galleries worldwide will participate in the V.I.P. Art Fair, an online-only fair, from Jan. 22 to 30. Each gallery will be able to show 8 to 20 artworks in its virtual booth and to store others in a virtual back room, from which it can bring pieces out to show to individual collectors. Browsing the fair is free, but chatting online with the dealers requires a ticket, which will cost $100 the first two days and $20 after that. The fair is the idea of the dealers James and Jane Cohan and the Internet entrepreneurs Jonas and Alessandra Almgren. AXA Art Insurance Corporation will offer information about art insurance to fair visitors, and the PBS program “Art21” will provide videos of studio visits with major artists and tours of major private collections.

headline: Coty, a Fragrance Giant, to Buy OPI, the Nail Polish Maker

headline: Thom Yorke’s Designs for Climate Change
text: About 2,000 people served as the medium on Saturday for a live sculpture designed by Thom Yorke of Radiohead and the artist Stanley Donwood in Brighton and Hove, England. The installation was part of a project organized by Earth 350, a nonprofit group working to address climate change. The group has unveiled installations around the world in the past week, most of which were visible from space. The exhibition was timed to the United Nations Climate Change Conference, which begins on Monday in Cancún, Mexico. The sculpture, of King Canute, was inspired by the legend of the king who put his throne at the edge of the sea only to have it become soaked when the waves would not be still, as he had commanded. “We need politicians today to have a ‘Canute’ moment,” Bill McKibben, the American author, environmentalist and founder of Earth 350, said in a statement on the group’s Web site.

headline: Paradoxical Truth
text: Professor Greene is lecturing. Down the hall, her arch-rival, Professor Browne, is also lecturing. Professor Greene is holding forth at length about how absurd Professor Browne’s ideas are. She believes Professor Browne to be lecturing in Room 33. So to emphasize her point, she writes on the blackboard the single sentence:

headline: Donation Helps Bring Dance Institute to Life
text: The National Institute of Dance Medicine and Science has received a donation of almost $47,000 from British Harlequin, a dance floor specialist, bringing the organization  the first of its kind in Britain  closer to fruition, according to Stage News, a British trade publication. The institute aims to provide high-quality, dance-specific health care and dance science support services equal to those offered to elite athletes. “When you look at squash, football and rugby, if you apply the same definition of ‘injury’ to those other populations, dancers get injured much more, and we are just not doing enough, not just in this country but worldwide,” said Emma Redding, head of dance science at Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance. Dance UK, a dancer advocacy organization, will work with organizations including Trinity, the Birmingham Royal Ballet’s Jerwood Center for the Prevention and Treatment of Dance Injuries and the University of Wolverhampton to form a network that will collectively make up the institute. Its first project will be a two-year, real-time study of the health of working professional dancers. “This is significant,” Ms. Redding said, “because the only research that has ever been done on injuries has been retrospective.” Guy Dagger, the managing director of British Harlequin, said he hoped its donation would encourage other companies to contribute.

headline: Timeless Alchemy, Even When No One Is Dancing
text: We go to the theater to watch and hear things happen. The ballets of George Balanchine are among the ultimate examples of this, and their most archetypal passages occur when all that’s happening is dance.

headline: Funny Man Finds Himself in Unfunny Circumstances
text: An impressive amount of melodrama, activity and funny voices is packed into the hectic hour of “Being Sellers,” a solo biographical play by Carl Caulfield about the actor Peter Sellers that is part of the annual Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters. Telling the old story of the sad clown, the play, which begins in 1980 at a hospital bed where the chameleonic actor is dying by himself, is filled with references that will make fans of movies like “The Pink Panther” and “Dr. Strangelove” nod their heads knowingly.

headline: Survivors Celebrate a Family Reunion
text: “We paying respect to the dead right now,” Juelz Santana told the Hammerstein Ballroom crowd Friday night, urging a moment of silence for the friends he had lost in recent months. “We gotta get this right.”

headline: Scholar Has Theory on Mozart the Debtor
text: The documents of Mozart’s life  letters, memoirs of friends, portraits, bureaucratic files  have long been scrutinized at a microscopic level. So when his name was discovered two decades ago in a Viennese archive from 1791, it caused a stir.

text: Texans receiver Andre Johnson and Titans cornerback Cortland Finnegan were ejected from their game Sunday after they squared off in what amounted to a hockey fight in the fourth quarter.

headline: Sometimes, a Modest Deal Can Secure a Championship
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  On Saturday at the Fall North American Championships here the winners of the Smith Life Master Women’s Pairs were Disa Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala., and Valerie Westheimer of New York. They finished one-third of a board ahead of Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., and Judith Shulman of Delmar, N.Y. Third were Brenda Bryant of Ferndale, Mich., and Kathleen Sulgrove of Twinsburg, Ohio.

headline: Subtlety and Power, With Dash of Drama
text: Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos had the New York Philharmonic sounding its best on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with impeccable ensemble and raw power among the performances’ most striking attributes.

headline: Poet’s Grim Prophecies, With Drama and Music
text: You have only to hear Ute Lemper declaim Charles Bukowski’s apocalyptic poem “Dinosauria, We” to be reminded that Bukowski, who died in 1994, had a gift for gimlet-eyed prophecy. He imagines a 21st century in which people are born “into hospitals which are so expensive that it’s cheaper to die/Into lawyers who charge so much it’s cheaper to plead guilty/Into a country where the jails are full and the madhouses closed/Into a place where the masses elevate fools into rich heroes.”

headline: B.C.S. Bowl Picture Clears Up
text: With one weekend left in college football’s regular season, the bowl picture has cleared up. Here are the projections for the five Bowl Championship Series games.

headline: Mexican Drug Gang Leader Confesses to Killings
text: MEXICO CITY  A notorious drug gang leader has been captured and has confessed to ordering most killings in the battle-scarred border city of Ciudad Juárez since August 2009, including the drive-by shootings of a United States consular employee and her husband, Mexico’s federal police said Sunday.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Takes Off, With Some Bumps
text: All $65 million of the new Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” took flight on Sunday night at its first preview performance, but not without bumps. The show stopped five times, mostly to fix technical problems, and Act I ended prematurely, with Spider-Man stuck dangling 10 feet above audience members, while Act II was marred by a nasty catcall during one of the midperformance pauses.

headline: For City Dwellers, a Taste of the Orderly Life
text: SURABAYA, Indonesia  Replicas of Singapore’s iconic monuments, like the Merlion and the Fountain of Wealth, stand beguilingly at key entrance points to the 5,000-acre city within a city. Roads meander around well-planned parks, along tree-lined boulevards, and through residential areas with familiar names like Raffles and Newton. Cars move in orderly fashion through streets that are wide, smooth and protected by guards ready to pounce on traffic violators and litterers alike.

headline: Robust Sales for Holiday Weekend
text: More Americans went shopping over the Thanksgiving weekend than in recent memory, and online shopping accounted for the highest percentage of the weekend’s sales yet.

headline: Calls From Man With Terror Links Prompted German Alert, Official Says
text: BERLIN  Germany’s recent decision to declare a terrorism alert and dispatch heavily armed police around the nation was set off by phone calls from a man who said he wanted to quit working with terrorists and warned of a pending Mumbai-style attack, according to a law enforcement official with firsthand knowledge of the alert.

headline: Liberal Groups to Propose Routes to Smaller Deficit

headline: Google Grows, and Works to Retain Nimble Minds

headline: A Stale Food Fight

Food Safety Modernization bill. This legislation is by no means perfect. But it promises to achieve several important food safety objectives, greatly benefiting consumers without harming small farmers or local food producers.

headline: Fraud Charges Mar Egypt Vote

headline: The Partisan Mind
text: Imagine, for a moment, that George W. Bush had been president when the Transportation Security Administration decided to let Thanksgiving travelers choose between exposing their nether regions to a body scanner or enduring a private security massage. Democrats would have been outraged at yet another Bush-era assault on civil liberties. Liberal pundits would have outdone one another comparing the T.S.A. to this or that police state. (“In an outrage worthy of Enver Hoxha’s Albania ...”) And Republicans would have leaped to the Bush administration’s defense, while accusing liberals of going soft on terrorism.

headline: Alfred Balk, Journalist and Author, Dies at 80
text: Alfred Balk, a reporter, author and magazine editor who wrote groundbreaking articles about housing segregation and the Nation of Islam, and whose refusal to identify a confidential source led to a landmark court case, died on Thursday at his home in Huntley, Ill. He was 80.

headline: Intolerance and the Law in Oklahoma
text: For a few days this month, it was illegal in Oklahoma for a state judge to base a court decision on Islamic religious law or consider any form of international law. It was a manufactured problem; the issue has never come up in the state’s courts. But more than 70 percent of voters in Oklahoma still approved a state constitutional amendment to that effect, apparently persuaded by anti-Islamic activists, and a few cynical politicians, that Oklahoma was about to be brought under Islam’s heel.

headline: Buccaneers Fall to Ravens in Their Latest Test

But on a Sunday that offered tests of legitimacy for several front-running N.F.C. teams, the Buccaneers failed theirs, losing to the Baltimore Ravens, 17-10.

headline: Dutch Composer Wins Grawemeyer Award
text: The fund that produces the University of Louisville’s Grawemeyer Award for musical composition, among the most prestigious in classical music, has declined so much that the prize has been cut in half, its administrator said. Even so, now at $100,000, it is one of the field’s richest. The winner this year is Louis Andriessen, 71, the Netherlands’ most prominent composer, the university said Sunday night. Mr. Andriessen won specifically for his multimedia opera “La Commedia,” which is based on Dante’s “Divine Comedy” and had its first performance in Amsterdam in 2008. The work was also performed last spring at Carnegie Hall, where Mr. Andriessen, left, was the subject of a series of concerts. The last five Grawemeyer winners in music were Gyorgy Kurtag, Sebastian Currier, Peter Lieberson, Brett Dean and York Höller. The awards are granted in four other areas: religion, education, political science and psychology. The Grawemeyer fund dropped to $17 million from about $29 million over six months in 2008 because of the stock market decline, said Allan Dittmer, the program’s executive director. “If we continued to give a $200,000 award, we would be deeply into our principal, which was dropping,” Mr. Dittmer said. “We had to do something.”

headline: Wolf Politics
text: These days, the gray wolf is in trouble in the Rocky Mountain West and in Washington, D.C. Several members of the House have introduced a bill that would permanently remove wolves from the protection of the Endangered Species Act. A more “moderate” proposal sponsored by two Montana Democrats, Senators Max Baucus and Jon Tester, would exempt only wolves in Montana and Idaho. Both bills could be pushed hard in the remaining days of Congress’s lame-duck session.

headline: Chaos at the Polls in Haiti

headline: Repatriating Tut
text: When King Tutankhamen’s tomb was discovered in 1922, the world instantly craved a first-hand sighting of the golden sarcophagus, exquisite funerary jewels and divine chariots accompanying the Boy King through the Big Sleep. Nearly 90 years later the enthusiasm  and the entrepreneurial desire to exploit it  continues.

headline: A London Show Celebrates the Book Cover
text: At a time when e-readers may be displacing the good, old-fashioned print book, an effort to revive interest in the art of the book cover is taking place in London. The gallery StolenSpace gave a simple task to a group of more than 30 artists, designers, ceramic artists and photographers: design a cover for your favorite book. Participants were free to paint, print, etch, sculpt, photograph, or use any medium of their choice, as long as the result was in the size of an average book (defined as 198mm by 129mm).

headline: Good Habits
text: Priests and nuns are not the most likely fashion inspirations, but the first hint that I remember of the clerical collar as a subversive take on the prim and the perverse was at the Prada men’s collection in January 2008. I remember watching the guys, in their streamlined tailoring, walk a weird cat’s cradle of a wooden runway. They were close enough for the audience to spot chests covered with what resembled pastors’ bibs, tied over bared shirt backs. Other looks, as if of a priest defrocking himself, were neckties used as nooses and visible underpants rising from trousers. But it was the abstract collars — and the sly sexuality that the enigmatic Miuccia Prada drew from them — that stayed in my mind.

headline: Chinese Export Regions Face Labor Shortages
text: BEIJING  Two of China’s main export manufacturing areas are suffering from an acute shortage of migrant workers, giving laborers more leverage over wages and curtailing the expansion plans of some companies, according to a report published Monday in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions About State’s Secrets
text: The New York Times is publishing State’s Secrets, a series of articles about a trove of more than 250,000 American diplomatic cables that were originally obtained  by WikiLeaks, an organization devoted to exposing official secrets. The cables reveal the daily traffic between the State Department and more than 270 diplomatic outposts around the world and offer a secret chronicle of the United States’ relations with other nations in an age of war and terrorism.

headline: Bears Are Contending Again
text: The funny thing about sports is, if your attention wanders for even a minute, you can lose track of everything.

headline: Waiting on the Teenage Brain
text: I spent the Thanksgiving weekend with four teenagers and one preteen. I adore all of them. But let’s just say that by Sunday I was more than ready to read Judith Newman’s article in Parade Magazine — the one titled “Inside the Teenage Brain,” which begins: “I would rather give birth to a baby elephant than raise a teenager again. It would be less painful.”

headline: The Post-Oscar Whirlwind
text: Before we plunge headlong into all the news and nonsense of this year’s race, let’s indulge in a bit of where-are-they-now for last year’s winners. The Bagger caught up with Kathryn Bigelow and Mark Boal, the director and writer, respectively, of “The Hurt Locker,” at a recent benefit at the Museum of Modern Art, where Ms. Bigelow was being honored. (The museum has acquired her print archives, and a retrospective of her work is planned for June.)

headline: A Touch of Norway at Carnegie Hall
text: Since 1991 the Risor Chamber Music Festival has been attracting internationally renowned artists and emerging Scandinavian musicians to a charming coastal fishing village in southeastern Norway for a cram-packed week in late June. On Wednesday evening the festival begins its first Carnegie Hall residency, with four concerts through Saturday: an enticing sampling of typically diverse Risor programs.

headline: Clinton Says U.S. Diplomacy Will Survive ‘Attack’
text: WASHINGTON  Some world leaders expressed anger on Monday over the disclosures in confidential American diplomatic cables, even as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said she was confident that the administration’s diplomatic relationships would withstand the upheaval.

headline: House Censure: Humbling to Some, but Not All
text: One threatened fellow lawmakers with a pistol. Two others assaulted their colleagues with canes, an old weapon of choice on Capitol Hill. In the heat of slavery and secession debates, some raised insults to an art form. A few took bribes or flirted with treason. Two offenders had sex with Congressional pages.

headline: 6 American Trainers Killed by an Afghan Police Officer
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six American service members who were training Afghan Border Police officers were killed on Monday when one of the trainees turned his gun on them, the Pentagon said.

text: On Monday, The Lede is continuing to follow reaction to the release of a trove of American diplomatic cables by WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowers’ Web site.

headline: Thank the Academy? Ravitch Would Rather Plead Poverty
text: Don’t expect Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch to bask in an optimistic glow Tuesday night when Common Cause New York honors him with its John Gardner Lifetime Achievement Award. He has two words for New Yorkers: “We’re broke.”

headline: Just Do It
text: Governments sometimes have a very difficult time understanding the need to make decisions, and make them effective immediately. Instead, they often announce a change in policy years in advance. That can create unfortunate side effects.

headline: TimesCast | November 29, 2010

headline: Wasted Youth | Skye Parrott at Capricious Space
text: Skye Parrott, the photographer, curator and one half of the duo behind the art and fashion journal Dossier, regularly shoots for the likes of Dazed and Confused and Vogue. “First Love, Last Rites,” now on view at Capricious space in Brooklyn, however, finds Parrott operating on a more personal level. Recreating events from her drug-fueled teens, Parrott has tried to dive headlong into her own blurry history — something more difficult than you might imagine. “In doing this work, I was keenly aware that what I remembered might not be ‘real,’ ” she says. Curious about what actually happened, after making the photographs she interviewed her boyfriend from that period to see what he remembered. “There was a lot of overlap,” she says, “but there were huge discrepancies, too. I think it points to the way that memories form us, and as we form, we reshape them to fit.”

headline: James Franco and Anne Hathaway to Host the Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES —﻿Out with the old, in with the young: James Franco and Anne Hathaway will co-host  the 83rd Academy Awards in February, an apparent bid to attract younger  viewers to the telecast.

headline: Second Hat in the Ring for Republican Leader
text: The fight for control of the Republican National Committee intensified on Monday when Ann Wagner, a former leader of the Missouri Republican Party, declared her intention to run for chairwoman of the national party.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: AbelsonTaylor, Chicago, hired two employees and promoted a third. Ayubu Azizi joins as senior copywriter; he had been copy supervisor at S&R Medical Communications, Durham, N.C. Greg Wilson joins as senior art director; he had been freelancing for the last four years. And Caren Spigland, senior copywriter, was promoted to associate creative director.

headline: You’ll Never Believe What the Landlord Wanted
text: This week’s installment of my column, The Appraisal, explores one of the most common and controversial demands that New York City landlords make on renters: If renters do not make a certain amount of money, they must find a guarantor willing to hand over reams of personal financial information and guarantee the rent.

headline: Revisiting ‘Revelations’
text: Members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater discuss the famed Ailey work, which celebrates its 50th anniversary this season.

headline: Irvin Kershner, Hollywood Director, Dies at 87
text: Irvin Kershner, a film director who made name-brand Hollywood movies with name-brand Hollywood stars  including “The Empire Strikes Back,” the second film in the original “Star Wars” trilogy  without ever becoming a name brand himself, died at his home in Los Angeles on Saturday. He was 87.

headline: Analysts Expect 6-Month Delay in Dreamliner Delivery
text: Market analysts on Monday projected a six-month delay in the first delivery of Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner and cut estimates of how quickly the company would increase production of the plane.

headline: Casting Director Dismissed From ‘Hobbit’
text: You’d think a movie project whose roster of characters runs from dwarves to dragons would need to be as inclusive as possible in its casting. But on Monday a casting agent was let go from Peter Jackson’s planned film adaptations of “The Hobbit,” after placing newspaper advertisements seeking extras with “light skin tones” and a prospective performer said she was told she was too dark to appear in the movies, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Fishing Banned in Stretch of Gulf
text: Citing an “abundance of caution,” federal officials shut down more than 4,000 square miles of the Gulf of Mexico to deepwater shrimping last week after a commercial shrimper hauled in a catch of royal red shrimp and found numerous tar balls in his net.

text: After a decade as the inspector general of the Justice Department, Glenn A. Fine told President Obama and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday that he will step down early next year.

headline: The Claim: A Cup of Coffee can Ease the Symptoms of Asthma
text: THE FACTS Caffeine is known more as a pick-me-up than a home remedy, but for years scientists have wondered whether it may have benefits for people with asthma.

headline: Numberplay: Scrambled Controls
text: Last year in The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, we presented a puzzle suite that showed what happens when you are given random information. Simple tasks become difficult, and hard problems doubly difficult when information is scrambled. In spite of this, however, it is usually possible to achieve your goals. Today’s puzzle is of this type. Like the Egg Drop Soup puzzle, it too came to me via a graduate student at the recent Gathering For Gardner.

headline: Being Happy in a Sad Place
text: In these quantitatively grim times, with unemployment high and growth low, the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco has made something of a (small) cottage industry of examining existential questions, not the least what makes us happy, sad, and perhaps suicidal.

headline: Freeze Frame
text: Yep, that’s exactly what we needed: a transparently cynical policy gesture, trivial in scale but misguided in direction, and in effect conceding that your bitter political opponents have the right idea.

headline: Asthma Symptoms? Try Caffeine
text: Today’s “Really?” column explores whether caffeine from coffee or strong tea can work as a home remedy for asthma symptoms.

headline: Head Out for a Daily Dose of Green Space
text: First, the bad news: Americans are suffering from an acute case of “outdoor deprivation disorder,” and the effects on physical and mental health are rising fast. Children aged 8 to 18 today spend more time than ever using electronic media indoors  seven and a half hours a day, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation  and less time in outdoor unstructured activity. In response to the No Child Left Behind law, 30 percent of kindergarten classrooms have eliminated recess to make more room for academics.

headline: Women’s World Cup Draw; U.S. Opens Against North Korea
text: The United States, which faced an uncharacteristic struggle to qualify for soccer’s 2011 Women’s World Cup, was drawn into a first-round group with North Korea, Colombia and Sweden in Frankfurt, Germany on Monday.

headline: National Dance Institute Finds a New Home
text: A Harlem real estate development will become the new home of the National Dance Institute, which provides dance training for public school children. The institute, currently on Broadway near Houston Street, said on Monday that it would take up residence at P.S. 90, a former school building at 220 West 148th Street between Adam Clayton Powell and Frederick Douglass Boulevards that is being turned into condominiums. The institute, founded in 1976 by the dancer Jacques d’Amboise, said it would have offices and studios at the space and would be able to expand its programs. More than half of the $20 million needed to carry out the project has been raised, the institute said.

headline: Fuel Lines of Tumors Are New Target
text: For the last decade cancer drug developers have tried to jam the accelerators that cause tumors to grow. Now they want to block the fuel line.

headline: Boehner Invites Republican Governors-Elect to Meet in D.C.
text: Stretching his influence beyond the Beltway, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the incoming House speaker, said Monday that he would host a meeting on Capitol Hill next week with the nation’s new Republican governors-elect.

headline: Splits in Euro Zone Emerge Amid Debt Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — Even as Europe struggles to contain its latest debt crisis, fresh fissures are emerging that show the euro zone diverging into two — or even three — different economic parts that threaten to compound the problems even further.

headline: Fell Off My Bike, and Vowed Never to Get Back On
text: I crashed on my bike on Oct. 3 and broke my collarbone, an experience so horrific that my first impulse was to say I would never ride on the road again.

headline: Coal Trends Still Rule Climate Talks
text: 8:00 p.m. | Updated  Today saw the official opening in Cancún, Mexico, of talks over a new treaty aimed, theoretically, at avoiding dangerous human interference with the climate system. But Chinese coal and American politics pretty much guarantee that negotiators, despite a relaxed dress code this year, will only nibble at the edges of the climate challenge. [8:00 p.m. | Updated  There’s more from me on the climate talks and congressional tussles over climate policy in an interview I did earlier today with Barbara Bernstein of KBOO radio in Corvallis, Ore.]

text: An outbreak of mysterious blisters in Liberia illustrates how panic can be stirred by a combination of overwrought journalism, listless government and traditional witchcraft.

headline: Inefficiency Hurts U.S. in Longevity Rankings
text: By any measure, the United States spends more on health care than any other nation. Yet according to the World Fact Book (published by the Central Intelligence Agency), it ranks 49th in life expectancy.

headline: Foot Injury Sidelines N.B.A.’s Top Rebounder
text: Weeks ago, Justin Kubatko noted the rebounding excellence of the Toronto Raptors’ Reggie Evans in this space, as Evans’ rebounding ethic is obscured by more conventional rebounding measures, but is resplendent under the light of more detailed statistics. Evans is still third in the league in rebounds per game, even though rebound percentage –- a percentage estimate of the rebounds a player grabbed while they were on the floor –- shows the Raptors’ forward to be far and away the most efficient rebounder in the league. When the noise from pace factors and varying opportunities are wiped clean, Evans is the league’s indisputable best on the boards.

headline: Narcissism No Longer a Psychiatric Disorder
text: Narcissistic personality disorder, characterized by an inflated sense of self-importance and the need for constant attention, has been eliminated from the upcoming manual of mental disorders, which psychiatrists use to diagnose mental illness.

headline: The Mystery of the Red Bees of Red Hook
text: Cerise Mayo expected better of her bees. She had raised them right, given them all the best opportunities  acres of urban farmland strewn with fruits and vegetables, a bounty of natural nectar and pollen. Blinded by devotion, she assumed they shared her values: a fidelity to the land, to food sources free of high-fructose corn syrup and artificial food coloring.

headline: Back to the Costly Skies
text: As American companies negotiate airline and hotel rates for 2011, they are encountering a market much different from a year ago, when the economy, and business travel with it, were still feeble.

headline: It’s No Simple Matter Before a Tree Joins Rockefeller Center History
text: In November 1986, a man in a hard hat took a chain saw to the trunk of the tree that had stood outside Mary and Vinnie Frohling’s home in Rockland County for half a century. The man with the saw was no ordinary lumberjack. He was from Rockefeller Center.

headline: In a Holiday Indicator, Retailers Say Online Sales Remain Strong
text: Online shoppers started buying on Thanksgiving and did not let up on so-called Cyber Monday, the day retailers designated for more discounts and promotions. By 6 p.m. on Monday, Eastern time, sales were 20 percent higher than during the same time period on the Monday after Thanksgiving a year ago, according to Coremetrics, a research firm owned by I.B.M. that tracks online sales.

headline: Rothenberg Looks Back, and Ahead to 2022 World Cup in the U.S.
text: Alan I. Rothenberg presided over a startlingly successful World Cup in the United States in 1994. And with FIFA’s all-powerful 24-man executive committee (minus two suspended members) poised to announce the host countries for the tournaments in 2018 and 2022 Thursday in Zurich, Rothenberg remains an unabashed booster of America.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Batting Practice
text: The Samurai Shopper is not easily beguiled by bread and circuses. Ever steadfast, I remain impervious to the flashy and trivial vanities that litter the cultural landscape. But those “Burlesque” posters of Cher and Christina Aguilera are getting to me, along with the overexposed Kardashian klaque. It’s not their beauty or fame that distracts me, it’s those fake eyelashes I love.

headline: A High School Reunion for Indie Filmmakers

headline: Kids Giving Gifts
text: In response to our conversation here last week about gift ideas for children who have too much “stuff,” a reader left a question in the comments. “We talk a lot about children getting presents, but how about the flip side: shouldn’t children be GIVING them?”

headline: CBS Renews ‘The Young and the Restless’
text: CBS is not giving up on the daytime soap entirely. The network announced Monday that it had renewed “The Young and the Restless” for three more seasons, keeping the daily drama on the network through 2014.

headline: Porsche Green Lights ‘Cajun’ Small S.U.V.
text: Porsche said Monday that its supervisory board had approved the development of a new small S.U.V. for series production. The vehicle is known as the Cajun — for now — and it will slot beneath the Cayenne S.U.V.

headline: Ex-Player Is Suing Over Pay for Injury
text: A recently retired N.F.L. player filed a lawsuit Monday claiming that the league’s disability plan withheld benefits for an injury caused by one of the helmet-to-helmet impacts the league has recently been trying to minimize.

headline: In the Energy Race, Echoes of Sputnik
text: With some House Republicans gunning for the stimulus bill, especially the portion that went to the Energy Department, the energy secretary went on a pre-emptive offensive of sorts on Monday in advance of the Republican takeover over the chamber, telling an audience at the National Press Club that that money was merely a down payment.

headline: Sign of the ‘Times': Dylan’s Lyrics for Sale
text: Come gather ’round, people: if your cash to you is worth spending on a one-of-a-kind piece of Bob Dylan memorabilia, you might consider saving the date of Dec. 10. That’s when Sotheby’s plans to auction Mr. Dylan’s handwritten lyrics to “The Times They Are a-Changin'” as part of a larger sale of books and manuscripts, the auction house said on Monday. In a catalog listing, Sotheby’s described the item as “a sheet of unruled three-hole notebook paper” on which Mr. Dylan wrote four verses of the famous protest song in simple block lettering (which you can see in closer detail here). He later recorded it for his 1964 album of the same title. (The verse that begins, “Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen,” does not appear in the document, though a fragment of lyrics from Mr. Dylan’s song “North Country Blues” can be seen on the reverse side.)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Haiti and South Korea.

headline: Judge Blocks Oklahoma’s Ban on Using Shariah Law in Court
text: HOUSTON  An Oklahoma constitutional amendment aimed at stopping the use of Islamic law in its courts was dealt a serious blow on Monday when a federal judge temporarily blocked the state from putting it into effect.

headline: G.M. Sells Parts Maker to a Chinese Company
text: DETROIT  General Motors said on Monday that it had completed a deal to sell a subsidiary that makes power-steering components to an affiliate of the Beijing municipal government.

headline: A To-Do (and To-Don’t) List for Parents
text: This whole going-off-college-thing goes so much better when there’s a true partnership between parent and child. I do get concerned when parents cross the line and begin taking on Junior’s role in the process — because there’s plenty enough to do for both Junior and Mom and Dad.

headline: Fast-Food Options for Kids
text: Jim Skinner, the chief executive officer of the McDonald’s Corporation, believes that his company is doing its part to provide healthy meal options for its customers, children included. In a recent interview with USA Today, Mr.  Skinner was asked what McDonald’s has done to help combat obesity. “I like to say that we’ve been part of the solution,” Mr. Skinner said.

headline: The Guantánamo Diaspora
text: President Obama signed an order shortly after taking office to close the prison within one year. But the deadline passed as it became harder than the administration expected to transfer the detainees. Some detainees cannot be prosecuted or released, and there is opposition to moving the detainees to American soil.

headline: Cables Depict U.S. Haggling to Clear Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — Last year, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia proposed an unorthodox way to return Guantánamo Bay prisoners to a chaotic country like Yemen without fear that they would disappear and join a terrorist group.

headline: North Korea Keeps the World Guessing
text: WASHINGTON — With North Korea reeling from economic and succession crises, American and South Korean officials early this year secretly began gaming out what would happen if the North, led by one of the world’s most brutal family dynasties, collapsed.

headline: Musicals Give Thanks After Fat Holiday Week
text: Thanksgiving tourists picked true to form on Broadway last week, opting for big musical blockbusters like “Wicked” — which grossed a rare $2 million for eight performances — and “The Lion King,” which, with $1.87 million, had its highest-grossing week in the 13-year history of the Disney musical on Broadway. The good tidings extended to holiday-themed shows like the new musical “Elf,” which, after “Wicked,” notched the largest one-week jump in grosses, earning $1,406,283 last week compared to $862,995 for the previous week.

headline: Recount Begins to Determine Governor’s Race in Minnesota
text: Election officials in Minnesota began a massive recount on Monday to determine the winner of the only gubernatorial race that is still undecided from the 2010 midterm elections.

text: A. O. Scott looks back at John Boorman's revenge film about the fate of the individual in the corporate world.

headline: A Few Financial Matters You Can Control
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Portraits of the Mind
text: The Times's assistant science editor interviews Carl Schoonover, a neuroscientist at Columbia University, about his book,  "Portraits of the Mind," featured in Tuesday's Science Times.

headline: ‘Why Mahler?’
text: In August 1991 Mikhail Gorbachev was meeting military ofﬁcials at his holiday home in the Crimea when, resisting a demand for a return to totalitarian rule, he was placed under house arrest. The phones went dead, and he was held incommunicado for three days. His wife, Raisa, collapsed with a hypertension attack. In Moscow protesters massed in the streets, and the president of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, led an armed vigil outside Parliament, tele­vised live around the world. The coup crumbled, and Gorbachev was restored to ofﬁce, only to be deposed at the year’s end by the drunken and rapacious Yeltsin.

headline: The Beautiful Mind
text: Images from “Portraits of the Mind: Visualizing the Brain From Antiquity to the 21st Century” show new techniques in trying to understand the mysteries of the brain.

headline: An Odyssey Through the Brain, Illuminated by a Rainbow
text: Who has seen the mind? Neither you nor I — nor any of the legions of neuroscientists bent on opening the secrets of that invisible force, as powerful and erratic as the wind.

headline: Celebrating a Man With Many Acolytes
text: Norman Lebrecht, in his new book, “Why Mahler?: How One Man and Ten Symphonies Changed Our World,” speaks of “Mahler’s capacity to pierce human defenses.” And it is certainly true that Mahler’s music can unhinge the susceptible.

headline: A Dirge for the Bluefin Tuna
text: International fisheries negotiators dashed hopes for protection of the bluefin tuna over the weekend in Paris, agreeing to leave fishing quotas for the endangered fish essentially unchanged next year. Conservationists did claim small victories in measures to protect sharks and turtles, however.

headline: Court’s Curious Decision on Airgas
text: The Delaware Supreme Court’s opinion in favor of Airgas in its battle with Air Products and Chemicals is notable for what it does not say or do. The court finds that Delaware’s staggered board statute is ambiguous; so the court looks to see what Airgas’s certificate of incorporation states. The court then finds that the certificate is also ambiguous.

headline: Europe’s Crisis of Liquidity
State Grants Waiver for Schools Chancellor
text: Cathleen P. Black, the publishing executive picked by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to be the next schools chancellor, cleared a final hurdle on Monday as the state granted her the waiver she needs to take office.

headline: Murder! Intrigue! Astronomers?
text: When Danish and Czech scientists exhumed the remains of the astronomer Tycho Brahe in Prague this month, they dug up much more than some bones and hairs. They found something that has eluded astronomers for thousands of years: a story with major box-office potential.

headline: Cowboys of Madagascar
text: Tuesday, Nov. 23

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Point Blank’
text: This week, A. O. Scott looks at one of the high points in the revenge film genre, 1967’s “Point Blank,” directed by John Boorman. Though many films have focused on a wronged character seeking payback, “there aren’t many characters who embody vengeance as forcefully, as purely, as nastily as Lee Marvin‘s Walker,” he says. The film fills the screen with enemies for Walker to confront and take down on his way to retribution, but Mr. Scott sees a deeper side too, calling it “an allegory about the fate of the individual in a world dominated by corporate power.” Have you seen “Point Blank?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Google Earth Pushes Boundaries Between Real and Virtual
text: In late September, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, explained at a press event that he wanted Google to be “the third half of your brain.” Mr. Brin wasn’t just referring to the company’s search products when he made that somewhat eerie proclamation. He was also alluding to a number of  products that should be expected in the coming years.

headline: Question for Big Film: It’s Not a Comedy?
text: LOS ANGELES — Harrison Ford glowered. Daniel Craig glared.

headline: Airlines Getting New Top Lobbyist

headline: A Tax Strategy for Athletes

headline: Tall Fliers Get Sympathy, but Not From Everyone
text: Travel has become less glamorous as the airline industry braves an unstable economy and terrorist threats. Enhanced security, fewer flights, longer waits and cutbacks in amenities make keeping both feet on the ground an attractive option to those who can get to their destination without hitting the tarmac.

headline: An Enlightened Exchange in Iran
text: This is a story about a courageous policy in an unexpected place. In this place homeless shelters have vending machines selling clean syringes for injecting drugs.  Drug users are not prosecuted as long as they are in treatment programs.  Drug addicts are given clean needles and methadone maintenance therapy ─ available on a widespread basis even in prison.  These tactics have worked to reduce crime, lower H.I.V. rates among drug users and keep AIDS from spreading out into the general population.  The place is not Amsterdam.  It is Tehran.

The Yankees will receive a draft pick as compensation next June.

headline: At 41, Defying Age and Batters

headline: France: Terrorism Suspect Is Extradited From Italy
text: A French citizen of Algerian descent who was arrested recently in southern Italy while carrying bomb-making materials was extradited to France on Monday, judicial officials said. The suspect, Ryad Hannouni, had been taken into custody after returning from the war zone around the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan. He was accused by French authorities of “participation in criminal networks aimed at supplying jihad in the Pakistani-Afghan zone,” and appeared later Monday before a French antiterrorist magistrate for questioning. Mr. Hannouni’s arrest last month near the central train station in Naples was followed by the arrests of 12 people in southern France in what the French Interior Ministry said was part of a campaign against terrorism.

headline: Gil McDougald, Ex-Yankee, Dies at 82
text: Gil McDougald, the Yankees’ versatile All-Star infielder who played on five World Series championship teams but was remembered as well for a single at-bat resulting in one of baseball’s most frightening moments, died Sunday at his home in Wall Township, N.J. He was 82.

headline: Wisconsin Gunman Shoots Himself After Standoff
text: CHICAGO  A student armed with a handgun held 23 other students and a teacher hostage for several hours on Monday before shooting himself at a high school in Marinette, Wis., which borders the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, the authorities said.

headline: Crosby’s Assist Helps Penguins Top Rangers
text: Fifteen minutes into Pittsburgh’s 3-1 victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, Ryan Callahan was tangled up with Sidney Crosby away from the puck, and they both fell to the ice.

headline: Massachusetts: Oxford Scientist Is Expected to Lead Tufts
text: Tufts University is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has appointed as its president Anthony P. Monaco, an American-born neuroscientist who has spent the last two decades at the University of Oxford in England. Dr. Monaco’s research has focused on the genetic basis of autism, language impairment and dyslexia. A native of Wilmington, Del., he received his bachelor’s degree at Princeton, and his M.D. and Ph.D. at Harvard. He would succeed Lawrence S. Bacow, who announced in February that he would stop down as president after 10 years.

headline: An Inspector General Is Leaving
text: After a decade as the inspector general of the Justice Department, Glenn A. Fine told President Obama and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday that he would step down at the end of January. In letters to the two men, Mr. Fine said, “It is time for me to pursue new professional challenges.” He had already served about five years in the office of the inspector general when President Bill Clinton appointed him to become its top official in 2000. His office attracted particularly widespread attention for its investigations during the Bush administration  including documenting politicized hiring practices in the department’s Civil Rights Division and the circumstances behind the firing of nine United States attorneys in 2006.

headline: Using World Cup Veterans, Barcelona Routs Its Rival

headline: Dreaming of Reform
text: The Dream Act, the immigration bill that opens a path to legalization for undocumented young people who go to college or serve in the military, has a shot at passing the lame-duck Congress. headline: Night Vision

headline: The Public School Bargain
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg avoided a dispute that would have paralyzed New York City’s school system when he agreed to appoint a career educator to serve as second in command to his pick for schools chancellor, Cathleen Black. Her lack of education experience had made it almost certain that the state education commissioner would veto her appointment. Ms. Black’s chief academic officer will be Shael Polakow-Suransky, a respected, hard-driving educator who has worked his way from middle school math teacher, to high school principal, to his most recent post as the school system’s accountability officer.

headline: Bella Akhmadulina, Bold Voice in Russian Poetry, Dies at 73
text: Bella Akhmadulina, a poet whose startling images and intensely personal style, couched in classical verse forms, established her as one of the Soviet Union’s leading literary talents, died on Monday at her home in Peredelkino, outside Moscow. She was 73.

headline: At Vanderbilt, Much To Be Thankful For
text: This Thanksgiving was a particularly special one for the Vanderbilt basketball team. It marked the first time in four years that we were actually able to spend Thanksgiving in Nashville and enjoy a traditional home-cooked holiday meal. We’ve had dinners on Thanksgiving before, but none like this. We starved ourselves for 24 hours beforehand and showed up to Coach’s house Joey Tribbiani style, in our maternity elastic-waistband pants. Then, of course, as we lay on the couch in a food coma, we reflected on the great things in our lives that we were thankful for.

headline: Lawmakers Resist Paterson’s Spending Cuts
text: ALBANY  Lawmakers who gathered here for a special session appeared almost certain on Monday night to set aside a package of spending cuts proposed by Gov. David A. Paterson, leaving this year’s state budget hundreds of millions of dollars out of balance as the governor-elect, Andrew M. Cuomo, prepares to take office on Jan. 1.

headline: Ryan Seacrest and Clear Channel in Expanded Radio Deal
text: LOS ANGELES  Clear Channel Communications is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has signed Ryan Seacrest to an expanded radio deal worth $60 million over three years, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Levine and Berlioz on Tanglewood Slate
text: James Levine, who returned to conducting this season after back surgery, plans to lead the Boston Symphony Orchestra in performances of the Berlioz Requiem and Mahler’s Symphony No. 5, along with a student performance of Debussy’s opera “Pelléas et Mélisande” at the Tanglewood music festival next summer, officials there said on Monday. Mr. Levine is the music director of the Boston Symphony, which takes up a summer residence at Tanglewood, in Lenox, Mass. Mr. Levine will also conduct all-Italian, all-Ravel and all-Sibelius programs. The festival, which runs from June 28 to Sept. 4 and brings in young musicians as students, will include appearances by Lorin Maazel, Yo-Yo Ma, Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, Susan Graham, Joshua Bell and James Taylor. The Mark Morris Dance Group will also present a new work.
