headline: Wall Street Shares Decline Again
text: Stocks on Wall Street declined on Tuesday as well as for the month of November as concerns over Europe’s financial health lingered.

headline: Quantifying the Importance of Jets-Patriots
text: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

headline: Now Showing | I Saloni Milano
text: This week marks the start of a six-week program in New York that celebrates Italian design and culture.  I Saloni Milano, or the Milan Furniture Fair — sponsored by Federlegno Arredo, an Italian federation of wood and cork furnishings manufacturers; Cosmit, the fair organizer; the Italian Trade Commission; and the Italian Ministry of Economic Development —  includes events at 20 Italian furniture showrooms until Jan. 8, as well as two special installations. On Monday night, “Perchance to Dream,” an exhibition by the artist and director Robert Wilson, opens at Center 548 in Chelsea, where it will run through Dec. 18. In the exhibition, Wilson has installed his video portrait of the Italian ballet star Roberto Bolle on 31 screens in seven different rooms, through which are interspersed pieces of Italian furniture that Wilson chose for their form, shape, color and shadows.

headline: Where Does That Starbucks Cup Go?
text: So when you finish drinking that Starbucks coffee and toss the cup into the trash or even the recycling bin, what happens to it?

headline: The Italian Job
text: OK, folks, this is getting really serious. Spain is bad enough, but Italy …

headline: Date Set for Nuclear Talks With Iran
text: TEHRAN  Iran and the European Union agreed Tuesday on a date for nuclear talks in Geneva next week, but President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad insisted in a speech that Iran would not give “one iota” in the discussions.

headline: J’Accuse! Craig Ferguson Meets an Ardent French Admirer
text: If you’re an American talk-show host who discovers your late-night program in Los Angeles is being copied by an imitator nearly 6,000 miles away in Paris, your avenues of recourse would seem to be limited. You could write threatening letters in hopes that your doppelganger finds new material, or you could just grin and bear it. Or you could do what Craig Ferguson did and invite your copycat onto your show.

headline: Learned Helplessness
text: This WSJ article about economists in search of a model takes it as given that all our models have failed completely in the crisis — which is a gross exaggeration.

headline: China Bars U.S. From American Geologist’s Appeal
text: BEIJING — The United States Embassy was denied access to an appeal hearing for an American geologist sentenced in July to eight years in prison for buying a database on China’s oil industry, an American official said here Tuesday.

headline: Air Products Extends Offer for Airgas
text: The takeover battle for Airgas will continue to run on as both sides await a decision from the Delaware Chancery Court on the company’s poison pill.

headline: The Graying Work Force
text: My 73-year-old father is retired, sort of. He works as a greeter in a grocery store in Calgary, Alberta, juggling shifts at work with caring for my young niece, who stays with my parents after school until my sister finishes work. You’ve likely seen someone like him in action — an elderly man or woman who says hello when you walk in, steers you to the right aisle and wishes you good day on your way out.

headline: For Fannie, a Glimmer of Light in the Gloom
text: The housing market just earned a much-needed moral victory. Although more than 4 percent of loans held by Fannie Mae are still delinquent, the rate declined recently as banks and the government refined their foreclosure prevention programs, Fannie’s monthly housing summary showed.

headline: Chancellor Appointee Gets Her  Waiver
text: Tuesday will be mild with highs in the 50s and a 50 percent chance of rain from the leaden skies. Brace yourselves for the storm headed our way.

headline: A Celebration of Indie Film, Uninhibited
text: Independent film as salvation: that was the message of the annual Gotham Independent Film Awards on Monday night. Patricia Clarkson, a host, called out the director Lisa Cholodenko (“The Kids Are All Right”) for saving her from a lifetime of playing plucky friends and long-suffering girlfriends and mothers. “She cast me as a German lesbian heroin addict” in “High Art,” Ms. Clarkson said. Anne Hathaway, presenting an award to James Schamus, the chief executive of Focus Features, thanked him for changing her career path via “Brokeback Mountain.” “Don’t get me wrong, I loved playing princesses,” she added, before praising Mr. Schamus for running a studio with spine, although she used a different, rather unprincessy anatomical word. (Mr. Schamus, a professor as well as a film executive, used a dry erase board and a philosophical metaphor during his acceptance speech.)

headline: Wanderlust | Hamburg
text: In the last few years, the Karolinenviertel neighborhood has gone the way of many other former industrial enclaves — the meatpacking plant has morphed into galleries and cafes and the front windows of old tenement buildings now gleam with merchandise. But this being a microhood within the city’s scruffy St. Pauli district (home also to one of Europe’s legendary red-light districts), Karolinen’s new coffee bars and design studios are cheek by jowl with punk hangouts and anarchist graffiti. It may be gentrified but it’s not glossed over.

headline: Senate Defeats Earmark Ban
text: The Senate on Tuesday defeated a proposed ban on the lawmaker-directed spending items known as earmarks.

headline: When Redesigning the Taxi, Don’t Forget Roof Romance
text: Looking for a new single taxi design to replace the jumble of models now on the street, the Taxi and Limousine Commission‘s “Taxi of Tomorrow” competition is down to three finalists chosen from a larger group of contenders. One is based on a Nissan van, another on the Ford Transit Connect and the third one a model from Karsan, a Turkish company. Factors to be considered in the final decision, says the mayor’s office and the commission, are space, safety, energy efficiency and access.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Where the Wild Sugar Plums Are
text: SEATTLE — One artificial Christmas tree, in lights, beams from the top of the Space Needle here; a real one stands in the foyer of the nearby Marion Oliver McCaw Hall, where Pacific Northwest Ballet‘s “Nutcracker” is playing. There’s snow on the Cascade Mountains, and apparently the city ground to a halt last week with three inches of snow, now vanished. You don’t need to know much about “The Nutcracker” to know that these things are fitting.

headline: People You Don’t Want to Friend on Facebook
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously offered their definitions of family.

headline: On Our Radar: Senators Seek Extension of Clean Power Grants
text: A group of 26 senators have called for the extension of a renewable power grant program created by the 2009 stimulus law, which they describe as an effective job-creation tool. In a letter Monday to leaders of both parties, the 25 Democrats and one Republican requested a two-year extension of the program, which provides direct cash grants to renewable energy developers in lieu of tax credits, which have become difficult to use during the economic downturn. [The Hill]

headline: Updates on Leak of U.S. Cables, Day 3
text: On Tuesday, The Lede continued to update readers on the global conversation about more than 250,000 American diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowers’ Web site. (For updates on the conversation so far, see our two previous live-blog posts.)

headline: Tuesday Reading: A Federal Pay Freeze
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Do Zombies Eat Ivy? The Undead Reach Academia
text: There is a zombie survival guide and a zombie etiquette guide, a best-selling version of “Pride and Prejudice” with zombies (soon to be a major motion picture), a collection of “Zombie Haiku,” at least two zombie-themed television series and, in time for the holidays, a book of zombie Christmas carols.

headline: Investigation Finds FEMA Improperly Awarded Grant to Acorn Affiliate
text: The Federal Emergency Management Agency improperly awarded a $450,000 grant for fire safety and prevention to a New Orleans affiliate of Acorn, the embattled community organizing group, according to an investigation by the inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Senate Passes Sweeping Law on Food Safety
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate passed a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s food safety system on Tuesday, after tainted eggs, peanut butter and spinach sickened thousands of people in the last few years and led major food makers to join consumer advocates in demanding stronger government oversight.

headline: Hit No. 3,000: A Moment Finally Tailor-Made for Pinstripes
text: All of the contentiousness surrounding Derek Jeter’s contract negotiations with the Yankees has now inspired a card-collecting blog to depict him in the uniforms of the other 29 major league teams. Wonder no more how Jeter would look with a Braves tomahawk on his chest, or a Chief Wahoo adorning his cap, or in the red pinstripes of the Phillies.

headline: Talking Tough and Drawing Viewers, Christie Is a YouTube Star
text: A little shaky, the camera shows Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey shedding his sport coat at a town-hall-style meeting as a teacher criticizes what she sees as his attacks on her profession. He begins to respond, the woman tosses her head in frustration, and Mr. Christie goes for the jugular.

headline: CBS News Is Replacing Its ‘Early Show’ Anchor Lineup
text: 8:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: More Green Days at the Box Office? Billie Joe Armstrong Returning to ‘American Idiot’
text: 11:00 a.m. | Updated

headline: Ristretto | The Kone
text: Of all the shiny objects I saw at WTF Espresso Bar, a tricked-out coffee shop that opened last month in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the gadget that caught my eye was a filter cone made out of perforated stainless steel. It was sitting in a Chemex brewer, which looked significantly more awesome when equipped with a metal filter that could draw blood. It was a Kone, a reusable filter developed by Keith Gehrke of Coava, a small-batch coffee roaster in Portland, Ore.

headline: The East Just Got Bigger
text: Today we have decided to begin a nationwide effort to rename all of the college conferences in response to the latest geographical absurdity that is Texas Christian University joining the Big East. It is not the first absurdity, geographical or otherwise, in college powers’ continuing game of Risk, of course, and it won’t be the last. But it seems like a good time to give one last flush to the notion of tradition and make a statement for truth in advertising. The Big East, for example, could now be called the Saving Ourselves from B.C.S. Obscurity Because Notre Dame Won’t Love Us Conference, although we do admit that’s a bit unwieldy in a logo.

headline: Handicapping the Oscar Hosts’ Oscar Chances
text: With the news Monday that James Franco and Anne Hathaway would be hosting the Oscars, award savants immediately began speculating on whether it would help or hurt the actors’ own statuette chances. Mr. Franco is a likely nominee for his role as the wounded hiker Aron Ralston in “127 Hours,” a title which could also be milked for the “this awards show is sooo long” jokes (paging Bruce Vilanch!). Ms. Hathaway has a longer shot for playing a lusty Parkinson’s patient in “Love and Other Drugs,” an Edward Zwick dramedy which performed poorly at the box office in its opening weekend.

headline: Hey, Some Friars Members Are Younger Than the Jokes
text: For years, one of the funniest lines associated with the Friars Club, the legendary fraternal organization in New York that has catered to people in the entertainment industry for 106 years, was about itself.

headline: Cures for a Dawdling Child?
text: A morning routine is an intricate and delicate thing. One misstep and the whole structure comes crashing to the ground, an implosion of backpacks and lunch bags and permission slips and Mommy’s train schedule and Daddy’s keys.

headline: Off the Menu: Octavia’s Porch
text: Octavia Menu

headline: On Senate Floor, McCain Praises Feingold
text: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, did not spend a lot of time during his recent re-election campaign talking up the McCain-Feingold Act. The tough campaign finance legislation, which he sponsored in 2002 with a Democratic colleague, Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, is unpopular with many conservative Republicans, and they have heaped scorn on Mr. McCain for his role in it ever since.

headline: New Education Chief Visits Bronx School
text: In her first public appearance since receiving a waiver from the state, the schools chancellor designee, Cathleen P. Black, greeted a student at Public School 109 in the Bronx on Tuesday morning as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other officials looked on.

headline: The Spirit Awards and Oscar Tea Leaves
text: “Winter’s Bone,” “Black Swan,” “127 Hours” and “The Kids Are All Right” were the big names recognized by Film Independent’s Spirit Awards, which announced their nominees today. Each got nods for best feature, best director, and some acting categories. “Greenberg” rounded out the list of best features, while John Cameron Mitchell earned a best director spot for “Rabbit Hole,” a wrenching story of a couple – Aaron Eckhart and Nicole Kidman — trying to cope after the death of their child. Ms. Kidman and Mr. Eckhart were also nominated as featured actors.

headline: Vain Glorious | Creed’s Spice and Wood
text: What: Spice and Wood, the latest fragrance from Creed.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Clara in the Rockies
text: DENVER — The Colorado Ballet program has a “Did You Know?” checklist of five points about “The Nutcracker.” I was aware of only two. Well, I wish I’d known when I was in Washington State that the “Bavarian Village” of Leavenworth there has a Nutcracker Museum with a collection of thousands. It’s also good to learn that the ability of nutcrackers to crack nuts is based on the physics of Archimedes’ lever and “moments of force.” And I’m happy to discover that the nutcracker is also a bird related to the jay and the crow, known in America as Clark’s Nutcracker.

headline: Savoring a Few Lasts, Amid a Flurry of Firsts
text: As we coast into the midpoint of Nicole’s senior year in high school, it seems there’s been a new and frequent focus on her last, well, everything. Her last Halloween in our pumpkin-laden town; her last birthday here at home (she turned 17 two weeks ago); her last Thanksgiving meal before leaving for college.

headline: How to Improve Your Financial Willpower
text: Ramit Sethi runs the Web site I Will Teach You to Be Rich.

headline: Health Dept. Puts Up Holiday Anti-Drinking Decorations
text: Just in time for the Holiday Binge season (less than 29 hours till Hanukkah!), the city health department has given us the gift of a highly visual public information campaign, this one about the dangers of excessive drinking, which the department recently linked to fully one-tenth of all hospitalizations and 3 percent of emergency-room visits in the city, as well as about 1,500 deaths per year.

headline: First Seas, Now Trees, Added to Google’s Earth
text: Last year, Google filled in the big blue blank spot on its online replica of the Earth with three-dimensional oceans. Whether they’ll help inspire people to take care of the real oceans remains unclear, but it can’t hurt. Now the company, in the latest iteration of Google Earth, is filling in some of the vast green blotches with three-dimensional trees.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: The senate passes an overhaul of food safety regulations. – Samantha Storey

headline: Poll: Low Expectations for Tuesday’s White House Meeting
text: A recent poll suggests that the public has low expectations for the bipartisan meeting at the White House on Tuesday morning. A broad majority of voters want Congressional Republicans to compromise with President Obama and other Democrats in order to get things done, but few think that will actually happen.

headline: Europe Threatens Inquiry Into Phone and Cable Fees
text: BERLIN  The European Union’s telecommunications commissioner on Tuesday threatened to crack down on member countries that allow powerful former telephone monopolies to charge steep fees that raise costs to consumers.

headline: N.Y. Assembly Approves Fracking Moratorium
text: The New York State Assembly voted 93 to 43 Monday night to place a temporary moratorium on a controversial type of natural gas exploration that combines hydraulic fracturing with horizontal drilling. The goal is to give the state more time to address safety and environmental concerns.

headline: Insect Metaphor Leads to Bad Sex-Writing Prize
text: The good news for Rowan Somerville: his novel “The Shape of Her” has just picked up a literary award that puts him in the company of previous winners like Norman Mailer, Tom Wolfe and Sebastian Faulks while vaulting him ahead of fellow nominees like Jonathan Franzen. The not-so-good news: he has won the 2010 Bad Sex in Fiction Award, a (dis)honor bestowed annually by the British publication Literary Review.

headline: Heatley and James: Two Sports, Two Returning Villains
text: LeBron James and Dany Heatley have a lot in common. Both lead their teams to their first conference finals appearance last spring. Both shocked the sports world with the way they orchestrated their departures. And both are now hated by the former fans that they spurned.

headline: A Taxi Roof With a View
text: Looking for a new single taxi design to replace the jumble of models now on the street, the Taxi and Limousine Commission’s “Taxi of Tomorrow” competition is down to three finalists chosen from a larger group of contenders. Taxi buffs and historians, however, are also looking to past taxis as inspiration and asking for a touch of romance: a roof with a view.

headline: A Failure of Care in Mexico
text: Randal C. Archibold goes inside two failing mental health facilities in Mexico City.

headline: How Partisanship Works
text: After reading thoughtful critiques of my most recent column from  Jim Fallows and Daniel Larison, I think I should clarify exactly how I think the influence of partisanship on political opinions tends to manifest itself.

headline: Abuses Found at Mexican Institutions for Disabled
text: MEXICO CITY  Ten years ago, a human rights group released a scathing, groundbreaking report on abusive, decrepit conditions in Mexican institutions for the mentally and physically disabled, moving the country to promise change and to take the lead in writing international agreements to protect the disabled.

headline: A.I.G. Plans First Bond Sale Since Crisis
text: 6:41 p.m. | Updated A.I.G. will sell about $2 billion worth of bonds in its first debt offering since the financial crisis.

headline: 2 Sides Clash in Trial Over Goldman Trading Code
text: Is Sergey Aleynikov an evil computer scientist who brazenly stole valuable, closely guarded trading code from Goldman Sachs, his former employer?

headline: Nets’ Latest Sponsor Lights Up for Russia
text: It’s been years since fans have been able to smoke in N.B.A. arenas, but that hasn’t stopped the Nets from selling a sponsorship to Zippo, makers of America’s most iconic lighters.

headline: Merck Appoints a New Chief Executive
text: Kenneth C. Frazier, the president of Merck, is to become chief executive of the pharmaceutical giant at the beginning of next year, the company said Tuesday.

headline: State’s Secrets: Teaching About WikiLeaks
text: A huge trove of confidential diplomatic cables — some 250,000 individual cables, the daily traffic between the State Department and more than 270 American diplomatic outposts around the world — were obtained by an organization called WikiLeaks and made available to several news organizations, including The New York Times. The Times began publication of articles based on the cables online on Sunday.

headline: Citigroup’s Top Lobbyist Steps Down
text: 1:08 p.m. | Updated After seven tumultuous years as head of Citigroup’s government affairs group, Nicholas Calio is stepping down to become the chief lobbyist for the airline industry.

headline: Senator Murray to Head Democratic Campaign Committee
text: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the chamber’s No. 4 Democrat, will become chairwoman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee for the 2012 elections, taking on a steep challenge as her party seeks to defend more than twice as many seats as Republicans‬.‪

headline: TimesCast | November 30, 2010
text: Executive Editor Bill Keller discusses the reaction to the leaked diplomatic cables; a report on living conditions of Mexico's  mentally disabled; and encouraging physical fitness for infants.

headline: Q&A: The Galápagos for Christmas, With Children
text: I have two kids, 7 and 11, and we’re looking for a fun holiday over Christmas break, somewhere hot. I’m thinking of the Galápagos or Costa Rica or anywhere in South America, as we’ve never been. Think these can be combined? Do you know a good travel agent and good hotels?

headline: Shop, China, Shop
text: Ms. Li could never shop at Louis Vuitton. Shaking her head, the 50-year-old woman watched customers in one of Beijing’s fanciest malls glide past a velvet rope into the French fashion house’s three-level store, where top-end handbags sell for more than twice China’s per-capita annual income. Her problem, Li told me, wasn’t that she was too poor, but too chic. “Even common people have L.V. bags these days,” said Li, who owns a hotel in China’s northeast. Li chose what she considered a tasteful gift for the young man who accompanied her in the mall that afternoon: a $2,400 Prada bag. This was a mere trifle compared with the haul of Tian Mingqiao, a 38-year-old iron-ore importer I met later that day. Nodding toward his companion, who was laden with shopping bags, the plump businessman in a velvet blue blazer said that he had just dropped $8,000 on shoes and clothing. A special occasion? No, he said, “I just had some free time.”

headline: Global Puck: Silver (or Gold) Lining for Brodeur?
text: Devils goalie Martin Brodeur made his N.H.L. debut on March 26, 1992, a year known in political circles for Queen Elizabeth’s famous “annus horribilis” speech that Christmas, a speech that looks increasingly applicable to Brodeur’s 2010-11 season.

headline: Quirky Tram Runs Again, Delighting Its Riders
text: In moments real and imagined, the Roosevelt Island Tramway can seem like a fragile way to get around town. In 2006, it left passengers stranded hundreds of feet in the air above the East River for as long as 10 hours; in the movies, it has a tendency to be hijacked by supervillains.

headline: ‘Scottsboro Boys’ to Close on Dec. 12
text: “The Scottsboro Boys” has become the first new commercial musical of the Broadway season to fall at the box office. The producers said on Tuesday that “Scottsboro,” which set the infamous 1930s Alabama rape trials to music and presented them subversively in the form of a minstrel show, would close on Sunday, Dec. 12, after 29 previews and 49 regular performances.

headline: Week 13 in Fantasy Football: The Waiver Wire
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 13. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Earthquake Off Long Island. I Felt It. Did You?
text: At first I felt a slight bouncy sensation, the kind of thing you could easily dismiss. Then it came again, a bit stronger this time, with an audible rattling of my desk and chair, before it petered out. The whole thing lasted maybe five seconds.

headline: Toyota to Replace Coolant Pump in 390,000 Priuses in North America
text: Toyota announced Tuesday that it was replacing the coolant pumps on 650,000 Prius hybrids worldwide, The Associated Press reported. But the automaker has stopped short of calling the action a recall.

headline: Jets’ Holmes Becomes a Game Changer
text: Florham Park, N.J.

headline: States See a Rebound in Tax Receipts
text: In another sign that financial comparisons with 2009 will make almost anyone look good, state tax revenues in the third quarter were up 2.6 percent in inflation-adjusted terms compared with last year.

headline: Obama Has Always Been At War With Eastasia
text: The organization formerly known as Obama for America is asking supporters to write letters in support of a federal pay freeze.

headline: Keeping It Clean
text: Just a reminder — this is a Times blog, so obscenities — even mild ones that you use all the, um, fleeting time — will get your comment deleted.

headline: Another Collapse at Pompeii Renews Calls for Better Care
text: ROME — Less than a month after Pompeii’s so-called House of Gladiators collapsed into rubble, portions of a garden wall at the nearby House of the Moralist fell down on Tuesday, prompting new calls to better safeguard the city buried by an eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D.

headline: G.M. to Hire 1,000 to Engineer More Electric Cars
text: DETROIT — General Motors is adding 1,000 jobs in Michigan to develop more electric and hybrid vehicles similar to the Chevrolet Volt, which it officially introduced on Tuesday, the company said.

headline: California Versus Spain
text: One commenter asks why the arguments for an independent Spanish currency don’t apply equally to, say, California. See earlier post.

headline: Phantom Twin
text: I don’t like losing things. I keep a list of books I know I once had, and know I’ve read, that I have somehow misplaced; “The Magic Mountain,” Loren Eiseley’s “The Star Thrower,” “The Complete Claudine” by Colette are on it, along with at least 40 other titles. Even when I lose a pair of pants, a sense of vexation, a confusion arises in me that seems out of all proportion to the loss, and if the pants are suddenly presented to me apologetically at the dry cleaners I feel a strange giddiness, a tincture of the kind of joy displayed by reunited families in movies about Mormon heaven. It is strange that in this world in which everything is sooner or later lost, where losing is the only certainty, one gets attached to even the smallest things and wants to be able to say goodbye even to a pair of pants, rather than have it simply disappear. One wants to see a logic in disappearances, and to know when one is losing things. Even if, in the end, we get to keep nothing.

headline: White House Meeting Ends in Kind Words but No Deals
text: President Obama and Republican Congressional leaders emerged from a high-profile, post-election meeting on Tuesday with gracious words and pledges of cooperation but no concrete agreements on the fiscal and national security issues that divide them.

headline: Pass the Hairspray, Fight AIDS
text: Remember the old slogan for Clairol hair coloring, “Only her hairdresser knows for sure”? A campaign to help fight AIDS, which is to get under way on Tuesday, is based on the idea of hairdressers imparting to customers their knowledge of preventing the spread of H.I.V., which causes AIDS.

headline: Miami and the Price of Anarchy
text: When utilized to its full potential, the pick-and-roll is not only among the most fluid and glorious displays of coordinated movement that the game of basketball has to offer, but also among the most potent. When operated by skilled practitioners, the pick-and-roll is a simple sequence with seemingly unlimited potential, so much so that defenders versed in limiting the pick-and-roll’s options are worth their weight in gold in today’s N.B.A. The various offensive systems in the league may stem from vastly different philosophies, but the pick-and-roll is something of a universal — a commonality too obvious, accessible, and useful for any scheme to ignore.

headline: Isherwood’s Singular Second Wind
text: “I shall make a terrible old man, I fear,” the English-American novelist Christopher Isherwood confided to his diary during the summer of 1961. He was only 56, but his fading looks and fear of being alone terrified him.

headline: Pharmerging Markets
text: Emerging markets targeted by pharmaceutical companies.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from South Korea, Russia and Turkey.

headline: FIA Releases List of Teams, Drivers and Engines for 2011
text: The 2011 Formula One season is already taking shape. The International Automobile Federation, the sport’s governing body, released on Tuesday  the official list of teams, drivers and engines that have entered  next year’s championship.

headline: FIA Releases List of Teams, Drivers and Engines for 2011
text: The 2011 Formula One season is already taking shape. The International Automobile Federation, the sport’s governing body, released on Tuesday  the official list of teams, drivers and engines that have entered  next year’s championship.

headline: Pentagon Sees Little Risk in Allowing Gay Men and Women to Serve Openly
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon has concluded that allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the United States armed forces presents a low risk to the military’s effectiveness, even at a time of war, and that 70 percent of surveyed service members believe that the impact on their units would be positive, mixed or of no consequence at all.

headline: Trial Will Pause to Celebrate, at Site Decided by a Newborn
text: It’s a boy, so Judge Kimba M. Wood will not have to carry out an unusual directive she issued in response to an unusual pretrial document filed by a Manhattan defense lawyer.

headline: Afghan Killer of Six Americans Was Trusted Police Officer
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Fellow villagers claimed he was just a poor kid who had taken a police job to help his family get by. Superiors saw him as a reliable foot soldier in the Afghan Border Police who had inexplicably snapped. The Taliban claimed he was a sleeper agent they had planted to kill NATO soldiers.

headline: WikiLeaks’ Next Target: Bank of America?
text: 3:33 p.m. | Updated with Bank of America statement

headline: Top Lobbyist Leaves Business to Avoid Conflicts
text: ALBANY — The arrival of a new governor usually heralds boom times for those lobbyists lucky enough to enjoy ties to the new administration.

headline: Despite ABB Deal, Europe Is Cautious on Mergers

headline: Student Killed in Brooklyn Car Crash

headline: In Kazakhstan, Clinton Defends Openness, but Condemns Diplomatic Cable Leaks
text: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke about the virtues of an open society here on Tuesday, at the start of her first overseas trip since the release of thousands of confidential diplomatic cables containing blunt appraisals of foreign countries and leaders.

headline: Europe Examines Ways to Quell Its Debt Crisis
text: LONDON — Fears over the European financial crisis began to spread Tuesday from the weaker countries to healthier ones, including Italy and Belgium, and even much stronger Germany, spurring a stepped up search for a solution to the economic problems putting a strain on Europe’s decade-old monetary union.

text: Alaska’s Senate election may still be somewhat in dispute back home, but the result is written in stone in Washington – literally.

headline: Jimmy Carter Visits the White House
text: Former President Jimmy Carter returned to the White House on Tuesday for the first time since President Obama took office.

headline: Osteria Morini
text: MICHAEL WHITE cooks pasta and people go crazy. This has been the case since he was the chef at Fiamma Osteria on Spring Street in the early years of the century, and it remains the case at Osteria Morini, a casual new restaurant on Lafayette Street.

headline: Michael Douglas Enters the Awards Fray
text: When the Bagger attended the premiere of “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps” in the otherwise woefully unglittery months before awards season began, the star of the afterparty was the billionaire Warren Buffett, who has a cameo in the film and, it turns out, a quick wit. (Asked if his money ever slept, Mr. Buffett replied, “My money doesn’t even take cat naps.”)

text: Photographs from South Korea, Russia and Turkey.

headline: Baker’s Secret | Tell Tale Preserve Company
text: There is a bag of oak-bourbon caramels to my right, smoked-almond brittle to my left. I will try to ignore their siren calls and relay the account of their maker, William Werner, a pastry chef who was last seen at Quince and who, in September, re-emerged as the founding father of San Francisco’s Tell Tale Society, a kind of CSA for treats. This Society is an offshoot of a grander venture still, a “patisserie and delicatessen” that will open its doors at 33 Maiden Lane in February under the name Tell Tale Preserve Company.

headline: Speed Camera Lottery Wins VW Fun Theory Contest
text: To compel drivers to obey posted speed limits, traffic authorities generally wield but one stick: the law book. However, a San Francisco father of three says he believes that if motorists were given positive incentives to check their speed, they would not only do so, but would have fun doing it.

headline: A Solar Installation Spree as the Deadline for Federal Grants Approaches
text: Owners of commercial buildings are rushing in such numbers to meet an end-of-the-year deadline for a federal Treasury grant program for solar energy installations that inventories of some equipment have dried up, solar energy experts said.

headline: Draft’s Vagaries on Display at the Garden
text: Based on their pedigree, or draft position, we might have envisioned Terrence Williams to be a Nets starter by now and the Knicks’ Landry Fields to be an apprentice in the N.B.A. Development League. But scouting reports are not the most effective indicators, given their preoccupation with vertical leap and 3-point range.

text: Updated | Dec. 1, 2010

headline: Beauty Discrimination During a Job Search
text: How much do looks matter during a job search? A new study suggests that while handsome men do better while looking for work, good looks can end up hurting a woman’s chances of scoring a job interview.

headline: On Her First Day, Black Reads to First Graders
text: Cathleen P. Black spent part of her first morning on the job as schools chancellor-designee on Tuesday reading to a classroom of first graders from a wooden rocking chair, a purple stuffed dog cradled in her lap.

headline: F.C.C. Investigates Complaint Against Comcast
text: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday that the agency was looking into claims by Level 3 Communications that Comcast had unfairly erected a toll booth that “threatens the open Internet.”

headline: Public Opinion on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: The Pentagon on Tuesday released its long-awaited report on “don’t ask, don’t tell,” the policy that allows gay men and women to serve in the military as long as they keep their sexual orientation quiet. The report, the result of a nine-month study, said that repealing the law would present a low risk to military effectiveness. It also found that 70 percent of service members believe that the impact of repealing the law would be positive, mixed or of no consequence at all.

headline: Video of Students and Police Clashing in Italy
text: Updated | 7:57 p.m. As Reuters reports, Italian students took to the streets of several cities on Tuesday to protest government plans to cut spending on education.

headline: Google Energy Guru Will Head Policy Center at Stanford
text: Dan W. Reicher, a former assistant secretary of energy, has left Google, where he spent the last four years as director of climate change and energy initiatives. In that post he helped develop Google’s goal of seeking to make renewable energy less expensive than coal, abbreviated as RE<C.

headline: Through the Eyes of a Foster Mom
text: In the British newspaper The Guardian this weekend, an unnamed foster mother (in Britain, she is called a “carer”) wrote an account of a year of her life.

headline: A Seat With a View Returns
text: The Roosevelt Island tram glided back into action on Tuesday morning, after a $25 million, eight-month makeover that disrupted the commute for those who regularly travel back and forth from the East River enclave.

headline: Historical Bleg
text: If anyone can help me with this, please weigh in: There’s a fact or maybe factoid I haven’t been able to pin down. I’m pretty sure that someone — Jean Monnet? — once joked that there should be a statue of Stalin in front of the European Commission building at Berlaymont, since he’s the man who made it all possible.

headline: First Look | Duchess of Windsor Auction
text: It’s official: royal fever is in full swing. QVC and the supermarket chain Tesco are selling synthetic versions of Catherine Middleton’s engagement ring from Wednesday and Sotheby’s London is auctioning the jewels of the Duchess of Windsor on Tuesday. “It is still the highest valued private jewelry collection ever sold,” said David Bennett, Sotheby’s chairman of Europe and the Middle East for International Jewelry. The last sale of the Duchess of Windsor’s jewelry was held in Geneva nearly a quarter of a century ago in 1987. The treasures include a 1935 gold Cartier cigarette case with gems denoting the royals’ exotic destination spots and the 1957 emerald, ruby and diamond 20th anniversary brooch. Now is a chance to buy a piece of eternal style. Lucky ones may get a chance to pair it with an invite to next year’s eagerly anticipated nuptials.

text: 5:29 p.m. | Updated

text: A view of the day in sports, from snowy slopes to hardwood courts.

headline: Director of Jewish Museum to Step Down
text: Joan Rosenbaum, who has led the Jewish Museum since 1981, will step down as director at the end of June, the museum plans to announce on Wednesday.

headline: Cables Praise French Friend With ‘Mercurial’ Side
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy is an unusually solid French friend of America. He is also a “mercurial” man operating in “a zone of monarch-like impunity” surrounded by advisers often too fearful to give honest counsel, according to leaked cables from the United States Embassy in Paris.

headline: Blackwater Aimed to Hunt Pirates
text: WASHINGTON  Besieged by criminal inquiries and Congressional investigators, how could the world’s most controversial private security company drum up new business? By battling pirates on the high seas, of course.

headline: What We’re Reading: Marijuana Price Index
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Principal of School Where Girl Drowned Is Removed
text: A Manhattan school principal who kept his job after a student drowned on a field trip last summer was removed from his position on Tuesday after an investigation found he had used a school employee, with whom he later became romantically involved, as a nanny, and allowed her to live rent-free in his apartment, the authorities said.

headline: Broadway Cowboy of Australia
text: It seems like only a year or two ago that David Campbell, the shape-shifting Australian pop singer, was hailed as the next big thing when he became the youngest performer ever to open at the Rainbow and Stars cabaret, now defunct, in Rockefeller Center. But the year was actually 1997, and Mr. Campbell was a 24-year-old eager beaver of seemingly boundless confidence and ambition. Although American stardom eluded him, he went on to establish himself as a top-of-the-line musical theater performer in his homeland while continuing to pay visits to the United States.

headline: Swiping, Linking and Highlighting: A Few New Features
text: On a site as big as NYTimes.com, changes and updates occur on a daily basis. Here’s a look at some of the features we’ve added in the past six months.

headline: Biden Meets With Rep. Issa
text: It was a day for summit meetings at the White House.

headline: Tales Within Tales Create a Tale of Two ‘Nutcracker’ Productions
text: The original source of the “Nutcracker” story, E. T. A. Hoffmann’s novella “Nutcracker and Mouseking” (1816), is a good example of what’s called metafiction. It’s a story within a story within a story: some characters pass from one layer to another, while others don’t. We can see why the heroine, Marie, is perplexed that most of those she knows and loves can’t see or believe the things she experiences; we can also see why they don’t believe her.

headline: A Rallying Cry in Support of an Immigration Bill
text: Activists across the country rallied on Tuesday in a day of support for the Dream Act, the long-languishing bill that would open a path to legalization for young people and may finally come up for a vote in the next several days.

headline: Assembly Passes Ban on Fracking
text: The Assembly voted Monday night to place a temporary moratorium on hydraulic fracturing, also known as fracking or hydrofracking, the controversial type of natural gas exploration that has divided property owners upstate. The goal of the ban is to give the state more time to address safety and environmental concerns. The measure has already been approved by the State Senate and so awaits only the governor’s signature. Read about the fracking ban on the Green blog. »

headline: First Round of Voting Ousts Islamists From Egypt’s Parliament
text: CAIRO  As the results of Egypt’s parliamentary elections trickled in Tuesday, no one was surprised that the governing party of President Hosni Mubarak won a huge victory. Nor were they surprised that the candidates of the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt’s only sizable opposition, took a beating.

headline: Will Top Firings Change Barneys’ Cool?
text: No department store in the 1990s had the cool factor of Barneys New York. It had the edgiest designers (Martin Margiela, Helmut Lang, Comme des Garçons), the kookiest windows and a team of buyers and merchandisers that made the store something of a hip event. Even when the store filed for bankruptcy protection, in 1996, it kept its cool.

headline: At the Gotham Awards
text: Images and quotes from attendees of the Gotham Awards, the independent film celebration that kicks off awards season.

headline: The Gold Mines Behind Padlocks
text: Thousands of people are going to quit their jobs on Thursday morning because of a zippy new reality series called “Storage Wars,” which has its premiere on Wednesday night on A&E. Why go to work when you can be a full-time storage-locker buyer?

headline: Untested Musicals Take Over Broadway
text: The 2010-11 Broadway season is shaping up as a bounty of new musicals with ambitious original scores. But new songs, untested on Broadway, come with risk, both artistically and  especially this season  financially.

headline: Dodd, Retiring, Has Some Final Words
text: In a stirring rhetorical capstone to his 30-year career, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, lamented that “our political system at the federal level is completely dysfunctional” but urged younger lawmakers to overcome the “intense partisan polarization” and respect the traditions of the Senate, particularly the rights of the minority.

headline: Friendly Enemies on Fox: ‘Simpsons’ and O’Reilly
text: “The Simpsons” has certainly never been shy about biting the corporate hand that feeds it  witness the recent opening-credit sequence of that Fox animated comedy, created by the underground artist Banksy, that imagined 20th Century Fox as a nightmarish third-world sweatshop.

text: A roundup of links for your edification or distraction as the evening rolls in.

text: By 11 p.m. on Wednesday (10 p.m., Central), the people who catalog such things will have already ferreted out and posted the many homages to “Twin Peaks” in “Dual Spires,” the new episode of “Psych” on USA that will have just ended.

headline: Checking In on Those Lingering Midterm Races
text: Since our last update, closure (or something close to closure) has come to seven of the nine midterm contests that were unresolved.

headline: Catholics Fire Back in Christmas Billboard Battle
text: The latest salvo in the Christmas wars has landed, blocks from the New York entrance of the Lincoln Tunnel.

headline: The Gotham Awards in Pictures
text: Now that we’re in our sophomore year as Oscarologists, the Bagger agrees with the assessment that the Gotham Awards are the high school reunion of the season. The red carpet, held indoors Monday night, had all the bright lights, noise and shoving of a school hallway (which would make the publicists what? The hall monitors?). There were freshman – newly-anointed indie stars like Lena Dunham and Greta Gerwig; seen-it-all seniors, like the director Darren Aronofsky; impossibly cool kids (Anthony Mackie); and the wise-cracking elders (Fran Lebowitz). As promised, here’s our yearbook.

headline: Debt Panel to Delay Vote Until Friday
text: The chairmen of President Obama’s debt-reduction commission say they will release a final plan by Wednesday morning, technically meeting the president’s deadline, but they delayed the panel’s vote until Friday to give members time to consider the far-reaching tax and spending proposals.

headline: Farewell to Reefs, Salt Ponds and Milkfish
text: Stuart Sandin of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography traveled to the Line Islands in early November to examine the coral reefs of inhabited and uninhabited islands. Here are the final two entries from his expedition.

headline: Now Open | C.H.C.M.
text: It seems as if men can get their work wear from any mall that has a J. Crew these days, but it turns out that the best of that lot has been hiding in plain sight for a year and a half on the expertly curated, under-the-radar menswear Web shop C.H.C.M. The owner, Sweetu Patel, knows a little something about timeless design after putting in five years on the floor of Cappellini, the SoHo Italian design emporium; for C.H.C.M. — which stands for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear —  he has carved a niche with classic American and European brands as well as hard-to-find Japanese ones. Last week, he brought those labels even closer within reach when he opened a fashionably minimalist, brick-and-mortar shop in NoHo. The store shares its raw, slightly underground space with the fashion designer Tunji Dada and the curator-about-town Josee Lepage, who was setting up her creative consultancy within plain view of the merchandise on Friday, opening day. “I wanted a nice space, good music, nothing pretentious — like the stores I grew up around in Northampton, England, in the late ’80s and early ’90s,” says Patel.

headline: New Arrivals Strain India’s Cities to Breaking Point
text: NEW DELHI — Mahitosh Sarkar came here from his distant village in West Bengal 12 years ago looking for a better life, and he found it. He abandoned the penniless existence of a subsistence fisherman to become a big-city vegetable seller. His wife found work as a maid. Their four children went to school. Their tiny household, a grim but weather-tight room in a dilapidated tenement, had a color TV and a satellite dish.

headline: A Melting Pot of All Kinds of Rhythms, Harmonies and Vamps
text: Harris Eisenstadt, a drummer and composer originally from Toronto, takes a fixer’s approach to music making, looking for ways to fit the pieces together. He works along jazz’s progressive fringe but doesn’t generally set out to make a ruckus. In his own music especially, he often seems intent on extracting consonance from dissonance or forging ungainliness into grace.

headline: Farewell to a Great Web Effort at Worldchanging
text: When I dove into the blogosphere with Dot Earth in 2007 after a quarter century of conventional journalism, I was excited to find some “veterans” — if that word is remotely appropriate online — actively pursuing a vision of a humanized, but thriving, planet over at the Web site Worldchanging.com.

headline: Midwest Emerges as Center for Clean Energy
text: CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio  With surprising speed, and with the help of ample public incentives, a solar energy manufacturing center has emerged in the upper Midwest that is helping to supply the world’s growing demand for clean power.

headline: Producer Says ‘Spider-Man’ Has Strong Ticket Sales
text: The new Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” sold more than $1 million in tickets within 24 hours after the show’s first preview on Sunday night, the lead producer, Michael Cohl, said on Tuesday. The show’s maiden performances have drawn comment since the creators are still working on technical sequences; at the first preview the show had to stop five times to deal with glitches. That shaky performance came as some theater producers said that Foxwoods Theater, the landlord for “Spider-Man,” had inquired whether they had shows in the works that might be fits for the theater. Late on Monday the theater’s general manager, Erich Jungwirth, said in a statement that he had indeed talked to producers “to see if there are any shows coming up that may be able to play in our venue.” Such conversations are customary, Mr. Jungwirth said. The producers found the outreach unusual because it came when “Spider-Man” was already delaying its first preview by two weeks and involved a theater with a $65 million show that needs a multiyear run to turn a profit. A spokesman for the production, Rick Miramontez, also said late on Monday, “We are looking forward to ‘Spider-Man’ being at the Foxwoods Theater for years to come.”

headline: Missing ‘Dancing,’ ABC Loses Top Spot
text: Without “Dancing With the Stars” on its Monday schedule, ABC fell to second place in the night’s ratings as CBS and its all-repeat lineup took the lead. According to Nielsen estimates, just six million viewers watched ABC’s spinoff series “Skating With the Stars” from 8 to 9:30 p.m. Reruns of sitcoms including “Two and a Half Men” (11.2 million) and “How I Met Your Mother” (8.5 million) lifted CBS to No. 1 over all. NBC was third with new episodes of “Chuck” (6.2 million), “The Event” (5.8 million) and “Chase” (6 million); Fox was fourth.

headline: $60 Million Radio Deal for Seacrest
text: LOS ANGELES  Ryan Seacrest, pop culture curator?

headline: For Start-Ups, the Ultimate Goal: Becoming a Verb
text: When starting a new Web site or Internet service, most technologists are aiming to sell to a larger company or gain hundreds of millions of users. But for some there is an even bigger glory than cash: their company name becomes a verb.

headline: New Music on Broadway
text: A look at some of the new shows of the season.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach | Surreal Reveal
text: Despite the slew of peripheral events on Tuesday’s calendar (don’t forget to R.S.V.P. for tonight’s Gaetano Pesce for Melissa shoes launch), the day before the official vernissage for Art Basel Miami Beach is relatively calm. For the last few years, it’s also been the day for early out-of-towners (Jane Holzer, Adam Lindemann) and locals (Tiqui Atencio, Ella Cisneros) to attend a preview hosted by Sotheby’s at Miami’s Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden. This year’s show, “Les Lalanne at Fairchild,” is the largest outdoor exhibition of works by the French sculptors Claude and François-Xavier Lalanne. The display includes over 20 sculptures dotted throughout the 83-acre sylvan paradise, including the couple’s well-known flock of epoxystone and bronze sheep and lambs. Claude’s favorite, however, is “Dimetrodon II” (1998), a copper and steel topiary dinosaur, which spouts water through its teeth. “How can you not love it?” asked Claude, whose husband died in 2008. “It’s a prehistoric monster who somehow finds himself in a big modern grotto.”“Les Lalanne at Fairchild” runs through April 1, 2011.

headline: Goldman’s $20 Million Consequence
text: Goldman Sachs made its bed. Now Judge Jed S. Rakoff says the Wall Street firm has got to lie in it.

headline: Colleges Are Producing New Style of AIDS Activist
text: NEW HAVEN  David Carel was never a rabble-rouser. But amid the clutter of his dorm room at Yale University, Mr. Carel, baby-faced and slight-shouldered at 19, keeps evidence of his new life as an AIDS activist: posters, banners and the flier demanding “$50 bn for Global AIDS” that he concealed in his fleece jacket one Saturday in late October when, heart pounding, he sneaked past security into a Democratic campaign rally in Bridgeport.

headline: When a Trusted Brand Disappears
text: MY mother discovered Camay soap 64 years ago, when she immigrated to New York from London at the end of World War II after marrying my father, an American soldier. She has seen much change in her 86 years, but her devotion to Camay has remained constant.

headline: Design Miami | Loitering Within Tents
text: Visitors to Design Miami, the city’s annual design fair, can finally save on town cars and taxis. In a long overdue move Craig Robins, Design Miami’s co-founder, has erected the fair’s tent (designed by Moorhead & Moorhead) in the parking lot across the street from the Miami Convention Center, where the concurrent Art Basel Miami Beach fair is held, saving collectors and admirers of contemporary furniture from having to trek across town to get to Miami’s far-flung design district.

headline: End Ethanol Subsidies, Senators Say
text: Subsidies and tariffs to promote domestic ethanol production are “fiscally irresponsible and environmentally unwise” and should be ended, a bipartisan group of United States senators declared in a letter to the chamber’s leaders on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Angels in America’ To Play Five More Weeks, With New Cast Members
text: Michael Urie (ABC’s “Ugly Betty”) and Adam Driver (“Mrs. Warren’s Profession”) will take over the central roles of Prior Walter and his unfaithful lover Louis Ironson in the current Off Broadway revival of “Angels in America” on Feb. 2, 2011, and play for a new five-week extension of the production through March 27, Signature Theater Company announced on Tuesday.

headline: For Every Holiday Party, the Right Drink
text: Cocktails that will match the food, match the company, match the feeling in the air.
